Pesachim



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>On the evening [<i>or</i>] of the fourteenth</b> of the month of Nisan, <b>one searches for leavened bread</b> in his home <b>by candlelight. Any place into which one does not</b> typically <b>take leavened bread does not require a search,</b> as it is unlikely that there is any leavened bread there. <b>And with regard to what</b> the Sages of previous generations meant when they <b>said</b> that one must search <b>two rows</b> of wine barrels <b>in a cellar,</b> i.e., <b>a place into which one</b> typically <b>takes</b> some <b>leavened bread,</b> the early <i>tanna’im</i> are in dispute. <b>Beit Shammai say</b> that this is referring to searching the first <b>two rows across the entire cellar, and Beit Hillel say:</b> There is no need to search that extensively, as it is sufficient to search <b>the two external rows, which are the upper ones.</b> This dispute will be explained and illustrated in the Gemara.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the term <b><i>or</i>,</b> translated as: The evening of? The Gemara provides two answers. <b>Rav Huna said:</b> It means <b>light, and Rav Yehuda said:</b> In this context, it means <b>evening.</b> At first glance, <b>it</b> could <b>enter your mind</b> to suggest that <b>the one who said light</b> means that one searches for leaven by the <b>actual light</b> of day, on the morning of the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>and the one who said evening</b> is referring to the <b>actual evening</b> of the fourteenth.
To clarify the meaning of the word <i>or</i>, the Gemara analyzes biblical verses and rabbinic statements. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a verse: <b>“As soon as the morning was <i>or</i>, the men were sent away,</b> they and their donkeys” (Genesis 44:3). <b>Apparently, <i>or</i> is day.</b> The Gemara rejects this contention. <b>Is it written: The light was morning? “The morning was light” is written.</b> In this context, <i>or</i> is a verb not a noun, <b>as the one who said:</b> The <b>morning lightened. And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: A person</b> should <b>always enter</b> an unfamiliar city <b>with “it is good”</b> (Genesis 1:4), i.e., before sunset, while it is light, as the Torah uses the expression “it is good” with regard to light upon its creation. This goodness is manifest in the sense of security one feels when it is light. <b>And</b> likewise, when one leaves a city <b>he</b> should <b>leave with “it is good,”</b> meaning after sunrise the next morning.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from another verse: <b>“And as the light [<i>or</i>] of the morning, when the sun rises,</b> a morning without clouds; when through clear shining after rain the tender grass springs out of the earth” (II Samuel 23:4). <b>Apparently, <i>or</i> is day.</b> The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <b>Is it written</b> that <b>the light was morning? “As the light of the morning” is written, and this is</b> what the verse <b>is saying: And as</b> brightly as <b>the morning light of this world</b> shines at its peak, <b>so will be the rising of the sun for the righteous in the World-to-Come,</b> as in those days the light of the sun will be seven times stronger than at present (see Isaiah 30:26).
The Gemara <b>raises an objection: “And God called the <i>or</i> Day,</b> and the darkness He called Night” (Genesis 1:5). <b>Apparently, <i>or</i> is day.</b> The Gemara rejects this proof as well. <b>This is</b> what the verse <b>is saying:</b> God <b>called the advancing light Day.</b> As stated previously, the word <i>or</i> can also be a verb; in this context, God called the beginning of that which eventually brightens, Day. The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>However, if</b> that <b>is so,</b> the continuation of the verse, <b>“and the darkness He called Night,”</b> should be understood to mean: <b>He called the advancing darkness Night,</b> even before it is actually dark. However, this cannot be the correct interpretation of the verse, <b>as we maintain it is day until the emergence of the stars.</b> Since the stars emerge only after the sky begins to darken, the advancing evening cannot be defined as part of the night.
The Gemara rejects the previous explanation. <b>Rather, this is what</b> the verse <b>is saying: God called the light</b> to come <b>and commanded it</b> to perform <b>the mitzva of the day, and God called the darkness and commanded it</b> to perform <b>the mitzva of the night.</b> Called, in this context, does not connote the giving of a name. It means that He instructed the day and night to carry out their characteristic functions.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> “Praise Him, sun and moon; <b>praise Him, all the stars of <i>or</i>”</b> (Psalms 148:3). <b>Apparently, <i>or</i> is</b> the <b>evening,</b> as the stars of light appear at night. The Gemara rejects this contention. <b>This is</b> what the verse <b>is saying: Praise Him, all the stars that radiate,</b> as in this context <i>or</i> is not a noun but rather a verb that describes the activity of the stars. The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>However, if</b> that <b>is so,</b> does the verse mean that <b>it is</b> the <b>stars that radiate that are required to praise</b> God, whereas those <b>that do not radiate</b> light <b>are not required to praise</b> Him? <b>But isn’t it written</b> in the previous verse: <b>“Praise Him, all His legions,”</b> indicating that all stars should praise God?
<b>Rather, this</b> phrase, the stars of light, comes to <b>teach us that the light of stars is also</b> considered <b>light.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <b>practical difference</b> that emerges from the fact that the light of the stars is classified as light? The Gemara answers: It is significant with regard <b>to one who vows</b> that he will derive no benefit <b>from light.</b> It is necessary to define precisely what is included in the term light. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: For <b>one who vows</b> that he will derive no benefit <b>from light, it is prohibited to</b> benefit even from <b>the light of</b> the <b>stars.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection: “A murderer rises with the <i>or</i> to kill the poor and needy; and in the night he is as a thief”</b> (Job 24:14).

Daf 2b

<b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the end of the verse <b>states: “And in the night he is as a thief,” apparently</b> the word <b><i>or</i></b> at the beginning of the verse <b>is</b> a reference to <b>day,</b> as the verse contrasts between night and <i>or</i>. The Gemara rejects this contention. <b>There, this is</b> what the verse <b>is saying: If</b> the <b>matter is as clear to you as light, that</b> the thief has <b>come</b> into the house prepared to take <b>a life,</b> he <b>is a murderer; and</b> the owner of the house <b>may save himself by</b> taking the <b>life</b> of the intruder. In that case, one may protect himself from a thief who breaks into his house, even by killing the intruder if necessary. <b>And if the matter is as unclear to you as the night, he should be</b> nothing more <b>than a thief in your eyes</b> and not a murderer; and therefore <b>one may not save himself by</b> taking the <b>life</b> of the thief. This verse is not referring to actual day and night; rather, it uses these terms as metaphors for certainty and uncertainty.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion that <i>or</i> means evening: <b>“Let the stars of the twilight be dark; let it look for <i>or</i> but have none; neither let it see the eyelids of the morning”</b> (Job 3:9). <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the verse <b>states: “Let it look for <i>or</i> but have none,” apparently <i>or</i> is day.</b> The Gemara rejects this contention. Actually, it is possible that <i>or</i>, in this context, means light in general, not specifically day. <b>There, Job is cursing his fortune. He said: Let it be</b> His <b>will that this man,</b> referring to himself, <b>will seek light and not find it.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection: “And I say, yet the darkness shall envelop me, and the <i>or</i> about me shall be night”</b> (Psalms 139:11). <b>Apparently, <i>or</i> is day.</b> The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>This is</b> what <b>David is saying there: I said</b> after I sinned that <b>darkness shall envelop me in the World-to-Come, which is like day. Now</b> that I know that I have been forgiven, even <b>this world, which is like darkness,</b> is <b>light for me.</b> That being the case, it cannot be derived from here that the word <i>or</i> describes the day.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a mishna. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One searches</b> on <b><i>or</i> of the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, <b>on the fourteenth</b> in the <b>morning, and at the time of</b> the <b>removal</b> of leavened bread. The Gemara infers from Rabbi Yehuda’s teaching: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>one searches</b> on <b><i>or</i> of the fourteenth and on the fourteenth</b> in the <b>morning, apparently <i>or</i> is</b> the <b>evening.</b> In the order of Rabbi Yehuda’s list, <i>or</i> of the fourteenth precedes the morning of the fourteenth. Therefore, <i>or</i> must be referring to the evening. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that this is the case.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a different source: <b>From when</b> on <b>the fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>is</b> it <b>prohibited to perform labor,</b> for those who are accustomed not to work on Passover eve? <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: From the time of <i>or</i>. Rabbi Yehuda says: From sunrise.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov said to Rabbi Yehuda: And where have we found</b> precedent for <b>a day,</b> in <b>part of which the performance of labor</b> is <b>prohibited, and</b> in another <b>part of which the performance of labor</b> is <b>permitted?</b> If, as you claim, the prohibition against performing labor takes effect only from sunrise, whereas the fourteenth of Nisan begins with the emergence of stars the previous evening, it is permitted to perform labor during the first part of the fourteenth, while during the second part of the same day labor is prohibited. <b>He said to him:</b> The fourteenth day <b>itself</b> can <b>prove</b> to be a precedent, <b>as</b> in <b>part of it,</b> from the beginning until the sixth hour of the day, <b>the eating of leavened bread</b> is <b>permitted, and</b> during another <b>part of it the eating of leavened bread</b> is <b>prohibited.</b>
With regard to the matter under discussion, the Gemara infers: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that it is prohibited to perform labor <b>from sunrise, apparently</b> the word <b><i>or</i> that Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov is saying, is</b> referring to the <b>evening.</b> This is an additional proof that <i>or</i> means night. The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>No,</b> this is not a proof. <b>What is</b> meant by <b><i>or</i>?</b> It means <b>dawn.</b> The dispute of the <i>tanna’im</i> is not whether the prohibition of labor begins at night or in the morning. Rather, they disagree as to whether labor is prohibited from dawn or only from sunrise.
The Gemara challenges this assumption: <b>If so,</b> consider that <b>which</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: <b>Where have we found</b> precedent for <b>a day,</b> in <b>part of which the performance of labor</b> is <b>prohibited, and</b> in another <b>part of which the performance of labor</b> is <b>permitted? Let him say to himself: Isn’t there</b> the <b>night,</b> during <b>which</b> even <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov</b> himself <b>permits</b> performance of labor at night? He certainly would not raise a difficulty against the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, which is equally difficult according to his own opinion.
The Gemara rejects this contention. <b>This is</b> what Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov <b>is saying: Granted,</b> according <b>to my</b> opinion, <b>I find</b> situations in <b>which the Sages distinguished between</b> the <b>day and</b> the preceding <b>night, as we learned</b> in a mishna <b>with regard to</b> a lenient <b>communal fast: Until when</b> may <b>one eat and drink</b> before the fast? It is permitted to eat and drink <b>until dawn;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> One may eat <b>until the call of the rooster,</b> which precedes dawn. In that case, the Sages distinguished between day and night. <b>However, according to your</b> opinion, <b>where do we find</b> a <i>halakha</i> with regard to which <b>the Sages divided the day itself?</b>
Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov: The day of the fourteenth <b>itself can prove</b> my opinion, <b>as</b> during <b>part of it, the eating of leavened bread</b> is <b>permitted, and</b> during <b>part of it the eating of leavened bread</b> is <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Rabbi Yehuda has spoken well to Rabbi Eliezer;</b> how can Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov counter this contention? The Gemara answers that <b>this is</b> what <b>Rabbi Eliezer is saying to him</b> in response: <b>I said to you</b> the prohibition of <b>labor,</b> which is <b>by rabbinic law, and you said to me</b> the prohibition of <b>leavened bread, which is by Torah law.</b> With regard to a Torah prohibition, it is possible <b>that until this</b> point, <b>God prohibited</b> doing so, <b>and until that</b> point, <b>God permitted</b> doing so, as the <i>halakha</i> is determined by a Torah decree. On the other hand, rabbinic prohibitions are enacted within clearly defined categories; in this case, an entire day.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is the response of <b>the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Yehuda, to this contention? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda notes that the <b>hours</b> when the prohibition of leaven is in effect on the morning of the fourteenth are determined <b>by rabbinic law.</b> Despite the fact it is prohibited by Torah law to eat leaven from midday, the distinction within the morning hours between the time when one may consume leaven and the time when one may derive benefit from leaven but not consume it is determined by the Sages. Apparently, the Sages institute ordinances that apply to part of a day.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how can <b>the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, respond to this claim? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov would say that in this case <b>the Sages established a preventive measure for a Torah law,</b> and decrees of this type are at times in effect for only part of the day. By contrast, when the Sages instituted independent ordinances, they invariably did so for the entire day. In any case, this source does not conclusively prove that <i>or</i> means evening.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> The court messengers <b>kindle torches</b> on the mountaintops as a signal that the court has sanctified and established a new month <b>only for a month that appeared at its</b> proper <b>time,</b> on the thirtieth day of the previous month, <b>to sanctify it</b> on that day. <b>And when do</b> the messengers <b>kindle</b> these <b>torches?</b> They light them on <b><i>or</i> of its additional</b> day, at the end of the thirtieth day from the beginning of the previous month, leading into the evening of the thirty-first day. The thirtieth day is called the additional day because it is sometimes appended to the previous month, which would otherwise consist of twenty-nine days. <b>Apparently, <i>or</i> is</b> the <b>evening,</b> as the court messengers would certainly not light the bonfires by day. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that this is the case.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> If a priest <b>was standing all night and sacrificing</b> the limbs of offerings <b>on the altar, in the <i>ora</i></b> he is <b>required</b> to <b>sanctify his hands and feet</b> again, by washing them in water from the basin; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. Since a new day has begun, the priest must wash his hands and feet from the basin, a prerequisite for each day’s service. With regard to the issue under discussion, apparently <i>or</i> means day. The Gemara rejects this contention: This is not a conclusive proof, as <b><i>ora</i> is different,</b> and indeed it is referring to the day. However, the word <i>or</i> may yet refer to the evening.
<b>Mar Zutra raises an objection</b>

Daf 3a

from a mishna that deals with the offering of <b>a woman who miscarries</b> on <b><i>or</i> of the eighty-first</b> day after her previous childbirth: The Torah obligates a woman to bring an offering after childbirth, including a miscarriage. However, one offering suffices for any births or miscarriages that occur within eighty days of the original birth, as the halakhic ramifications of that birth last eighty days (see Leviticus 12:1–6). The mishna cited addresses the borderline case of a woman who miscarries on the night of the eighty-first day following the birth. <b>Beit Shammai exempt</b> her <b>from</b> bringing another <b>offering,</b> as the offering she brought for the previous childbirth exempts her from bringing another for the miscarriage. <b>And Beit Hillel obligate</b> her to bring a second offering.
<b>Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: What is different</b> between <b><i>or</i> of the eighty-first and the day of the eighty-first? If they are equal</b> with regard <b>to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>ritual impurity,</b> i.e., the blood of this woman is no longer ritually pure and all of the standard strictures of ritual impurity apply to her, <b>will</b> the two time periods <b>not be equal</b> with regard <b>to the offering</b> as well? In terms of the meaning of <i>or</i>, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: What is different</b> between <b><i>or</i> of the eighty-first and the day of the eighty-first, learn from it that <i>or</i> is night.</b> Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that <i>or</i> means night.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> with regard to the meaning of the word <i>or</i> from a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that a peace-offering, which may be eaten for two days, <b>may</b> also <b>be eaten</b> on <b><i>or</i> of the third</b> day. <b>And</b> it is <b>a logical derivation</b> that leads to that conclusion. How so? Other <b>offerings,</b> e.g., sin-offerings, <b>are eaten for one day, and peace-offerings are eaten for two days. Just as there,</b> with regard to other offerings, the <b>night follows the</b> previous <b>day,</b> i.e., the offering may be eaten during the day and the subsequent night, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to peace-offerings, say that the <b>night follows the day,</b> and rule that they may be eaten on the night after the second day.
Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And when you sacrifice a peace-offering to God, you shall sacrifice it of your own will. <b>It shall be eaten the same day you sacrifice it, and on the next day; and if any remains until the</b> third <b>day,</b> it shall be burnt with fire” (Leviticus 19:5–6). This verse means that <b>it</b> may <b>be eaten while it is still day,</b> i.e., during the second day, <b>and it</b> may <b>not be eaten</b> on <b><i>or</i> of the third</b> day.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If a peace-offering may not be eaten beyond the second day, one <b>might</b> have thought that it should <b>be burned immediately</b> after the conclusion of the second day, <b>and this</b> too is the conclusion of <b>a logical derivation:</b> Other <b>offerings are eaten for one day and night, and peace-offerings are eaten for two days and one night. Just as there,</b> the offerings are <b>burned immediately</b> after their permitted time <b>for eating</b> concludes, on the morning of the second day, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to peace-offerings, one could say that they must be <b>burned immediately after</b> their permitted time for <b>eating</b> concludes, at night after the second day.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And if any remains of the flesh of the sacrifice on the third day, it shall be burnt with fire”</b> (Leviticus 7:17), meaning: <b>You</b> must <b>burn it during the day, and you do not burn it at night.</b> With regard to the meaning of <i>or</i>, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>states:</b> One might have thought that <b>it may be eaten</b> on <b><i>or</i> of the third</b> day, <b>apparently <i>or</i> is evening.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that <i>or</i> is evening.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof: On <b><i>or</i> of Yom Kippur, one recites seven</b> blessings in the <i>Amida</i> prayer <b>and confesses</b> his sins; in <b>the morning prayer, one recites seven</b> blessings <b>and confesses; in the additional prayer, one recites seven</b> blessings <b>and confesses; in the afternoon prayer, one recites seven</b> blessings <b>and confesses; in the evening</b> prayer, <b>one recites</b> an <b>abridged</b> version of the standard <i>Amida</i> prayer of <b>eighteen</b> blessings, as the people are weary from fasting. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel says in the name of his forefathers: One recites the eighteen complete</b> blessings, <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>he is required to recite <i>havdala</i> in</b> the fourth blessing of the <i>Amida</i>: Who graciously grants knowledge. It cannot be inserted in the abridged version. <b>Apparently, <i>or</i> is evening.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that <i>or</i> means evening.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof, <b>as it was taught</b> in <b>the school of Shmuel: On the evening of the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, <b>one searches for leavened bread by candlelight. Apparently, <i>or</i> is evening,</b> as this <i>baraita</i> replaces <i>or</i> with the word evening.
It is clear from these proofs that the expression <i>or</i> in the mishna means the evening before the day. How, then, could the <i>amora’im</i> dispute whether it is referring to the morning or evening? <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects its previous assumption with regard to the dispute, <b>as everyone, both Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda, agrees</b> that <b><i>or</i> is evening, and they do not disagree</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i>. However, this <b>Master</b> stated the <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the expression accepted in <b>his place, and</b> that <b>Master</b> stated the <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the expression accepted in <b>his place. In Rav Huna’s place, they call</b> the evening <b>light, and in Rav Yehuda’s place they call it night,</b> although both terms refer to the same period.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the <i>tanna</i></b> of <b>our</b> mishna, <b>what is the reason</b> that he <b>didn’t</b> explicitly <b>teach: The night</b> of the fourteenth, as it was taught in the school of Shmuel? The Gemara answers: <b>He employed a euphemism.</b> Since the <i>tanna</i> of our mishna did not want to mention darkness, he preferred the term <i>or</i> to refer to the night of the fourteenth. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> a statement of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi. As Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: A person should never express a crude matter, as the</b> formulation of <b>a verse</b> was <b>distorted</b> by the addition of <b>eight letters rather than</b> have it <b>express a crude matter, as it is stated: “From the pure animals and from the animals that are not pure [<i>asher einena tehora</i>]”</b> (Genesis 7:8). To avoid using the Hebrew term for impure [<i>teme’a</i>], which is four letters: <i>Tet</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>alef</i>, <i>heh</i>, the verse replaced the term with the euphemism meaning “that are not pure,” which is spelled with twelve letters: <i>Alef</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>reish</i>; <i>alef</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>nun</i>, <i>nun</i>, <i>heh</i>; <i>tet</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>reish</i>, <i>heh</i>.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> A different verse added <b>nine</b> letters, <b>as it is stated: “If there be among you any man who is not ritually pure [<i>asher lo yihye tahor</i>] by reason of that which happened to him by night”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:11). To avoid using the three-letter Hebrew word for impure, <i>tameh</i>, spelled <i>tet</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>alef</i>, the verse employs the twelve-letter phrase “who is not ritually pure,” spelled: <i>Alef</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>reish</i>; <i>lamed</i>, <i>alef</i>; <i>yod</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>heh</i>; <i>tet</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>reish</i>. <b>Ravina said:</b> The verse actually adds <b>ten</b> letters because of the letter <b><i>vav</i> of</b> the word <b><i>tahor</i>,</b> as the word is spelled in its plene form. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> Yet another verse adds <b>sixteen</b> letters, <b>as it is stated: “For he said, something has happened to him, he is not ritually pure; surely he is not ritually pure [<i>bilti tahor hu ki lo tahor</i>]”</b> (I Samuel 20:26). To avoid using the three-letter word <i>tameh</i>, the verse employs the nineteen-letter phrase “he is not ritually pure; surely he is not ritually pure,” spelled: <i>Beit</i>, <i>lamed</i>, <i>tav</i>, <i>yod</i>; <i>tet</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>vav</i>, <i>reish</i>; <i>heh</i>, <i>vav</i>, <i>alef</i>; <i>kaf</i>, <i>yod</i>; <i>lamed</i>, <i>alef</i>; <i>tet</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>vav</i>, <i>reish</i>.
Likewise, a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught</b> in <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael: A person should always converse euphemistically, as</b> one finds in the following verses. The first: “And whichever saddle that the <i>zav</i> rides upon shall be ritually impure” (Leviticus 15:9), which discusses the impurity imparted by <b>a <i>zav</i></b> to an object on which he sits, <b>calls</b> this action <b>riding. And</b> the verse: “And anyone who touches anything on which she sat” (Leviticus 15:22), which discusses the parallel ritual impurity <b>of a woman,</b> a <i>zava</i>, <b>calls</b> the action <b>sitting.</b> Since riding is slightly demeaning for a woman, as it involves an immodest splaying of the legs, the verse avoids the term riding and opts to convey the more modest image of sitting. <b>And it says</b> in another verse: <b>“And you choose the language of the crafty”</b> (Job 15:5), meaning that one should be clever when speaking and avoid inappropriate phrases. <b>And it says</b> in another verse: “My words shall utter the uprightness of my heart; <b>and that which my lips know they shall speak sincerely”</b> (Job 33:3).
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the need for the proofs from the two additional verses introduced by the phrase: <b>And it says?</b> The <i>baraita</i> already proved its point from the verses with regard to <i>zav</i> and <i>zava</i>. The Gemara answers: The additional verses are necessary, <b>lest you say: This</b> requirement to use clean language <b>applies only in</b> the language written in <b>the Torah, but in rabbinic</b> formulations, <b>no,</b> there is no obligation to use clean language. To counter this argument, the <i>tanna</i> says, <b>come</b> and <b>hear: And it says: “And you choose the language of the crafty,”</b> which indicates that this principle extends beyond the language of the Torah. <b>And lest you say that this</b> requirement <b>applies only to rabbinic</b> language, <b>but</b> when it comes <b>to ordinary speech, no,</b> one need not speak euphemistically, the <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And it says: “And that which my lips know they shall speak sincerely,”</b> i.e., one must speak euphemistically in every situation.
With regard to the above <i>baraita</i> taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael, the Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to a woman, is</b> the term <b>riding not written</b> in the Torah? <b>But isn’t it written: “And Rebecca and her damsels arose and they rode upon camels”</b> (Genesis 24:61)? The Gemara answers: <b>There, due to fear of camels, that is standard conduct.</b> Since a camel’s back is high off the ground, a woman cannot sit on it sidesaddle; consequently, she may ride on it without being considered immodest. The Gemara cites another relevant verse. <b>But isn’t it written: “And Moses took his wife and his children and rode them upon his donkey”</b> (Exodus 4:20)? The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> despite the fact that his wife was also on the donkey, the verse employs the language of riding

Daf 3b

<b>due to his children,</b> as <b>it is standard practice</b> for children to ride.
The Gemara raises another difficulty. <b>But isn’t it written</b> with regard to Abigail: “And it was so, <b>as she rode on her donkey</b> and came down by the covert of the mountain” (I Samuel 25:20). This verse employs the language of riding in reference to a woman on a donkey. The Gemara answers: <b>There, due to the fear of the night, it is standard practice</b> for a woman to ride and not merely sit on the donkey. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>There is no</b> consideration <b>due to the fear of the night</b> that would explain why she was permitted to ride in the regular manner; rather, <b>there is</b> a consideration <b>due to fear of David. And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>There is no</b> consideration <b>due to fear of David either;</b> however, <b>there is</b> a consideration <b>due to the fear of</b> the incline when riding down <b>the mountain.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> the word <b>impure written in the Torah?</b> Apparently, the Torah does not consistently employ euphemisms, and indeed the word impure appears regularly. <b>Rather, anywhere that</b> two phrases <b>are equal</b> in length, the verse <b>speaks</b> employing <b>a euphemism. Anywhere that the words</b> of the euphemism <b>are</b> more <b>numerous,</b> requiring a lengthier description, the Torah <b>speaks</b> employing <b>concise language, in accordance with</b> that <b>which Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said, and some say it</b> was <b>Rav Huna</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>Rav said in the name of Rabbi Meir: A person should always teach his student in a concise manner.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And anywhere that</b> the phrases <b>are equal in</b> length, does the verse always <b>speak</b> employing <b>dignified language? Aren’t</b> the Hebrew words for <b>rides [<i>rokhevet</i>],</b> spelled: <i>Reish</i>, <i>vav</i>, <i>kaf</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>tav</i>; <b>and sits [<i>yoshevet</i>],</b> spelled: <i>Yod</i>, <i>vav</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>tav</i>, <b>of equal</b> length, and yet the verse <b>states: Rides</b> (I Samuel 25:20). The Gemara answers: The Hebrew word for <b>rides is written</b> without a <i>vav</i> in the defective form, rendering it shorter than the term for sits. Brevity takes precedence over dignified language.
The Gemara relates an incident involving the use of appropriate language: There were <b>these two students who were sitting before Rav</b> and were weary from studying a complex issue. <b>One</b> of them <b>said: This <i>halakha</i></b> we are studying <b>is rendering us</b> as tired <b>as a tired [<i>mesankan</i>] something else,</b> a euphemism for a pig. <b>And</b> the other <b>one said: This <i>halakha</i> is rendering us</b> as tired <b>as a tired kid. Rav</b> would <b>not speak with that</b> student who made reference to a pig, as one who speaks inappropriately is undoubtedly flawed in character.
The Gemara additionally relates that there were <b>these two students who were sitting before Hillel, and one of them</b> was <b>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai. And some say</b> they were sitting <b>before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and one of them was</b> the <i>amora</i> <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan. One</b> of them <b>said: Due to what</b> reason need <b>one</b> be careful to <b>harvest grapes in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity,</b> by insisting on the use of pure vessels, <b>and one need not harvest olives in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity? And</b> the other <b>one said</b> the same point, only he worded it differently: <b>Due to what</b> reason need <b>one harvest grapes in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity, but one</b> may <b>harvest olives in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity?</b> Their teacher <b>said: I am certain that this</b> first student, who spoke in a clean manner, will <b>issue</b> halakhic <b>rulings in Israel.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> it was <b>not</b> even <b>a few days later that he issued</b> halakhic <b>rulings in Israel.</b>
The Gemara relates an incident involving the use of appropriate language. There were <b>these three priests</b> in the Temple, each of whom received a portion of the showbread divided among the priests. Since there were many priests, each one received only a small amount. <b>One said to them: I received a bean-sized</b> portion. <b>And one said: I received an olive-bulk. And one said: I received</b> a portion the size <b>of a lizard’s tail. They investigated the background</b> of the latter priest, who used the imagery of an impure creeping animal, <b>and they found a trace [<i>shemetz</i>] of disqualification in his</b> background. The Gemara assumes that they found a problem in his lineage that disqualified him from the priesthood. 
The Gemara asks: <b>But wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>one does not investigate</b> a priest’s lineage <b>beyond the altar?</b> When the court investigated the lineage of a priest, they would investigate his ancestry only until they discovered a priest who sacrificed offerings on the altar. At that point, they would halt the investigation. A priest of questionable lineage would certainly not have been permitted to serve on the altar. However, in this incident the lineage of a priest who had brought offerings was indeed called into question.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Do not say</b> that they found <b>a trace [<i>shemetz</i>] of disqualification,</b> referring to his lineage. <b>Rather, say</b> that they found <b>arrogance [<i>shaḥatz</i>] of disqualification,</b> and for that reason he was disqualified from the priesthood. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>There it is different, as he cast aspersions upon himself.</b> Although it is generally assumed that any priest who participates in the Temple service is qualified to do so, this priest discredited his own lineage through his conduct.
With regard to the investigation of the priestly lineage, the Gemara relates: <b>A certain gentile would ascend</b> on the pilgrimage to Jerusalem, claiming he was Jewish, <b>and eat Paschal</b> lambs <b>in Jerusalem.</b> He would then return home and boast about how he had tricked the Jews. <b>He said: It is written:</b> “This is the statute of the Paschal lamb; <b>no foreigner may eat of it”</b> (Exodus 12:43), and another verse says: <b>“Any uncircumcised man shall not eat of it”</b> (Exodus 12:48). <b>And</b> yet, <b>I ate from the finest of the fine</b> portions of the Paschal lamb.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said to him,</b> in an attempt to thwart any repetition of this action: <b>Did they feed you from the fat tail</b> of the lamb? Do you really think they gave you the finest portion? The gentile was ignorant of the fact that the fat tail is sacrificed on the altar, not eaten. The gentile <b>said to him: No.</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira replied: If so, <b>when you ascend there</b> next time, <b>say to them: Feed me the fat tail.</b> The next year <b>when he ascended, he said to</b> the other members of the group he joined: <b>Feed me from the fat tail. They said to him: The fat tail is</b> offered <b>up to God.</b>
<b>They said to him: Who said that to you,</b> to ask for that portion? <b>He said to them</b> testily: It was <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira. They said: What is this</b> incident that has come <b>before us?</b> Could Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira have told him to eat the fat tail? This matter must be investigated further. <b>They investigated his background and found that he was a gentile, and</b> they <b>killed him. They sent</b> a message <b>to Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira: Peace unto you, Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, as you</b> are <b>in Netzivin and your net is spread in Jerusalem.</b> Despite your distance from Jerusalem, you enabled us to apprehend a person who deceived us.
The Gemara relates another incident in praise of one who is careful to refrain from improper or negative language. <b>Rav Kahana fell ill, and the Sages sent Rabbi Yehoshua, son of Rav Idi,</b> as their emissary to him. <b>They said to him: Go</b> and <b>assess what is</b> Rav Kahana’s <b>condition</b> at present. Rabbi Yehoshua, son <b>of</b> Rav Idi, <b>went and found that</b> Rav Kahana <b>had passed away. He rent his garment and turned</b> his garment around so <b>the tear</b> would be <b>behind him</b> and would not be immediately apparent, <b>and he was crying</b> as he <b>was coming. They said to him: Did</b> Rav Kahana <b>pass away? He said to them: I did not say</b> that, as the verse states: <b>“And he who utters slander is a fool”</b> (Proverbs 10:18). This verse indicates that it is undesirable to be a bearer of bad tidings, and if one must inform others of the unfortunate news, he should do so in an indirect manner.
The Gemara continues to cite examples of clean language: <b>Yoḥanan from Ḥakuk went to the villages. When he came, they said to him:</b> Did the <b>wheat</b> crop <b>develop nicely?</b> Reluctant to say that the wheat crop did not develop nicely, <b>he said to them:</b> The <b>barley</b> crop <b>developed nicely,</b> leaving them to draw their own conclusion. <b>They said to him,</b> mockingly: <b>Go out and inform the horses and donkeys</b> about the barley, <b>as it is written: “Barley and hay for the horses and swift steeds”</b> (I Kings 5:8). The Gemara asks: <b>What could he have said</b> to better express the bad news euphemistically? The Gemara answers: He could have said: <b>Last year’s wheat</b> crop <b>developed nicely. Alternatively,</b> he could have said that this year’s crop of <b>lentils,</b> which is also food for people, <b>has developed nicely.</b>

Daf 4a

The Gemara relates: <b>Rav</b> was <b>the son of Rabbi Ḥiyya’s</b> half <b>brother and the son of</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya’s half <b>sister,</b> as Ayevu, Rav’s father, married his own stepsister, Imma. <b>When</b> Rav <b>ascended there,</b> to Eretz Yisrael, Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>said to</b> Rav: <b>Is</b> your father, <b>Ayevu, alive? He said to him,</b> replying with a question: <b>Is</b> your sister, <b>Imma, alive? He said to him:</b> Indeed, <b>is Imma alive? He said to him: Is Ayevu alive?</b> Upon hearing this, Rabbi Ḥiyya understood that both Ayevu and Imma had passed away, and Rav did not wish to say so explicitly.
Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>said to his attendant: Remove my shoes and carry my garments after me to the bathhouse.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Learn from</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya’s instructions <b>three</b> <i>halakhot</i>. <b>Learn from it</b> that <b>wearing shoes</b> is <b>prohibited</b> for <b>a mourner,</b> which is why he instructed his servant to remove his shoes. <b>And learn from it</b> that for <b>distant tidings</b> mourning <b>is practiced only one day.</b> One who receives tidings of the death of a relative more than thirty days after he died, does not mourn for seven days. The <i>halakhot</i> of mourning apply for only a single day. <b>And learn from it</b> that with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of mourning, the legal status of <b>part of the day is like</b> that <b>of an entire</b> day. The Gemara derives this <i>halakha</i> from the fact that Rabbi Ḥiyya removed his shoes and immediately thereafter went to the bathhouse, an act that is prohibited for a mourner. He was permitted to do so because the restrictions of the mourning period were no longer in effect after briefly going without shoes.
With regard to the precision required in language, the Gemara relates: <b>A certain</b> man <b>would</b> regularly <b>say</b> whenever involved in conflict: <b>Adjudicate my case [<i>dunu dini</i>].</b> The Sages <b>said: Learn from it</b> that <b>he descends from</b> the tribe of <b>Dan, as it is written: “Dan will judge [<i>yadin</i>] his people like one of the tribes of Israel”</b> (Genesis 49:16). He expressed himself that way due to his lineage.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: <b>A certain</b> man <b>would</b> regularly <b>walk and say: The bushes on the seashore are cypresses</b> (<i>ge’onim</i>), i.e., items located by the sea are more beautiful than those found in other places. <b>They examined</b> his lineage <b>and found that he descends from</b> the tribe of <b>Zebulun, as it is written: “Zebulun shall dwell by the seashore”</b> (Genesis 49:13). That explains his love of all things close to the sea.
The Gemara returns to the issue of the search for leaven. <b>And now that we maintain that everyone agrees</b> the word <b><i>or</i></b> in the mishna <b>is evening,</b> consider the following: <b>After all, both according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda and according to</b> that of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who disagree with regard to the deadline decreed by the Sages to remove all leaven, <b>it is prohibited</b> to derive benefit from <b>leavened bread</b> by Torah law <b>only from the sixth hour</b> of the day <b>and onward. And</b> if so, <b>let us search</b> for leaven at <b>six</b> hours of the day, and eliminate the leaven at that point.
<b>And lest you say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the principle that <b>the vigilant are early</b> in the performance <b>of mitzvot, let us search in the morning.</b> The principle: The vigilant are early in the performance of mitzvot, is derived, <b>as it is written: “And on the eighth day the flesh of his foreskin shall be circumcised”</b> (Leviticus 12:3). <b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The entire day is suitable for</b> performance of the mitzva of <b>circumcision; however, the vigilant are early</b> in the performance <b>of mitzvot,</b> and circumcise in the morning. <b>As it is stated</b> with regard to the binding of Isaac: <b>“And Abraham arose early in the morning”</b> (Genesis 22:3) after hearing God’s command. This indicates that Abraham arose early in his eagerness to perform God’s commandment.
The Gemara cites an answer to its initial question of why the search for leaven is not conducted in the morning. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> One searches for leaven <b>in</b> the evening as it is <b>a time when people are found in their homes,</b> and they have the opportunity to perform the search. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>the light of the lamp is favorable for</b> conducting a <b>search</b> specifically at night. As the search is conducted with a lamp, it is preferable to search at night.
<b>Abaye said: Therefore,</b> in light of the above <i>halakha</i>, <b>a Torah scholar should not begin his</b> regularly scheduled <b>period</b> of Torah study <b>in the evening</b> at the conclusion <b>of the thirteenth</b> of Nisan <b>that</b> is <b>the evening of the fourteenth,</b> as <b>perhaps he will become engrossed in the <i>halakha</i></b> he is studying <b>and will come to be prevented from</b> performing the <b>mitzva</b> of searching for leaven.
<b>They raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak:</b> With regard to <b>one who lets a house to another on the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, <b>upon whom</b> is it incumbent <b>to search</b> for leaven? Is it incumbent <b>upon the lessor to search</b> for leaven, <b>as the leavened bread is his; or</b> is it <b>perhaps</b> incumbent <b>upon the lessee to search, as the</b> source of the <b>prohibition is in his domain</b> since he will be living in the house during Passover? He answered: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an answer from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who lets a house to another,</b> the obligation is <b>upon the lessee to affix a <i>mezuza</i> for it.</b> Apparently, the person renting the house is obligated to perform the mitzvot connected to the house.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>There,</b> in the case of <i>mezuza</i>, <b>didn’t Rav Mesharshiya say:</b> Affixing <b>a <i>mezuza</i> is the obligation of the resident?</b> The fact is that the owner of an uninhabited house is not obligated to affix a <i>mezuza</i> to its doors. If so, the question remains, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>here? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to them</b> that <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> the resolution to this dilemma in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who rents a house to another, if before he delivered the keys to</b> the renter <b>the fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>began,</b> the obligation is <b>upon the lessor to search</b> for leaven. <b>And if</b> it was <b>after he delivered the keys to him</b> that <b>the fourteenth began,</b> the obligation is <b>upon the lessee to search</b> for leaven.
<b>They raised</b> another <b>dilemma before Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak:</b> With regard to <b>one who lets a house to another on the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, is <b>its presumptive status</b> that it has been <b>searched or</b> is <b>it not its presumptive status that it has been searched?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the practical difference</b> between these possibilities? <b>Let him ask</b> the owner of the house. The Gemara responds: The situation here is one <b>where</b> the owner is <b>not</b> here <b>to ask him.</b> The dilemma is whether or not <b>to impose upon</b> the renter to search for the leaven. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to them</b> that <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> the resolution to this dilemma based on a related <i>baraita</i>: <b>Everyone is believed</b> to provide testimony <b>about the elimination of leavened bread; even women, even slaves,</b> and <b>even minors.</b> Although these people are typically not relied upon to deliver testimony, they are believed when they provide testimony that they have eliminated leaven. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>they are believed?</b>

Daf 4b

<b>Isn’t</b> it <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that the presumptive status</b> of the house is that it <b>has been searched, as</b> this <i>tanna</i> <b>maintains: All are</b> considered <b><i>ḥaverim</i> with regard to the search for leavened bread?</b> A <i>ḥaver</i> is one with the presumptive status of trustworthiness with regard to a given matter, e.g., ritual purity and impurity, tithes, etc. In this case, since everyone has <i>ḥaver</i> status with regard to searching for leaven, everyone is deemed trustworthy to have performed the requisite action. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a <i>ḥaver</i> who died and left a storehouse filled with produce, even</b> if the produce was there only <b>that day,</b> the fruit has the <b>presumptive status</b> of produce that was ritually <b>prepared,</b> i.e., tithed, as there is no doubt that the <i>ḥaver</i> tithed his produce before he died. The same applies to the search for leaven: All are considered <i>ḥaverim</i> and are believed.
The Gemara challenges this claim: <b>And from where</b> can this be proven? It is possible that in general a house does not have presumptive status that it was searched, and <b>perhaps it is different here, due to</b> the fact that <b>these</b> people, e.g., a woman, slave, or minor, expressly <b>stated</b> that they conducted the search. Perhaps that is why the house is considered to have been searched. The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>there is any substance in the statement of these</b> people? Since the testimony of all these is disqualified, they lack credibility, and their statements are not reliable. Instead, the reason that there is no need to search the rented property for leaven must be because of the presumption that it has already been searched.
The Gemara retorts: <b>Rather, what is</b> the reason that one need not search the rented property for leaven? Is it due to the fact <b>that its presumptive status</b> is that it <b>has been searched?</b> If so, <b>this</b> statement should not read: <b>Everyone is believed,</b> as women, slaves, or minors themselves have no credibility. <b>It should have</b> been formulated: With regard to <b>all houses on the fourteenth,</b> their <b>presumptive status is</b> that <b>they have</b> already <b>been searched,</b> as that is the actual rationale for the lenient ruling.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Rather, what</b> is the alternative? Is it that this <i>halakha</i> is <b>due to</b> the <b>statement of these</b> people, and by inference, <b>if these</b> people <b>do not say</b> that the house has been searched, then <b>no,</b> it cannot be assumed that it was searched? If so, <b>resolve</b> the original dilemma <b>from here,</b> as this is proof <b>that</b> the <b>presumptive status</b> of the house is <b>not</b> that it <b>has been searched,</b> unless someone explicitly states that this is the case.
The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <b>No, actually</b> I can <b>say to you that</b> on the fourteenth <b>its presumptive status</b> is that it <b>has been searched, and with what</b> case <b>are we dealing here?</b> This <i>halakha</i> is referring to a situation <b>where our presumption is</b> that the owner <b>did not search</b> the house, <b>and these</b> women, slaves, or minors <b>say: We searched it. Lest you say</b> that <b>the Sages do not believe them,</b> as they are unfit to testify, the <i>baraita</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that <b>since the search for leavened bread is</b> an ordinance <b>by rabbinic law, as by Torah law mere nullification</b> of one’s ownership before the prohibition of the leaven takes effect <b>is sufficient, the Sages believe them with regard to</b> an ordinance instituted <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>one who lets a house to another</b> for Passover, <b>with the presumptive status</b> that <b>it was searched, and</b> the lessee <b>discovered that it was not searched, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is it considered a mistaken transaction,</b> and the renter can abrogate the deal, claiming that he agreed on the basis of his belief that the property had already been searched? <b>Or no,</b> it is not considered a mistaken transaction?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma, <b>as Abaye said: Needless to say,</b> that <b>in a place where</b> people typically <b>do not pay a wage</b> and hire others to conduct the search for leaven <b>and</b> everyone <b>searches</b> himself, <b>a person prefers to fulfill</b> the <b>mitzva himself. However, even in a place where</b> people <b>pay a wage and</b> have others <b>search</b> for leaven, it is not a mistaken transaction due to the fact <b>that a person prefers to perform</b> the <b>mitzva with his</b> own <b>money.</b> Consequently, it is not considered a mistaken transaction, as a person does not object to having to perform a mitzva.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there,</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir says: One</b> may <b>eat</b> leaven on the fourteenth day during <b>the entire</b> first <b>five</b> hours of the day, <b>and</b> he <b>burns</b> the leaven <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One</b> may <b>eat</b> leaven for <b>the entire</b> first <b>four</b> hours of the day, <b>and one leaves</b> it <b>in abeyance during the fifth</b> hour, at which point eating leaven is prohibited but it need not be burned yet, <b>and one burns</b> the leaven <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour. <b>Everyone agrees, in any case,</b> that <b>leavened bread is prohibited</b> by Torah law <b>from the sixth hour and onward. From where do we</b> derive this?
<b>Abaye said: Two verses are written,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is derived by comparing them. <b>It is written</b> in one verse: <b>“Seven days, leaven shall not be found in your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:19), indicating that throughout these seven days it is prohibited to maintain leaven in one’s house. <b>And it is written</b> in another verse: <b>“Yet on the first day you shall remove leaven from your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:15), indicating that one must remove the leaven on the first day, after the Festival has begun. <b>How</b> can <b>this</b> apparent contradiction be resolved? The Gemara responds: The latter verse comes <b>to include the fourteenth</b> day of Nisan with regard <b>to the elimination</b> of leaven. The phrase: On the first day, does not refer to the fifteenth of Nisan or to the beginning of the festival of Passover. It is referring to the fourteenth, the day on which the Paschal lamb is slaughtered.
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> perhaps, that the verse comes <b>to include the night of the fifteenth,</b> the first night of Passover, with regard <b>to the elimination</b> of leaven. <b>As,</b> were it not for this verse, <b>it could enter your mind to say:</b> Seven <b>days is written,</b> which indicates by inference: During the <b>days, yes,</b> one is obligated to remove leaven, but during the <b>nights, no,</b> there is no requirement to do so. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us:</b> On the first day, one may not be in possession of leaven <b>even</b> during the <b>nights.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> was <b>not necessary to</b> be derived by the Sages, as it can be learned from another source.

Daf 5a

The time for <b>the removal of leaven is juxtaposed to</b> the time when <b>the eating of leavened bread</b> is prohibited. When the prohibition against eating leaven goes into effect, the obligation to remove leaven is in effect as well. <b>And</b> furthermore, the time of the prohibition against <b>the eating of leavened bread</b> is juxtaposed <b>to</b> the time for <b>the eating of <i>matza</i>,</b> as its prohibition takes effect from the time that the mitzva to eat <i>matza</i> takes effect.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>The removal of leaven</b> is juxtaposed <b>to the eating of leavened bread,</b> as they appear in the same verse, <b>as it is written: “Seven days leaven shall not be found in your houses, as anyone who eats that which is leavened,</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off</b> from the congregation of Israel” (Exodus 12:19).
<b>And</b> the prohibition against <b>the eating of leavened bread</b> is juxtaposed <b>to the eating of <i>matza</i>,</b> as both appear in the same verse, <b>as it is written: “You shall not eat anything that is leavened; in all of your dwellings you shall eat <i>matzot</i>, etc.”</b> (Exodus 12:20), <b>and it is written with regard to <i>matza</i>:</b> “On the first day, on the fourteenth day <b>in the evening you shall eat <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Exodus 12:18). Since the <i>halakha</i> that leaven is prohibited on the first night of Passover is derived from this source, there is no need for an additional derivation.
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that the verse: “Yet on the first day you shall remove leaven from your houses” comes <b>to include the night of the fourteenth</b> in the obligation <b>to remove</b> leaven, which would mean that one must remove all leaven from his house on the night of the fourteenth. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: That is not possible, as <b>“on the day” is written.</b>
The Gemara continues to ask: <b>And say</b> that leaven must be removed immediately <b>from the morning</b> of the fourteenth. The Gemara answers: That is also incorrect, as the verse says, “Yet on the first day”; and the word <b>yet divides.</b> The connotation of the word yet is one of restriction. In this context, it teaches that leaven is prohibited not for the entire day, but only for part of it. One is obligated to remove leaven only for the second half of the fourteenth of Nisan, not for the first half of the day.
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: We found</b> that the <b>fourteenth</b> day <b>is called: First, as it is stated: “On <i>harishon</i>, on the fourteenth day of the month”</b> (Exodus 12:18). <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> It is evident from the verse itself that it is referring to the removal of leaven on the fourteenth, <b>as <i>rishon</i> means previous.</b> In this context, first means the day that precedes the others, i.e., the day before the Festival begins, <b>as the verse stated: “Are you first [<i>rishon</i>] man born?</b> Or were you brought forth before the hills?” (Job 15:7). Based on the parallelism between the two parts of the verse, the word <i>rishon</i> here means before; the one preceding all others.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if that is <b>so,</b> consider a verse written with regard to <i>Sukkot</i>: <b>“And you shall take for yourselves on the first [<i>harishon</i>] day</b> the fruit of a beautiful tree, branches of palm trees, and boughs of thick trees, and willows of the brook” (Leviticus 23:40). <b>So too,</b> in this case, does <b><i>harishon</i> mean</b> the day <b>previous</b> to the Festival? Clearly, one is not obligated to take the four species on the fourteenth of Tishrei, the eve of <i>Sukkot</i>.
The Gemara rejects this contention. <b>There it is different, as it is written</b> immediately thereafter: <b>“And you shall rejoice before the Lord your God seven days”</b> (Leviticus 23:40). <b>Just as the seventh</b> of these seven days is <b>the seventh day of the Festival,</b> so <b>too,</b> the <b>first</b> of these days is the <b>first</b> day <b>of the Festival</b> itself, not the day before <i>Sukkot</i>. However, where it is not explicitly stated, <i>rishon</i> means the day before the Festival.
The Gemara raises a difficulty. <b>Here too, it is written</b> with regard to Passover: <b>“Yet on the first [<i>harishon</i>] day you shall remove</b> leaven from your houses”; <b>“for seven days you shall eat <i>matza</i>”</b> (Exodus 12:15). Just as seventh here is referring to the seventh day of the Festival, so too, <i>rishon</i> must refer to the first day of the Festival. The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let</b> the verse <b>write <i>rishon</i>; why do I</b> need the addition of the definite article, <b><i>harishon</i>? Learn from it, as we said:</b> <i>Harishon</i> means the day before the Festival.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>If so, there too,</b> with regard to <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>why do I</b> need the verse to say <b><i>harishon</i>? And furthermore, there it is written: “On the first [<i>harishon</i>] day a solemn rest and on the eighth day a solemn rest”</b> (Leviticus 23:39). Here too, <b>say</b> that <b>first means previous,</b> the day preceding the Festival. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>It is different there, as the verse said: “And on the eighth day a solemn rest,”</b> from which it can be inferred that <b>just as</b> the <b>eighth</b> means the <b>eighth</b> day <b>of the Festival,</b> so <b>too, <i>rishon</i></b> is referring to the <b>first</b> day <b>of the Festival.</b>
The Gemara repeats its earlier question: <b>Why do I</b> need the verse to say <b><i>harishon</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: The definite article comes <b>to exclude the intermediate days</b> of the Festival. It is not prohibited to perform labor on these days, as the full-fledged sanctity of the Festival does not apply to them. The Gemara says: The status of <b>the intermediate days is derived from</b> the words <b>first and eighth.</b> The fact that the verse mentions only the first and the eighth days as Festivals clearly indicates that the days between them are not Festivals.
The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, a special verse was <b>necessary</b> to exclude the intermediate Festival days, as otherwise <b>it could enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since the Merciful One writes: “And on the eighth day,”</b> the principle: The letter <b><i>vav</i> adds to the previous matter,</b> applies. When a phrase begins with the conjunction <i>vav</i>, meaning and, it is a continuation of the previous matter rather than a new topic. Based on this principle, I might have said <b>that</b> one must treat <b>even the intermediate days</b> as full-fledged Festival days. Therefore, the definite article <b>teaches us</b> not that this is not so.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let the Merciful One write</b> in the Torah <b>neither</b> the conjunction <b><i>vav</i> nor</b> the definite article <b><i>heh</i>.</b> Since they neutralize each other, as explained above, the same result could have been achieved by omitting both. <b>And furthermore, there,</b> in its description of Passover, <b>it is written: “On the first [<i>harishon</i>] day you shall have a sacred convocation;</b> you shall do no servile work” (Leviticus 23:7). Does <b>first mean previous,</b> the day preceding the Festival, in this case too? Labor is permitted on the eve of the Festival.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that <b>those three</b> times the word <b><i>rishon</i></b> is mentioned with regard to the Festivals are <b>necessary for that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: In reward for the three</b> times the word <b><i>rishon</i></b> is stated with regard to the Festivals observed by the Jewish people, <b>they were entitled to three</b> matters also referred to as <b><i>rishon</i>: To eradicate the descendants of Esau, to the construction of the Temple, and to the name of Messiah.</b>
The <i>tanna</i> provides the sources for his statement. <b>To eradicate the descendants of Esau, as it is written: “And the first [<i>harishon</i>] came forth red, all over like a hairy mantle;</b> and they called his name Esau” (Genesis 25:25). <b>And to the construction of the Temple, as it is written:</b> “The <b>Throne of Glory, on High from the beginning [<i>merishon</i>], the place of our Temple”</b> (Jeremiah 17:12). <b>And</b> the Jewish people were also entitled <b>to the name of Messiah, as it is written: “A harbinger [<i>rishon</i>] to Zion</b> I will give: <b>Behold, behold them;</b> and to Jerusalem a messenger of good tidings” (Isaiah 41:27). However, <i>harishon</i> stated with regard to Passover is referring to the day before the Festival.
<b>Rava said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that leaven is prohibited from midday on the fourteenth of Nisan is derived <b>from here: “You shall not slaughter the blood of My offering over leavened bread;</b> neither shall the offering of the feast of the Passover be left to the morning” (Exodus 34:25). This verse means that <b>you shall not slaughter the Paschal lamb while</b> your <b>leavened bread is still intact.</b> In other words, all leaven must be removed before the time the Paschal lamb may be slaughtered.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And say</b> that the verse means that <b>each and every person</b> must ensure that he has no leaven in his possession <b>when he slaughters</b> his own Paschal lamb, and there is no fixed time for this prohibition. The Gemara answers: <b>The Merciful One states the time of</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of the Paschal lamb, which begins at the end of the sixth hour. In other words, this verse is referring to a particular point in time, rather than the individual act of slaughtering the Paschal lamb.
The Gemara adds that some of the aforementioned opinions <b>were also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“Yet on the first day you shall remove leaven from your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:15). This prohibition is in effect <b>from the eve of the Festival. Or perhaps</b> that is <b>not</b> the case, but <b>it</b> applies <b>only to the Festival itself. The verse states: “You shall not slaughter the blood of My offering over leavened bread”</b> (Exodus 34:25), meaning that <b>you shall not slaughter the Paschal lamb while</b> your <b>leavened bread is still intact.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: There is no need</b> for this proof, <b>as it says: “Yet on the first day you shall remove leaven from your houses,” and it is written:</b> “And on the first day there shall be to you a sacred convocation, and on the seventh day a sacred convocation; <b>you shall perform no manner of work</b> on them” (Exodus 12:16). <b>And we found that kindling</b> a fire <b>is a primary category of</b> prohibited <b>labor.</b> Since the fire in which the leaven is burned is not for the preparation of food, kindling it is not performed for the purpose of the Festival. Therefore, it is prohibited to burn the leaven on the Festival itself. Consequently, one must burn the leaven on the day before the Festival.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: There is no need</b> for that proof either, <b>as it says: “Yet on the first day you shall remove leaven from your houses.”</b> This prohibition applies <b>from the eve of the Festival. Or perhaps</b> that is <b>not</b> the case, but <b>it</b> applies only <b>to the Festival itself. The verse states: Yet,</b> which comes <b>to divide</b> the day into two parts; the first half, when leaven is permitted, and the second half, when it is prohibited. <b>And if</b> this verse is referring <b>to</b> the first day of <b>the Festival itself, is</b> leaven <b>permitted</b> on the actual Festival? As explained above, <b>the removal of leaven is juxtaposed to the eating of leavened bread, and the eating of leavened bread</b> is juxtaposed <b>to the eating of <i>matza</i>. Rava said:</b>

Daf 5b

<b>Learn from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Akiva three</b> <i>halakhot</i>. <b>Learn from it</b> that <b>the removal of leavened bread</b> can be performed <b>only by</b> means of <b>burning.</b> Rabbi Akiva bases his opinion on the fact that it is prohibited to kindle a fire on the Festival.<br><b>And</b> second, <b>learn from it</b> that the prohibition against kindling a fire on Shabbat <b>was</b> specifically singled <b>out</b> in the Torah <b>to divide</b> the various primary categories of labor and to establish liability for performance of each of them. The dissenting opinion is that kindling is singled out to teach that there is no capital punishment for performing that primary category of labor.<br><b>And</b> third, <b>learn from it</b> that <b>we do not say: Since</b> it is <b>permitted</b> to <b>kindle</b> a fire <b>for</b> the <b>purpose</b> of preparing food, it is <b>also permitted</b> to light a fire <b>not for</b> the <b>purpose</b> of preparing food, e.g., to burn leaven.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“Seven days leaven shall not be found in your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:19). To <b>what</b> purpose does <b>the verse state</b> this prohibition? <b>Wasn’t it already stated:</b> “And <b>no leaven shall be seen with you, neither shall there be leavened bread seen with you, in all your borders”</b> (Exodus 13:7)?
The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>Because it is stated: “And no leaven shall be seen with you,”</b> which teaches that <b>your</b> own leaven <b>you</b> may <b>not see, but you may see</b> leaven that belongs <b>to others,</b> i.e., gentiles, <b>and</b> leaven consecrated <b>to God.</b> In light of this <i>halakha</i>, I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one</b> may <b>conceal</b> leaven in one’s home or <b>accept deposits</b> of leaven <b>from a gentile.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Shall not be found,”</b> meaning that one may not retain any type of leaven in one’s house at all.
The <i>tanna</i> continues: Had only this verse been stated, <b>I</b> would <b>have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a gentile whom you did not overcome and who does not dwell with you in the courtyard.</b> With regard to <b>a gentile whom you overcame and who dwells with you in the courtyard, from where</b> do we know that he is also included in this prohibition? <b>The verse states: “It shall not be found in your houses”</b> at all, i.e., anywhere in one’s possession.
The <i>baraita</i> further states that from the verse: “It shall not be found in your houses,” <b>I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than the fact that this prohibition applies to leaven <b>that is</b> actually <b>in your houses. From where</b> is it derived that this <i>halakha</i> applies even to leaven <b>in pits, ditches, and caves? The verse states: In all your borders,</b> i.e., anywhere that belongs to you.
<b>And still I</b> can <b>say:</b> If there is leaven <b>in your houses, one violates</b> the prohibition that leaven <b>shall not be seen and</b> the prohibition that <b>it shall not be found, as well as</b> the prohibitions of <b>you shall not conceal and you shall not receive deposits from a gentile.</b> Meanwhile, <b>in your borders,</b> outside your home, <b>your</b> own leaven <b>you may not see, but you may see</b> leaven that belongs <b>to others,</b> i.e., gentiles, <b>and</b> leaven consecrated <b>to God. From where</b> is it derived that it is proper <b>to apply</b> the prohibition <b>that was said about this</b> place <b>to that</b> place, <b>and</b> the prohibition <b>that was said about that</b> place <b>to this</b> place?
The <i>tanna</i> answers that <b>the verse states</b> the term <b>leaven</b> with regard to houses and the term <b>leaven</b> with regard to borders <b>as a verbal analogy. It states leaven with regard to houses:</b> “Seven days <b>leaven shall not be found in your houses,” and it states leaven with regard to borders: “Neither shall there be leaven seen with you.” Just as</b> for the <b>leaven stated with regard to houses one transgresses</b> the prohibition that leaven <b>shall not be seen and</b> the prohibition that <b>it shall not be found, and</b> the prohibitions of <b>one shall not conceal and one shall not receive deposits from a gentile,</b> so <b>too,</b> for the <b>leaven stated with regard to borders, one transgresses</b> the prohibition that leaven <b>shall not be seen and</b> the prohibition that <b>it shall not be found, and</b> the prohibitions of <b>one shall not conceal and one shall not receive deposits from a gentile.</b>
The converse is also true: <b>Just as</b> concerning the <b>leaven stated with regard to borders, your</b> own leaven <b>you may not see, but you may see</b> leaven that belongs <b>to others,</b> i.e., gentiles, <b>and</b> leaven consecrated <b>to God,</b> so <b>too,</b> concerning the <b>leaven stated with regard to houses: Your</b> own leaven <b>you may not see, but you may see</b> leaven that belongs <b>to others and</b> leaven consecrated <b>to God.</b>
The Gemara addresses several difficult aspects of this <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said: I</b> would <b>have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a gentile whom you did not overcome and who does not dwell with you in the courtyard.</b> With regard to <b>a gentile whom you overcame and who dwells with you in the courtyard, from where</b> is it derived that he is also included in this prohibition? <b>The verse states: “It shall not be found</b> in your houses.”
The Gemara questions the logic of this proof. <b>On the contrary;</b> the prohibition regarding the leaven of a gentile who is subservient to and lives with a Jew is more obvious than the prohibition regarding the leaven of a gentile who is neither. The <i>tanna</i> should have started with the leaven belonging to a gentile who is subservient to a Jew. <b>Abaye said: Reverse</b> the order of the statement: I might have thought that only leaven owned by a gentile whom you overcame and who dwells with you in the courtyard is prohibited; but leaven owned by a gentile whom you did not overcome and who does not dwell with you in the courtyard is permitted.
<b>Rava said: Actually, do not reverse</b> the order, as this statement is not in fact a continuation of the previous one <b>and</b> instead <b>it applies to the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, which deals with the time when leaven is permitted. The entire statement should read as follows: <b>Your</b> own leaven <b>you</b> may <b>not see, but you may see</b> leaven that belongs <b>to others,</b> i.e., gentiles, <b>and</b> leaven consecrated <b>to God,</b> as one is not commanded to remove leaven that belongs to a gentile. <b>I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a gentile whom you did not overcome and who does not dwell with you in the courtyard,</b> as the leaven belonging to that gentile is in no way tied to the Jew. With regard to <b>a gentile whom you overcame and who dwells with you in the courtyard, from where</b> is it derived that he is also included in this leniency? <b>The verse states: “It shall not be found.”</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>This <i>tanna</i> seeks permission</b> for seeing the leaven of a gentile, and yet <b>he cites a verse to</b> establish <b>a prohibition.</b> The Gemara answers that the <i>tanna</i> did not cite proof from the phrase: It shall not be found. <b>Due to</b> the fact <b>that it is stated:</b> “No leaven shall be seen <b>with you</b> in all your borders” (Exodus 13:7) and “No leaven shall be seen <b>with you</b> in all your borders” (Deuteronomy 16:4) <b>twice,</b> one of them is superfluous and may be appended to: It shall not be found, creating the prohibition: It shall not be found with you. Only leaven belonging to a Jew is prohibited.
The Gemara continues its analysis of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said:</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one</b> may <b>conceal</b> leaven in one’s home or <b>accept deposits</b> of leaven <b>from the gentiles.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: It shall not be found.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t you say in the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Your</b> own leaven <b>you may not see, but you may see</b> leaven that belongs <b>to others and</b> leaven consecrated <b>to God,</b> indicating that it is permitted to have leaven in one’s house if it belongs to a gentile?
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult;</b> in <b>this</b> case it is prohibited, <b>as he accepted upon himself responsibility</b> to pay for the leaven if it is destroyed. Therefore, it is considered as though the leaven belonged to him. In <b>that</b> case it is permitted, <b>as he did not accept upon himself responsibility,</b> and therefore the leaven remains the full-fledged property of the gentile.
That ruling <b>is like that which Rava said to the residents of Meḥoza: Remove the leavened bread that belongs to the members of the</b> gentile <b>army from your houses.</b> Gentile soldiers would bring flour with them and force the people in the city to prepare bread on their behalf. Rava explained the rationale for his ruling: <b>Since if</b> the flour <b>were stolen or if it were lost, it stands in your possession and you</b> would be <b>required to pay</b> for it, its legal status <b>is as</b> if it were <b>yours, and it is prohibited</b> to keep it during Passover.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>This</b> explanation works out <b>well according to the one who said:</b> The legal status of <b>an object that effects monetary</b> loss <b>is like</b> that of <b>money.</b> If an item is inherently or currently worthless, but if it is lost or stolen one would be obligated to pay to replace it, its legal status is like that of money. Therefore, the Jews’ responsibility for the leaven renders its legal status as if it belonged to them. <b>However, according to the one who said:</b> The legal status of an object that effects monetary loss <b>is not like</b> that of <b>money, what can be said?</b>
The Gemara answers: It is <b>different here, as</b> the verse <b>said: “It shall not be found,”</b> indicating that leaven may not be found in any place, even if there is only a token connection between the leaven and the Jew in whose property it is situated, and even if he is not required to pay for it if it is lost or stolen.
<b>Some state</b> a contrary version of the above discussion. <b>This</b> explanation works out <b>well according to the one who said:</b> The legal status of <b>an object that effects monetary</b> loss <b>is not like</b> that of <b>money.</b>

Daf 6a

<b>That is</b> the reason <b>that</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for the Torah to write: <b>It shall not be found,</b> to indicate that there is a <i>halakha</i> unique to leaven. In this case, it is considered as though it were in his possession. <b>However, according to the one who said:</b> The legal status of an object that effects monetary loss <b>is like</b> that of <b>money, why do I</b> need the phrase: <b>It shall not be found?</b> Obviously, the leaven is prohibited, as it is considered his property. The Gemara answers: It is nonetheless <b>necessary,</b> as <b>it could enter your mind to say: Since when</b> the leaven <b>is intact it returns</b> to the gentile <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, it retroactively did <b>not stand in</b> the Jew’s <b>possession</b> and the Jew did not violate the prohibition against having leaven found on his property. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that it is considered as though the leaven belonged to the Jew.
<b>They raised a dilemma before Rava:</b> Is the owner of <b>an animal</b> born into a herd from which <b>the royal tax [<i>arnona</i>]</b> is collected <b>obligated in</b> the mitzva to give <b>the firstborn</b> animal to a priest, as the animal still belongs to a Jew? <b>Or</b> perhaps he is <b>not obligated</b> to give <b>the firstborn</b> animal to the priest, as the obligation does not take effect on an animal partly owned by a gentile. The Gemara elaborates on the parameters of raising the dilemma: In <b>any</b> case <b>where</b> the Jew <b>could dismiss</b> the gentile tax collector <b>with money</b> in lieu of the animals, <b>we do not raise the dilemma, as</b> he is clearly <b>obligated</b> in the mitzva of the firstborn. The authorities own no part of the animal; the Jew merely owes them a monetary debt. Therefore, the animal is the property of the Jew exclusively.
The situation <b>when we</b> do <b>raise the dilemma</b> is specifically <b>where</b> the Jew <b>cannot dismiss</b> the gentile tax collector <b>with money. What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> is this case? <b>He said to them:</b> The owner is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of the firstborn. The Sages raised a difficulty: <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that he is <b>obligated</b> in the mitzva of the firstborn? He replied: <b>There</b> it is speaking of a case <b>where</b> the Jew <b>could dismiss</b> the gentile tax collector with money.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>Rava said:</b> The owner of <b>an animal</b> born into a herd from which <b>the royal tax</b> is collected <b>is exempt from</b> the mitzva of <b>a firstborn, even though</b> the Jew <b>could dismiss</b> the gentile tax collector with money. However, the owner of <b>dough</b> from which <b>the royal tax</b> is collected <b>is obligated in <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> despite the fact that the owner of dough partially owned by a gentile is generally not obligated. This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though</b> the Jew <b>cannot dismiss</b> the gentile tax collector by paying him the value of the dough.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for the difference between the <i>halakha</i> of a firstborn animal and the <i>halakha</i> of <i>ḥalla</i>? <b>An animal</b> generates <b>publicity;</b> as everyone knows that this Jew’s animal was confiscated by the authorities, no one will suspect him of intentionally refraining from fulfilling the mitzva. In contrast, <b>dough</b> does <b>not</b> generate <b>publicity.</b> Since not everyone knows that the dough is partially owned by a gentile, those who see a Jew failing to separate <i>ḥalla</i> will suspect him of neglecting the mitzva.
