<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a gentile who enters the courtyard of a Jew with his dough in his hand,</b> the Jew <b>need not remove</b> the leaven by evicting the gentile from his property. However, if the gentile <b>deposited</b> the leaven <b>with him,</b> and the Jew accepted responsibility, <b>he must remove</b> it. If <b>he designated</b> a room in his <b>house for</b> the gentile to place his leavened food, <b>he need not remove</b> it, <b>as it is stated: “It shall not be found”</b> (Exodus 12:19).
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying?</b> How does the verse: It shall not be found, prove this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The verse cited <b>is referring to the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and this is</b> what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying:</b> If the gentile <b>deposited</b> the leavened dough <b>with</b> the Jew, <b>he,</b> i.e., the Jew, <b>must remove</b> the dough from his property, <b>as it is stated: It shall not be found.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: Actually</b>, the verse cited <b>is referring to the last clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and this is</b> what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying:</b> If <b>he designated</b> a room in his <b>house for</b> the gentile to place the leavened dough, <b>he need not remove it, as it is stated: It shall not be found in your houses, and that</b> house <b>is not his; since when the gentile brings</b> the dough <b>into</b> the house, <b>he brings</b> it <b>into his</b> own <b>house,</b> as the space was designated for his use.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that rental</b> denotes that the renter <b>acquires</b> the rented space as he would a full-fledged acquisition with regard to responsibility for that space? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>Even in a place</b> with regard to <b>which they said</b> it is permitted for a Jew <b>to rent</b> houses to gentiles, e.g., in Syria, <b>they did not say</b> that one may rent it <b>for</b> use as <b>a residence, because</b> the gentiles will <b>bring idolatry into it. And if it enters your mind</b> to say <b>that rental</b> denotes that the renter <b>acquires</b> the rented space as he would a full-fledged acquisition, <b>when</b> the gentile <b>brings</b> the idols <b>into</b> the house <b>he brings them into his own house.</b> Why, then, is it prohibited for the owner to rent it to a gentile?
The Gemara answers: It is <b>different here</b> with regard to leaven, <b>as the Merciful One expresses it</b> using <b>the language: It shall not be found,</b> meaning, <b>that which is found in your possession</b> is prohibited, <b>excluding this</b> leaven, <b>which is not found in your possession.</b> However, with regard to other prohibitions, one who rents a place to others remains somewhat responsible for his property, despite the fact that he does not live there.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who finds leavened bread in his house on the Festival,</b> i.e., the first day of Passover, <b>covers it with a vessel</b> and burns it at the conclusion of the Festival day. <b>Rava said: If</b> that leaven <b>is consecrated, he need not</b> cover it. <b>What is the reason</b> for this difference? The reason is that people <b>distance</b> themselves <b>from</b> consecrated food in any case, due to the severity of the prohibition against misuse of consecrated property. Therefore, there is no concern that he will eat it.
<b>And Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> If <b>leavened bread belonging to a gentile</b> is in a Jew’s house, he, i.e., the Jew, should <b>erect a barrier ten handbreadths</b> high around <b>it</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>as a conspicuous marker,</b> so that he will not mistakenly eat it. <b>And if</b> the leaven <b>is consecrated, he need not</b> do so. <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? Since <b>people distance</b> themselves <b>from</b> consecrated food, they will not mistakenly eat it.
<b>And Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>one who sets sail, or one who departs in a caravan</b> traveling to a distant place; if he did so <b>before</b> it was <b>thirty days</b> prior to Passover, he <b>need not remove</b> the leaven from his possession. If he departs <b>within thirty days</b> of the Festival, <b>he must remove</b> the leaven. <b>Abaye said: That</b> which <b>you said,</b> that <b>within thirty days one must remove</b> the leaven, <b>we only said</b> this in a case <b>where his intention is to return</b> home adjacent to Passover (Ran). <b>However,</b> in a case <b>where it is not his intention to return</b> before Passover, <b>he need not remove</b> the leaven.
<b>Rava said to him: But if he intends to return</b> home shortly before the Festival, <b>even</b> if he was gone <b>from Rosh HaShana,</b> shouldn’t he remove the leaven, as failure to do so will lead to his arriving home and discovering leaven in his house just before the Festival? <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> According to <b>that</b> which <b>you said,</b> i.e., that if he leaves <b>before</b> it was <b>thirty days</b> prior to Passover <b>he need not remove</b> the leaven, <b>we said</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only if he does not intend to return</b> before Passover. <b>However,</b> if <b>he intends to return, even</b> if he was gone <b>from Rosh HaShana, he must remove</b> the leaven.
<b>And Rava followed his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> stated elsewhere, as Rava maintains that one must remove all leaven from his possession within thirty days of Passover, even if he will not be there on the Festival itself. <b>As Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>one who turns his house into a storehouse,</b> and there is leaven beneath the stored grain, if he does so <b>before</b> it was <b>thirty days</b> prior to Passover, <b>he need not remove</b> the leaven. Since the leaven is concealed, it is considered removed after the fact. If it is <b>within thirty days, he must remove</b> the leaven, as it is not considered removed <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>And</b> even if this occurred <b>before</b> it was <b>thirty days</b> prior to Passover, <b>we only said</b> that he is not obligated to remove the leaven if <b>it is not his intention to clear away</b> the stored grain before Passover. <b>However,</b> if <b>his intention is to clear away</b> the grain before Passover, <b>he must remove</b> the leaven <b>even before</b> it was <b>thirty days</b> prior to Passover, as perhaps he will not have time to remove the leaven before the Festival.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the purpose of this</b> period of <b>thirty days</b> that renders it significant? The Gemara answers: <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One asks</b> about <b>and teaches the <i>halakhot</i> of Passover thirty days before Passover. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> One begins studying those <i>halakhot</i> <b>two weeks</b> before the Festival. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason for the</b> opinion of the <b>first <i>tanna</i>,</b> that one begins studying the <i>halakhot</i> of Passover thirty days before the Festival?

Daf 6b

The Gemara explains that this <i>halakha</i> is derived from the fact <b>that Moses was standing at</b> the time of the <b>first <i>Pesaḥ</i>,</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>and warning</b> the people <b>about</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>,</b> which occurred a month later, on the fourteenth of Iyyar. <b>As it is stated</b> that God said to Moses: <b>“Let the children of Israel perform the <i>Pesaḥ</i> at its appointed time”</b> (Numbers 9:2). A subsequent verse says: “And Moses told the children of Israel to perform the <i>Pesaḥ</i>, and they performed the <i>Pesaḥ</i> in the first month on the fourteenth of the month in the evening, in the desert of Sinai” (Numbers 9:4–5). <b>And it is written</b> in the next verse: <b>“And there were people who were impure due to a dead body</b> and could not perform the Passover on that day, and they came before Moses and before Aaron on that day” (Numbers 9:6), at which point Moses explained the <i>halakhot</i> of the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> to them. This proves that one begins studying the <i>halakhot</i> of the Festival thirty days beforehand.
<b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in rejecting that proof: <b>Since</b> Moses <b>was speaking with regard to the laws of Passover, he completed</b> teaching <b>all the matters of Passover,</b> including those of the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. Consequently, one cannot derive a principle from this case.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason for Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s</b> ruling? He explains <b>that Moses was standing on the first day</b> of Nisan <b>and warning about</b> the performance of <b>the</b> first <b><i>Pesaḥ</i>, as it is stated: “This month shall be for you the beginning of the months,</b> the first of the months of the year” (Exodus 12:2). <b>And it is written</b> in the next verse: <b>“Speak to the entire congregation of Israel, saying: On the tenth day of this month they shall take for them every man a lamb, according to their fathers’ houses,</b> a lamb for each household” (Exodus 12:3). The Torah proceeds to detail the <i>halakhot</i> of the Paschal lamb sacrificed on the fourteenth day of that month.
The Gemara asks: Although this source does indicate that one should study the <i>halakhot</i> of Passover prior to the Festival, <b>from where</b> is it derived <b>that he was standing</b> and saying these matters <b>on the</b> day <b>of the New Moon? Perhaps he was standing on the fourth of the month or on the fifth of the month</b> of Nisan?
<b>Rather, Rabba bar Shimi said in the name of Ravina:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is derived <b>from here: “And God spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the first month of the second year</b> after they came out of the land of Egypt” (Numbers 9:1), <b>and it is written: “And let the children of Israel perform the <i>Pesaḥ</i> at its appointed time”</b> (Numbers 9:2). Evidently, Moses taught the <i>halakhot</i> of Passover two weeks prior to the Festival. The Gemara asks: <b>Here too, from where</b> is it derived <b>that he was standing on the</b> day <b>of the New Moon? Perhaps he was standing on the fourth of the month or on the fifth of the month?</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between the term <b>wilderness</b> written here <b>and</b> the term <b>wilderness</b> written previously. <b>It is written here: “In the wilderness of Sinai,” and it is written there: “And God spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai in the Tent of Meeting on the first of the second month”</b> (Numbers 1:1). <b>Just as there</b> it occurred <b>on</b> the day of <b>the New Moon,</b> on the first of the month, so <b>too here,</b> with regard to Passover, <b>it was on</b> the day of <b>the New Moon.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let</b> the Torah <b>write first</b> that which occurred <b>in the first month and then let it write</b> that which occurred <b>in the second month,</b> as the portion of the Paschal lamb preceded the beginning of the book of Numbers chronologically. <b>Rav Menashiya bar Taḥlifa said in the name of Rav: That is to say</b> that <b>there is no earlier and later,</b> i.e., there is no absolute chronological order, <b>in the Torah,</b> as events that occurred later in time can appear earlier in the Torah.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This principle <b>applies only</b> when the Torah deals <b>with two</b> separate <b>matters, but within one matter, that which</b> is written <b>earlier</b> occurred <b>earlier, and that which</b> is written <b>later</b> occurred <b>later; as, if you do not say so</b> but you claim that there is no definite order within each matter, then the hermeneutic principle: When a <b>generalization</b> is followed by a <b>detail the generalization</b> refers <b>only</b> to <b>that which</b> is specified in <b>the detail,</b> is problematic. This principle is valid only if there is a definite order to the verses and words in each matter. If there is no definite order, <b>perhaps</b> it is actually a <b>detail</b> followed by a <b>generalization,</b> which is interpreted by means of an alternate hermeneutic principle with different results.
<b>And furthermore,</b> this is equally difficult with regard to the hermeneutic principle: “When <b>a detail</b> is followed by a <b>generalization, the generalization becomes an addition to the detail,</b> adding cases dissimilar to the detail. Here too, <b>perhaps it is a generalization</b> followed by <b>a detail,</b> as there is no defined order. Apparently, there must be a fixed order within a given matter.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> based on the above reasoning one cannot apply these principles <b>even</b> with regard <b>to two matters. This</b> statement works out <b>well according to</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said:</b> With regard to <b>a generalization and a detail that</b> appear in the Torah <b>removed from one another, one cannot derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from it <b>with</b> the principle of <b>a generalization and a detail. However, according to the one who said: One derives</b> from a generalization and a detail that are removed from one another by means of said principle, <b>what is there to say?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Even according to the one who said that one derives</b> a <i>halakha</i> from a generalization and a detail that are removed from one another, <b>this applies only</b> with regard <b>to one matter,</b> i.e., verses dealing with the same issue, even if they do not appear together. <b>However,</b> if they address <b>two</b> different <b>matters, one cannot derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from a generalization and a detail, as the Torah is not written in absolute chronological order.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who searches</b> for leaven <b>must render</b> all his leaven <b>null and void,</b> cognitively and verbally. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>If you say it is due to crumbs</b> that he failed to detect in his search, <b>they are</b> inherently <b>insignificant,</b> and null and void by definition.
<b>And lest you say: Since they are protected on account of</b> their very presence in <b>his house,</b> whose protection is important to him, they <b>are significant</b> and are not null and void, <b>wasn’t it taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> that this is not the case? When the end of the fig season arrives, and those <b>remaining figs</b> on the trees are few and of inferior quality, there is room to assume that the owner has renounced his ownership over them. However, he continues to <b>guard his field due to the grapes,</b> which are harvested at that time. Similarly, when the end of the grape season arrives, those few <b>remaining grapes</b> are of inferior quality and the owner <b>guards his field due to the cucumbers and due to the gourds,</b> which have not yet been harvested.
<b>When the owner is particular about</b> the figs and the grapes respectively, <b>it is prohibited</b> to take them, <b>due to</b> the prohibition against <b>robbery, and</b> one with permission to eat them is <b>obligated due to</b> the mitzva to separate the <b>tithe</b> from them, as they are considered like any other fruit. <b>When the owner is not particular about them,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> to eat them <b>due to</b> the fact that the prohibition against <b>robbery</b> does not apply, <b>and</b> one who eats them is <b>exempt due to</b> the fact that the obligation to separate the <b>tithe</b> does not apply, as they are ownerless property. This indicates that if one is not particular about an object, even if it is located in property that he is guarding for another purpose, that object is not thereby rendered significant. The same reasoning applies to breadcrumbs that remain in one’s house.
<b>Rava said:</b> The reason for the requirement to render leaven null and void is based on <b>a decree lest he find a fine cake [<i>geluska</i>]</b> among the leaven that he did not destroy <b>and his thoughts are upon it.</b> Due to its significance, he will hesitate before removing it and will be in violation of the prohibition against owning leaven. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him nullify it when he finds it.</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion. <b>Perhaps he will find it</b> only <b>after it is</b> already <b>forbidden, and</b> at that time <b>it is no</b> longer <b>in his possession and he is</b> therefore <b>unable to nullify</b> leaven when it is already Passover, <b>as Rabbi Elazar said: Two items are not in a person’s possession</b> in terms of legal ownership, <b>and</b> yet <b>the Torah rendered</b> him responsible for <b>them as though</b> they were <b>in his property. And these are they: An</b> open <b>pit in the public domain,</b> for which the one who excavated it is liable to pay any damages it causes even though it does not belong to him; <b>and leaven</b> in one’s house <b>from the sixth hour</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan <b>and onward.</b> As this leaven has no monetary value, since it is prohibited to eat or to derive benefit from it, it is not his property, and nevertheless he violates a prohibition if it remains in his domain.
The Gemara returns to the issue of the nullification of leaven. If so, <b>let him render</b> the leaven <b>null and void during the fourth hour or let him render it null and void during the fifth hour</b> of the fourteenth of Nisan. Why is he required to do so when he searches for leaven on the evening of the fourteenth? The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the fourth hour <b>is neither the time</b> of the <b>prohibition</b> of the leaven <b>nor the time</b> of its <b>removal,</b> it is a nondescript point in time. There is concern that <b>perhaps he will be negligent and will not render it null and void,</b> and the leaven will remain in his possession.

Daf 7a

The Gemara asks: <b>But let him render</b> the leaven <b>null and void during the sixth</b> hour, when he burns it. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> there is <b>a rabbinic prohibition</b> that takes effect <b>on</b> the leaven, as it is prohibited to derive benefit from it after the fifth hour, its legal status <b>is like</b> that of leaven prohibited <b>by Torah law, and</b> therefore <b>it is not in his possession and he</b> is <b>unable to nullify</b> it.
The Gemara continues: There is proof that the Sages were stringent with regard to leaven prohibited by rabbinic law, <b>as Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>a man who betroths</b> a woman on the fourteenth of Nisan <b>from</b> the beginning of <b>the sixth hour and onward, even</b> if he does so <b>with wheat from the mountains [<i>kurdanaita</i>],</b> which is particularly hard and there is no certainty that it will ferment even if water falls on it, nevertheless, as it is possible that the wheat leavened, its legal status is that of leaven. Consequently, it is prohibited to derive benefit from this wheat, which is legally worthless. Therefore, if a man gives the wheat to a woman for the purpose of betrothal, <b>one</b> need <b>not</b> be <b>concerned that</b> it is <b>a betrothal.</b> The reason is that a betrothal is effective only if the man gives the woman an object worth at least a <i>peruta</i>. In this case the Sages disqualify the betrothal and allow the woman to marry another man, despite the fact that by Torah law she is betrothed to the first man, as the leaven with which he betrothed her is prohibited only by rabbinic law.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And</b> is it indeed the case that <b>after the</b> leaven has become <b>prohibited</b> one is <b>unable to render it null and void? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>was sitting in the study hall and he remembered that there is leavened bread in his house,</b> he should <b>render it null and void in his heart, both on Shabbat and on the Festival?</b> The Gemara analyzes this statement: <b>Granted,</b> on <b>Shabbat you</b> can <b>find</b> this case, as one can nullify the leaven before it becomes prohibited, in a case <b>where the fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>occurs on Shabbat</b> and he remembers to nullify the leaven before the prohibition takes effect. <b>However,</b> if he remembered on the <b>Festival</b> itself, <b>it is after the prohibition</b> has taken effect, as the Festival has already begun, and yet the <i>baraita</i> says that one may render the leaven null and void.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Here we are dealing with a student sitting before his teacher, and he remembers that there is kneaded dough in his house, and he is afraid lest it leaven</b> before he can return home to warn the members of his household. Since the dough has not yet leavened and is not yet prohibited, he can take <b>earlier</b> action <b>and render it null and void before it becomes leavened.</b>
The Gemara comments: The language of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise</b> in accordance with this explanation, <b>as</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> If one <b>was sitting in the study hall.</b> This indicates that the dough has not yet risen, and the problem is that he cannot arrive home in time to prevent it from rising. However, if it had already become leavened, rendering it null and void will not remedy the situation even if he were home. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> proof that Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov’s interpretation is correct.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to a vessel that contains several loaves in which there was <b>bread that became moldy,</b> and it is not evident whether it is leaven or <i>matza</i>, <b>once there was more <i>matza</i></b> than leaven in the vessel, it is <b>permitted.</b> The Gemara first analyzes the case itself: <b>What are the circumstances? If you say that he knows that</b> this loaf <b>is leavened bread,</b> even if <b>there were more <i>matza</i>, what of</b> it? What difference does it make that most of the food is <i>matza</i>, if it is clear that this loaf is leaven?
<b>Rather,</b> Rav must be speaking of a case <b>where we do not know whether it is leavened bread</b> or <b>whether it is <i>matza</i>.</b> However, in that case, <b>why</b> discuss <b>specifically</b> a situation <b>where there was more <i>matza</i></b> in the vessel? <b>Even</b> in a case <b>where there was not more <i>matza</i></b> in the vessel <b>as well,</b> the questionable loaf is likely to be <i>matza</i>, as <b>let us follow the last</b> item placed in the vessel, which even on the first day of Passover would be <i>matza</i>.
<b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>coins that were found before animal merchants</b> in Jerusalem, <b>they are always</b> assumed to be money of the second <b>tithe,</b> as most of the animals purchased in Jerusalem were bought with that money. This <i>halakha</i> applies both during a Festival and throughout the year, as people would purchase animals for meat with their second-tithe money, and it can therefore be assumed that these coins have the status of second tithe. However, if the money was found <b>on the Temple Mount</b> it is <b>non-sacred</b> money, even during a Festival. It can be assumed that one who enters the Temple Mount has already purchased all the animals that he required beforehand. Any coins in his possession are non-sacred money, not tithes.
If the money was found elsewhere <b>in Jerusalem during the Festival,</b> when many people came to Jerusalem with their second-tithe money, the coins are presumed to be second-<b>tithe</b> money. However, if the coins were found <b>during the rest of the year,</b> it is <b>non-sacred</b> money.
The Gemara explains the proof. <b>And Rav Shemaya bar Zeira said: What is the reason</b> that during the rest of the year the coins are considered non-sacred money, even on the day after the Festival? <b>Since the markets of Jerusalem tend to be cleaned every day,</b> any money left there would already have been found by the street cleaners. Consequently, any coins found there were left there recently. <b>Apparently, we say</b> that <b>the first ones are gone and these</b> objects <b>are later ones. Here too,</b> with regard to moldy bread, <b>let us say: The first ones</b> have been eaten and <b>are gone, and this</b> food <b>is from now</b> and is undoubtedly <i>matza</i>.
The Gemara rejects this proof: It is <b>different here, as the mold proves about</b> the loaf that it is leaven, as food does not become moldy unless it has been sitting for a long time. The Gemara retorts: <b>If its mold proves about</b> the loaf that it is leaven, <b>if there was more <i>matza</i></b> in the vessel, <b>what of</b> it? Even in that case, the very fact that it is moldy proves that it is leaven. <b>Rabba said: Do not say there was more <i>matza</i></b> than leaven in the vessel; <b>rather, say that several days of</b> eating <b><i>matza</i> have passed over</b> the vessel. In other words, several days of the Festival, during which <i>matza</i> is consumed, have passed. Therefore, it is more likely that the moldy loaf is <i>matza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the moldy loaf is <i>matza</i>, not leaven. The Gemara answers: <b>No, it is necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> with regard to a situation where <b>its mold is extensive. Lest you say: Since its mold is extensive the matter is revealed that it is certainly leavened bread,</b> therefore Rav <b>teaches us</b> that one cannot be entirely sure that this is the case.
The Gemara explains the reason for the uncertainty. <b>Since several days of</b> eating <b><i>matza</i> have passed over</b> the vessel, <b>we say: Each and every day he baked warm loaves, which he placed upon</b> the previous days’ <i>matza</i>, causing <b>it to grow moldier.</b> Therefore, it is possible that even though only a brief time has passed, the <i>matza</i> has grown very moldy, due to the moisture and heat inside the vessel.
In regard to the aforementioned principle, the Gemara asks: <b>And do we,</b> in general, <b>follow the last</b> item in determining the identity of the item in question? <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>a box</b> that people <b>used for</b> both <b>non-sacred coins and</b> second-<b>tithe coins, if the majority</b> of its use was for <b>non-sacred</b> money, the coins are considered <b>non-sacred. If the majority</b> of its use was for second-<b>tithe</b> coins, the coins are considered second-<b>tithe</b> money. The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> is this so? <b>Let us follow</b> the <b>last</b> item placed in the box.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> people <b>used</b> the box <b>for</b> both <b>non-sacred coins and</b> second-<b>tithe coins, and he does not know which</b> of the two kinds of money was placed there <b>last.</b><br><b>Rav Zevid said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where he used</b> one part of the box for <b>piles</b> of non-sacred coins and another part of the box for <b>piles</b> of second-tithe coins. In this case, there was no definitive most recent use of the box, as a coin may have moved from one side of the box to the other.<br><b>Rav Pappa said:</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> the coin <b>was found in a hole</b> in the box. The concern is that this coin might not be of the type last placed into the box. Instead, it is possible that this coin remained from a previous use and was not removed because it was obscured in the hole.
<b>Rav Yehuda said: One who searches</b> for leaven <b>must recite a blessing.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What blessing does he recite,</b> i.e., what is the correct formula of the blessing? <b>Rav Pappi said in the name of Rava</b> that one <b>recites:</b> Who has made us holy through His mitzvot and has commanded us <b>to remove leavened bread. Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava:</b> One should recite: <b>Concerning the removal of leavened bread.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>With regard to</b> the formula: <b>To remove, everyone agrees that</b> it <b>certainly refers to the future.</b> This formulation undoubtedly indicates that the person reciting the blessing is about to begin fulfilling the mitzva of removing leaven, and it is therefore an appropriate blessing.

Daf 7b

<b>Where they disagree is with regard to</b> the formula: <b>Concerning the elimination</b> of leaven. One <b>Sage,</b> Rav Pappi, <b>maintains</b> that <b>it is referring to</b> an act that was performed <b>previously.</b> Since this formula is referring to the removal of leaven as a task already completed, it would be more appropriate for a blessing recited after performance of that mitzva was completed. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rav Pappa, <b>maintains</b> that this expression <b>refers to the future.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav Pappi’s opinion from the formula of the blessing recited just prior to circumcision: <b>Blessed</b> are You…<b>Who has made us holy through His mitzvot and has commanded us concerning circumcision.</b> Apparently this expression indeed is referring to a future act.
The Gemara rejects this contention: That is no proof, as <b>what</b> alternative formula <b>can we recite there?</b> If <b>we say:</b> He, Who has made us holy through His mitzvot and commanded us <b>to circumcise, is there no alternative to he</b> himself, i.e., the boy’s father, <b>circumcising</b> his son? The father is commanded to circumcise his son, and he may appoint one who is not commanded to circumcise his son to act in his stead. Therefore, the more general formula of the blessing is recited: About the circumcision. The Gemara raises a difficulty: In a case where <b>the child’s father</b> himself circumcises his son, <b>what can be said?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Yes, it is indeed so.</b> If the father himself performs the circumcision he in fact recites the blessing: And has commanded us to circumcise.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav Pappi’s opinion. The blessing recited over ritual slaughter is: <b>Blessed</b>…<b>Who has made us holy through His mitzvot and has commanded us concerning slaughtering.</b> This blessing likewise indicates that this formula is appropriate prior to an action. The Gemara again rejects this claim: <b>There too, what</b> alternative formula <b>can we recite?</b> If <b>we say:</b> Who has commanded us <b>to slaughter, is there no alternative to his slaughtering</b> the animal? There is no mitzva to slaughter an animal. It is merely the necessary preparation before one may eat meat. Therefore, the more general formula of the blessing is recited: Concerning slaughtering.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If so, with regard to the slaughter of the <b>Paschal lamb and</b> other <b>consecrated</b> animals, <b>what can be said?</b> One is indeed commanded to slaughter these animals. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so.</b> When slaughtering the Paschal lamb or any other offering, one recites: Who has commanded us to slaughter.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav Pappi’s opinion from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who prepares a <i>lulav</i> for himself recites the blessing: Who has given us life, sustained us, and brought us to this time.</b> When <b>he takes it to fulfill with it</b> the obligation to take the <i>lulav</i>, <b>he says: Who has made us holy through His mitzvot and has commanded us concerning the taking of the <i>lulav</i>.</b> Although he has yet to perform the mitzva, he does not recite the formula: To take. The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there, as at the time when he lifts</b> the <i>lulav</i> before he recites the blessing, he already <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation by Torah law. Consequently, the formula: Concerning the taking, is indeed more appropriate for an action that he has already performed.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>If so,</b> the statement that he takes it <b>to fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with it</b> is imprecise, as the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> said that he took the <i>lulav</i> <b>with which</b> he already <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so;</b> the <i>tanna</i> should have formulated the <i>halakha</i> in that manner. <b>But due to</b> the fact <b>that he wants to teach the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: One who comes <b>to sit in the <i>sukka</i>, he likewise taught</b> in <b>the first clause: To fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with it.</b> This phrase maintains the consistency of the language of the <i>Tosefta</i>, even though it is imprecise with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of <i>lulav</i>.
<b>As it teaches in the latter clause</b> of this <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who erects a <i>sukka</i> for himself recites: Blessed are You, God, Who has given us life, sustained us, and brought us to this time.</b> When <b>he enters to sit in</b> the <i>sukka</i> <b>he says: Blessed</b>…<b>Who has made us holy through His mitzvot and has commanded us to sit in the <i>sukka</i>.</b> In summary, no conclusive proof has been found for either side of this debate. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that one should recite: <b>Concerning the removal of leaven,</b> as that expression is referring to the future as well.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>In any event,</b> it is clear from the previous discussion that <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>one is required to recite a blessing prior to</b> performing a mitzva. <b>From where do we</b> derive this principle? It is <b>as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>all the mitzvot, one recites a blessing over them prior to [<i>over</i>] their performance.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where may it be inferred that</b> the word <b><i>over</i> is the language of priority? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said that the verse said: “And Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain, and overran [<i>vaya’avor</i>] the Cushite”</b> (II Samuel 18:23), i.e., Ahimaaz overtook the Cushite. <b>Abaye said:</b> It is derived <b>from here: “And he passed [<i>avar</i>] before them”</b> (Genesis 33:3). <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the proof is <b>from here: “And their king passed [<i>vaya’avor</i>] before them and God at their head”</b> (Micah 2:13).
<b>In the school of Rav they say:</b> One recites a blessing prior to performing all mitzvot, <b>except for</b> the ritual <b>immersion</b> after a nocturnal emission <b>and</b> the blowing of the <b><i>shofar</i>.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Granted</b> one does not recite a blessing prior to <b>immersion, as</b> this <b>man</b> who has not yet immersed <b>is still unfit</b> to recite a blessing because he is ritually impure. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a <i>shofar</i>, what is the reason</b> that one does not recite a blessing before sounding the <i>shofar</i>? <b>And lest you say</b> the reason is <b>due to</b> a concern <b>lest the sounding</b> of the <i>shofar</i> emerge <b>flawed,</b> and the blessing will be in vain, <b>if so,</b> one should not recite a blessing <b>even</b> prior to ritual <b>slaughter and circumcision,</b> as in those cases too one might fail to perform the action in the requisite manner.
<b>Rather, Rav Ḥisda said: Except for</b> prior to <b>immersion alone was stated,</b> due to the aforementioned reason. The Gemara adds: <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to one who <b>immersed</b> for ritual purification after a nocturnal emission <b>and emerged, as he emerges he recites: Blessed</b>…<b>Who has made us holy through His mitzvot and commanded us concerning immersion.</b>
The mishna states that one searches for leaven <b>by the light of the lamp, etc.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> i.e., that the search should be conducted by the light of the lamp, derived? <b>Rav Ḥisda said: We derive</b> it by the hermeneutic principles of verbal analogy and juxtaposition: The term <b>finding</b> in one context is derived <b>from finding</b> in another context, <b>and finding</b> is derived <b>from</b> the word <b>searching, and</b> this <b>searching</b> is derived <b>from searching</b> elsewhere, <b>and searching</b> there is derived <b>from</b> the word <b>lamps, and lamps</b> is derived <b>from lamp.</b>
The Gemara cites the relevant verses included in the above derivation. <b>Finding</b> in one context is derived <b>from finding</b> in another context by verbal analogy, as <b>it is written here: “Seven days leaven shall not be found in your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:19), <b>and it is written there: “And he searched, starting with the eldest, and ending with the youngest; and</b> the goblet <b>was found</b> in Benjamin’s sack” (Genesis 44:12). <b>And</b> the word <b>finding</b> in this verse is connected <b>to searching in that same</b> verse by juxtaposition, as the verse says: “And he searched... and was found.”
<b>And searching</b> is derived <b>from lamps</b> by means of juxtaposition, <b>as it is written:</b> “And it shall come to pass that <b>at that time I will search Jerusalem with lamps”</b> (Zephaniah 1:12). <b>And</b> finally, the word <b>lamps</b> is derived <b>from lamp</b> by means of juxtaposition, <b>as it is written: “The spirit of man is the lamp of God, searching all the inward parts”</b> (Proverbs 20:27). Together these verses indicate that the search for leaven must be conducted by the light of the lamp.
Similarly, <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> On <b>the night of the fourteenth one searches for leavened bread by the light of the lamp. Although there is no</b> absolute <b>proof for</b> this <b>matter, there is an allusion to</b> this <b>matter, as it is stated: “Seven days leaven shall not be found</b> in your houses,” <b>and it says: “And he searched, starting with the eldest, and ending with the youngest;</b> and the goblet was found.” <b>And it says: “At that time I will search Jerusalem with lamps,” and it says: “The spirit of man is the lamp of God, searching</b> all the inward parts.”
With regard to this teaching, the Gemara asks a question: <b>What is</b> the reason for the last citation introduced by the final <b>And</b> the verse <b>says?</b> Why doesn’t the previous verse, “At that time I will search Jerusalem with lamps,” provide sufficient proof that the search must be conducted by the light of the lamp?
<b>And</b> the Gemara answers: The last verse is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>this</b> verse: <b>“At that time,</b> etc.” <b>is a leniency, as God is saying: I will not search Jerusalem by the light of a torch, whose light is great,</b> and through which I will expose every sin. <b>Rather,</b> I will search <b>by the light of</b> a small <b>lamp, whose light is smaller,</b> which will ensure <b>that great sins will be discovered and small sins will not be discovered.</b> To counter this argument, the <i>tanna</i> states: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, “The spirit of man is the lamp of God,</b> searching all the inward parts.” This verse indicates that everything will be found by the light of the lamp, which is the most effective manner of searching.
<b>The Sages taught: One does not search</b> for leaven, <b>neither by the light of the sun, nor by the light of the moon, nor by the light of a torch. Rather,</b> the search should be conducted <b>by the light of a lamp,</b>

Daf 8a

<b>because the light of a lamp is effective for searching. And even though there is no proof for</b> this <b>matter, there is an allusion to</b> this <b>matter, as it is stated: “Seven days leaven shall not be found in your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:19), <b>and it says: “And he searched, starting with the eldest,</b> and ending with the youngest; and the goblet was found in Benjamin’s sack…” (Genesis 44:12). <b>And it says: “At that time I will search Jerusalem with lamps”</b> (Zephaniah 1:12), <b>and it says: “The spirit of man is the lamp of God, searching all the inward parts”</b> (Proverbs 20:27).
The Gemara asks a question: <b>This light of the sun,</b> by which one may not conduct the search for leaven, <b>what are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If we say</b> it is referring to conducting a search <b>in the courtyard, didn’t Rava say</b> that <b>a courtyard does not require searching, due to the ravens</b> and other birds <b>that are found there,</b> and will certainly eat any leaven there? <b>Rather,</b> perhaps this ruling is referring <b>to a portico,</b> which is not frequented by ravens. However, this cannot be the correct interpretation either, as <b>didn’t Rava say</b> with regard to that case that <b>a portico may be searched by its</b> own <b>light,</b> i.e., one need not use a lamp at all when searching a portico, but one may search it by sunlight?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this statement with regard to sunlight <b>is necessary with regard to the skylight that is in a room.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to the area to <b>which</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring, <b>where</b> in the room is it located? <b>If</b> he is referring to the place <b>opposite the skylight,</b> the legal status of <b>that</b> area is like that of <b>a portico,</b> as its abundant sunlight is adequate to search for leaven. <b>Rather,</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring <b>to the sides</b> of the room. In those areas, one cannot rely on the sunlight from the skylight. He must search by the light of the lamp.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is the light of <b>a torch not</b> bright enough for searching? <b>But didn’t Rava say: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written, “And a brightness appears as the light; He has rays at His side; and there is the hiding of His power”</b> (Habakkuk 3:4), which indicates that God will provide rays of glory for the righteous in the future? The Sages explained this verse by means of a parable: <b>To what are the righteous comparable before the Divine Presence?</b> They are comparable <b>to a lamp in the face of a torch.</b> This statement indicates that the light of a torch is significantly greater than that of a lamp, and consequently a torch should be more effective in the search for leaven. <b>And</b> likewise <b>Rava said:</b> One who uses <b>a torch for</b> the blessing over fire in <b><i>havdala</i></b> has performed <b>the mitzva</b> in <b>the optimal manner.</b> Apparently, the light of a torch is greater than that of a lamp.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> does not prohibit the use of a torch due to its failure to provide sufficient light. Rather, it is due to the fact that one <b>can put this</b> lamp <b>into holes and crevices,</b> as it is a small flame, <b>and</b> one <b>cannot put that</b> torch <b>into holes and crevices,</b> as it is a large flame.<br><b>Rav Zevid said: This</b> lamp projects <b>its light before it,</b> facilitating the search, <b>and that</b> torch projects <b>its light behind it,</b> on the person conducting the search.<br><b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The reason is that when using <b>this</b> torch one <b>fears</b> starting a fire, <b>and</b> when using <b>that</b> lamp he does <b>not fear</b> starting a fire.<br><b>Ravina said: This</b> lamp consistently <b>draws light, and</b> the light of <b>that</b> torch <b>fluctuates.</b> Although overall the torch provides greater light than a lamp, it is less effective for use in a search.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Any place into which one does not</b> typically <b>take</b> leaven does not require searching. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does the inclusive phrase: <b>Any place,</b> come <b>to include?</b> The Gemara answers that it comes <b>to include that which the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The upper and lower holes</b> in the wall of a house that are difficult to use, as well as <b>a veranda roof, a closet roof, a cowshed,</b> chicken <b>coops, a storehouse for straw, a wine cellar, and a storeroom for oil;</b> all these <b>do not require</b> that a <b>search</b> be conducted. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A bed that divides</b> the area <b>inside a house and</b> space <b>separates</b> the bottom of the bed from the floor <b>requires a search,</b> as there might be leaven beneath it.
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> between this <i>baraita</i> and another: With regard to <b>a hole</b> in a wall <b>that is between</b> a house belonging to one <b>person</b> and a house belonging <b>to another, this</b> neighbor <b>searches to the point that his hand reaches, and that</b> neighbor <b>searches to the point that his hand reaches. And</b> as for leaven found in <b>the rest</b> of the hole, each one <b>renders it null and void in his heart. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A bed that divides</b> the area <b>inside a house, with wood and stones placed under it, and</b> space <b>separates</b> the bottom of the bed from the wood and stones beneath it, <b>does not require searching.</b>
This is <b>difficult</b> due to a contradiction between the ruling with regard to <b>a bed</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, where Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says that it requires a search, and the ruling with regard to <b>a bed</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, where he rules that no search is required. Furthermore, it is similarly <b>difficult</b> due to a contradiction between the ruling with regard to <b>holes</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, that a search is not required, and the ruling with regard to <b>holes</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, that a search is required.
The Gemara answers: The apparent contradiction between the first ruling with regard to <b>holes</b> and the second ruling with regard to <b>holes</b> is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which rules that one need not search them, is referring <b>to upper and lower</b> holes, which are difficult to use. <b>And that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which rules that one is required to search them, is referring <b>to intermediate</b> holes, whose use is convenient. The apparent contradiction between the first ruling with regard to <b>a bed</b> and the second ruling with regard to <b>a bed is</b> similarly <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which rules that one is required to search them, is referring <b>to a</b> bed that is <b>raised</b> off the floor, and <b>that</b> ruling, that one need not search them, is referring <b>to a</b> bed that is <b>low</b> and the space beneath it cannot be used, and presumably, there is no leaven there.
With regard to this <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara asks: <b>And do wine storages not require searching? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Wine storages require searching; oil storages do not require searching.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where one supplies</b> wine from the storage during the meal. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> then in the case of <b>oil</b> storages, if one supplies oil from the storage during the meal, he should be obligated to search there <b>as well.</b>
The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>oil, there is a fixed</b> quantity used <b>for eating</b> a meal. A person knows how much oil he will require before the meal begins, and he will therefore supply himself with any oil that he will need before the meal, and no leaven will enter the storage. However, with regard to <b>wine, there is no fixed</b> quantity used <b>for drinking,</b> as one does not know how much wine he will drink during the meal. Consequently, it is possible that he will descend to his wine cellar with bread in his hand to replenish his supply of wine.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches:</b> The Sages <b>rendered</b> the legal status of the <b>beer storages in Babylonia like</b> that of <b>wine storages in Eretz Yisrael,</b> with regard <b>to one who supplies</b> wine from the storage during the meal. Any storage from which one replenishes his supply during the meal requires searching for leaven.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: A fish storage does not require searching.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that a fish storage <b>requires searching?</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult; this</b> lenient ruling is referring <b>to large</b> fish, and <b>that</b> stringent ruling deals <b>with small</b> fish. Since one does not know exactly how many small fish he will require for the meal, he might need to replenish his supply during his meal.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said: A salt storage and a storage for candles require searching</b> for leaven, as one might have entered those storages during a meal. <b>Rav Pappa</b> likewise <b>said: A wood storage and a storage for dates require searching</b> for the same reason.
<b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: The Sages <b>do not require one to place his hand into holes and crevices to search</b> for leaven, <b>due to the danger</b> involved. The Gemara asks: Due to <b>what danger? If we say</b> it is <b>due to the danger of a scorpion</b> that might be in this hole, <b>when he made use of</b> the hole in the first place, <b>how did he make use</b> of it if there were scorpions there? If the hole is never used, there is no need to search it in any case. The Gemara answers: <b>No, it is necessary</b> to search this hole in a case <b>where</b> leaven <b>fell</b> into it unintentionally.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring to a case where leaven <b>fell</b> into the hole, again, <b>why do I</b> need to conduct a <b>search? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna with regard to <b>leaven upon which a rockslide fell, it is considered removed</b> from the owner’s possession? Here too, any leaven that fell into the hole should be considered removed. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> where the <i>tanna</i> said it is as though it were removed, he is referring to a case <b>where</b> the rockslide buries the leaven so that even <b>a dog cannot search for it. Here,</b> it is referring a hole that is not so deep, and therefore <b>a dog can search for it</b> and extract the leaven from the hole.
The Gemara questions the <i>halakha</i> in the <i>Tosefta</i> from a different angle. Why is there any concern about danger in this case? <b>But didn’t Rabbi Elazar say: Those on the path to perform a mitzva are not</b> susceptible to <b>harm</b> throughout the process of performing the mitzva? <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> Here we are concerned <b>lest he will</b> also <b>have lost a needle</b> in the same place, <b>and he will look for it</b> while he is searching for the leaven. Since he is not merely searching for leaven, the merit of the mitzva will not protect him.
The Gemara asks: <b>And in a case like that,</b> where there is personal interest intermingled with the performance of a mitzva, is <b>it not</b> nevertheless considered <b>a mitzva? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>one who says:</b> I am contributing <b>this <i>sela</i> to charity so that my son will live, or</b> if he says: I am performing the mitzva so that <b>I will be one</b> destined for <b>the World-to-Come,</b>

Daf 8b

<b>this</b> person <b>is a full-fledged righteous person</b> as far as that mitzva is concerned? These ulterior motives, e.g., seeking a reward, do not detract from the value of the mitzva. The Gemara answers: There is still concern <b>lest he look for</b> the needle <b>after he searched</b> for leaven and completed the search. There is danger that since he already completed the mitzva, its merit will not protect him when he is searching for the needle.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The danger referred to by the <i>Tosefta</i> is the <b>danger</b> posed <b>by gentiles.</b> And this ruling <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of the <i>tanna</i> <b>Pelimu. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a hole</b> in a wall located <b>between</b> the residences of <b>a Jew and a gentile, one searches</b> in the hole <b>as far as his hand reaches, and the rest he renders null and void in his heart. Pelimu said:</b> One does <b>not search the entire</b> hole at all, <b>due to the danger</b> involved.
The Gemara asks: Due to <b>what danger? If we say</b> it is due to <b>the danger of sorcery,</b> i.e., the gentile will suspect the Jew of casting spells on him and will come to hate him and threaten him, if so, <b>when he made use of</b> the hole in the first place, <b>how did he make use</b> of it without arousing the enmity of his gentile neighbor? If the hole is never used there is no need to search it in any case. The Gemara answers: <b>There, when he made use of</b> the hole, it was during the <b>day and</b> there was <b>light, and</b> the gentile would <b>not raise</b> the suspicion that the Jew was casting spells <b>in his mind. Here,</b> it is during the <b>night and</b> the search <b>is</b> performed with <b>a lamp, and</b> the gentile would <b>raise</b> the suspicion that the Jew was casting spells <b>in his mind.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Elazar say</b> that <b>those on the path to perform a mitzva are not</b> susceptible to <b>harm</b> throughout the process of performing the mitzva? The Gemara responds: In a place <b>where danger is commonplace it is different,</b> as one should not rely on a miracle, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to God’s command to Samuel to anoint David as king in place of Saul: <b>“And Samuel said: How will I go, and Saul will hear and kill me; and God said: Take in your hand a calf</b> and say: I have come to offer a sacrifice to God” (I Samuel 16:2). Even when God Himself issued the command, there is concern with regard to commonplace dangers.
<b>They raised a dilemma before Rav:</b> With regard to <b>those members of the school of Rav who live in the fields [<i>baga</i>]</b> far away from the city, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether they may <b>come early</b> before dawn <b>and</b> in the evening after <b>dark to Rav’s school,</b> or should they be concerned about robbers? <b>He said to them: Let them come,</b> and responsibility for their safety is <b>upon me and my neck.</b> They asked him: <b>What is</b> your opinion about <b>returning</b> home? <b>He said to them: I do not know</b> if it is possible to rely on the protection of the mitzva when returning home.
On a related note, <b>it was stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said: Those on the path to perform a mitzva are not</b> susceptible to <b>harm; neither when they go nor when they return.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did he say this?
The Gemara answers: It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Isi ben Yehuda says: With regard to</b> that <b>which the Torah said: “And no man shall covet your land,</b> when you go up to appear before God your Lord three times in the year” (Exodus 34:24), this <b>teaches that your cow shall graze in the meadow and no beast will harm it,</b> and <b>your rooster shall peck in the garbage</b> dump <b>and no marten</b> [<b><i>ḥulda</i></b>] <b>shall harm it.</b> In other words, your property will be protected while everyone ascends to Jerusalem for the Festival, despite the fact that the farm will not be defended.
<b>And are</b> these <b>matters not</b> inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i>? And if those</b> animals <b>that typically are harmed</b> by other animals <b>are not harmed,</b> due to the protection provided by the mitzva, <b>people who typically are not harmed,</b> as they are capable of protecting themselves, <b>all the more so,</b> will not be harmed due to the protection provided by the mitzva of ascending to Jerusalem for the Festival. <b>I have only</b> derived that one is protected <b>when going</b> to Jerusalem; <b>from where</b> is it derived that one is protected even <b>when returning</b> from the Temple? <b>The verse states:</b> “You shall roast and eat the Paschal lamb in the place which God your Lord shall choose; <b>and you shall turn in the morning and go to your tents”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:7). This <b>teaches that you shall go and</b> upon your return <b>find your tent in peace,</b> unharmed.
The Gemara asks: <b>And once</b> we derived <b>that</b> the merit of a mitzva protects a person <b>even when returning, why do I</b> need a source to teach that he is protected <b>when</b> he <b>goes?</b> This teaching could also be derived by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference. The Gemara answers: Actually, the first verse is interpreted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ami, as Rabbi Ami said: Any person who has land</b> in his possession is obligated to <b>ascend</b> to the Temple <b>for the</b> three pilgrim <b>Festivals. And</b> one <b>who does not have land</b> in his possession <b>is not</b> obligated to <b>ascend for the Festivals,</b> as the verse states: Your land, in the context of the obligation to ascend to Jerusalem for the three Pilgrim Festivals.
Apropos the ascent to Jerusalem for a Festival and the performance of a mitzva with ulterior motives, the Gemara cites that which <b>Rabbi Avin bar Rav Adda said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Due to what</b> reason <b>are there no fruits of Ginnosar,</b> which were of the highest quality, growing <b>in Jerusalem?</b> Why is Jerusalem not graced with this produce? The reason is <b>so that</b> the <b>pilgrims would not say: If we had ascended only to eat the fruit of Ginnosar, it would have been sufficient for us.</b> The <b>ascent</b> to Jerusalem would <b>then be</b> performed <b>not for its own sake.</b>
<b>On a similar</b> note, <b>Rabbi Dostai, son of Rabbi Yannai, said: Due to what</b> reason <b>are the hot springs of Tiberias not</b> located <b>in Jerusalem?</b> It is <b>so that</b> the <b>pilgrims would not say: If we had only ascended to bathe in the hot springs of Tiberias, it would have been sufficient for us.</b> The <b>ascent</b> to Jerusalem would <b>then be</b> performed <b>not for its own sake.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And with regard to what</b> did the Sages of previous generations <b>say</b> that one must search <b>two rows</b> of wine barrels in a cellar, <b>etc.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>A cellar, who mentioned</b> anything about that? What led the <i>tanna</i> to begin a discussion of a wine cellar?
The Gemara answers that <b>this is</b> what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: Any place into which one does not take leaven does not require searching, and wine storages and oil storages also do not require searching. And with regard to what</b> did the Sages <b>say</b> that one must search <b>two rows in a cellar?</b> This statement is referring to <b>a place into which one brings leavened bread, and where one supplies</b> wine from the storage during the meal.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Beit Shammai say</b> that one must search the first <b>two rows</b> across the entire cellar. <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> The <b>two rows that they stated</b> are two full rows in the front, <b>from the ground up to the ceiling. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> These two rows are <b>one row</b> at a right angle, <b>like the shape of</b> the letter <b><i>gamma</i> [gam],</b> i.e., the entire length and height of the front row and the entire top row of the barrels along the length and width of the cellar.
The Gemara comments: One <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda,</b> and one <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> One <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda: Beit Shammai say</b> that one must search <b>two rows across the entire front of the cellar, and the two rows that were stated</b> are <b>from the ground up to the ceiling.</b> One <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> One must search <b>two rows across the entire cellar,</b> i.e., the <b>outer</b> row that <b>faces the door, and</b> the <b>upper row</b> that <b>faces the ceiling.</b> The rows <b>inward</b> from the outermost one <b>and</b> the rows <b>lower than</b> the uppermost one <b>do not require searching.</b>
We further learned in the mishna that <b>Beit Hillel say:</b> It is sufficient to search <b>the two external rows, which are the upper ones.</b> There is an amoraic dispute with regard to this statement. <b>Rav said</b> it is referring to the <b>uppermost</b> row of barrels <b>and</b> the row <b>that is beneath it. And Shmuel said</b> it means <b>the uppermost</b> front row <b>and the</b> next one <b>that is inward</b> into the cellar. <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>Rav? He infers</b> from the term: <b>Outer</b> rows, that Beit Hillel mean that both rows face outward. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But doesn’t</b> the mishna also <b>teach: Upper</b> rows, indicating that both rows are adjacent to the ceiling? The Gemara answers: This term comes <b>to exclude the lowest of the lower</b> rows. One must search only the top two rows.
<b>And Shmuel said</b> the mishna is referring to <b>the uppermost</b> front row <b>and the</b> next one <b>that is inward</b> into the cellar. <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>Shmuel? He infers</b> from the term: <b>Upper</b> rows, that one must search the first two rows on the top level of barrels. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But doesn’t</b> the mishna also <b>teach: Outer</b> row? The Gemara answers that this word comes <b>to exclude the innermost of the inner</b> rows. One must search only the two outermost rows. The Gemara comments: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, and all</b> the other <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> who recite the <i>mishnayot</i> and <i>baraitot</i> by heart, <b>teach in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel.</b>

Daf 9a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> After conducting the search, <b>one</b> need <b>not</b> be <b>concerned that perhaps a marten dragged</b> leaven <b>from house to house, or from place to place,</b> placing leaven in a house that was already searched. <b>As if so,</b> one need also be concerned that perhaps leaven might have been dragged <b>from courtyard to courtyard and from city to city.</b> In that case, <b>there is no end to the matter,</b> and it would be impossible to rely on any search for leaven.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers from the mishna: <b>The reason</b> that one need not search again <b>is that we did not see</b> the marten <b>drag</b> the leaven from the house; <b>however, if we saw</b> the marten <b>drag</b> leaven from the house, <b>we</b> are indeed <b>concerned</b> that it dragged the leaven into the second house, and it therefore <b>requires searching</b> for leaven.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But why</b> is this so? <b>Let us say</b> that the marten <b>ate</b> the bread it took. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>The residences of gentiles are ritually impure,</b> as their wives may have miscarried, and due to the fact that gentiles would bury their stillborn babies in their houses, all their residences are deemed ritually impure due to the possibility of impurity imparted by a corpse. <b>And how long</b> must a gentile have <b>stayed in a residence</b> for <b>the residence to require searching?</b> He must have lived there for <b>forty days.</b> The reason is that until forty days after conception the miscarried fetus is not classified as a stillborn, as it is not sufficiently developed before that stage.
This mishna continues: <b>And</b> this decree applies <b>even though</b> the gentile resident <b>has no wife.</b> In issuing the decree, the Sages did not distinguish between a married couple and a single man, so that people would not err in its application (<i>Me’iri</i>). <b>And any place where a marten or a pig can enter</b> unimpeded <b>need not be searched,</b> as presumably if a stillborn was buried there, one of these animals would have taken it. As this mishna indicates that there is a presumption that martens eat whatever they find, the Gemara suggests that the same should apply to leaven. Therefore, even if one actually saw the marten take the bread, he can assume that the animal ate it, obviating the need for an additional search.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> as in <b>this</b> case, where no search is required, it is referring <b>to flesh,</b> whereas in <b>that</b> case, where one is required to search again, it is referring <b>to bread.</b> Rabbi Zeira elaborates: <b>With regard to flesh,</b> a marten <b>does not leave</b> remnants behind, and therefore the stillborn would have been entirely consumed. <b>With regard to bread,</b> however, the marten <b>leaves</b> remnants behind, requiring an additional search.
<b>Rava said: What is this</b> comparison? These cases are not comparable. <b>Granted, there,</b> with regard to the stillborn, one could <b>say</b> that it <b>was</b> in the house <b>and</b> one could <b>say</b> that it <b>was not</b> in the house. <b>And</b> even <b>if you say</b> it <b>was</b> there, <b>say</b> that the marten <b>ate it.</b> The very presence of the stillborn in the house is based on an assumption, and even if it was there, it was probably consumed. <b>However, here, where one definitely saw</b> the marten <b>take</b> the bread, <b>who will say that</b> the marten <b>ate it? It is</b> a conflict between <b>an uncertainty</b> whether or not the marten ate the bread, <b>and a certainty</b> that the bread was there. The principle is that <b>an uncertainty does not override a certainty.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty against this principle: <b>And</b> is it so that <b>an uncertainty does not override a certainty? But wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a <i>ḥaver</i> who died and left a storehouse filled with produce, even</b> if the produce was there only <b>that day,</b> the fruit has the <b>presumptive status</b> of produce that was ritually <b>prepared,</b> i.e., properly tithed. The assumption is that the owner tithed it himself or commanded others to do so. <b>However, here, this produce</b> was <b>certainly untithed</b> at the outset, <b>and</b> there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether <b>they</b> are <b>tithed or whether they are not tithed.</b> Despite this conflict, <b>the uncertainty</b> whether they were tithed <b>comes and overrides the certainty</b> that they were untithed produce.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>There,</b> the conflict <b>is</b> between <b>certainty and certainty, as</b> the produce is <b>certainly tithed, in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina Ḥoza’a. As Rabbi Ḥanina Ḥoza’a said:</b> There is <b>a presumption with regard to a <i>ḥaver</i> that he does not</b> allow produce <b>that is not</b> ritually <b>prepared,</b> to <b>leave his possession.</b> It is therefore certain that the produce is tithed.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that in that case the conflict <b>is</b> between <b>uncertainty and uncertainty,</b> as <b>perhaps one could say</b> that the produce was <b>never initially untithed.</b> It is possible that there was never an obligation to tithe this produce, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Oshaya.</b>
<b>As Rabbi Oshaya said: A person may employ artifice</b> to circumvent obligations incumbent upon him in dealing <b>with his grain, and bring it into</b> the courtyard <b>in its chaff so that his animal may eat</b> from it. <b>And</b> this grain <b>is exempt</b> from <b>tithes.</b> Although the obligation to tithe produce that has been fully processed applies even to animal fodder, it is permitted to feed one’s animal untithed produce that has not been fully processed. In light of this <i>halakha</i> it is possible that the fruit of the <i>ḥaver</i> in the storehouse may not have been subject to the obligation to be tithed. Consequently, the aforementioned case involving produce is a conflict between two uncertain factors, as it is uncertain whether or not the owner was obligated to tithe the produce in the first place, and even if he was required to do so, it is uncertain whether or not the <i>ḥaver</i> tithed it.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty against Rava: <b>And</b> is it so that <b>an uncertainty does not override a certainty? But wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving the maidservant of a certain violent person in</b> the city of <b>Rimon, who threw a stillborn</b> baby <b>into a pit,</b>

Daf 9b

<b>and a priest came and glanced at</b> the baby <b>to ascertain whether it is male</b> or <b>whether it is female,</b> as a woman who has just given birth, even to a stillborn, is ritually impure for different lengths of time, depending on whether she gave birth to a male or a female (see Leviticus 12). <b>And</b> the <b>incident came before the Sages,</b> to rule whether or not the priest contracted ritual impurity when standing over the corpse, <b>and they deemed him ritually pure.</b> The basis for this ruling was <b>due to</b> the fact that as <b>a marten and a polecat [<i>bardelas</i>] are found there,</b> it is likely that the baby was dragged away before the priest arrived at the pit.
<b>And</b> yet <b>here, where it is certain that she threw</b> the stillborn baby into the pit, <b>and it is uncertain</b> whether a marten or polecat <b>dragged it</b> away <b>and it is uncertain</b> whether <b>it did not drag it</b> away <b>at that time,</b> the Sages nevertheless ruled that <b>an uncertainty comes and overrides a certainty.</b> The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Do not say</b> in the <i>baraita</i> <b>that she</b> certainly <b>threw a stillborn into a pit; rather, say that she threw</b> an object <b>similar to a stillborn into a pit.</b> Perhaps it was not a stillborn baby; it might have simply been congealed blood, which does not transmit impurity. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>this is</b> a conflict between <b>uncertainty and uncertainty.</b> It is unclear whether there was anything in the pit that could have rendered the priest ritually impure, and even if there was, it might have already been dragged away.
The Gemara retorts: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>To ascertain whether it is male</b> or <b>whether it is female,</b> indicating that the only uncertainty was with regard to gender; it was certainly a stillborn baby. The Gemara rejects this proof, as <b>this is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> The priest sought <b>to ascertain whether she miscarried</b> mere <b>wind,</b> i.e., an amorphous mass, or <b>if she miscarried a stillborn</b> baby. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>she miscarried a stillborn,</b> he sought <b>to ascertain whether it is male</b> or <b>whether it is female.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>There it is</b> not a conflict between certainty and uncertainty; rather it is between <b>certainty and certainty. Since a marten and a polecat are found there, they certainly dragged it</b> away <b>at that time,</b> without delay. <b>Although</b> martens <b>leave</b> part of their food, <b>in any case they certainly dragged</b> the baby to their holes <b>at that time. Another version</b> of this answer: <b>Although we do not say that they certainly ate</b> the stillborn, <b>we do say that they certainly dragged it to their holes.</b> Consequently, the ruling in this case does not contradict the general principle that an uncertainty does not override a certainty.
The Gemara proceeds to analyze a more fundamental aspect of the mishna: <b>And do we say</b> that <b>one</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps a marten dragged</b> the leaven? <b>But isn’t it taught in the last clause,</b> in the next mishna: With regard to the leaven <b>that</b> one <b>leaves</b> after the search, he should <b>place it in</b> a <b>concealed</b> location, so <b>that</b> it <b>will not require searching after it?</b> Apparently, there is concern lest a marten take some of the remaining leaven.
<b>Abaye said:</b> This is <b>not difficult; this</b> ruling is referring <b>to the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, whereas <b>that</b> ruling is referring <b>to the thirteenth.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>On the thirteenth</b> of Nisan, <b>when bread is</b> still <b>found in every house,</b> the marten <b>does not conceal</b> the leaven, and therefore there is no concern that perhaps the marten dragged the leaven elsewhere and concealed it. However, <b>on the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, <b>when bread is not found in any</b> of the <b>houses,</b> the marten <b>hides</b> the leaven.
<b>Rava said</b> in surprise: <b>And is the marten a prophetess that knows that now</b> is <b>the fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>and no</b> one will <b>bake until the evening, and it leaves</b> over bread <b>and conceals</b> it in its hole? <b>Rather, Rava</b> rejected Abaye’s answer and <b>said:</b> With regard to the leaven <b>that</b> one <b>leaves</b> after the search, he should <b>place it in</b> a <b>concealed</b> location, <b>lest a marten take it before us and</b> it <b>will require searching after it.</b> Only if one actually sees the marten take the leaven, is he required to search after it.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava: One who wishes to eat leavened bread after</b> his <b>search, what should he do?</b> With regard to the leaven <b>that</b> one <b>leaves</b> after the search, he should <b>place it in</b> a <b>concealed</b> location, <b>so that a marten will not come and take it before us, and he will need to search</b> the house <b>after it.</b>
<b>Rav Mari said</b> that there is a different resolution of the apparent contradiction between the <i>baraitot</i>: One conceals the leaven that he found, due to <b>a decree lest he place ten</b> pieces of bread <b>and find</b> only <b>nine.</b> Since the tenth piece is missing, he will be obligated to conduct an additional search.
Apropos the issue of leaven taken by a rodent, the Gemara analyzes a series of similar cases. In a case where there were <b>nine piles of <i>matza</i> and one pile of leavened bread, and</b> one saw <b>a mouse come and take</b> a morsel from a pile, <b>and we do not know if it took <i>matza</i></b> or <b>if it took leavened bread, this is</b> akin to the case of <b>nine stores</b> in the mishna cited below. If a portion became <b>separated</b> from one of the piles and we did not know if it was <i>matza</i> or leaven, <b>and</b> one saw <b>a mouse come and take it, that is</b> akin to the case mentioned in <b>the latter clause</b> of that mishna.
The Gemara elaborates. <b>As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>nine stores</b> in a city, <b>all of which sell</b> kosher <b>meat</b> from <b>a slaughtered</b> animal, <b>and one</b> other store that <b>sells meat</b> from unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses, and</b> a person <b>took</b> meat <b>from one of them and he does not know from which one he took</b> the meat, in this case of <b>uncertainty,</b> the meat <b>is prohibited.</b> This ruling is based on the principle: The legal status of an item fixed in its place is that of an uncertainty that is equally balanced. In this case, when it comes to determining whether or not this meat comes from a kosher store, the two types of stores are regarded as though they were equal in number.
This <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And in</b> the case of meat <b>found</b> outside, <b>follow the majority.</b> If most stores in the city sell kosher meat one can assume that the meat he found is kosher, based on the principle: Any item separated, i.e., not fixed in its place, is presumed to have been separated from the majority. By the same token, if most stores in that city sell non-kosher meat, the meat found is presumed to be non-kosher. These two principles can be applied to the cases involving piles of <i>matza</i> and leaven: If the morsel was separated from the piles when taken by the mouse, follow the majority. However, if the mouse took the morsel from one of the piles, the legal status of the morsel is that of an equally balanced uncertainty concerning whether it was taken from a pile of <i>matza</i> or a pile of leaven, and the owner is required to conduct an additional search.
The Gemara discusses another case: There are <b>two piles, one of <i>matza</i> and one of leavened bread, and before them</b> there are <b>two houses, one</b> which was <b>searched and one</b> which was <b>not searched, and two mice came,</b> and in our presence <b>one took <i>matza</i> and one took leavened bread.</b> Each mouse went into a different house, <b>and we do not know which</b> mouse <b>entered this</b> house <b>and which</b> mouse <b>entered that</b> house. It is unclear whether or not the mouse that took the leaven entered the house that was searched. <b>This</b> situation <b>is</b> akin to the case of <b>two baskets.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: There are <b>two baskets, one</b> filled with <b>non-sacred</b> produce <b>and</b> the other <b>one</b> filled with <b><i>teruma</i>, and before them</b> are <b>two</b> vessels each containing a <b><i>se’a</i></b> of produce, <b>one</b> filled with <b>non-sacred</b> produce <b>and</b> the other <b>one</b> filled with <b><i>teruma</i>. And these,</b> the contents of each of the baskets, <b>fell into those,</b> each of the <i>se’a</i> vessels. It is possible that the <i>teruma</i> fell into the non-sacred produce, and it is prohibited for non-priests to eat a mixture of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce. Nevertheless, the contents of the <i>se’a</i> vessel containing the non-sacred produce <b>is permitted, as I say</b> that <b>the non-sacred produce fell into the non-sacred produce and the <i>teruma</i> fell into the <i>teruma</i>.</b> Likewise, with regard to leaven, presumably the mouse took the leaven into the house that had not been searched, and there is no need to conduct an additional search of the house that was already searched.
The Gemara rejects this comparison: <b>Say that we state</b> and apply the principle: <b>As I say,</b> and assume that everything occurred in a way that preserves the produce in its permitted state

Daf 10a

only with regard <b>to <i>teruma</i></b> that in modern times is sacred <b>by rabbinic law,</b> as the Torah obligation to separate <i>teruma</i> was abrogated after the destruction of the First Temple. However, with regard <b>to leavened bread,</b> which is prohibited <b>by Torah law, do we say</b> that this principle applies? The Gemara responds: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>the search for leavened bread</b> is required <b>by Torah law? It is</b> a <b>rabbinic</b> ordinance, <b>as by Torah law, mere nullification is sufficient.</b> Since the issue at hand is not the Torah prohibition of leaven but the rabbinic ordinance to search one’s house, this <i>halakha</i> is comparable to the case of baskets of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce.
