The Gemara presents another situation: In a case where there is <b>one pile of leavened bread and before it</b> there are <b>two houses</b> that were <b>searched, and a mouse came and took</b> a morsel from the pile, <b>and we do not know if it entered this</b> house <b>or if it entered that</b> house, <b>this is</b> akin to the case of <b>two paths, as we learned</b> in a mishna: There were <b>two paths, one</b> of which was <b>ritually impure</b> due to a corpse buried there, <b>and one</b> of which was <b>ritually pure. And</b> someone <b>walked on one of them,</b> but he does not remember which, <b>and</b> afterward <b>he engaged in</b> handling items of <b>ritual purity,</b> e.g., <i>teruma</i> or consecrated items; <b>and another</b> person <b>came and walked on the second</b> path, and he too does not remember which path it was, <b>and he</b> also <b>engaged in</b> handling items of <b>ritual purity.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If this</b> one <b>asked</b> a Sage <b>by himself, and that</b> one <b>asked</b> a Sage <b>by himself, they are</b> both <b>pure.</b> When considered separately, each person retains his presumptive status of ritual purity. However, if they <b>both</b> came to ask <b>at the same time, they are</b> both <b>ritually impure.</b> Since one of the two certainly passed on the impure path, even though it is uncertain which, both are deemed impure due to that uncertainty. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: One way or another they are</b> both <b>ritually impure.</b>
<b>Rava said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> who said: If they came <b>at the same time, everyone agrees</b> that <b>they are ritually impure,</b> as even Rabbi Yehuda concedes that this is the <i>halakha</i>. If they came independently, <b>one after the other, everyone agrees</b> that <b>they are ritually pure. They disagree only with regard to</b> a case where one <b>comes to ask about himself and about the other. Rabbi Yosei likens this</b> case <b>to</b> one where they come to ask <b>at the same time, and Rabbi Yehuda likens it to</b> a case where they come <b>one after the other.</b>
The Gemara addresses another case: If one saw a mouse take leaven and there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether the mouse <b>entered</b> a house that was already searched and <b>uncertainty</b> whether the mouse <b>did not enter</b> that house, <b>that is</b> akin to the <i>halakha</i> of ritual impurity in <b>a valley, and</b> is subject <b>to the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna with regard to <b>one who enters a valley during the rainy season,</b> when seeds are sprouting, people do not have permission to wander in the field of another, as they might harm the plants. For the purpose of this <i>halakha</i> a valley in the rainy season is considered a private domain, and there is a general principle that in the case of uncertainty concerning whether or not one contracted ritual impurity in a private domain he is ritually impure. <b>And if</b> there was <b>ritual impurity in a certain field, and one</b> person <b>said: I walked in that place,</b> in the valley, <b>and I do not know whether I entered that field or whether I did not enter, Rabbi Eliezer deems him pure, and the Rabbis deem him impure.</b>
Rabbi Eliezer deems him pure, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer would say:</b> Concerning <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>entry,</b> i.e., whether or not he entered the place, he is <b>ritually pure;</b> however, if one certainly entered the place and the <b>uncertainty</b> is with regard to <b>contact</b> with <b>ritual impurity,</b> he is <b>ritually impure.</b> According to this opinion, the principle with regard to uncertain impurity in the private domain applies only in a case where the uncertainty is with regard to contact. The Rabbis, however, do not distinguish between these situations, as they maintain he is impure regardless of whether the uncertainty is with regard to entry or with regard to contact. This dispute applies to the case of whether or not one is required to conduct an additional search for leaven in a case where there is uncertainty whether or not leaven was taken into the house.
The Gemara discusses another case: If one saw a mouse <b>enter</b> a house with leaven in its mouth <b>and</b> someone <b>searched and did not find</b> any leaven there, this is akin to <b>the dispute between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis. As we learned</b> in a mishna, <b>Rabbi Meir would say: Any object that has</b> the <b>presumptive status of ritual impurity,</b> i.e., it is certain that an impure object was buried in a particular place, that place <b>forever</b> remains <b>in its ritual impurity,</b> even if it was excavated and the source of impurity was not found, <b>until it becomes known to you where the ritual impurity is.</b> The assumption is that the impurity was not found because the search was not conducted properly.
<b>And the Rabbis say</b> in this case: He continues <b>searching until he reaches bedrock or virgin soil,</b> under which there is certainly no ritual impurity. If he searched that extensively and failed to discover any impurity, it is apparently no longer there. This dispute applies to the aforementioned case involving leaven.
The Gemara analyzes yet another case: If one saw a mouse <b>enter</b> a house with leaven in its mouth <b>and</b> one <b>searched and found</b> a morsel of leaven there, but there is uncertainty whether or not the morsel that he found is the morsel that the mouse took into the house, this would be akin to <b>the dispute between Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a field in which a grave was lost,</b> i.e., there is certainly a grave located in the field but its precise location is unknown, <b>one who enters</b> the field <b>is ritually impure,</b> as he might have stepped on the grave. <b>If a grave was</b> later <b>found</b> and marked <b>in</b> the field, <b>one who enters</b> and walks on the other parts of the field <b>is ritually pure, as I say:</b> The <b>grave that was</b> previously <b>lost is</b> the <b>grave that was</b> subsequently <b>found.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: The entire field must be searched,</b> as perhaps the grave discovered is not the one that was lost. This dispute applies to the above case of leaven.
The Gemara discusses another situation: If a person <b>placed nine</b> morsels of leaven <b>and found ten,</b> indicating that mice had added at least one morsel, this is akin to <b>the dispute between Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and the Rabbis. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a person who <b>placed a <i>maneh</i>,</b> one hundred dinars, of second tithe, <b>and found two hundred</b> dinars: Since it is evident that someone came and placed at least one extra <i>maneh</i> there whose status is unclear, the pile is presumed to contain <b>non-sacred</b> money <b>and second-tithe</b> money <b>intermingled with each other.</b> The assumption is that the additional money is non-sacred, and it is impossible to determine which is the non-sacred money and which is the second-tithe money. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> It is <b>all non-sacred</b> money. Since someone else was clearly involved, it is possible that he took the <i>maneh</i> and left behind two hundred other dinars. Consequently, it is impossible to identify any of this money as the original <i>maneh</i>. This same reasoning can be applied to the case of leaven. Since there were undoubtedly mice present, it is possible that the mice took the morsels, moved them, and replaced them with other morsels. As a result, the entire house must be searched again.
The Gemara raises the reverse situation. If one <b>placed ten</b> morsels <b>and found nine, this is</b> comparable to the case mentioned in <b>the latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i>, <b>as it was taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>left two hundred</b> dinars of second-tithe money <b>and found a <i>maneh</i>,</b> presumably, one <b><i>maneh</i></b> from the initial two hundred remains <b>placed, and</b> the other <b><i>maneh</i></b> is <b>taken</b> and missing. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>And the Rabbis say,</b> in keeping with their aforementioned opinion: It is <b>all non-sacred</b> money, as the assumption is that whoever took part of the money actually took it all, and this is a different <i>maneh</i>. Since it is different money, it is presumably non-sacred money, not second-tithe money. This dispute applies to the case where one finds fewer morsels of leaven than he left.

Daf 10b

The Gemara addresses yet another case: If one <b>placed</b> leaven <b>in this corner and found</b> it <b>in another corner,</b> this is akin to <b>the dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Rabbis, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>an axe that was lost in a house, the house is impure, as I say</b> that <b>a ritually impure person entered</b> the house <b>and took</b> the axe, touching other items in the process. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: The house is ritually pure, as I say</b> that <b>he lent</b> the axe <b>to another</b> person <b>and forgot, or that he took it from this corner and placed it in the other corner and forgot.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>A corner, who mentioned anything about it?</b> The <i>baraita</i> was referring to an axe that was lost, not one that was in a different corner.
The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete, and is teaching the following:</b> With regard to <b>an axe that was lost in a house, the house is ritually impure, as I say</b> that <b>an impure person entered</b> the house <b>and took</b> the axe, <b>or, if</b> the owner <b>placed it in this corner and</b> later <b>found it in another corner, the house is</b> likewise <b>ritually impure, as I say</b> that <b>an impure person entered</b> the house <b>and took</b> the axe <b>from this corner and placed in another corner. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: The house is ritually pure, as I say</b> that <b>he lent it to another</b> person <b>and forgot, or that he took it from this corner and placed it in that corner and forgot</b> about it. When the <i>baraita</i> is interpreted in this manner, the dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Rabbis applies to the question about leaven.
<b>Rava said:</b> If one saw <b>a mouse enter</b> a house with a <b>loaf</b> of bread <b>in its mouth, and he entered after</b> the mouse <b>and found crumbs,</b> the house <b>requires</b> additional <b>searching, due to</b> the fact that <b>a mouse does not typically generate crumbs.</b> Therefore, it cannot be assumed that these crumbs are from the loaf snatched by the mouse. <b>And Rava</b> also <b>said:</b> If one saw <b>a child enter with a loaf in his hand, and he entered after</b> the child <b>and found crumbs,</b> the house <b>does not require</b> additional <b>searching, because a child typically generates crumbs,</b> and one can therefore assume that the crumbs are from that loaf.
Although the rulings in these cases were clear to Rava, <b>Rava raised a dilemma</b> with regard to a related case: If one saw <b>a mouse enter with a loaf in its mouth, and</b> he saw <b>a mouse leave with a loaf in its mouth, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara elaborates: <b>Do we say</b> that <b>this</b> mouse <b>that entered is that</b> same mouse <b>that left</b> and there is no more leaven left in the house? <b>Or perhaps it is a different</b> mouse.
The Gemara adds: <b>If you say</b> that <b>this</b> mouse <b>that entered was this</b> one <b>that left,</b> another dilemma arises: If one saw <b>a white mouse enter with a loaf</b> of bread <b>in its mouth and a black mouse leave with a loaf</b> of bread <b>in its mouth, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do I say <b>this is certainly a different</b> mouse, <b>or perhaps</b> the black mouse <b>took</b> the loaf <b>from</b> the white mouse?
The Gemara continues to suggest variations on this case: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>mice do not take from each other,</b> as one mouse is generally not significantly stronger than another, if one saw <b>a mouse enter with a loaf</b> of bread <b>in its mouth and a marten leave with a loaf</b> of bread <b>in its mouth, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do I say that <b>the marten certainly took it</b> from the mouse, as it is larger and stronger? <b>Or perhaps it is a different</b> loaf, <b>for if it is so, that</b> the marten <b>took</b> the loaf <b>from the mouse, the mouse</b> itself <b>would</b> also <b>be found in its mouth,</b> as the marten would presumably take not only the loaf of bread but the mouse as well.
<b>And if you say</b> that we accept the contention that <b>if it is so, that</b> if the marten <b>took it from the mouse the mouse</b> itself <b>would be in its mouth,</b> in regard to a case where one saw <b>a mouse enter with a loaf</b> of bread <b>in its mouth and a marten leave with</b> both <b>a loaf</b> of bread <b>and a mouse in its mouth, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do I say that <b>this is certainly the same</b> mouse and loaf, <b>or perhaps</b> even this conclusion can be disputed: <b>If it is so, that this is the same</b> mouse, the <b>loaf would have been found in the mouse’s mouth</b> rather than in the marten’s mouth. Consequently, this must be a different loaf of bread. <b>Or perhaps</b> the loaf of bread <b>fell</b> from the mouse’s mouth <b>due to</b> its <b>fear</b> and the marten <b>took it</b> separately. No satisfactory answer was found for these dilemmas and the Gemara concludes: <b>Let</b> them <b>stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rava raised a dilemma:</b> If there was <b>a loaf</b> of bread <b>on a high beam</b> in the ceiling, does one <b>need</b> to climb <b>a ladder</b> to <b>take it down or</b> is this effort <b>not necessary? Do we say: The Sages did not</b> obligate one to <b>exert</b> himself that much in his search for leaven, and <b>since</b> the loaf of bread <b>will not fall on its own he will not come to eat it? Or perhaps</b> it can be claimed that <b>sometimes</b> the loaf may <b>fall and he will come to eat it,</b> as objects placed high up occasionally drop.
<b>And if you say</b> with regard to a loaf of bread on a beam, <b>sometimes</b> it will <b>fall and he will come to eat it,</b> in a case where the <b>loaf was in a pit,</b> does one <b>need</b> to use <b>a ladder to bring it up, or</b> is this effort <b>not necessary?</b> The Gemara explains the two sides of the dilemma: <b>Here</b> the loaf <b>will certainly not come up on its own,</b> and one can therefore let it remain where it is; <b>or perhaps</b> there is still a concern that <b>sometimes he</b> might <b>go down</b> into the pit <b>to perform</b> some <b>requirement of his, and he will come to eat it.</b>
The Gemara continues to discuss the various permutations of this case. And <b>if you say</b> that <b>sometimes one goes down</b> into the pit <b>for</b> some <b>requirement of his, and he will come to eat it,</b> with regard to <b>a loaf</b> that was <b>in the mouth of a snake,</b> is it <b>necessary</b> for him to bring <b>a snake charmer to take</b> the loaf <b>out</b> of the snake’s mouth, <b>or</b> is this effort <b>not necessary?</b>
Once again the Gemara explains the two sides of the dilemma: Do I say that <b>with regard to his</b> own <b>body the Sages</b> obligate one to <b>exert</b> himself and search everywhere, but <b>with regard to his money the Sages do not</b> obligate one to <b>exert</b> himself, i.e., he is not required to spend money in order to destroy leaven? <b>Or perhaps,</b> the legal status of his money is <b>no different</b> than that of his body, as one must remove leaven wherever he finds it, in any way he can? This series of dilemmas is also left answered and the Gemara concludes: <b>Let</b> them <b>stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One searches</b> for leaven <b>on the evening of the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, <b>and on the fourteenth</b> in <b>the morning, and at the time of</b> the <b>removal</b> of leaven. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> that is not the case; however, if <b>one did not search on the evening of the fourteenth he</b> should <b>search on the fourteenth</b> during the day.
If <b>he did not search on the fourteenth, he should search during the festival</b> of Passover. If <b>he did not search during the Festival, he should search after the Festival,</b> as any leaven that remained in his possession during the Festival is classified as leaven owned by a Jew during Passover, which one is obligated to remove. <b>And</b> the principle is: With regard to the leaven <b>that</b> one <b>leaves</b> after the search, he should <b>place it in</b> a <b>concealed</b> location where it will most likely be left untouched, <b>so that it will not require searching after it</b> if it goes missing.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason for</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> that one must conduct a search three times? The Gemara answers: It is <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna who both say:</b> The requirement to conduct three searches <b>corresponds to</b> the <b>three</b> times that <b>the removal</b> of leaven <b>is</b> mentioned <b>in the Torah.</b> One verse says: “<i>Matzot</i> shall be eaten for seven days, and <b>no leavened bread shall be seen with you, neither shall there be leaven seen with you,</b> in all your borders” (Exodus 13:7), and another verse states: <b>“Seven days shall there be no leaven found in your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:19), while a third verse says: “Seven days shall you eat <i>matzot</i>, <b>yet on the first day you shall remove leaven from your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:15).
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> to this explanation, seeking to prove that even according to Rabbi Yehuda one need not conduct three searches for leaven. He explained that Rabbi Yehuda lists the three times when one may conduct a search for leaven. It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Anyone who did not search at these three times</b> may <b>no longer search. Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yehuda does not hold that one must conduct three searches. Rather, in regard to whether or not one may conduct a search for leaven if he failed to conduct a search at one of those three opportunities, it is <b>from this</b> point <b>forward that they disagree.</b> The Rabbis hold that one may conduct the search even after the time of the removal of leaven, and Rabbi Yehuda disagrees.
<b>Mar Zutra taught</b> Rav Yosef’s statement in <b>this</b> manner: <b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> from that which <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Anyone who did not search at one of these three times</b> may <b>no longer search.</b> In Mar Zutra’s version, Rabbi Yehuda explicitly states: One of these three times, which reinforces the claim that he obligates one to conduct only one search. The Gemara similarly concludes: <b>Apparently,</b> it is with regard to whether or not <b>one</b> may <b>no longer search that they disagree.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara concludes that <b>Rabbi Yehuda also said: If one did not search</b> for leaven bread at the first opportunity, he may do so at the second or third opportunities; however, he may not search for leaven after these three times have passed.
<b>And here,</b> in the mishna, it is <b>about this that they disagree:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>maintains</b> that <b>before the prohibition</b> against eating leaven takes effect, <b>yes,</b> one may conduct a search; <b>after the prohibition</b> against eating leaven takes effect, <b>no,</b> one may no longer conduct a search, due to a rabbinic <b>decree lest one come to eat from</b> the leaven while searching for it. <b>And the Rabbis maintain: We do not issue a decree</b> lest one come to eat from the leaven, and he may therefore conduct a search even after the prohibition against eating leaven has taken effect.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And does Rabbi Yehuda issue a decree lest one come to eat</b> from the leaven in whose removal he is engaged? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>Once the <i>omer</i></b> offering <b>was sacrificed,</b> people would <b>go out and find the markets of Jerusalem filled with flour and toasted grain,</b> all from the new crop. This grain was undoubtedly harvested and processed when the Torah prohibition against eating from the new crop was still in effect.

Daf 11a

However, with regard to those people who harvest the crop before the <i>omer</i> is sacrificed, <b>they act contrary to the will of the Sages.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> The concern is that while working with the grain they might come to eat from it, despite the fact that it is still prohibited. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: They act in accordance with the will of the Sages. And</b> in that case, <b>Rabbi Yehuda did not issue a decree lest one eat from it.</b> Why, then, does he issue a decree with regard to leaven? <b>Rava said</b> that the prohibition of <b>new</b> grain <b>is different: Since</b> before the <i>omer</i> <b>you permitted one</b> to harvest the crop <b>only by picking</b> it by hand and may not harvest it in the typical manner, <b>he will remember</b> the prohibition and refrain from eating it. That is not the case with regard to leaven.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> This works out <b>well</b> in explaining Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion with regard <b>to the time</b> when one is <b>picking</b> the grain; however, with regard to the time of <b>grinding and sifting, what can be said?</b> Apparently, it is permitted to perform these acts in a typical manner. Why, then, is there no concern lest one eat the grain at that stage? The Gemara responds: <b>This is not difficult,</b> as one also performs <b>grinding</b> in an atypical manner. One must grind the grain before the sacrificing of the <i>omer</i> <b>with a hand mill,</b> not with a mill powered by an animal or by water. Likewise, <b>sifting</b> is performed atypically, not in the interior of the sifter. Instead, it is performed <b>on top of</b> the <b>sifter.</b> Since all of these actions are performed in an atypical manner, there is no concern lest he come to eat the grain.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>However,</b> with regard to that <b>which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>harvest</b> grain from <b>a field that requires irrigation and</b> from fields <b>in the valleys,</b> as their grain ripens long before the <i>omer</i> is sacrificed, <b>but one</b> may <b>not pile</b> the produce, and the Gemara adds: <b>And we established</b> that this mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda; what can be said?</b> The use of the term: One may harvest, in this mishna indicates that the grain was harvested in a typical manner, not by hand.
<b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> This difference between the cases of the <i>omer</i> and leaven is not based on the manner in which one harvests, grinds, or sifts. Instead, the reason for the different rulings is that <b>from new</b> grain, one <b>distances himself,</b> as it is prohibited to eat the new grain all year until the <i>omer</i> is offered. But <b>from leavened bread</b> one <b>does not distance himself,</b> as it is permitted during the rest of the year. Therefore, he is more likely to unwittingly eat leaven.
<b>Rava said:</b> Is the contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and the other statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda difficult,</b> while the contradiction between one statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> and the other statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> is <b>not difficult?</b> There is also an apparent contradiction between the opinion of the Rabbis, i.e., Rabbi Meir, who rule that the Sages issued a decree with regard to new grain but did not issue a decree with regard to leaven.
Rava explains as follows: The contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and the other statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> is <b>not difficult, as we resolved</b> it above. The contradiction between one ruling <b>of the Rabbis</b> and the other ruling <b>of the Rabbis</b> is <b>also not difficult:</b> The Rabbis maintain that there is no need to issue a decree prohibiting searching for leaven after leaven is prohibited, as, with regard to one who <b>himself is seeking out</b> leaven <b>to burn it,</b> will <b>he eat from</b> that leaven? However, in the case of new grain, he is processing the grain, preparing it for consumption. Therefore, the concern is that he will come to eat it unwittingly.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and the other statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as the difficulty can be resolved in an alternative manner, <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna that the markets of Jerusalem were filled with <b>flour and toasted grain.</b> It is permitted to prepare only these foods before the <i>omer</i>, as they will not be eaten without further preparation. Therefore, there is no concern lest one eat it unwittingly before the <i>omer</i> offering is sacrificed.
The Gemara rejects this interpretation: <b>That</b> statement <b>of Rav Ashi is a mistake,</b> as this suggestion can easily be refuted. <b>That</b> works out <b>well</b> with regard to the status of the grain <b>from</b> the point that the grain was processed into flour or <b>toasted grain and forward,</b> as there is no concern lest one come to eat it. However, with regard to its status <b>initially until</b> it became <b>toasted grain, what can be said?</b> There must have been a certain point when the grain kernels were edible before they were transformed into toasted grain. Why is there no concern that one might come to eat the grain at this earlier stage?
<b>And lest you say</b> that the grain is distinguished <b>by</b> the atypical manner in which it is <b>harvested, in accordance with</b> the earlier statement of <b>Rava, but</b> with regard to the difficulty raised to Rava’s opinion that <b>one may harvest a field that requires irrigation and</b> a field <b>that is in the valleys</b> in the typical manner <b>and we established</b> that statement <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, what can be said? Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects this explanation and concludes that <b>Rav Ashi’s</b> statement <b>is a mistake.</b>
The above conclusion was that Rabbi Yehuda distinguishes between prohibitions involving substances from which people regularly separate themselves and prohibitions involving substances from which people are not used to keeping their distance. The Gemara asks: <b>And anywhere that</b> one <b>does not distance</b> himself from a prohibition, <b>does Rabbi Yehuda issue a decree</b> that one must keep away from a prohibited item to avoid accidentally using it?
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A person may not pierce</b> a hole <b>in an eggshell, and fill it with oil, and place it beside a lamp so that</b> the egg <b>will drip</b> additional oil into the lamp and thereby extend the time that it burns? <b>And</b> this is the ruling <b>even</b> if <b>it is</b> not an actual egg but <b>an earthenware</b> tube, from which most people consider it unsuitable to drink. The concern is lest one forget and take the tube and use the oil for some other purpose, and violate the prohibition against extinguishing a flame on Shabbat.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> using a tube in that manner, as he is not concerned lest one remove it. Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda does not issue a decree even with regard to an item from which people do not distance themselves, e.g., oil. The Gemara answers: <b>There, due to the stringency of Shabbat, one distances</b> himself, as on Shabbat one is careful to distance himself from a candle or anything placed alongside it.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raised a contradiction</b> between this <i>halakha</i> <b>of Shabbat</b> and another <i>halakha</i> of <b>Shabbat, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the rope of a bucket that was severed</b> on Shabbat, where one needs the rope to draw water from a well, <b>he may not tie it</b> with a regular knot, as by Torah law it is prohibited to tie a permanent knot. <b>Rather,</b> he may <b>tie it</b> into <b>a bow.</b> However, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One</b> may <b>wrap a money belt [<i>punda</i>] around it or a sash [<i>pesikya</i>], provided that he does not tie it</b> into <b>a bow,</b> lest he tie a proper knot.
This presents <b>a difficulty,</b> as there is a contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who permits placing a tube of oil beside the lamp, and the other statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who prohibits tying a bow to reattach the severed rope of a bucket. There is likewise <b>a difficulty</b> between one statement <b>of the Rabbis,</b> who prohibit placing a tube of oil beside the lamp, and the other ruling <b>of the Rabbis,</b> where they permit tying a bow to reattach the severed rope of a bucket.
The Gemara answers: The apparent contradiction between one statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> and the other statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as one usage of <b>oil</b> might <b>be confused with</b> another usage of <b>oil.</b> Given that it is permitted to use oil for other purposes, one is apt to utilize this oil as well. However, tying <b>a bow will not be confused with</b> the dissimilar tying of <b>a knot.</b> Consequently, the Rabbis do not issue a decree in that case.
The Gemara continues: Likewise, the contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and the other statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>the reason for</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> is <b>not because he issues a decree</b> to prohibit tying <b>a bow due to</b> the prohibition against tying <b>a knot. Rather,</b> the reason is more fundamental, <b>because Rabbi Yehuda maintains</b> that <b>a bow itself is</b> a full-fledged <b>knot.</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, tying a bow is included in the prohibition against tying a knot on Shabbat.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raised a contradiction between</b> one statement of <b>the Rabbis</b> and another statement <b>of the Rabbis, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One may tie a bucket with a sash,</b> to draw water from a well, <b>but</b> one may <b>not</b> do so <b>with a rope, and Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> the use of a rope. Before addressing the aforementioned contradiction, the Gemara asks: The mishna is referring to <b>a rope of what</b> kind? <b>If you say</b> it is referring to <b>a standard rope,</b> does <b>Rabbi Yehuda permit</b> tying a knot in this rope? <b>It is a permanent knot, as</b> in tying the rope to the bucket <b>he certainly comes to negate</b> any other use of the rope. He performs a primary category of prohibited labor by tying a permanent knot.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the mishna is speaking about a rope used in the work <b>of a weaver [<i>gardi</i>].</b> The legal status of this rope differs from that of an ordinary rope, as the weaver will certainly not leave his rope attached to a bucket and thereby negate any other use. Consequently, this knot is a temporary one.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> did <b>the Rabbis issue a decree</b> prohibiting the rope <b>of a weaver due to a standard rope</b> but they did not issue a decree prohibiting a bow due to a knot? The Gemara explains: <b>Yes,</b> the Rabbis indeed issued a decree prohibiting the rope of a weaver, as one <b>rope may be interchanged with</b> another <b>rope,</b> leading one to mistakenly tie a knot with a different rope. However, <b>a bow is not interchanged with a knot.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And anywhere that</b> one <b>distances himself</b> from the prohibition, does <b>Rabbi Yehuda not issue a decree? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: What should one do if he has an unblemished <b>firstborn</b> kosher <b>animal</b> whose <b>blood</b> circulation is <b>constricted,</b> and it can be healed only through bloodletting? This situation is problematic, as an unblemished firstborn animal is consecrated, and wounding it is prohibited. <b>Even if it dies</b> due to this condition, <b>one</b> may <b>not let its blood</b> at all; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: One</b> may <b>let</b> the animal’s blood, <b>provided that he does not inflict a blemish on</b> the firstborn animal. In this case Rabbi Yehuda issues a decree with regard to a firstborn animal, despite the fact that its use is generally prohibited and people distance themselves from consecrated items. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of a firstborn animal, <b>since a person is agitated</b> and anxious

Daf 11b

<b>about his property,</b> as the priest who is watching the firstborn wants to slaughter it before it dies, as if it dies, eating it would be prohibited. Therefore, <b>we say: If you permit him</b> to let blood <b>in a place that does not cause a blemish in</b> the animal, <b>he will come to do</b> so <b>in a place that causes a blemish in it,</b> to save his animal.
<b>And the Rabbis</b> respond that if that is the case, <b>all the more so</b> should it be permitted to let blood in a manner that will not cause a blemish, <b>for if you do not permit him</b> to take any steps to save the animal <b>at all, he will come to act</b> in a prohibited manner and cause a blemish. If there is a legitimate alternative, he will not cause a blemish in the firstborn.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>And do we say</b> that <b>according to Rabbi Yehuda a person is agitated about his property? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One</b> may <b>not scrape an animal on a Festival</b> with a fine-tooth comb, <b>because</b> in doing so <b>he inflicts a wound,</b> which is prohibited on Festivals? <b>However, one</b> may <b>scratch</b> an animal with a wide-tooth comb, as this does not inflict a wound. <b>And the Rabbis say: One</b> may <b>neither scrape nor even scratch,</b> for if one were permitted to scratch an animal he might come to scrape it as well.
<b>And it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>What is scraping and what is scratching? Scraping</b> is performed with a comb with <b>small</b> teeth <b>and</b> with which <b>one inflicts a wound. Scratching</b> is performed with a comb that has <b>large</b> teeth <b>and</b> with which <b>one does not inflict a wound.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda does not issue a decree to prohibit scratching lest one come to scrape, even though he is agitated over his property.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>There,</b> with regard to a firstborn, it is different, <b>for if he leaves it</b> and does nothing the animal <b>will die,</b> and therefore <b>we say</b> that <b>a person is agitated over his property.</b> In his agitated state he will overlook the details of permitted and prohibited actions and violate a prohibition. <b>Here,</b> however, <b>if he leaves</b> his animal and does not comb it, <b>it will merely</b> suffer <b>pain</b> from the stinging insects. In that case <b>we do not say</b> that <b>a person is agitated about his property.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yehuda, what is different with regard to leavened bread that he issued a decree</b> lest a person come to eat the prohibited food, <b>and what is different with regard to scraping that he did not issue</b> a comparable <b>decree?</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda maintains that unleavened <b>bread</b> might be <b>interchanged with</b> leavened <b>bread,</b> whereas <b>scraping</b> would <b>not be interchanged with scratching.</b> Since one uses a completely different utensil in the performance of the prohibited action, interchanging the two actions is unlikely.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The <i>tanna’im</i> disagree regarding until what time leaven may be eaten and at what time it must be removed on Passover eve. <b>Rabbi Meir says: One</b> may <b>eat</b> leaven <b>the entire fifth</b> hour of the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>and one</b> must <b>burn</b> it immediately afterward <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One</b> may <b>eat the entire fourth</b> hour <b>and</b> one <b>places it in abeyance</b> for <b>the entire fifth</b> hour, <b>and one burns</b> it <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour.
<b>And furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said: Two disqualified loaves of a thanks-offering are placed on the bench</b> in the colonnade in the Temple as an indicator. There was a specially designated place for these loaves in the Temple. <b>As long as</b> the loaves <b>are placed</b> there, <b>the entire nation</b> continues to <b>eat</b> leaven. When <b>one</b> of the loaves <b>was taken</b> away, the people know that the time had come <b>to place</b> the leaven <b>in abeyance,</b> meaning that they <b>neither eat nor burn</b> their leaven. When <b>they were both taken</b> away, <b>the entire nation began burning</b> their leaven.
<b>Rabban Gamliel says</b> that the times are divided differently: <b>Non-sacred</b> foods <b>are eaten the entire fourth</b> hour, <b>and <i>teruma</i></b> may be eaten during <b>the entire fifth</b> hour. Since it is a mitzva to eat <i>teruma</i> and burning it is prohibited, additional time was allocated for its consumption. <b>And one burns</b> all leaven including <i>teruma</i> <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara seeks to draw a comparison between this dispute of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda and a dispute between them on a different topic. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there:</b> If <b>one</b> witness <b>says</b> that an incident occurred <b>on the second</b> day <b>of the month and one</b> other witness <b>says</b> that it happened on <b>the third</b> day of that month, <b>their testimony is valid.</b> This minor contradiction does not invalidate the testimony.
The mishna explains: The reason is <b>that this</b> witness <b>knows about the addition</b> of an extra day <b>to</b> the previous <b>month.</b> Since he knows that the court added a day to the previous month, which lasted thirty days, he testifies that the incident occurred on the second day of the month. <b>And that</b> witness <b>does not know about the addition</b> of an extra day <b>to</b> the previous <b>month,</b> and he therefore thinks that the incident in question occurred on the third of the month.
If <b>one says</b> that the incident occurred on <b>the third</b> day of the month <b>and one says</b> it happened <b>on the fifth, their testimony is void,</b> as there is no way to rationalize this contradiction. Similarly, if <b>one says</b> the incident occurred <b>at two hours</b> of the day <b>and one says</b> it happened <b>at three hours, their testimony is valid,</b> as that discrepancy could be the result of the lack of precision. However, if <b>one says</b> it occurred <b>at three</b> hours <b>and one says</b> it took place <b>at five</b> hours, <b>their testimony is void.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> In the last case, <b>their testimony is valid,</b> as it could be that one is slightly mistaken. However, if <b>one says</b> it happened <b>at five</b> hours <b>and one says at seven</b> hours, everyone agrees that <b>their testimony is void.</b> That is a clear contradiction that cannot be rationalized as a miscalculation, <b>as at five</b> hours of the day <b>the sun</b> is <b>in the east, and at seven</b> hours <b>the sun</b> is already <b>in the west.</b> It is impossible to confuse the fifth hour with the seventh.
<b>Abaye said: When</b> analyzing the matter, <b>you will find</b> that you can <b>say</b> that <b>according to the statement of Rabbi Meir a person does not err at all,</b> as Rabbi Meir assumes that people know the exact time of day. <b>According to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda a person errs</b> up to <b>half an hour.</b> Abaye elaborates: <b>According to the statement of Rabbi Meir, a person does not err at all,</b> and the reason that in the case where one says two hours and one says three the testimony is valid is that <b>the incident</b> actually <b>occurred as the second</b> hour <b>ended and the third</b> hour <b>began. And</b> when <b>this</b> witness <b>said</b> it happened in <b>the second</b> hour he was referring to <b>the end of the second</b> hour. When <b>that</b> witness <b>said the third</b> hour he was referring to <b>the beginning of the third</b> hour. It is possible that both witnesses spoke the truth.
Abaye continues his explanation: <b>According to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, a person errs</b> by <b>half an hour,</b> as <b>when</b> the <b>incident occurred, it occurred at the midpoint of the fourth</b> hour, at three and a half hours of the day. <b>And this</b> witness, <b>who says three</b> hours, means <b>the end of the third hour, and</b> he <b>errs</b> by saying that it occurred <b>half an hour before</b> the incident actually occurred. <b>And that</b> witness, <b>who says five</b> hours, means <b>the beginning of the fifth</b> hour, i.e., the end of the fourth hour, <b>and he errs</b> by saying that it occurred <b>half an hour after</b> the incident actually occurred. Since it is possible that their testimonies do not conflict, their testimony is valid.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of this statement. <b>Abaye said: When</b> analyzing the matter, <b>you will find</b> that you can <b>say</b> that <b>according to Rabbi Meir a person errs a bit,</b> and <b>according to Rabbi Yehuda a person errs</b> by <b>an hour and a bit.</b> Abaye elaborates: <b>According to Rabbi Meir, a person errs a bit,</b> as <b>when</b> the <b>incident occurred, it occurred either at the end of the second</b> hour <b>or at the beginning of the third</b> hour, <b>and one of</b> the two witnesses <b>errs a bit. According to Rabbi Yehuda, a person errs</b> by <b>an hour and a bit,</b> as <b>when</b> the <b>incident occurred, it occurred either at the end of the third</b> hour <b>or at the beginning of the fifth</b> hour,

Daf 12a

<b>and one of them errs</b> by <b>an hour and a bit.</b>
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda, went and said the <i>halakha</i></b> of Abaye <b>before Rava.</b> Rava <b>said</b> to him that Abaye’s explanation must be rejected: <b>And were we</b> to <b>closely examine</b> the statements <b>of these witnesses</b> and ask them when precisely the incident occurred, and find <b>that the one who says at three</b> hours means that it occurred <b>at the beginning of the third</b> hour, <b>and the one who says at five</b> hours means that it occurred <b>at the end of the fifth</b> hour, it would <b>be contradictory testimony and we would not kill</b> the accused on the basis of this testimony; <b>and will we arise and kill</b> based <b>on uncertainty?</b> Although their testimony could be valid, it could also be void. Can the court execute the accused based on that uncertainty? <b>And</b> consider that <b>the Merciful One says</b> in the Torah: <b>“And the congregation shall judge…and the congregation shall deliver”</b> (Numbers 35:24–25), from which it is derived that judges must do everything in their power to save an accused from the death penalty.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> In fact, <b>according to the statement of Rabbi Meir, a person errs</b> by <b>two hours less a bit; according to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, a person errs</b> by <b>three hours less a bit.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>According to the statement of Rabbi Meir, a person errs</b> by <b>two hours less a bit.</b> How so? <b>When</b> the <b>incident occurred,</b> it was <b>either at the beginning of the second</b> hour <b>or at the end of the third</b> hour <b>and one of</b> the witnesses <b>erred by two hours less a bit,</b> as that is a reasonable discrepancy.
<b>According to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, a person errs</b> by <b>three hours less a bit.</b> How so? <b>When</b> the <b>incident occurred,</b> it was <b>either in the beginning of the third</b> hour <b>or at the end of the fifth</b> hour, <b>and one of them errs</b> by <b>three hours less a bit.</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, that is a reasonable discrepancy.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna: The judges of the court <b>would examine</b> witnesses <b>with seven</b> forms of <b>interrogation: In which seven-year</b> Sabbatical cycle of the Jubilee did the incident occur, <b>in which year</b> of the seven-year Sabbatical cycle, <b>in which month</b> of that year, <b>on which</b> date <b>of that month, on which day</b> of the week, <b>at which hour</b> of the day, <b>at which place</b> did the incident occur? <b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between interrogations and examinations?</b> With regard to each of the forms of <b>interrogation,</b> if <b>one of</b> the witnesses <b>said: I do not know, their testimony is void.</b> However, with regard to <b>examinations, even if</b> they <b>both say: We do not know, their testimony is valid.</b>
The Gemara continues. <b>And we discussed</b> this <i>baraita</i>: In <b>what</b> way are <b>interrogations different and</b> in <b>what</b> way are <b>examinations different?</b> Why is the testimony of a person who cannot answer one of the interrogations void, but his testimony is valid if he cannot answer one of the examinations?
<b>And we said</b> in response: With regard to <b>interrogations,</b> if <b>one of them says: I do not know, their testimony is void, as</b> this <b>is testimony that you cannot render as false, conspiring</b> testimony. Witnesses are determined to be false, conspiring witnesses when other witnesses arrive in court and testify that the first pair of witnesses could not possibly have witnessed the incident in question, as they were at a different place at that time together with them. If a witness says he does not know when the incident occurred or where it occurred, it would be impossible to testify that he was elsewhere and render him a false, conspiring witness. The Torah disqualifies the testimony of a witness who cannot be rendered a false, conspiring witness.
However, with regard to <b>examinations,</b> even if the witness cannot remember every detail, <b>it</b> remains <b>testimony that you can render as false, conspiring</b> testimony. Even without that detail, the second pair of witnesses can still testify that the first pair of witnesses was with them in a different place at that time.
Based on the above, the Gemara returns to discuss the matter of discrepancies in the testimony of the witnesses with regard to the hour that the incident occurred. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>a person errs</b> by <b>that much,</b> e.g., several hours, with regard to the <b>interrogations of what time</b> of day the incident occurred, this <b>is also testimony that you cannot render as false, conspiring</b> testimony, <b>for</b> if other witnesses claim that they were elsewhere at that time, the witnesses can <b>say: We are mistaken,</b> and the incident did not actually occur at that time, but a few hours earlier or later. Consequently, it is impossible to prove that they are false, conspiring witnesses.
The Gemara explains <b>that we give</b> leeway to the first pair of witnesses for <b>the entire</b> duration of the potential margin of <b>their error.</b> In order to render them false, conspiring witnesses, the second pair of witnesses must testify that the first witnesses were with them for the entire period during which their testimony would be accepted, despite the discrepancy with regard to the hour in which it occurred. <b>According to Rabbi Meir, we give</b> the witnesses who testified that the incident occurred at two or three hours of the day, <b>from the beginning of the first hour until the end of the fifth</b> hour. If they testified that the incident occurred in the second hour or the third hour, the court must take into account a mistake of two hours in either direction.
<b>And by right we should give them even more</b> leeway <b>at the beginning.</b> Since one errs by two hours less a bit, if the witnesses testified that the incident occurred at approximately two hours of the day, they might have erred by roughly two hours and the incident actually occurred before sunrise. <b>However,</b> since <b>between day and night people do not err,</b> and as the witnesses testify that the incident occurred during the second or third hour of the day, it could not have occurred before sunrise.
<b>And according to Rabbi Yehuda, we give</b> the witnesses a margin of error <b>from the beginning of the first hour until the end of the sixth</b> hour. <b>And by right we should give them even more</b> leeway <b>at the beginning,</b> as according to his opinion one errs by three hours less a bit, and therefore the margin for error should be greater.

Daf 12b

<b>However, between day and night people do not err,</b> and therefore there is no concern that they might have erred in this regard. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>by right we should give them even more</b> leeway <b>at the end</b> of the period. <b>However,</b> this too is not a reasonable discrepancy, <b>as at five</b> hours of the day <b>the sun</b> is <b>in the east and at seven</b> hours <b>the sun</b> is <b>in the west.</b> No one confuses the morning with the afternoon.
In light of the above conclusions, the Gemara returns to address the issue of leaven. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Meir says: One</b> may <b>eat</b> leaven <b>the entire fifth</b> hour of the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>and one</b> must <b>burn</b> it immediately afterward <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One</b> may <b>eat the entire fourth</b> hour, <b>and</b> one <b>places it in abeyance</b> for <b>the entire fifth</b> hour, <b>and one burns</b> it <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>According to Abaye’s</b> explanation <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir, that he said a person does not err</b> about the time <b>at all, let him eat</b> leaven for <b>the entire sixth</b> hour, as by Torah law it is permitted to eat until the end of the sixth hour, i.e., midday. The Sages issued a decree prohibiting the consumption of leaven from the beginning of the sixth hour, lest one unwittingly come to eat after midday. However, according to Rabbi Meir, people do not err in this regard at all and that concern is unfounded. <b>And according to that version</b> of Rabbi Meir’s opinion, <b>that</b> he <b>said a person errs a bit, let</b> him <b>eat</b> leaven <b>until</b> just before <b>the end of the sixth</b> hour.
<b>And</b> according to <b>Abaye’s</b> explanation <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, that he said: A person errs</b> by <b>half an hour; let</b> him <b>eat</b> leaven <b>until the midpoint of the sixth</b> hour. <b>And even according to the version</b> of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, <b>that</b> he <b>said: A person errs</b> by <b>an hour plus a bit; let him eat</b> leaven <b>until</b> just before <b>the end of the fifth</b> hour. From the fact that this is not the ruling of these Sages, apparently Abaye’s assessment of the amount of time that a person errs is incorrect.
<b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> There is a difference between the issues of testimony and leaven, as <b>testimony is entrusted to the vigilant.</b> One comes to testify only if he thoroughly scrutinized the subject of his testimony. Therefore, he will not err significantly with regard to the time in question. However, the prohibition against eating <b>leavened bread is</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>entrusted to all,</b> and not everyone is able to correctly determine the time. Consequently, Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda both extend the margin for error, so that people will not unwittingly eat leaven after the time that it is prohibited to do so.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rava’s</b> explanation <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir, that he said: A person errs</b> by <b>two hours less a bit; from the beginning of the fifth</b> hour <b>let one no</b> longer <b>eat</b> leaven. After all, one could confuse the fifth hour with the seventh hour, when it is prohibited to eat leaven by Torah law. The Gemara answers: Since at <b>five</b> hours <b>the sun</b> is <b>in the east and</b> at <b>seven</b> hours <b>the sun</b> is <b>in the west,</b> no one confuses morning with afternoon.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, during the sixth</b> hour <b>let him eat</b> leaven <b>as well,</b> as one distinguishes between the sixth hour and the seventh hour since the sun tends westward only during the seventh hour. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> In the <b>sixth</b> hour, <b>the day,</b> i.e., the sun, <b>stands at the meridian,</b> equidistant between east and west, and it is unclear toward which direction it tends. Therefore, confusion between the sixth and seventh hours is possible.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rava’s</b> explanation <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, that he said: A person errs</b> by <b>three hours less a bit; from the beginning of the fourth</b> hour <b>let one no</b> longer <b>eat</b> leaven. The Gemara answers: If, since at <b>five</b> hours <b>the sun</b> is <b>in the east and at seven</b> hours <b>the sun</b> is <b>in the west,</b> one does not confuse the morning with the evening, <b>and all the more so</b> one will not confuse seven hours of the day with <b>four</b> hours of the day, when the sun is further east. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> i.e., there is no concern lest one confuse morning and afternoon, <b>during the fifth</b> hour <b>let him eat</b> leaven <b>as well.</b>
<b>Abaye interpreted it in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava: Testimony is entrusted to the vigilant,</b> and therefore a witness is less likely to err, whereas the prohibition against eating <b>leavened bread is entrusted to all.</b> Since a common person is more likely to err, the Sages were more stringent with regard to leaven than with regard to testimony.
<b>And Rava said: That is not the reason</b> for the added hour in the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as he is not concerned lest people err. <b>Rather, Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he said: The removal of leaven</b> can be performed <b>only</b> by <b>burning</b> it, <b>and</b> therefore by prohibiting the consumption of leaven, <b>the Sages provided him</b> with <b>one hour during which to gather wood</b> to burn the leaven.
<b>Ravina raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava</b> from a <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: When</b> is it that the elimination of leaven can be performed only by burning it? It is only when one removes the leaven <b>not at the time</b> designated <b>for its removal.</b> Then, one should seek out the preferred method of removal and implement it in the ideal manner. <b>However,</b> when one removes the leaven <b>at the time</b> designated <b>for its removal,</b> at the end of the sixth hour when he must remove the leaven immediately, <b>the removal of</b> leaven may be performed <b>in any manner,</b> and one need not seek wood for burning. Why, then, was it necessary for the Sages to provide him with an hour to gather wood?
<b>Rather, Rava</b> reconsidered the previous explanation and <b>said: It is a</b> rabbinic <b>decree due to a cloudy day,</b> when one is unable to observe the precise position of the sun, increasing the likelihood of confusion. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> then <b>even at fourth</b> hour <b>let one no</b> longer <b>eat</b> leaven, as according to Rabbi Yehuda a person errs by three hours less a bit. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The <b>fourth</b> hour <b>is mealtime for everyone,</b> and therefore everyone is aware of that hour and will not confuse it with another.
In light of Rav Pappa’s statement, the Gemara discusses the topic of mealtimes. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Eating in <b>the first hour</b> of the morning is the time of <b>eating for <i>Ludim</i>,</b> who are members of a nation of cannibals, and they are ravenous and in a hurry to eat. <b>The second</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for robbers [<i>listin</i>].</b> Since they spend the night stealing, they eat early in the morning. <b>The third</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for heirs,</b> i.e., people who inherited a lot of money and do not work for their sustenance. Their only preoccupation in the early hours of the morning is eating. <b>The fourth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for workers. The fifth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for Torah scholars. The sixth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for all people.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: But <b>didn’t Rav Pappa say</b> that the <b>fourth</b> hour <b>is</b> the <b>time of eating for all? Rather, reverse</b> the fourth, fifth, and sixth hours: The <b>fourth</b> hour is <b>mealtime for all people,</b> the <b>fifth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for workers,</b> and <b>the sixth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for Torah scholars.</b>
One who eats <b>from</b> this point <b>forward</b> does not benefit from eating, as he is <b>like one who throws a stone into a</b> leather <b>bottle,</b> i.e., it does not contribute to his health. <b>Abaye said: We only said that</b> eating from the sixth hour onward is not beneficial, <b>when he did not taste anything in the morning; however, if he tasted something in the morning we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: Like</b> the <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda <b>with regard to testimony, so too</b> is their <b>dispute with regard to leavened bread.</b> The Gemara comments: This is <b>obvious,</b> as <b>this is</b> precisely <b>that which we said.</b> The Gemara explains: Rav Ashi comes to <b>teach us</b> that <b>the answers that we answered,</b> distinguishing between the cases of testimony and leaven, <b>are</b> legitimate <b>answers. And do not say</b> that the different rulings in the two cases reflect a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> with regard to the opinions of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda and the answers are merely forced attempts to resolve the contradiction but not legitimate answers.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: They taught</b> that the court does not reject testimony due to a discrepancy over time <b>only with regard to</b> testimony ascribed to different <b>hours</b> of the day. <b>However,</b> if <b>one</b> witness <b>says</b> that the incident occurred <b>before sunrise and</b> the other <b>one says</b> it occurred <b>after sunrise, their testimony is void.</b> The Gemara asks: It is <b>obvious</b> that this is the case, as a blatant contradiction of this kind could not possibly be the result of miscalculation.
<b>Rather,</b> emend the previous statement: If <b>one</b> witness <b>says</b> the incident occurred <b>before sunrise and one says</b> it occurred <b>during sunrise, their testimony is void.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>That too is obvious,</b> as the difference between those times is similarly conspicuous. The Gemara answers: It is necessary to teach this <i>halakha</i>, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>both of</b> the witnesses <b>are saying one matter, and</b> the fact <b>that</b> one witness <b>says</b>

Daf 13a

that the incident occurred <b>during sunrise</b> is because <b>he was standing</b> out <b>in the open and</b> they were <b>mere rays of light that he saw</b> which he mistook for sunrise. In actuality, he too is testifying to an incident that occurred before sunrise, and the testimony of the two witnesses is therefore compatible testimony. Rav Shimi bar Ashi therefore <b>teaches us</b> that there is no concern that it transpired in that manner.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. Rava said to Rav Naḥman: And let the Master say</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who maintains that one may eat during the entire fifth hour, <b>as the <i>tanna</i> taught</b> an <b>unattributed</b> mishna <b>in accordance with his opinion,</b> indicating that this is the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: For the <b>entire time that one is permitted to eat</b> leaven himself, <b>he feeds</b> it to his animal. It can be inferred from this mishna that there is no intermediate period when it is prohibited for a person to eat leaven but he may feed it to his animal. This unattributed mishna must be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, as Rabbi Yehuda maintains that during the fifth hour it is prohibited to eat leaven but one may feed it to an animal.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>That</b> mishna <b>is not</b> classified as <b>unattributed,</b> as it is in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Gamliel, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> had the mishna been in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, the term: <b>Permitted,</b> is <b>difficult.</b> Instead, the mishna should have been formulated: When one eats he may feed.
Rava raised an additional difficulty to Rav Naḥman: <b>And let the Master say</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel, as he is</b> the <b>decisor</b> in this dispute, and there is a general principle that the <i>halakha</i> is always in accordance with the decisor who states an opinion that compromises between two opinions cited previously. <b>He said to him: Rabban Gamliel is not a decisor; he is stating a reason of his</b> own. Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Meir disagree with regard to consumption of any type of leaven; they do not distinguish between <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred food. Since Rabban Gamliel distinguishes between the time one must desist from eating <i>teruma</i> and the latest time that one may eat non-sacred food, his is evidently an unrelated opinion that is in no way a compromise between the other two rulings.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: When <b>Rav said</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, he ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>that occurs on Shabbat,</b> one does not remove leaven on Passover eve in the usual manner. Rather, <b>one removes everything</b> leavened <b>before Shabbat, and one burns ritually impure <i>teruma</i>:</b> <i>Teruma</i> <b>in abeyance,</b> whose purity is uncertain, <b>and</b> even any <b>pure</b> <i>teruma</i> that he does not require for his Shabbat meals. <b>And one leaves from the pure</b> leaven <b>food for two meals,</b> the meal at night and the one in the morning, <b>in order to eat</b> and finish <b>until four hours</b> of Shabbat morning. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar ben Yehuda of Bartota, who said</b> it <b>in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
The Sages <b>said to him: One</b> should <b>not burn pure</b> <i>teruma</i>, as <b>perhaps those</b> who can <b>eat it will be found</b> on Shabbat, and he will have retroactively violated a Torah prohibition by burning pure <i>teruma</i> unnecessarily. Instead, one places the <i>teruma</i> aside, and if no one is found to eat it, he feeds it to the dogs or renders it null and void in his heart. <b>He said to them: They already sought</b> people to eat the <i>teruma</i> <b>and they did not find</b> any other priests in the city to eat it. <b>They said to him: Perhaps</b> those priests who could eat the <i>teruma</i> on that Shabbat <b>slept outside the wall</b> of the city and will enter the city on Shabbat morning, at which point they could eat the <i>teruma</i>.
<b>He said to</b> the Sages: <b>According to your statement,</b> that you take into account this unlikely scenario, <b>one</b> should <b>not even burn <i>teruma</i> in abeyance,</b> as <b>perhaps Elijah</b> the Prophet <b>will come</b> on Shabbat and establish prophetically that the <i>teruma</i> is not ritually impure, <b>and render it ritually pure. They said to him:</b> That possibility is no source of concern, as <b>the Jewish people have already been assured that Elijah will come neither on a Friday nor on the eve of a Festival, due to the exertion</b> involved preparing for the upcoming holy day. Consequently, Elijah will certainly come neither on Friday, nor on Shabbat itself, which is Passover eve.
<b>They said: They did not move from there until</b> the Sages voted and <b>they established the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Yehuda of Bartota, who said</b> it <b>in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
Apropos the previous statement that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>what, is it not</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his opinion <b>even</b> with regard <b>to eating?</b> Rav’s ruling indicates that one may eat leaven until the end of the fourth hour, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. <b>Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava: No,</b> the aforementioned ruling applies only to the obligation <b>to remove</b> leaven, i.e., the Sages agreed that it is permitted to remove pure <i>teruma</i> on Friday only if there is no one available to eat it.
The Gemara notes: <b>And even Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds in accordance with this</b> statement <b>of Rav Naḥman,</b> and rules that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. <b>As Ravin bar Rav Adda said:</b> There was <b>an incident</b> that occurred involving <b>a certain person who deposited a saddlebag [<i>disakkayya</i>] filled with leavened bread with Yoḥanan Ḥakuka’a, and mice bore</b> a hole <b>in</b> the bag, <b>and leavened bread was spilling out</b> of the sack. <b>And he came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi on Passover eve to ask what he should do. In <b>the first hour</b> of the day Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: Wait,</b> as the owner of the bag might yet return to take it from you and eat the leaven. In <b>the second</b> hour <b>he said to him: Wait.</b> In <b>the third</b> hour <b>he said to him: Wait.</b> In <b>the fourth</b> hour <b>he said to him: Wait. In the fifth</b> hour, concluding that the person was not coming, <b>he said to him: Go and sell it in the market.</b>
<b>What, did</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>not</b> mean that Yoḥanan Ḥakuka’a should sell this leaven <b>to gentiles, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who says that it is prohibited for a Jew to eat leaven during the fifth hour? <b>Rav Yosef said: No,</b> it could be that he meant to sell it <b>to a Jew, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> that one may eat leaven during the fifth hour. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi was simply advising him to sell the leaven quickly before the sixth hour begins, at which point it would be prohibited for Jews to eat it. <b>Abaye said to him: If</b> it is permitted <b>for a Jew</b> to eat leaven, <b>let him take it for himself</b> and pay the owner back later. Why trouble him to sell it to someone else?
The Gemara responds: Eating it himself is not an option <b>due to</b> the potential of <b>suspicion. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a similar situation: <b>Collectors of charity who have no poor people to</b> whom they can <b>distribute</b> the money, <b>change</b> the money <b>with other</b> people <b>and do not change it themselves,</b> i.e., with their own coins.
Likewise, <b>collectors of</b> food for <b>the charity plate,</b> who would collect food in large vessels for the poor to eat, <b>who do not have poor people</b> to whom <b>to distribute</b> the food, <b>sell</b> the food <b>to others and do not sell it to themselves, as it is stated: “And you shall be clear before God and before Israel”</b> (Numbers 32:22). It is not sufficient that a person is without sin in the eyes of God. He must also appear upright in the eyes of other people so that they will not suspect him of wrongdoing.
<b>Rav Adda bar Mattana said to Rav Yosef: You told us explicitly</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi meant: <b>Go and sell it to gentiles, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> Rav Yosef took ill late in life and forgot his studies, and therefore his student would remind him that he also agreed with that version of the incident.
<b>Rav Yosef said: In accordance with whose</b> opinion, i.e., the opinion of which <i>tanna</i>, <b>is that <i>halakha</i> which was taught by Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, that one should sell leaven deposited with him in order to prevent the depositor from losing his possession? Rav Yosef explains: It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who deposits produce with another, even if</b> the produce will be <b>ruined</b> by insects or mold, <b>he</b> should <b>not touch them. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> He should <b>sell them in court, due to</b> the obligation to <b>restore lost property.</b> Just as one is required to return a lost item, he is likewise required to prevent loss of another’s property for which he assumed responsibility.
<b>Abaye said to him: Wasn’t it stated with regard to that</b> mishna that <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The Rabbis <b>taught</b> that one may not touch them <b>only</b> if

Daf 13b

<b>their decrease</b> in value is <b>at the standard</b> rate of stored produce, due to rot and rodents. <b>However,</b> if <b>their decrease</b> in value is <b>beyond the standard</b> rate, everyone agrees that <b>one sells them in court; and all the more so</b> in the case <b>here,</b> with regard to leavened bread, <b>as</b> the bread will be <b>entirely lost.</b> Once the leaven is prohibited, it remains prohibited even after Passover. Consequently, everyone agrees that one is obligated to sell the leaven.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said: Two</b> disqualified <b>loaves</b> of a thanks-offering are placed on the pillars surrounding the Temple as an indicator. The <b><i>tanna</i></b> who recited <i>mishnayot</i> in the study hall <b>taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Yehuda:</b> The loaves were placed <b>on [<i>al gav</i>] the bench</b> in the Temple. <b>He said to him: And does he need to conceal them?</b> No one would see them if they were placed there. Rather, <b>teach</b> the <i>baraita</i>: <b>On the roof of [<i>al gag</i>] the colonnade,</b> where everyone could see them.
<b>Raḥava said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: The Temple Mount was a double colonnade,</b> i.e., surrounded by two rows of columns. <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> it <b>was called an <i>istevanit</i></b> and it was <b>a colonnade within a colonnade.</b>
We learned in the mishna that Rabbi Yehuda says these two loaves placed outside were <b>disqualified.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> were <b>they disqualified?</b> What caused their disqualification? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: Since</b> the thanks-offerings brought that day <b>are numerous,</b> and the priests are unable to eat their portions from the loaves of all the offerings, the remaining loaves <b>are disqualified by</b> virtue of their being <b>left overnight.</b> The Gemara explains that so many loaves were brought that day, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>not bring a thanks-offering on the festival of Passover due to the leavened bread</b> included <b>with it,</b> as ten of the forty loaves brought with a thanks-offering are loaves of leavened bread.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: It is <b>obvious</b> that one may not bring this offering on Passover, as it contains leaven. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said: Here</b> this <i>baraita</i> is not referring to the prohibition against bringing the offering on Passover itself. Rather, <b>we are dealing with</b> the issue of sacrificing a thanks-offering on <b>the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, <b>and</b> this <i>tanna</i> <b>maintains: One</b> may <b>not bring consecrated</b> offerings <b>to</b> a <b>situation</b> where the time that they may be eaten is restricted, thereby increasing <b>the</b> likelihood of <b>disqualification.</b> Although it is permitted to eat leavened bread until the sixth hour of the fourteenth of Nisan, one may not bring a thanks-offering on Passover eve. The reason is that a thanks-offering may be eaten for one full day and the following night, and if it is brought on the eve of Passover, the time available before disqualification is reduced.
<b>And</b> therefore, <b>everyone</b> who ascended on the pilgrimage to Jerusalem and were obligated to bring thanks-offerings <b>brought them on the thirteenth</b> of Nisan. <b>And since</b> these thanks-offerings <b>are numerous, they are disqualified by</b> virtue of their being <b>left overnight,</b> as priests are unable to eat their portions from the loaves of all the offerings brought that day.
<b>They said in the name of Rabbi Yannai:</b> The loaves placed as an indicator <b>were not disqualified</b> by being left overnight. <b>Rather, why did</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>call them disqualified?</b> It was due to the fact <b>that no</b> animal <b>offering was slaughtered together</b> with <b>them</b> to consecrate them, but they were consecrated as thanks-offering loaves independently. They could not be eaten until the offering with which they were brought was slaughtered. The Gemara asks: <b>And let us slaughter</b> the thanks-offering to render the loaves permitted. The Gemara answers: The mishna is referring to a case <b>where the</b> animal for the <b>offering was lost.</b>
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>And let us bring another</b> animal to replace the first one for <b>sacrifice and let them slaughter</b> it. The Gemara answers: This is a case <b>where</b> the one who consecrated the thanks-offering <b>said: This is a thanks-offering and these are its loaves.</b> He consecrated the animal and the loaves together, <b>and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba, as Rabba said:</b> If <b>the loaf</b> of a thanks-offering is <b>lost,</b> its owner <b>brings another loaf</b> to complete the offering. However, if <b>the thanks-offering was lost</b> and the loaves remain, one may <b>not bring another thanks-offering. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The loaves</b> are brought <b>due to the thanks-offering but the thanks-offering is not brought on account of the loaves.</b> The animal sacrificed is the primary component of the offering while the loaves are subordinate to it.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let us redeem</b> the loaves from their consecrated status <b>and render them non-sacred,</b> and there will be no need to burn the loaves. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that <b>actually</b> the case is one <b>where the</b> animal <b>offering was</b> indeed <b>slaughtered over</b> the loaves to permit <b>them, but</b> the animal’s <b>blood spilled</b> before it could be sprinkled on the altar. Once the animal has been slaughtered, the loaves are fully consecrated and cannot be redeemed, but in this case, neither can they be eaten, as the blood was not sprinkled on the altar.
<b>And in accordance with whose</b> opinion is this statement that the slaughter of the animal consecrates the loaves and from that point they can no longer be redeemed? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: Each</b> of <b>two factors</b> that are indispensable in <b>permitting</b> the sacrifice of an offering, <b>elevates</b> the subordinate components of the offering to consecrated status, <b>without the other.</b> In this case, the loaves are consecrated when the animal to be sacrificed is slaughtered, even if the blood was not sprinkled, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The lambs sacrificed</b> on the festival of <b>Assembly,</b> i.e., <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>consecrate the loaves</b> that accompany them <b>only by</b> means of their <b>slaughter. How so?</b> If <b>one slaughtered</b> the lambs <b>for their</b> own <b>sake,</b> i.e., as lambs for <i>Shavuot</i>, in the appropriate manner, <b>and</b> the priest <b>sprinkled their blood for their</b> own <b>sake, the loaves are consecrated.</b>
However, if <b>one slaughtered them not for their</b> own <b>sake, and</b> the priest <b>sprinkled their blood not for their</b> own <b>sake, the loaves are not consecrated,</b> as the factors indispensable in rendering the offering permitted were not properly performed. If <b>one slaughtered them for their</b> own <b>sake, and he sprinkled their blood not for their</b> own <b>sake,</b> the fact that the lambs were properly slaughtered renders the loaves partially consecrated. Therefore, <b>the loaves are consecrated</b> to the extent that they cannot be redeemed, <b>but they are not consecrated</b> to the extent that they may be eaten. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: Actually, the loaves are consecrated only when one slaughters</b> the offerings <b>for their</b> own <b>sake and sprinkles their blood for their</b> own <b>sake,</b> i.e., only if both factors indispensable in rendering the offering permitted were properly performed. The previous answer in the Gemara is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara adds: <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the previous answer is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> it is understood, as <b>with what</b> case <b>are we dealing here?</b> It is in a unique case <b>where</b> after the slaughter, <b>the blood was received in the cup and it</b> only then <b>spilled</b> before it was sprinkled.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>his father,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>who stated</b> a principle: The legal status of <b>any</b> blood <b>that is about to be sprinkled</b> and prepared for sprinkling <b>is like</b> that of blood that <b>had</b> already <b>been sprinkled.</b> Therefore, the loaves are consecrated when the blood is received in the vessel and thereby prepared to be sprinkled. They may not be eaten until the blood is actually sprinkled.
<b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>they said in the name of Rabbi Elazar:</b> These loaves <b>were</b> entirely <b>fit. As long as</b> the loaves <b>were placed</b> there, <b>the entire nation</b> continued to <b>eat</b> leaven. When <b>one of</b> the loaves <b>was taken</b> away, the people knew that the time had come <b>to place</b> the leaven <b>in abeyance,</b> meaning that they <b>neither eat nor burn</b> their leaven. When <b>both of</b> the loaves <b>were taken</b> away, <b>they all began burning</b> their leaven.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Abba Shaul says:</b>

Daf 14a

<b>Two cows would plow on the Mount of Olives</b> on Passover eve. <b>As long as both of them are plowing, the entire nation</b> continues to <b>eat</b> leavened bread. When <b>one of</b> the cows <b>is taken</b> away, the people know that the time has come <b>to place</b> their leaven <b>in abeyance,</b> meaning that they <b>neither eat nor burn</b> it.
