When <b>both of them were taken</b> away, <b>the entire nation began burning</b> their leaven.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Apropos the removal of leaven on Passover eve, including the consecrated loaves of thanks-offerings and <i>teruma</i>, the mishna cites a related <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest says: In</b> all <b>the days of the priests, they did not refrain from burning meat that became ritually impure by</b> coming into contact with <b>a secondary source of ritual impurity,</b> i.e., an object that had come into contact with a primary source of impurity, together <b>with meat that became ritually impure by</b> contact with <b>a primary source of impurity.</b> They would do so <b>even though they</b> would thereby <b>add</b> a degree of <b>impurity to</b> the <b>impurity</b> of the first piece of meat, which was previously impure to a lesser degree.
<b>Rabbi Akiva added</b> to the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest <b>and said: In</b> all <b>the days of the priests, they did not refrain from lighting</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>oil that was</b> ritually <b>disqualified by</b> coming into contact with <b>one who immersed himself during that day</b> and who does not become completely purified until nightfall <b>in a lamp that became ritually impure</b> with first-degree impurity <b>through</b> contact with one who became <b>ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse.</b> They did so <b>even though they</b> would thereby <b>add impurity to</b> the <b>impurity</b> of the oil. A person who immersed himself during that day assumes the status of second-degree ritual impurity. His contact renders the oil ritually impure with third-degree ritual impurity. The lamp with first-degree ritual impurity renders the oil ritually impure with second-degree impurity.
<b>Rabbi Meir said: From their statements we learned that one</b> may <b>burn ritually pure <i>teruma</i> with impure</b> <i>teruma</i> when removing leaven <b>on Passover</b> eve. The rationale that applies to the two previous cases applies here as well. Since both items are being burned, one may disregard the fact that one item will assume a higher degree of ritual impurity in the process. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: That is not the inference</b> from which the <i>halakha</i> in the case of ritually pure and ritually impure <i>teruma</i> can be learned. In those first two cases, the two items are both ritually impure, albeit at different degrees of ritual impurity. Rabbi Meir is referring to the combination of impure <i>teruma</i> with pure <i>teruma</i>, which would render pure <i>teruma</i> ritually impure.
<b>And</b> in fact <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who disagree with regard to the burning of leavened <i>teruma</i>, nevertheless <b>concede that one burns this</b> ritually pure <i>teruma</i> <b>by itself and that</b> impure <i>teruma</i> <b>by itself. With regard to what did they disagree?</b> They disagreed <b>with regard to</b> whether one may burn <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> whose purity is uncertain, <b>and</b> definitely <b>impure</b> <i>teruma</i> together, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer says: This</b> <i>teruma</i> in abeyance <b>should be burned by itself, and that</b> impure <i>teruma</i> <b>should be burned by itself; and Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> In that case, <b>both of them</b> may be burned <b>as one.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara analyzes the mishna’s first statement: <b>Now</b> consider, <b>what is</b> the status of <b>meat that became ritually impure by</b> coming into contact with <b>a secondary source of impurity?</b> It assumes <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity status. <b>When one burns</b> that meat together <b>with meat that became ritually impure by</b> coming into contact with <b>a primary source of ritual impurity, what is</b> the status of that first piece of meat? It assumes <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity status. Meat that touches a primary source of impurity assumes first-degree ritual impurity status, which transmits second-degree impurity to other meat.
The Gemara continues: Since when the first piece of meat is placed next to the meat that came into contact with a primary source it assumes second-degree impurity, this <b>is</b> a case where the meat is with <b>second-</b>degree status, <b>and</b> through contact with the primary source it would assume <b>second-</b>degree status. In <b>what</b> sense <b>is there</b> a case of <b>adding impurity to its impurity</b> here? There is no change in the status of the first piece of meat at all.
<b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> The above interpretation is incorrect, as <b>here we are dealing with</b> the <b>secondary source of a secondary source of ritual impurity,</b> i.e., meat that came in contact with second-degree ritual impurity. The statement in the mishna: That became ritually impure by coming into contact with a secondary source of ritual impurity, should not be understood as saying that it came into contact with meat with first-degree ritual impurity status, <b>as</b> in this case, the meat came into contact with meat with second-degree ritual impurity status and <b>is</b> impure with <b>third-</b>degree ritual impurity. <b>And</b> Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest <b>maintains</b> that <b>it is permitted to render</b> impure with <b>second-</b>degree impurity an object with <b>third-</b>degree ritual impurity by burning it with meat that came into contact with a primary source of ritual impurity.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Isn’t</b> there a principle that <b>food does not transmit ritual impurity to</b> other <b>food, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>food transmits impurity to</b> other <b>food;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “And if water is placed upon the seed, and any</b> part <b>of a carcass falls upon it, it is impure”</b> (Leviticus 11:38). The Sages derived from this verse: <b>It,</b> the food exposed to the source of impurity, <b>is impure, but it does not render similar</b> foods <b>impure.</b> Apparently, food does not transmit impurity to other food.
<b>This</b> works out <b>well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye, who said: They taught</b> this principle that food does not transmit ritual impurity to other food <b>only with regard to non-sacred</b> food; <b>however, with regard to <i>teruma</i> and consecrated</b> food, food <b>transmits</b> impurity to other foods it touches, and <b>it renders</b> the <i>teruma</i> or consecrated food <b>similar to it</b> in terms of impurity.
<b>And</b> this is <b>also</b> the case <b>according to</b> the opinion stated by <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava in the name of Rava, who said: They taught</b> this principle, that food does not transmit ritual impurity to other food, <b>only with regard to non-sacred</b> food <b>and <i>teruma</i>; however, with regard to consecrated</b> food, food <b>transmits</b> impurity to other foods it touches, and <b>it renders</b> the consecrated food <b>similar to it</b> in terms of impurity. According to this opinion, it works out <b>well.</b> As the mishna is dealing with a case of consecrated meat, impurity can be transmitted from one food item to another.
<b>However,</b> this is not the case <b>according to</b> the opinion stated by <b>Ravina in the name of Rava, who said: The Torah stated</b> this principle in <b>a categorical verse,</b> without any exceptions, meaning it is <b>no different</b> with regard to <b>non-sacred</b> food, and it is <b>no different</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>, and</b> it is <b>no different</b> with regard to <b>consecrated</b> food, as in all of these cases one type of food <b>does not render</b> other food <b>similar to it</b> in terms of impurity. According to this opinion, <b>what can be said</b> in terms of understanding the statement in the mishna: Even though they thereby add impurity to its impurity?
The Gemara answers in defense of this opinion: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is with a case <b>where there are liquids with the meat</b> when it comes into contact with the primary source of ritual impurity. Since the other piece of meat comes into contact with the liquid on that meat, <b>it becomes impure due to</b> contact with <b>the liquid.</b> Although food does not transmit impurity to food, liquid transmits impurity to food.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, this</b> phrase: <b>With meat that became ritually impure by</b> contact with <b>a primary source of impurity,</b> is imprecise. The <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> said: <b>With meat and liquids,</b> as the liquids are essential for the transmission of impurity. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains: <b>Although food does not transmit impurity to</b> other <b>food by Torah law, in any event, by rabbinic law,</b> food <b>transmits impurity</b> to other food. The mishna is based on the rabbinic decree that food transmits impurity to other food.
It was stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Akiva added: In</b> all <b>the days of the priests, they did not refrain from lighting</b> <i>teruma</i> oil that was ritually disqualified by coming into contact with one who immersed himself during that day, in a lamp that was rendered ritually impure with first-degree impurity through contact with one who became ritually impure with impurity imparted by a corpse. The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> consider, <b>what is</b> the status of <b>oil that was disqualified by one who immersed himself during that day?</b> As one who immersed himself during that day assumes second-degree impurity, the oil that he touches assumes <b>third-</b>degree ritual impurity status. <b>And when he lights it in a lamp that was rendered ritually impure through</b> contact with one who became <b>ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> who has first-degree impurity status, <b>what is</b> the impurity status of the oil? It assumes <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity status.
If so, <b>what is</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>teaching us</b> by this <i>halakha</i>? This statement apparently teaches us that with regard to an object that is ritually impure with <b>third-</b>degree impurity status, <b>it is permitted to render it</b> impure with <b>second-</b>degree impurity status. Yet <b>this is</b> the same <i>halakha</i> as <b>that</b> which was taught by Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest. What is novel about the <i>halakha</i> taught by Rabbi Akiva? <b>Rav Yehuda said: Here, we are dealing with a metal lamp,</b> which has a unique halakhic status. <b>As the Merciful One states:</b>

Daf 14b

“And whoever touches <b>one who is slain with a sword</b> in the open field, or one who dies on his own, or a bone of a man, or a grave, shall be unclean seven days” (Numbers 19:16). The Sages derived from the phrase: One who is slain with a sword, that the legal status of a metal <b>sword</b> in terms of its degree of impurity <b>is like</b> that of <b>one who is slain.</b> Any metal vessel that becomes impure through contact with a corpse assumes the impurity status of a corpse, the ultimate primary source of ritual impurity. The same is true with regard to a metal vessel that came into contact with a person or vessel that became impure with impurity imparted by a corpse. In that case the metal vessel assumes the impurity status of that person or vessel, <b>and</b> therefore, <b>this</b> metal lamp <b>is a primary source of impurity. And</b> yet Rabbi Akiva <b>maintains</b> that <b>it is permitted to render</b> this oil, which is impure with <b>third-</b>degree impurity, impure with <b>first-</b>degree impurity through contact with the metal lamp.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what impelled Rav Yehuda to establish</b> the mishna as referring specifically to the case <b>of a metal lamp? Let him establish it</b> as referring specifically to the case <b>of an earthenware lamp.</b>
<b>And</b> if so, <b>what does</b> Rabbi Akiva’s statement <b>add?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Whereas there,</b> in Rabbi Ḥanina’s testimony, he is referring to a case where one piece of <b>ritually impure</b> meat came into contact with another piece of <b>impure</b> meat, <b>here,</b> in Rabbi Akiva’s testimony, he is referring to a case where oil that is <b>disqualified</b> came into contact with a lamp with first-degree impurity status, rendering the oil <b>impure.</b> Oil with second-degree ritual impurity status disqualifies <i>teruma</i>, as <i>teruma</i> with third-degree ritual impurity status does not transmit ritual impurity to other <i>teruma</i>. In that case, the novelty in Rabbi Akiva’s statement is that a disqualified item is burned together with an impure item even though it is thereby rendered impure.
<b>Rava said: The mishna was difficult for</b> Rav Yehuda: <b>Why</b> did the <i>tanna</i> <b>specifically teach</b> the case of <b>a lamp that became ritually impure</b> with first-degree impurity <b>through</b> contact with one who became <b>ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse? Let it teach that</b> the lamp <b>became impure by</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal,</b> which is a much more common primary source of impurity.
<b>Rather, what is the substance</b> with regard to <b>which</b> there is <b>a distinction between its impurity</b> when exposed to <b>impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse</b> and its impurity when exposed to impurity imparted by a <b>creeping animal? You must say</b> that the substance <b>is metal.</b> A metal vessel that comes into contact with a creeping animal assumes first-degree ritual impurity status, whereas if it comes into contact with a person or a vessel that came into contact with a corpse, it becomes a primary source of impurity.
<b>Rava said: Learn from</b> this statement that <b>Rabbi Akiva holds: The ritual impurity of liquids</b> with regard <b>to transmitting impurity to other</b> objects is <b>by Torah law,</b> contrary to those <i>tanna’im</i> who hold that liquids transmit impurity only by rabbinic decree. <b>As, if it enters your mind</b> that this type of impurity is <b>by rabbinic law, now, this lamp, what effect does</b> this lamp <b>have on that oil? If</b> it is to <b>disqualify</b> the oil <b>itself, it is</b> already <b>disqualified from the outset.</b> Rather, Rabbi Akiva evidently maintains that through contact with the lamp this oil becomes impure and transmits impurity to food by Torah law.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>From where</b> do you know that this is Rabbi Akiva’s opinion? <b>Perhaps</b> Rabbi Akiva holds that through contact with the lamp, the oil will be able <b>to transmit ritual impurity to other</b> objects <b>by rabbinic law.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>If</b> the oil confers impurity <b>by rabbinic law, why</b> does Rabbi Akiva refer <b>particularly</b> to a case where the oil became impure <b>by</b> contact with <b>a primary source of impurity?</b> If Rabbi Akiva sought to cite an example of rabbinic impurity, he could have cited <b>even</b> a case where the oil came into contact <b>with</b> an object with <b>first-</b>degree impurity status, <b>or</b> an item with <b>second-</b>degree impurity status. By rabbinic law, in those cases <b>too,</b> the oil <b>is</b> impure with <b>first-</b>degree ritual impurity and transmits impurity to food.
The Gemara cites the source for that <i>halakha</i>. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Any</b> item that <b>disqualifies <i>teruma</i>,</b> e.g., anything with second-degree ritual impurity status, <b>transmits impurity to liquids,</b> conferring upon them <b>first-</b>degree ritual impurity status. These liquids assume a higher degree of impurity than the item that rendered them impure. This rabbinic decree applies to anything with second-degree ritual impurity status <b>except</b> for one <b>who</b> was impure and <b>immersed himself during that day</b> and the sun has not yet set. If such a person touches liquids, he does not confer upon them first-degree impurity status. Instead, that case conforms to the standard process of transmission of ritual impurity, and he confers upon them third-degree ritual impurity status and invalidates them.
The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather, learn from</b> the fact that Rabbi Akiva did not cite the example of oil that became impure through contact with an item with first or second-degree ritual impurity that Rabbi Akiva holds that the <i>halakha</i> that liquids transmit impurity to other items <b>is by Torah law.</b>
It was taught in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Meir said: From their statements we learned</b> that one may burn ritually pure <i>teruma</i> with impure <i>teruma</i> when removing leaven on Passover eve. The Gemara asks: <b>From whose statements</b> was this conclusion inferred? <b>If you say</b> that this conclusion is inferred <b>from the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest, is</b> Rabbi Meir’s statement <b>comparable</b> to that case? <b>There,</b> Rabbi Ḥanina said that one may burn one <b>ritually impure</b> item <b>and</b> another <b>ritually impure</b> item together, whereas <b>here,</b> Rabbi Meir is referring to burning <b>pure and impure</b> <i>teruma</i> together.
<b>But rather,</b> Rabbi Meir’s conclusion is inferred <b>from the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Is it comparable</b> to that case? <b>There,</b> Rabbi Akiva said that a <b>disqualified</b> item and an <b>impure</b> item may be burned together, whereas <b>here,</b> Rabbi Meir is referring to burning a <b>pure</b> item and an <b>impure</b> item together.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir maintains</b> that <b>the mishna</b> is referring <b>to</b> an object that is <b>a primary source of impurity by Torah law and</b> an object that is <b>a secondary source of impurity by rabbinic law, which by Torah law is entirely pure.</b> Since the <i>teruma</i> is pure by Torah law, the novelty of Rabbi Meir’s statement is that although by Torah law one of the foods is pure and the other is impure, due to the rabbinic decree of impurity, one may burn the two items together.

Daf 15a

<b>And what</b> did Rabbi Meir mean when he said: <b>From their statements?</b> He meant: <b>From the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish said</b> another explanation of the mishna <b>in the name of bar Kappara: The</b> case in the <b>mishna</b> is one involving <b>a primary source of ritual impurity by Torah law and a secondary source of impurity by Torah law. And what</b> did Rabbi Meir mean by the phrase: <b>From their statements?</b> He was not referring to the <i>tanna’im</i> in this mishna, but rather: <b>From the statements of Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua</b> cited elsewhere.
The Gemara asks: To <b>which</b> statement of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua</b> is Rabbi Meir referring? <b>If you say</b> he is referring to <b>this</b> statement of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, as we learned</b> in a mishna: In the case of <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> produce <b>with regard to which uncertainty developed</b> with regard to its <b>impurity,</b> and which therefore may not be eaten, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that one must nevertheless safeguard the <i>teruma</i> from ritual impurity. Therefore, he maintains: <b>If</b> the barrel <b>was resting in a vulnerable place,</b> where it may come into contact with impurity, <b>one</b> should <b>place it in a concealed place, and if it was exposed, he</b> should <b>cover it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> That is not necessary. Rather, even <b>if it was placed in a concealed place,</b> he may <b>place it in a vulnerable place</b> if he chooses. <b>And if it was covered, he</b> may <b>expose it,</b> as he need no longer safeguard this <i>teruma</i> from impurity. According to Rabbi Yehoshua, as <i>teruma</i> whose impurity status is uncertain, may be used only for lighting a fire, there is no requirement to prevent it from contact with ritual impurity. The same reasoning applies to pure leaven: One is not required to safeguard it from impurity in the process of its removal.
The Gemara rejects the comparison: <b>Is</b> this dispute with regard to the placement of doubtfully impure <i>teruma</i> <b>comparable</b> to the case of burning ritually pure and impure items together? <b>There,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua permits <b>mere</b> passive <b>causation</b> of impurity; however, he does not permit one to actively render <i>teruma</i> whose impurity status is uncertain, impure. <b>Here,</b> however, in the statement of Rabbi Meir, he actively renders leavened <i>teruma</i> <b>impure with</b> his <b>hands.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Meir did not infer his opinion from that statement; instead, he inferred it from <b>this</b> other statement of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua. As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> wine <b>that broke in the upper</b> area of a <b>winepress,</b> where grapes are pressed, <b>and</b> there is <b>impure, non-sacred</b> wine in the <b>lower</b> area of the press, where the wine flows from the upper area, the following dilemma arises: If the <i>teruma</i> wine flows into the non-sacred wine, the <i>teruma</i> will be rendered ritually impure. The result will be significant financial loss, as the legal status of all the wine in the lower press will be that of impure <i>teruma</i>, which is prohibited even for priests to drink.
In that case, <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua concede that if one is able to rescue</b> even <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>from</b> the barrel that broke by receiving the <i>teruma</i> wine in a vessel before it becomes impure, and thereby keep the wine <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity, he</b> should <b>rescue</b> it. <b>And</b> if <b>one cannot</b> receive the wine in a pure vessel, as only impure vessels are available, such that if he uses them to receive the wine or to seal the upper press he will render the <i>teruma</i> impure, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The <i>teruma</i> wine should be allowed to <b>descend and become impure</b> on its own, <b>but one</b> should <b>not</b> actively <b>render it impure with</b> his <b>hand. Rabbi Yehoshua says: One</b> may <b>even render it impure with</b> his <b>hand.</b> Since it will become impure on its own regardless of his actions, there is no objection to rendering the <i>teruma</i> impure preemptively in order to prevent greater financial loss. Apparently, according to Rabbi Yehoshua, it is permitted to render an item impure if it will be lost in any case.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> that Rabbi Meir is referring to the above dispute, <b>this</b> expression: <b>From their statements,</b> is imprecise, as his ruling is not based on Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion at all. Instead, Rabbi Meir <b>should have</b> said: <b>From his statement,</b> as he learns his ruling solely from the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua.
The Gemara answers that <b>this is</b> what Rabbi Meir <b>is saying: We learned</b> this ruling <b>from the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua.</b> Since the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, this is a substantive source. The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as</b> the continuation of the mishna <b>teaches: Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua concede.</b> This indicates that Rabbi Meir is referring to their opinions. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that this is the correct interpretation of Rabbi Meir’s statement.
<b>And likewise, Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: The</b> case in the <b>mishna</b> is one involving <b>a primary source of ritual impurity by Torah law and a secondary source of impurity by Torah law. And what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>From their statements?</b> It means <b>from the statements</b> of <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua</b> in the dispute cited above.
<b>Rava raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i> that elaborates on the mishna. <b>Rabbi Yosei said</b> to Rabbi Meir: <b>The</b> inferred <b>conclusion</b> of burning pure and impure leaven together <b>is not similar to the</b> case from which you cited <b>proof. When the Sages testified, about what did they testify? If</b> your source is the testimony of Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest, he testified <b>about the meat that became ritually impure through</b> contact with <b>a secondary source of impurity,</b> saying <b>that one</b> may <b>burn it</b> together <b>with the meat that became impure through</b> contact with <b>a primary source of impurity.</b> In that case, <b>this</b> meat <b>is impure and that</b> meat <b>is</b> similarly <b>impure.</b>
<b>If</b> your source is the testimony of Rabbi Akiva, he testified <b>about</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>oil that was</b> ritually <b>disqualified by</b> coming into contact with <b>one who immersed himself during that day,</b> saying <b>that one may kindle it in a lamp that became ritually impure</b> with first-degree impurity <b>through</b> contact with one who became <b>ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse.</b> That is a case where <b>this</b> oil <b>is disqualified and that</b> lamp <b>is impure. We also concede with regard to <i>teruma</i> that became impure through</b> contact with <b>a secondary source of impurity that one</b> may <b>burn it with <i>teruma</i> that became impure through</b> contact with <b>a primary source of impurity.</b>
<b>However, how will we burn</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance,</b> whose impurity status is uncertain, together <b>with ritually impure</b> <i>teruma</i>? <b>Perhaps Elijah</b> the Prophet <b>will come</b> and establish prophetically that the <i>teruma</i> is not ritually impure, <b>and he will render it ritually pure.</b> The legal status of <i>teruma</i> in abeyance is uncertain. How can one actively render it impure when it might ultimately be determined that it is pure?

Daf 15b

The <i>Tosefta</i> continues: <b><i>Piggul</i></b> is an offering disqualified by the improper intention during the performance of the four sacrificial rites to sacrifice it or eat it after its appropriate time; <b>and <i>notar</i></b> is the flesh of a sacrifice that is left over beyond its allotted time. The Sages decreed ritual impurity on both, and both, as well as sacrificial meat deemed <b>ritually impure</b> by Torah law, may not be eaten and must be burned. <b>Beit Shammai say: They</b> may <b>not be burned together,</b> as in doing so the <i>piggul</i> and <i>notar</i>, which are impure by rabbinic law, will come into contact with meat impure by Torah law, adding impurity to their impurity. <b>And Beit Hillel say: They</b> may <b>be burned together.</b>
The Gemara returns to the issue under discussion: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir is saying</b> that he derives his opinion <b>from the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua, why does Rabbi Yosei respond to him from the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest? Rav Naḥman said to him: Rabbi Yosei</b> did <b>not</b> have Rabbi Meir’s reasoning <b>in mind,</b> as he did not understand Rabbi Meir’s reasoning. <b>As</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>maintains</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir is saying to him</b> proof <b>from</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest, and</b> Rabbi Meir <b>said to him: I am stating</b> my proof <b>from</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>said to</b> Rabbi Meir in response: <b>And even according to Rabbi Yehoshua, that is not the inference</b> from which the <i>halakha</i> of burning pure and impure leavened <i>teruma</i> together can be learned, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua concede that one</b> should <b>burn this</b> meat <b>by itself and that</b> meat <b>by itself,</b> as stated in the mishna. From an analysis of the mishna and the <i>Tosefta</i>, it is possible to reconstruct the original dispute.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the above statement: <b>But why</b> does Rabbi Yosei say: <b>That is not the inference</b> from which it can be learned? On the contrary, it <b>is</b> a perfectly <b>legitimate inference.</b> In both cases the dispute is the same: Is one permitted to actively render an object impure preemptively if it will ultimately be destroyed regardless?
The Gemara rejects this contention: The case <b>there,</b> of the broken barrel in the upper press, where according to Rabbi Yehoshua it is permitted to actively render the <i>teruma</i> impure, <b>is different, as</b> in that case <b>there is</b> the potential <b>loss of non-sacred</b> produce. If one does not render the <i>teruma</i> in the upper press impure by receiving it in impure vessels, it will flow down and render the impure, non-sacred wine in the lower press impure <i>teruma</i>. However, in the case of leaven, no loss will be incurred. Why, then, shouldn’t each <i>teruma</i> be burned independently?
<b>Rav Yirmeya strongly objects to this</b> claim: In <b>the mishna, too, there is</b> the <b>loss of wood,</b> as one requires additional wood to kindle a second fire and burn the impure <i>teruma</i> separately. <b>A certain Elder said to him:</b> With regard to this and similar issues, the Sages <b>were concerned about a great loss;</b> however, <b>they were not concerned about</b> the <b>minimal loss</b> of several pieces of wood.
<b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei refers <b>to</b> the <b>sixth</b> hour, when leaven is prohibited by rabbinic decree. <b>However, in</b> the <b>seventh</b> hour, when leaven is prohibited by Torah law, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>one</b> may <b>burn</b> ritually pure leavened <i>teruma</i> together with impure leavened <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Asi: Let us say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains</b> that <b>the mishna</b> is referring <b>to</b> an object that is <b>a primary source of impurity by Torah law and</b> an object that is <b>a secondary source of impurity by rabbinic law. And what</b> is the meaning of Rabbi Meir’s statement: <b>From their statements?</b> He meant <b>from the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest,</b> as explained above. The dispute refers to a rabbinic prohibition, e.g., a secondary source of impurity or the obligation to burn leaven during the sixth hour. In a case where the leaven is not yet prohibited by rabbinic law, e.g., in the fourth or fifth hour, even Rabbi Meir agrees that one may not burn ritually pure and impure <i>teruma</i> together.
Rabbi Asi <b>said to him: Yes,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan indeed interprets the mishna in this manner. <b>It was also stated</b> explicitly that this is the case, as <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The mishna</b> is referring <b>to</b> an object that is <b>a primary source of impurity by Torah law and</b> an object that is <b>a secondary source of impurity by rabbinic law. And what</b> is the meaning of: <b>From their statements?</b> It means <b>from the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest. And the dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei is with regard <b>to</b> the <b>sixth</b> hour, when leaven is prohibited by rabbinic law. <b>However, everyone agrees</b> that <b>in</b> the <b>seventh</b> hour <b>one</b> may <b>burn</b> them together, as both pieces of leavened <i>teruma</i> are prohibited by Torah law.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the end of the <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s assertion that even Rabbi Yosei agrees that it is permitted to burn together two objects prohibited by Torah law. As the <i>baraita</i> states with regard to <b><i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, and ritually impure</b> sacrificial meat that <b>Beit Shammai say: They</b> may <b>not be burned together, and Beit Hillel say: They</b> may <b>be burned together.</b> All of these items are prohibited by Torah law, and Rabbi Yosei would agree that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>It is different there,</b> as <i>piggul</i> and <i>notar</i> <b>are ritually impure by rabbinic law,</b> and therefore Rabbi Yosei would agree that they may be burned together in that case. That is not true in the case of leaven in the seventh hour, which is not impure even by rabbinic law, although it is prohibited by Torah law. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b><i>Piggul</i> and <i>notar</i>,</b> leftover sacrificial flesh, <b>render</b> one’s <b>hands impure</b> by rabbinic decree.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion: With regard to <b>bread that became moldy and is no longer fit for a person to eat, but a dog can</b> still <b>eat it,</b> this bread can <b>become impure</b> with <b>the ritual impurity of food</b> if it is the size <b>of an egg-bulk,</b> as it is still classified as food. If it is pure leavened <i>teruma</i>, <b>it is burned with impure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>on Passover</b> eve. Since the moldy bread is no longer edible, it is not necessary to refrain from burning it together with impure items. Apparently, this is Rabbi Yosei’s opinion, as Rabbi Meir maintains that pure and impure <i>teruma</i> are burned together even if neither is moldy. Since Rabbi Yosei concedes in the case of moldy bread, the same should apply to leavened <i>teruma</i> after the seventh hour, which is prohibited by Torah law.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>It is different there,</b> in the case of moldy bread, <b>as it is</b> for all intents and purposes <b>mere dust,</b> and its legal status is no longer that of food.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that Rabbi Meir’s proof is based on the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest, <b>why</b> does the mishna mention that Rabbi Eliezer <b>concedes</b> to Rabbi Yehoshua? The Gemara explains that <b>this is</b> what <b>Rabbi Yosei is saying to Rabbi Meir: Even according to Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who <b>rules leniently</b> in this case, <b>when he rules leniently</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> burning <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance</b> together <b>with impure</b> <i>teruma</i>; <b>however,</b> with regard <b>to</b> burning <b>pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>and impure</b> <i>teruma</i> together, <b>no,</b> he does not permit doing so.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> that Rabbi Meir’s proof is based on the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest, <b>why</b> did Rabbi Yosei say: <b>That is not the inference</b> from which it can be learned? On the contrary, it <b>is</b> a perfectly <b>legitimate inference.</b> According to Rabbi Meir, pure <i>teruma</i> is prohibited during the sixth hour by rabbinic law. Just as Rabbi Ḥanina holds that one may actively transmit impurity to an object that is impure by rabbinic law by burning it together with an object that is impure by Torah law, so too, according to Rabbi Meir one may transmit impurity to an item prohibited by rabbinic law by burning it together with an item that is impure by Torah law.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: Here,</b> the mishna is referring <b>to meat that became ritually impure</b> through contact with a secondary source of impurity <b>by means of liquids that became impure due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal</b> and thereby assumed second-degree ritual impurity. <b>And Rabbi Meir conforms to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, and Rabbi Yosei</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning.</b>
<b>Rabbi Meir</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning</b> with regard to this issue, <b>as he said: The ritual impurity of liquids</b> with regard <b>to transmitting impurity to other</b> objects is <b>by rabbinic law.</b> The meat that became impure through contact with a secondary source of impurity is in fact entirely pure by Torah law. Therefore, he learns from the mishna that it is permitted to burn pure and impure items together.
<b>And Rabbi Yosei</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he said: The ritual impurity of liquids</b> with regard <b>to transmitting impurity to other</b> objects is <b>by Torah law.</b> Accordingly, the meat that Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest referred to in the mishna was impure by Torah law. Therefore, this case cannot serve as a precedent for the claim that it is permitted to burn pure and impure <i>teruma</i> together on Passover eve. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 16a

If there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether or not a certain <b>liquid has become ritually impure,</b> it is presumed <b>impure.</b> It is an uncertainty with regard to Torah law, and the <i>halakha</i> is stringent in such cases. However, if the uncertainty is with regard <b>to rendering other</b> items <b>impure,</b> they are <b>pure,</b> as liquids transmit impurity by rabbinic law, and the <i>halakha</i> is lenient with regard to uncertainties of that kind. These are <b>the statements of Rabbi Meir, and Rabbi Elazar would say likewise in accordance with his statements. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> When there is uncertainty with regard to these liquids, the item is <b>impure in all</b> cases, even in terms of transmitting impurity to other items, as he maintains that the impurity of liquids is by Torah law.
<b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> In cases of uncertainty as to whether or not these liquids transmitted impurity <b>to foods,</b> the ruling is that the foods are <b>impure,</b> in accordance with the principle that when there is uncertainty in cases of Torah law, the <i>halakha</i> is stringent. Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon maintain that liquids transmit impurity to food by Torah law. However, when there is uncertainty as to whether or not these liquids transmitted impurity <b>to vessels,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is lenient, and they are <b>pure.</b> Even Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon concede that liquids transmit impurity to vessels only by rabbinic law. This <i>baraita</i> clearly indicates that Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei indeed dispute whether or not the impurity of liquids applies by Torah law.
With regard to the <i>Tosefta</i>, the Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Elazar maintain</b> that <b>liquids have ritual impurity</b> by Torah law <b>at all? Wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: There is no impurity for liquids at all</b> by Torah law. <b>Know</b> that this is so, <b>as Yosei ben Yo’ezer of Tzereida testified about</b> the grasshopper called <b><i>eil kamtza</i></b> that it is <b>kosher</b> and may be eaten; <b>and</b> he testified <b>about liquids</b> in <b>the slaughterhouse</b> in the Temple that they were <b>ritually pure,</b> as there was no decree of impurity issued with regard to them. The fact that these liquids are ritually pure indicates that by Torah law liquids cannot transmit impurity at all. Instead, that type of impurity is by rabbinic law, and rabbinic decrees of impurity were not in effect in the Temple.
The Gemara adds: <b>This</b> works out <b>well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, who said</b> that in this context the term <b>ritually pure</b> means that they do not <b>transmit impurity to other</b> items; <b>however, they themselves</b> can <b>become impure.</b> If that is Rabbi Elazar’s opinion, he indeed holds in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Meir that liquids transmit impurity by rabbinic law but themselves become impure by Torah law, as stated in the <i>baraita</i> above. <b>However, according to Rav, who said that</b> Yosei ben Yo’ezer holds that the liquids are <b>actually ritually pure</b> and they themselves cannot be rendered impure, <b>what can be said?</b> According to Rav, Rabbi Elazar maintains that there is no impurity at all by Torah law with regard to liquids. In what sense does he hold in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who said that liquids themselves can become impure by Torah law?
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> When the <i>baraita</i> said that Rabbi Elazar agreed with Rabbi Meir, it was <b>with regard to one</b> of Rabbi Meir’s opinions. Rabbi Elazar agrees with Rabbi Meir that in a case where there is uncertainty with regard to rendering other items impure, they are pure, as liquids transmit impurity by rabbinic law. However, Rabbi Elazar maintains that the impurity of liquids themselves is also not by Torah law, and therefore in a case of uncertainty with regard to impurity of the liquids themselves, the ruling is that they are pure.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying:</b> And Rabbi Elazar would say <b>in accordance with</b> Rabbi Meir’s <b>statements,</b> in the plural, indicating <b>that</b> the points of agreement are <b>many? And furthermore,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching: Likewise.</b> This term also indicates that Rabbi Elazar agrees completely with Rabbi Meir. Since no resolution was found for this contradiction, the Gemara concludes that it is indeed <b>difficult</b> to understand the <i>baraita</i> according to Rav.
After citing the testimony of Yosei ben Yo’ezer and the associated amoraic dispute, the Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav said:</b> Yosei ben Yo’ezer said that the liquids in the Temple are <b>actually ritually pure</b> and neither become impure nor transmit impurity. <b>And Shmuel said</b> that the liquids are <b>ritually pure</b> in the sense that they do not <b>transmit impurity to other</b> items; <b>however, they themselves</b> can <b>become impure.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rav said</b> that liquids are <b>actually pure,</b> as <b>he maintains</b> that <b>the ritual impurity of liquids</b> is <b>by rabbinic law, and when the Sages issued</b> this <b>decree</b> they did so only with regard <b>to ordinary liquids.</b> However, with regard <b>to the liquids of the slaughterhouse</b> in the Temple, <b>they did not issue</b> the <b>decree.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara elaborates on the opinion of Shmuel: <b>Shmuel said</b> that the liquids are <b>ritually pure</b> in the sense that they do not <b>transmit impurity to other</b> items; <b>however, they themselves</b> can <b>become impure,</b> as Shmuel <b>maintains</b> that the <b>ritual impurity of liquids</b> themselves is <b>by Torah law,</b> whereas their capacity <b>to transmit impurity to other</b> objects is <b>by rabbinic law. And when the Sages issued</b> this <b>decree,</b> they did so only with regard <b>to ordinary liquids.</b> However, with regard <b>to the liquids of the slaughterhouse</b> in the Temple <b>they did not issue</b> the <b>decree. And when</b> Shmuel said that <b>the Sages did not issue</b> their <b>decree</b> with regard to the liquids of the slaughterhouse, he meant that they did not do so with regard to their capacity <b>to transmit impurity to other</b> items; <b>however,</b> as far as <b>their own impurity</b> is concerned, <b>they become</b> impure like other liquids.
<b>Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana said to his son: When you enter before Rav Pappa, raise</b> the following <b>contradiction before him: Did Shmuel</b> actually <b>say</b> that the liquids are <b>ritually pure</b> in the sense that they do not <b>transmit impurity to other</b> items <b>but they themselves are</b> susceptible to <b>impurity?</b> Is there anything that by Torah law can itself become impure but does not transmit impurity to other items? <b>Read here</b> a verse that clearly states that any item that is itself impure, including liquids, transmits impurity to other items: <b>“And the flesh that touches anything impure shall not be eaten;</b> it shall be burnt in fire” (Leviticus 7:19).
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> The legal status of liquids is <b>just as it is</b> in the case <b>of fourth-</b>degree ritual impurity <b>in a consecrated</b> item, with regard to which everyone agrees that it becomes impure but does not transmit impurity to other items. <b>Rav Ashi strongly objects to this</b> contention: How is it possible to compare these two cases? <b>Fourth-</b>degree impurity <b>in</b> a <b>consecrated</b> item <b>is not called impure;</b> it is disqualified. However, <b>this</b> liquid <b>is called impure.</b> Therefore, the two <i>halakhot</i> are not comparable. No resolution is found for this contradiction, and the Gemara concludes that it is indeed <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara cites several sources to decide the dispute between the <i>tanna’im</i> and between Rav and Shmuel with regard to whether or not the impurity of liquids is by Torah law. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: “And all drink that may be drunk in any vessel shall be impure”</b> (Leviticus 11:34). This verse clearly indicates that liquids can become impure. The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the term: <b>Shall be impure,</b> in this context? It means that the liquid <b>renders</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity.
The Gemara retorts: Does it in fact mean that the liquid <b>renders</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? That cannot be as <b>you</b> already <b>learned</b> that <b>from the beginning of</b> this <b>verse: “From all food that may be eaten,</b> on which water has come shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:34). The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, the second part of the verse is also necessary: <b>One</b> part of the verse, the latter part, is referring <b>to</b> water <b>detached</b> from its source, in vessels, <b>and one</b> part, the former part, is referring <b>to</b> water still <b>attached</b> to its source in the ground.
<b>And</b> both derivations <b>are necessary,</b> as neither <i>halakha</i> could have been derived from the other. <b>As, had</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> only about the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> water <b>detached</b> from its source, one might have thought that this water renders food susceptible to ritual impurity <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he ascribed significance to</b> the water by drawing it from its source. <b>However,</b> with regard to water still <b>attached</b> to its source, say that it does <b>not</b> render food susceptible to ritual impurity.
<b>And had</b> the Torah <b>taught</b> only the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> water still <b>attached</b> to its source, one might have thought that <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it stands in its place</b> this water <b>is significant; however,</b> with regard to water <b>detached</b> from its source, <b>say no,</b> it does <b>not</b> render food susceptible to ritual impurity, as it is disconnected from its source. It was therefore <b>necessary</b> for the Torah to mention both cases.
The Gemara cites another proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: “However, a spring or a cistern, a gathering of water shall be pure,</b> but he who touches their carcass shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:36). It can be inferred from this verse that all water can be rendered impure, with the exception of spring water and water in a cistern, which are in the ground. The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>“Shall be pure”?</b> This phrase means that one who immerses in this water is purified <b>from his ritual impurity,</b> and does not refer to the impurity of liquids at all.
The Gemara stated that both water detached from its source and water still <b>attached</b> to its source render food susceptible to ritual impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> water <b>detached</b> from its source <b>render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to contract impurity? <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, say:</b> With regard to the <b>liquids of the slaughterhouse</b> in the Temple, <b>not only are they pure,</b> but <b>neither do they render</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? Apparently, water detached from its source does not render food susceptible to impurity by Torah law. The fact that the Sages suspend the capacity of certain liquids to render produce susceptible to impurity indicates that the fact that water removed from its source renders food susceptible to impurity must be by rabbinic decree. Otherwise, that capability could not have been suspended in the Temple.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Explain this</b> statement as referring <b>to blood.</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina was not referring to all liquids in the Temple, but only to blood. <b>As Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to blood of consecrated</b> offerings <b>that it does not render</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to impurity? <b>As it is stated:</b> “You shall surely not eat the blood; <b>you shall pour it upon the earth like water”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:16). The Sages derived from this verse: <b>Blood that is poured like water,</b> i.e., blood from a non-sacred domesticated animal that pours out when it is slaughtered and is not received in a vessel as sacrificial blood assumes the legal status of water and <b>renders</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity.

Daf 16b

Conversely, <b>blood that is not poured out like water</b> but is received in a vessel to be sprinkled on the altar <b>does not render</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to contract impurity. <b>Rav Shmuel bar Ami strongly objects to this: There is</b> the <b>blood squeezed</b> from an animal after slaughter once the initial spurt of blood has concluded, <b>which is poured like water,</b> as it is unfit for sprinkling upon the altar. <b>And</b> nevertheless, this blood <b>does not render</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to impurity.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to him: Leave</b> aside <b>the blood squeezed</b> after the initial spurt, which is an exceptional case, <b>as even from non-sacred</b> animals it <b>does not render</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>either.</b> With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that blood renders produce susceptible to ritual impurity, the legal status of blood squeezed after the initial spurt is not that of blood at all.
The Gemara comments: <b>Rav Shmuel bar Ami accepted this</b> statement <b>from</b> Rabbi Zeira and cited a verse that supports it. <b>As the Merciful One states: “Only be strong not to eat the blood; for the blood is the soul”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:23). This verse indicates: <b>Blood</b> with regard to which <b>the soul leaves</b> the body when it is spilled <b>is called blood;</b> however, <b>blood</b> with regard to which <b>the soul</b> does not <b>leave</b> the body when it is spilled, but which is squeezed out afterward, <b>is not called blood.</b>
The Gemara cites an additional proof that the impurity of liquids is by Torah law. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> With regard to <b>blood that became ritually impure, and</b> a priest <b>sprinkled it</b> on the altar, the following distinction applies: If he did so <b>unwittingly,</b> the offering <b>is accepted.</b> If he sprinkled the blood <b>intentionally,</b> the offering <b>is not accepted.</b> Apparently, blood becomes ritually impure by Torah law, even if it does not transmit impurity to other items. The Gemara rejects this contention: This impurity is <b>by rabbinic law, and</b> this ruling is <b>not in accordance with</b> Rav’s explanation of the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei ben Yo’ezer of Tzereida,</b> as he maintains that sacrificial blood does not become impure at all.
The Gemara cites a proof from another mishna. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: For what does the frontplate</b> of the High Priest <b>atone</b> and thereby allow the blood of the offering to be sprinkled? It atones <b>for the blood, and for the meat, and for the fat that became impure, whether</b> one caused it to become impure <b>unwittingly or intentionally, whether due to</b> circumstances <b>beyond</b> his <b>control or willfully,</b> and <b>whether</b> it is the offering <b>of an individual or</b> that <b>of a community.</b> Apparently, the blood of an offering can become impure.
The Gemara rejects this proof: The mishna is referring to blood that is impure <b>by rabbinic law, and</b> here too, it <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Yosei ben Yo’ezer of Tzereida,</b> who says that consecrated blood does not become impure at all.
The Gemara cites an additional proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another verse written about the frontplate: “And it shall be upon Aaron’s forehead, <b>and Aaron shall bear the sin committed with the consecrated</b> objects, which the children of Israel shall hallow, even all their sacred gifts; and it shall be always upon his forehead, that they may be accepted before God” (Exodus 28:38).
<b>And</b> the Sages expounded: <b>Which sin does it bear? If</b> you say it atones for <b>the sin of <i>piggul</i>,</b> an offering disqualified by the intention to sacrifice or eat the offering after the permitted time, <b>it is already stated:</b> “And if it is eaten at all on the third day, it is <i>piggul</i>; <b>it shall not be accepted”</b> (Leviticus 19:7). <b>If</b> you say it atones for <b><i>notar</i>,</b> i.e., meat of an offering left after the time that one was permitted to eat it, <b>it is already stated:</b> “And if any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace-offerings is eaten on the third day, it shall not be accepted, <b>neither shall it be credited</b> to he who offered it” (Leviticus 7:18).
Evidently, the frontplate <b>bears only the sin of impurity</b> in the offering of an individual, <b>as</b> in some circumstances, impurity <b>was exempted from its general</b> prohibition on behalf <b>of the community.</b> It was permitted to sacrifice communal offerings in the Temple in a state of impurity. <b>What, does</b> this <b>not</b> apply to <b>impure blood</b> as well? Apparently, blood can also become impure. <b>Rav Pappa said: No,</b> the reference is not to impure blood but to <b>the impurity of handfuls</b> of flour separated by the priest from a meal-offering. The handful of flour renders the meal-offering permitted to be eaten by the priests, parallel to the blood of an animal offering.
The Gemara cites an additional proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which was said to the prophet Haggai: “Thus said the Lord of Hosts: Ask now the priests with regard to the Torah, saying: <b>If a person bears hallowed flesh in the corner of his garment, and with his garment he touches bread, or stew, or wine, or oil, or any food, shall it be sacred? And the priests answered and said: No”</b> (Haggai 2:11–12). This question is asked with regard to the flesh of a creeping animal and whether or not the substances that come into contact with it become impure.

Daf 17a

<b>And Rav said: The priests erred</b> in this regard, as those substances are actually impure. This source indicates that along with the meat, the stew, wine, and oil, which are liquids, also become ritually impure. The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>This</b> difficulty <b>is reasonable only</b> according <b>to Rav,</b> and <b>Rav teaches</b> that the testimony of Yosei ben Yo’ezer was that <b>the liquids of the slaughterhouse,</b> blood and water associated with the slaughter of offerings, do not become ritually impure. <b>However,</b> Rav agrees that <b>the liquids of the chamber of the altar,</b> wine and oil that accompany the offering on the altar, can <b>become impure.</b> The rabbinic decree that liquids can become impure is not in effect with regard to the liquids of the Temple slaughterhouse, but it is in effect with regard to the liquids offered on the altar. Therefore, the liquids listed by Haggai can become impure and transmit impurity by rabbinic law.
Apropos Rav’s statement with regard to Haggai’s exchange with the priests, the Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav said: The priests erred,</b> as they should have said the oil is rendered impure. <b>And Shmuel said: The priests did not err.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rav said</b> that <b>the priests erred,</b> as Haggai <b>raised the dilemma before them</b> whether or not <b>consecrated</b> items become impure with <b>fourth-</b>degree ritual impurity. The question in the verse pertains to the following case: One is carrying a dead creeping animal in the corner of his garment and bread comes into contact with it, conferring upon the bread first-degree ritual impurity status; and stew comes in contact with the bread, conferring upon the stew second-degree ritual impurity status; and wine comes in contact with the stew, conferring upon the wine third-degree ritual impurity status; and oil comes into contact with the wine. The question is: In that case, does the wine confer upon the oil fourth-degree ritual impurity? <b>And</b> when <b>the priests said to him</b> that it is <b>pure,</b> they erred. In fact, the oil is disqualified with fourth-degree ritual impurity, because it is a consecrated item.
<b>And Shmuel said: The priests did not err,</b> as Haggai <b>raised the dilemma before them</b> whether or not <b>consecrated</b> items become impure with <b>fifth-</b>degree ritual impurity. According to Shmuel’s explanation, the case is as follows: The corner of the garment comes into contact with a dead creeping animal, conferring upon the garment first-degree ritual impurity status; bread comes into contact with the garment, conferring upon the bread second-degree ritual impurity status; stew comes in contact with the bread, conferring upon the stew third-degree ritual impurity status; and wine comes in contact with the stew, conferring upon the wine fourth-degree ritual impurity status; and oil comes into contact with the wine. In that case, does the wine confer upon the oil fifth-degree ritual impurity? <b>And</b> the priests correctly <b>said to him</b> that the oil is <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this dispute: <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, that is</b> the reason that it is <b>four</b> items <b>that are written</b> in the dilemma raised in the verse: <b>Bread, stew, wine, and oil,</b> as the dilemma pertains to fourth-degree ritual impurity. <b>However,</b> according <b>to Shmuel, from where does he</b> learn that the dilemma involves <b>five</b> items?
The Gemara explains Shmuel’s opinion. <b>Is it written</b> in the verse: <b>And its corner touched</b> the bread, indicating that the primary source of impurity that was in the corner of the garment touched the bread? <b>It is</b> actually <b>written</b> in the verse: <b>“And it touched the corner of his garment,”</b> meaning the bread came into contact <b>with that</b> which <b>touched</b> the primary source of ritual impurity that was in <b>the corner of his garment.</b> The bread came into contact with the corner of the garment, not with the primary source of impurity itself. Accordingly, the garment assumes first-degree ritual impurity status, which confers upon the bread second-degree ritual impurity status, which confers upon the stew third-degree ritual impurity status, which confers upon the wine fourth-degree ritual impurity status. Since the wine cannot confer fifth-degree ritual impurity status upon the oil, the oil remains pure.
The Gemara cites proof from the subsequent verse. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: “And Haggai said: If one who is impure with</b> impurity imparted by <b>a corpse touches any of these, shall he be impure? And the priests answered and said: He shall be impure”</b> (Haggai 2:13). <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to Shmuel, from</b> the fact that <b>here,</b> with regard to a dead creeping animal, the priests <b>did not err,</b> as Shmuel maintains that the dilemma was with regard to fifth-degree ritual impurity, <b>there too they did not err. However,</b> according <b>to Rav, what is different here,</b> concerning the impurity of a creeping animal, such <b>that</b> the priests <b>erred, and what is different there,</b> with regard to impurity imparted by a corpse, such <b>that they did not err?</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> The priests of Haggai’s era <b>were experts with regard to</b> the severe <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> as they knew that the impurity of a dead body confers upon a consecrated item fourth-degree ritual impurity status. However, <b>they were not experts with regard to the</b> lesser <b>impurity of a creeping animal.</b>
<b>Ravina said</b> that the distinction between the cases is different. <b>There,</b> the first dilemma addressed <b>fourth-</b>degree ritual impurity, whereas <b>here,</b> the dilemma addressed <b>third-</b>degree ritual impurity. Haggai’s second dilemma does not begin with contact with an item that came into contact with a corpse; rather, it begins with contact with the corpse itself. Since a corpse is the ultimate primary source of impurity, the fourth item is impure with third-degree ritual impurity. The priests knew that <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this matter from the next verse: <b>“And Haggai answered and said: So is this people, and so is this nation before me, said God;</b> and so is all the work of their hands; and that which they offer there is impure” (Haggai 2:14). <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> that the priests erred, <b>that is</b> the reason <b>that it is written:</b> “That which they offer there is <b>impure,”</b> as the priests’ lack of familiarity with the <i>halakhot</i> of impurity increase the likelihood that all of their Temple service is ritually impure. <b>However,</b> according <b>to Shmuel, why</b> does the verse say that their offerings are <b>ritually impure?</b>
The Gemara answers: According to Shmuel, this is not a statement. Rather, the verse <b>is</b> a rhetorical question expressing <b>bewilderment:</b> Is all the Temple service of the priests really impure? Apparently, they are familiar with the <i>halakhot</i> of impurity. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it written</b> in that verse: <b>“And so is all the work of their hands,”</b> which is a statement, not a question? <b>Mar Zutra, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Ashi, said: Since they corrupted their deeds</b> by sinning in general, <b>the verse ascribes to them</b> wrongdoing <b>as if they sacrificed offerings in</b> a state of <b>impurity.</b>
Apropos the two versions of Yosei ben Yo’ezer’s testimony that the liquids in the Temple are ritually pure, the Gemara addresses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav teaches</b> that Yosei ben Yo’ezer spoke of <b>the liquids of the slaughterhouse,</b> blood and water, <b>and Levi taught</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>the liquids of the altar,</b> which include the wine of libations and oil of meal-offerings in addition to blood and water.
The Gemara comments: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Levi, this</b> works out <b>well if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, who said</b> that Yosei ben Yo’ezer testified that the liquids are <b>ritually pure</b> in the sense that they do not <b>transmit impurity to other</b> items <b>but they themselves</b> can <b>become impure.</b> In that case, <b>you</b> can <b>find</b> a scenario for Haggai’s second question; <b>all</b> the substances mentioned <b>made contact</b> with an object with first-degree ritual impurity status. Levi can explain that the prophet’s dilemma is not in a case where the different items came into contact with each other, as he is of the opinion that liquids do not transmit impurity. Rather, the stew, wine, and oil each came in contact with an object with first-degree impurity, in accordance with Shmuel’s opinion that consecrated liquids themselves can become impure. Accordingly, the priests answered that these objects are impure.
<b>However,</b> if Levi <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> that the liquids are <b>actually ritually pure, under what circumstances can</b> a scenario in which wine and oil, liquids offered on the altar, can become ritually impure <b>be found?</b> Rather, <b>perforce</b> you must say that <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel</b> with regard to the meaning of the term pure in this context.
The Gemara continues: <b>And</b> according <b>to Shmuel, this</b> works out <b>well if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, who taught</b> that the decree to which Yosei ben Yo’ezer testified was issued with regard to <b>the liquids of the slaughterhouse, but the other liquids of the altar transmit impurity as well.</b> If that is Shmuel’s opinion he can explain Haggai’s dilemma, as <b>it is</b> only an item with <b>fourth-</b>degree impurity status <b>that does not render</b> another item impure with <b>fifth-</b>degree ritual impurity. However, an item with third-degree impurity status <b>renders</b> another item impure with <b>fourth-</b>degree ritual impurity.
<b>However, if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Levi, who taught</b> that <b>the liquids of the altar,</b> including wine and oil, do not transmit impurity, <b>why</b> does Haggai <b>specifically</b> state that a liquid with <b>fourth-</b>degree impurity status <b>does not render</b> another liquid impure with <b>fifth-</b>degree ritual impurity? Even if these liquids had first- or second-degree ritual impurity status, they <b>do not render</b> another item impure with <b>second- and third-</b>degree ritual impurity, as Levi maintains that consecrated liquids do not transmit impurity at all. Rather, <b>perforce he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> with regard to the object of Yosei ben Yo’ezer’s decree.
The Gemara cites a source in support of each version, as <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> and <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Levi.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Levi:</b> With regard to <b>the blood, the wine, the oil, and the water,</b> in the case of all <b>liquids of the altar that became ritually impure inside</b> the Temple <b>and</b> one <b>took them outside, they are pure</b> in the sense that they do not transmit impurity to other objects. This is because when they were within the Temple confines that more stringent form of impurity did not take effect. However, <b>if they became impure outside</b> the Temple <b>and</b> one <b>took them inside</b> the Temple, <b>they are impure</b> even in terms of transmitting impurity to other items, as they too retain their prior level of impurity.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi say:</b> With regard to <b>the liquids of the altar,</b> the Sages <b>said they are ritually pure only in their place. What, does</b> this statement <b>not</b> come <b>to exclude liquids that became impure inside</b> the Temple <b>and</b> one <b>took them outside,</b> as in that case once they left the Temple they would be retroactively impure in terms of transmitting impurity? This contradicts the Gemara’s previous assertion. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the statement comes <b>to exclude</b> liquids <b>that became impure outside</b> the Temple <b>and</b> one <b>brought them inside.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Didn’t</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>say: In their place,</b> indicating that these liquids are pure in terms of transmitting impurity only if they remain inside the Temple? The Gemara answers that <b>this is</b> what Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>is saying:</b> The Sages <b>said they are pure only</b> with regard <b>to those</b> liquids <b>that became impure in their place,</b> not with regard to those that became impure elsewhere and were brought into the Temple. In any case, the language of the <i>baraita</i> clearly indicates that the legal status of wine and oil is like that of other sacred liquids, in accordance with the opinion of Levi.
And it <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav: The blood and the water, the liquids of the slaughterhouse, that became ritually impure, whether</b> they were <b>in vessels or on the ground, are pure.</b>

Daf 17b

<b>Rabban Shimon says:</b> If the liquids were <b>in vessels,</b> they are <b>ritually impure;</b> however, if they were <b>in the ground,</b> they are <b>ritually pure,</b> as explained below.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Even according to the one who says</b> that in general <b>the ritual impurity of liquids</b> is <b>by Torah law,</b> the purity of <b>the liquids of the</b> Temple <b>slaughterhouse is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, which the Sages <b>learned through tradition. Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to Rav Pappa: But</b> with regard to <b>that which Rabbi Eliezer said: There is no impurity for liquids at all</b> by Torah law, <b>know</b> that this is so, <b>as Yosei ben Yo’ezer of Tzereida testified about liquids</b> in <b>the slaughterhouse</b> in the Temple that they were <b>ritually pure.</b> This statement indicates that liquids become impure only by rabbinic decree, a decree that is not in effect in the Temple.
Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, continued: <b>And if they learned</b> the ritual purity of liquids of the slaughterhouse as <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai <b>through tradition, do we derive</b> other <i>halakhot</i> <b>from it?</b> There is a principle that one cannot derive halakhic principles from <i>halakhot</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai. How, then, could Rabbi Eliezer cite this <i>halakha</i> as a proof for his opinion?
Furthermore, <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi,</b> also in rejection of Rav Pappa’s statement: <b>Isn’t it Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that in general <b>the ritual impurity of liquids</b> is <b>by Torah law? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> With regard <b>to vessels</b> that came into contact with impure liquid, the vessels <b>are pure,</b> as by Torah law liquids do not transmit impurity to vessels. However, with regard <b>to foods</b> that came into contact with impure liquid, the foods are <b>impure,</b> as by Torah law liquids transmit impurity to foods.
Ravina continues: <b>And</b> yet <b>here,</b> with regard to the liquids in the Temple, <b>Rabban Shimon said:</b> Liquids <b>in vessels are ritually impure,</b> and liquids <b>in the ground are pure. And if</b> you say that the purity of the liquids of the Temple slaughterhouse <b>is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> if the liquids are <b>in vessels</b> and <b>what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> if the liquids are <b>in the ground?</b> If there is an accepted halakhic tradition that ritual impurity does not apply to these liquids, there should be no difference whether the liquid is in vessels or in the ground. The Gemara comments: Indeed, it is <b>difficult</b> according to Rav Pappa’s opinion.
<b>Rav Pappa said: That</b> which <b>you said,</b> that the liquids in the Temple <b>are ritually pure</b> when <b>in the ground,</b> the Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to <b>water, but</b> with regard to <b>blood, no,</b> it does not apply. According to Rabbi Shimon, blood can become impure even in the ground.
<b>And even</b> with regard to <b>water, we said</b> that it is ritually pure <b>only when it is a quarter-</b><i>log</i>, <b>which is a suitable</b> measure <b>in which to immerse needles and hooks.</b> By Torah law, a quarter-<i>log</i> of water collected in one place can serve as a ritual bath in which one can immerse objects that can be completely immersed in that amount of water. Because it has the status of a ritual bath, it too does not become ritually impure. Although the Sages decreed that one should not immerse vessels in a quarter-log of water, the water is pure by Torah law. Therefore, the Sages did not extend their decree to this measure of water inside the Temple. <b>However,</b> if the water <b>is less than a quarter-</b><i>log</i>, it is <b>ritually impure</b> even in the ground, as that water cannot be used as a ritual bath.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited above, with regard to uncertainty about contact with impure liquids, that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> They are <b>impure in all</b> cases. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that Rabbi Yehuda maintains</b> that <b>the impurity</b> of <b>liquids</b> in terms of their capability <b>to transmit impurity to vessels</b> is <b>by Torah law?</b>
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>all vessels that have an exterior</b> that can be used <b>and an interior</b> that serves as a receptacle, <b>such as cushions, blankets, sacks, and leather</b> grain <b>sacks,</b> if the <b>interior of</b> one of these vessels <b>became ritually impure, its exterior is impure</b> as well. However, if <b>its exterior became impure, its interior is not impure,</b> because the primary use of these vessels is as a receptacle.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is in a case <b>where</b> the vessels <b>became impure due to</b> contact with impure <b>liquids. However,</b> if <b>they became impure due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal,</b> then if <b>the interior became impure the exterior is impure,</b> and likewise, if <b>the exterior became impure the interior is</b> also <b>impure.</b>
The Gemara explains the difficulty posed by Rabbi Yehuda’s statement in this mishna: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that <b>the ritual impurity of liquids</b> with regard to their capacity <b>to transmit impurity to vessels</b> is <b>by Torah law, what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> if the vessel <b>is rendered impure due to liquids,</b> and <b>what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> if the vessel <b>is rendered impure due to a creeping animal?</b> Rather, Rabbi Yehuda maintains that the impurity of liquids is by rabbinic law, and the Sages distinguished between the impurity of the exterior and interior of a vessel to distinguish between impurity by Torah law and impurity by rabbinic law and prevent the burning of <i>teruma</i> that is impure with impurity by rabbinic law. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Rabbi Yehuda retracted</b> his previous statement in the <i>baraita</i> and accepted the ruling that the impurity of liquids is only by rabbinic decree.
<b>Ravina said: Actually,</b> it is possible that Rabbi Yehuda <b>did not retract</b> his previous statement, as <b>this</b> case, where he distinguishes between impurity on the interior and the exterior of vessels, was stated with regard <b>to liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with impure <b>hands</b> that did not undergo ritual washing. Unwashed hands are impure by rabbinic decree, and therefore the impurity of such liquid is likewise rabbinic. Conversely, <b>that</b> case, where the impurity of liquids is by Torah law, was stated with regard <b>to liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal.</b> As that impurity is by Torah law, no distinction is made between the interior and exterior of vessels.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, instead of teaching: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case where the vessels <b>were rendered impure due to</b> contact with <b>liquids,</b> as opposed to the other case in which the vessels became impure due to contact with creeping animals, <b>let him distinguish and teach</b> the distinction <b>within</b> the case <b>itself: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is in a case where these vessels <b>became impure by</b> contact with <b>liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with impure <b>hands. However,</b> in a case where these vessels <b>became impure by</b> contact with <b>liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal,</b> if <b>the interior became impure, the exterior is impure,</b> and if <b>the exterior became impure, the interior is</b> likewise <b>impure. Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects Ravina’s explanation and states that <b>it is clear as we initially answered,</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda retracted</b> his previous ruling.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Was <b>it</b> only <b>from</b> his ruling with regard to liquids that transmitted ritual impurity to <b>vessels</b> by Torah law <b>that</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>retracted</b> his opinion, <b>but with regard to foods he</b> still <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon,</b> that liquids transmit impurity to foods by Torah law? <b>Or perhaps he completely retracted</b> his previous opinion, and Rabbi Yehuda in fact holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who rules that there is no Torah basis for the impurity of liquids.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from a mishna: With regard to <b>a cow that drank purification waters</b> in which the ashes of the red heifer were mixed and which were to be sprinkled on one who was ritually impure with impurity imparted by a corpse, and the cow was slaughtered before it digested the water, <b>its flesh is impure</b> due to contact with this water. Pure items that come in contact with the purification waters become impure, as derived from a verse. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b>

Daf 18a

The purification waters <b>are nullified in its innards</b> and do not impurify the meat of the cow. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that it was <b>from</b> his ruling with regard to liquids transmitting impurity to <b>vessels</b> by Torah law <b>that</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>retracted</b> his opinion, <b>but with regard to foods he holds in accordance with</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon</b> that liquids transmit ritual impurity to food by Torah law, <b>why</b> does he say that the purification waters <b>are nullified in its innards entirely</b> and no longer transfer impurity at all?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Although</b> these waters <b>do not transmit a severe</b> form of <b>ritual impurity</b> to a person or vessel that comes into contact with them, <b>in any event let them transmit a lesser</b> form of <b>impurity</b> to food that comes into contact with them. Rabbi Yehuda’s ruling with regard to the purification waters indicates that he retracted his previous opinion entirely and he maintains that there is no impurity of liquids by Torah law at all. Since this impurity is by rabbinic law, the Sages did not extend their decree to the uncommon circumstance of the purification waters.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>What, too, is</b> the meaning of Rabbi Yehuda’s phrase: <b>They are nullified in its innards? It</b> means that <b>they are nullified</b> only <b>from a severe</b> form of <b>impurity. However,</b> according to Rabbi Yehuda, the purification waters <b>transmit a lesser form of impurity.</b> This proves <b>by inference that the first <i>tanna</i> maintains</b> that the purification waters <b>also transmit a severe</b> form of <b>impurity</b> to people and vessels. This is a problematic conclusion, as the first <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: Its flesh is impure,</b> which clearly indicates that its flesh alone is impure, whereas the purification waters swallowed by the cow do not transmit impurity to people or vessels. The result is that according to this approach, there is no difference between the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and the first <i>tanna</i>.
The Gemara answers: The <b>entire</b> mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> the mishna <b>is incomplete and is teaching the following:</b> With regard to <b>a cow that drank the purification waters, its flesh is impure.
