In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said with regard to <b>a lesser</b> form of <b>impurity, but</b> with regard to <b>a severe</b> form of <b>purity, no,</b> its flesh is not impure, <b>as Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The waters <b>are nullified in its innards</b> and their status is no longer that of purification waters. Instead, their impurity is by rabbinic law, like any other liquid.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Actually,</b> it is possible to explain that the waters <b>are nullified in its innards entirely</b> from any type of impurity, as this issue is unrelated to the question of whether the impurity of liquids is by Torah law or rabbinic law. Rather, this <i>halakha</i> is <b>due to</b> the fact that purification waters <b>become a foul liquid</b> when ingested, and the principle is that offensive liquid can neither be rendered impure itself nor transfer impurity to other items.
It was taught in the <i>baraita</i> about uncertainty as to the impurity of liquids that <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> With regard <b>to foods</b> that came into contact with impure liquid, the foods <b>are impure.</b> However, with regard <b>to vessels</b> that came into contact with impure liquid, the vessels <b>are pure. Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish said: Rabbi Yosei said</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, his teacher, who interpreted</b> the term <b><i>yitma</i>,</b> which is an intransitive verb in the simple conjugation meaning: <b>It shall be impure,</b> as though it were written <b><i>yetamme</i>,</b> a transitive verb in the intensive conjugation meaning: <b>It shall render impure,</b> i.e., it transmits impurity to other items.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>On that day,</b> when they appointed Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya the <i>Nasi</i>, <b>Rabbi Akiva taught: “And every earthenware vessel</b> into which <b>any of them</b> falls, whatever is in it shall be impure [<i>yitma</i>], and you shall break it” (Leviticus 11:33). The verse <b>does not say: It is impure [<i>tameh</i>]; rather,</b> it says: <b>It shall be impure [<i>yitma</i>],</b> indicating that an item in an impure earthenware vessel <b>transmits impurity to other</b> items. <b>This</b> verse <b>teaches about a loaf</b> with <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity status, i.e., ritual impurity imparted through contact with a vessel impurified by a creeping animal, <b>that</b> the loaf <b>renders</b> other items impure with <b>third-</b>degree ritual impurity, even <b>non-sacred</b> items.
The Gemara inquires: <b>And here,</b> with regard to the ritual impurity of liquids, <b>how does</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>interpret</b> the verses? The Gemara cites the verse: “From all food which may be eaten, upon which water has come, shall be impure; <b>and all drink that may be drunk in every vessel, shall be impure [<i>yitma</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 11:34). Rabbi Yosei interprets the end of the verse as: <b>Shall render impure [<i>yetamme</i>],</b> indicating that liquid also <b>transmits impurity to foods.</b> The Gemara discusses this derivation: Do <b>you say</b> that this expression teaches that liquid <b>transmits ritual impurity to foods, or perhaps</b> the verse <b>is</b> teaching <b>only</b> that <b>it transmits impurity to</b> other <b>liquids,</b> but not to food? <b>You said</b> in response: <b>That was not</b> the correct interpretation.
The Gemara wonders about the unusual expression. <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>That was not</b> the correct interpretation? How can this difficulty be dismissed so easily? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It means that <b>we did not find</b> any case of <b>ritual impurity that renders a similar</b> item impure. Therefore, it must be that the verse teaches that this liquid transmits impurity to food.
<b>Ravina said: From</b> an analysis of <b>the verse itself you also cannot say</b> that the term: <b>Shall be impure,</b> means that the liquid <b>transmits ritual impurity</b> only to <b>liquids. As, if it enters your mind</b> to say that the term: <b>Shall be impure, in the latter</b> portion of the verse means that <b>it transmits ritual impurity</b> only to <b>liquids,</b> then the term: <b>Shall be impure, in the first</b> portion of the verse, in reference to food, should <b>also</b> mean that <b>it transmits ritual impurity</b> only to <b>liquids.</b> And if that is so, <b>let</b> the verse <b>combine</b> the two cases <b>and write them</b> together as follows: <b>From all food which may be eaten, upon which water has come, and all drink that may be drunk in every vessel, shall be impure.</b>
Ravina concludes his proof: <b>Why do I</b> need the term: <b>Shall be impure, twice? Rather,</b> it must be that the term: <b>Shall be impure, in the first</b> portion of the verse teaches that food <b>transmits ritual impurity</b> to <b>liquids,</b> while the term: <b>Shall be impure, in the latter</b> portion of the verse teaches that liquid <b>transmits ritual impurity</b> to <b>food.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that the term teaches that liquid <b>transmits ritual impurity to vessels.</b> The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>And isn’t it an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? <b>Just as</b> an impure <b>vessel, which transmits impurity to liquid</b> that comes into contact with it, nevertheless <b>does not transmit impurity to</b> another <b>vessel,</b> so too, <b>liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a vessel, is it not right that they</b> should <b>not transmit impurity to vessels?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>And say that when</b> liquids <b>do not transmit ritual impurity</b> to a vessel, that is in the case of <b>liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with an impure <b>vessel,</b> as the vessel itself does not transmit impurity to another vessel. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal,</b> a more severe form of impurity, <b>indeed, they</b> should <b>transmit impurity</b> even to vessels. The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Are liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal stated</b> explicitly in the Torah? The impure liquids mentioned in the verse became impure by contact with a vessel that came into contact with a dead creeping animal.

Daf 18b

The Gemara asks: <b>And doesn’t</b> the impurity of liquids that came into contact with a creeping animal <b>come from an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a vessel,</b> which itself became impure due to contact with a creeping animal, <b>transmit impurity,</b> with regard to <b>liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that they transmit impurity to a vessel?
The Gemara answers: Since the basic <i>halakha</i> of these liquids is derived by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, no stringencies are added to it, in accordance with the principle: <b>It is sufficient [<i>dayyo</i>]</b> for the conclusion that <b>emerged from the</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference</b> to <b>be like the source of the inference.</b> In other words, a <i>halakha</i> derived by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference is no more stringent than the source from which it is derived. In this case, liquid that became impure through contact with a creeping animal transmits impurity to the same extent that liquid that became impure through contact with a vessel does.
The Gemara asks: <b>How does</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>interpret</b> the term: <b>Shall be impure, in the first</b> portion of the verse: <b>“From all food which may be eaten, upon which water has come, shall be impure”</b> (Leviticus 11:34)? He interprets the term: <b>Shall be impure,</b> as: Shall render impure. Food <b>transmits ritual impurity to liquids.</b> Do <b>you say</b> that the term teaches that food <b>transmits impurity to liquids, or perhaps</b> the term teaches <b>only</b> that food <b>transmits impurity to a vessel?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>You</b> can <b>say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that negates this possibility: <b>Just as liquid, which transmits impurity to food, does not transmit impurity to a vessel,</b> with regard to <b>food, which does not transmit impurity to food, is it not right that it</b> should <b>not transmit impurity to a vessel?</b> If so, <b>how</b> then <b>do I establish</b> the meaning of the term: <b>Shall be impure,</b> which in this context indicates that food impurifies other items? This term indicates that food <b>transmits impurity to liquids, which are susceptible to contracting impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Why did</b> Rabbi Akiva mention <b>specifically</b> that food impurifies <b>liquids due to</b> the fact that <b>they are susceptible to contracting impurity? Let him derive</b> this proof from the simple fact <b>that there is no other item</b> that food could render impure. As food does not transmit impurity to food, the only remaining alternative is that food impurifies liquids.
The Gemara answers that <b>this is</b> what Rabbi Akiva <b>is saying: And lest you say</b> that the impurity of <b>food is severe,</b> as evidenced by the fact <b>that</b> it <b>transmits ritual impurity to liquids</b> despite the fact that liquids do not transfer impurity to other liquids, and therefore <b>let</b> food <b>transmit impurity to a vessel,</b> despite the fact that liquid does not transmit impurity to a vessel; therefore, the Gemara states <b>that</b> the fact that food transmits impurity to liquids <b>is</b> actually <b>a stringency</b> characteristic of <b>liquids,</b> not of food. The impurity of food is not more severe than that of liquids; rather, food transmits impurity to liquids <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that liquids</b> are <b>susceptible to contracting impurity.</b>
<b>And</b> in <b>what</b> manner <b>is their susceptibility</b> manifest? It is manifest in the fact <b>that they become ritually impure without</b> being first rendered <b>susceptible</b> to impurity. Foods can become impure only after first coming into contact with one of seven liquids. Liquids do not require any preparatory stage before becoming impure.
<b>Is</b> the principle: <b>Shall be impure</b> teaches <b>that</b> ritual impurity <b>does not render a similar</b> item impure, e.g., that food does not transfer ritual impurity to other food, <b>derived from here?</b> It is <b>derived from there: “But if water is put upon the seed, and any of their carcass falls upon it, it is impure for you”</b> (Leviticus 11:38), from which it is inferred: <b>It is impure;</b> however, <b>it does not transmit impurity</b> to a <b>similar</b> item. Why is an additional source necessary to teach this same principle? The Gemara explains: Both verses are necessary, as <b>one</b> refers <b>to liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal,</b> while <b>one</b> verse refers <b>to liquids that come to</b> a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with an impure <b>vessel.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> both verses <b>are necessary,</b> as neither of the <i>halakhot</i> could have been derived from the other. <b>As, had</b> the verse <b>taught us</b> only the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to liquids that come</b> to a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a vessel,</b> one might have thought that liquids do not transfer impurity to similar items only <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>their</b> impurity is <b>not severe,</b> as it did not result from contact with a primary source of impurity; <b>however, with regard to liquids that come</b> to a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal, which are</b> impure with a <b>severe</b> form of impurity that resulted from contact with a primary source of impurity, <b>say that</b> they <b>transmit impurity</b> to a <b>similar</b> item.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the verse <b>teach us</b> that liquids do not transmit impurity with regard to <b>liquids that come</b> to a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal, and all the more so</b> will that be the case with regard to <b>liquids that come</b> to a state of impurity <b>due to</b> contact with <b>a vessel.</b> The Gemara answers: This is not difficult, as at times with regard to <b>a matter that</b> could be <b>derived by</b> means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, the verse</b> nevertheless <b>unnecessarily wrote it</b> explicitly.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: But didn’t Rava say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> with regard to the third-degree ritual impurity status of non-sacred items? Contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, Rabbi Yosei maintains that an item with second-degree ritual impurity does not confer third-degree impurity status upon non-sacred items by Torah law.
<b>And</b> similarly, <b>Rabbi Akiva does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> with regard to the fourth-degree impurity of consecrated property. The relevance of these observations to the issue at hand is that if Rabbi Yosei maintains that the impurity of liquids is by Torah law, he evidently interprets the verse as: <i>Yetamme</i>, just as Rabbi Akiva does. However, in that case, he would also hold that second-degree ritual impurity confers upon another non-sacred item third-degree impurity status, as that <i>halakha</i> is also derived from the term: <i>Yetamme</i>.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Rabbi Yosei said</b> this <i>halakha</i> that liquids transmit impurity by Torah law <b>in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, his teacher;</b> however, <b>he himself does not hold</b> accordingly, as Rabbi Yosei is of the opinion that liquids do not transmit impurity to other items by Torah law.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana</b> with regard to Rava’s statement: <b>Granted, Rabbi Yosei does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei said: From where</b> is it derived with regard <b>to a consecrated</b> item with <b>fourth-</b>degree ritual impurity <b>that it is</b> only <b>disqualified</b> and does not transfer impurity to other objects?
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is a logical</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: Just as one who lacks atonement,</b> e.g., a <i>zav</i> or leper who immersed at the conclusion of his period of impurity but has not yet brought an offering for his atonement, <b>who is permitted</b> to eat <b><i>teruma</i>, disqualifies</b> a <b>consecrated</b> item if he comes into contact with it, with regard to <b>third-</b>degree ritual impurity, <b>which disqualifies <i>teruma</i>,</b> and in that way is more severe than one who lacks atonement, <b>is it not right that it</b> should <b>confer fourth-</b>degree ritual impurity status <b>upon a consecrated</b> item? The status of an item with third-degree ritual impurity should be no less severe than that of a person who lacks atonement.
The Gemara notes: <b>And we derived third-</b>degree impurity <b>with regard to consecrated</b> items <b>from the Torah, and fourth-</b>degree impurity of consecrated items <b>by</b> means of the above <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference.</b> In light of the <i>dayyo</i> principle, one might have thought that this <i>a fortiori</i> inference cannot serve as the basis of the <i>halakha</i> that consecrated property can assume fourth-degree impurity status. Since the source of this inference is third-degree impurity status, the conclusion that emerges can be only that consecrated objects can assume third-degree impurity status, like <i>teruma</i> itself. The Gemara explains that the <i>dayyo</i> principle does not apply in this case. If the <i>a fortiori</i> inference is rendered moot as a result of applying that principle, the principle is not applied. Because the fact that consecrated objects can assume third-degree impurity status is derived from the verse, if that which emerges from the inference is that <i>halakha</i> itself, the <i>a fortiori</i> inference is moot. Therefore, the principle does not apply and the fact that consecrated objects can assume fourth-degree impurity status is derived from the inference.
The Gemara elaborates. The fact that consecrated objects can assume third-degree impurity status is derived <b>from the Torah, as it is written: “And the flesh that touches</b>

Daf 19a

<b>any impure thing shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 7:19). <b>Are we not dealing</b> even with a case <b>where</b> meat <b>touched</b> an object that was ritually impure with <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity? And nevertheless, the verse states explicitly that it is impure and assumes third-degree ritual impurity status. No other source is needed to teach that consecrated objects can assume third-degree ritual impurity status. Therefore, <b>fourth-</b>degree impurity status can be derived <b>by</b> means of the <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, <b>as we stated</b> above.
The Gemara returns to its previous point: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that Rabbi Yosei <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> that non-sacred objects can assume third-degree impurity status, <b>let him also teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>fourth</b> degree of impurity <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i>, and</b> the <b>fifth</b> degree <b>with regard to consecrated</b> items, on the basis of that same <i>a fortiori</i> inference. The fact that he does not extend the <i>a fortiori</i> inference to include these <i>halakhot</i> proves that Rabbi Yosei does not agree with Rabbi Akiva’s opinion on this issue.
<b>However,</b> with regard to the fact that <b>Rabbi Akiva does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, from where do we</b> derive this? Perhaps he accepts Rabbi Yosei’s <i>a fortiori</i> inference and holds that <i>teruma</i> assumes fourth-degree impurity status and consecrated items assume fifth-degree impurity status.
Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi that there is indirect proof that this is the case. <b>As it is not</b> possible <b>to avoid</b> finding at least one <b><i>tanna</i> who teaches fourth-</b>degree impurity with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> and fifth-degree impurity with regard to <b>consecrated</b> items, <b>and says</b> that <b>this is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who derived it from the <i>a fortiori</i> inference of Rabbi Yosei. In response to this claim, the Gemara asks: <b>And will we stand and rely on that</b> proof? Can proof for Rabbi Akiva’s opinion be cited from the fact that no such <i>tanna</i> was found? Perhaps there is some source for that <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rav Ashi, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Kahana, left</b> the study hall to examine this matter. <b>He analyzed</b> the issue <b>and found</b> proof positive that Rabbi Akiva does not hold that there is fifth-degree impurity with regard to consecrated items. He proved this from <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A vessel joins that which is in it</b> into a single unit. For example, if there are fruits in a vessel between which there is no contact and one of them became ritually impure, all of the fruits are impure, as they are joined by the vessel. This principle applies <b>with regard to consecrated property, but not with regard to <i>teruma</i>. And the fourth</b> degree of impurity <b>disqualifies consecrated</b> items but does not transmit impurity, <b>while third-</b>degree impurity disqualifies <b><i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is <b>from the testimony of Rabbi Akiva</b> that <b>this mishna is taught, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Akiva added</b> in his testimony with regard to <b>the</b> fine <b>flour, the incense, the frankincense, and the coals</b> on the altar, which are not foods and do not ordinarily become impure, <b>that if</b> a person <b>who immersed during that day,</b> who disqualifies consecrated items, <b>touches some of them, he disqualifies all of them,</b> as the vessel joins them into one unit.
This <i>baraita</i>, which is the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, states that with regard to <b>fourth-</b>degree impurity, <b>yes,</b> consecrated objects assume that status; however, with regard to <b>fifth-</b>degree impurity, <b>no,</b> consecrated objects do not assume that status. With regard to <b>third-</b>degree impurity, <b>yes,</b> <i>teruma</i> assumes that status; however, with regard to <b>fourth-</b>degree impurity, <b>no,</b> <i>teruma</i> does not assume that status.
The Gemara comments: <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>holds</b> that <b>joining</b> in a single vessel, of frankincense, incense, or coals, is a <i>halakha</i> <b>by rabbinic law,</b> not by Torah law, as the ritual impurity of frankincense and coals is by rabbinic law. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>disputes that</b> statement of <b>Rabbi Ḥanin, who said: Joining</b> in a vessel is a <i>halakha</i> <b>by Torah law, as it is stated: “One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense”</b> (Numbers 7:20). <b>The verse rendered everything in the spoon,</b> i.e., all the incense, as <b>one</b> entity.
Apropos ritual purity and impurity in the Temple, the Gemara cites that <b>we learned</b> in a mishna <b>there:</b> The Sages testified <b>about</b> the case of <b>a needle that was found in the meat</b> of an animal that was led through water, <b>that the knife and the hands</b> that touched the needle <b>are ritually pure but the meat is impure,</b> as the needle might have been impure. If the needle <b>was found in the secretions</b> of the animal’s stomach, <b>everything is pure,</b> as secretions do not transfer impurity to the meat. <b>Rabbi Akiva said: We were privileged</b> to learn a novel <i>halakha</i> from here, which is <b>that there is no impurity of hands in the Temple</b> as in this case the hands did not become impure upon contact with the needle.

Daf 19b

The Gemara asks: <b>And let us say</b> that Rabbi Akiva says that we learn from here <b>that there is no ritual impurity of hands and vessels in the Temple,</b> as the mishna says that the knife which touched the needle is also pure. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina:</b> The testimony that there is no ritual impurity for <b>hands was taught prior to the decree</b> of impurity <b>for vessels</b> that came in contact with impure liquids outside the Temple. Therefore, there was no novelty in the fact that there is no ritual impurity of vessels in the Temple.
<b>Rava said: But weren’t both decrees issued on the same day? As we learned</b> in a mishna: The impurity of a Torah <b>scroll</b> and other sacred scrolls, <b>and</b> the impurity of <b>hands</b> that were not washed or immersed, <b>and</b> the impurity of <b>one who immersed himself during that day, and</b> the impurity of <b>foods and vessels that became impure by</b> contact with impure <b>liquids,</b> all these are included in the eighteen matters with regard to which decrees were issued on the same day.
<b>Rather, Rava said: Leave the impurity of</b> the <b>knife, as even</b> outside the Temple <b>in non-sacred</b> circumstances <b>it does not become impure.</b> As in the case of <b>this knife, what did it touch</b> that could transmit impurity? <b>If you say that it touched the meat, food does not transmit impurity to a vessel.</b> If you say, <b>rather, that it touched the needle, a vessel does not transmit impurity to</b> another <b>vessel.</b>
With regard to <b>this needle,</b> the Gemara asks: <b>What is its</b> impurity <b>status? If we say</b> that there is <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to the impurity of the <b>needle, wasn’t it stated</b> that there is a dispute between <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina? One said:</b> The Sages <b>did not issue a decree</b> in the case of <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to the impurity of <b>spittle that is</b> found <b>in Jerusalem.</b> Any spittle found outside of Jerusalem might have come from a <i>zav</i> or from a gentile, whose legal status in this regard is like that of a <i>zav</i>. The Sages decreed that any contact with this spittle should be treated as uncertain contact with a primary source of ritual impurity. That decree was not issued with regard to spittle found in Jerusalem. <b>And one said:</b> The Sages <b>did not issue a decree</b> in the case of <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to the impurity of <b>vessels in Jerusalem.</b> As opposed to the situation outside of Jerusalem, there is no presumption of impurity with regard to vessels found in Jerusalem, including a needle.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where one lost a needle</b> that became impure through contact with a person or vessel impure with <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted <b>by a corpse.</b> Since the needle is a metal utensil, it assumes the same degree of impurity as the source of its impurity, in this case a primary source of impurity. <b>And he</b> then <b>recognized</b> the needle <b>in the meat</b> of the offering. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Avin, said:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where the cow was muzzled as it came from outside of Jerusalem.</b> The needle is clearly from outside of Jerusalem, and in all cases of uncertainty with regard to vessels outside of Jerusalem the ruling is that they are impure.
The Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> dispute with regard to the decree that was not issued in Jerusalem <b>itself. Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> disagreed. <b>One said:</b> The Sages <b>did not issue a decree</b> in the case of <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to the impurity of <b>spittle that is</b> found <b>in Jerusalem. And one said:</b> The Sages <b>did not issue a decree</b> in the case of <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to the impurity of <b>vessels in Jerusalem.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>We</b> already <b>learned</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>spittle,</b> and similarly, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>vessels.</b> What do these <i>amora’im</i> add to the earlier tannaitic rulings?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>We</b> already <b>learned</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>spittle, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Any spittle found in Jerusalem is pure, except for</b> the spittle <b>that is</b> found in the <b>upper market,</b> an area frequented by gentiles (Rambam). The Gemara explains: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for the <i>amora</i> to teach that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> in a case <b>where</b> there is <b>a presumption</b> that there had been <b>a <i>zav</i></b> in the area where the spittle was found. Even in that case, no decree of impurity was issued with regard to spittle in Jerusalem.
Likewise, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>vessels, as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>all the vessels found in Jerusalem,</b> if they were found <b>on the path</b> leading <b>down to the ritual bath</b> they <b>are</b> presumed <b>ritually impure.</b> These vessels were probably not yet immersed, as people typically bring impure vessels to the ritual bath. By inference, <b>all other</b> vessels found elsewhere <b>are</b> presumed <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And according to your reasoning, say the latter clause</b> of the mishna as follows: If the vessels were discovered <b>on the path up</b> from the ritual bath, <b>they are</b> presumed <b>ritually pure.</b> One can learn by inference from this statement the diametric opposite: <b>All other</b> vessels <b>are</b> presumed <b>ritually impure.</b>
<b>Rather, the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>is precise</b> in its formulation, and therefore inferences may be drawn with regard to other vessels. <b>And the latter clause is not precise</b> in this way, <b>and</b> it comes <b>to exclude</b> only <b>the</b> small <b>passageways</b> near the ritual bath, where it is unclear whether the vessels there were being taken to the bath for immersion or from the bath after being immersed. Since the vessels were certainly impure when brought to the ritual bath, and it is uncertain whether or not they were immersed, they retain the presumptive status of impurity. However, in cases where the uncertainty is whether or not the vessels were impure at all, then where the impurity is by rabbinic decree, that decree is not in effect in Jerusalem, and the vessels are ritually pure.
<b>And</b> the Gemara suggests that according <b>to Rav, who said</b> this is referring to a case <b>where one lost a needle</b> that became impure through contact with a person or vessel impure with <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted <b>by a corpse, and he recognized</b> the needle <b>in the meat</b> of the offering, <b>the conclusion should be different. Since the Master said</b> that the verse: <b>“One who is slain with a sword”</b> (Numbers 19:16) teaches that the legal status of a metal <b>sword is like</b> that of <b>one who is slain</b> in terms of its degree of impurity, not only the meat, but <b>a person and vessels as well</b> should <b>become ritually impure</b> by touching the needle. Just as a sword that comes into contact with a corpse assumes its status as an ultimate primary source of ritual impurity, so too, any metal vessel that comes into contact with a person or vessel that is impure with impurity imparted by a corpse assumes its status as a primary source of ritual impurity.
<b>Rav Ashi said: That is to say</b> that the Temple <b>courtyard is a public domain</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of uncertain impurity. <b>And</b> therefore, the ruling in this case <b>is</b> that of <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>impurity in a public domain,</b> as there is no proof that either the vessels or one’s hands came into contact with the ritually impure needle. <b>And</b> the guiding principle in <b>any</b> case of <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>impurity in a public domain</b> is that <b>its uncertainty</b> is ruled to be <b>ritually pure.</b> Therefore, the meat, which definitely came into contact with the needle, is impure, while everything else is ritually pure.
The Gemara asks: One can learn by inference that if this uncertainty developed <b>in the private domain, its uncertainty</b> is ruled to be <b>ritually impure.</b> Why would that be the case? <b>Since this needle</b> is <b>an item that does not have knowledge to be asked,</b> as an inanimate object cannot be consulted with regard to how it became impure or whether it became impure at all, the following principle is in effect: With regard to <b>any item</b> or person <b>that does not have knowledge to be asked,</b> the person referring to one who lacks the competence to answer the question, <b>whether</b> the uncertainty developed <b>in the public domain or whether</b> it was <b>in the private domain, its uncertainty</b> is ruled to be <b>ritually pure.</b>
The Gemara responds: Although a needle does not have knowledge to be asked, it is nevertheless impure <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> its uncertainty <b>is uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>impurity that comes</b> about <b>by means of a person.</b> The knife did not come into contact with the needle on its own; rather, a person was holding the knife. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan stated</b> another principle: In a case of <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>impurity that comes</b> about <b>by means of a person,</b>

Daf 20a

its owners will have no choice but to <b>consult</b> a Sage <b>about it</b> to determine whether or not it is ritually pure, as <b>even with regard to a vessel that is placed upon the ground,</b> which is certainly not capable of providing an answer if asked, its legal status is <b>like</b> that of <b>an item that has knowledge to be asked.</b> The fact that the knife is an inanimate object is not reason enough to rule it ritually pure. It was therefore necessary to say that the knife is ritually pure because the Temple courtyard is a public domain. If it was a private domain, the knife would be deemed impure.
It was taught that if an impure needle were found in an animal, <b>the meat is ritually impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With what</b> liquid <b>was this meat rendered susceptible</b> to impurity? A food can become impure only if it were rendered susceptible to impurity through contact with a liquid; how, then, could the sacrificial meat become impure immediately after the animal was slaughtered?
<b>If we say that it was rendered susceptible</b> to impurity <b>by</b> the <b>blood</b> that flowed when it was slaughtered, <b>didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to blood of consecrated</b> offerings <b>that it does not render</b> produce <b>susceptible</b> to impurity? <b>As it is stated: “You shall surely not eat the blood; you shall pour it upon the earth like water”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:16). The Sages derived from this verse: <b>Blood that is poured like water,</b> i.e., blood from a non-sacred domesticated animal that is poured out when it is slaughtered and not received in a vessel like sacrificial blood, assumes the legal status of water and <b>renders</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. <b>Blood that is not poured out like water,</b> but is received in a vessel to be sprinkled on the altar, <b>does not render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity.
<b>Rather,</b> say <b>that</b> this meat <b>was rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by the</b> other <b>liquids of the slaughterhouse,</b> e.g., the water that was kept near the altar for washing the offerings. <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, say</b> with regard to <b>the liquids of the slaughterhouse: Not only are they ritually pure,</b> as noted in the testimony of Yosei ben Yo’ezer, <b>but they do not</b> even <b>render</b> meat <b>susceptible</b> to impurity?
<b>Rather,</b> say that the meat <b>is rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by the esteem for sacred</b> objects. According to this principle, certain items that cannot become impure by Torah law become susceptible to impurity by rabbinic law due to their extreme sanctity. The Gemara rejects that possibility: <b>Say that the esteem for sacred</b> objects <b>is effective to disqualify</b> the meat <b>itself</b> despite the fact that it was not rendered susceptible to receive impurity, but <b>does it also</b> transmit impurity to the extent that one <b>counts first- and second-</b>degree impurity from contact with that meat? Can impurity based on the esteem for sacred objects be transmitted to other objects like standard impurity?
If so, <b>resolve</b> from here <b>that which Reish Lakish raised as a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>a mass from meal-offerings,</b> does one <b>count first- and second-</b>degree impurity from contact with it <b>or not?</b> Due to the esteem for sacred objects, the offering itself can become impure without having been rendered susceptible through contact with liquid; however, the dilemma is whether or not it transmits impurity to other objects.
The Gemara responds: Perhaps the dilemma with regard to the status of ritual impurity due to esteem for sacred objects has not in fact been resolved. In the case of meat, <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where</b> the meat <b>was</b> from <b>a cow</b> brought as <b>a peace-offering sacrifice,</b> whose hide and meat belong to its owner, <b>and</b> the owner <b>led it through the river</b> to clean it, and he slaughtered it <b>while liquid was still moist upon it.</b> While the animal was being flayed, water fell on the meat, rendering it susceptible to impurity.
We learned in a mishna cited above: If the needle <b>was found in the secretions</b> of the animal’s stomach, <b>everything,</b> meat, knife, and hands, <b>is pure.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And let these secretions,</b> which are liquid, <b>return and transmit impurity to the meat</b> itself. Like any other liquid, the secretions assume first-degree ritual impurity by rabbinic decree. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> It is referring <b>to thick,</b> solid <b>secretions,</b> which are not liquid. <b>Rav Ashi said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that it is referring <b>to soft secretions,</b> it does not transfer impurity <b>because it is an offensive liquid,</b> which does not transmit impurity.
<b>The <i>tanna</i></b> who recited <i>mishnayot</i> and <i>baraitot</i> in the study hall <b>taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Sheshet.</b> Based on the verses, it is possible to create the following scenario: The carcass of <b>a creeping animal transmits impurity to liquids,</b> the <b>liquids transmit impurity to a vessel,</b> the <b>vessel transmits impurity to foods, and</b> the <b>foods transmit impurity to liquids. And we have</b> thereby <b>learned</b> that there are <b>three</b> successive levels <b>of impurity with regard to a</b> dead <b>creeping animal.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>These are four</b> levels, not three. The Gemara answers: <b>Cut</b> the <b>liquids of the first clause,</b> so that the <i>baraita</i> reads: The carcass of a creeping animal transmits impurity to a vessel and the vessel to foods, etc.
The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary, cut</b> the <b>liquids of the latter clause,</b> which states that foods transmit impurity to liquids. The Gemara explains: <b>The only <i>tanna</i> that we find who said</b> that <b>liquids transmit impurity to a vessel is Rabbi Yehuda.</b> And even <b>he retracted</b> this statement. <b>And your mnemonic</b> to remember the order of the transfer of impurity in this <i>baraita</i> is <b>a brewing vat,</b> as the order is similar to the production of beer. First one brings the vessel, then one places barley, the food, in it, and then the water. That is the order of the transmission of impurity in the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there:</b> With regard to the carcass of <b>a creeping animal that was found in an oven, the bread inside it</b> is impure with <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity. This is <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>the oven</b> is impure with <b>first-</b>degree impurity and transmits impurity to the bread.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rava: And let us view that oven as one filled with impurity,</b> as an earthenware vessel is rendered impure by a creeping animal in the airspace of the oven even without making contact with it. <b>And</b> consequently <b>this bread</b> should <b>be</b> impure with the <b>first-</b>degree of impurity. The oven should be considered as if it were filled with carcasses of creeping animals and the bread should assume first-degree impurity status as though it became impure directly from a creeping animal.
<b>He said to him: This</b> suggestion <b>cannot enter your mind, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>all the vessels</b> found in an earthenware oven <b>become impure from the airspace of</b> an impure <b>earthenware vessel.</b>

Daf 20b

Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to creeping animals: “And every earthenware vessel into which any of them falls, <b>whatever is in it shall be impure,</b> and you shall break it” (Leviticus 11:33). <b>And juxtaposed to it</b> is the verse: <b>“From all food</b> in it which may be eaten, upon which water comes, shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:34). This indicates that <b>food is rendered impure by the airspace of an earthenware vessel, but not all vessels are rendered impure by the airspace of an earthenware vessel.</b> This <i>baraita</i> proves that the earthenware vessel itself is not considered to be filled with carcasses of creeping animals, and therefore it does not render everything inside it impure with first-degree impurity. Were the earthenware vessel indeed considered as if it were filled with impurity, vessels inside it would also assume first-degree ritual impurity.
<b>Rav Ḥisda raised a contradiction</b> between one statement with regard to <b>Passover and</b> another statement with regard to <b>Passover, and he resolved</b> this contradiction himself. The Gemara elaborates: <b>Did Rabbi Yehoshua</b> actually <b>say</b> that <b>both of them</b> may be burned <b>as one,</b> <i>teruma</i> whose purity is uncertain, and definitely impure <i>teruma</i>, on Passover eve?
<b>And</b> he <b>raised a contradiction</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i>, as <b>Rabbi Yosei said: The</b> inferred <b>conclusion</b> of burning pure and impure leaven together <b>is not similar to the</b> case from which you cited <b>proof. When</b> Rabbi Meir said that <b>the Sages,</b> Rabbi Ḥanina the deputy High Priest and Rabbi Akiva, <b>testified, about what did they testify? If</b> you assert that Rabbi Meir said with regard <b>to meat that became ritually impure through</b> contact with <b>a secondary source of impurity, that one</b> may <b>burn it</b> together <b>with meat that became impure through</b> contact with <b>a primary source of impurity,</b> that is a case where both <b>this</b> meat <b>is impure and that</b> meat <b>is impure,</b> albeit not at the same level of impurity.
Rabbi Yosei continues: <b>If</b> you say that Rabbi Meir is referring <b>to</b> the statement of Rabbi Akiva, with regard <b>to oil that was disqualified by one who immersed himself during that day, that one</b> may <b>kindle it in a lamp that became ritually impure</b> with first-degree impurity <b>through</b> contact with one who became <b>ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> that is a case where <b>this</b> substance <b>is disqualified and that</b> object <b>is impure. We also concede with regard to <i>teruma</i> that became impure from a secondary source of impurity, that one</b> may <b>burn it with <i>teruma</i> that became ritually impure from a primary source of impurity,</b> even though the first <i>teruma</i> will assume a greater degree of impurity. <b>However, how will we burn</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> whose impure status is uncertain, together <b>with ritually impure</b> <i>teruma</i>? <b>Perhaps Elijah</b> the Prophet <b>will come</b> and establish prophetically that the <i>teruma</i> is not ritually impure, <b>and render it ritually pure.</b>
<b>And</b> Rav Ḥisda himself <b>resolved</b> the contradiction: <b>This</b> statement that was taught in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua, that one burns <i>teruma</i> in abeyance together with ritually impure <i>teruma</i>, is the ruling of <b>Rabbi Shimon and in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> whereas <b>that</b> statement, that one may not burn them together, is the ruling of <b>Rabbi Yosei and in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
The Gemara cites the source of this tannaitic dispute with regard to Rabbi Yehoshua’s opinion. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the <b>fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>occurs on Shabbat,</b> one may not remove the leaven on Passover eve in the usual manner, and therefore <b>one removes everything before Shabbat, and he burns</b> all <b><i>teruma</i></b> together, <b>impure</b> <i>teruma</i>, <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance, and pure</b> <i>teruma</i>. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> One burns <b>pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>by itself,</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance by itself, and impure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>by itself.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon said: Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua did not disagree about ritually pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>and about impure</b> <i>teruma</i>. They agree <b>that one</b> may <b>not burn</b> them together. And neither did they disagree <b>about</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance and about pure</b> <i>teruma</i>. They agree <b>that one</b> may <b>burn</b> them together. Since the <i>teruma</i> is not definitely impure, he does not appear to be directly impurifying the <i>teruma</i>. <b>With regard to what did they disagree?</b> They disagree <b>with regard to</b> burning <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance and impure</b> <i>teruma</i> together, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer says: This</b> <i>teruma</i> should <b>be burned by itself and that</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>by itself.</b> Since this case involves <i>teruma</i> that is definitely impure, if the <i>teruma</i> in abeyance is actually pure, by burning them together he will have rendered it impure. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> One may burn <b>both of them as one.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Isn’t the mishna</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei?</b> How can Rabbi Yosei’s statement be attributed to Rabbi Shimon? The Gemara answers: <b>This is</b> what <b>Rabbi Yosei is saying to Rabbi Meir: Even</b> according to <b>Rabbi Shimon in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, who is lenient, where he</b> rules <b>leniently</b> it is only <b>with regard to</b> burning <i>teruma</i> <b>in abeyance and impure</b> <i>teruma</i> together. <b>However, with regard to ritually pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>and impure</b> <i>teruma</i> together, <b>no,</b> even he does not permit burning them together.
Similarly, <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, raised a contradiction</b> between the previous statement with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> and a <i>halakha</i> <b>of Passover, and he resolved it</b> himself. The Gemara clarifies: <b>Did Rabbi Yehoshua</b> actually <b>say</b> that <b>both</b> <i>teruma</i> in abeyance and impure <i>teruma</i> may be burned <b>together?</b>
<b>And</b> he <b>raised a contradiction</b> from a mishna: In the case of <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> produce <b>with regard to which uncertainty developed</b> about its <b>impurity, Rabbi Eliezer says: If</b> the barrel <b>was resting in a vulnerable place,</b> where it may come into contact with impurity, <b>one</b> should <b>place it in a concealed place, and if it was exposed he</b> should <b>cover it. Rabbi Yehoshua says: If it was placed in a concealed place</b> he may <b>place it in a vulnerable place. And if it was covered he</b> may <b>expose it.</b>
The Gemara infers from this mishna: In any case, passive <b>causation</b> of <i>teruma</i> whose impurity is uncertain to become definitely impure, <b>yes,</b> it is permitted. However, to actively render <i>teruma</i> impure <b>with</b> one’s <b>hands, no,</b> it is prohibited. This ruling contradicts the previous <i>halakha</i> that one may burn <i>teruma</i> in abeyance and impure <i>teruma</i> together. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, <b>resolved</b> this apparent contradiction himself: <b>This</b> statement, that one is permitted to burn <i>teruma</i> in abeyance together with ritually impure <i>teruma</i>, is the ruling of <b>Rabbi Shimon in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> whereas <b>that</b> statement, that one may cause this impurity only passively, is the ruling of <b>Rabbi Yosei in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
Similarly, <b>Rabbi Elazar raised a contradiction</b> between one <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> and another <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>, and resolved</b> the contradiction himself. The Gemara explains: <b>Did Rabbi Yehoshua</b> actually <b>say</b> that passive <b>causation</b> of <i>teruma</i> whose impurity is uncertain to become definitely impure, <b>yes,</b> it is permitted; however, to actively render <i>teruma</i> impure <b>with</b> his <b>hands, no,</b> it is prohibited?
<b>And</b> he <b>raised a contradiction</b> against this from a mishna: With regard to <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> wine <b>that broke in the upper</b> area <b>in a winepress,</b> where grapes are pressed, <b>and</b> there is <b>impure, non-sacred</b> wine in the <b>lower</b> area of the press, where the wine flows from the upper area, if the <i>teruma</i> wine would flow into the non-sacred wine, the <i>teruma</i> wine would be rendered ritually impure. The result would be significant financial loss, as the legal status of all the wine in the lower press would be that of impure <i>teruma</i>, which is prohibited even for priests to drink.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer concedes to Rabbi Yehoshua that if one is able to rescue</b> even <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>from</b> the barrel that broke and keep the wine <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity,</b> by receiving the <i>teruma</i> wine in a vessel before it becomes impure, <b>he</b> should <b>rescue</b> it. <b>And</b> if <b>one cannot</b> receive the wine in a pure vessel, as only impure vessels are available, so that if he uses them to receive the wine or to seal the upper press he will render the <i>teruma</i> impure, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The <i>teruma</i> wine should be allowed to <b>descend and become impure</b> on its own, <b>but one</b> should <b>not</b> actively <b>render it impure with</b> his <b>hand.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: One</b> may even actively <b>render it impure with</b> his <b>hand,</b> by stopping the pipe connecting between the upper and lower presses with an impure vessel or by receiving the wine in impure vessels. Evidently, Rabbi Yehoshua allows one even to actively impurify pure <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>resolved</b> this contradiction himself: <b>There,</b> with regard to the broken barrel, <b>it is different, as,</b> in that case, <b>there is</b> the potential <b>loss of non-sacred</b> produce, when the <i>teruma</i> wine descends to the lower press. The non-sacred wine will become prohibited due to the mixture with impure <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rava strongly objects to this</b> claim: In <b>the mishna too there is</b> a <b>loss of wood,</b> as one requires additional wood to kindle a second fire and burn the impure <i>teruma</i> separately. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> With regard to this and similar issues, the Sages <b>were concerned about a great loss.</b> However, <b>they were not concerned about</b> the <b>minimal loss</b> of several pieces of wood.
<b>And from where do you say</b> that the Sages <b>were concerned about a great loss and they were not concerned about a minimal loss? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i> oil that broke in the upper</b> area of the olive <b>press, and in the lower</b> area of the press there is <b>impure, non-sacred</b> produce, <b>Rabbi Eliezer concedes to Rabbi Yehoshua that if one can rescue</b> even <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> of the oil <b>in</b> a state of <b>purity from</b> the barrel, <b>he</b> should <b>rescue</b> it. <b>And</b> if <b>one cannot</b> receive the oil in a pure vessel, the <i>teruma</i> oil should be allowed to <b>descend and become impure</b> on its own, <b>but one</b> should <b>not</b> actively <b>render it impure with</b> his <b>hand.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>What is different</b> about <b>oil</b> that, as opposed to wine, everyone agrees may not be actively rendered impure? If you say the reason is <b>that</b> even if the <i>teruma</i> falls into the lower press and is intermingled with impure <i>teruma</i>, <b>it is</b> still <b>suitable for lighting</b> and not entirely lost, if so, <b>wine is also fit for sprinkling</b> in one’s house to provide a pleasant fragrance. Impure <i>teruma</i> wine could be used for that purpose.
<b>And lest you say</b> that <b>sprinkling</b> wine <b>is not</b> a significant <b>matter,</b> and would be tantamount to destroying the <i>teruma</i>, <b>didn’t Shmuel say in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: One drinks from</b> wine valued at <b>a <i>log</i> for a <i>sela</i>, and one sprinkles from</b> wine valued at <b>a <i>log</i> for two</b> <i>sela</i>. Apparently, sprinkling is a more significant use than drinking. The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to new</b> wine still in the press, which does not have a strong fragrance and cannot be used for sprinkling.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>But isn’t</b> the wine <b>fit to be aged,</b> at which point it could be used for sprinkling, and would not be entirely lost. The Gemara answers: One may <b>thereby come to encounter a stumbling block,</b> as he might, with the passage of time, forget that it is ritually impure and come to drink it. The Gemara asks: If so, with regard to <b>oil too, one</b> may <b>thereby come to encounter a stumbling block,</b> in the same way.
The Gemara answers: The Gemara answers: Ritually impure <i>teruma</i> oil is permitted <b>because he places it in a repulsive vessel,</b> so that people will be disinclined to consume it and will use it only for lighting. The Gemara suggests: With regard to <b>wine, too,</b> he can <b>place it in a repulsive vessel.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: That is not possible. Is it reasonable that <b>one</b> who <b>wants</b> the wine <b>for sprinkling will place it in a repulsive vessel?</b> One sprinkles wine to add a pleasant odor, which would not be the case if the wine has been left in a disgusting vessel.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> concern for <b>a stumbling block</b> by keeping prohibited items <b>is itself</b> subject to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i> wine that became ritually impure, Beit Shammai say: It</b> should <b>be poured out all at once, and Beit Hillel say:</b> One should wait until it ages, at which stage <b>it</b> may <b>be used for spraying.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: I will decide</b> this dispute. If the barrel was <b>in a field, it</b> should <b>be poured out all at once,</b> lest the ritual impurity of the barrel be forgotten by the time it is brought inside the house. However, if the barrel was <b>in the house,</b> where it could be used immediately, <b>it</b> may <b>be used for sprinkling. Some say</b> that Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, decided: <b>In</b> the case of <b>new</b> wine, <b>it</b> should <b>be poured out all at once;</b> but <b>in</b> the case of <b>old</b> wine, <b>it should be used for spraying. They said to him:</b>

Daf 21a

<b>The decision</b> of the <b>third</b> opinion of Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, is <b>not</b> considered <b>a decision</b> in this case, as the other two Sages do not raise the issue of a stumbling block at all.
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua with regard to a barrel of <i>teruma</i> that broke in an upper press and was flowing down into the lower press applies only to a case <b>where</b> one <i>se’a</i> of <i>teruma</i> <b>fell into less than one hundred <i>se’a</i> of impure, non-sacred</b> wine in the lower press.
<b>However,</b> if the <i>teruma</i> wine <b>fell into one hundred</b> <i>se’a</i> of <b>ritually impure, non-sacred</b> produce, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the wine should be allowed to <b>descend and become ritually impure</b> by itself, <b>and one</b> should <b>not</b> actively <b>render it impure with</b> his <b>hand.</b> The reason is that if <i>teruma</i> falls into non-sacred produce one hundred times greater in quantity than itself, the <i>teruma</i> is nullified by the non-sacred produce, and therefore, it would be permitted for a non-priest to eat it. Although it becomes ritually impure, the legal status of the nullified <i>teruma</i> is that of non-sacred produce.
The Gemara comments: <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> wine <b>that broke in the upper winepress, and in the lower</b> press there is <b>one hundred</b> times that amount of <b>ritually impure, non-sacred</b> wine, <b>Rabbi Eliezer concedes to Rabbi Yehoshua that if one is able to rescue</b> even <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>from</b> the barrel that broke and keep the wine <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity, he</b> should <b>rescue</b> it. <b>And</b> if <b>not,</b> one should let the <i>teruma</i> wine <b>descend and become impure</b> on its own, <b>but he</b> should <b>not</b> actively <b>render it impure with</b> his <b>hand.</b>
After citing proof for the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, from this source, the Gemara questions the formulation of the <i>baraita</i> itself. <b>This</b> expression: <b>Rabbi Eliezer concedes to Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> is puzzling, as Rabbi Eliezer ruled that one may never directly render the barrel impure. The <i>baraita</i> <b>should</b> say the opposite: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua concedes to Rabbi Eliezer,</b> as it is Rabbi Yehoshua who concedes that one may not render impure the barrel of <i>teruma</i> in the upper vat. <b>Rava said: Reverse</b> the names, so that it is Rabbi Yehoshua who concedes to Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Actually, do not reverse</b> the names. Rather, <b>with what are we dealing here?</b> We are referring to a case where it is possible to collect the wine only <b>in a vessel whose interior is ritually pure and whose exterior is impure</b> by rabbinic law, having become impure through contact with impure liquids. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>we</b> should <b>issue a decree</b> that one may not rescue even a quarter-<i>log</i>, <b>lest the</b> vessel’s <b>exterior touch the <i>teruma</i></b> and render it impure, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that Rabbi Eliezer concedes to Rabbi Yehoshua that despite that concern, it is permitted to rescue a quarter-<i>log</i> of pure <i>teruma</i>.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> For the <b>entire time that it is permitted to eat</b> leavened bread, <b>one</b> may also <b>feed</b> it <b>to</b> his <b>domesticated animals, to non-domesticated animals, and to birds; and one</b> may <b>sell</b> it <b>to a gentile; and it is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from it.</b> After <b>its time passes, it is prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit from it, and one may not</b> even <b>light an oven or a stove with</b> leavened bread. With regard to the manner of removal of leavened bread, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The removal of leavened bread is</b> to be accomplished <b>only</b> through <b>burning. And the Rabbis say:</b> Burning is not required, as <b>one</b> may <b>even crumble</b> it <b>and throw</b> it <b>into the wind or cast</b> it <b>into the sea.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara reads the mishna precisely: For the <b>entire time that it is permitted to eat</b> leavened bread, <b>one</b> may <b>feed</b> it to his animals. <b>However,</b> apparently, for the <b>entire time that it is not permitted to eat</b> leavened bread, <b>one</b> may <b>not feed</b> his animals. <b>Let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. As, if</b> it were in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, isn’t there</b> the <b>fifth</b> hour, when <b>one</b> may <b>not eat</b> leavened bread <b>but one</b> may <b>feed</b> it to his animals? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Meir says: One</b> may <b>eat</b> leavened bread on the morning of the fourteenth day of Nisan for <b>the entire fifth</b> hour, <b>and he burns</b> it <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One</b> may <b>eat</b> it for <b>the entire fourth</b> hour, <b>he suspends</b> his consumption of it for <b>the entire fifth</b> hour, <b>and he burns it at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour. Apparently, there is an hour in which it is prohibited to eat leavened bread, but it is permitted to feed it to one’s animals.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what</b> can be said? This mishna follows the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> If so, <b>this</b> statement: For the <b>entire time that it is permitted to eat</b> leavened bread <b>one</b> may <b>feed,</b> is imprecise. <b>It should have</b> said: For the <b>entire time that one eats</b> leavened bread <b>he</b> may <b>feed.</b> As it stands, there is no parallel between the phrase: It is permitted to eat, and the phrase: One may feed. Therefore, it appears that the mishna is referring to two different people or cases.
<b>Rabba bar Ulla said: The mishna is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel. As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabban Gamliel says: Non-sacred</b> leavened bread may <b>be eaten</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan during <b>the entire fourth</b> hour, leavened bread that is <b><i>teruma</i></b> may be eaten during <b>the entire fifth</b> hour, <b>and one burns</b> the leavened bread <b>at the beginning of the sixth</b> hour. <b>And this is</b> what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> For the <b>entire time that it is permitted</b> for <b>a priest to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> although an Israelite may not eat leavened bread at that time, <b>an Israelite</b> may <b>feed non-sacred</b> food <b>to</b> his <b>domesticated animals, to non-domesticated animals, and to birds.</b>
The Gemara continues to read the mishna precisely. The mishna states that one may feed his leavened bread to his domesticated animals, to non-domesticated animals, and to birds. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna <b>to teach</b> about the case of <b>domesticated animals, and why do I</b> need it <b>to teach</b> about <b>non-domesticated animals</b> as well? The <i>halakha</i> should be the same for both cases. The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> to teach us both cases, <b>as had it taught</b> only about <b>domesticated animals,</b> one would have said that it is permitted feed them <b>because if</b> the animal <b>leaves over</b> some leavened bread <b>one will see</b> what is left over and dispose of it. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a non-domesticated animal, if it leaves over</b> any of the leavened bread, <b>it hides it</b> to save for later. Therefore, one could <b>say</b> that it is <b>not</b> permitted to feed it so close to the time when leavened bread is prohibited.
<b>And had it taught</b> only the case of <b>a non-domesticated animal,</b> one might say that it is permitted to feed leavened bread to such an animal <b>because if it leaves over</b> any food <b>in any case it will hide</b> it, and the owner will not violate the prohibition: It shall not be seen. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a domesticated animal, sometimes it leaves over</b> food, <b>and it does not enter his mind</b> that the animal will do so. <b>And</b> in that case both prohibitions: <b>It shall not be seen and it shall not be found,</b> would <b>apply to him.</b> Consequently, one could <b>say</b> that it would <b>not</b> be permitted for him to feed a domesticated animal. Therefore, <b>it was necessary</b> to teach both cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna to mention <b>birds</b> as well? The Gemara answers: There is no inherent need to mention birds; however, <b>since</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> the cases of <b>domesticated animals and non-domesticated animals, it also taught</b> the case of <b>birds,</b> as these are normally grouped together.
It was stated in the mishna that whenever it is permitted to eat leavened bread, one may also <b>sell it to a gentile.</b> The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious,</b> as the mishna already taught that one may benefit from it? The Gemara answers: This is stated <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Beit Shammai say: A person</b> may <b>not sell his leavened bread to a gentile unless he knows that</b> the leavened bread <b>will be consumed before Passover.</b> According to Beit Shammai, a person retains some responsibility for his leavened bread even when it is no longer in his possession. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> For the <b>entire time that it is permitted</b> for a Jew <b>to eat</b> leavened bread, <b>it is</b> also <b>permitted for him to sell it</b> to a gentile. The Jew ceases to be responsible for leavened bread sold to a gentile from the moment it is sold.

Daf 21b

<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira,</b> who agrees in principle with Beit Shammai’s opinion, <b>says:</b> With regard to <b><i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a dip that contains leavened breadcrumbs, <b>and all types of <i>kutaḥ</i>, it is prohibited to sell</b> it to a gentile <b>thirty days before Passover.</b> Because <i>kutaḥ</i> is spicy, people use only a bit at a time, so it will likely last until Passover.
It was stated in the mishna that as long as leavened bread may be eaten, <b>it is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No, it is necessary to teach this</b> in a case <b>where one charred</b> the leavened bread with fire <b>before its time,</b> i.e., before it became prohibited, rendering it inedible. <b>And it teaches us</b> that the <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava. As Rava said:</b> If one <b>charred</b> leavened bread <b>before its time, it is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from it even after its time,</b> since it no longer has the legal status of leavened bread.
It was stated in the mishna: After <b>its time passes, it is prohibited to benefit from it.</b> The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No, it is necessary for</b> the mishna to teach that it remains prohibited to benefit from leavened bread during additional <b>hours</b> that are delineated <b>by rabbinic law. As Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard <b>to one who</b> takes wheat grains that may have come into contact with water and become leavened and <b>betroths</b> a woman with the leaven <b>from</b> the beginning of <b>the sixth hour,</b> when the leaven is prohibited by rabbinic law, <b>and onward</b> on Passover eve, <b>even</b> if he betrothed her <b>with wheat from the mountains,</b> which is especially hard and unlikely to become leavened, nonetheless, <b>we are not concerned that</b> this <b>betrothal</b> is valid. This is because when performing a betrothal with money one must give the woman an object worth as least the value of a <i>peruta</i>, and leaven from which one is prohibited to benefit is considered worthless.
It was stated in the mishna: <b>And one may not</b> even <b>light an oven or a stove with</b> leavened bread once it becomes prohibited. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious,</b> as this is also a type of benefit? The Gemara answers: <b>No, it is necessary</b> to teach this due <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>the removal of leavened bread is</b> to be performed only <b>through burning.</b> Otherwise, <b>it could enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Yehuda said that its mitzva is</b> performed through <b>burning, while one is burning it let him benefit from it.</b> Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that it is prohibited to benefit from leavened bread even while burning it.
<b>Ḥizkiya said: From where</b> is it derived in the mishna <b>that it is prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit from leavened bread on Passover? As it is stated: “Leavened bread shall not be eaten”</b> (Exodus 13:3). Since the verse uses the passive, it should be understood as follows: <b>There shall be no permitted consumption of it</b> at all, even deriving benefit, as benefit could be exchanged for money, which could be used to buy food. The Gemara reads precisely: <b>The reason</b> deriving benefit is prohibited <b>is that the Merciful One writes</b> in the Torah<b>: “Leavened bread shall not be eaten.” Had</b> the Torah <b>not written: “Shall not be eaten,”</b> and instead used the active form: You shall not eat, <b>I would have said</b> that the <b>prohibition of eating is implied</b> but that <b>the prohibition of</b> deriving <b>benefit is not implied.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> this conclusion <b>disagrees with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Abbahu,</b> as <b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>wherever it is stated: “It shall not be eaten,” “You,</b> singular, <b>shall not eat,”</b> or <b>“You,</b> plural, <b>shall not eat,” both a prohibition of eating and a prohibition of</b> deriving <b>benefit are implied, unless the verse specifies</b> that one may benefit, <b>in the manner that it specified with regard to an</b> unslaughtered <b>animal carcass.</b>
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“You shall not eat of any unslaughtered animal; you may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates, that he may eat it; or you may sell it to a foreigner;</b> for you are a sacred people to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 14:21). <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that it is permitted <b>to a resident alien through giving and to a gentile through selling. From where</b> do I derive that it is permitted <b>to a resident alien through selling? The verse states: “You may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates…or you may sell it,”</b> meaning that one has the option to do either of these. <b>From where is it derived</b> that it is permitted <b>to a gentile through giving</b> and one is not required to sell it to him? <b>The verse states: “You may give it</b>…<b>that he may eat it, or you may sell it to a foreigner.”</b> Therefore, <b>you may say</b> that he may transfer it to <b>both a resident alien and a gentile, both through giving and through selling.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> These <b>matters are</b> meant to be understood <b>as they are written;</b> he may transfer an unslaughtered animal carcass <b>to a resident alien</b> only <b>through giving and to a gentile</b> only <b>through selling.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>If it could enter your mind</b> to understand the verse <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rabbi Meir said, then let the Merciful One write: You may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates that he may eat it and sell it</b> to a foreigner. <b>Why do I</b> need the word <b>“or”</b> between these two options? <b>Learn from it</b> that <b>the matters are</b> to be understood <b>as they are written.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Meir</b> explain the formulation of the verse? The Gemara answers that Rabbi Meir would explain that the word <b>“or”</b> teaches one <b>to give precedence to giving to a resident alien over selling to a gentile.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? According to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>this</b> matter <b>does not need a verse, since you are commanded to sustain a resident alien,</b> as it is a mitzva for one to sustain a resident alien who has renounced idol worship, <b>and you are not commanded to sustain a gentile. There is no need for a verse</b> to teach this; <b>it is</b> based on a <b>logical inference.</b>
The Gemara applies this discussion to the previously mentioned topic. <b>Granted,</b> Rabbi Abbahu’s opinion is reasonable <b>according to Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that one may transfer an animal carcass <b>to both a convert and a gentile, both through selling and through giving. From</b> the fact that <b>a verse was necessary to permit</b> one to derive <b>benefit from an animal carcass,</b> one can learn that with regard to <b>all</b> other <b>prohibitions in the Torah</b> about which it states only that one may not eat an item, <b>it is prohibited both to eat it and to derive benefit from it.</b>
<b>However, according to Rabbi Yehuda, who said</b> that the word “or” <b>comes to</b> teach that the <b>matters are</b> to be understood <b>as they are written, from where does he derive</b> with regard to <b>all prohibitions</b> of eating <b>mentioned in the Torah that it is prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> as well? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it</b> from another verse. It is stated with regard to an animal with a condition that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>]: “And you shall be sacred men to Me, therefore you shall not eat any flesh that is torn of beasts in the field; <b>you shall cast it to the dogs”</b> (Exodus 22:30).

Daf 22a

The Gemara concludes: <b>It,</b> i.e., a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>you</b> may <b>throw to a dog, but you</b> may <b>not throw all</b> other items <b>prohibited by Torah law to a dog,</b> as both eating and deriving benefit are prohibited. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what <i>halakha</i> does <b>Rabbi Meir</b> learn from this verse? The Gemara answers that Rabbi Meir draws the following inference: <b>It, you</b> may <b>throw to a dog, but you</b> may <b>not throw</b> the meat of <b>a non-sacred animal that was slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard to a dog,</b> as it is prohibited to benefit from it.
<b>And</b> from where does <b>the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Yehuda, learn this <i>halakha</i> about non-sacrificial meat that was slaughtered in the Temple courtyard? The Gemara answers: He holds that the prohibition of deriving benefit from the meat of a <b>non-sacrificial animal that was slaughtered in the courtyard is not by Torah law;</b> rather, the Sages decreed that it is prohibited. Since it is not prohibited by Torah law, no verse is necessary.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa raised an objection: And</b> yet there is still the prohibition of <b>the sciatic nerve, as the Merciful One says: “Therefore the children of Israel may not eat the sciatic nerve”</b> (Genesis 32:33), <b>and we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A person</b> may <b>send the thigh</b> of an animal <b>to a gentile</b> as a gift <b>with the sciatic nerve inside it,</b> he is not required to remove it. This is <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>its place is clear,</b> and it is obvious that this nerve has not been removed. Therefore, there is no concern that another Jew will assume that the first Jew removed this portion of the animal, which might cause him to accidentally eat the sciatic nerve. Apparently, one may benefit from this prohibited portion of the animal even though the verse says that one may not eat it.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Rabbi Abbahu holds</b> that <b>when it was permitted</b> by the Torah to derive benefit from <b>an animal carcass, it, its fats, and its sinews,</b> such as the sciatic nerve, were all <b>permitted.</b> Therefore, the sciatic nerve is included in this exception and one may benefit from it. The Gemara challenges: <b>It works out well according to the one who said that sinews give flavor,</b> meaning that they have the taste of meat and therefore have the legal status of meat of an animal carcass. <b>However, according to the one who says</b> that <b>sinews do not give flavor</b> and are not categorized as meat, <b>what can be said?</b> If they are not considered to be meat, why are they included in the exception made for an animal carcass?
The Gemara answers: <b>Whom did you hear that said</b> that <b>sinews do not give flavor?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Shimon, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who eats the sciatic nerve from a non-kosher domesticated animal, Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes: One for eating the sciatic nerve and one for eating the meat of a non-kosher animal. <b>And Rabbi Shimon exempts</b> him entirely, since according to his opinion the prohibition to eat the sciatic nerve applies only to a kosher animal. In addition, one violates the prohibition of eating from a non-kosher animal only when it has the flavor of meat.
And it indeed follows logically that just as Rabbi Shimon exempts one who eats the sciatic nerve in that particular case, <b>so too here, Rabbi Shimon prohibits</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> from the sciatic nerve. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>It is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from the sciatic nerve;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Shimon prohibits</b> it. Since Rabbi Shimon holds that the sciatic nerve does not give flavor, it cannot be included in the exception of the animal carcass. Therefore, from the verse that prohibits eating the sciatic nerve he learns that one may not benefit from it either, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Abbahu. Rabbi Abbahu’s position fits according to both opinions. However, the mishna that indicates that it is permitted to derive benefit from the sciatic nerve is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, as he holds that the sciatic nerve gives flavor and is therefore included in the exception of the animal carcass.
The Gemara further challenges Rabbi Abbahu’s opinion: <b>And</b> yet there is the prohibition of eating <b>blood, as the Merciful One says:</b> “Therefore I said to the children of Israel: <b>No soul of you shall eat blood,</b> neither shall any convert that dwells among you eat blood” (Leviticus 17:12). According to Rabbi Abbahu’s opinion, one may derive from this verse that in addition to the prohibition against eating blood, it is prohibited to benefit from it as well. <b>And we learned</b> in a mishna: Both <b>these and these,</b> the remnants of the blood from sin-offerings brought on the altar and other blood sprinkled on it, descend and <b>mix in the canal</b> from which water leaves the Temple. They then <b>exit to the Kidron Valley and are sold</b> at a special price <b>to gardeners as a fertilizer. And</b> one who does not first purchase the blood from the Temple <b>misuses consecrated property.</b> Apparently, under certain circumstances, one may benefit from blood which it is prohibited to consume.
The Gemara answers: <b>Blood is different, as it is juxtaposed</b> in the Torah <b>to water. As it is written</b> with regard to blood: <b>“You shall not eat it; you shall pour it out upon the earth like water”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:24). From here it is derived: <b>Just as it is permitted</b> to benefit from <b>water, so too, it is permitted</b> to benefit from <b>blood.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> instead that blood is meant to be <b>like water offered as a libation on the altar,</b> which is consecrated and from which one is prohibited to benefit. <b>Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> The comparison to permitted water can be deduced from that which the verse says: <b>“Like water [<i>kamayim</i>],”</b> meaning, like <b>most water;</b> and one is permitted to benefit from most types of water. The Gemara asks: <b>And is it written: Most water?</b> The Torah wrote: “Like water,” which could indicate a comparison to any type of water. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said</b> that the verse should be understood as follows: <b>Like water that is poured out,</b> from which one may benefit, <b>and not like water that is offered as a libation.</b> Water offered on the altar is described using the term libation, and not using the term poured as found in the verse.
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that blood is meant to be <b>like water poured before idolatry,</b> from which one may not benefit. The Gemara rejects this: <b>There,</b> that <b>is also called a libation</b> and not pouring, <b>as it is written:</b> “Who did eat the fat of their sacrifices, <b>and drink the wine of their libations”</b> (Deuteronomy 32:38).

Daf 22b

The Gemara asks: <b>According to Ḥizkiya,</b> who says that: You shall not eat, indicates only that eating is prohibited but that benefit is permitted, <b>for what <i>halakha</i> is blood juxtaposed to water?</b> According to his opinion, there is no need for the verse to teach that one may benefit from blood.
