However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa, who disagrees with them</b> and <b>says:</b> These priestly clothes may no longer be used by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, <b>but they are fit</b> for use <b>by a common priest,</b> since these garments are similar to those worn by common priests every day. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of: <b>“And he shall leave them there”?</b> This indicates <b>that</b> the High Priest <b>may not use them on another Yom Kippur.</b> According to this opinion, <b>what can be said?</b> According to the opinion of Rabbi Dosa, there is only one verse that teaches about misuse of consecrated property with an item that has already been used for performing its mitzva. Therefore, it should be possible to derive a principle from the verse dealing with the removal of ashes.
The Gemara answers: A principle cannot be based on this verse, <b>because removal of ashes and the heifer whose neck is broken,</b> from which one may not derive benefit after the ceremony, <b>are two verses that come as one. And two verses that come as one do not teach</b> a principle.
The Gemara asks: <b>It works out well according to the one who said</b> that <b>they do not teach</b> a principle, i.e., according to the Rabbis. <b>However, according to the one who said</b> that <b>they do teach</b> a principle, i.e., Rabbi Yehuda in tractate <i>Sanhedrin</i>, <b>what can be said?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Two</b> phrases indicating <b>exclusions are written</b> with regard to these <i>halakhot</i>, limiting this rule to them. With regard to the removal of ashes <b>it is written: “And he shall put it.”</b> The word “it” limits the <i>halakha</i> to this particular circumstance. With regard to the heifer whose neck is broken <b>it is written: “The</b> heifer <b>which had its neck broken”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:6). The word “the” indicates that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to this type of heifer and not to any other similar case.
After this tangential discussion of the laws of misuse of consecrated property, the Gemara returns to Abaye and Rava’s dispute about the status of unintended benefit, seeking to prove one side or the other. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof based on what was taught: If <b>one brought</b> the heifer whose neck is to be broken or the red heifer <b>into a cow pen, and it threshes</b> grain while walking with other cows, then <b>it is valid.</b> Under normal circumstances, had one used the heifer for work, it would be disqualified from use in its ceremony. However, in this case, the red heifer may still be burned, and the heifer is still fit to have its neck broken in the ritual. Apparently, the verses “Upon which a yoke has not been placed” (Numbers 19:2) and “Which has not been used for work” (Deuteronomy 21:3) still apply to it, because the owner did not intend for it to work. If he brought it in <b>so that it may nurse</b> from its mother <b>and so it will thresh</b> grain, then <b>it is disqualified</b> from use in these rituals.
<b>And here, isn’t it</b> a case <b>where it was not possible</b> to act differently, as the heifer needs to nurse, <b>and he intended</b> that it thresh the grain? <b>And it is teaching that</b> the heifer <b>is disqualified</b> from use. This proves that when one intends to derive benefit, even if there is no other way to act, it is prohibited to derive benefit. The Gemara rejects this: <b>It is different there, as it is written: “Which has not been used for work” in any case.</b> Therefore, while the heifer is disqualified from use even if the situation was unavoidable, no general conclusion can be drawn from this case.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> that this verse means that it has not performed any work at all, then it should apply <b>even to the first clause.</b> Even when it threshes the grain against the will of the owner, it has still done work and should be rendered disqualified.

Daf 26b

The Gemara answers. <b>This</b> case <b>is comparable only to that</b> other case: If <b>a bird landed on</b> the red heifer <b>it</b> remains <b>valid,</b> since this is not considered to be like bearing a yoke. If <b>a male</b> animal <b>mounted it</b> to mate with it, <b>it is unfit</b> and may not be used for the ritual. The same applies in this case: When the owner moves the heifer into a pen and it threshes, since the owner is uninterested in this action, it is like the case of the bird and the heifer remains valid. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the difference between the case where a bird lands on it and where a male animal attempts to mate with it?
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> that the verse says: “And the elders of that city shall take a heifer of the herd, which has not been used for work, and which has not drawn in the yoke” (Deuteronomy 21:3). <b>If it were written: “He worked [<i>avad</i>],” and we read: “He worked [<i>avad</i>],”</b> this word choice would indicate that the heifer could still be used <b>until he,</b> the owner of the heifer himself, <b>used it</b> willingly for labor. <b>If it were written: “It was worked [<i>ubbad</i>],” and we read: “It was worked [<i>ubbad</i>],”</b> it would indicate that <b>even</b> if it performed labor <b>on its own it is also</b> prohibited to use it, since some form of labor had been done with it.
<b>Now that it is written: “He worked [<i>avad</i>],” but we read</b> this word as: <b>“It was worked [<i>ubbad</i>],”</b> both meanings are intended: It is prohibited if <b>it is worked in a similar</b> manner to the way <b>he works.</b> In other words, <b>just as</b> the owner <b>works</b> the animal in a way <b>that is beneficial to him, so too,</b> the animal becomes prohibited only when <b>it is worked</b> in a way <b>that causes him to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from this labor. Therefore, it still may be used if a bird lands on it, because the owner does not derive benefit from this in any way. However, if a male bull mates with this heifer it is rendered unfit, since the owner generally has an interest in this occurring.
The Gemara cites an additional proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> from that which is taught: If one finds <b>a lost item, he</b> may <b>not spread it out over a bed or over a frame for his</b> own <b>purposes,</b> since this is deriving benefit from an object that does not belong to him. <b>However, he</b> may <b>spread it out over a bed or a frame for its</b> own <b>sake</b> if it requires airing. <b>If guests happen</b> to come <b>to him, he may not spread it out, neither for its sake nor for his</b> own <b>purpose.</b> Apparently, the benefit is unavoidable and intended, as there is no other way for him to care for the lost object, and he benefits from having his guests see the item; nonetheless, it is still prohibited. This seems to prove that Rava’s opinion is correct.
The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <b>It is different there, as</b> he risks <b>damaging it, either due to the evil eye</b> that he casts upon it <b>or due to the thieves</b> who will now know that this valuable item is in his possession and will attempt to steal it. It is not prohibited because of the benefit; rather, it is prohibited due to the concern that he may damage the item.
The Gemara offers a final proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof based on the following mishna: <b>Clothing merchants</b> who sell garments made of diverse kinds, a prohibited mixture of wool and linen, may <b>sell them as they normally would</b> to gentiles. A merchant may place the garments he is selling on his shoulders and need not be concerned about the prohibition against wearing diverse kinds, <b>provided he does not intend</b> to benefit from the garments <b>in the sun</b> as protection <b>from the sun, or in the rain</b> as protection <b>from the rain. However, the modest</b> people, those who are meticulous in their performance of mitzvot, <b>suspend</b> the wool and linen garments <b>on a stick behind them.</b>
<b>And here, isn’t it</b> a case where <b>it is possible</b> for all clothing merchants <b>to act like the modest</b> people and not derive benefit from the mixture of wool and linen? Nonetheless, the mishna states that <b>when one does not intend</b> to benefit from the prohibited item, <b>it is permitted</b> to do so. This presents <b>a conclusive refutation to he who taught the first version</b> of <b>Rava’s</b> statement. According to this version, one is prohibited from deriving benefit when it is possible to avoid doing so and he does not intend to derive benefit. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, it is <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
It was taught in the mishna that <b>one may not</b> even <b>light</b> the oven <b>with</b> leavened bread. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>an oven that one lit with the peels of <i>orla</i></b> fruit, <b>or with straw</b> of grain that was planted in a prohibited mixture <b>of diverse kinds in a vineyard,</b> if it was a <b>new</b> oven, and by lighting it he hardened the oven and made it stronger for use in the future, then <b>it</b> must <b>be shattered.</b> Since prohibited items were used in the process of forming the oven, one may not derive benefit from the use of the prohibited items. However, if it was an <b>old</b> oven, <b>it</b> may <b>be cooled,</b> and it is prohibited to use the oven only while it is still hot.
With regard to <b>one</b> who <b>baked bread in</b> the oven while it was heated or strengthened by the prohibited items, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: It is prohibited</b> to eat or derive benefit from <b>the bread,</b> since prohibited items were involved in the process of preparation. <b>And the Rabbis say: It is permitted</b> to eat and derive benefit from <b>the bread.</b> If <b>he cooked</b> the bread <b>over the coals</b> that remained from prohibited wood, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Whether</b> it was <b>an old</b> oven <b>or a new</b> oven <b>it</b> may <b>be cooled;</b> there is never a need to shatter the oven? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that one is required to shatter the oven, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that it is sufficient to let the oven cool, is in accordance with the opinion of the <b>Rabbis.</b> Since the prohibited objects merely strengthen the oven, the Rabbis hold that it is enough to let the oven cool. By cooling the oven one no longer derives benefit from the prohibited items used to light it, and there is no need to shatter the oven.
The Gemara challenges this answer: <b>Say</b> that <b>you heard that Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi prohibits one from deriving benefit from bread baked using the prohibited objects as kindling <b>because there is improvement from the wood</b> used to light the oven <b>in the bread,</b> and therefore, it is prohibited. However, in a different case, namely, when <b>both this and that cause it,</b> i.e., both permitted and prohibited items contribute to the result, such as when one subsequently bakes in this oven and benefit is derived both from the prohibited wood that strengthened the oven and from permitted wood that is used in subsequent baking, <b>did you hear him</b> say that it is prohibited as well? <b>Rather,</b> reject this explanation and say: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> stringent <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who says that in a case where both this and that cause it, it is prohibited. And <b>that</b> lenient <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with regard to that principle.
The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> statement of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> serves as the basis for this explanation? <b>If you say</b> that it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> with regard to <b>leaven, as we learned</b> in a mishna: In a case where <b>non-sacred leaven and</b> leaven of <b><i>teruma</i> fell into</b> non-sacred <b>dough, and neither one</b> alone <b>is</b> potent <b>enough to cause</b> the dough <b>to become leavened bread,</b> and <b>they</b> were <b>joined</b> together <b>and caused</b> the dough <b>to become leavened bread,</b> there is a dispute as to whether this dough is considered to be <i>teruma</i> or non-sacred bread. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: I follow the final</b> element that fell into the dough. If the <i>teruma</i> fell in last, the dough is prohibited to non-priests. <b>And the Rabbis say: Whether the prohibited item,</b> i.e., the <i>teruma</i>, <b>fell</b> in <b>first or the prohibited item fell</b> in <b>last, it never</b> renders the dough <b>prohibited</b>

Daf 27a

<b>until there is enough</b> of the prohibited leaven <b>to cause</b> the dough <b>to become leavened bread. And Abaye said:</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>taught</b> that when the permitted leaven fell in last, the mixture is permitted <b>only</b> when <b>he first removed the prohibited</b> leaven before the permitted leaven fell into the dough and made it rise. <b>However, if he did not first remove the prohibited leaven,</b> the dough <b>is prohibited</b> even if the permitted leaven fell in last. <b>Apparently,</b> when <b>both this and that cause</b> the dough to become leavened bread, <b>it is prohibited.</b>
The Gemara rejects this statement: And <b>from where</b> is it apparent <b>that the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> opinion <b>is in accordance with Abaye’s</b> explanation? <b>Perhaps the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> opinion <b>is due to</b> the following, which Rabbi Eliezer said explicitly: <b>I follow the final</b> element. <b>And it is no different</b> if <b>he first removed the prohibited item and it is no different</b> if <b>he did not first remove the prohibited item. However,</b> if they both fell in <b>at once it should be permitted,</b> because where both this and that cause the dough to become leavened bread Rabbi Eliezer rules that the mixture is permitted.
<b>Rather,</b> the reference is to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> with regard to <b>wood from an <i>asheira</i>. As we learned</b> in a mishna: If <b>one took wood from</b> an <i>asheira</i>, <b>it is prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit from it.</b> With regard to <b>one</b> who <b>lit an oven with</b> the wood, if it was a <b>new</b> oven, <b>it</b> must <b>be broken.</b> If it was an <b>old</b> oven, <b>it</b> may <b>be cooled.</b>
If <b>one baked bread</b> with <i>asheira</i> wood as the fuel, <b>it is prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit from it.</b> If this bread <b>was mixed together with other</b> bread, <b>and</b> that <b>other</b> bread <b>was mixed with other</b> bread, <b>it is prohibited to derive benefit from all</b> of this bread. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: He casts the benefit into the Dead Sea [<i>Yam HaMelaḥ</i>].</b> In other words, one is not required to destroy the entire mixture when the prohibited bread is mixed with a large quantity of other bread. Instead one should designate money equal in value to the value of the original wood from the <i>asheira</i>, and he should destroy this money to offset the benefit he derived from the prohibited wood. The first <i>tanna</i> <b>said to him: Idolatry cannot be</b> monetarily <b>redeemed.</b> Once the bread becomes prohibited, it cannot be redeemed by having its value cast into the Dead Sea. Apparently, the opinion of both Sages, including Rabbi Eliezer, is that when both this permitted object and that prohibited object cause a change to another item, the latter item is prohibited.
The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <b>Say that you heard that Rabbi Eliezer</b> and the first <i>tanna</i> are stringent in this matter <b>with regard to idolatry, whose prohibition is stringent.</b> However, <b>with regard to other prohibitions in the Torah,</b> which are less stringent, <b>did you hear him</b> express this opinion? The Gemara responds to this question: <b>Rather, if</b> it is <b>so</b> that Rabbi Eliezer does not hold the same opinion with regard to other prohibitions, <b>to whom will you attribute</b> this <i>baraita</i>? If it is not Rabbi Eliezer who says this, then who is it? <b>And furthermore, wasn’t</b> it <b>taught explicitly</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And, similarly, Rabbi Eliezer would prohibit</b> these types of mixtures <b>with regard to all prohibitions in the Torah.</b>
<b>Abaye said: If you say,</b> based on the previously stated opinions, that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that when <b>both this and that cause, it is prohibited,</b> then the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>is</b> identical to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> as both state that it is prohibited for this same reason. <b>And if you say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that when <b>both this and that cause, it is permitted, and here,</b> where Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi rules that it is prohibited, <b>it is because there is improvement from the wood in the bread</b> itself, then in that case, deriving benefit from any of <b>these</b> earthenware <b>bowls, cups, and flasks</b> that were made in such an oven should also <b>be prohibited,</b> since the improvement from the wood is in them as well. If one were to use such utensils he would be deriving benefit from a prohibited item.
<b>When</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Sages <b>disagree is</b> in a case <b>where an oven and a pot</b> were formed using prohibited wood. <b>According to the one who says</b> that when <b>both this and that cause it is prohibited, it is prohibited</b> to derive benefit from these as well, since the prohibited item was a contributing factor in the initial formation of the object. However, <b>according to the one who says</b> that when <b>both this and that cause, it is permitted, it is permitted</b> to derive benefit from them. This is because one derives benefit from the prohibited oven and pot only once they have been subsequently heated by permitted wood. Therefore, the influence on the pot of the prohibited item is only one component in the preparation of this food.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>even according to the one who says</b> that when <b>both this and that cause, it is permitted, the pot</b> made through the use of prohibited wood <b>is prohibited, since it holds the food</b> inside it <b>before the permitted wood is placed</b> in the oven. Therefore, one derives benefit from the prohibited vessel itself without any contribution from a permitted source.
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>an oven that one lit with peels of <i>orla</i></b> fruit, <b>or with straw</b> of grain that was planted in a prohibited mixture of <b>diverse kinds in a vineyard,</b> if it is a <b>new</b> oven, <b>it</b> must <b>be shattered.</b> If it is an <b>old</b> oven, <b>it</b> may <b>be cooled.</b> If <b>one baked bread in it, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: The bread is permitted, and the Rabbis say: The bread is prohibited.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>Wasn’t the reverse taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel teaches the reverse,</b> that it is Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi who permits one to derive benefit from this bread even in the previously mentioned <i>baraita</i>.
<b>And if you wish, say:</b> Shmuel accepts the original text of the <i>baraita</i> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is the one who prohibits deriving benefit from the bread. And <b>generally, Shmuel holds</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>over his</b> individual <b>colleague</b> who disagrees; however, the <i>halakha</i> does <b>not</b> follow him <b>over</b> several of <b>his colleagues</b> who disagree. <b>And in this</b> particular case, the <i>halakha</i> follows Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>even over his colleagues. And</b> Shmuel <b>holds: I will reverse</b> the two sides presented here, <b>in order to establish the Rabbis’</b> opinion <b>as a prohibition.</b> Therefore, the conclusion will be to rule that it is prohibited, in accordance with the majority opinion. Although in Shmuel’s version the attributions of the opinions are technically inaccurate, the benefit is that when people see that the Rabbis rule that it is prohibited in this case, they will be inclined to accept their majority opinion, which is the correct <i>halakha</i>.
It was taught as part of the previously stated <i>halakha</i> that if <b>one cooked</b> the bread <b>over coals</b> produced from an <i>asheira</i>, <b>everyone agrees that the bread is permitted.</b> The Gemara records a dispute: <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said</b> one opinion, <b>and Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> another opinion. <b>One</b> of them <b>said: They taught</b> this leniency <b>only</b> when one cooks with <b>dim coals,</b> whose heat is merely a remnant of the earlier lighting; <b>however,</b> when one cooks with <b>glowing coals,</b> the bread is <b>prohibited. And one</b> of them <b>said: Even</b> when <b>the coals are glowing,</b> the bread is <b>also permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to the one who said</b> that baking with <b>glowing</b> coals renders the bread <b>prohibited,</b> this is <b>because there is improvement from the</b> prohibited <b>wood in the bread. However, according to the one</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>even</b> when baking with <b>glowing</b> coals the bread is <b>permitted,</b> since they are no longer considered to be wood, <b>where do you find the case</b> where <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems bread to be prohibited because there is improvement from</b> the prohibited <b>wood in it?</b> Why should there be a difference between glowing coals and actual burning wood? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The case is <b>when a flame is</b> directly <b>opposite</b> the bread. When he cooks the bread directly in front of the wood, it is improved directly by the wood. When the coals are merely glowing, there is no direct benefit from the wood.

Daf 27b

The Gemara asks: Does this prove <b>by inference that the Rabbis who disagree with</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>permit</b> one to eat this bread <b>even when the flame is opposite it? But</b> if this is the case, <b>where do you find the case</b> where <b>it is prohibited according to the Rabbis</b> to derive benefit from <b>wood? Rav Ami bar Ḥama said:</b> It is found <b>in</b> the case of <b>a stool</b> made from the wood. Although they hold that it is permitted to derive indirect benefit from the wood, even the Rabbis agree that one may not derive benefit from a stool that is made from the wood itself.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raised a dilemma before Rav Ḥisda:</b> With regard to <b>an oven that one kindled with consecrated wood and baked bread in it, according to the Rabbis, who permitted</b> the bread <b>in the first</b> case where it was baked with <i>orla</i> wood, <b>what is the <i>halakha</i>? He said to him: The bread is prohibited.</b> He responded: <b>What is the difference between this</b> bread <b>and</b> bread baked with <b><i>orla</i></b> peels? <b>Rava said: How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? <i>Orla</i> is nullified</b> in a mixture of one part in <b>two hundred;</b> it is possible that less than this amount of <i>orla</i> was absorbed by the bread. However, <b>consecrated</b> wood <b>is not nullified even in</b> a mixture of one part in <b>one thousand.</b> Therefore, even when there is only a miniscule amount of the consecrated matter in the bread it is still prohibited.
<b>Rather, Rava said: If it was difficult for</b> Rami bar Ḥama, <b>this is</b> what he found <b>difficult: Didn’t the kindler</b> of the fire transgress the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of <b>consecrated property,</b> as anyone who unwittingly uses consecrated property for a non-sacred use violates this prohibition? <b>And any</b> case <b>where the kindler</b> of an oven <b>misuses consecrated property</b> by doing so, the wood <b>is transferred to non-sacred</b> status. The wood loses its sanctity when misused, and the one who misused it must donate other wood to the Temple in its place. In that case, the wood used to heat the oven is non-sacred wood and the bread should be permitted.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Here, we are dealing with wood</b> which had been set aside <b>for</b> purchasing <b>peace-offerings.</b> This wood, while sanctified, has a lesser status of sanctity and does not become fully consecrated until the blood of the offering has been sprinkled. <b>And</b> this dilemma was raised <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who <b>said:</b> If one <b>unwittingly</b> misused <b>consecrated property, it becomes desecrated</b> and loses its elevated status. However, if one used the object <b>intentionally, it is not desecrated</b> and remains consecrated. Since the act here is intentional, the consecrated wood does not lose its status.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that when one <b>intentionally</b> uses this object it does <b>not</b> lose its status? <b>Since</b> it is <b>not subject to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>misuse of consecrated property,</b> as one is liable to bring an offering only for unwitting misuse of consecrated property, <b>it is not transferred to non-sacred</b> status. The same <i>halakha</i> applies to the wood set aside for <b>peace-offerings as well. Since</b> at that stage <b>it is not subject to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>misuse of consecrated property,</b> as that applies only after the animal’s blood has been sprinkled, then according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, even if one unwittingly uses this wood, <b>it is not transferred to non-sacred</b> status; rather, it remains prohibited.
The Gemara asks: <b>And anywhere the kindler</b> of an oven transgresses the prohibition of <b>misuse of consecrated property</b> by using consecrated wood, <b>is it transferred to non-sacred</b> status? <b>Wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>all</b> prohibited items <b>that must be burned, their ashes are permitted</b> after the burning, <b>except for wood from an <i>asheira</i>? And consecrated ash is prohibited forever.</b> Therefore, it is possible that when one kindles an oven with this consecrated wood, although he misuses consecrated property, the ash remains prohibited.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> That <i>baraita</i> is discussing a case <b>where a fire began on its own among consecrated wood and there is no one who misused consecrated property.</b> Since this is the case, even the ash that is left from this wood remains consecrated property and one may not benefit from it. <b>Rav Shemaya said:</b> This <i>baraita</i> is dealing <b>with those</b> types of consecrated ash <b>that require burial,</b> such as the ash removed from the altar. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “And he shall take up the ash from where the fire has consumed the burnt-offering on the altar, and he shall put it beside the altar” (Leviticus 6:3). The phrase <b>“And he shall put it”</b> indicates that he must do so <b>gently; “and he shall put it”</b> also indicates that he must place <b>all of it; “and he shall put it”</b> also indicates <b>that he</b> may <b>not scatter</b> the ashes. Apparently, even after the offering has been burned it remains sacred, and one may not derive benefit from it. However, when it was burned it was not subject to misuse of consecrated property, as its burning is a necessary step in the process of sacrificing the offerings.
It was taught in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The removal of leavened bread is</b> to be accomplished <b>only</b> through <b>burning. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: The removal of leavened bread is</b> to be accomplished <b>only through burning. And a logical derivation leads</b> to this conclusion: <b>Just as</b> that which is <b>left over</b> from an offering after the time period in which it may be eaten, <b>which is not subject to</b> the prohibitions: <b>It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, requires burning, so too,</b> with regard to <b>leavened bread,</b> which is more stringent <b>as it is subject to</b> the prohibitions of: <b>It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear <b>that it requires burning?</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to him: Any logical derivation that you derive</b> whose <b>initial</b> teaching <b>is stringent but whose subsequent</b> consequences <b>are lenient is not</b> a valid <b>logical derivation.</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, if one <b>did not find wood to burn</b> his leavened bread, must <b>he sit idly</b> and not remove it? <b>And the Torah said: “You shall remove leaven from your houses”</b> (Exodus 12:15), indicating that this must be done <b>in any manner which you can remove it.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda’s logical derivation leads to a leniency.
<b>Then Rabbi Yehuda presented a different logical derivation</b> based on the principle of: What do we find with regard to, rather than on an <i>a fortiori</i> inference (Rashash). <b>It is prohibited to eat the leftover</b> of offerings <b>and it is prohibited to eat leavened bread.</b> Based on this similarity, one can conclude that <b>just as the leftover</b> of offerings <b>requires burning, so too, leavened bread requires burning.</b>
<b>They said to him:</b> The case of <b>an animal carcass can prove</b> that eating the leftover of offerings is not a factor in determining whether or not leavened bread requires burning, <b>as eating</b> an animal carcass <b>is prohibited and it does not require burning.</b> Therefore, there is no clear connection between the prohibition to eat a particular object and a requirement to burn it. <b>He said to them:</b> There is a <b>difference</b> between these cases, as it is explicitly stated that one may benefit from an animal corpse. Therefore, the following comparison can be made: <b>It is prohibited to eat and</b> derive <b>benefit from the leftover</b> of sacrificial meat, <b>and it is prohibited to eat and</b> derive <b>benefit from leavened bread. Just as the leftover</b> of sacrificial meat <b>requires burning, so too, leavened bread requires burning.</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> The case of <b>an ox that is stoned can prove</b> that this is not a clear factor, <b>as it is prohibited to eat and</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from such an ox <b>and it does not require burning. He said to them:</b> There is a <b>difference</b> between leavened bread and an ox that is stoned, as there is an additional factor that is not relevant to the ox. <b>It is prohibited to eat and</b> derive <b>benefit from the leftover</b> of sacrificial meat, and one who does so is <b>punished with <i>karet</i>. And it is prohibited to eat and</b> derive <b>benefit from leavened bread, and</b> one who does so is <b>punished with <i>karet</i>. Just as the leftover</b> of sacrificial meat requires <b>burning, so too, leavened bread</b> requires <b>burning. They said to him:</b> If so, <b>the fats of an ox that is stoned can prove</b> that this too is an insignificant factor, <b>as it is prohibited to eat</b> the fats and derive <b>benefit</b> from them, and one who eats them is <b>punished with <i>karet</i>, and they do not require burning.</b>

Daf 28a

<b>Then Rabbi Yehuda presented a different logical derivation:</b> The prohibition against eating and deriving benefit from <b>leftover</b> sacrificial meat <b>is</b> clearly included <b>in</b> the prohibition of: <b>And you shall not leave over. And leavened bread is</b> also included, in a sense, <b>in</b> the prohibition of: <b>And you shall not leave over,</b> as once the time it may be eaten expires, one violates the prohibitions of: It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, by owning it. <b>Just as leftover</b> sacrificial meat <b>is subject to burning, so too, leavened bread is subject to burning.</b>
<b>They said to him: According to your opinion, an uncertain guilt-offering and a bird</b> sacrificed <b>as a sin-offering in a case of doubt will prove</b> that this comparison is not valid, <b>as they are</b> also included <b>in</b> the prohibition of: <b>And you shall not leave over,</b> since these offerings are prohibited after the time in which they may be eaten has expired. <b>As we say that they are subject to burning, but you say</b> that an uncertain guilt-offering <b>is subject to burial. Rabbi Yehuda was silent,</b> as he had no response.
<b>Rav Yosef said: This is as people say: In the spoon that the carpenter made, the mustard will burn his</b> palate. In other words, one can be harmed by his own actions. Similarly, in this case the strongest proof against Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion is the one based on Rabbi Yehuda’s own statement.
<b>Abaye said</b> another folk expression: <b>He who made the stocks [<i>saddana</i>] shall sit in the stocks; he is repaid through his</b> own <b>handiwork.</b>
<b>Rava said</b> another similar saying: <b>He who made the arrows shall be killed with his</b> own <b>arrows; he is repaid through his</b> own <b>handiwork.</b>
It was taught in the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that leavened bread need not be burned; rather, <b>one</b> may even <b>crumble</b> it <b>and throw</b> it <b>into the wind</b> or the sea. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>With regard to what</b> case <b>are they speaking?</b> Do they mean that he must specifically <b>crumble</b> it <b>and throw</b> it <b>into the wind</b> or <b>crumble</b> it <b>and throw</b> it <b>into the sea? Or perhaps one</b> may <b>crumble</b> it <b>and throw</b> it <b>into the wind, but he</b> may <b>cast</b> it <b>into the sea in its pure, unadulterated form,</b> without crumbling it first. <b>We also learned</b> in a mishna <b>with regard to idolatry in a case like this</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: He</b> may <b>grind</b> the idol <b>and throw</b> the dust <b>into the wind or cast it into the sea. And a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>With regard to what</b> case <b>are they speaking?</b> Must one specifically <b>grind</b> it <b>and throw</b> it <b>into the wind or grind</b> it <b>and throw</b> it <b>into the sea? Or</b> perhaps <b>he</b> may <b>grind</b> it <b>and throw</b> it <b>into the wind; however, he</b> may <b>throw</b> it <b>into the sea in its pure,</b> unadulterated form.
<b>Rabba said: It stands to reason that since idols are thrown into the Dead Sea, they do not need grinding,</b> as there is no concern that they will be removed and used again. However, <b>leavened bread that</b> may be <b>thrown into other rivers, needs crumbling</b> before being cast away. <b>Rav Yosef said to him: On the contrary, the opposite is</b> more <b>reasonable. Idols, which do not</b> normally <b>disintegrate</b> in the water, <b>need grinding.</b> However, <b>leavened bread, which disintegrates in the water</b> on its own, <b>does not need crumbling.</b>
A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba</b> and a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef.</b> The Gemara explains: A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba:</b> If <b>one was walking in the desert</b> with leavened bread in his hand and the time came on the eve of Passover to remove it, then <b>he</b> must <b>crumble</b> the leavened bread <b>and throw it into the wind.</b> If <b>he was traveling on a ship, he</b> must <b>crumble</b> the leavened bread <b>and throw it into the sea.</b> And a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef:</b> If <b>one was walking in the desert</b> and found an idol, <b>he</b> must <b>grind it and throw it into the wind.</b> If <b>he was traveling on a ship, he</b> must <b>grind it and throw it into the sea.</b>
The Gemara comments: The requirement of <b>grinding</b> in one <i>baraita</i> <b>is difficult for Rabba,</b> since according to his opinion there is no need to grind idols before throwing them into the sea. And the requirement of <b>crumbling</b> leavened bread mentioned in the other <i>baraita</i> <b>is difficult for Rav Yosef,</b> as in his opinion leavened bread need not be crumbled before it is thrown into the sea. The Gemara answers: The requirement of <b>grinding is not difficult for Rabba. This</b> case, where one is not required to grind it, is where he throws it <b>into the Dead Sea. That</b> case, where he is required to grind it before throwing it, is where he throws it <b>into other rivers.</b> Similarly, the requirement of <b>crumbling is not difficult for Rav Yosef. This</b> case is dealing <b>with</b> a bag <b>of wheat</b> that became leavened. Since wheat does not disintegrate on its own, one must grind it up and scatter it into the water. <b>That</b> case is referring <b>to bread.</b> Since bread will disintegrate in the water on its own, there is no need to crumble it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>It is permitted</b> for a Jew <b>to</b> derive <b>benefit from leavened bread of a gentile over which Passover has elapsed,</b> i.e., leavened bread that remains after the conclusion of Passover. However, <b>it is prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> leaven <b>of a Jew</b> over which Passover has elapsed, <b>as it is stated:</b> “And no leavened bread shall be seen with you, <b>neither shall there be leaven seen with you,</b> in all your borders” (Exodus 13:7).
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara begins by asking: <b>Who is</b> the author of <b>the mishna? It is not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and it is not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, and it is not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b> The Gemara clarifies this question: <b>What is</b> the case about which these Sages disagree, and what are their opinions on this issue? The Gemara explains: <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who eats or derives benefit from <b>leavened bread, whether before its time,</b> starting at midday on Passover eve, <b>or after its time,</b> i.e., leavened bread over which Passover has elapsed, <b>transgresses a negative mitzva. During its time,</b> on Passover itself, one who eats leavened bread <b>transgresses a negative mitzva and</b> is liable to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>

Daf 28b

<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> One who eats or derives benefit from <b>leavened bread,</b> both <b>before its time and after its time, does not transgress any</b> prohibition. <b>During its time one</b> is liable to receive <b><i>karet</i> and transgresses a negative mitzva</b> for eating or deriving benefit from leavened bread. <b>And from the time that it is prohibited to eat</b> leavened bread, beginning at midday on Passover eve, <b>it is</b> also <b>prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it. The Gemara comments: With this last sentence <b>we have come to</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> as this statement appears to present Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion and not that of Rabbi Shimon. <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: Be astounded with yourself. How can it be prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit from leavened bread for all seven</b> days? In other words, he disagrees with the premise that it is prohibited to derive benefit from leavened bread even during the seven days of Passover.
The <i>baraita</i> discusses a related issue: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who eats leavened bread</b> on Passover eve <b>from the sixth hour and onward transgresses a negative mitzva? As it is stated:</b> “And you shall sacrifice the Paschal lamb to the Lord your God, of the flock and the herd, in the place which the Lord shall choose to cause His name to dwell there. <b>You shall eat no leavened bread with it;</b> for seven days you shall eat <i>matzot</i>, the bread of affliction” (Deuteronomy 16:2–3). The juxtaposition of the Paschal lamb with the prohibition of leavened bread teaches that the prohibition to eat leavened bread begins from the time that the Paschal lamb is slaughtered, namely, the afternoon of the fourteenth of Nisan. <b>This is the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon said to him: Is it possible to say this? Isn’t it already stated: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it; for seven days you shall eat <i>matzot</i>”?</b> Since the verse links the prohibition of leavened bread to the mitzva of eating <i>matza</i>, one should also say that one must eat <i>matza</i> on the fourteenth of Nisan. <b>If so, what</b> does it mean when <b>the verse states: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it”?</b> The verse indicates that <b>at a time when he is</b> under the obligation to <b>get up and eat <i>matza</i>, he is subject to</b> the prohibition of: <b>You shall eat no leavened bread. And at a time when he is</b> under no obligation to <b>get up and eat <i>matza</i>, he is not subject to</b> the prohibition of: <b>You shall eat no leavened bread.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>There are three verses</b> that <b>are written</b> with regard to this prohibition, and in Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion each one teaches that the prohibition applies at a different time. One verse states: <b>“Leavened bread shall not be eaten”</b> (Exodus 13:3). Another verse states: <b>“And all that which is leavened you shall not eat;</b> in all your habitations you shall eat <i>matzot</i>” (Exodus 12:20). And a third verse states: <b>“You shall eat no leavened bread with it”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3). <b>One</b> verse indicates that there is a prohibition against eating leavened bread even <b>before its time,</b> on Passover eve. <b>One</b> verse indicates that there is a prohibition against eating leavened bread <b>after its time</b> as well, if a Jew owned it during Passover. <b>And one verse</b> indicates that the prohibition applies <b>during Passover</b> itself.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> interpret these three verses? The Gemara explains: <b>One</b> verse is required <b>to</b> teach about the prohibition <b>during its time.</b> The verse: <b>“And all that which is leavened</b> you shall not eat” <b>is required</b> for another <i>halakha</i>, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>I have</b> derived that leavened bread is prohibited <b>only if it became leavened on its own,</b> through its own natural process. <b>From where do I derive</b> that if it became leavened <b>due to another substance</b> it is considered to be leavened bread as well? <b>The verse states: “All that which is leavened you shall not eat.”</b> This indicates that all leavened bread, no matter how it became so, is forbidden during Passover.
The verse <b>“Leavened bread shall not be eaten” is</b> also <b>required</b> for another <i>halakha</i>. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the</b> prohibition against eating <b>leavened bread</b> during <b>the</b> first <b>Passover in Egypt applied for only one day? The verse states: “Leavened bread shall not be eaten,”</b> and this is <b>juxtaposed to</b> the verse that states: <b>“This day you go forth</b> in the month of spring” (Exodus 13:4). This indicates that the prohibition against eating leavened bread during the first Passover in Egypt applied for only that one day.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda, from where does he</b> derive that leavened bread that became leavened <b>due to another substance</b> is prohibited? The Gemara answers: He derives it from the fact <b>that the Merciful One expresses</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with the</b> general <b>term: “That which is leavened”;</b> no additional amplification is required.
The Gemara asks: And this teaching <b>of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> with regard to the Passover in Egypt, <b>from where does</b> Rabbi Yehuda derive it? The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say that</b> he derives it <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the phrase <b>“this day” is juxtaposed to it.</b> In Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, the entire verse: “Leavened bread shall not be eaten” is not required to make this point; instead, this verse indicates that there is an additional time when leavened bread is prohibited. Nonetheless, the juxtaposition with the following phrase does indicate something significant, namely, that the prohibition in Egypt was limited to one day. <b>If you wish, say</b> instead that Rabbi Yehuda <b>does not employ</b> the <b>homiletic</b> method of <b>juxtaposition</b> of verses, except in limited circumstances. Accordingly, Rabbi Yehuda does not accept Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s opinion at all and holds that the prohibition against eating leavened bread during the Passover in Egypt applied for all seven days.
<b>The Master said</b> in the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who eats leavened bread from the sixth hour and onward transgresses a negative mitzva? As it is stated: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it”; this is the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon said to him: And is it possible to say this? Isn’t it already stated: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it; for seven days you shall eat <i>matzot</i>,”</b> linking the time of the prohibition against eating leavened bread with the time of the mitzva to eat <i>matza</i>?
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> indeed, <b>Rabbi Shimon is saying well to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> so how does Rabbi Yehuda use this verse to support his opinion? The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> That verse <b>comes to establish it as an obligation even nowadays.</b> One might have assumed that after the destruction of the Temple, when the Paschal lamb can no longer be brought, the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> no longer applies either. Therefore, the verse links the prohibition against eating leavened bread to the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> in order to teach that just as it is prohibited to eat leavened bread even in the absence of the Temple, so too, there remains an obligation to eat <i>matza</i> as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Shimon, from where does he</b> derive the need <b>to establish it as an obligation</b> even after the destruction of the Temple? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from</b> the following verse: “In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month <b>in the evening, you shall eat</b> <i>matzot</i>, until the twenty-first day in the evening” (Exodus 12:18). This verse connects the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> to the date of Passover and not only to the Paschal lamb. The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda,</b> what does he derive from this verse? The Gemara answers: He <b>requires it</b> to teach that there remains an obligation <b>for one who is</b> ritually <b>impure or on a distant journey</b> and cannot bring the Paschal lamb. <b>It could enter your mind to say that since he will not eat the Paschal lamb, he is also not</b> obligated <b>to eat <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs.</b> Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that he is obligated to eat them.
<b>And Rabbi Shimon,</b> from where does he derive this <i>halakha</i>? In his opinion, <b>a verse is not necessary</b> to teach that <b>one who is</b> ritually <b>impure or on a distant journey</b> is obligated to eat <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs, <b>as he is no worse than an uncircumcised man or a resident alien. As it is written: “And no uncircumcised man shall eat of it”</b> (Exodus 12:48). The added emphasis in <b>“of it”</b> indicates that only <b>it,</b> the Paschal lamb, <b>he does not eat; however, he</b> must <b>eat <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda,</b> how would he respond? The Gemara answers: Granted, the Torah did not need to add this verse. Nonetheless, <b>it is written in this</b> context that one who is impure or on a distant journey is obligated to eat <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs. <b>And it is written in that</b> context with regard to the uncircumcised man and the resident alien as well.
After clarifying the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Shimon, and Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, the Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is the mishna</b> taught? <b>If</b> one suggests that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> this cannot be, as Rabbi Yehuda <b>said leavened bread without stipulation</b> that the leavened bread belong to a Jew, indicating that one may not <b>even</b> benefit from leavened bread <b>of a gentile</b> over which Passover elapsed. Therefore, since this opinion contradicts the statement made in the mishna discussed here, Rabbi Yehuda can be ruled out as its author. <b>And if</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b>

Daf 29a

Rabbi Shimon <b>also permits</b> one to derive benefit from leavened bread after Passover even if it was <b>owned by a Jew. And if</b> the mishna follows the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, he would permit</b> one <b>to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it <b>even during</b> Passover.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Actually,</b> it is possible to explain that the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> he <b>derives</b> the restrictions pertaining to <b>the eating of leaven from</b> the restrictions relating to <b>seeing leaven.</b> The prohibition against <b>seeing leaven</b> is worded: “It shall not be seen by you.” It is understood to mean that <b>you should not see your own</b> or another Jew’s leaven. <b>But you may see</b> leaven that belongs <b>to others,</b> i.e., gentiles, <b>and</b> leaven consecrated <b>to God. Similarly,</b> with regard to the prohibition against <b>eating leaven</b> that was owned by a Jew during Passover after Passover, <b>you may not eat your own</b> leavened bread, <b>but you may eat</b> the leavened bread <b>of others or</b> the leaven consecrated <b>to God</b> after Passover.
<b>And by right it</b> should have <b>taught</b> that <b>even the eating</b> of leavened bread belonging to a gentile <b>is permitted</b> after the conclusion of Passover, <b>but since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught that it is forbidden to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> leavened bread belonging to <b>a Jew</b> after Passover, <b>he also taught</b> that <b>it is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> leavened bread belonging to <b>a gentile.</b> However, one should understand that it is permitted to eat this leavened bread as well. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>by right it</b> should have <b>taught that</b> even during Passover <b>it is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> leavened bread that belongs to gentiles. <b>But since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> about the leavened bread belonging to a <b>Jew after</b> Passover, <b>he also taught</b> about the leavened bread belonging to a gentile <b>after</b> Passover. Thus, one should not infer <i>halakhot</i> from the exact formulation of these details in the <i>baraita</i>, but rather understand that the mishna follows Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion.
<b>Rava said:</b> This is not so. <b>Actually,</b> our mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> However, this is difficult, as Rabbi Shimon states that it is permitted for a Jew to derive benefit from leavened bread that had been owned by another Jew during Passover, while our mishna explicitly states that this is forbidden. This can be resolved by explaining that <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> argues that it is permitted only according to Torah law. However, one who intentionally commits such a transgression <b>incurs a penalty. Since he transgressed</b> the prohibition <b>it shall not be seen and</b> the prohibition <b>it shall not be found,</b> the Sages decreed that it is forbidden for him to derive benefit from this leavened bread.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, this</b> explanation <b>is</b> consistent with <b>that which was taught</b> in the mishna: Leavened bread that <b>belonged to a Jew is forbidden because it is stated: “It shall not be seen”</b> (Exodus 13:7). According to this explanation, the connection between the prohibition against deriving benefit from leavened bread that was owned by a Jew during Passover and the verse prohibiting seeing leaven during Passover is clear. The prohibition against deriving benefit from this leavened bread is a rabbinically instituted fine for transgressing the Torah prohibition of “It shall not be seen.” <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov,</b> which states that our mishna follows the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, and which renders forbidden by Torah law deriving benefit from leavened bread that was owned by a Jew during Passover, why is this verse cited? The mishna <b>should have said</b> that it is forbidden <b>due to</b> the verse <b>“Leavened bread shall not be eaten”</b> (Exodus 13:3), as that is the verse from which Rabbi Yehuda derives this prohibition.
The Gemara answers: <b>Do you hold</b> that this proof <b>is referring to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, where the prohibition against deriving benefit from leavened bread owned by a Jew is discussed? <b>It is referring to the first clause</b> of the mishna, which discusses permission to derive benefit from leavened bread owned by a gentile, <b>and this is</b> what <b>it is saying: Leavened bread of a gentile, over which Passover has elapsed,</b> i.e., that remains after the conclusion of Passover, <b>it is permissible to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> it, <b>due to</b> the verse where <b>it is stated: “It shall not be seen by you.”</b> This indicates that <b>you may not see your own</b> leaven, <b>but you may see</b> leaven that belongs <b>to others and</b> leaven consecrated <b>to God. And he derives</b> the details <b>about</b> the prohibition <b>of eating leaven from</b> the prohibition <b>of seeing leaven.</b> The verse “It shall not be seen by you” should be understood as an explanation of what is permitted and not as an explanation of what is forbidden.
The Gemara comments that Rava and Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov <b>follow their</b> line of <b>reasoning. For it was stated</b> that they dispute this issue: With regard to <b>one who eats leaven of a gentile over which Passover has elapsed,</b> i.e., that remains after the conclusion of Passover, <b>according to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, Rava said: He is flogged,</b> as he has violated a Torah prohibition. <b>And Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: He is not flogged.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Rava said</b> that according to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>he is flogged,</b> as <b>Rabbi Yehuda does not derive</b> the prohibition against <b>eating leaven from</b> the prohibition against <b>seeing leaven.</b> Instead, he derives the prohibition from a verse that does not use the words “to you,” and therefore leavened bread owned by a gentile over Passover is forbidden in all circumstances. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: He is not flogged,</b> as Rabbi Yehuda <b>learns</b> the prohibition against <b>eating leaven from</b> the prohibition against <b>seeing leaven,</b> and thus it is limited to leavened bread owned by a Jew.
The Gemara notes: <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov retracted that</b> position on this matter. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who eats consecrated leavened bread during the festival</b> of Passover is guilty of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated items. If one performed this action unintentionally, then he must offer a guilt-offering to atone for using a consecrated item for non-sacred purposes. <b>And some say: He is not</b> guilty <b>of misuse</b> of consecrated items.
The Gemara asks: To <b>whom is</b> the phrase in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Some say,</b> referring? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This is Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana would render</b> the status of <b>Yom Kippur the same as</b> that of <b>Shabbat with regard to payment</b> for damage caused by a person in violation of the prohibitions of that day.
<b>Just as</b> one who desecrates <b>Shabbat</b> by intentionally causing damage to his fellow’s property, e.g., by lighting his stack of grain on fire, <b>is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty, since one who intentionally desecrates Shabbat is punished by stoning <b>and</b> is therefore <b>exempt from payment,</b> the basis for this exemption being the principle that after committing multiple transgressions, one is punished only with the most severe punishment; <b>so too,</b> one who causes damage by desecrating <b>Yom Kippur is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty, as this violation is punished with <i>karet</i>, i.e., spiritual death at the hand of Heaven, <b>and is</b> therefore <b>exempt from payment.</b> According to this position, one who eats leavened bread during Passover and is deserving of <i>karet</i> should also be exempt from other punishments, including the penalty for misuse of consecrated items. In any case, it is clear that both Sages mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> agree that leavened bread has monetary value. This must be due to the fact that one is permitted to derive benefit from it after Passover. Therefore, it appears that they both accept Rabbi Shimon’s position.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> The dispute mentioned in this <i>baraita</i> should be understood differently. Both <i>tanna’im</i> in the <i>baraita</i> accept the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, which states that one may derive benefit from leavened bread during Passover, and thus, in principle, one should be permitted to derive benefit from this consecrated leavened bread. Yet, unlike non-sacred leavened bread, which one may sell to gentiles or feed to dogs, it is prohibited to use consecrated leavened bread in this way. Therefore, the question whether this leavened bread has any monetary value depends on the question whether <b>one</b> may <b>redeem consecrated items in order to feed them to dogs,</b> and it is about this point that the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree.</b>
<b>The one who said</b> that <b>he misused</b> consecrated items by using this leavened bread during Passover <b>holds</b> that <b>one</b> may <b>redeem consecrated items in order to feed them to dogs.</b> Because the food may be redeemed for this purpose, the consecrated leavened bread does have some monetary value, and therefore using it is considered misuse of consecrated items. <b>And the one who said that he did not misuse</b> consecrated items <b>holds</b> that consecrated property may <b>not be redeemed</b> for this purpose, but only in order to provide food for a Jewish person. In this case, since it is forbidden to eat this leavened bread during Passover, the consecrated leavened bread has no value at all at this time. Therefore, one who eats such leavened bread is not guilty of misuse of consecrated items.
The Gemara comments: <b>Rav Aḥa bar Rava taught</b>

Daf 29b

<b>this <i>halakha</i> in the name of Rav Yosef with the following formulation: Everyone agrees that one</b> may <b>not redeem consecrated items in order to feed them to dogs. And here, they disagree</b> with regard to the question of whether <b>an item that can cause a financial</b> loss <b>is considered to be of monetary</b> value. The Sages disagree about the status of an object that does not have any present value but if lost or destroyed will cause the owner financial loss. In other words, they disagree as to whether such an item is considered to have inherent value. This dispute can be applied to our discussion of the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, who states that one is permitted to eat leavened bread after Passover even if it was owned by a Jew.
The Gemara explains: <b>The one who said</b> that <b>he misused</b> consecrated property by using consecrated leavened bread during Passover <b>holds that an item that can cause a financial</b> loss <b>is considered to be of monetary</b> value. Although the leavened bread is currently worthless, it can be eaten after Passover and will have some value at that time. It is therefore considered to have monetary value now, such that one who uses it is guilty of misuse of consecrated items. <b>And the one who said</b> that <b>he did not misuse</b> consecrated property <b>holds</b> that <b>an item that can cause a financial</b> loss <b>is not considered to be of monetary</b> value. Therefore, since the leavened bread is currently worthless, one who uses it would not be guilty of misuse of consecrated property.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov</b> explains the issue as follows: <b>Everyone agrees that an item that can cause a financial</b> loss <b>is considered to be of monetary</b> value, <b>and here they disagree with regard to</b> the same point of <b>dispute as Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon.</b> The opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>he did not misuse</b> consecrated items is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that one may not derive benefit from leavened bread that was owned by a Jew during Passover. Thus, the consecrated leavened bread is worthless, since it will remain prohibited after Passover as well. <b>And the one who said</b> that <b>he misused</b> consecrated items is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that one may derive benefit from leavened bread after the conclusion of Passover even if it was owned by a Jew during Passover. Therefore, the consecrated leavened bread is considered to be of monetary value, and one who uses it is guilty of misuse of consecrated items.
The Gemara raises a challenge: <b>But isn’t it Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov who said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda derives</b> the details of the prohibition against <b>eating leaven from</b> the details of the prohibition against <b>seeing leaven?</b> Just as it is permitted to see the leavened bread of a gentile or of God, so too, it is permitted to eat this type of leavened bread after Passover. Therefore, consecrated leavened bread would be permitted after Passover even according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. <b>Rather,</b> it should be understood that <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov retracted that</b> explanation of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, and agrees with Rava, who explains that Rabbi Yehuda maintains that any leavened bread in existence during Passover is forbidden afterward.
<b>Rav Ashi said that everyone</b> agrees <b>that one does not redeem</b> consecrated property in order to feed it to dogs, <b>and</b> similarly, everyone agrees that <b>an item that can cause a financial</b> loss <b>is not considered to be of monetary</b> value. <b>And here,</b> in this <i>baraita</i>, <b>they disagree with regard to</b> the same point of <b>dispute as</b> do <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and the Rabbis.</b> The opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>he misused</b> consecrated items by eating the consecrated leavened bread is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> who maintains that one may derive benefit from leavened bread that belongs to a Jew even during the seven days of Passover. Therefore, since the leavened bread has some value, one is guilty of misuse of consecrated items by using it. <b>And</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>he did not misuse</b> consecrated items is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who maintain that one may not derive benefit from leavened bread during Passover, thus rendering the consecrated leavened bread worthless. Although it may have some value after Passover, an item that can cause a financial loss is not considered to be of monetary value, and therefore it is presently considered to be worthless.
<b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>leavened bread</b> that becomes mixed with permitted food, the following distinction applies. <b>During its time</b> of prohibition, i.e., during the seven days of Passover, <b>leavened bread is forbidden whether</b> it is mixed <b>with its own type,</b> for example, when leavened flour is mixed with <i>matza</i> flour or when unleavened <i>matza</i> is mixed with leavened <i>matza</i>, <b>or</b> it is mixed <b>with another type</b> of substance. <b>Not during its time</b> of prohibition, but rather after Passover, if it is mixed <b>with its own type</b> of substance, then <b>it is prohibited.</b> However, if it is mixed <b>with another type</b> of substance, then <b>it is permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With what are we dealing? If you say that</b> there is enough leavened bread such that it <b>gives flavor</b> to the mixture, i.e., at least one part in sixty, then if it is <b>not during its time</b> and mixed <b>with another type</b> of substance, why <b>is it permitted? Doesn’t it give flavor</b> to the mixture, and, as one who eats this mixture will distinguish the forbidden flavor, the entire mixture is forbidden?
<b>Rather,</b> this case is dealing <b>with any amount,</b> a minimal quantity of leavened bread that has been mixed with a large quantity of matza. The <i>halakha</i> in this case is that <b>leavened bread during its time</b> of prohibition <b>is forbidden, whether</b> it is mixed <b>with its own type</b> of substance <b>or with another type</b> of substance. This statement of <b>Rav</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line <b>of reasoning</b> as follows: <b>As</b> it is <b>Rav and Shmuel who both say:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> foods <b>forbidden by the Torah</b> that become mixed with permitted foods, if the permitted food is of <b>its own type,</b> such that it is impossible to distinguish one from another, then even <b>any amount</b> of the prohibited substance renders the entire mixture prohibited. However, if the forbidden food was mixed <b>with another type</b> of substance, then the mixture becomes prohibited only when there is enough of the forbidden item to <b>give flavor</b> to the mixture.
<b>Rav rendered an</b> additional <b>decree</b> prohibiting <b>leavened bread during its time</b> of prohibition, when that leavened bread is mixed with <b>another type</b> of food even when only a small bit of it is mixed in, <b>due to</b> the prohibition against consuming a comparable mixture <b>with its own type</b> of substance. Owing to the severity of the prohibition against consuming leavened bread during Passover, Rav thought it necessary to render this additional decree. Rav’s statement that leavened bread <b>is forbidden not during its time,</b> when it is mixed <b>with its own type</b> of substance, <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who says that according to the Torah, leavened bread is forbidden even after Passover, and thus even a mixture of it is prohibited.
<b>But</b> if it is mixed with <b>another type</b> of substance <b>it is permitted, because</b> there is <b>no</b> need to go <b>so far</b> as <b>to render a decree with regard to</b> a mixture with <b>another type</b> of substance <b>not during its time, due to</b> the prohibition of a mixture with <b>the same type</b> of substance. Rav maintains that when any prohibited item falls into a mixture of a different type of substance, it is nullified, unless it gives flavor to the new mixture. Therefore, the same principle should apply to leavened bread after Passover, and a small amount should be nullified once the more serious prohibition no longer applies to it.
In contrast, <b>Shmuel said</b> that if <b>leavened bread</b> becomes mixed with permitted food <b>during its time</b> of prohibition, then the following distinction applies: If it becomes mixed <b>with its own type</b> of food <b>it is forbidden,</b> but if it becomes mixed <b>with another type</b> of food <b>it is permitted. If it</b> becomes mixed together <b>not during its time</b> of prohibition, but after Passover, then regardless <b>of whether</b> it becomes mixed <b>with its own type or with another type</b> of substance, <b>it is permitted.</b> With regard to the statement that <b>leavened bread</b> mixed <b>with the same type</b> of substance <b>during its time</b> of prohibition <b>is forbidden, Shmuel</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> below: <b>As</b> it is <b>Rav and Shmuel who both say:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> foods <b>prohibited by the Torah</b> that become mixed with permitted foods, if the permitted food is of <b>its own type,</b> such that it is impossible to distinguish one from another, then even <b>any amount</b> of the prohibited substance renders the entire mixture prohibited. However, if the prohibited food is mixed <b>with another type</b> of substance, then the mixture becomes prohibited only when there is enough of the forbidden item to <b>give flavor</b> to the mixture.
And Shmuel <b>did not render a decree</b> prohibiting a mixture <b>with another type</b> of substance, <b>due to</b> the prohibition against consuming a mixture with <b>its same type.</b> However, <b>not during its time,</b> but rather after Passover, the mixture <b>is permitted,</b> regardless of <b>whether</b> it was mixed <b>with its own type or with another type.</b> And this statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who states that after Passover one may derive benefit from leavened bread that was owned by a Jew during Passover.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to <b>leavened bread</b> that falls into a mixture <b>during its time</b> of prohibition, <b>whether</b> it is mixed <b>with its own type</b> of substance <b>or another type</b> of substance, <b>it becomes prohibited only when</b> there is enough of the forbidden item to <b>give flavor</b> to the mixture. However, <b>not during its time</b> of prohibition, but rather after Passover, <b>it is</b> always <b>permitted,</b> regardless <b>of whether</b> it falls into a mixture <b>of its own type</b> of substance <b>or</b> whether it falls into a mixture of <b>another type</b> of substance.
The Gemara explains this position: With regard to the statement that <b>leavened bread</b> that falls into a mixture <b>during its time</b> of prohibition, <b>whether with its own type</b> of food <b>or with another type</b> of food, then it is prohibited only <b>when it gives flavor</b> to the mixture, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> below. <b>As</b> it is <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish who both say:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> foods <b>forbidden by the Torah</b> that fall into a mixture, <b>whether of its own type</b> of food <b>or another type</b> of food, the mixture <b>is prohibited when</b> there is enough of the forbidden item <b>to give flavor</b> to the mixture. If less than this amount falls into the mixture, it is nullified by the large majority of permitted food. Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement that <b>not during its time</b> of prohibition, but rather after Passover, <b>it is permitted,</b> regardless of <b>whether</b> it falls into a mixture <b>of its own type</b> of food <b>or</b> into a mixture of <b>another type</b> of food, is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that leavened bread owned by a Jew during Passover is not prohibited afterward.

Daf 30a

<b>Rava said: The <i>halakha</i> is</b> that with regard to the prohibition against eating a mixture of <b>leavened bread during its time</b> of prohibition, i.e., during Passover, regardless of whether it is mixed <b>with its own type or with another type, it is forbidden,</b> even if <b>any amount</b> becomes mixed in, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav. Not during its time</b> of prohibition, but rather after the conclusion of Passover, regardless of whether the leavened bread was mixed <b>with its own type or with another type, it is permitted,</b> even when it gives flavor to the mixture. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who states that leavened bread owned by a Jew during Passover is permitted after Passover.
The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rava</b> actually <b>say this,</b> that according to Rabbi Shimon, leavened bread owned by a Jew on Passover is permitted after Passover? <b>But didn’t Rava</b> himself <b>say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon imposed a penalty</b> forbidding one from deriving benefit from leavened bread owned by a Jew during Passover, <b>since he transgressed</b> the prohibition <b>it shall not be seen and</b> the prohibition <b>it shall not be found?</b>
The Gemara resolves this challenge: <b>This</b> penalty <b>applies</b> only to leavened bread that is <b>in its pure</b> unadulterated form, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>a mixture, no,</b> one does not impose a penalty, even though the leavened bread is still extant. The Gemara adds: <b>And Rava follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> stated elsewhere, that indicates that he rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, <b>as Rava said: While we were</b> studying <b>in Rav Naḥman’s house,</b> on the evening <b>when the seven days of Passover had passed, he said to us: Go and buy leavened bread from the gentiles</b> who baked it on that day, the last day of Passover. Based on this story, it is clear that he maintained that one may eat leavened bread that was owned by a gentile during Passover.
<b>Rav said:</b> Earthenware <b>pots</b> in which leavened bread was cooked <b>during Passover</b> should <b>be broken,</b> as some small quantity of the flavor of the leavened bread was absorbed into the pot. It is therefore prohibited to cook in them again, as the forbidden flavor of this leavened bread would be transmitted to the new food. The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> was Rav so stringent with regard to these pots? <b>Let him retain</b> the pots until <b>after</b> the conclusion of <b>Passover and prepare</b> mixtures <b>of another type</b> of food <b>in them.</b> Even Rav maintains that when a small bit of leavened bread is mixed with another type of food after Passover, the mixture is permitted. The Gemara explains that he did not allow this due to <b>a rabbinic decree that perhaps one will come to prepare a mixture of the same type in</b> these pots, causing their contents to become prohibited. He therefore instructed that one destroy these pots in order to avoid this pitfall.
<b>And Shmuel said: They</b> need <b>not be broken. Rather, he</b> should <b>retain them until after its time,</b> i.e., the conclusion of Passover, <b>and</b> then he may <b>prepare</b> food of <b>either the same type or another type in them.</b>
<b>And Shmuel follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> stated elsewhere, <b>as Shmuel said to the pot merchants,</b> who would dramatically raise their prices after Passover: <b>Level the prices for your pots. And if</b> you do <b>not</b> bring your prices down, <b>I will teach you</b> that the <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> that one is permitted to derive benefit from leavened bread after Passover. This ruling would lead people to retain their vessels and desist from purchasing new vessels after Passover, and consequently the merchants would lose business.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let him</b> indeed <b>teach</b> this ruling <b>to them, for Shmuel holds</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> as was previously mentioned. As such, why did he not publicize his opinion on the matter? The Gemara answers: <b>It was Rav’s locale,</b> and therefore it would not be appropriate for Shmuel to publicly present a position with which Rav did not agree. However, when he saw the merchants raising their prices in an unfair manner, he nevertheless threatened to make his opinion on the matter public.
The Gemara recounts: There was <b>a certain oven that they smeared with grease</b> from meat, and consequently the flavor of meat was absorbed into it, and then they used it to bake bread. <b>Rava bar Ahilai prohibited eating this bread even with salt,</b> and not just with milk. This status would apply <b>forever</b> to bread baked in this oven, even during subsequent baking, <b>lest one eat</b> such bread <b>with <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a dairy-based seasoning, which would be a violation of the prohibition against eating meat with milk.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this statement: It was taught that <b>one</b> may <b>not knead the dough with milk, and if he</b> did <b>knead</b> the dough with milk, then <b>all of the bread is prohibited due to</b> concern that he will commit <b>a habitual transgression.</b> As one habitually eats bread with meat, there is a concern that one will come to eat this bread with meat as well, unwittingly transgressing the prohibition against eating meat with milk. <b>Similarly,</b>

Daf 30b

<b>one</b> may <b>not smear the</b> inside of an <b>oven with the fat tail [<i>alya</i>]</b> of a sheep, because it is meat. <b>And if one</b> did <b>smear</b> it over the oven, then <b>all of the bread</b> baked in it <b>is prohibited,</b> lest one accidentally eat this bread with milk. However, this applies only <b>until one kindles the oven</b> and burns off this fat. The Gemara infers from this <i>baraita</i> <b>that</b> if <b>the oven was kindled</b> afterward then <b>it is permitted in any case.</b> This would seem to present a <b>conclusive refutation of</b> the statement of <b>Rava bar Ahilai</b> who maintains that the bread cooked in this oven is prohibited forever, even after the oven is rekindled. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this <b>is a conclusive refutation</b> of his opinion.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Since</b> the statement of <b>Rava bar Ahilai was refuted, why did Rav say</b> that <b>pots</b> that were used for leavened bread <b>on Passover</b> should <b>be broken?</b> Presumably, their status could be remedied in the same way as was that of this oven, by heating them on a fire until the flavor of the leavened bread absorbed in them was removed. Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> There is a distinction between these two cases. <b>There,</b> it is referring to <b>a metal oven,</b> which can be cleansed through an additional kindling, while <b>here,</b> it is referring <b>to an earthenware pot,</b> where additional kindling is insufficient, as the earthenware has the capacity to absorb more of the flavor of the leavened bread and it cannot be purged by fire.
<b>If you wish, say</b> instead that <b>both this,</b> the oven, <b>and that,</b> the pot, <b>are earthenware,</b> but that the following distinction applies. <b>This,</b> the oven, <b>is kindled from the inside,</b> and as the fire is kindled inside the oven itself, it consumes the absorbed flavor of the leavened bread. While <b>that,</b> the pot, <b>is kindled from the outside,</b> such that the flavor of the prohibited material absorbed in the pot is not purged by the fire. <b>And if you say, so too</b> here, in the case of the pot, <b>he should perform the kindling</b> procedure on the pots from the <b>inside</b> to remove that which has been absorbed, this is not reasonable. Presumably, the owner of the pot will <b>be concerned lest it burst</b> if he makes the pot too hot. Therefore, he will not use sufficient heat to ensure that the leavened bread that has been absorbed will be completely purged.
The Gemara concludes: <b>Therefore,</b> based on this principle, <b>this griddle</b> made from earthenware tiles that was used to bake bread is a type of oven where <b>the kindling is from the outside and</b> therefore <b>prohibited. But if he fills it with</b> burning <b>coals,</b> then <b>it seems well</b> and it can be used afterward. Because this vessel is often subject to a high level of heat, the owner will not be concerned that it will break when heated.
