<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> With regard to <b>these knives, how do we prepare them</b> for use <b>during Passover?</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him: For me,</b> personally, <b>we craft new ones.</b> Ravina <b>said to him:</b> It works out <b>well for Master, as you are able</b> to afford new knives. However, <b>what</b> should <b>one who is unable</b> to purchase new knives do? <b>He said to him: I was speaking of</b> making them <b>like new</b> by thoroughly cleaning them in the following manner: One should cover <b>the</b> wooden <b>handles in mud,</b> so that they will not be burned, and heat <b>the metal with fire</b> until it is white-hot. <b>And then I place the handles</b> of the knives <b>in boiling water</b> in order to remove anything that had been absorbed into the wood. <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that with regard to both <b>this,</b> the blade, and <b>that,</b> the handle, it is sufficient to immerse them <b>in boiling water,</b> so long as this water is still <b>in a primary vessel.</b> The water must still be in the original pot in which it was boiled and not poured from another pot.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: A wooden ladle</b> should <b>be purged in boiling water in a primary vessel</b> in order to remove the flavor of the forbidden food that it absorbed. The Gemara states: He <b>holds</b> in accordance with the principle: <b>As it absorbs</b> the flavor of the forbidden substance, <b>so it emits it.</b> The same cooking method and level of heat that caused the flavor of the forbidden substance to be absorbed in the vessel suffices to discharge the flavor of that substance from the vessel. Therefore, a ladle that absorbed flavor of leavened bread from a pot of boiling water which was over a fire will discharge the flavor of leavened bread once it is placed in the boiling water again.
<b>They raised a dilemma before Ameimar:</b> Concerning <b>certain glazed [<i>konya</i>]</b> earthenware <b>vessels, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to using them during Passover?</b> The Gemara explains: With regard to <b>green</b> vessels, the dilemma need <b>not</b> even <b>be raised,</b> as <b>they are certainly prohibited</b> as their coating does not prevent them from absorbing the flavor of leavened bread. <b>Let the dilemma be raised</b> with regard to <b>black and white</b> vessels: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> here? <b>And</b> furthermore, the dilemma need <b>not be raised when they have cracks; as</b> the leavened bread will remain stuck in these cracks, <b>they are certainly prohibited. Let the dilemma be raised</b> with regard to <b>smooth</b> vessels: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in that case?
Ameimar <b>said to him: I saw that</b> some of the liquid <b>is expelled [<i>demidayeti</i>]?</b> from the outside of the vessel. <b>Apparently they absorb and are</b> therefore <b>prohibited,</b> as they cannot be prepared for use on Passover through cleansing, <b>and the Torah testified about earthenware vessels</b> that when they absorb the flavor of a prohibited substance, <b>they will never leave their defective</b> status and they remain permanently prohibited. The Torah states that a person may cleanse other vessels by scouring and rinsing them, whereas it states that earthenware vessels must be broken.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>wine</b> used for a <b>libation,</b> with regard to which the <i>halakha</i> of earthenware vessels is more lenient? <b>As Mareimar taught: A glazed</b> earthenware <b>vessel is permitted whether it is black, white, or green</b> if it was used to store wine belonging to gentiles. Any wine that came in contact with gentiles is suspected of having been poured as a libation offering to idolatry. <b>And if you say</b> that it is possible to distinguish between the prohibition of <b>wine</b> used for a <b>libation,</b> which is a <b>rabbinic</b> prohibition, <b>and that of leavened bread,</b> which is forbidden <b>by Torah</b> law, this is difficult, as <b>all</b> ordinances <b>that the Sages instituted, they instituted similar to Torah</b> law. Once they have declared that this item is prohibited, the principles applicable to Torah prohibitions apply to it as well. Ameimar <b>said to him:</b> The distinction between the two cases is that with regard to <b>this</b> vessel, which is used for cooking during Passover, its primary <b>use is with hot</b> foods, and therefore the flavor of the leavened bread has become absorbed within its walls. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>this</b> vessel, which is used to store wine, <b>its</b> primary <b>use is with cool</b> liquids, which are not absorbed to the same degree.
The Gemara continues discussing the ways that a vessel must be cleansed so that it can be used during Passover. <b>Rava bar Abba said that Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said that Shmuel said: Any vessel that was used for leavened bread</b> only <b>while cool can be used for <i>matza</i>,</b> because no flavor of the leavened bread was absorbed by the vessel. The <b>exception</b> to this rule is <b>the leaven container</b> where the yeast was stored, <b>since its leavening is</b> more <b>potent,</b> and it can be assumed that the flavor from the yeast has entered the walls of the vessel even without heat. <b>Rav Ashi said: And the spice container,</b> in which potent spices that contained flour were stored, <b>has the same</b> status <b>as the leaven container whose leavening is potent.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>certain bowls of Meḥoza, since it is common to knead leavened bread in them and</b> then <b>store the leavened bread in them, they are considered to be like a leaven container whose leavening is potent.</b> The Gemara asks: Why did Rava find it necessary to make this statement? Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that these bowls are the same as a leaven container? The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>since</b> these bowls <b>are spacious, the air dominates them and they do not absorb</b> the leavened bread in the same way as does a leaven container, therefore, <b>he teaches us</b> that no such distinction applies.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a gentile lent money to a Jew,</b> and the Jew gave him <b>leavened bread as</b> collateral until after Passover, and <b>after Passover</b> the gentile retains this leavened bread in lieu of payment, then <b>one is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> this leavened bread. Since the leavened bread was retained by the gentile based on the transfer that took place prior to Passover, the leavened bread is considered to have belonged to the gentile during Passover. Whereas if <b>a Jew lent money to a gentile,</b> and <b>leavened bread</b> was given as collateral during Passover in the same manner as in the previous case, then <b>after Passover it is forbidden to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from this leavened bread. Since this leavened bread was considered to be in the Jew’s property during Passover, it is forbidden to derive benefit from it afterward.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagree about the rights of a <b>creditor</b> with regard to collateral. <b>Abaye said: He retroactively collects</b> the property. In a case where the creditor had a lien on the property of the debtor and the debtor defaults on the loan, it is considered as if the creditor acquired rights to the collateral at the time of the loan and not at the time of collection. <b>And Rava said:</b> This is not the case, but rather, <b>he acquires</b> the collateral <b>from that point forward,</b> and has rights to the collateral only from the time that the loan was due. This dispute has ramifications for the status of the property, and actions undertaken with regard to it, during the intervening period. The Gemara sets several limitations on the scope of this dispute: <b>Anywhere that the debtor consecrated or sold</b> the field that was serving as collateral, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>the creditor can come and seize</b> this property and override the sale, because its status as collateral preceded its sale.

Daf 31a

<b>Or</b> if the debtor consecrated the property, the creditor can <b>come and redeem</b> it through a symbolic payment to the Temple. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: The creditor may <b>add an additional dinar</b> to the amount of the loan <b>and redeem this property.</b> Although strictly speaking he need not redeem it, this payment was instituted so that it would not appear as though property were removed from the consecrated Temple jurisdiction without a payment. <b>When they disagree</b> is in a case <b>when the creditor sold or consecrated</b> the property in the interim between the giving of the collateral and the time the loan was due.
<b>Abaye said: He retroactively acquires</b> the collateral. <b>Since the time arrived and he did not repay</b> his loan, <b>it has become clear retroactively that it was in</b> the creditor’s <b>jurisdiction at the outset.</b> Therefore, <b>he did well to consecrate or sell</b> it. However, <b>Rava said: He collects it from that point forward, since if the</b> borrower <b>had money he would remove the</b> creditor’s lien <b>with</b> this <b>money</b> and the lender would not acquire the property. <b>It is found</b> that the creditor <b>acquires</b> the property <b>now,</b> at the time when the loan is due, and consequently he did not have the right to consecrate or sell it before this time.
Before bringing proofs for either side of this dispute, the Gemara attempts to clarify Rava’s position. <b>Did Rava</b> actually <b>say this?</b> A statement he makes in a different context appears to contradict the one made in his name here. <b>But didn’t Rami bar Ḥama say: Reuven sold a field to Shimon with a guarantee</b> that if the field is repossessed, Reuven will compensate Shimon for his loss. Shimon did not pay for the purchase, and instead <b>set up</b> the value of the field <b>as a loan.</b> In the meantime, <b>Reuven died and a creditor of Reuven’s came</b> to collect for a loan that Reuven had taken before he sold the field, as Reuven had no other land remaining, and he <b>seized</b> the land <b>from Shimon,</b> since it was mortgaged to this loan. <b>And Shimon went and appeased</b> the creditor <b>with money</b> so the creditor would allow him to keep this field.
<b>By right, Reuven’s sons</b> can <b>come and say to Shimon</b> that he must pay them the money that he owes for the field. And they are not required to pay Shimon if he demands compensation for the repossession of his field. They can say that <b>our father left us movable property in your hands,</b> i.e., the money you owe us for the field, <b>and,</b> as a general rule, <b>movable property that has been left to orphans is not mortgaged to a creditor.</b> The orphans can claim that the field belongs to Shimon, and as there is no land left for the orphans, there is no way for Shimon to recover the compensation that he is owed. The money he owes Reuven is considered movable property, and therefore he cannot recover his losses from these funds.
<b>And Rava said</b> with regard to this case: <b>If Shimon is clever he will pay them</b> what he owes with <b>real estate</b> and not with money. Since they now have real estate received from their father’s estate, Shimon <b>can then collect</b> the field <b>from them</b> as compensation for the original field that Reuven sold to Shimon. <b>As Rav Naḥman said:</b> When <b>orphans collect real estate for a debt owed to their father</b> from one person, another <b>creditor can come and seize this</b> land <b>from them</b> in order to repay the father’s debt.
The Gemara applies this discussion to our original case. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that a creditor <b>collects retroactively,</b> and the field is considered as though it belonged to the creditor from the time of the loan, <b>due to this</b> reason, <b>he can then collect</b> the money <b>from them, because it is considered as though he collected it during their father’s lifetime.</b> Because the field given by Shimon to repay his debt retroactively belonged to Reuven from the time that Shimon agreed to pay for the field, therefore Shimon can now claim this land from Reuven’s heirs. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>he collects</b> it <b>from this point forward, why can he then collect</b> this land <b>from them? It is as though the orphans purchased this property. And if orphans buy property, does</b> it become <b>indebted to a creditor</b> of their father? Only property that belonged to the father can be seized in order to pay back his debt, and therefore Rava’s statement in the case appears to contradict his statement with regard to the transfer of ownership of collateral.
The Gemara resolves this contradiction: <b>It is different there,</b> in this case, <b>as</b> Shimon could have <b>said to</b> Reuven’s children that <b>just as I am indebted to your father, so too, I am indebted to your father’s creditor.</b> And this principle can be learned <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Natan</b> that one who lends to one person and borrows from another can be considered as a middleman between his creditor and his borrower. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Natan says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that when one lends one hundred</b> dinar <b>[<i>maneh</i>] to his fellow, and that fellow</b> lends a similar sum <b>to</b> a third <b>fellow, that we take</b> the money <b>from this one,</b> the second debtor, <b>and give it to that one,</b> the first creditor, without going through the middleman, who is both the first debtor and the second creditor? <b>The verse states: “And he shall give it to him whom he has wronged”</b> (Numbers 5:7), which indicates that the loan should be repaid to the creditor to whom the money is ultimately owed. Therefore, payment is made to the original creditor regardless of the issue of retroactive acquisition of the collateral.
The Gemara proceeds to bring proofs for the two sides of the question of retroactive acquisition. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>a gentile lent money to a Jew,</b> and the Jew gave him <b>leavened bread as</b> collateral during Passover, and <b>after Passover</b> the gentile attained this leavened bread in lieu of payment, then <b>one is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> the leavened bread. The Gemara attempts to clarify this position: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>he retroactively collects</b> this property, and the leavened bread was acquired retroactively by the gentile, <b>it is due to this</b> that <b>one is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from it</b> after Passover.
<b>But if you say</b> that <b>he collects it from this point forward,</b> then <b>why</b> should <b>one be permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> this leavened bread? The leavened bread <b>was in the possession of a Jew</b> during Passover, and therefore it should be forbidden. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case where <b>he deposited [<i>hirhin</i>]</b> the leavened bread <b>with</b> the gentile in his home, and since the leavened bread was in the gentile’s possession during Passover, it is considered as if it belonged to the gentile, provided the gentile ultimately retains ownership of the leavened bread when the Jew defaults on the loan.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this dispute is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> As it was taught: If <b>a Jew lends money to a gentile</b> and the gentile gives him <b>leavened bread as</b> collateral, <b>then</b> the Jew <b>does not commit any transgression after Passover. They said in the name of Rabbi Meir that he commits a transgression. What, isn’t it that they disagree about this, that one Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that the Jew transgresses by owning leavened bread <b>because he retroactively collects</b> the leavened bread and has therefore owned it during Passover, <b>and one Sage,</b> who states that the Jew does not commit a transgression, <b>holds</b> that <b>he collects it from this point forward,</b> and therefore it was not considered to be in his possession during Passover?
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it that way? <b>Say the latter clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i>: <b>However, if a gentile lends</b> money <b>to a Jew with leavened bread</b> as collateral, then <b>after Passover everyone agrees that he commits a transgression. However,</b> if the preceding explanation is correct, <b>it needed</b> to state <b>the opposite</b> of what it said in the first clause, as the case in the latter clause is the reverse of that in the first clause. Namely, <b>according to the one who said there,</b> in the first clause of the <i>baraita</i>, that <b>he does not commit a transgression,</b> he should say that <b>here,</b> in this case, <b>he does commit a transgression. And according to the one who said there,</b> in the first clause of the <i>baraita</i>, that <b>he does commit a transgression,</b> he should say that <b>here,</b> in the latter clause, <b>he does not commit a transgression.</b> For if the creditor retroactively acquires the collateral, then it is as though it belonged to a gentile during Passover, and therefore the Jew would not have committed a transgression by owning it.

Daf 31b

<b>Rather, with what are we dealing here?</b> With a situation <b>where he,</b> the gentile debtor, <b>deposited</b> the leavened bread that was serving as collateral <b>with him,</b> the Jewish creditor, <b>and they disagree with regard to</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yitzḥak. As Rabbi Yitzḥak said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a creditor acquires collateral</b> given to him, and is considered its owner so long as the item is in his possession? <b>As it is stated:</b> “You shall surely return the pledge to him when the sun goes down, that he may sleep in his garment, and bless you; <b>and it shall be a righteousness for you</b> before the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 24:13). Rabbi Yitzḥak infers: <b>If</b> the creditor <b>does not acquire the collateral,</b> then <b>from where is the righteousness</b> involved in returning it? In this case, the creditor would not be giving up anything of his own. <b>From here</b> it is learned <b>that a creditor acquires the collateral.</b>
The Gemara applies this principle to the explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>this applies only when a Jew</b> takes collateral <b>from a</b> fellow <b>Jew, such that I would read</b> and apply the verse <b>“It shall be righteousness for you”</b> and establish that the collateral becomes the property of the lender. <b>However,</b> the verse does not speak about the case where <b>a Jew</b> takes collateral <b>from a gentile,</b> and therefore <b>he does not acquire</b> the collateral; it still belongs to the gentile. Therefore, when a Jew has leavened bread as collateral from a gentile to whom he lent money on Passover, he does not violate any prohibition, as the collateral still belongs to the gentile.
However, <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that one can derive <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference:</b> If <b>a Jew acquires</b> collateral <b>from</b> another <b>Jew, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that he will he acquire collateral <b>from a gentile? However,</b> with regard to <b>a gentile who lends money to a Jew with leavened bread as</b> collateral, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>he transgresses</b> this prohibition after Passover. <b>There,</b> in that case, <b>the gentile certainly does not acquire</b> collateral <b>from the Jew,</b> and such a transaction could be completed only via the usual modes of acquisition.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>a gentile lent money to a Jew,</b> and the Jew gave him <b>leavened bread as</b> collateral until after Passover, and <b>after Passover</b> he retains this leavened bread in lieu of payment, then <b>one is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> this leavened bread. <b>Even granted</b> that this is referring to a case where <b>he deposited</b> the leavened bread <b>with him,</b> the gentile, <b>didn’t you say</b> that <b>a gentile does not acquire</b> collateral <b>from a Jew,</b> and if this is the case, then why is it permissible to derive benefit from this leavened bread? According to the previously stated principle, this leavened bread remains Jewish property. The Gemara resolves this question: <b>This is not difficult,</b> for <b>this</b> case, where the gentile acquires the leavened bread and therefore it is permitted to derive benefit from it, is <b>when</b> the gentile <b>said to him</b> that if he does not repay his loan, then the collateral will be acquired <b>from now,</b> i.e., from the time of the loan. <b>And that</b> case, where it is forbidden to derive benefit from the leavened bread, is <b>when he did not say</b> that it would be acquired <b>from now</b> by the gentile.
<b>From where do you say that he distinguishes between</b> a case <b>where he said</b> that the collateral would be acquired <b>from now and</b> a case <b>where he did not say</b> that it would be acquired <b>from now? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a gentile deposited with a Jew bread baked in an oven [<i>purni</i>]</b> as collateral for a loan, then <b>he,</b> the Jew, <b>does not transgress</b> the prohibition it shall not be seen and the prohibition it shall not be found. <b>However, if he said to him: I have made them yours</b> from now if I do not repay my loan, then it is considered as though the bread belonged to the Jew, and <b>he transgresses</b> this prohibition. If one assumes that there is no difference between a case where the debtor says: From now, and a case where he doesn’t say: From now, then <b>what is different in the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>and what is different in the latter clause? Rather,</b> must <b>one not conclude from it that there is a difference between</b> a case <b>where he says to him</b> that he will acquire it <b>from now and</b> a case <b>where he does not say to him</b> that he will acquire it <b>from now?</b> The Gemara concurs: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is the case.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: With regard to the case of <b>a store</b> owned by <b>a Jew and</b> whose <b>contents belong to the Jew, and gentile workers would enter there</b> periodically, then <b>it is forbidden to</b> derive <b>benefit from the leavened bread that is found there after Passover, and needless to say,</b> it is forbidden <b>to eat</b> this leavened bread, for it is presumed to belong to the Jewish owner. Conversely, if <b>a store</b> is owned by <b>a gentile and its contents belong to the gentile, and Jewish workers enter and exit</b> the store, then it can be presumed that <b>the leavened bread that is found there after Passover</b> belonged to the gentile, and therefore one is <b>permitted to eat it</b> after Passover. And <b>needless to say,</b> it is permitted <b>to</b> derive <b>benefit from</b> this leavened bread.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Leavened bread upon which a rockslide has fallen is considered as though it has been eliminated,</b> and it is not necessary to dig it up in order to burn it. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Any</b> leavened bread that has been covered to such an extent <b>that a dog cannot search after it</b> is considered to have been eliminated.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> Although it is not necessary to dig up the leavened bread, one is nevertheless <b>required to nullify</b> the leavened bread <b>in his heart</b> lest it become exposed during Passover. Although it may not be visible at the moment, this leavened bread may be uncovered during Passover, and he will transgress a prohibition by its being seen. It was <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>How much,</b> how deep, <b>will a dog search?</b> It will search <b>three handbreadths</b> deep.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Yosef, said to Rav Ashi: With regard to that which Shmuel said,</b> that deposited <b>money is considered to be guarded</b> securely by an unpaid bailee, who would nonetheless not be responsible if it were stolen, <b>only</b> when it is buried <b>in the ground, is it necessary</b> to bury this deposited money <b>three handbreadths deep,</b> comparable to leavened bread, <b>or not? He said to him: Here,</b> with regard to Passover, the concern is that the dog will find the food <b>due to</b> its <b>smell,</b> and therefore <b>three handbreadths are required. There,</b> in the case of money, <b>it is</b> necessary to bury the money <b>in order to conceal it from view.</b> Therefore, <b>it is not required</b> to bury it <b>three</b> handbreadths deep, as animals will not search for it and people will not see it. The Gemara asks: If this is the case, then <b>how</b> deep is one required to bury it? <b>Rafram bar Pappa</b> from the city of <b>Sikhra said: One handbreadth</b> is sufficient for the money to be considered concealed.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>If one unwittingly eats <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread on Passover,</b> not realizing that the food was <i>teruma</i>, then <b>he must pay the principal and an</b> additional <b>fifth.</b> This is because one who unwittingly eats <i>teruma</i> must compensate the priest for the value of the <i>teruma</i> and add a fifth of the value, even though the <i>teruma</i> is considered to be valueless on Passover. If he <b>intentionally</b> ate the <i>teruma</i> then <b>he is exempt from payment;</b> as he is liable to receive the severe punishment of <i>karet</i>, he is therefore exempt from the lesser punishment of payment. If he ate impure <i>teruma</i> in this manner then he is not even required to pay <b>its monetary</b> value <b>in wood,</b> for one who derives benefit from impure <i>teruma</i> calculates its value by treating it as though it were fuel for burning. While impure <i>teruma</i> can be used in this manner during the rest of the year, one may not derive any benefit from leavened bread on Passover, and therefore such <i>teruma</i> is worthless.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there,</b> in <i>Terumot</i>: <b>One who unwittingly eats <i>teruma</i> pays the principal and an</b> additional <b>fifth, both one who eats</b> it, <b>and one who drinks</b> it.

Daf 32a

<b>And</b> even with regard to <b>one who anoints</b> himself with the <i>teruma</i> oil, <b>both</b> in a case of <b>ritually impure <i>teruma</i> as well as</b> in a case of <b>ritually pure <i>teruma</i>, he must pay</b> an additional <b>fifth</b> if he unwittingly consumes this <i>teruma</i>. If he unwittingly consumes this fifth then he must pay <b>an</b> additional <b>fifth of the fifth.</b> The original fifth has a status comparable to <i>teruma</i> itself, and therefore one is required to pay an additional fifth for consuming it.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages with regard to the laws of <i>teruma</i>: <b>When he pays</b> for this <i>teruma</i>, <b>does he pay according to the measure</b> of the <i>teruma</i> <b>or according to its monetary</b> value? The Gemara explains the question in greater detail: <b>Anywhere that</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>is worth four <i>zuz</i> at the outset,</b> i.e., at the time he consumed the <i>teruma</i>, <b>and is worth</b> only <b>one <i>zuz</i> at the end,</b> at the time of payment, <b>do not raise a dilemma,</b> for in that case <b>he is certainly</b> required <b>to pay according to the monetary</b> value <b>at the outset.</b> The rationale behind this ruling is <b>that he is no worse than a thief,</b> and therefore the law in this case is the same as if he had stolen property from another person. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>All thieves must repay</b> what they have stolen according to the value of the stolen object <b>at the time it was stolen,</b> even if its value subsequently goes down.
<b>You can raise the dilemma,</b> however, with regard to a case <b>where it was worth one <i>zuz</i> at the outset,</b> when it was consumed, <b>and at the end,</b> at the time of the payment, <b>it was worth four <i>zuz</i>. What</b> is the ruling in that case? Does <b>he pay according to the measure</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>as the</b> treasurer of the consecrated property can <b>say to him: You ate a <i>se’a</i> and you</b> must <b>pay a <i>se’a</i>,</b> even if the value of the <i>teruma</i> has increased, <b>or perhaps he</b> must repay <b>according to the monetary</b> value, and if <b>he ate a <i>zuz</i></b> worth of <i>teruma</i> then <b>he</b> must <b>pay a <i>zuz</i>?</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an answer to this question from what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who ate dried figs</b> that were <i>teruma</i> <b>and paid</b> the priest <b>with dates,</b> may <b>a blessing rest upon him,</b> as dates are worth more than dried figs. <b>Granted, if you say that one</b> must <b>repay according to the measure</b> of <i>teruma</i> he ate, it is <b>due to this</b> that <b>a blessing</b> should <b>rest upon him, as he ate a <i>se’a</i> of dried figs that are worth one <i>zuz</i> and gave</b> in return <b>a <i>se’a</i> of dates worth four <i>zuz</i>. However, if you say that</b> he must <b>repay according to the monetary</b> value of the <i>teruma</i>, then why <b>should a blessing rest upon him? He ate a <i>zuz</i> worth</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>and he paid a <i>zuz</i> worth</b> as compensation; what is laudatory about his payment?
<b>Abaye said: Actually,</b> one can explain that <b>he</b> must <b>repay according to the monetary</b> value of the <i>teruma</i>, <b>and why</b> is it stated that a <b>blessing</b> should <b>rest upon him?</b> This is <b>because he ate an item that buyers don’t jump at,</b> i.e., it is undesirable to buyers, <b>but paid with an item that buyers jump at.</b> Consequently, although the produce he gives is worth no more than the produce he ate, the priest still prefers this type of payment, as he can more easily resell this produce.
The Gemara seeks proof with regard to this dispute: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One who unwittingly eats <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread on Passover</b> must <b>pay the principal and an</b> additional <b>fifth. Granted, if you say that he</b> must <b>pay according to the measure</b> of <i>teruma</i> that he ate, <b>it is well.</b> As he ate a <i>se’a</i> of <i>teruma</i> he must also repay a <i>se’a</i>. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>he</b> must <b>pay according to the monetary</b> value of the <i>teruma</i>, this is difficult, for <b>is leavened bread on Passover of</b> any <b>monetary</b> value? Certainly it is not worth anything, given that it is forbidden to benefit from this food. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> this leavened bread does indeed have monetary value. In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said</b> that <b>it is permissible to</b> derive <b>benefit from leavened bread on Passover.</b>
The Gemara challenges this suggestion: <b>If that is so,</b> then <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna, where it is stated: <b>If</b> he consumes the <i>teruma</i> <b>intentionally, then he is exempt from payment and from</b> paying the priest <b>for its monetary</b> value as <b>wood.</b> But <b>if</b> this follows the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> then <b>why</b> is he <b>exempt from payment</b> to the priest for the value of the <i>teruma</i> <b>and for its monetary</b> value <b>in wood?</b> Although he is exempt from paying the additional fifth as he acted intentionally, he nonetheless should be required to compensate the priest for the financial loss he caused him, as in any other case of theft.
The Gemara answers: <b>He holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana rendered</b> the status of <b>Yom Kippur the same as</b> that of <b>Shabbat with regard to payment.</b> In his opinion, not only a person who committed a transgression punishable by a court-administered capital punishment, like one who desecrated Shabbat, is exempt from monetary payment incurred at the time of the transgression. Even one who is deserving of a divinely administered capital punishment, such as one who desecrates Yom Kippur and is punished with <i>karet</i>, is exempt from monetary payment for property he damaged in the course of such an act. Therefore, since one who consumes another person’s leavened bread during Passover is deserving of <i>karet</i>, he is exempt from monetary payment incurred by this act.
The Gemara comments: The question of whether one must repay according to the measurement or the monetary value of the <i>teruma</i> is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>If one eats <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread on Passover,</b> whether intentionally or unwittingly, then <b>he is exempt from payment and</b> for <b>its monetary</b> value <b>in wood;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b> Whereas <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to pay. <b>Rabbi Akiva said to Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri: What benefit</b> can <b>he derive from this?</b> What benefit could the priest have derived from this <i>teruma</i> as it is prohibited to benefit from this <i>teruma</i> and the <i>teruma</i> is therefore worthless? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said to Rabbi Akiva: What benefit</b> can <b>one derive from eating ritually impure <i>teruma</i> on the rest of the days of the year,</b> and yet nevertheless the non-priest is still obligated to <b>pay</b> for what he has taken. Despite the fact that a priest may not eat impure <i>teruma</i>, a non-priest must reimburse the priest for the principal of the <i>teruma</i> and add an additional fifth if he eats it.
Rabbi Akiva <b>said to him: No,</b> a distinction can be made between these two cases: <b>If you say</b> that he is obligated to pay <b>in</b> a case of <b>ritually impure <i>teruma</i> on the rest of the days of the year, that although it is not permissible to eat it,</b> the priest <b>is</b> nevertheless <b>permitted to burn it</b> and derive benefit from the heat generated as a result of this burning, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> the same <b>with regard to this,</b> <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread during Passover, <b>that is not permitted to be eaten or burned? Rather, to what may this be compared?</b> It is similar <b>to <i>teruma</i> of berries and grapes that became ritually impure, which is not permitted to be eaten or burned,</b> as berries and grapes are unfit for firewood.
The <i>Tosefta</i> adds: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said,</b> that these <i>tanna’im</i> disagree about the reimbursement for <i>teruma</i>? It was said with regard to a case where <b>he separated <i>teruma</i></b> in a permitted manner <b>and it became leavened</b> during Passover. <b>However, if he separated the <i>teruma</i> from leavened bread during Passover,</b> then <b>everyone agrees that it is not consecrated,</b> as it is worthless.
<b>It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the verse “And if a man eats a sacred thing in error, then he shall add a fifth part in addition to it, <b>and shall give to the priest the sacred item”</b> (Leviticus 22:14), the Sages expound as follows: He must give the priest <b>an item that is fit to be consecrated, to the exclusion of one who eats <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread on Passover, who is exempt from payment</b> of the <i>teruma</i> and even from paying <b>its monetary</b> value <b>as wood;</b> this is the statement of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to reimburse the priest for these items. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov said to Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma: What benefit can</b> the priest <b>derive from this</b> <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread, as it is prohibited to benefit from it? <b>Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma said to Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov: What benefit can one derive from eating ritually impure <i>teruma</i> on the rest of the days of the year,</b> and yet a non-priest who eats it must <b>pay</b> the priest.
Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov <b>said to him: No,</b> a distinction can be made between these two cases: <b>If you say</b> he is obligated to pay <b>in</b> a case of <b>ritually impure <i>teruma</i> on the rest of the days of year, that although it is not permissible to eat it,</b> the priest <b>is</b> nonetheless <b>permitted to burn it</b> and derive benefit from the heat generated as a result of this burning, <b>shall you say</b> the same <b>with regard to this,</b> <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread during Passover, <b>that is not permitted to be eaten or burned?</b> Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma <b>said to him: Even</b> <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread on Passover <b>is permitted to be burned, for if the priest wishes, he may throw it before his dog or burn it under his food,</b> for Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma agrees with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili that one may derive benefit from leavened bread during Passover.

Daf 32b

<b>Abaye said: Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, Rabbi Akiva, and Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri all hold</b> that <b>it is forbidden to</b> derive <b>benefit from leavened bread during Passover. And they disagree with regard to the following</b> issue: <b>Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>one pays according to the monetary</b> value, and therefore he need not pay anything for consuming <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread during Passover. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri holds</b> that <b>one pays according to the measure</b> of <i>teruma</i> that he consumed, such that even if he ate <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread on Passover he must repay this amount.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <b>obvious?</b> There does not seem to be another way to explain these opinions. The Gemara rejects this question: This statement is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri also holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> that states that <b>one</b> must <b>pay according to the monetary</b> value of the <i>teruma</i>. <b>And there,</b> in the case of leavened bread, <b>this is the reason that</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri <b>deems him liable</b> to pay for the <i>teruma</i> <b>because he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said: It is permissible to</b> derive <b>benefit from leavened bread during Passover.</b> Therefore, <b>he teaches us</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri agrees that one may not derive benefit from leavened bread during Passover.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And say it is indeed so,</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri accepts Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s position. The Gemara rejects this possibility: <b>If this was</b> the case, then <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri should have responded to Rabbi Akiva in the same way</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar Ḥisma responded to Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov,</b> by saying that this leavened bread may be fed to a dog thus deriving benefit from it. Since he did not offer this answer, it is clear that he agrees that deriving benefit from leavened bread during Passover is forbidden.
After mentioning cases where a person damages <i>teruma</i>, the Gemara continues with a discussion of this topic. <b>The Rabbis taught:</b> A non-priest <b>who eats an olive-bulk of <i>teruma</i></b> must <b>pay the principal</b> value of the <i>teruma</i> itself <b>and an</b> additional <b>fifth. Abba Shaul says:</b> He is not required to pay <b>unless</b> the <i>teruma</i> he ate is <b>worth a <i>peruta</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>?</b> It is because <b>the verse states: “And if a man eats a sacred item in error,</b> then he shall add a fifth part in addition to it, and he shall give to the priest the sacred item” (Leviticus 22:14). The minimal amount that is halakhically considered <b>eating is an olive-bulk.</b>
<b>And what is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul? The verse states: “And he shall give,” and</b> giving <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i> is not</b> legally considered to be <b>giving.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the other</b> one, Abba Shaul, <b>too, isn’t it written: “Eats,”</b> implying that there must be at least an olive-bulk portion? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>comes to exclude one who damages</b> <i>teruma</i> without deriving benefit from it, such that he is exempt from the requirement to add an additional fifth. This is derived from the fact that the verse specifies that only one who eats is required to add a fifth.
<b>And</b> according to <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> one can ask: <b>Isn’t it written “And he shall give”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> phrase <b>is necessary</b> to teach the requirement that <i>teruma</i> must be <b>an item that is fit to be consecrated,</b> as an item cannot become <i>teruma</i> unless it is has some value. This is meant <b>to exclude one who eats <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread on Passover,</b> since it is worthless and therefore cannot be designated as <i>teruma</i>.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who eats less than an olive-bulk of <i>teruma</i> must pay the principal, but is not</b> required <b>to pay the</b> additional <b>fifth.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If there was not the value of a <i>peruta</i></b> of <i>teruma</i>, then <b>he should also not</b> be required to <b>pay for the principal</b> either, because that is less than the amount for which one is obligated to pay. <b>But if there was the value of a <i>peruta</i></b> of <i>teruma</i>, then <b>he should</b> be required to <b>pay the</b> additional <b>fifth as well.</b> The Gemara explains the case: <b>Actually,</b> it should be understood <b>that there was the value of a <i>peruta</i></b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and nonetheless, since</b> the food <b>was not</b> at least <b>an olive-bulk, he is</b> required <b>to pay</b> only <b>the principal, but he does not pay the</b> additional <b>fifth.</b>
<b>The Sages said before Rav Pappa</b> that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul. As, if it were in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul, didn’t he say:</b> One is obligated to pay <b>because there is the value of a <i>peruta</i>, even if it is not</b> at least <b>an olive-bulk? Rav Pappa said to them:</b> This is no proof, as <b>even</b> if <b>you say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul, Abba Shaul requires two</b> conditions: That the <i>teruma</i> be at least an olive-bulk in volume, and that it be worth at least a <i>peruta</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>Does Abba Shaul</b> actually <b>require two</b> conditions? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>Abba Shaul says:</b> For <b>that</b> food <b>which is</b> at least <b>the value of a <i>peruta</i></b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>one is liable to</b> pay <b>compensation</b> to the priest, but for <b>that</b> food <b>which does not contain the value of a <i>peruta</i></b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>he is not liable to</b> pay <b>compensation</b> to the priest? The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Abba Shaul: <b>They said</b> that the item must be <b>worth a <i>peruta</i> only with regard to misuse</b> of consecrated items; <b>however, with regard to <i>teruma</i>, one is liable</b> to reimburse the priest <b>only when he eats an olive-bulk</b> or more. <b>And if it is so,</b> that Abba Shaul requires both conditions, and this is a case where there is an olive-bulk, then the Rabbis should have worded their objection differently. <b>They should</b> have said: <b>Since it is</b> at least <b>an olive-bulk,</b> he is liable to pay, even though it is not worth a <i>peruta</i>. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this is <b>a conclusive refutation,</b> and Rav Pappa’s position is rejected.
The Gemara notes that <b>Rav Pappa</b> himself <b>also retracted</b> this explanation. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “If any one commits a trespass, and sins through error, in the sacred items of the Lord, then he shall bring his guilt-offering to the Lord, a ram without blemish from the flock, according to your valuation in silver shekels, after the shekel of the sanctuary, for a guilt-offering” (Leviticus 5:15), the <i>baraita</i> explains: The phrase <b>“and sins through error” excludes one who</b> sins <b>intentionally</b> through misuse of consecrated property. Could this <b>not</b> be derived through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference,</b> as follows: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>other mitzvot for which one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i></b> the verse <b>exempts one</b> from bringing an offering when the transgression was committed <b>intentionally, is it not right that</b> with regard to <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>which does not</b> incur the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>,</b> it should <b>exempt one who acts intentionally?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> rejects this claim: <b>No, if you say that</b> this is true with regard to <b>the rest of the mitzvot,</b> even those for which one is liable to receive <i>karet</i>, for which <b>one is not liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty if he violates them, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say that</b> this is the case with regard to <b>misuse</b> of consecrated items, for which <b>one is liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty, as this offense is punishable by death at the hand of Heaven? Since one cannot logically deduce this principle, <b>the verse states “through error”</b> to <b>exclude one</b> who acted <b>intentionally.</b>
<b>And Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin</b> in wonderment with regard to this <i>baraita</i>: <b>This <i>tanna</i> initially</b> considers the punishment of <b><i>karet</i> to be stronger</b> by assuming that misuse of consecrated property was less severe because it was not punished by <i>karet</i>, <b>and subsequently</b> he considers the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven <b>to be stronger</b> by stating that one cannot deduce this principle from other sins whose punishment is not death at the hand of Heaven.
<b>And</b> Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin <b>said to him</b> that it is possible to maintain the accepted position that <i>karet</i> is more stringent by explaining <b>that this is</b> what <b>he is saying: No,</b> these are incomparable for the following reason: <b>If you say</b> that one is exempt from an offering when he violates <b>the rest of the mitzvot, for</b> which <b>one is not liable to</b> receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven if he eats <b>less than an olive-bulk</b> of a forbidden substance, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is the case <b>with regard to misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>for</b> which <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven if he eats <b>less than an olive-bulk?</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <b>said to him: May your mind be settled, as you have settled my mind</b> and put it at ease by answering this question that was troubling me. Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin <b>said to him: What is settling</b> about this explanation? <b>Rabba and Rav Sheshet threw an axe at</b> my answer; i.e., they reject my explanation, as follows: <b>Who did you hear that said</b>

Daf 33a

that <b>one who intentionally misuses</b> consecrated items is liable <b>to</b> receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven? It is <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who intentionally misuses</b> consecrated items, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that he is liable to receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven. <b>The Rabbis say:</b> he violates <b>a warning,</b> a standard prohibition, and is flogged.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? From where does he derive his opinion? <b>Rabbi Abbahu said: He derives</b> it by means of a verbal analogy between the word <b>sin</b> stated with regard to misuse of consecrated items and the word <b>sin</b> stated <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i>.</b> With regard to misuse of consecrated items, the verse states: “If any one commits a trespass, and sins through error, in the sacred items of the Lord” (Leviticus 5:15); with regard to <i>teruma</i>, the verse states: “Lest they bear sin for it, and die due to it, if they profane it” (Leviticus 22:9). Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi makes the following comparison: <b>Just as</b> eating <b><i>teruma</i></b> is punishable by the <b>death</b> penalty, <b>so too, misusing</b> consecrated items is punishable by the <b>death</b> penalty.
<b>From this</b> verbal analogy, the comparison between <i>teruma</i> and misuse of consecrated property can be extended to other issues as well: <b>Just as one</b> is punished only for eating at least <b>an olive-bulk of <i>teruma</i>, so too,</b> one is punished for <b>misusing</b> consecrated items only if there is at least <b>an olive-bulk</b> of consecrated items. This indicates that the <i>baraita</i> cannot be explained in accordance with the opinion of Abba Shaul, who requires that the item be worth at least a <i>peruta</i>.
<b>Rav Pappa strongly objects to</b> Rav Sheshet and Rabba’s rejection of the explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> do you know that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> that one is only punished after eating an olive-bulk of <i>teruma</i>? <b>Perhaps he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul, who said</b> one is liable for eating <i>teruma</i> provided the food <b>contains the value of a <i>peruta</i> of <i>teruma</i>, even if it is less than an olive-bulk.</b> As the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse of consecrated items are derived from <i>teruma</i>, one is liable for eating both <i>teruma</i> and consecrated items only if the object is worth at least a <i>peruta</i>. As such, Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin’s explanation of the <i>baraita</i> should not be rejected.
With regard to the issue mentioned previously, the Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t Rav Pappa the one who said</b> that <b>Abba Shaul said</b> that it <b>requires two</b> conditions, that the object be worth a <i>peruta</i> and that it be an olive-bulk in volume? <b>Rather, learn from this</b> that Rav Pappa <b>retracted</b> his statement with regard to Abba Shaul’s opinion.
<b>Mar, son of Rabbana, said</b> the following to resolve the difficulty in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>This is</b> what <b>it is saying: No, if you say</b> that one is exempt from an offering <b>with regard to the rest of the mitzvot, where acting without intent is not treated</b> as though one acted <b>with intent,</b> i.e., <b>if one intended to cut</b> something that is <b>detached</b> from the ground on Shabbat, which is not prohibited by Torah law, <b>and</b> mistakenly <b>cut</b> something that is <b>attached</b> to the ground, then <b>he is exempt</b> because he acted without intent; <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> the same <b>with regard to misuse</b> of consecrated items, about which the <i>halakha</i> is stringent, such <b>that if one intended to warm himself with non-sacred</b> wool <b>shearings,</b> and owing to an error or lack of information <b>he warmed himself with shearings from a burnt-offering,</b> then <b>he has misused</b> consecrated property? Thus, misuse of consecrated property is more stringent than other commandments, in that one violates it even when acting without intent, and one cannot deduce the <i>halakha</i> in the case of misuse of consecrated property from the <i>halakha</i> in the case of the rest of the mitzvot.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> should be understood differently, and <b>this is</b> what <b>it is saying: No, if you say</b> this leniency <b>with regard to rest of the mitzvot, where one who is acting unawares is not liable</b> in the same way <b>as</b> one who <b>is acting aware</b> of his actions, such as in a case where one intended to perform a permitted act and mistakenly performed a prohibited one, i.e., <b>if one intended to lift</b> something that is <b>detached</b> from the ground, but his knife happened to <b>cut</b> something that is <b>attached</b> to the ground, in violation of the act of harvesting on Shabbat, then <b>he is exempt; shall you</b> also <b>say</b> the same <b>with regard to misuse</b> of consecrated items, <b>where if one places his hand in a vessel to take an object</b> and unknowingly <b>places his hand in consecrated oil</b> then <b>he has misused</b> consecrated items? Therefore, misuse of consecrated items is more stringent than other commandments, as one commits the sin of misusing consecrated property even if he uses the consecrated object while attempting to perform a different action and is unaware that he is performing a prohibited act.
<b>The Master said</b> above in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said</b> that the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree with regard to the obligation to pay for <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread? It is said with regard to a case where <b>one separated <i>teruma</i></b> in a permitted manner <b>and it became leavened</b> during Passover. <b>However, if he separated <i>teruma</i> from leavened bread</b> during Passover, <b>everyone agrees that it is not consecrated</b> since it is worthless.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived, that a worthless item cannot be designated as <i>teruma</i>? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>the verse states:</b> “The first fruits of your grain, your wine, your oil, and the first of the fleece of your sheep, <b>shall you give to him”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:4), <b>and not to his fire.</b> One must give the priest something that he can use for any purpose, and not something that the priest will be forced to burn as fuel. Even those who permit one to derive benefit from leavened bread during Passover agree that it may not be eaten, and therefore leavened bread cannot be consecrated as <i>teruma</i> in this case.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raised an objection</b> based on that which was taught in a mishna: <b>One may not separate</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>from ritually impure</b> produce <b>for ritually pure</b> produce, <b>but if one unwittingly separated</b> it in this manner then <b>his <i>teruma</i> is</b> valid <b><i>teruma</i>. And why</b> should this be valid <i>teruma</i>? <b>Let</b> the priest <b>say:</b> The verse requires that the <i>teruma</i> be given <b>“to him” and not to his fire,</b> and this ritually impure <i>teruma</i> must be burned. In that case, why should this produce actually become <i>teruma</i>? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. There,</b> in the case of impure <i>teruma</i>, <b>it had a period of fitness,</b> and it could have been given as <i>teruma</i> before it became impure. <b>Here,</b> in the case of leavened bread, <b>it did not</b> ever <b>have a period of fitness,</b> and therefore it cannot be consecrated as <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> in <b>which</b> this leavened bread <b>did not have a period of fitness</b> even on Passover? This could have happened only in a case <b>where it</b> became <b>leavened</b> while it was still <b>attached</b> to the ground and could not yet become <i>teruma</i>. <b>However,</b> if <b>it</b> became <b>leavened</b> after being <b>detached</b> from the ground, then can this leavened bread <b>indeed become consecrated</b> as <i>teruma</i>, even though the <i>baraita</i> indicates that no leavened bread can be designated as <i>teruma</i> during Passover? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzhak <b>said to</b> Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: <b>Yes,</b> this is indeed the case despite this puzzling limitation, and the biblical expression can be applied homiletically: <b>“The matter is by the decree of the watchers, and the sentence by the word of the sacred ones”</b> (Daniel 4:14). The Sages, who are compared to celestial beings, agree with my statement. <b>And so too, in the study hall, they teach in accordance with my</b> opinion, despite the puzzling nature of this ruling.
<b>When Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, came,</b>

Daf 33b

<b>he said</b> that <b>the verse states:</b> “The <b>first fruits</b> of your grain, your wine, your oil, and the first of the fleece of your sheep, shall you give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4), implying <b>that its remnants are recognizable for an Israelite,</b> as the notion of a first part indicates that there is another portion remaining which is fit to be consumed by the Israelite. <b>This</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>is excluded as there is no recognizable remnant</b> left that may be consumed by the Israelite, because it is leavened bread. Since even after this portion has been separated the remainder of the produce may not be eaten, that which was separated does not become <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav Avya sat before Rav Ḥisda, and he sat and said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to <b>grapes that became ritually impure,</b> one should <b>tread on them less than an egg-bulk at a time, and the wine</b> that comes from them is <b>kosher</b> even <b>for libations</b> because it is ritually pure. <b>Apparently</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>holds: The liquid is stored</b> inside the grape, as the juice is not considered to be part of the grape itself but rather stored in the grape as though contained in a receptacle. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion, <b>when do</b> these liquids <b>become ritually impure?</b> This occurs only <b>when one squeezes them,</b> and prior to this the juice remains pure even if the grape was impure. And <b>when one squeezes them, there is less than the</b> minimum <b>measure</b> of grape flesh that would transfer ritual impurity, as food can impart ritual impurity only if it is at least an egg-bulk in size.
The Gemara challenges this statement: <b>If that is so, then even</b> if he squeezes <b>an egg-bulk</b> of grapes, the juice will still not become impure. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: In the case of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse</b> and <b>who squeezed olives or grapes</b> in the <b>exact</b> amount of <b>an egg-bulk,</b> the liquid <b>is</b> ritually <b>pure.</b> Once the first drop of liquid is squeezed out, less than an egg-bulk of food remains, and it cannot render the liquid impure. In that case, why did Rabbi Yoḥanan permit squeezing only less than an egg-bulk? The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> it was speaking of a case where the ruling was <b>after the fact;</b> however, <b>here,</b> it is discussing the ruling <b><i>ab initio</i>,</b> and the mishna states that one may press juice only from less than an egg-bulk of grapes due to <b>a</b> rabbinic <b>decree lest one come to perform</b> the act of squeezing on <b>more than an egg-bulk,</b> causing the liquid to become impure.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said to</b> Rav Aḥa bar Rav Avya: <b>Who will listen to you and to Rabbi Yoḥanan your teacher</b> with regard to this issue? <b>As, where did the impurity that was in</b> the grape juice <b>go?</b> The Gemara notes that <b>apparently</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>holds: Liquids are absorbed</b> within the fruit and are therefore considered to be part of the grape itself. <b>And since the flesh of the grape became ritually impure, the liquid became ritually impure</b> as well.
Rav Aḥa <b>said to him: Do you not hold</b> that <b>liquids are stored</b> inside the grape? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: In the case of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse</b> and <b>who squeezed olives or grapes</b> in the <b>exact</b> amount of <b>an egg-bulk,</b> using a flat wooden utensil without touching the liquid itself, the liquid is ritually <b>pure. Granted, if you say</b> that the juice is <b>stored</b> inside the grapes, then it is <b>due to that</b> reason that the liquid <b>is pure. But if you say</b> that the liquid is <b>absorbed</b> within the grapes, <b>why</b> is the juice <b>pure?</b> According to this opinion, once the grape itself becomes impure, the juice, which is attached to it and absorbed in it, becomes impure as well.
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case where <b>the grapes have not been rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, since they have not come in contact with liquids. <b>When do they become susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? This is only <b>once one presses them</b> and they become wet with their own juice. However, <b>when he presses them,</b> they decrease in volume <b>and are lacking the measure</b> of volume required to become impure. This must be the explanation, <b>for if you do not say so,</b> it is difficult to reconcile this mishna with <b>that which was taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited above: <b>To what</b> may <b>this</b> case of <i>teruma</i> of leavened bread <b>be compared?</b> It may be compared <b>to <i>teruma</i> of berries, olives, and grapes that became impure, which can neither be eaten nor burned.</b> However, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement <b>they may even be eaten, as if one wishes he may tread less than an egg-bulk</b> at a time.
<b>Rava said:</b> It is possible to reject this proof, as even if this action is permitted in principle, there is <b>a rabbinic decree</b> prohibiting it <b>lest he encounter a stumbling block.</b> If one keeps ritually impure fruit of <i>teruma</i> in order to press it for its juice, it is possible that he will forget its status and accidentally eat it. <b>Abaye said to him: Are we concerned about</b> this type of <b>stumbling block? Wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>light</b> a fire <b>with bread and oil of <i>teruma</i> that became ritually impure?</b> It can be deduced from this <i>baraita</i> that there is no concern that a person will forget and eat these foods. Rava <b>said to him: Bread</b> is only permitted when <b>one throws it among the wood</b> used for fuel so that it is ruined and no longer considered edible. <b><i>Teruma</i> oil</b> is permitted only <b>when one puts it into a repulsive vessel</b> so that no one will drink it.
With regard to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself,</b> it was taught: <b>One</b> may <b>light with bread and oil of <i>teruma</i> that became ritually impure.</b> The Sages limited the application of this <i>halakha</i>, as <b>Abaye said in the name of Ḥizkiya and Rava said</b> in the name of the Sages from <b>the school of Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Marta</b> that <b>Rav Huna said: They taught</b> that one may use impure <i>teruma</i> as firewood <b>only</b> with regard to <b>bread; however,</b> with regard to <b>wheat, no,</b> one may not light a fire <b>with it, lest one encounter a stumbling block</b> and eat it, because wheat will not become inedible by being placed among the firewood. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even wheat</b> may be used as fuel. The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> does he permit this? <b>Let us be concerned lest he encounter a stumbling block.</b> The Gemara answers based on what <b>Rav Ashi said</b> with regard to a different issue:

Daf 34a

This is referring <b>to boiled and repulsive</b> wheat, i.e., wheat that one boiled and then placed in a repulsive area, in which case he need not be concerned that this wheat will accidentally be eaten; <b>so too</b> here, it is referring <b>to boiled and repulsive</b> wheat. The Gemara asks: <b>Where was Rav Ashi’s</b> explanation <b>stated?</b> It was stated <b>with regard to this: As Rabbi Avin bar Rav Aḥa said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Abba Shaul was the</b> dough <b>kneader of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi’s <b>house, and they would heat water for him,</b> to make dough, <b>with wheat of ritually impure <i>teruma</i>,</b> which was purchased from priests at a low price, <b>in order to knead dough in ritual purity.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> did they do this? <b>Let us be concerned lest they encounter a stumbling block</b> by accidentally eating this wheat. With regard to this <b>Rav Ashi said</b> that it was only done when the wheat was <b>boiled and repulsive</b> and could only be used for lighting a fire.
After mentioning ways in which impure <i>teruma</i> was used, the Gemara mentions other <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to this issue. <b>Abaye bar Avin and Rav Ḥananya bar Avin taught</b> the tractate of <b><i>Terumot</i> in the school of Rabba. Rava bar Mattana met them</b> and <b>said to them: What</b> novel idea can <b>you say</b> has been taught with regard to <b><i>Terumot</i> in the school of</b> our <b>Master,</b> Rabba? <b>They said to him: What</b> is <b>difficult for you?</b> There must be some issue troubling you that has caused you to ask this question. <b>He said to them:</b> The following statement that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna in <i>Terumot</i> is unclear: <b>Saplings</b> of <b><i>teruma</i> that became ritually impure and were planted are pure</b> such that they <b>do not impart ritual impurity</b> once they have been planted, <b>but they are prohibited to be eaten as <i>teruma</i>.</b> The question arises: <b>If they do not impart ritual impurity, why is it prohibited to eat them?</b> If their impurity has been eliminated then it should be permitted to eat them, like other ritually pure <i>teruma</i>.
Abaye bar Avin and Rav Ḥananya bar Avin <b>said to</b> Rava bar Mattana: <b>This is what Rabba said</b> in explaining this mishna: <b>What</b> does it mean that <b>they are prohibited</b> to be eaten? It means that <b>they are prohibited</b> to be eaten <b>by non-priests,</b> but a priest may eat them. Once these saplings are planted, they lose their ritual impurity but retain their status as <i>teruma</i>. Rava bar Mattana challenged this answer: If this is the case, <b>what is</b> the mishna <b>teaching us</b> with this statement? Is it teaching us that <b>growths of <i>teruma</i></b> are considered <b><i>teruma</i>?</b> It is unnecessary to teach this principle, as <b>we</b> already <b>learned: Growths of <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., produce that grows from <i>teruma</i> that was planted in the ground, are considered <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> Why, then, is it necessary to teach this principle again?
<b>And if you say</b> as follows: This case is referring to <b>the growths of growths</b> of <i>teruma</i>, i.e., plants that grew from the original growths of <i>teruma</i>, and <b>what is it teaching us?</b> It is teaching that <b>an item whose seed does not disintegrate</b> when planted in the ground maintains its <i>teruma</i> status. While most seeds will disintegrate, other plants, such as onions and garlic, merely continue growing when planted. In that case, this mishna would be informing us that even the growths of growths of such plants retain their <i>teruma</i> status. However, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> that <b>as well.</b> As the mishna states: With regard to <b>untithed produce [<i>tevel</i>], its growths,</b> the produce that grows from it, <b>are permitted in</b> the case of <b>items whose seed disintegrates; however, in</b> the case of <b>items where the seed does not disintegrate, it is prohibited to eat even the growths of growths</b> unless they are tithed. There would be no need for the mishna to teach us this <i>halakha</i> a second time. <b>They were silent</b> and did not have an answer to this question.
<b>They said to</b> Rava bar Mattana: <b>Have you heard something in this</b> regard? <b>He said to them: This is what Rav Sheshet said: What</b> is the meaning of the word <b>prohibited</b> in this context? It means that it is <b>prohibited for priests, since it has been disqualified for them due to the diversion of attention.</b> <i>Teruma</i> and other consecrated property must be guarded, and when one fails to do so, it is treated as though it were impure. Therefore, these <i>teruma</i> saplings are treated as though they have become impure once the priest diverts attention from them, and they remain prohibited to him even after another generation grows from them.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that a <b>diversion of attention constitutes an inherent disqualification, it works out well.</b> According to this opinion, a diversion of attention does not disqualify <i>teruma</i> due to a concern that it became impure. Instead, there is an independent rabbinic decree rendering <i>teruma</i> that has not been watched impure even when this <i>teruma</i> could not possibly have become impure. According to this opinion, one can understand why this growth may not be eaten by a priest. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that a <b>diversion of attention is a disqualification due to</b> a concern about <b>ritual impurity, what is there to say?</b> It is stated in the mishna that by planting these saplings they become pure, even if they were certainly ritually impure prior to being planted. If this is the case with regard to <i>teruma</i> that is certainly impure, all the more so should it apply to a case where there is only a chance that the <i>teruma</i> is ritually impure.
Apropos the discussion of diversion of attention, the Gemara cites a dispute between <i>amora’im</i> with regard to this issue, <b>as it was stated:</b> What is the nature of the disqualification of <b>diversion of attention? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is a disqualification</b> due to a concern about <b>ritual impurity</b> that may have been contracted while one’s attention was diverted. And <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: It is an inherent disqualification.</b>
The Gemara discusses the ramifications of this dispute: According to <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who <b>said it is a disqualification</b> due to a concern about <b>ritual impurity, if Elijah comes and renders it ritually pure</b> then <b>we will listen to him,</b> because it was treated as impure only due to a doubt with regard to its actual status. However, according to <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>it is an inherent disqualification,</b> even <b>if Elijah comes and renders it pure we will not listen to him.</b> The reason for this is that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish believes that this decree is unrelated to the question of whether the object actually became impure.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> based on what is taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: There was a small gap between the ramp and the altar on the western</b> side <b>of the ramp, where they would throw disqualified birds</b> that had been designated as <b>sin-offerings.</b> If birds became disqualified for any reason, such as a diversion of attention, they were left there <b>until their form decayed,</b> i.e., until the next morning, at which point they would be definitively disqualified due to remaining in the Temple overnight and could be <b>taken out to the place</b> designated for <b>burning. Granted, if you say</b> that a diversion of attention <b>is a disqualification</b> due to a concern for <b>ritual impurity, for this reason it requires decay of form</b> to ensure that the bird is certainly disqualified. Currently the bird is disqualified only due to uncertainty, <b>and Elijah may come and render it ritually pure. However, if you say</b> that <b>it is an inherent disqualification,</b> then <b>why do I</b> need to leave it until <b>it has decay of form?</b> It should be definitively disqualified once there has been a diversion of attention. <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>this is the principle:</b>

Daf 34b

<b>Any</b> offering <b>that has a disqualification in the body</b> of the animal, i.e., it has a definite disqualification with regard to the meat itself, <b>should be burned immediately.</b> If it has a disqualification <b>in the blood</b> of the animal, e.g., if the blood was spilled, or a disqualification of <b>its owner,</b> e.g., if the owner became impure, then it should be left until <b>its form is decayed and taken out to the place</b> designated for <b>burning.</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>said to him: This <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, <b>is</b> of the same opinion as the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who taught in <b>the school of Rabba bar Avuh, who said: Even <i>piggul</i>,</b> an offering that was invalidated due to inappropriate intent while being offered, <b>requires decay of form.</b> Even with regard to an inherent disqualification in the meat of the offering, where the Torah says explicitly that the offering should be burned, as is the case with regard to <i>piggul</i>, the animal should be set aside until the next day, when its form has decayed.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>raised a</b> further <b>objection to</b> the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish based on another <i>baraita</i>, where it is taught: <b>If the meat became impure or disqualified, or if it was taken out of the walls</b> that delineate its permitted area, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: He sprinkles</b> the blood of these offerings nonetheless, as in his opinion the blood may be sprinkled regardless of the status of the meat of the offering. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: He does not sprinkle</b> the blood unless the meat is fit to be brought as an offering. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua concedes that if</b> the blood <b>was sprinkled,</b> the offering <b>is accepted.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: To <b>what</b> type of <b>disqualification</b> is the <i>baraita</i> referring? <b>Is it not</b> disqualification on account of <b>a diversion of attention?</b> It cannot be a case where it was disqualified due to impurity or being taken outside of the walls, since these are mentioned explicitly. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that a diversion of attention is <b>a disqualification</b> based on a concern about <b>ritual impurity, this is</b> how <b>you</b> can <b>find</b> a case that the offering is accepted <b>because the frontplate atones</b> for cases where there is a disqualification related to ritual impurity. <b>But if you say that it is an inherent disqualification, why</b> is the offering <b>accepted</b> according to Rabbi Yehoshua, given that it is a disqualified offering?
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish rejects this interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>: No, this is not a case where the offering was disqualified due to a diversion of attention. In <b>what</b> way <b>was</b> the offering <b>disqualified?</b> It was <b>disqualified due to</b> contact with <b>one who immersed himself during the day.</b> One who immersed himself during the day invalidates items due to ritual impurity. Although these items themselves are invalidated, they cannot in turn render other items ritually impure. The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so, this is</b> the same as the disqualification of <b>ritual impurity.</b> What, then, is the difference between this disqualification and that of ritual impurity previously mentioned by the <i>baraita</i>? The Gemara answers that <b>two types of ritual impurity</b> are mentioned here: One type of impurity can also impart impurity to other objects, and a second type can invalidate another object but will not impart impurity.
<b>When Ravin ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he stated</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> of</b> Rav Sheshet <b>before Rabbi Yirmeya. And</b> Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said: Foolish Babylonians! Because you dwell in a dark land, you state <i>halakhot</i> that are dim. Have you not heard this</b> statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish in the name of Rabbi Oshaya?</b>
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said in the name of Rabbi Oshaya: With regard to <b>the water</b> used for the water libation during the <b>festival</b> of Sukkot which was drawn over the course of the day in order to be poured the next day and consequently <b>became impure,</b> the following distinction applies: If it <b>was</b> brought into <b>contact</b> with a ritual bath of pure water and <b>was then consecrated, it is ritually pure.</b> However, <b>if it was consecrated and was then</b> brought into <b>contact</b> with the ritual bath, <b>it is ritually impure.</b>
The question arises: <b>Since</b> this type of purification <b>is</b> similar <b>to planting,</b> as when the impure water came in contact with the water of the ritual bath, it is considered as though the water was planted in the ground and thereby purified, <b>what does it matter if it was</b> brought into <b>contact and then consecrated or consecrated and then</b> brought into <b>contact? Apparently planting is not</b> effective with regard <b>to consecrated items,</b> i.e., such items are not purified through this process. Therefore, <b>here too, planting is not</b> effective with regard <b>to <i>teruma</i>.</b> Despite the fact that planting is generally effective in removing the impure status of the water, the Sages imposed higher standards with regard to consecrated items. Similarly, the Sages imposed higher standards for removing the <i>teruma</i> status of the plants. One can explain that the produce grown from <i>teruma</i> mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> remains prohibited for non-priests because it is still considered <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rav Dimi sat and said this <i>halakha</i></b> that was stated by Rav Oshaya with regard to principle of bringing liquid into contact with a ritual bath. <b>Abaye said to him: Did</b> Rav Oshaya state his ruling that bringing a liquid into contact with a ritual bath is not effective for consecrated items with regard to a case where <b>he consecrated</b> the water by placing it <b>in a</b> sacred <b>vessel, but</b> if he consecrated it <b>through speech then the Sages did not impose a higher</b> standard, in which case the water can be purified by being brought into contact with a ritual bath? <b>Or perhaps the Sages imposed a higher</b> standard in a case <b>where</b> one consecrates it <b>through speech as well?</b>
Rav Dimi <b>said to him: I did not hear</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>this</b> case; however, <b>I heard</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a similar case. As Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to <b>grapes that became ritually impure, if one trod on them and afterward consecrated them, they are pure.</b> According to this opinion, the wine inside the grape does not become impure from the grape itself. However, if <b>he consecrated</b> the grapes <b>and afterward pressed them, they are impure,</b> because the <i>halakha</i> is especially stringent with regard consecrated items. <b>And yet</b> with regard to <b>grapes which are</b> only <b>consecrated through speech,</b> as the wine/grapes offered on the altar are not brought in a sacred vessel, <b>even so, the Sages imposed a higher</b> standard such that these grapes become impure after they have been consecrated.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This case does not serve as a proof since <b>you spoke of grapes, and here we are dealing with grapes of <i>teruma</i>, whose consecration through speech is comparable to consecration in a</b> sacred <b>vessel,</b> as <i>teruma</i> cannot be consecrated by being placed in a sacred vessel. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>those</b> items <b>that require a</b> sacred <b>vessel</b> in order to be fully consecrated, such as water used for a libation, <b>the Sages did not impose a higher</b> standard in a case where one consecrated it <b>through speech.</b> Therefore, this case cannot be used to resolve Abaye’s question.
