The Gemara asks about Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement with regard to wine pressed from impure grapes: The phrase <b>if one tread upon them</b> is stated without qualification, indicating that the wine is ritually pure <b>even</b> if he pressed <b>many</b> grapes at once. <b>And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say this? Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say:</b> With regard to <b>grapes that became ritually impure grapes, one</b> should <b>tread on them less than an egg-bulk at a time.</b> When there is less than an egg-bulk of grapes, they do not impart ritual impurity.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> this answer: <b>Here, too,</b> it is to be understood that one must tread on <b>less than an egg-bulk at a time. And if you wish, say</b> this answer instead: <b>There,</b> where the Gemara requires less than an egg-bulk, it is a case where the grapes <b>came into contact</b> with an item that was impure with <b>first-</b>degree ritual impurity, such <b>that they became</b> impure with <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity. When a liquid touches an object that is impure with second-degree ritual impurity, it becomes impure by rabbinic decree with first-degree ritual impurity. Therefore, in that case one must be careful to tread only on less than an egg-bulk at a time. <b>Here,</b> it is speaking of a case where <b>they came into contact</b> with an item that was impure with <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity, such <b>that they became</b> impure with <b>third-</b>degree ritual impurity. In that case, the liquid that comes out of the grapes would not become ritually impure at all.
<b>Rava said: We, too, have learned</b> that the Sages created higher standards with regard to consecrated items. As it was taught that the verse says with regard to the red heifer: “And for the impure they shall take the ashes of the burning of the sin-offering, <b>and he shall put flowing water into a vessel”</b> (Numbers 19:17), which teaches that the flowing water from the spring <b>should flow</b> directly <b>into the vessel</b> in which it will be sanctified. On the other hand, the verse says <b>“and he shall put,”</b> meaning that the water should be poured into the vessel. <b>Apparently</b> the water <b>is detached, but it is</b> clearly <b>attached</b> to the spring, as it was previously stated that the water must flow directly into the vessel.

Daf 35a

<b>Rather,</b> this is merely <b>a higher standard,</b> as by Torah law the water may be drawn with one vessel and sanctified in another vessel. The Sages added that this water must be sanctified in the same vessel in which it was drawn from the spring, and they found support for their opinion in the Torah. <b>Here too,</b> the Sages established <b>a higher standard</b> for a consecrated object that became ritually impure, as they decreed that it cannot be ritually purified through insertion in the ground.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: We, too, learned</b> a similar statement in a <i>baraita</i>: When the period of ritual impurity of a <i>zav</i> or leper has been completed, and he <b>immersed</b> during the day <b>and emerged,</b> he may <b>eat tithes</b> immediately. Once <b>the sun set for him, he</b> may <b>eat <i>teruma</i>.</b> Rav Shimi bar Ashi infers from this statement: <b>With regard to <i>teruma</i>, yes,</b> he may eat it; however, <b>with regard to consecrated</b> food, <b>no,</b> he may not. Given that conclusion, Rav Shimi bar Ashi asks: <b>Why</b> is there a difference between <i>teruma</i> and consecrated foods? After all, <b>he is ritually pure. Rather,</b> the Sages established a <b>higher standard</b> for consecrated food, and permitted one to eat them only after sacrificing the requisite purification offering. <b>Here too,</b> the Sages established <b>a higher standard</b> for the ritual purity of consecrated liquids.
<b>Rav Ashi said: We, too, learned</b> another case where the Sages established a higher standard. The verse says: “And the flesh that touches any ritually impure thing shall not be eaten; it shall be burnt with fire. And as for the flesh, anyone who is ritually pure may eat from it” (Leviticus 7:19). <b>And the flesh</b> comes <b>to include the wood</b> in the Temple <b>and the frankincense.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Do wood and frankincense</b> have the <b>capacity to become ritually impure,</b> given that they are neither food nor drink? <b>Rather,</b> the Sages established <b>a higher standard</b> for these objects due to their sanctity; <b>here too,</b> the Sages established <b>a higher standard</b> for the ritual purity of consecrated liquids.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>These are</b> the types of grain <b>with which a person fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on the</b> first night of <b>Passover: With wheat, with barley, with spelt [<i>kusmin</i>], with rye [<i>shifon</i>], and with oats [<i>shibbolet shu’al</i>]. And one fulfills</b> his obligation by eating not only <i>matza</i> made from properly tithed grains, but even <b>with</b> <i>matza</i> made from <b>doubtfully tithed produce, and</b> <i>matza</i> made <b>with first tithe from which its <i>teruma</i> was</b> already <b>taken,</b> or <b>second tithe and consecrated food that were redeemed. And priests</b> may eat <i>matza</i> prepared <b>from <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> the portion of dough that is given to priests, <b>or with <i>teruma</i>,</b> as priests are permitted to eat these portions.
<b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> fulfill one’s obligation to eat <i>matza</i> made <b>with untithed produce, nor with</b> <i>matza</i> made from the <b>first tithe from which its <i>teruma</i> was not separated, nor with</b> <i>matza</i> made either from the <b>second tithe, nor</b> from <b>consecrated</b> grain <b>that was not redeemed.</b> With regard to one who prepared <b>loaves of</b> <i>matza</i> that are brought with <b>a thanks-offering,</b> or to the <b>wafers</b> brought <b>by a nazirite,</b> the Sages drew the following distinction: If <b>he prepared them for himself,</b> then he <b>does not fulfill</b> his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with them.</b> However, if <b>he prepared them to sell them in the market</b> to those who require these loaves or wafers, <b>one fulfills</b> the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with them.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara identifies the species mentioned in the mishna. One of the Sages <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Spelt</b> is <b>a type of wheat,</b> while <b>oats [<i>shibbolet shu’al</i>] and rye [<i>shifon</i>]</b> are <b>a type of barley.</b> The Gemara translates the lesser-known species into the vernacular Aramaic: <b>Spelt</b> is called <b><i>gulba</i>; rye</b> is <b><i>dishra</i>;</b> and <b>oats</b> are <b><i>shevilei ta’ala</i>.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>These</b> species, <b>yes,</b> they may be used for <i>matza</i>; however, <b>rice [<i>orez</i>] and millet [<i>doḥan</i>], no,</b> they may not be used.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> that <i>matza</i> cannot be prepared from rice or millet, <b>derived? Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said, and likewise</b> a Sage <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught, and likewise</b> a Sage <b>of the school of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov taught</b> that <b>the verse states: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it; seven days you shall eat with it <i>matza</i>,</b> the bread of affliction” (Deuteronomy 16:3). This verse indicates that only with <b>substances which will come to</b> a state of <b>leavening, a person fulfills his obligation to</b> eat <b><i>matza</i> with them,</b> provided he prevents them from becoming leavened. This <b>excludes these</b> foods, i.e., rice, millet, and similar grains, <b>which,</b> even if flour is prepared from them and water is added to their flour, <b>do not come to</b> a state of <b>leavening but to</b> a state of <b>decay [<i>siraḥon</i>].</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, who said: Rice is</b> a full-fledged <b>type of grain, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating it in <b>its leavened</b> state, like other types of grain. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri prohibits</b> eating cooked <b>rice and millet</b> on Passover, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that they are close to being leavened.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the scholars who were studying this issue. What is the meaning of the expression: <b>That it is close to becoming leavened?</b> Does this mean <b>that it will be leavened</b> even <b>quicker</b> than wheat or barley? <b>Or</b> does it <b>perhaps</b> mean that <b>it is</b> only <b>close to being leavened,</b> i.e., it resembles leavened bread, but <b>it is not full-fledged leavened bread.</b> In other words, perhaps Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri maintains that these grains cannot in fact become full-fledged leavened bread, and one is not punished with <i>karet</i> for eating them on Passover. However, he rules that one should nevertheless avoid eating them, due to their similarity to leavened bread.
The Gemara responds: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this question, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said: Rice is</b> a full-fledged <b>type of grain.</b> Therefore, <b>one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating it in <b>its leavened</b> state, <b>and a person</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with it on Passover.</b> This <i>baraita</i> clearly indicates that, according to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, rice becomes leavened like other grains, and the expression: It is close to becoming leavened, means that it becomes leavened quicker than other grains.
<b>And so too, Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri would say:</b> One who has prepared bread from <b><i>keramit</i>,</b> a type of wild wheat, is <b>obligated to</b> separate <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> just as he must separate <i>ḥalla</i> from dough prepared of other types of grain. The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>keramit</i>? Abaye said:</b> It is a plant called <b><i>shitzanita</i>.</b> Since this name was not widely known either, the Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>shitzanita</i>? Rav Pappa said: This is the wild grain that is found between papyrus reeds.</b>
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> With regard to <b>dough that was kneaded with wine, oil, or honey, one is not liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating it in <b>its leavened</b> state, since these liquids will not cause the dough to be leavened. <b>Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, were sitting before Rav Idi bar Avin, and Rav Idi bar Avin was sitting and dozing</b> as his students conversed. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said to Rav Pappa: What is the reason of Reish Lakish,</b> who maintains that one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for this type of leavening?
Rav Pappa <b>said to him: The verse states: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it;</b> seven days you shall eat with it <i>matza</i>” (Deuteronomy 16:3). In light of the juxtaposition of leavened bread and <i>matza</i>, Reish Lakish compares these two types of bread: With regard to those <b>substances</b> through <b>which a person fulfills his obligation to</b> eat <b><i>matza</i>, one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating them in their <b>leavened</b> state. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>this</b> dough, which was kneaded with wine, oil, or honey, <b>since a person does not fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with it,</b> as <b>it is</b> called <b>rich,</b> i.e., enhanced, <b><i>matza</i>, one is not liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating it in <b>its leavened</b> state on Passover. <i>Matza</i> is called the bread of affliction, or the poor man’s bread, a description that does not apply to dough prepared with wine, oil, or honey.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raised an objection to Rav Pappa:</b> We learned with regard to one who took a baked item, <b>dissolved it in water, and swallowed</b> this mixture on Passover: <b>If</b> the baked item <b>is leavened bread,</b> he is <b>punished with <i>karet</i>; and if it is <i>matza</i>, a person does not fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on Passover</b> with this food. The reason one does not fulfill the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> is because swallowing in this manner is not considered an act of eating. <b>But here</b> this is a case <b>where a person does not fulfill his obligation to</b> eat <b><i>matza</i></b> with this dissolved food, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>he is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating it in <b>its leavened</b> state. This ruling conflicts with Rav Pappa’s general principle.
At this point <b>Rav Idi bar Avin woke up,</b> due to their discussion, and <b>said to them: Children, this is the reasoning of Reish Lakish:</b> One is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating dough kneaded with oil or honey, <b>because</b> oil and honey <b>are</b> considered <b>fruit juices,</b>

Daf 35b

<b>and fruit juice does not</b> cause dough to be <b>leavened.</b> Therefore, dough prepared with these liquids is not considered full-fledged leavened bread.
The Gemara turns to the cases of the mishna. The mishna taught that one can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with doubtfully tithed produce and</b> with produce <b>of</b> the <b>first tithe,</b> from which <i>teruma</i> has been separated. The Gemara asks: Can one really fulfill his obligation with <b>doubtfully tithed produce?</b> It is <b>not suitable for him</b> to eat. The Sages prohibited the eating of doubtfully tithed produce that has not been tithed. The Gemara answers: <b>Since, if one</b> so <b>desires</b> he may <b>renounce</b> all <b>his property,</b> thereby becoming a poor person who is permitted to eat doubtfully tithed produce, <b>now too it is suitable for him,</b> even though he did not declare his property ownerless. Consequently, if he used doubtfully tithed produce as <i>matza</i>, he has fulfilled the mitzva after the fact.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>feed the poor doubtfully tithed produce, and</b> he may also feed Jewish <b>soldiers [<i>akhsanya</i>]</b> who lodge with him <b>doubtfully tithed produce. And Rav Huna said</b> that it <b>was taught</b> that <b>Beit Shammai say: One</b> may <b>neither feed the poor doubtfully tithed produce, nor</b> feed <b>soldiers doubtfully tithed produce. And Beit Hillel say: One</b> may <b>feed</b> these groups doubtfully tithed produce. This mishna indicates that doubtfully tithed produce is not prohibited to the same extent as entirely untithed produce, as in certain situations the prohibition pertaining to doubtfully tithed produce does not take effect.
The mishna taught that one can fulfill the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> with produce of the <b>first tithe from which its <i>teruma</i>,</b> the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, <b>was taken</b> and given to a priest. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious, as, since its <i>teruma</i> has been taken, it is non-sacred</b> food? What novel element is taught by this statement?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> in a case where a Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest while the grain was still <b>on</b> its <b>stalks.</b> Ordinarily, the Levite would be given his first tithe only after the priest had taken the <i>teruma gedola</i>; however, in this case the Levite took his portion before the priest. <b>And the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe was taken</b> by the Levite from his tithe so that he would be permitted to eat the tithe; however, <b>the <i>teruma gedola</i> was not taken from</b> the produce at all. <b>And</b> the novel element of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Abbahu.</b>
<b>As Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: First tithe</b> in which the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest while the grain was still <b>on the stalks is exempt from <i>teruma gedola</i>,</b> even though the Levite thereby reduces the amount of grain the priest receives. <b>As it is stated:</b> “Moreover you shall speak to the Levites and say to them: When you take from the children of Israel the tithe which I have given you from them as your inheritance, <b>and you shall set apart from it a gift for the Lord, a tithe from the tithe”</b> (Numbers 18:26). This verse teaches that the Levite is obligated to set apart <b>a tithe from the tithe,</b> i.e., the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, <b>and not <i>teruma gedola</i> and the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe from the tithe.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: However, if</b> that <b>is so, even</b> if the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest after the kernels of grain were removed from the stalks and placed <b>in a pile,</b> the Levite should not have to separate <i>teruma gedola</i> in this case either. Abaye <b>said to him: With regard to your</b> claim, <b>the verse states: “From all that is given to you, you shall set apart all of that which is the Lord’s <i>teruma</i>,</b> of all the best of it, even its consecrated portion” (Numbers 18:29). This verse teaches that the Levites must designate a portion of the gifts they receive and give it to the priests.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> to lead you to require the separation of <i>teruma gedola</i> from first tithe that was taken from grain in piles and not from first tithe that was taken from grain on stalks? Abaye answers: <b>This</b> produce, after being threshed and placed into piles, is completely processed and <b>has become grain; and that</b> produce on the stalk <b>did not</b> yet <b>become grain,</b> and the Levite is therefore exempt from separating <i>teruma gedola</i> from it. Produce that has been arranged in a pile is called grain by the Torah and is given to the priest. Once it is classified as grain, the right of the priest takes effect and the Levite is required to separate <i>teruma gedola</i> from it.
The mishna taught that one can fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> with <b>second-tithe</b> grain <b>and</b> with <b>consecrated</b> grain <b>that was redeemed.</b> The Gemara asks: It is <b>obvious</b> that this is the case, as consecrated grain that has been redeemed is non-sacred produce. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case where the consecrated property was not completely redeemed, i.e., <b>where one gave</b> payment for <b>the principal,</b> the value of the tithe, <b>but he did not give</b> payment for the additional <b>fifth</b> due when redeeming consecrated items. <b>And</b> the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that failure to add <b>the fifth does not invalidate</b> the redemption. Although there is an obligation to pay this additional fifth, the neglect of this duty does not prevent the grain from becoming non-sacred.
<b>And</b> the mishna further taught that <b>priests</b> can fulfill their obligation <b>with</b> <i>matza</i> of <b><i>ḥalla</i> and with <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara again asks: It is <b>obvious</b> that this is the case. Since a priest is permitted to eat <i>ḥalla</i> and <i>teruma</i>, he can fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> with them. The Gemara responds: This ruling is nevertheless necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>we require <i>matza</i></b> that may be eaten <b>equally by anyone,</b> which would mean that <i>matza</i> that may not be eaten by regular Israelites is prohibited to priests as well. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the repetition of the words <b>“<i>matzot</i>,” “<i>matzot</i>”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3, 8) comes to <b>amplify,</b> i.e., one can fulfill one’s obligation to eat <i>matza</i> even with foods that may be eaten only by specific people.
We learned in the mishna: <b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> fulfill this obligation <b>with untithed produce.</b> The Gemara asks: It is <b>obvious</b> that this is the case, as it is always prohibited to eat <i>tevel</i>. The Gemara explains: <b>No, it is necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where</b> it is considered <b>untithed produce by rabbinic</b> law, and by Torah law the produce is permitted. For instance, this is the case with regard to grain <b>that one sowed in an unperforated flowerpot.</b> Anything grown disconnected from the ground is not defined as produce of the ground, and its owner is exempt by Torah law from tithing it. However, by rabbinic law, grain sowed in <b>an unperforated flowerpot</b> is considered untithed.
It was also taught in the mishna: <b>And</b> one does <b>not</b> fulfill his obligation <b>with</b> <i>matza</i> from produce <b>of</b> the <b>first tithe, whose <i>teruma</i>,</b> <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, <b>was not taken.</b> The Gemara asks: It is <b>obvious</b> that this is the case, as this produce may not be eaten. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach this with regard to a case <b>where</b> the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest after the kernels of grain were placed <b>in a pile</b> but before <i>teruma gedola</i> was separated from the produce.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Lest you say, as Rav Pappa said to Abaye,</b> that in that case too, the Levite should be exempt from the requirement to separate <i>teruma gedola</i> from this produce, the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>teaches us, as</b> Abaye <b>responded</b> to Rav Pappa, that there is a difference between a case when the grain was on the stalks and when it was collected in a pile. Therefore, one may not eat this produce before separating <i>teruma gedola</i> from it.
It was further taught in the mishna: <b>And</b> one does <b>not</b> fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with second-tithe</b> produce <b>or consecrated</b> grain <b>that was not redeemed.</b> The Gemara asks: Isn’t that, too, <b>obvious,</b> as it is prohibited to eat these foods?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> this is speaking of a case <b>where they were redeemed, and what</b> is the meaning of the expression: <b>They were not redeemed?</b> It means <b>that they were not redeemed properly,</b> e.g., <b>second-tithe</b> grain that <b>was redeemed with an unminted coin [<i>asimon</i>]. As the Merciful One says</b> with regard to the redemption of the second tithe: “And you shall turn it into money, and bind up the money in your hand, and go to the place which the Lord your God shall choose” (Deuteronomy 14:25). The phrase <b>“and bind up [<i>ve’tzarta</i>] the money”</b> indicates that the produce must be exchanged for <b>an object that has a form [<i>tzura</i>],</b> not unminted metal.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>consecrated</b> property, we are dealing with a case <b>where he redeemed it</b> by exchanging it <b>for land instead of money, as the Merciful One says: “And he will give</b> the fifth part of <b>the money</b> of your valuation unto it <b>and it shall be assured to him”</b> (see Leviticus 27:19). If one redeemed consecrated property with land rather than money, the consecrated status is not transferred to the land.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a person fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with untithed produce that was not amended</b> with regard to tithes. The Gemara analyzes the apparently redundant phrase <b>untithed produce that was not amended.</b> But isn’t <b>all untithed produce also not amended,</b> by definition?
<b>Rather,</b> this <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>untithed produce that was incompletely amended.</b> How so? For example, produce <b>from which <i>teruma gedola</i> was taken, but</b> the <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe was not taken from</b> it. Alternatively, the <b>first tithe</b> was separated from the produce, <b>but not</b> the <b>second tithe; or,</b> it is referring even to grain from which all the tithes were separated, apart from the <b>poor man’s tithe.</b> Although no sanctity applies to the poor man’s tithe, which is simply a monetary gift to the poor, until this tithe has been separated the grain remains untithed. <b>From where</b> is it derived that these types of grain cannot be used for <i>matza</i>?
<b>The verse states: “You shall not eat leavened bread with it;</b> seven days you shall eat with it <i>matza</i>” (Deuteronomy 16:3). One fulfills his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with</b> food <b>whose prohibition</b> is solely <b>due to</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not eat leavened bread with it,</b> if it was not preserved in an unleavened state. This command <b>excludes this</b> grain, <b>which is not prohibited due to</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not eat leavened bread, but</b> rather <b>due to</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not eat untithed produce.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise at this <i>baraita</i>. <b>And the prohibition of leavened bread, where did it go?</b> In other words, doesn’t the prohibition: “You shall not eat leavened bread” apply to untithed produce as well? <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said: One prohibition does not take effect where another prohibition</b> already exists. No additional prohibitions can apply to an object that is already prohibited, e.g., untithed grain. Consequently, the prohibition of leavened bread does not take effect on untithed produce. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b>

Daf 36a

<b>One who</b> unwittingly <b>eats</b> an unslaughtered <b>animal</b> carcass <b>on Yom Kippur is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering to atone for this consumption. The prohibition against eating on Yom Kippur does not apply to the already prohibited meat of an animal carcass, which means only the prohibition against eating an unslaughtered animal carcass is violated by this act.
<b>Ravina said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with <b>the Rabbis,</b> who maintain that a prohibition can take effect where another prohibition already exists, it can be explained as follows: One fulfills his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with</b> food <b>whose prohibition</b> is <b>solely due to</b> the commandment: <b>Do not eat leavened bread,</b> which <b>excludes this</b> grain, <b>which is forbidden not only due to</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not eat leavened bread, but also due to</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not eat untithed produce.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty against this explanation: <b>Is</b> the word: <b>Only, written</b> in the <i>baraita</i>? This word, which is critical for Ravina’s explanation, does not appear in the <i>baraita</i> at all. <b>Rather, it is clear</b> that this must be explained <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Sheshet,</b> who maintains that the <i>baraita</i> should be attributed to Rabbi Shimon.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a person can fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <b><i>matza</i></b> on Passover <b>with</b> <i>matza</i> of <b>second tithe in Jerusalem.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “You shall eat no leavened bread with it; seven days you shall eat with it <i>matza</i>, <b>the bread of affliction [<i>leḥem oni</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3), <i>oni</i> with the letter <i>ayin</i>, i.e., poor man’s bread. As this is similar to the phrase: Bread of acute mourning [<i>leḥem oni</i>], <i>oni</i> with an <i>alef</i>, it can be inferred that this mitzva must be fulfilled with <i>matza</i> <b>that</b> can <b>be eaten</b> during a period of <b>acute mourning,</b> on the day one’s close relative has died. This <b>excludes this</b> second tithe, <b>which cannot be eaten during</b> a period of <b>acute mourning but only</b> in a state <b>of joy,</b> as the Torah states: “I have not eaten from it in my acute mourning” (Deuteronomy 26:14). This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The repetition of <b><i>matzot matzot</i></b> serves to <b>amplify,</b> and teaches that all types of <i>matza</i> may be eaten on Passover. The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states <i>leḥem oni</i>,</b> poor man’s bread? The <i>baraita</i> answers: This phrase <b>excludes dough that was kneaded with wine, oil, or honey,</b> which is not classified as poor man’s bread and therefore cannot be used for this mitzva.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Akiva?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Is it written</b> in the consonantal text <b><i>leḥem oni</i></b> with a <i>vav</i>? That would allude to the comparison of <i>matza</i> to food eaten by an <i>onen</i>, an acute mourner, as <i>onen</i> is also spelled with a <i>vav</i>. Actually, <b>it is written <i>leḥem oni</i></b> without a <i>vav</i>, meaning poor man’s bread.
<b>And Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> could respond: <b>Do we vocalize</b> the word as <b><i>ani</i>,</b> as would be appropriate for a phrase meaning a poor man’s bread? In fact, <b>we vocalize</b> it <b><i>oni</i>,</b> which means oppression, affliction, or mourning. <b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> could retort: The fact <b>that we vocalize</b> the word <b>as <i>oni</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> a statement of <b>Shmuel. As Shmuel said:</b> The expression <b><i>leḥem oni</i></b> means <b>bread over which many matters are recited [<i>onin</i>],</b> an allusion to the Passover Seder, at which one recites the Haggadah and eats <i>matza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Akiva maintain</b> with regard to <b>dough that was kneaded with wine, oil, or honey,</b> that it may <b>not</b> be used for <i>matza</i>? <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>not knead dough on Passover with wine, oil, or honey? And if one kneaded</b> dough in this manner, <b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> The dough must <b>be burned immediately,</b> as it is leavened faster than other types of dough. <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that although it is leavened quickly, one can still prevent it from being leavened, and if he does so it may <b>be eaten. And Rabbi Akiva said: It was my Shabbat</b> to serve <b>before Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua</b> during Passover (Rav Yehuda ben Rav Binyamin HaRofeh), <b>and I kneaded for them dough with wine, oil, and honey, and they said nothing to me</b> by way of objection.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And although one</b> may <b>not knead</b> dough with these ingredients, <b>one</b> may <b>spread</b> these substances on the surface of the dough. The Gemara comments: With regard to this latter statement, <b>we have come</b> back <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> who said that one may not knead bread with wine, oil, or honey. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> With regard to dough <b>into which one</b> may <b>knead</b> wine, oil, or honey, <b>one</b> may likewise <b>spread</b> them on the dough, whereas concerning dough <b>into which one</b> may <b>not knead</b> these ingredients, <b>one</b> may <b>not spread</b> them on the dough either. <b>And everyone agrees that one</b> may <b>not knead the dough with warm</b> water, as this will cause it to be leavened quickly. In any case, it is evident from here that Rabbi Akiva himself prepared <i>matza</i> with wine, oil, and honey.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> statement of Rabbi Akiva’s, which maintains that one does not fulfill his obligation with <i>matza</i> prepared with wine, oil, and honey, is referring to <b>the first day of the Festival,</b> during which there is a special commandment to eat <i>matza</i>. However, <b>that</b> second <i>baraita</i>, in which Rabbi Akiva states that he prepared this type of dough himself, pertains to <b>the second day</b> of Passover, when no special requirement to eat <i>matza</i> is in effect. On the second day, there is no mitzva to eat <i>matza</i>. It is only forbidden to own or eat leavened bread; consequently, so-called rich, or enhanced <i>matza</i>, prepared from fruit juices, is permitted.
The Gemara adds that this is <b>as Rabbi Yehoshua said to his sons:</b> On <b>the first night</b> of Passover, <b>do not knead for me</b> dough <b>with milk,</b> but <b>from</b> the first night <b>onward, knead</b> my dough for <b>me with milk.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Throughout the whole year <b>one</b> may <b>not knead dough with milk, and if he kneaded</b> dough with milk, <b>the entire bread is prohibited, due to</b> the fact that one will become <b>accustomed to sin,</b> by unwittingly eating it with meat? <b>Rather, this is what he is saying:</b> On <b>the first</b> night of Passover <b>do not knead me</b> dough <b>with honey;</b> however, <b>from then onward, knead me</b> dough <b>with honey.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>actually</b> Rabbi Yehoshua said: <b>With milk, as Ravina said:</b> If this bread, kneaded with milk, is prepared in the shape <b>of an ox’s eye, it is permitted.</b> In other words, if one forms this dough in a unique shape, e.g., the eye of an ox, one may eat it, as it is clearly distinguishable from ordinary bread. Therefore, there is no concern that it will be eaten with meat. <b>Here too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is speaking about a case where he told them to prepare this <i>matza</i> in the shape <b>of an ox’s eye.</b>
It was incidentally mentioned in the previous <i>baraita</i>: <b>And everyone agrees that one</b> may <b>not knead dough with warm</b> water. The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> that of <b>meal-offerings? As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>All meal-offerings are kneaded with warm water and are watched so that they will not be leavened.</b> The Gemara explains that there is a distinction between these two cases: <b>If they say</b> it is permitted <b>for diligent</b> priests to bake with warm water, <b>shall they</b> also <b>say</b> the same with regard <b>to those who are not diligent?</b> The priests are diligent and expert in the Temple service and are able to take extreme care, but not everyone can be relied upon to guard the dough unfailingly.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> if we rely on the diligence of the priests, <b>let them also soak</b> the grains in water to help them remove the husks. <b>Why did Rabbi Zeira say</b> that <b>Rabba bar Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to the <b>wheat</b> used <b>in the meal-offerings, one</b> may <b>not soak it?</b> The Gemara answers: The <b>kneading</b> of the dough <b>is</b> performed <b>by diligent</b> priests; however, the act of <b>soaking is not</b> performed <b>by diligent</b> priests. Instead, this soaking is performed outside of the Temple confines by less reliable non-priests.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>kneading, is it</b> performed only <b>by diligent</b> priests? <b>But isn’t it written:</b> “And when any one brings a meal-offering to the Lord, his offering shall be of fine flour; <b>and he shall pour oil upon it,</b> and place frankincense upon it. <b>And he shall bring it to</b> Aaron’s sons <b>the priests;</b> and he shall take from it his handful of its fine flour, and of its oil, together with all its frankincense” (Leviticus 2:1–2). These verses indicate that <b>from the</b> scooping of a <b>handful and onward,</b> the <b>mitzva</b> must be performed <b>by</b> members of <b>the priesthood. This teaches about the pouring</b> of the oil <b>and the stirring</b> of the mixture <b>that</b> they <b>are valid</b> even if they are performed <b>by any person,</b> even a non-priest.
The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>kneading, although</b> it <b>is not</b> performed <b>by diligent</b> priests, <b>it is</b> nevertheless performed <b>in</b> the <b>place of</b> the <b>diligent.</b> Kneading may be carried out by a non-priest, but it must still be performed in the Temple courtyard. <b>As the Master said: Mixing is valid</b> if performed <b>by a non-priest;</b> however, if it is conducted <b>outside the walls of the courtyard, it,</b> the meal offering, <b>is disqualified.</b> This serves <b>to exclude soaking, which is neither</b> performed <b>by</b> the <b>diligent nor</b> performed <b>in</b> the <b>place of the diligent.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> that of <b>the <i>omer</i> meal-offering,</b> which must also be guarded from leavening? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the <b><i>omer</i> offering, one soaks it and gathers it,</b> without concern that it will become leavened. The Gemara answers: An act performed by the <b>community is different,</b> as the Great Sanhedrin supervises these operations, and those executing them no doubt proceed with great caution.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation by</b> eating <i>matza</i> prepared from the wheat of <b>first fruits;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “In all of your habitations you shall eat <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Exodus 12:20). This verse indicates that one fulfills his obligation only with <b><i>matza</i> that</b> may <b>be eaten “in all of your habitations.”</b> This expression <b>excludes first fruits, which</b> may <b>not be eaten in all of your habitations, but</b> only <b>in Jerusalem.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> That verse is not the source for this <i>halakha</i>; rather, the fact that one cannot fulfill his obligation with <i>matza</i> of first fruits is derived from the juxtaposition of <b><i>matza</i> and bitter herbs: Just as bitter herbs are not first fruits,</b> as they are not included in the seven species to which the mitzva of first fruits applies, <b>so too <i>matza</i></b> may <b>not be</b> from <b>first fruits. If</b> you will claim: <b>Just as bitter herbs</b> are <b>from a species</b> that are <b>not</b> brought as <b>first fruits, so too <i>matza</i></b> must be prepared <b>from a species</b> that are <b>not</b> brought as <b>first fruits,</b> e.g., spelt,

Daf 36b

<b>I would</b> then think this comparison <b>excludes wheat and barley, which are from a species</b> that are brought as <b>first fruits</b> and should therefore not be used for the mitzva of <i>matza</i>. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “<i>Matzot</i>,” “<i>matzot</i>”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3, 8) to <b>amplify</b> and teach that any <i>matza</i> is acceptable for this mitzva. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the repetition of <b><i>matzot matzot</i></b> comes to <b>amplify</b> this <i>halakha</i> that any <i>matza</i> is fit for Passover use, it should <b>also</b> include <i>matza</i> prepared from <b>first-fruit</b> wheat. The Gemara answers: This is indeed true, and <b>Rabbi Akiva retracted</b> his statement. He too derives the <i>halakha</i> from the verse: “In all of your habitations.”
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a person</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation with</b> <i>matza</i> from <b>first fruit;</b> therefore <b>the verse states: “In all of your habitations you shall eat <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Exodus 12:20). The verse indicates that one can fulfill his obligation with <b><i>matza</i> that</b> may <b>be eaten in all habitations.</b> It <b>excludes first fruits, which</b> may <b>not be eaten in all habitations, but only in Jerusalem.</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>I</b> should <b>also exclude second-tithe</b> produce as fit for <i>matza</i>; therefore <b>the verse states: “<i>Matzot</i>,” “<i>matzot</i>.”</b> As stated above, this repetition serves to <b>amplify,</b> and it includes second tithe in the materials that may be used in the preparation of <i>matza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you <b>to include second-tithe</b> produce due to the words <i>matzot matzot</i> <b>but to exclude first fruits?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>I include</b> the <b>second tithe, which has</b> a means by which it may be <b>permitted</b> to be eaten <b>in all habitations,</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> as will be explained. <b>And I exclude first fruits, which do not have,</b> under any circumstances, a manner by which it is <b>permitted</b> to eat them <b>in all habitations.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>As Rabbi Eliezer said: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to second-tithe</b> produce <b>that became ritually impure, that one</b> may <b>redeem it even in Jerusalem?</b> Second-tithe produce that has been redeemed may be removed from the city. <b>The verse states:</b> “And if the way is too long for you, <b>so that you are not able to carry it [<i>se’eto</i>],</b> because the place is too far from you, which the Lord your God shall choose to set His name there, when the Lord your God shall bless you” (Deuteronomy 14:24).
<b>And</b> it is derived by means of a verbal analogy that this <b>carrying [<i>se’et</i>] is nothing other</b> than <b>eating, as it is stated: “And portions [<i>masot</i>] were taken to them from before him”</b> (Genesis 43:34). In light of this parallel language, the Gemara understands the phrase “so that you are not able <i>se’eto</i>” to mean: So that you are not able to eat it. Like second-tithe produce that has not yet been taken into Jerusalem, second-tithe produce in the capital that cannot be eaten due to ritual impurity can be redeemed and taken out of the city. Consequently, second tithe can indeed be considered food that may be eaten “in all of your habitations.”
The Gemara applies this discussion to the issue at hand: <b>Who did you hear that said:</b> One can <b>fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with second tithe?</b> It is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, and</b> yet <b>he excludes first fruits</b> due <b>to</b> the expression: <b>“In all of your habitations.” Learn from this that</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>retracted</b> his opinion and accepted Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s derivation.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> why does he learn this <i>halakha</i> from the phrase: “In all of your habitations”? <b>Let him derive it from</b> the phrase: <b><i>Leḥem oni</i></b> (Deuteronomy 16:3). Rabbi Yosei HaGelili derives from this expression that <i>matza</i> must be prepared from produce <b>that</b> can <b>be eaten in</b> a state of <b>acute mourning;</b> that <b>excludes this</b> second tithe, <b>which</b> may <b>be eaten only in</b> a state of <b>joy.</b> This exposition should apply to first fruits as well, as they must also be eaten in a state of joy.
The Gemara explains: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>maintains in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who says that an acute mourner may eat first fruits. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>First fruits are prohibited to an acute mourner, and Rabbi Shimon permits</b> an acute mourner to eat first fruits.
The Gemara explains this dispute: <b>What is the reason for the Rabbis’</b> opinion, which maintains that an acute mourner may not eat first fruits? <b>As it is written: “You may not eat within your gates</b> the tithe of your corn, or of your wine, or of your oil, or the firstlings of your herd or of your flock, nor any of your vows which you vow, nor your free-will offerings, nor the offering of your hand” (Deuteronomy 12:17). <b>And the Master said: “The offering of your hand,” these are first fruits, as</b> this verse <b>compares first fruits to</b> the second <b>tithe: Just as</b> the second <b>tithe is prohibited to an acute mourner,</b> as stated explicitly in the Torah, <b>so too</b> are <b>first fruits prohibited to an acute mourner.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shimon</b> says in response to this contention: First fruits <b>are called <i>teruma</i> by the Merciful One</b> and therefore their status is <b>like</b> that of <b><i>teruma</i>: Just as <i>teruma</i> is permitted to an acute mourner, so too first fruits</b> are <b>permitted to an acute mourner.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Shimon, although he does not</b> accept this <b>juxtaposition</b> of first fruits and second tithe, <b>in any case</b> the word <b>joy is written with regard to</b> first fruits, <b>as it is written: “And you shall rejoice in all the good</b> that the Lord has given you and your household” (Deuteronomy 26:11). In light of this, how can Rabbi Shimon permit an acute mourner to eat first fruits?
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Shimon does not learn from <b>that</b> verse that one must eat first fruits while he is personally happy; rather, <b>it comes</b> to teach us <b>that</b> first fruits should be eaten during the <b>period of rejoicing. As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>From <i>Shavuot</i> until <i>Sukkot</i>, one brings</b> first fruits <b>and recites</b> the prayers of thanks to God that appear in the Torah. <b>From <i>Sukkot</i> until Hanukkah one</b> may <b>bring</b> first fruits, <b>but he does not recite</b> the portion from the Torah. This mishna states that the ideal time for bringing first fruits to the Temple is during the joyous harvest season, from which it may be inferred that this verse is not referring to personal joy of the one bringing the first fruits, but rather to the period of communal joy.
<b>The Sages taught</b> that the phrase <b>poor man’s bread [<i>leḥem oni</i>] excludes</b> <i>matza</i> that <b>was boiled [<i>ḥalut</i>]</b> in hot water after it was baked, which is considered to be a relative delicacy; <b>and</b> this expression also excludes <i>matza</i> that was baked as a <b>large cake [<i>ashisha</i>].</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a person fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>only with coarse [<i>hadra’a</i>] bread;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “<i>Matzot</i>,” “<i>matzot</i>,”</b> which serves to <b>amplify</b> and include <i>matza</i> prepared with fine-grade flour. <b>And</b> in fact, one could fulfill his obligation <b>even with <i>matzot</i> like those of</b> King <b>Solomon,</b> which were prepared from the finest sifted flour. <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Poor man’s bread”?</b> This phrase comes <b>to exclude boiled</b> <i>matza</i> <b>and large cakes,</b> but it does not exclude <i>matza</i> prepared from refined flour.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> may it be <b>inferred</b> that <b><i>ashisha</i> is an expression</b> that indicates <b>importance? As it is written</b> with regard to King David’s celebration after he brought the Ark of the Covenant to Jerusalem: <b>“And he dealt among all the people, among the whole multitude of Israel, both to men and women, to every one a cake of bread, and an <i>eshpar</i>, and an <i>ashisha</i>,</b> and all the people departed, every one to his house” (II Samuel 6:19).
<b>And Rav Ḥanan bar Abba said:</b> The word <b><i>eshpar</i></b> refers to a portion of meat equivalent to <b>one-sixth of an ox,</b> and the word <b><i>ashisha</i></b> refers to a cake prepared from <b>one-sixth of an <i>eipha</i></b> of flour. <b>And</b> this interpretation <b>disputes</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel said: <i>Ashisha</i></b> means <b>a jug of wine, as it is written: “And those who love the jug [<i>ashishei</i>] of grapes”</b> (Hosea 3:1).
<b>The Sages taught: One</b> may <b>not bake thick bread on the Festival, on Passover,</b> as it might be leavened before it has a chance to bake; this is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai.</b>

Daf 37a

<b>And Beit Hillel permit</b> one to bake bread in this manner. The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> thickness is required for the <i>matza</i> to be considered <b>thick bread? Rav Huna said:</b> This category includes <i>matza</i> that is <b>a handbreadth</b> thick. The proof is <b>as we found by the shewbread,</b> which could not be leavened and which was <b>a handbreadth</b> thick.
<b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to this</b> explanation: <b>If</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that it is permitted to bake bread a handbreadth thick for the shewbread, which was prepared <b>by diligent</b> priests who ensured that the dough did not become leavened, will <b>they say</b> the same <b>with regard to</b> other people <b>who are not</b> as <b>diligent?</b> Furthermore, <b>if they said</b> this <b>with regard to well-kneaded bread,</b> will <b>they say</b> the same <b>with regard to bread that is not well kneaded?</b>
Rav Yosef continues: <b>If they said</b> that bread a handbreadth thick is permitted in a case where the bread was cooked <b>with dry wood,</b> which was brought to the Temple during the dry summer months, as the heat generated from this type of wood would cause the bread to cook quickly before it leavened, will <b>they say</b> the same with regard to ordinary people who cook <b>with moist wood? If they said</b> this <b>with regard to a hot oven</b> in the Temple, will <b>they</b> also <b>say</b> it is permitted <b>with regard to a cool oven?</b> Finally, <b>if they said</b> so <b>with regard to</b> the shewbread, which was baked <b>in a metal oven</b> that could be heated quickly, will <b>they say</b> the same <b>with regard to a clay oven?</b> Clearly, these two cases are different, and no comparison can be drawn between the shewbread and ordinary <i>matza</i>.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said: I asked my special Rabbi, and who is this? Rav. Some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rav said: I asked my special Rabbi, and who is this? Our holy Rabbi,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the expression: <b><i>Pat ava</i>?</b> He explained that it means: <b>A large</b> quantity <b>of bread,</b> a large batch of dough prepared in one session. <b>And why did they call it: <i>Pat ava</i>,</b> thick bread? It is referred to by this name <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> it requires <b>a large</b> amount <b>of kneading. And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>in the place where this <i>tanna</i> lived, a large quantity of bread was</b> simply <b>called <i>pat ava</i>,</b> thick bread.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this prohibition against preparing a large batch? <b>If</b> the reason <b>is due to the unnecessary exertion</b> that is required to knead a large amount of dough, which is an improper activity on a Festival, <b>why</b> discuss <b>particularly</b> the application of this <i>halakha</i> <b>to Passover?</b> The same <i>halakha</i> <b>should</b> apply <b>also to other Festivals.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so;</b> it is prohibited to prepare a large quantity of dough during any Festival. <b>And</b> while <b>this <i>tanna</i> was referring to the festival of Passover,</b> he incidentally mentioned a <i>halakha</i> that actually applies to other Festivals as well. The Gemara comments: <b>That</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, which states that <b>Beit Shammai say: One</b> may <b>not bake <i>pat ava</i> on a Festival, and Beit Hillel permit</b> baking bread in this manner on a Festival.
<b>The Sages taught: One fulfills</b> the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on Passover with fine bread, with coarse bread, and</b> after the fact <b>with</b> <i>matza</i> <b>shaped in figures, although they said</b> that <b>one should not bake</b> <i>matza</i> <b>shaped in figures on Passover</b> <i>ab initio</i>. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Baitos ben Zonin asked the Sages</b> about <b>this matter: Why did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that <b>one</b> may <b>not prepare</b> <i>matza</i> <b>shaped in figures on Passover</b> <i>ab initio</i>? <b>They said to him:</b> The reason is <b>because a woman will tarry over it</b> as she prepares the bread, so that she can form the figure before it is baked, <b>and she will</b> thereby <b>cause it to become leavened.</b>
<b>He said to them: It is possible</b> for a woman <b>to prepare</b> this <i>matza</i> <b>with a mold, and</b> she could <b>set it immediately,</b> without delaying the baking process. <b>They said to him:</b> People would fail to understand the distinction, and <b>they would say</b> that <b>all shaped</b> <i>matza</i> <b>is prohibited, and</b> yet <b>Baitos’ shaped</b> <i>matza</i> <b>is permitted.</b> Consequently, the Sages rejected this distinction, and prohibited all forms of <i>matza</i> shaped in figures on Passover.
<b>Rabbi Elazar bar Tzadok said: Once I followed my father,</b> Rabbi Tzadok, <b>into Rabban Gamliel’s home, and they brought before him</b> <i>matza</i> <b>shaped in figures on Passover. I said: Father, didn’t the Sages say</b> that <b>one</b> may <b>not prepare</b> <i>matza</i> <b>shaped in figures on Passover? He said to me: My son, they did not say this</b> prohibition <b>for</b> the <i>matza</i> of <b>all</b> ordinary <b>people; rather, they said so</b> in regard to the <i>matza</i> <b>of bakers,</b> who are under pressure to enhance the appearance of their products in order to increase sales. The dough could leaven, since bakers might take too much time to ensure that the shape of their <i>matza</i> is exactly right.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>this is</b> what Rabbi Tzadok <b>said to</b> his son: The Sages <b>did not say</b> that this practice is prohibited with regard to the <i>matza</i> <b>of bakers,</b> who are expert and efficient in their work and will do it quickly, but <b>rather</b> this prohibition applies to the <i>matza</i> <b>of all</b> ordinary <b>people.</b> According to both versions of this exchange, it is permitted to eat this <i>matza</i> after the fact. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: One</b> may <b>prepare</b> <i>matzot</i> <b>shaped as thin</b> wafers, <b>but one</b> may <b>not prepare</b> <i>matzot</i> <b>shaped as thick loaves,</b> as the latter is more likely to be leavened.
<b>The Sages taught: Sponge-like cakes, honey cakes, spiced cakes [<i>eskeritin</i>], pan-fried bread [<i>ḥallat hamasret</i>], and</b> bread prepared from <b>a mixture</b> of permitted grain and <i>teruma</i>, their owners <b>are</b> all <b>exempt from <i>ḥalla</i>.</b> The Gemara clarifies these obscure terms. <b>What is pan-fried bread? Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: This is boiled bread</b> baked <b>by</b> ordinary <b>homeowners</b> in a deep frying pan.
<b>Reish Lakish said: These</b> dishes <b>are pot-boiled stew [<i>ilpas</i>],</b> not bread. Since this food is prepared in a pot and not in an oven, it has been boiled rather than baked, and its owner is therefore exempt from <i>ḥalla</i>. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Even the owner of bread prepared like <b>a pot-boiled stew is obligated</b> in <i>ḥalla</i>, but the owners of <b>these</b> pan-fried breads and the other baked goods listed are exempt, <b>as</b> these breads <b>were baked in the sun.</b> Since they were not baked over a fire, they are not classified as bread with regard to the mitzva of <i>ḥalla</i>.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish statement from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>sponge-cakes, honey cakes, or spiced cakes,</b> if one <b>prepared them in a pot,</b> he is <b>obligated</b> to separate <i>ḥalla</i>. However, if he prepared them <b>in the sun,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from this mitzva. This is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish. Ulla said: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> could have <b>said to you: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where one heated</b> the pot over the fire <b>and afterward pasted</b> the dough to the sides of the hot pot. This is considered like baking in an oven, and one is therefore obligated to separate <i>ḥalla</i> from the dough.
The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> if one <b>pasted</b> the dough to the sides of the pot <b>and afterward heated</b> it, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>So too,</b> you will say <b>that</b> is he is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of <i>ḥalla</i>? If so, <b>rather than teach</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i> that the owner of the bread is <b>exempt if it was baked in the sun, let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>distinguish and teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>within</b> the presentation of this case <b>itself: In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that one who prepares this bread in a pot is obligated to separate <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>said? For example, when one heated the pot and afterward pasted</b> the bread to its sides; <b>but if he placed the bread</b> in the pot <b>and</b> then <b>boiled</b> it, he is <b>exempt.</b> Why didn’t the <i>baraita</i> formulate the <i>halakha</i> in this manner?
The Gemara answers: The text of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete and is teaching the following: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where one heated</b> the pot <b>and afterward pasted</b> the bread to its sides. <b>However,</b> if <b>one placed</b> the bread inside the pot <b>and afterward boiled</b> it, <b>it is</b> considered <b>as though it had been cooked in the sun, and</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from separating <i>ḥalla</i>.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a difficulty from a <i>baraita</i>: One can <b>fulfill</b> the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with half-baked <i>matza</i> and pot-boiled <i>matza</i>.</b> Apparently, dough baked in a pot is classified as bread. The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where one heated</b> the pot like an oven, <b>and afterward he pasted</b> the dough to the sides of the pot.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is half-baked <i>matza</i>? Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> This refers to <b>any</b> <i>matza</i> <b>that</b> is sufficiently baked so that <b>when</b> it is <b>broken no strands</b> of dough <b>emerge from its sides. Rava said: And likewise the loaves of the thanks-offering</b> may be used if they have been baked to this extent. The Gemara asks: It is <b>obvious</b> that this is the case, as <b>here,</b> with regard to <i>matza</i>, <b>“bread” is written, and there,</b> with regard to the loaves of the thanks-offering, <b>“bread” is</b> also <b>written</b> (Leviticus 7:13). Since both loaves are called bread, it is obvious that the same criteria should apply to both cases.
The Gemara rejects this assertion: This statement is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> the following: <b>Since it is written</b> with regard to a thanks-offering: <b>“And he shall present from it</b>

Daf 37b

<b>one out of each offering</b> for a gift to the Lord; it shall belong to the priest who sprinkles the blood of the peace-offerings” (Leviticus 7:14), and the word <b>“one”</b> indicates that it must be a whole loaf, i.e., <b>that</b> one should <b>not take a broken</b> piece, <b>and here</b> the bread has not been properly baked, it might therefore have been thought that <b>it is considered as though it were broken.</b> Consequently, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is nevertheless classified as bread.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> With regard to <b><i>me’isa</i>,</b> dough that was boiled in water, <b>Beit Shammai exempt</b> one from separating <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>and Beit Hillel obligate one</b> to do so. As for dough that has undergone the process of <b><i>ḥalita</i>, Beit Shammai obligate</b> one to separate <i>ḥalla</i> from it, <b>and Beit Hillel exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>me’isa</i> and what is <i>ḥalita</i>?</b> The Gemara explains: <b><i>Me’isa</i></b> is dough prepared by pouring <b>flour on boiling water [<i>muglashin</i>],</b> whereas <b><i>ḥalita</i></b> is formed by pouring <b>boiling water on flour.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said in the name of his father: From</b> both <b>this,</b> <i>me’isa</i>, <b>and that,</b> <i>ḥalita</i>, one <b>is exempt</b> from separating <i>ḥalla</i>. <b>And some say</b> that he said: With regard to both <b>this and that,</b> one <b>is obligated</b> to separate <i>ḥalla</i>. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> With regard to both <b>this and that,</b> if one <b>prepared them in a pot, he is exempt</b> from the mitzva of <i>ḥalla</i>; however, if he prepared the bread <b>in an oven, he is obligated</b> to separate <i>ḥalla</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> who taught that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagree with regard to these two cases, <b>what is different</b> about <b><i>me’isa</i> and what is different</b> about <b><i>ḥalita</i>?</b> Why do Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel reverse their opinions with regard to these types of bread? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said, and likewise Rabbi Yehuda said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> who <b>said: As</b> is the <b>dispute with regard to this</b> type of bread, <b>so</b> is the <b>dispute with regard to that</b> one; i.e., Beit Hillel are either lenient or stringent in both cases. <b>And</b> the variation in the <i>baraita</i> is due to <b>a break</b> in its text, which is actually a combination of two sources, because <b>he who taught this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>did not teach that</b> one, as the two statements were taught by different Sages.
The Gemara now states the objection: <b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching</b> that <b>the Rabbis say:</b> With regard to both <b>this and that,</b> <i>me’isa</i> and <i>ḥalita</i>, <b>if one prepared them in a pot</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of <i>ḥalla</i>, but if he prepared them <b>in an oven</b> he is <b>obligated</b> to separate <i>ḥalla</i>. This is apparently <b>a conclusive refutation of Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who claims that one is obligated to separate <i>ḥalla</i> from bread cooked in a pot. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said to you: It is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: I <b>might</b> have thought that one is <b>obligated</b> to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> from <b><i>me’isa</i> and <i>ḥaluta</i>;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states “bread”</b> to inform us that this is not the case.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Bread is nothing other</b> than that which <b>is baked in an oven.</b> The Gemara asks: The opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda is the same as</b> that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>. Rather, is it not</b> the case that <b>the</b> practical difference <b>between them is</b> in the case of bread prepared as <b>pot-boiled stew? The first <i>tanna</i> maintains</b> that one is <b>obligated</b> to separate <i>ḥalla</i> from bread prepared as <b>pot-boiled stew,</b> unlike bread prepared by <i>me’isa</i> and <i>ḥalita</i>. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda maintains:</b> Similar to <i>me’isa</i> and <i>ḥalita</i>, one is <b>exempt</b> from separating <i>ḥalla</i> from bread prepared as <b>pot-boiled stew,</b> as it was not baked in an oven.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> it is possible to say <b>that everyone agrees</b> that the owner of bread prepared as <b>pot-boiled stew is exempt</b> from <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>and here they disagree</b> with regard to a case <b>where one subsequently baked it in the oven. The first <i>tanna</i> maintains that since</b> one <b>subsequently baked it in the oven, it is called bread,</b> and one must separate <i>ḥalla</i> from it. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda maintains</b> that <b>bread is nothing other</b> than that which <b>is initially baked in an oven, and since</b> this food <b>was not initially baked in an oven, it is not</b> classified as <b>bread.</b>
<b>Rava said: What is the reason of Rabbi Yehuda? As it is written: “And ten women shall bake your bread in one oven”</b> (Leviticus 26:26). Rava learns from this verse that <b>bread baked in one oven is called bread, and that</b> which <b>is not baked in one oven,</b> but rather in several different vessels, <b>is not called bread.</b>
<b>Rabba and Rav Yosef sat behind Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Zeira sat before Ulla</b> to hear him teach Torah. <b>Rabba said to Rabbi Zeira: Raise</b> the following <b>dilemma of Ulla:</b> If <b>one pasted</b> bread <b>inside</b> a pot <b>and heated it from the outside, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is one obligated to separate <i>ḥalla</i> from this bread? <b>He said to him: Why should I say</b> this question to Ulla? <b>For if I say</b> this <b>to him, he</b> will <b>say to me: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to bread prepared as <b>pot-boiled stew?</b> In other words, he will reply that my question is effectively the same as that well-known case.
<b>Rav Yosef</b> further <b>said to Rabbi Zeira: Raise the</b> following <b>dilemma of Ulla: If one pasted</b> bread <b>inside</b> a pot and lit <b>a torch opposite it, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He</b> again <b>said to him: Why should I say</b> this question to Ulla? <b>As if I say</b> this <b>to him, he</b> will <b>say to me:</b> The <b>majority</b> of <b>poor people do this</b> when they use a pot for cooking, and therefore this too should be considered the same as bread prepared like pot-boiled stew.
<b>Rav Asi said:</b> With regard to <b>dough of second-tithe</b> produce, <b>in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Meir,</b> one is <b>exempt from</b> separating <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> from it. The reason is that Rabbi Meir considers second tithe to be consecrated property, which means that although its owner is entitled to use this produce, it does not in fact belong to him. By contrast, <b>in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis,</b> who maintain that second-tithe produce is the property of its owner, one is <b>obligated</b> to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> from it.

Daf 38a

With regard to <b><i>matzot</i> of second-tithe</b> produce: <b>In accordance with the statement of Rabbi Meir, a person cannot fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on</b> the first night of <b>Passover with this</b> <i>matza</i>. Rabbi Meir considers it consecrated property, and one must eat <i>matza</i> that belongs to him, not consecrated property. <b>In accordance with the statement of the Rabbis, one</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation with</b> this type of <i>matza</i> <b>on</b> the first night of <b>Passover.</b>
The same dispute applies to <b>a citron of second-tithe</b> produce: <b>In accordance with the statement of Rabbi Meir, one cannot fulfill his obligation</b> to take the four species <b>on</b> the first day of the <b>festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i> <b>with this</b> citron. <b>In accordance with the statement of the Rabbis, a person can use this</b> citron <b>to fulfill his obligation on</b> the first day of the <b>festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>.
<b>Rav Pappa strongly objects to this</b> statement: <b>Granted,</b> one must separate <i>ḥalla</i> from this <b>dough, as it is written:</b> “Of the first of your dough you shall give to the Lord a portion [<i>ḥalla</i>] for a gift throughout your generations” (Numbers 15:21). This verse can be read in a very precise manner, so that the expression <b>“your dough”</b> indicates that <i>ḥalla</i> is separated only <b>from</b> dough <b>that belongs to you.</b>
With regard to <b>a citron too,</b> a similar conclusion can be drawn, <b>as it is written: “And you shall take for yourselves</b> on the first day a fruit of goodly trees, branches of palm trees, and boughs of thick trees and willows of the brook” (Leviticus 23:40). Here too, the expression <b>“for yourselves”</b> indicates that what you take <b>must belong to you. However,</b> with regard to <b><i>matza</i>, is it written</b> that you must use <b>your</b> own <b><i>matza</i>?</b> Since there is no such requirement, it stands to reason that even consecrated <i>matza</i> is valid for this mitzva.
<b>Rava said, and some say Rav Yeimar bar Shelamya</b> said: This principle can be <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between <b>“bread”</b> and <b>“bread.” It is written here,</b> with regard to <i>matza</i>: <b>“Poor man’s bread”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3), <b>and it is written there,</b> with regard to <i>ḥalla</i>: <b>“And it shall be that when you eat of the bread of the land,</b> you shall set apart a portion for a gift to the Lord” (Numbers 15:19). <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of <i>ḥalla</i>, it must be separated only <b>from</b> food <b>that belongs to you, so too here,</b> with regard to <i>matza</i>, it must be prepared only <b>from</b> produce <b>that belongs to you.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> Rav Asi: With regard to <b>dough of second-tithe</b> produce, one is <b>exempt from</b> separating <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> from it; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> One is <b>obligated</b> in this mitzva. Since this is a conclusive proof, the Gemara expresses surprise at the formulation: <b>Let us say that it supports him. This</b> statement <b>is</b> identical <b>to that</b> one; i.e., the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> is identical to Rav Asi’s opinion.
The Gemara explains: <b>This is what</b> the statement: Let us say, <b>is saying: Let us say from</b> the fact that <b>they disagree with regard to dough, so too, they disagree with regard to these</b> other issues. <b>Or perhaps it is different there,</b> with regard to <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>as it is written: “Your dough,” “your dough,” twice.</b> This repetition might indicate that the mitzva of <i>ḥalla</i> applies only to one who maintains full ownership of the dough. Although Rabbi Meir contends that one need not separate <i>ḥalla</i> from second-tithe produce, he does not necessarily issue a similar ruling with regard to <i>matza</i> or a citron, as there is no explicit proof to this effect.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raised a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the possibility <b>that a person</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with <i>ḥalla</i></b> separated from <b>second-tithe</b> dough <b>in Jerusalem?</b> The Gemara clarifies this dilemma: <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, do not raise</b> this <b>dilemma.</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili maintains that one can fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> only with food that may be eaten in a state of acute mourning. The Gemara explains why the dilemma does not arise according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: <b>Now</b> that it has been mentioned that one <b>cannot fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with</b> the <b>non-sacred</b> portion of second-tithe produce, i.e., with that which was not sanctified as <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to mention that one cannot fulfill his obligation <b>with its <i>ḥalla</i>? When you raise the dilemma,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara explains: Unlike Rabbi Yosei, Rabbi Akiva does not interpret the phrase “poor man’s bread [<i>leḥem oni</i>]” as though it were written with an <i>alef</i>, which indicates that it is referring to the bread of acute mourning [<i>aninut</i>], i.e., the period of mourning on the day of the death of a close relative. Consequently, the following dilemma arises: It can be suggested that <b>it is with</b> the <b>non-sacred</b> portion of the second-tithe produce <b>that one</b> can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation, <b>for if</b> the produce <b>becomes ritually impure</b> it <b>can be permitted</b> to be eaten <b>in</b> any <b>habitation</b> in Israel after it has been redeemed. Rabbi Akiva agrees that any food that can be eaten in an unrestricted manner in certain circumstances can also be used for the obligation to eat <i>matza</i>. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b><i>ḥalla</i>, which, if it becomes ritually impure, cannot be permitted</b> to be eaten <b>in</b> any <b>habitation, but goes,</b> i.e., it is slated <b>for burning,</b> this <i>ḥalla</i> <b>cannot</b> be used to <b>fulfill</b> one’s obligation.
<b>Or perhaps we say: Since, if one had not designated</b> the produce as <i>ḥalla</i> <b>and it had become ritually impure,</b> it could be redeemed and <b>be permitted</b> to be eaten <b>in</b> any <b>habitation,</b> and one could <b>fulfill</b> the obligation of <i>matza</i> <b>with it, now too,</b> one can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with it,</b> despite the fact that it has been designated as <i>ḥalla</i>. Since the sanctity is not inherent in the dough itself, it does not undermine its status as fit for <i>matza</i>.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of this analysis: With regard to <b>this</b> case, <b>certainly do not raise the dilemma, as</b> here <b>we certainly</b> apply the principle of: <b>Since,</b> as stated above. In other words, there is no doubt that <i>ḥalla</i> taken from second-tithe produce can be used for <i>matza</i>, as its sanctity is not inherent. Rather, <b>when you raise the dilemma,</b> it is with regard to <b><i>ḥalla</i> that was purchased with second-tithe money,</b> as this type of food can be ritually purified if it becomes ritually impure.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, do not raise</b> this <b>dilemma, since they say that</b> it <b>can be redeemed</b> for a second time; <b>this</b> case <b>is</b> identical to the case of second-<b>tithe</b> produce itself. In this regard, the Rabbis do not distinguish between the money with which the second tithe was redeemed and the second-tithe produce itself. <b>Rather, when you raise the dilemma,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said</b> that an object that was purchased with second-tithe money and that became ritually impure must <b>be buried.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna with regard to food <b>that was purchased with second-tithe money that became ritually impure,</b> this ritually impure food should <b>be redeemed</b> for money, with which one must purchase other food. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It should <b>be buried.</b> Since this food was merely purchased with second-tithe money, it does not have the same degree of sanctity as the tithe itself. Therefore, its status as a second-tithe object cannot be transferred to yet a third object. Consequently, if it becomes impure, it cannot be redeemed for money but must be buried as an item for which there is no use.
The Gemara clarifies the aforementioned dilemma: <b>Do we say</b> the following: <b>Since, if it were not purchased</b> with second-tithe money, <b>and</b> furthermore, <b>since, if one had not designated it</b> as <i>ḥalla</i> <b>and it became ritually impure,</b> this produce would be <b>permitted</b> to be eaten <b>in</b> any <b>habitation,</b> one can therefore <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with it</b> even after its status has changed by being purchased with second-tithe money and designated as <i>ḥalla</i>?
<b>Or perhaps we say one</b> of these logical arguments starting with: <b>Since, but we do not say two</b> arguments of: <b>Since.</b> If so, one cannot fulfill his obligation with <i>matza</i> of <i>ḥalla</i> separated from second tithe. <b>Rava said: It stands to reason</b> that <b>the category of tithe is a single</b> designation. In other words, provided that the food is included in the general framework of second tithe, it can be used for <i>matza</i>, and this applies even to the <i>ḥalla</i> separated from second tithe.
We learned in the mishna that if one prepared the <b>loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers</b> for himself, he cannot use them to fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> on Passover. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabba said: As the verse states:</b>

Daf 38b

<b>“And you shall guard the <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Exodus 12:17). This verse teaches that one may use only <b><i>matza</i> that has been guarded</b> from becoming leavened <b>for the purpose</b> of <b>matza,</b> i.e., with the intention of fulfilling one’s obligation of <i>matza</i> with it. This explanation <b>excludes this</b> <i>matza</i>, which was prepared for a nazirite or a thanks-offering and <b>which was not guarded for the purpose</b> of <b><i>matza</i> but for the purpose of a sacrifice.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> a different reason: One may not use <i>matza</i> prepared for a nazirite or a thanks-offering because <b>the verse states: “Seven days you shall eat <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Exodus 12:15), which indicates that one can fulfill his obligation only with <b><i>matza</i> that</b> can <b>be eaten for</b> all <b>seven days.</b> This requirement <b>excludes this</b> <i>matza</i>, which is of nazirite’s wafers or the loaves of a thanks-offering and <b>which cannot be eaten for seven days, but</b> only <b>for</b> one <b>day and</b> one <b>night.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba, and it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba:</b> I <b>might</b> have thought <b>that one can fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “And you shall guard the <i>matzot</i>,”</b> indicating that one must use <b><i>matza</i> that has been guarded</b> from becoming leavened <b>for the purpose of <i>matza</i></b> on Passover. This requirement <b>excludes this</b> <i>matza</i>, <b>which was not guarded for the purpose</b> of <b><i>matza</i> but for the purpose of a sacrifice.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef:</b> I <b>might</b> have thought <b>that a person can fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “Seven days you shall eat <i>matzot</i>,”</b> from which it is inferred that one must fulfill this obligation with <b><i>matza</i> that</b> can <b>be eaten for</b> all <b>seven</b> days. This requirement <b>excludes this</b> <i>matza</i>, <b>as it cannot be eaten for seven days but</b> only <b>for a day and a night.</b>
The Gemara asks a question of both opinions: And <b>let him derive</b> this <i>halakha</i>, that one cannot fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers, from the phrase <b>“bread of affliction [<i>leḥem oni</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3). According to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, this phrase means: One can fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> only <b>with</b> food that may <b>be eaten in</b> a state of <b>acute mourning.</b> This requirement <b>excludes this</b> <i>matza</i>, i.e., the loaves of the thanks-offering and the nazirite wafers, <b>which is not eaten in</b> a state of <b>acute mourning but in</b> a state <b>of joy,</b> as an acute mourner is prohibited from eating sacrificial foods.
The Gemara answers: Rabba and Rav Yosef both <b>maintain in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that since <b><i>oni</i>,</b> meaning poverty, <b>is written,</b> the <i>matza</i> must be bread of poverty. According to Rabbi Akiva, this phrase does not teach the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to consumption by acute mourners.
The Gemara asks another question: <b>And let him derive</b> this <i>halakha</i>, that one cannot fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers, from the fact <b>that it is <i>matza ashira</i>,</b> enhanced <i>matza</i>, as both the loaves of the thanks-offering and the nazirite’s wafers contain oil. <i>Matza</i> that contains ingredients besides flour and water is classified as <i>matza ashira</i> and cannot be used for the mitzva of eating <i>matza</i> on the first night of Passover.
