<b>Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said:</b> This is an incorrect definition, as the total amount of oil in these loaves or wafers <b>is</b> only <b>a quarter</b>-<i>log</i>, <b>and</b> as this small amount of oil <b>is divided between several loaves,</b> it is nullified in the mixture. Consequently, the loaves of the thanks-offering and the nazirite’s wafers are not <i>matza ashira</i>.
The Gemara again asks: <b>And let him derive</b> this <i>halakha</i>, that one cannot fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers from that fact <b>that</b> these types of bread <b>cannot be eaten in every habitation.</b> It was previously stated that the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> can be fulfilled only with food that can be eaten anywhere in Israel, whereas offerings may be eaten only in Jerusalem.
<b>Reish Lakish said: That is to say, the loaves of the thanks-offering and the nazirite’s wafers</b> may <b>be eaten in Nov and Givon.</b> In other words, the omission of this reason indicates that offerings could have been sacrificed on the communal altars during the period when improvised altars were permitted, before the Temple was built. These offerings are not among those that can be sacrificed only: “In the place that the Lord shall choose” (Deuteronomy 12:5). This means that during that period the loaves of the thanks-offering and the nazirite’s wafers could indeed have been eaten anywhere, as improvised altars were built in any place. Consequently, even after the Temple was built, the loaves of the thanks-offering and the nazirite’s wafers are still considered fit to be eaten anywhere in Israel.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ilai said: I asked Rabbi Eliezer</b> ben Hyrcanus: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the possibility <b>that a person</b> can <b>fulfill</b> the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with the loaves of a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers? He said to me: I did not hear</b> anything about this issue. <b>I went and asked Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who <b>said to me: They said,</b> concerning <b>loaves for a thanks-offering or a nazirite’s wafers that</b> one <b>prepared for his own</b> offering, that <b>a person cannot fulfill his obligation with them.</b> However, if one baked them <b>to sell in the market, he</b> can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with them.</b>
<b>When I returned and recited</b> these <b>matters to Rabbi Eliezer, he said to me</b> in excitement: By the <b>covenant, these are the</b> very <b>matters that were stated to Moses on Mount Sinai.</b> Rabbi Eliezer swore that this <i>halakha</i> had been transmitted over the generations going back to Moses on Mount Sinai. <b>Some say</b> he spoke in astonishment: By the <b>covenant!</b> Are <b>these</b> in fact <b>the matters that were stated to Moses on Mount Sinai? And doesn’t</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>require a reason?</b> Since there is no explicit tradition in this regard, it is necessary to provide a reason for this distinction.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> indeed, <b>what is the reason</b> for this distinction between these loaves one prepared for himself and those he intended to sell in the market? <b>Rabba said:</b> With regard to <b>anything</b> sold <b>in the market,</b> the merchant may <b>change his mind</b> about it. <b>He</b> might <b>say: If it is sold, it is sold;</b> but <b>if it is not sold</b> for an offering, <b>I will fulfill</b> my obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with it.</b> Since the merchant had in mind from the outset that these <i>matzot</i> might be used for the mitzva on Passover, he is permitted to use them to fulfill his obligation.

Daf 39a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these are the vegetables with which a person</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation</b> to eat bitter herbs <b>on Passover:</b> One can fulfill his obligation <b>with <i>ḥazeret</i>, with chervil [<i>tamkha</i>], and with field eryngo [<i>ḥarḥavina</i>], and with endives [<i>olashin</i>], and with <i>maror</i>. One fulfills</b> his <b>obligation with them whether</b> they are <b>fresh</b> or <b>whether</b> they are <b>dry. However,</b> one does <b>not</b> fulfill his obligation if they are <b>pickled</b> in water or vinegar, <b>nor</b> if they are <b>over-boiled [<i>shaluk</i>]</b> in hot water, <b>nor</b> if <b>they are boiled [<i>mevushal</i>].</b>
The mishna adds: <b>And</b> all these different types of vegetables <b>join together to</b> the measure of <b>an olive-bulk,</b> i.e., it is not necessary to eat this amount from one specific type of vegetable. <b>And one fulfills</b> his obligation by eating <b>their stalk,</b> as it is not necessary to eat the leaves. <b>And</b> one fulfills the obligation <b>with doubtfully tithed</b> produce, <b>with first-tithe</b> produce <b>whose <i>teruma</i> has been taken</b> and given to a priest, <b>and</b> with both <b>second-tithe</b> produce <b>and consecrated property that were redeemed.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara identifies the plants mentioned by the mishna by their Aramaic names. <b><i>Ḥazeret</i></b> is <b>lettuce. <i>Olashin</i></b> is called <b><i>hindevi</i>.</b> With regard to <b><i>tamkha</i>, Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: It is called <i>temakhta</i></b> in Aramaic. As for <b><i>ḥarḥavina</i>, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said:</b> This is the plant <b>that</b> grows <b>around the palm tree.</b> The mishna taught: <b>And with <i>maror</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: This is a plant called <b><i>merirata</i>.</b>
<b>Bar Kappara teaches: These are the vegetables with which a person</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation</b> to eat bitter herbs <b>on Passover: With endives, chervil, <i>ḥarḥallin</i>, field eryngo, and <i>ḥazeret</i>. Rav Yehuda says: Also wild endives, garden endives, and <i>ḥazeret</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: Why does Rav Yehuda mention <b>garden endives and <i>ḥazeret</i>? These were</b> already <b>taught in the first clause.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>this is</b> what Rav Yehuda <b>is saying: Even wild endives are</b> equivalent to <b>garden endives and <i>ḥazeret</i></b> and may be used as bitter herbs on Passover. <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> The plants <b><i>asvas</i>, and <i>tura</i>, and sweet myrrh [<i>mar yero’ar</i>]</b> can <b>also</b> be used to fulfill this obligation. <b>Rabbi Yosei said to him: <i>Asvas</i> and <i>tura</i></b> are two names for <b>one</b> plant, <b>and <i>mar</i> is</b> the same plant as <b><i>yero’ar</i>.</b>
A Sage of <b>the school of Rabbi Samuel teaches: These are the vegetables with which a person</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation</b> to eat bitter herbs <b>on Passover: With <i>ḥazeret</i>, endives, chervil, field eryngo, <i>ḥarginnin</i>, and <i>hardofannin</i>. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> One can <b>also</b> fulfill his obligation with <b><i>ḥazeret yolin</i> and <i>ḥazeret gallin</i>,</b> as they are <b>similar to</b> the aforementioned vegetables.
<b>Rabbi Ile’a said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer:</b> One can <b>also</b> fulfill his obligation with <b><i>arkablim</i>. And I went around all of</b> Rabbi Eliezer’s <b>students looking for a colleague</b> who agreed with me that Rabbi Eliezer said this, <b>but I did not find</b> anyone who remembered this ruling. <b>But when I came before Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, he conceded to my statement.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Any</b> plant <b>that has</b> white <b>sap</b> when it is cut may be used as bitter herbs. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: Anything whose surface is light</b> green may be used as bitter herbs. <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say: Any bitter herb</b> that <b>has sap and whose surface is light</b> green is fit for this mitzva. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From the statements of all these</b> Sages, <b>we can learn</b> that <b>a bitter green herb has sap and its surface is light</b> green. <b>Rav Huna said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b><i>Aḥerim</i>.</b>
<b>Ravina found Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, searching for <i>merirata</i></b> to use as bitter herbs. <b>He said to him: What is your opinion,</b> that you seek this particular herb? If you are looking for <b>that</b> which <b>is most bitter, but we learned <i>ḥazeret</i></b> first in the mishna, which indicates that this is the preferred choice. <b>And</b> likewise, a Sage of <b>the school of Shmuel taught <i>ḥazeret</i></b> first, before the other types of bitter herbs. <b>And Rabbi Oshaya said:</b> The optimal fulfillment of the <b>mitzva</b> is with <b><i>ḥazeret</i>, and Rava said: What is <i>ḥazeret</i>?</b> It is <b>lettuce [<i>ḥassa</i>].</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>lettuce [<i>ḥassa</i>]?</b> It refers to the fact <b>that God has mercy [<i>ḥas</i>] on us. And Rabbi Samuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Why are the Egyptians likened to bitter herbs</b> in the verse: “And they embittered their lives” (Exodus 1:14)? This comparison serves <b>to tell you</b> that <b>just as these bitter herbs are soft at first and harsh in the end, so too, the Egyptians were soft at first,</b> when they paid the Jews for their work, <b>but were harsh in the end,</b> as they enslaved them. This idea applies solely to <b><i>ḥazeret</i>,</b> which has a bitter aftertaste, but not to other types of bitter herbs, which are bitter from the beginning. Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, <b>said to</b> Ravina: <b>I retract</b> my position and concede that it is preferable to use <i>ḥazeret</i> for bitter herbs.
<b>Rav Reḥumi said to Abaye: From where</b> is it known <b>that this bitter herb</b> that must be eaten on Passover night <b>is a type of vegetable?</b> Perhaps one could <b>say</b> that the mitzva should be performed with <b>the bile of a <i>kufya</i></b> fish, which is very bitter, but not necessarily with a type of plant? He answered: Bitter herbs are <b>similar to <i>matza</i>; just as <i>matza</i></b> must be prepared only from food <b>that grows from the ground, so too, bitter herbs</b> must be from food <b>that grows from the ground.</b> The Gemara asks: How do we know that a bitter herb is specifically a vegetable rather than the bitter <b>oleander</b> bush? The Gemara answers: Bitter herbs are <b>similar to <i>matza</i>; just as <i>matza</i></b> is prepared from <b>a type of plant,</b> but not including a tree, <b>so too, bitter herbs</b> must be from <b>a type of plant</b> that is not a tree.
The Gemara asks a similar question: Perhaps I can <b>say</b> that one may use <b><i>harzipu</i>,</b> a vegetable that poisons animals, as the bitter herb. The Gemara answers: It must be <b>similar to <i>matza</i>; just as <i>matza</i></b> is prepared from plants <b>that</b> are fit for human consumption and <b>can be purchased with</b> second-<b>tithe money, so too, bitter herbs</b> must be from a species <b>that can be purchased with</b> second-<b>tithe money.</b>
<b>Rabba bar Rav Ḥanin said to Abaye:</b> I can <b>say that</b> the <b>bitter herb</b> mentioned in the Torah includes merely <b>one</b> species, i.e., only the bitterest plant can be used for this obligation. Abaye responded: For this reason <b>it is written: “Bitter herbs”</b> (Exodus 12:8) in the plural, indicating that many types of bitter herbs are fit for this purpose. Rabba retorted: <b>But</b> one can <b>say that “bitter herbs”</b> refers to <b>two</b> different species, but no more. Abaye explained: Bitter herbs are <b>similar to <i>matza</i>; just as <i>matza</i></b> can be prepared from <b>many types</b> of grain, <b>so too, bitter herbs</b> can be taken from <b>many</b> different <b>types</b> of vegetables.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to the <b>vegetables that the Sages said a person can fulfill with them his obligation</b> to eat bitter herbs <b>on Passover, they</b> may <b>all be planted in one</b> garden <b>bed.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>That is to say that</b> the prohibition against planting <b>diverse kinds</b> of seeds <b>does not apply to them?</b> Rav’s statement indicates that all these species are so similar that they may be planted together without violating the prohibition against planting different species of crops in one area of a field.
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> from a mishna: <b><i>Ḥazeret</i> and <i>ḥazeret gallin</i>; endive and wild endive; leek and wild leek; coriander and wild coriander; mustard and Egyptian mustard; and Egyptian gourd and <i>harmutza</i>,</b> a type of gourd, <b>are not</b> considered a mixture of <b>diverse kinds</b> when planted <b>together.</b> This indicates that <b><i>ḥazeret</i> and <i>ḥazeret gallin</i>, yes,</b> they may be planted together; however, <b><i>ḥazeret</i> and endives, no,</b> they may not be planted together.
<b>And lest you say that all</b> these species <b>are taught together,</b> and the mishna is actually saying that any of these species may be planted together, <b>but didn’t Rav</b> himself <b>say</b> that these plants <b>were taught in pairs,</b> i.e., one may plant each plant only with its pair that is listed in the mishna, due to their similarity; however, one may not, e.g., plant lettuce and endive together. It therefore remains unclear what Rav meant when he said that vegetables fit for use as bitter herbs may be planted in a single garden bed.
The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term <b>planted, which Rav said?</b> It means that these plants may <b>be properly planted.</b> In other words, they may be planted together provided that there is an appropriate amount of space between them, so that there is no violation of the prohibition against planting diverse kinds of seeds. The Gemara asks: If he wishes to inform us about planting them <b>properly, we</b> already <b>learned</b> this in a mishna:

Daf 39b

With regard to a garden <b>bed that is six by six handbreadths</b> in area, <b>one</b> may <b>plant in it five</b> different types of <b>seeds, four</b> types <b>on the four sides of the bed and one</b> type <b>in the middle.</b> This mishna teaches that it is permitted to plant different types of seeds in one garden bed, provided that one maintains the appropriate distance between them. The Gemara explains: Rav’s statement is nevertheless necessary. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>that applies only to seeds, but with regard to vegetables, no,</b> it is prohibited to plant them in a single garden bed even if this separation is maintained, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that it is permitted to plant in this manner with vegetables as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that vegetables are stronger</b> in the level of their prohibition <b>than seeds? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna in <i>Kilayim</i>: With regard to <b>multiple types of seeds, one</b> may <b>not plant</b> them together <b>in one</b> garden <b>bed,</b> even if there is space between them; <b>however,</b> with regard to <b>multiple types of vegetables, one</b> may <b>plant</b> them together <b>in one bed?</b> This mishna apparently indicates that the <i>halakha</i> is stricter concerning seeds. The Gemara answers: Rav’s statement is necessary. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>these bitter herbs are a type of seed,</b> not a vegetable, and therefore it is prohibited to plant them in a bed with other seeds, Rav <b>teaches us</b> that all the various bitter herbs are classified as types of vegetables.
The Gemara asks: <b>Could it</b> even <b>enter your mind</b> that bitter herbs are types of <b>seeds? But didn’t we learn</b> the word <b>vegetables</b> in a mishna? <b>And bar Kappara</b> likewise <b>taught: Vegetables. And</b> furthermore, the Sage of <b>the school of Shmuel taught: Vegetables.</b> The Gemara explains: It was <b>necessary for</b> Rav to mention the status of <b><i>ḥazeret</i>. It could enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> <i>ḥazeret</i> <b>ultimately hardens</b> into a type of seed, <b>one</b> must therefore <b>give it more space</b> in a garden bed than other vegetables. Rav’s statement indicates that this is not the case.
The Gemara offers support for this contention: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, say:</b> With regard to <b>a stalk of cabbage that has hardened, one</b> must <b>allow a <i>beit rova</i></b> of space <b>for it,</b> in which no other seeds may be planted. <b>Apparently, since it will ultimately harden, one</b> must <b>give it more space. Here too,</b> in the case of the <i>ḥazeret</i>, it might have been thought that <b>one</b> is required to <b>give it more space.</b> Therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that all types of bitter herbs, even lettuce, may be planted together in one bed without leaving additional space between each species.
The mishna taught that one can <b>fulfill</b> his <b>obligation</b> to eat bitter herbs <b>with</b> these types of vegetables, <b>whether</b> they are <b>fresh</b> or <b>whether</b> they are <b>dried. Rav Ḥisda said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard <b>to the stem. However,</b> with regard <b>to the leaves,</b> if they are <b>moist, yes,</b> they may be used as bitter herbs, but if they are <b>dry, no,</b> they may not serve as bitter herbs.
The Gemara asks: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that it is taught</b> in <b>the last clause</b> of the mishna: <b>In their stems,</b> it may <b>be inferred that the first clause</b> of the mishna refers to the <b>leaves.</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> <b>is explaining</b> his statement in the first clause of the mishna: <b>When</b> he <b>taught</b> that one may eat herbs <b>whether</b> they are <b>fresh</b> or <b>whether dried,</b> the <i>tanna</i> was referring <b>to the stem,</b> not the leaves.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: One can <b>fulfill</b> the obligation <b>with</b> the bitter herbs themselves <b>or with their stems, whether</b> they are <b>fresh</b> or <b>whether</b> they are <b>dried;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> With regard to <b>fresh</b> bitter herbs, one can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with them;</b> however, with regard to <b>dry</b> bitter herbs, one <b>cannot fulfill</b> the obligation <b>with them. And everyone agrees that</b> one can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with them</b> if they are <b>withered</b> and are no longer fresh. <b>However,</b> one may <b>neither</b> use bitter herbs that have been <b>pickled, nor over-boiled, nor boiled.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>The principle is: Anything that has the taste of bitter herbs,</b> one can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with it; but anything that does not have the taste of bitter herbs, one cannot fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with it.</b> This <i>baraita</i> indicates that neither Rabbi Meir nor the Rabbis distinguish between the leaves of these herbs and their stems. The Gemara answers: <b>Interpret</b> Rabbi Meir’s statement, that one can fulfill the obligation with both fresh and dried bitter herbs, as referring <b>to the stem</b> but not to the leaves. <b>The Sages taught:</b> One <b>cannot fulfill</b> the obligation <b>with them</b> when they are <b>withered. They said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok:</b> One can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with them</b> even when they are <b>withered.</b>
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raised a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the possibility <b>that a person</b> can <b>fulfill his obligation with bitter herbs of second-tithe</b> produce <b>in Jerusalem? In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who permits one to fulfill the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> with second-tithe produce because it can be eaten anywhere if it becomes ritually impure, <b>do not raise this dilemma. Now</b> that it has been mentioned that in the case <b>of <i>matza</i>,</b> where the obligation applies <b>by Torah</b> law, one can <b>fulfill</b> his <b>obligation</b> with second tithe in this manner, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to mention that one can use second tithe for <b>bitter herbs, which</b> nowadays applies <b>by rabbinic</b> law, as there is no Paschal lamb?
<b>When you raise the dilemma,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> who maintains that one cannot fulfill his obligation with <i>matza</i> of second-tithe produce. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to bitter herbs? The Gemara explains the two sides of this dilemma: Does Rabbi Yosei HaGelili say <b>it is</b> only <b>with regard to <i>matza</i></b> of second-tithe produce, where the obligation applies <b>by Torah</b> law, that one does <b>not fulfill</b> the mitzva; <b>however,</b> with <b>bitter herbs,</b> a mitzva that applies <b>by rabbinic</b> la<b>w,</b> one can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation with this second-tithe produce?
<b>Or perhaps, everything that the Sages instituted, they instituted</b> in a manner <b>similar</b> to the model provided <b>by Torah</b> law. If this principle is accepted, it would mean the following: Just as one may not use second-tithe produce for <i>matza</i>, so too, one may not use second tithe as bitter herbs, despite the fact that the obligation to eat them is rabbinic. <b>Rava said: It stands to reason</b> that since the verse juxtaposes <b><i>matza</i> and bitter herbs,</b> similar restrictions apply to both mitzvot. Consequently, just as according to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili one cannot use second-tithe produce for <i>matza</i>, so too, one cannot use this produce for bitter herbs.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One</b> may <b>not soak coarse bran for</b> feeding <b>chickens,</b> lest it be leavened. <b>However, one</b> may <b>pour boiling water</b> onto the bran before feeding it to the chickens, as it will not become leavened from this brief exposure to water. <b>A woman</b> may <b>not soak coarse bran to bring by hand to the bathhouse</b> for use as a cleanser; <b>however, she</b> may <b>rub</b> coarse bran <b>on her dry skin.</b> Likewise, the Sages said: <b>A person</b> may <b>not chew wheat and place it on his wound, due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the wheat <b>will be leavened</b> from the saliva and his chewing.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught: The following</b> foods <b>do not come to</b> a state of <b>leavening:</b> Foods that have already been <b>baked, or boiled, or over-boiled in hot water.</b> With regard to the statement that <b>boiled</b> food will not become leavened, the Gemara asks: Why not? <b>When it is boiled it will become leavened.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> merely <b>said</b> that if <b>it was</b> first <b>baked and</b> afterward <b>boiled,</b> it will not be leavened; however, if it was initially boiled it will become leavened.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> In the case of <b>flour into which</b> water is <b>dripping, even</b> if the water drips <b>the entire day</b> the flour <b>will not come to</b> a state of <b>leavening,</b> as the ceaseless dripping prevents fermentation. <b>Rav Pappa said: And that is</b> the case only <b>if one drop drips into the other,</b> i.e., the dripping is continuous, preventing the mixture from settling.
<b>The school of Rabbi Sheila say: <i>Vatika</i>,</b> a pastry prepared from a mixture of different liquids, is <b>permitted</b> on Passover. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b><i>vatika</i> is forbidden?</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that <i>vatika</i> is permitted, is referring to a case <b>in which it was prepared with oil and salt,</b> whereas <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> forbade <i>vatika</i> <b>prepared with water and salt,</b> as that dish will become leavened.
<b>Mar Zutra said: A person should not line</b> the edge <b>of a pot with roasted flour, lest</b> some of the flour <b>was not properly roasted and it will come to</b> a state of <b>leavening</b> in the pot. <b>Rav Yosef said: A person should not scald</b>

Daf 40a

<b>two wheat grains in boiling water</b> at the same time, <b>lest one move and rest in the slit [<i>tzirya</i>] of the other,</b> thereby <b>preventing the column [<i>dikkula</i>] of</b> boiling <b>water from entering</b> all <b>four sides</b> of the grain, <b>and</b> the grain <b>will come to</b> a state of <b>leavening.</b>
<b>And Abaye said: A person</b> may <b>not roast two stalks together, lest water leave one and be absorbed by the other, and it come to</b> be <b>leavened. Rava said to him: If so,</b> one should not <b>even</b> roast <b>one</b> stalk, <b>lest the</b> liquid <b>leave one end</b> of the stalk <b>and be absorbed by</b> its <b>other end. Rather, Rava said:</b> One need not be concerned about this possibility, as <b>it is</b> considered <b>fruit juice, and fruit juice does not leaven</b> grain.
The Gemara adds: <b>And Abaye retracted</b> his opinion with regard to <b>that</b> <i>halakha</i> of stalks, as he maintains <b>that anything that is absorbing</b> liquid will <b>not become leavened</b> unless it is fully soaked in water. <b>As Abaye said:</b> With regard to <b>this jug used for</b> drying the stalks by means of <b>roasting,</b> if it is <b>inverted it is permitted,</b> as the liquid that is discharged from one stalk will not be absorbed by the other stalks. However, if the vessel is <b>upright it is prohibited,</b> as the liquid retained in the vessel might be absorbed by the other stalks and leaven them. <b>Rava said: Even</b> if the jug is <b>upright, it is also permitted. This</b> liquid <b>is</b> considered <b>fruit juice, and fruit juice does not leaven</b> grain.
<b>The Sages taught: One</b> may <b>not soak barley</b> in water <b>on Passover</b> to make it easier to remove the chaff from the grain. <b>And if one did soak</b> barley grain and <b>it split, it is prohibited.</b> If <b>it did not split, it is permitted.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> If one sees that the grain is expanding, <b>he</b> should <b>soak it in vinegar, and</b> the <b>vinegar will cause</b> the grain <b>to contract,</b> thereby preventing leavening. However, <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> in not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Mar Ukva said:</b> When the Sages were referring to a case where the barley grain split, the prohibition does <b>not</b> apply only if <b>it actually split</b> and a crack is visible. <b>Rather,</b> this is referring even to a case where <b>if</b> the barley grains <b>were placed on a barrel</b> of wine <b>they</b> would <b>split by themselves,</b> due to the effect of the wine. <b>And</b> by contrast, <b>Shmuel said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> applies only if <b>it actually split.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Shmuel took action</b> in accordance with his ruling, when he was <b>in the village of bar Ḥashu’s house.</b> He prohibited only barley grains that had <b>actually split,</b> but permitted those that were about to split.
<b>Rabba said: A pious person will not soak</b> wheat at all during Passover. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> discuss <b>particularly a pious person?</b> This <i>halakha</i> should apply to <b>everyone as well, as it was</b> expressly <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>not soak barley on Passover.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>this is</b> what Rabba <b>is saying: A pious person</b> will <b>not even soak wheat, which is firmer</b> than barley and less likely to split, due to the concern that it might become leavened.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to</b> Rabba: <b>Anyone who listens to Abba,</b> Rabba’s first name, <b>will eat moldy bread</b> during Passover, as flour cannot be properly prepared without soaking, and therefore <i>matza</i> should not be prepared from this flour. <b>As in Rav Huna’s house they would soak</b> the grain, <b>and in Rava bar Avin’s house they would</b> likewise <b>soak</b> their grain. <b>But Rava said:</b> Soaking grain should not be avoided merely for reasons of piety; rather, it is absolutely <b>prohibited to soak</b> grain.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>not soak barley on Passover,</b> indicates that <b>it is barley that</b> one may <b>not</b> soak; however, it is <b>permitted</b> to soak <b>wheat,</b> how will Rava explain this <i>baraita</i>? The Gemara explains: The <i>baraita</i> is <b>speaking</b> employing the didactic style of: <b>Needless to say.</b> It should be understood as follows: <b>Needless to say, wheat</b> may not be soaked, <b>since</b> wheat grains <b>have a slit through which water will enter,</b> and the wheat will therefore expand quickly when left to soak. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>barley, which is smooth</b> and no water will enter the grain, one might <b>say</b> that this <b>seems well,</b> i.e., it is permitted, to soak barley. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that it is prohibited to soak even barley.
<b>Rava</b> reconsidered and <b>then said:</b> This is not the case. Rather, <b>it is permitted to soak</b> grain, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with</b> a <i>matza</i> <b>loaf</b> prepared from <b>refined</b> flour <b>and with</b> <i>matza</i> baked from <b>coarse</b> flour. <b>And it is impossible</b> to produce <b>refined</b> <i>matza</i> <b>without soaking</b> the grain, as this is the only way to remove the chaff completely from the grain.
<b>Rav Pappa raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>flour and refined flour</b> that belong <b>to gentiles, in villages</b> they <b>are ritually pure, and in cities</b> they <b>are ritually impure.</b> It is assumed that grain in cities is soaked before it is ground into flour. Once water comes in contact with this grain, it becomes susceptible to ritual impurity, and it subsequently becomes impure when touched by gentiles.
As for flour <b>in villages, what is the reason</b> that it is ritually pure? Is it <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that they do not soak</b> the flour, and therefore it does not become liable to ritual impurity? <b>And</b> yet their flour <b>is</b> nonetheless <b>called refined flour.</b> It can be inferred from this that it is possible to prepare refined flour without soaking the grain.
Rava answered: You should <b>interpret</b> the distinction of the <i>baraita</i> as referring only <b>to</b> ordinary <b>flour,</b> not refined flour, which is invariably susceptible to ritual impurity due to the soaking. <b>After</b> Rava <b>left,</b> Rav Pappa <b>said: What is the reason</b> that <b>he did not say</b> a proof <b>from this</b> statement <b>that Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>wheat</b> that will be used <b>for meal-offerings, one</b> may <b>not soak it,</b> and yet it <b>is</b> nonetheless <b>called refined flour?</b> The Torah insists that the flour used for meal-offerings be prepared from refined flour.
<b>Rava</b> reconsidered and <b>then said:</b> It is not only permitted to soak the grains; it is actually <b>a mitzva to soak</b> them, <b>as it is stated: “And you shall guard the <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Exodus 12:17). The Gemara explains this statement: <b>If</b> it is <b>not</b> the case <b>that</b> grain <b>requires soaking, for what</b> purpose is <b>guarding</b> necessary? <b>If</b> you claim that this verse is referring to <b>guarding when kneading,</b> that cannot be the case, as <b>guarding</b> grain <b>while kneading is not</b> considered <b>guarding.</b> If one failed to protect the wheat from becoming leavened up to that point, it is of no use to be careful while kneading it. Consequently, this mitzva to guard the dough cannot be referring to the kneading stage.
<b>As Rav Huna said:</b> In the case of <b>dough</b> prepared <b>by gentiles,</b> if one knows that it has not become leavened, <b>a person</b> may <b>fill his stomach with them</b> on Passover night, <b>provided that he eats an olive-bulk of <i>matza</i> in the end,</b> to fulfill the obligation to eat <i>matza</i>. The Gemara infers from this statement: With regard to the <i>matza</i> that he eats <b>in the end, yes,</b> he fulfills his obligation with this <i>matza</i>. But with regard to the <i>matza</i> he ate <b>in the beginning, no,</b> he does not fulfill the mitzva with dough prepared by gentiles.
<b>What is the reason</b> that one cannot fulfill his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> with dough prepared by gentiles? It is <b>because</b> he <b>did not perform</b> his duty to <b>guard</b> this dough. <b>But one</b> can <b>perform</b> his duty to <b>guard it from</b> the time of <b>baking and onward. Rather, isn’t it</b> correct to <b>conclude from</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>that</b> the grain <b>must</b> be guarded <b>from the beginning,</b> i.e., from the time it is soaked, which proves that soaking the grain is part of the process of preparing <i>matza</i>?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>And from where</b> do we know that this conclusion is correct? <b>Perhaps it is different there, as at the time when guarding is required,</b> i.e., when water was added to the flour, <b>he did not perform</b> his duty to <b>guard it</b> properly. <b>However,</b> in a case <b>where at the time when guarding is required,</b> when water is added the flour, <b>he</b> properly <b>performed</b> his duty to <b>guard it, so too,</b> it is possible that <b>guarding</b> flour at the time <b>of kneading is</b> considered proper <b>guarding.</b> Therefore, this question cannot be resolved based on the case of dough prepared by gentiles.
<b>And although</b> this proof was rejected, <b>Rava did not retract</b> his statement that guarding grain must begin before kneading. <b>For he</b> would <b>say to those who cut</b> and tied <b>the stalks [<i>kifei</i>]</b> of grain in the field: <b>When you cut</b> the grain, <b>cut it for the purpose of the mitzva. Apparently,</b> Rava <b>maintains</b> that <b>it is necessary to guard</b> the grain <b>from the outset,</b> i.e., <b>from the beginning</b> of its preparation <b>until its end.</b>
The Gemara relates with regard to <b>Mar, son of Ravina,</b>

Daf 40b

that <b>his mother</b> would <b>bring him</b> wheat <b>in a trough.</b> In other words, she would guard the wheat grains from when they were harvested by placing them in vessels and guarding them until Passover.
The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain boat</b> carrying <b>wheat, which capsized</b> before Passover <b>in</b> the <b>Ḥishta</b> River. <b>Rava permitted</b> its owners <b>to sell</b> the recovered grain <b>to gentiles</b> before Passover.
<b>Rabba bar Levai raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a garment in which diverse kinds,</b> a prohibited mixture of wool and linen, <b>has been lost,</b> i.e., a wool garment into which a linen thread was sewn or vice versa, <b>one</b> may <b>not sell it to a gentile; and one</b> may <b>not</b> even <b>fashion it</b> into <b>a saddlecloth for a donkey.</b> It is prohibited to do so lest one remove a piece of this garment and sew it onto his own clothing. <b>However, one</b> may <b>fashion it</b> into <b>a shroud for a dead body,</b> as there is no concern that he will remove it from the dead.
The Gemara clarifies this issue: <b>What is the reason</b> that one may <b>not</b> sell it <b>to a gentile?</b> Is it <b>not due to</b> the concern <b>that</b> the gentile <b>will resell it to a Jew?</b> Since the mixture of wool and linen is not visible, it is possible for a Jew to use this cloth unawares. The same concern applies to grain: It is not apparent that the grain that capsized in the river is prohibited. It should therefore be prohibited to sell this wheat to gentiles, lest they resell it to Jews.
<b>Rava</b> reconsidered and <b>then said: He should sell</b> this wheat <b>one <i>kav</i> at a time,</b> i.e., in small measures, each <b>to</b> a different <b>Jew,</b> but not to any one Jew in large quantities, <b>so that</b> all of this wheat <b>will be used before Passover.</b> By selling it in this manner, all the grain will be used quickly and no one will unwittingly eat these leavened grains on Passover.
<b>The Sages taught: One</b> may <b>not stir</b> flour into <b>a pot</b> of food <b>on Passover</b> to absorb the foam that has accumulated during the cooking process. <b>And one who wishes to stir</b> flour should <b>add the flour and afterward add vinegar,</b> which will prevent the flour from becoming leavened. <b>And some say:</b> One may <b>even add vinegar and afterward add the flour,</b> as vinegar prevents flour from becoming leavened even after the flour is diluted in water.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> whose opinion is introduced by the phrase <b>some say?</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a stew pot or a pot</b> of food <b>that one removed</b> from the fire when it was <b>seething,</b> one may <b>not add spices to them on Shabbat. However, one</b> may <b>add</b> spices <b>to a dish or to</b> the large <b>plate</b> into which the food is poured from the pot. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One</b> may <b>add</b> spices <b>to any</b> food that has been removed from the fire, <b>except to</b> a dish <b>that contains vinegar or brine,</b> as this food is considered as though it were still seething, due to the pungency of the vinegar or brine. Since Rabbi Yehuda maintains that vinegar has the same effect as boiling, he would agree that vinegar, like boiling water, prevents flour from becoming leavened.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let us establish</b> the opinion of: Some say, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei. As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Rabbi Yosei says,</b> with regard to wheat grains that were soaked in water: <b>One</b> should <b>soak them in vinegar, and</b> this <b>vinegar will cause</b> the wheat <b>to contract</b> and prevent it from becoming leavened.
The Gemara answers: <b>When we learn</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> this <b>applies</b> only to a situation <b>where</b> the vinegar is <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, in which case its pungency prevents the wheat from becoming leavened. <b>However,</b> if the vinegar is added <b>by means of a mixture, no,</b> Rabbi Yosei’s statement does not apply to a case of this kind.
<b>Ulla said:</b> In <b>both</b> of <b>these</b> cases, whether the vinegar is added first or afterward, its use is <b>prohibited,</b> as one must avoid scenarios that might lead to a prohibition, <b>as per</b> the well-known adage: <b>Go around, go around,</b> and <b>do not approach the vineyard, they say to the nazirite.</b> Since a nazirite is prohibited from drinking wine and eating grapes, it is preferable for him to avoid a vineyard entirely. A similar principle applies to other prohibitions.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Pappi permitted the cooks [<i>burdikei</i>] of the household of the Exilarch to mash roasted grains into a pot</b> of food, to dissolve the accumulated foam. <b>Rava said: Is there</b> anyone <b>who permits this matter in a place where servants are found?</b> Servants are unlikely to be careful with regard to these prohibitions. They will use raw flour for this purpose, which will lead to a violation of the prohibition against leavened bread on Passover. <b>Some say</b> that <b>Rava himself</b> would <b>add roasted grains into</b> his own <b>pot.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One</b> may <b>not add flour to <i>ḥaroset</i>,</b> a seasoned, pungent food, <b>or to mustard,</b> to dull the sharp taste. In both cases, the pungency of these foods might accelerate the leavening of the flour. <b>And if one added</b> flour to either of these, the mixture may <b>be eaten immediately</b> before it is leavened; <b>and Rabbi Meir prohibits</b> this, lest the food be leavened immediately.
The mishna continues: <b>One</b> may <b>not boil the Paschal</b> lamb <b>in</b> ordinary <b>liquids or in fruit juices,</b> as the Torah explicitly states that it must be roasted. <b>However,</b> one may <b>baste</b> it while it is roasting <b>and dip it into</b> liquid while eating it.
The <i>tanna</i> further states: <b>Water that has been used by a baker</b> for cooling his hands or washing dishes should <b>be poured out, because</b> this water <b>leavens</b> the dough, as the water probably contains a small quantity of flour and dough.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis concerns a case where one adds flour <b>to mustard,</b> which is extremely pungent and will not leaven the flour immediately. <b>But</b> in a case where flour is added <b>to</b> the less pungent <b><i>ḥaroset</i>,</b> which will leaven the flour quickly, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the mixture must <b>be burned immediately.</b>
<b>And that</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>not add flour to <i>ḥaroset</i>, and if one did add</b> flour it should <b>be burned immediately.</b> With regard to flour that was added <b>to mustard, Rabbi Meir says:</b> It should <b>be burned immediately, and the Rabbis say:</b> It should <b>be eaten immediately,</b> before it is leavened. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda, said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> concerning this issue. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda:</b>

Daf 41a

Did <b>the Master say</b> this statement <b>with regard to <i>ḥaroset</i>, or did the Master say</b> it <b>with regard to mustard? He said to him: What is</b> the <b>practical difference</b> whether he was referring to <i>ḥaroset</i> or mustard? Both of these are mentioned together, and the same <i>halakha</i> applies to both.
He said to him: There is a difference with regard <b>to that</b> which was stated by <b>Rav Kahana, as Rav Kahana said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis concerns a case in which flour was added <b>to mustard. However,</b> if flour was added <b>to <i>ḥaroset</i>, everyone agrees</b> that <b>it</b> must <b>be burned immediately.</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak was asking Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda, whether he disagrees with Rav Kahana and maintains that the Rabbis dispute the <i>halakha</i> in the case of <i>ḥaroset</i> as well.
<b>He said to him: I did not hear</b> about this statement; <b>that is to say, I do not hold</b> in accordance with it. I do not distinguish between these two cases, as in my opinion the Rabbis permit one to eat even this <i>ḥaroset</i>.
<b>Rav Ashi said: It is reasonable</b> to rule <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Kahana, from</b> the fact <b>that Shmuel said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who maintains that vinegar will prevent grain from becoming leavened. <b>What, isn’t it</b> correct to infer from here that vinegar added to flour <b>does not shrink</b> the grain and will <b>even leaven</b> it? According to this explanation, food that contains vinegar, e.g., <i>ḥaroset</i>, is likely to be leavened immediately, as claimed by Rav Kahana.
The Gemara rejects this interpretation: <b>No,</b> this is no proof, as <b>perhaps</b> Shmuel meant that, according to the opinion of the Rabbis, vinegar will <b>neither cause</b> the wheat <b>to shrink nor leaven</b> it. Consequently, this statement cannot serve as a proof of the opinion of the Rabbis with regard to <i>ḥaroset</i>.
The mishna taught that <b>one</b> may <b>not boil</b> the Paschal lamb in liquid. To explain this issue, the Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> that interprets the verse: “You shall not eat it partially roasted, nor boiled in any way in water, but roasted with fire; its head with its legs, and with the innards in it” (Exodus 12:9). <b>The Sages taught: “In water”; I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than the prohibition against boiling the Paschal lamb <b>in water. From where</b> do I know that it is likewise prohibited to boil it in <b>other liquids?</b>
<b>You said</b> that this can be derived by means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: And just as water, which does not temper the taste</b> of the food boiled in it, is <b>prohibited</b> for boiling the Paschal lamb, with regard to <b>other liquids, which do temper the taste</b> of the food boiled in them, is it <b>not all the more so</b> that it is prohibited to boil the Paschal lamb in them?
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi provides a different derivation and <b>says:</b> From the phrase <b>“In water,” I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than the prohibition against boiling the Paschal lamb <b>in water. From where</b> do I learn that it is likewise prohibited to boil it in <b>other liquids? The verse states: “Nor boiled in any way,”</b> which means: <b>In any case,</b> i.e., boiling the Paschal lamb in any type of liquid is prohibited.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> these two derivations? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to meat <b>that is roasted in a pot</b> without the addition of any liquid, but is cooked in its own juices. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, it is prohibited to prepare the Paschal lamb in this manner, as this is considered boiling, whereas the Rabbis maintain that an action is classified as boiling only if one adds liquid to the meat.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> with regard to <b>that</b> phrase, <b>“boiled in any way,” what do they do with it?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>required for that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one boiled</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and afterward roasted it, or roasted it and afterward boiled it, he is liable</b> to receive lashes for boiling the Paschal lamb.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> if one <b>boiled</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and afterward roasted it, he is liable, as he boiled it</b> first and is punished for this act. <b>However,</b> if <b>he roasted it and afterward boiled it,</b> and <b>it is</b> a food that has been <b>roasted by fire, why</b> is he liable?
<b>Rav Kahana said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? It is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who maintains that boiling after roasting nullifies the previous act of roasting. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation to eat <i>matza</i> <b>with a wafer that has been soaked</b> in water <b>or with a boiled</b> wafer <b>that has not</b> yet <b>dissolved;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says: One</b> can <b>fulfill</b> his obligation <b>with a wafer that has been soaked</b> in a cooked dish <b>but not with a boiled</b> wafer, <b>even if it has not dissolved.</b> Evidently, Rabbi Yosei maintains that food that was initially baked and subsequently boiled is no longer categorized as baked, and the same presumably applies to meat that was roasted and then boiled.
<b>Ulla said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to boiled <i>matza</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> there is no difficulty, as the cases of <i>matza</i> and the Paschal lamb are dissimilar in this regard. <b>Here,</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb, <b>it is different, as the verse states: “Nor boiled in any way,”</b> which indicates that it is prohibited to boil it <b>in any case.</b> No restriction of this kind is stated with regard to <i>matza</i>.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> I <b>might</b> have thought <b>that</b> if <b>one roasted</b> the Paschal lamb <b>fully, he</b> should <b>be liable.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall not eat it partially roasted, nor boiled in any way in water”</b> (Exodus 12:9). This verse teaches that <b>I,</b> God, <b>said to you</b> that the Paschal lamb is prohibited if it is <b>partially roasted or boiled in any way, but not</b> if <b>it is fully roasted.</b> One who roasts the Paschal lamb fully has not violated a prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case that render it necessary for a verse to teach that roasting the Paschal lamb fully is not a violation of a prohibition? <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> This is referring to a situation <b>where one burned it.</b> The verse indicates that even one who entirely burns the Paschal lamb does not violate this prohibition.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one who ate an olive-bulk</b> portion of the Paschal sacrifice <b>raw</b> should <b>be liable</b> for violating a prohibition. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall not eat it partially roasted [<i>na</i>], nor boiled in any way in water.”</b> This verse <b>teaches</b> that <b>I,</b> God, <b>said to you</b> that it is prohibited to eat the Paschal lamb <b>partially roasted or boiled, but</b> there is <b>no</b> prohibition against eating <b>it raw.</b>
I <b>might</b> have thought <b>that it is permitted</b> to eat it raw <i>ab initio</i>. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “But roasted with fire”</b> (Exodus 12:9). This teaches that the mitzva is to roast the Paschal lamb with fire, <i>ab initio</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of cooking that are defined as <b><i>na</i>,</b> partially roasted? <b>Rav said: As the Persians say: <i>Avarnim</i>,</b> half roasted.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: One who cooks</b> food <b>in the hot springs of Tiberias on Shabbat is exempt.</b> One violates the Shabbat prohibition of cooking only if he uses a fire. In the case of <b>a Paschal</b> lamb <b>that was cooked,</b> i.e., boiled, <b>in the hot springs of Tiberias,</b> one is <b>liable</b> for boiling the offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different with regard to Shabbat, that</b> one is <b>not</b> punished for cooking in this manner? The reason is <b>that</b> a fire, or <b>a fire derivative, is required</b> for an act to be defined as cooking on Shabbat, <b>but there is no</b> fire here, as the hot springs are not generated by fire. If so, <b>with regard to</b> the <b>Paschal</b> lamb <b>as well, it is not a fire derivative,</b> and it should not be considered boiling with regard to this prohibition either.
<b>Rava said: What is</b> the meaning of the word <b>liable that</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>taught?</b> It means <b>that</b> in doing so <b>one violated</b> the positive mitzva, <b>due to</b> that which is written: <b>“Roasted with fire.”</b> In other words, one who boils the Paschal lamb in the hot springs of Tiberias did not in fact violate the prohibition of boiling the Paschal lamb, but he has also not fulfilled the positive mitzva to roast the offering.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Natan, teaches this</b> interpretation <b>of Rav Ḥisda’s</b> statement <b>explicitly,</b> i.e., that <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> himself <b>said: One who cooks in the hot springs of Tiberias on Shabbat is exempt, and</b> with regard to <b>a Paschal</b> lamb <b>that was cooked in the hot springs of Tiberias,</b> one <b>is liable</b> to receive punishment for this act. In doing so, <b>he violated</b> a positive mitzva, <b>due to</b> that which is written: <b>“Roasted with fire.”</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> One who <b>ate</b> the Paschal lamb <b>partially roasted,</b>

Daf 41b

he <b>receives two</b> sets of <b>lashes,</b> for violating the prohibitions: “You shall not eat it partially roasted” (Exodus 12:9) and: “You shall only eat it…roasted with fire” (Exodus 12:9). One who ate it <b>boiled receives two</b> sets of <b>lashes,</b> for the prohibitions: “Nor shall it be boiled in any way in water” (Exodus 12:9), and “You shall only eat it…roasted with fire.” One who ate the Paschal lamb after it had been <b>partially roasted and</b> then <b>boiled receives three</b> sets of <b>lashes,</b> for eating the Paschal lamb partially roasted, for eating it boiled, and for failing to eat it roasted.
<b>Abaye said: One does not receive lashes for a prohibition stated in general terms.</b> The prohibition inferred from the verse "You shall only eat it...roasted in fire" includes many types of cooking, and one is not punished with lashes for violating this mitzva, as it is a general prohibition that includes meat cooked in several different ways.
<b>Some say</b> that Abaye said: <b>It is two</b> sets of <b>lashes that he does not receive,</b> as the mitzva that the Paschal lamb be roasted with fire does not add to the specific prohibitions against eating it partially roasted or cooked. However, <b>at any rate one set of lashes he does receive.</b> Therefore, one who prepared a Paschal lamb without properly cooking it but without roasting it is punished with lashes for failing to roast it “with fire.”
<b>Some say</b> that <b>one does not receive even one</b> set of <b>lashes</b> for violating this prohibition, <b>as the prohibition</b> he transgressed <b>is not specific</b> to one matter, <b>like the prohibition against muzzling.</b> The principle that one is liable to receive lashes for violating a prohibition is derived from the juxtaposition of the mitzva: “You shall not muzzle an ox while it treads out the corn” (Deuteronomy 25:4) with the verses that deal with lashes. It is inferred from this juxtaposition that one is not liable to receive lashes for violating prohibitions that are dissimilar to that of muzzling, e.g., a prohibition that is not specific to one matter.
The Gemara cites a parallel dispute with regard to a different <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rava said:</b> If a nazirite <b>ate</b> a grape <b>skin he receives two</b> sets of <b>lashes,</b> as the verse states: “All the days that he is a nazirite he shall eat nothing that is made of the grapevine; from pressed grapes to a grape pit he shall not eat” (Numbers 6:4). He receives two sets of lashes, one for eating food that grew on a grapevine and one for consuming the skin of a grape. Likewise, if he ate a grape <b>pit he receives two</b> sets of <b>lashes,</b> one for eating a grape pit and the other for eating a grape product. If he ate a grape <b>skin and</b> a grape <b>pit he receives three</b> sets of <b>lashes,</b> one for eating the grape skin, one for eating the grape pit, and the third for eating a grape product.
<b>Abaye said:</b> As with regard to the Paschal lamb, <b>one does not receive lashes for a prohibition stated in general terms. Some say</b> that according to Abaye, <b>it is two</b> sets of <b>lashes that he does not receive;</b> however, <b>at any rate one set of lashes he does receive.</b> And <b>some say: One does not receive even one</b> set of <b>lashes for</b> transgressing this prohibition, <b>as the prohibition</b> he transgressed <b>is not specific</b> to one matter, <b>like the prohibition against muzzling.</b>
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>one ate a partially roasted olive-bulk</b> of the Paschal lamb <b>while it was still day</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>he is exempt.</b> If he ate <b>a partially roasted olive-bulk after dark, he is liable</b> to receive lashes. If <b>he ate a roasted olive-bulk</b> of the Paschal lamb <b>while it was still day</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>he has not disqualified himself from</b> his <b>group.</b> Once he has started eating the offering, he may not leave the group he joined that arranged to partake together of a single Paschal lamb. Nevertheless, this case is different, as he began eating before the obligation to eat the Paschal lamb went into effect, and therefore he has not disqualified himself from his group by eating the Paschal lamb of another group. However, if he ate <b>a roasted olive-bulk after dark,</b> when he is obligated to eat the Paschal lamb, <b>he disqualifies himself from the group</b> he had joined.
<b>It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: I <b>might</b> have thought that one who <b>eats a partially roasted olive-bulk</b> of the Paschal lamb <b>while it was still day is liable</b> to receive lashes. <b>And this</b> is <b>a logical derivation</b> by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>If at</b> the <b>time when one is included in</b> the mitzva <b>to arise</b> and <b>eat</b> the <b>roasted</b> Paschal lamb, <b>he is</b> also <b>included in</b> the prohibition <b>not to eat</b> it <b>partially roasted,</b> then <b>at a time when one is not included in</b> the mitzva <b>to arise</b> and <b>eat</b> the <b>roasted</b> Paschal lamb, <b>isn’t it right that he</b> should be <b>included in</b> the prohibition <b>not to eat</b> it <b>partially roasted?</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps this is <b>not</b> the case, as the opposite can be stated: <b>At</b> the <b>time when one is not included in</b> the mitzva <b>to arise</b> and <b>eat</b> the <b>roasted</b> Paschal lamb, <b>he is included in</b> the prohibition <b>not to eat</b> it <b>partially roasted.</b> However, <b>at a time when one is included in</b> the mitzva <b>to arise</b> and <b>eat</b> the <b>roasted</b> Paschal lamb, <b>he is not included in</b> the prohibition <b>not to eat</b> it <b>partially roasted,</b> as the prohibition applies only before one is permitted to eat the Paschal lamb.
The Gemara adds: <b>And do not be confounded</b> by this suggestion, <b>as</b> the prohibition against eating from the Paschal lamb is <b>relaxed</b> because of special circumstances <b>with regard to roasted</b> meat. Before nightfall of the fifteenth of Nisan it is prohibited to eat the Paschal lamb regardless of how it was prepared, but once it grows dark it is permitted to eat it roasted. Perhaps the relaxation of this prohibition indicates that one who eats a partially roasted Paschal lamb after nightfall also does not violate a transgression.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall not eat it partially roasted, nor boiled in any way [<i>bashel mevushal</i>] in water, but roasted with fire”</b> (Exodus 12:9). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “Roasted with fire,”</b> since the previous verse already said: “On this night you shall eat the meat roasted with fire” (Exodus 12:8), <b>what</b> then is the meaning when <b>the</b> second <b>verse states: “Roasted with fire”?</b> This verse comes <b>to tell you</b> that <b>at</b> the <b>time when one is included in</b> the mitzva <b>to arise</b> and <b>eat</b> the <b>roasted</b> Paschal lamb, <b>he is</b> also <b>included in</b> the prohibition <b>not to eat</b> it <b>partially roasted,</b> whereas <b>at a time when one is not included in</b> the mitzva <b>to arise</b> and <b>eat</b> the <b>roasted</b> Paschal lamb, <b>he is not included in</b> the prohibition <b>not to eat</b> it <b>partially roasted</b> either.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I</b> could have simply <b>read “boiled [<i>bashel</i>],”</b> as this word suffices to teach that eating a boiled Paschal lamb is prohibited after dark. <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> the seemingly superfluous word <b><i>mevushal</i>,</b> which also means boiled? These two words together are translated as “boiled in any way.” <b>As</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>I have only</b> derived that this prohibition applies <b>when it was boiled after dark,</b> when the obligation to eat the Paschal lamb is in effect. <b>From where</b> do I derive that one is liable <b>if he boils it while it was still day? The verse states</b> the inclusive phrase <b><i>bashel mevushal</i>,</b> which teaches that this prohibition applies <b>in any case.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi himself <b>derived</b> from the expression <b>“<i>bashel mevushal</i>”</b> the prohibition <b>against roasting</b> the meat of the Paschal lamb <b>in a pot,</b> i.e., cooking the meat in a pot without the addition of liquids, <b>and</b> the prohibition against boiling it <b>with other liquids.</b> How can he derive another <i>halakha</i> from this same phrase?
The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if this verse is referring only to the matter of cooking meat with other liquids or without any liquids, <b>let the verse say either “<i>bashel bashel</i>” or “<i>mevushal mevushal</i>,”</b> and one <i>halakha</i> would be derived from the extraneous word. <b>What</b> is derived from the varied wording <b>“<i>bashel mevushal</i>”? Learn from this</b> verse <b>two</b> <i>halakhot</i>, one with regard to the manner of the cooking of the Paschal lamb, and the other concerning the time of its cooking.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If one <b>ate</b> from <b>a roasted</b> Paschal lamb <b>when it was still day, he is liable</b> to receive lashes, and likewise if one ate <b>after dark an olive-bulk that was partially roasted, he is liable</b> to receive lashes.
This <i>baraita</i> <b>taught</b> that the case of <b>roasted</b> meat is <b>similar to</b> the case of <b>partially roasted</b> meat: <b>Just as</b> one who consumes <b>partially roasted</b> meat is in violation <b>of a prohibition, so too,</b> one who consumes this <b>roasted</b> meat while it is still day is in violation <b>of a prohibition.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>partially roasted</b> meat, <b>it is written: “You shall not eat it partially roasted”</b> (Exodus 12:9). <b>However,</b> with regard to meat that has been <b>roasted, from where do we</b> derive that one who eats it before the proper time has committed a transgression?
The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written: “And they shall eat the meat on that night,</b> roasted with fire, and <i>matzot</i>; with bitter herbs they shall eat it” (Exodus 12:8). The Gemara derives from this verse: <b>At night, yes,</b> the Paschal lamb may be eaten; however, <b>by day, no,</b> it may not be eaten in any manner.
The Gemara asks: <b>This is a prohibition that comes by inference from a positive mitzva,</b> i.e., it is not stated in the Torah in the form of a prohibition. There is a principle that <b>every prohibition that comes by inference from a positive mitzva</b> is classified as <b>a positive mitzva.</b> One who transgresses a mitzva of this kind is considered to have transgressed a positive mitzva, not a prohibition.
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>?

Daf 42a

<b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “Either <b>a bull or a lamb that has anything too long or too short, you may offer it as a free-will offering</b> [to the Temple treasury]; but for a vow [as a sacrifice] it shall not be accepted” (Leviticus 22:23). From here we learn that <b>it,</b> i.e., a blemished animal, <b>you</b> may <b>consecrate for maintaining the Temple, but you</b> may <b>not consecrate unblemished</b> animals <b>for maintaining the Temple.</b> In other words, any animal fit to be sacrificed as an offering may not be consecrated for maintaining the Temple but only as an offering. <b>From here</b> the Sages <b>stated: Whoever consecrates unblemished</b> animals <b>for maintaining the Temple transgresses a positive mitzva.</b>
From here <b>I have only</b> derived that he violates <b>a positive mitzva; from where do I</b> derive that he also transgresses <b>a prohibition? The verse states</b> at the beginning of that passage: <b>“And the Lord spoke to Moses saying”</b> (Leviticus 22:17). This introductory statement <b>teaches with regard to the entire portion that a prohibition applies to it.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> adds that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to Bar Kappara: From where may it be inferred</b> that this is the case? How does Rabbi Yehuda derive his statement that a prohibition applies to the entire portion from the phrase “And the Lord spoke to Moses saying”?
<b>He said to him: As it is written: “Saying [<i>leimor</i>].”</b> Rabbi Yehuda expounds this term as though it read: Say no [<i>lo emor</i>]. In other words, the word <b>no,</b> an expression of prohibition, <b>is stated with regard to</b> the subsequent <b>matters,</b> which means that these mitzvot are categorized as prohibitions.
In <b>the school</b> of <b>Rav they say</b> a slightly different explanation: The term: Saying, can be expounded as if it were written <b><i>lav emor</i>,</b> meaning: <b>Say a prohibition.</b> In other words, the verse indicates that Moses was instructed to inform the Jewish people of a prohibition. This teaches that any mitzva introduced by the word <i>leimor</i> should be treated as a prohibition. Since the <i>halakhot</i> of the Paschal lamb are preceded by the phrase: “And the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron in the Land of Egypt saying” (Exodus 12:1), it can be inferred that the subsequent mitzvot are also prohibitions.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Water that has been used by a baker</b> for cooling his hands or washing dishes must be poured out, as it contains a small, undefined quantity of leavened dough. <b>It was taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>pour out</b> this water <b>in a place with an incline, and he</b> may <b>not pour</b> it <b>out in a</b> level <b>place where</b> the water <b>collects. And it was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may even <b>pour out</b> this water <b>in a</b> level <b>place where</b> the water <b>collects.</b>
The Gemara resolves this contradiction: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that it is prohibited to pour out this water in a level place, is referring <b>to a large</b> amount of water <b>that will collect</b> in one place. Since there is a large amount of water, the flour in the water will not be absorbed into the ground but will leaven. Conversely, <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that it is permitted to pour out the water in a level place, is referring to a situation <b>where</b> there was <b>not a large amount</b> of water, so that it <b>will not collect.</b> Instead, this water will be absorbed into the ground before the dough leavens.
<b>Rav Yehuda said: A woman</b> may <b>knead</b> <i>matza</i> dough <b>only with water that rested,</b> i.e., water that was left indoors overnight to cool. If water is added to dough immediately after it was drawn, when it is still lukewarm, the dough will leaven at a faster rate.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Mattana taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in Paphunya. On the next day,</b> the eve of Passover, <b>everyone brought their jugs to him and said to him: Give us water.</b> They misunderstood his expression <i>mayim shelanu</i>, water that rested, as the near homonym <i>mayim shelanu</i>, our water, i.e., water that belongs to the Sage, and they therefore came to take water from his house. <b>He said to them: I say</b> and meant: <b>Water that rested [<i>devitu</i>]</b> in the house overnight.
<b>Rava taught: A woman</b> may <b>not knead</b> dough for <i>matza</i> <b>in the sun, nor with</b> water that has been <b>heated by the sun, nor with water collected [<i>hagerufin</i>] in an urn heated</b> by coals <b>[<i>mulyar</i>] And</b> in addition, <b>she</b> may <b>not remove her hand from the oven,</b> i.e., interrupt her baking, <b>until she finishes</b> forming <b>all the loaves</b> from the dough, so that it should not become leavened in the interim. <b>And</b> she <b>requires two vessels, one in which she mixes</b> the water into the dough <b>and one in which she cools her hands</b> so that the heat from her hands does not cause the dough to leaven.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If <b>she transgressed and kneaded</b> the dough with warm water, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Mar Zutra said: It is permitted</b> after the fact. <b>Rav Ashi said: It is forbidden.</b>
<b>Mar Zutra said: From where do I say</b> my opinion on this issue? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>not soak barley on Passover, and if one soaked</b> barley and it <b>split,</b> the barley <b>is forbidden.</b> If it did <b>not split,</b> the barley <b>is permitted.</b> This case indicates that even if one violates the principles established by the Sages with regard to adding water to flour on Passover, the product is forbidden only after the fact if it actually leavened.
<b>And Rav Ashi said</b> in response: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>all of them are woven in the same</b> act of <b>weaving?</b> In other words, is the <i>halakha</i> identical in all cases? <b>Where it was stated</b> that the Sages did not punish the violator by rendering his food prohibited, <b>it was stated; and where it was not stated</b> that they refrained from punishing the violator, <b>it was not stated.</b> It is therefore possible that the Sages rendered dough kneaded with warm water forbidden, to punish the woman who prepared it in this manner.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> And for possessing <b>these one transgresses [<i>overin</i>]</b> the prohibitions of: It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, <b>on Passover,</b> although not all of them are considered food: <b>Babylonian <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a dip with a sharp flavor that contains flour; <b>Median beer; Edomite vinegar; Egyptian <i>zitom</i>,</b> a type of beer; <b>dyers’ broth [<i>zoman</i>]; bakers’ well-worked dough; and <i>kolan of soferim</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The same prohibition <b>also</b> applies to <b>women’s adornments,</b> i.e., cosmetics, that contain leaven.
<b>This is the principle:</b> If one possesses <b>any</b> substance <b>that is</b> derived <b>from a type of grain</b> that became leavened, although it is not actually bread, <b>one transgresses</b> the prohibitions of: It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, <b>on Passover. These</b> substances are included <b>in the warning,</b> i.e., the biblical prohibition of possessing leaven, <b>but there is no element of <i>karet</i></b> if one eats them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Since the mishna mentions <i>kutaḥ</i>, the Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> where <i>kutaḥ</i> is discussed. <b>The Sages taught</b> that <b>three things were said with regard to <i>kutaḥ</i>: It blocks the heart, it blinds the eyes, and it weakens the body.</b>
The Gemara explains each statement: <b>It blocks the heart due to</b> the <b>whey.</b> Whey was added to <i>kutaḥ</i> and was considered to be an inferior type of food. <b>It blinds the eyes due to the salt</b> in it, which can be dangerous if it enters the eyes. <b>And it weakens the body due to the mold in the bread,</b> as one of the ingredients of <i>kutaḥ</i> was crumbs from dough that had become leavened to the point that they were nearly spoiled.
After mentioning this <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara continues to discuss the nutritional effects of other foods. <b>The Sages taught: Three things increase</b> one’s <b>waste, lower</b> one’s <b>stature, and take one five-hundredth of a person’s vision</b> if he eats them regularly. And <b>they are: Bread</b> from <b>coarse</b> flour, <b>new beer, and raw vegetables.</b>
Similarly, <b>the Sages taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>Three things decrease</b> one’s <b>waste, straighten</b> one’s <b>stature, and improve</b> one’s <b>vision,</b> and <b>they are: Bread</b> from <b>fine</b> flour, <b>fatty meat, and aged wine.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Fine bread</b>

Daf 42b

is made <b>from refined flour; fatty meat</b> refers to meat <b>from a goat that has not</b> yet <b>given birth; and aged wine</b> refers to wine that has been <b>aged significantly,</b> for at least three years.
The Gemara states a general principle: <b>Any</b> food or medical treatment <b>that is effective in</b> healing <b>this</b> sickness or this limb <b>is deleterious for that</b> one. <b>And</b> any food or treatment <b>that is deleterious for this</b> one <b>is effective</b> in healing <b>that</b> one, <b>except for moist ginger, long peppers, and bread</b> made of <b>refined</b> flour, <b>and fatty meat, and aged wine, which are effective to heal all</b> limbs <b>of the body.</b>
The Gemara returns to its discussion of the details mentioned in the mishna. Why is <b>Median beer</b> prohibited during Passover? It is because the Medians <b>place barley water into it.</b>
<b>And Edomite vinegar</b> is prohibited because the Edomites <b>place barley into it.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Initially,</b> when the Temple stood <b>and they would bring</b> wine <b>libations from Judea,</b> the wine would be blessed and would be preserved without any additives. <b>The wine of Judea would not turn to vinegar unless they placed barley into it</b> to achieve this effect. <b>And they would call</b> this vinegar to which barley had been added <b>ordinary vinegar,</b> since wine would not become vinegar without this additive.
<b>And now,</b> after the destruction of the Temple, <b>Edomite wine does not turn to vinegar unless one places barley into it. This is called Edomite vinegar, to fulfill that which is stated</b> with regard to Tyre, and the same applies to other enemies of the Jewish people: “Because Tyre has said against Jerusalem: Aha, she is broken that was the gate of the peoples; she is turned unto me; <b>I shall be filled with her that is laid waste”</b> (Ezekiel 26:2). The Sages expound: <b>If this one,</b> Jerusalem, <b>is full,</b> then <b>that one,</b> her enemy, <b>is laid waste; and if this</b> enemy <b>is full,</b> then <b>she,</b> Jerusalem, <b>is laid waste.</b> Therefore, when the Jewish people fall, their enemies can achieve the success that was once attained by the Jews. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This notion can be derived <b>from here,</b> where the verse states regarding Esau and Jacob: <b>“The one people shall be stronger than the other people”</b> (Genesis 25:23), meaning that when one nation gains power, the other is weakened, because they cannot both be strong at the same time.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: In Judea, initially, one who would purchase vinegar from an <i>am ha’aretz</i>,</b> i.e., one who is not scrupulous in matters of ritual purity and tithes and is therefore suspect of not having tithed his fruit properly, would <b>not need to tithe it due to</b> the fact that <b>it can be assumed</b> that ordinary vinegar <b>was made only from <i>temed</i>,</b> a liquid produced from grape remnants. After filtering the wine from the stems, seeds, and skins, water was poured over these remnants. The liquid was then drained off and allowed to ferment until it became vinegar. This liquid was called <i>temed</i>, and it is not necessary to tithe it. Vinegar was produced in this way because the wine of that time was so strong that it did not turn to vinegar on its own. <b>But now, one who purchases vinegar from an <i>am ha’aretz</i> must tithe it,</b> as the wine nowadays turns to vinegar quickly, <b>and the presumption is</b> that vinegar <b>comes only from wine.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Yehuda hold that <i>temed</i> is not subject to tithing? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who produces <i>temed</i> and adds a measured</b> amount <b>of water and</b> afterward <b>finds a corresponding</b> amount of liquid to that which <b>he measured, he is exempt</b> from tithing this <i>temed</i> because it is clear that the grape produce added only flavor and did not add to the volume of the <i>temed</i>. And <b>Rabbi Yehuda obligates</b> one to tithe the <i>temed</i> even in that case. If this is so, how can Rabbi Yehuda permit a person to purchase <i>temed</i> from an <i>am ha’aretz</i>? According to his opinion in this <i>baraita</i>, <i>temed</i> must be tithed.
The Gemara answers: <b>This is</b> what Rabbi Yehuda <b>is saying:</b> One is required to tithe <i>temed</i>; however, <b><i>amei ha’aretz</i> are not suspected</b> of failing to tithe <b><i>temed</i>.</b> Because <i>temed</i> is so inexpensive, the assumption is that <i>amei ha’aretz</i> are not sparing with it and are willing to tithe it. <b>If you wish, say</b> instead that even if <i>amei ha’aretz</i> <b>are suspected</b> of failing to tithe <i>temed</i>, <b>and</b> this is <b>not difficult</b> for the following reason: <b>This</b> mishna is referring to a case where the <i>temed</i> was produced <b>with dregs</b> that contain some amount of wine, and therefore Rabbi Yehuda says that a person is required to tithe it. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where the <i>temed</i> was produced <b>with grape pits; because</b> it is assumed that no wine is mixed into the <i>temed</i>, Rabbi Yehuda states that one is exempt from tithing it.
It is stated in the mishna that <b>Egyptian <i>zitom</i></b> is considered leavened food. The Gemara asks: <b>What is Egyptian <i>zitom</i>?</b>
<b>Rav Yosef taught</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: It is <b>one-third barley, one-third safflower, and one-third salt.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa removes barley</b> from the list of ingredients <b>and includes wheat;</b> he maintains that Egyptian <i>zitom</i> was made with wheat rather than barley. The Gemara comments: <b>Your mnemonic</b> to remember which Sage expressed which version is the word <b><i>sisanei</i>,</b> meaning a twig basket. <i>Sisanei</i> contains the letter <i>samekh</i> twice, which can help one remember that Rav Yosef, whose name contains a <i>samekh</i>, says that Egyptian <i>zitom</i> is made from <i>se’orim</i>, barley, a word that contains the letter <i>sin</i>, which makes the same sound as <i>samekh</i>.
The Gemara describes how Egyptian <i>zitom</i> is prepared: Those who prepare it <b>soak</b> the ingredients together, <b>and</b> then they <b>roast them and grind them</b> together. <b>They drink</b> the mixture <b>from Passover to <i>Shavuot</i>.</b> This drink <b>relaxes</b> the bowels of one who is <b>constipated, and it constipates</b> one whose bowel movements are <b>loose.</b> However, <b>it is dangerous for a sick person or a pregnant woman</b> to drink this mixture.
It was taught in the mishna that <b>dyers’ broth</b> is considered leavened. The Gemara explains: <b>Here,</b> in Babylonia, <b>they interpreted</b> that this is <b>bran water [<i>maya deḥivri</i>] that</b> people <b>use to dye leather.</b>
It was further stated in the mishna that <b>bakers’ well-worked dough</b> is also considered leavened. The Gemara explains the nature of this substance: It is <b>bread made from grain that was</b> harvested before it was <b>one-third</b> ripe and then made into a loaf. This loaf was placed <b>on top of a pot to draw out the filth</b> from the broth.
It was further taught in the mishna that the <i>kolan</i> of <i>soferim</i>, <b>kolan of soferim,</b> is considered leavened. The Gemara explains: <b>Here,</b> in Babylonia, <b>they interpreted that</b> this expression is referring to <b>shoemakers’ glue</b> that is made from flour.
<b>Rav Shimi from Ḥozna’a said: This is the</b> depilatory <b>paste of the daughters of the wealthy, of which they would leave a remnant for the daughters of the poor.</b> It was the common practice for women to remove hair from different parts of their bodies by applying various pastes, some of which contained flour. The <i>kolan</i> of <i>soferim</i> mentioned in the mishna was such a substance. It was given this name because wealthy young women would give the paste [<i>kolan</i>] to poor young women whose fathers were schoolteachers [<i>soferim</i>], so that the poor women could utilize it as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so?
