But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach</b> a mnemonic by noting that the mishna lists <b>four items</b> that are used by the ordinary people <b>of the state,</b> i.e., <i>kutaḥ</i>, beer, vinegar, and <i>zitom</i>, <b>and three items of artisans,</b> i.e., dyers’ broth, kolan of soferim, and bakers’ well-worked dough? <b>And if you say</b> that kolan of soferim is <b>the</b> depilatory <b>paste of the daughters of the wealthy,</b> then <b>what artisanship is there in that?</b> According to this interpretation, that substance does not belong on the list of artisans’ items.
The Gemara answers with another question: <b>Rather what,</b> will you say that this is referring to <b>shoemakers’ glue?</b> If so, <b>why did</b> the authors of the mishna <b>call it bookmakers’ glue [<i>kolan shel soferim</i>]? It should</b> have been called <b>shoemakers’ glue [<i>kolan shel ratzanin</i>]. Rav Oshaya said: Actually,</b> one should explain that <i>kolan</i> is referring to <b>shoemakers’ glue; and why is it called bookmakers’ glue?</b> The reason is that <b>bookmakers also use it to attach their pages.</b> During the time of the mishna, this paste was referred to as bookmakers’ glue.
It is stated in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that <b>women’s adornments are also</b> prohibited as leavened food. The Gemara asks: <b>Could it enter your mind</b> to say <b>that adornments</b> made from silver, gold, or woven materials contain leaven? <b>Rather, say</b> instead that this means: <b>Even women’s cosmetics</b> or other items used by women to enhance their skin are prohibited if they contain leavened ingredients. <b>As Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: With regard to the Jewish women</b>

Daf 43a

<b>who reached</b> physical <b>maturity, but had not</b> yet <b>reached the age</b> of majority, and women who sought to remove hair for cosmetic purposes: <b>They would smear daughters of the poor with lime; they would smear daughters of the wealthy with fine flour; they would smear daughters of kings with <i>shemen hamor</i>, as it was stated:</b> “For so were the days of their anointing filled, <b>six months with <i>shemen hamor</i>”</b> (Esther 2:12).
The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>shemen hamor</i>? Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya said: <i>Setaket</i>. Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said:</b> It is <b>olive oil</b> extracted from an olive <b>that</b> has <b>not</b> yet <b>reached a third</b> of its growth; the acidic oil is effective as a depilatory.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b><i>anpiknin</i></b> is <b>olive oil</b> from an olive <b>that has not reached a third</b> of its growth. <b>And why is it spread</b> on the body? It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it removes [<i>mashir</i>] the hair and pampers the skin.</b>
The mishna states: <b>This is the principle:</b> One violates these prohibitions on Passover with <b>anything that is</b> prepared <b>from a type of grain. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said: Now that we learned</b> that by possessing <b>anything that is a type of grain one violates</b> the prohibition against leaven <b>during Passover, why did the Sages list these</b> items individually? They could have simply stated the principle. The <i>baraita</i> explains that the Sages provided a list of prohibited foods <b>so that</b> one <b>would become familiar with these</b> items <b>and with their names,</b> so that it would become widely known that these foods contain a small quantity of grain.
The Gemara cites an incident that underscores the significance of familiarity with the names of foods: <b>As in this</b> case <b>of that</b> man <b>from the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, who <b>visited Babylonia,</b> and <b>had meat with him, he said to</b> his hosts: <b>Bring me a dip</b> with which to eat my bread. <b>He heard them saying: Bring him <i>kutaḥ</i>. Since he heard</b> the word <b><i>kutaḥ</i>, he stopped</b> eating, as he knew that <i>kutaḥ</i> contains milk and may not be eaten with meat. This incident underscores that it is advantageous for one to familiarize himself with the names and ingredients of different foods, so that he will be aware of the nature of the food even if he does not recognize it.
It is stated in the mishna: <b>These</b> substances <b>are included in the prohibition</b> but are not punishable by <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i> who</b> maintains that both <b>full-fledged, leavened grain bread in a mixture, and hardened</b> leaven, <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, which is not suitable for consumption, are both included <b>in a prohibition?</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Leavening</b> dough, i.e., dough that is at the beginning of the leavening process and is presently hardened leaven, must <b>be burned, or</b> one <b>gives it to his dog. And one who eats it</b> is flogged <b>with forty</b> lashes.
Before analyzing the contents of the <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara addresses an apparent contradiction within the <i>baraita</i>. <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself is difficult. You said</b> that <b>leavening</b> dough must <b>be burned; apparently it is prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from hardened leaven. <b>And then it teaches: Or</b> one <b>gives it to his dog; apparently, it is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from the leaven.
The Gemara answers that <b>this is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Leavening</b> dough must <b>be burned,</b> i.e., leavening dough as defined <b>by Rabbi Meir</b> must be burned <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who maintains that leavening dough is full-fledged leaven. Alternatively, the <i>baraita</i> may be explained as referring to leavening dough as defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> that it is prohibited to derive benefit from leavening dough. Each <i>tanna</i> maintains that it is prohibited to derive benefit from any dough classified as leavening dough by his definition. When the <i>baraita</i> says <b>that one gives it to his dog,</b> it means: Leavening dough as defined <b>by Rabbi Meir,</b> is only hardened leaven <b>according to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and therefore one may feed it to his dog. Rabbi Yehuda maintains that it is permitted to derive benefit from this type of leaven.
With regard to the final statement of the <i>baraita</i>, that <b>one who eats</b> leavening dough is flogged <b>with forty</b> lashes, <b>we have</b> once again <b>arrived at</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> Rabbi Meir holds that one who eats this leavening dough, from which it is permitted to derive benefit according to Rabbi Yehuda, is flogged with forty lashes.
According to this explanation of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>we</b> have <b>learned</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir</b> maintains that <b>hardened</b> leaven <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, is included <b>in a prohibition,</b> and one who eats this leaven is flogged. <b>And all the more so,</b> one who eats <b>full-fledged, leavened grain bread in a mixture</b> is flogged but does not receive <i>karet</i>, as he is not eating the leaven in and of itself. Nevertheless, the prohibition against eating leavened bread on Passover applies in that case.
<b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>For</b> eating <b>full-fledged, leavened grain bread</b> one is <b>punishable</b> by <b><i>karet</i>,</b> whereas <b>for</b> eating <b>a mixture</b> that contains leaven one is punished merely <b>for</b> violating <b>a prohibition.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say: For</b> eating <b>full-fledged, leavened grain bread</b> one is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>;</b> however, <b>for</b> eating leaven in <b>its mixture</b> one is <b>not</b> punished <b>at all. And we learned according to Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> that <b>full-fledged, leavened grain bread in a mixture is</b> included <b>in a prohibition, and</b> that is true <b>all the more so</b> with regard to <b>hardened leaven in its pure,</b> unadulterated form.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman did not state</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Yehuda,</b> that the mishna is in accordance with Rabbi Meir’s ruling?
The Gemara answers that Rav Naḥman could have <b>said to you</b> that the following distinction applies: <b>Perhaps Rabbi Meir stated</b> his opinion <b>only there,</b> with regard to <b>hardened</b> leaven <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form; <b>however,</b> with regard to <b>full-fledged, leavened grain bread in a mixture, no,</b> one is punished not with mere lashes but with <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda did not state</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Naḥman,</b> that the mishna is in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer’s ruling?
The Gemara answers that Rav Yehuda could have <b>said to you: Rabbi Eliezer stated</b> his opinion <b>only there,</b> with regard to <b>full-fledged, leavened grain bread in a mixture</b> that it is included in the prohibition. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>hardened</b> leaven <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, <b>he did not state</b> his ruling and perhaps Rabbi Eliezer maintains that it is permitted to eat hardened leaven.
The Gemara notes that <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda,</b> who said that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Meir’s opinion: <b>“You shall eat nothing leavened;</b> in all your dwellings you shall eat <i>matzot</i>” (Exodus 12:20). The Sages taught: This verse comes <b>to include Babylonian <i>kutaḥ</i>, Median beer, Edomite vinegar, and Egyptian <i>zitom</i>.</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that one who eats any of these items <b>will be punishable</b> by <b><i>karet</i>.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “For whoever eats leavened bread…</b>that soul <b>shall be cut off</b> from Israel” (Exodus 12:15), from which the Sages derived: <b>For</b> eating <b>full-fledged, leavened grain bread</b> one is <b>punished</b> with <b><i>karet</i>, but for</b> eating <b>its mixture</b> one is only in violation <b>of a prohibition.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the above statement: <b>Whom did you hear that said that for</b> eating <b>a mixture</b> which contains leaven one is in violation <b>of a prohibition? It is Rabbi Eliezer. However,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is not stating</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>hardened</b> leaven <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form. This <i>baraita</i> lists only items that contain leaven in a mixture, but not other substances whose legal status is that of hardened leaven, e.g., broth, worked dough, and glue. <b>Learn from this that Rabbi Eliezer is not of</b> the opinion that <b>hardened</b> leaven is prohibited.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Eliezer, from where does he</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that leaven in <b>its mixture</b> is included <b>in a prohibition?</b> The Gemara answers that he derives it <b>as it is written: “You shall eat nothing leavened.”</b>
The Gemara challenges this derivation: <b>If so,</b> if the expression: Anything leavened, includes leaven in a mixture, <b>let one also be liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i></b> for eating leaven in a mixture. <b>As it is written:</b> “Seven days no leaven shall be found in your houses; <b>for whosoever eats anything [<i>kol</i>] leavened,</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off</b> from the people of Israel, whether he is a sojourner or one born in the land” (Exodus 12:19). Apparently, one is punished with <i>karet</i> for eating anything that contains leaven.
The Gemara answers that Rabbi Eliezer <b>needs that</b> phrase: Anything leavened, in order to derive <b>for that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: From the phrase: Anything <b>leavened, I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that an item <b>that became leavened on its own</b> is prohibited. However, <b>from where</b> do I derive that one is punished with <i>karet</i> for eating an item that became leavened <b>due to a different factor? The verse states:</b> “Whosoever eats <b>anything [<i>kol</i>] leavened…shall be cut off,”</b> indicating that food that became leavened due to a different factor is considered leavened bread.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if the phrase: Anything leavened, is referring to food that became leavened by means of something else, then when this same phrase appears with regard <b>to</b> the <b>prohibition,</b> I should explain that it <b>comes for that</b> purpose <b>as well.</b> Consequently, there should be no violation for eating a mixture that contains leaven, as apparently, the phrase: Anything leavened, does not refer to that case at all.
<b>Rather, the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> is that he derives this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the term <b>anything [<i>kol</i>].</b> He does not derive his opinion from the term leavened; he bases his ruling on the inclusive term anything.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>There, too,</b> in the verse that mentions the punishment of <i>karet</i>, <b>isn’t it written:</b> “For <b>whosoever [<i>kol</i>]</b> eats anything leavened, that soul shall be cut off”? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Eliezer <b>requires that</b> term <b>to include women</b> who are also punishable by <i>karet</i> for eating leavened bread.
The Gemara asks: Is this source necessary to derive this <i>halakha</i>? The fact that <b>women</b> may not eat leavened bread is <b>derived from</b> the statement that <b>Rav Yehuda</b> said that <b>Rav said. As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said, and similarly,</b> the Sage in <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: The verse said:</b> “Speak to the children of Israel: <b>A man or woman, when they commit any of the sins of men,</b> to commit a trespass against the Lord, and that soul shall be guilty” (Numbers 5:6). <b>The Torah rendered a man equal to a woman for all punishments of the Torah.</b> Since the punishment of <i>karet</i> for eating leavened bread on Passover is included in this general principle, there is no need for a separate source to include women.
The Gemara answers: Nonetheless, it is <b>necessary</b> to cite a source that men and women are equal specifically with regard to the punishment of <i>karet</i> for eating leavened bread,

Daf 43b

as <b>it could enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since it is written: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it; seven days you shall eat with it <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3), one might have thought that <b>anyone included</b> in the obligation <b>to eat <i>matza</i> is</b> also <b>included</b> in the <b>prohibition against eating leavened bread. And these women, since they are excluded</b> from the obligation <b>to eat <i>matza</i>, as it is a time-bound, positive mitzva</b> from which they are exempt as a rule, I might <b>say they are also excluded from the prohibition against eating leavened bread.</b> Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that women are also prohibited from eating leavened bread.
The Gemara comments: <b>And now</b> that women <b>have been included in the prohibition against eating leavened bread, they</b> should <b>also be included</b> in the obligation <b>to eat <i>matza</i>,</b> even though it is a time-bound, positive mitzva, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer. As Rabbi Eliezer said: Women are obligated to eat <i>matza</i> by Torah</b> law, <b>as it is stated: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it;</b> seven days you shall eat with it <i>matzot</i>” (Deuteronomy 16:3). These two commandments are juxtaposed to teach that <b>anyone included</b> in <b>the prohibition against eating leavened bread is</b> also <b>included in</b> the obligation <b>to eat <i>matza</i>. And these women too, since they</b> are <b>included</b> in <b>the prohibition against eating leavened bread, they are</b> also <b>included in</b> the obligation <b>to eat <i>matza</i>.</b>
The Gemara questions this derivation: <b>What did you see</b> that led you to understand <b>that</b> the term <b>anything [<i>kol</i>]</b> comes to <b>include women and to exclude</b> leaven in <b>its mixture?</b> On the contrary, <b>say</b> that it comes <b>to include</b> in the punishment of <i>karet</i> one who eats <b>its mixture.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It is reasonable</b> to explain that the verse comes to include women since the verse is <b>dealing with those who</b> are obligated in the mitzva not to <b>eat</b> leavened bread, <b>it includes those who eat,</b> as the verse says: “For anyone who eats leavened bread…shall be cut off.” It stands to reason that the expression: Anyone [<i>kol</i>] includes additional people who are punishable by <i>karet</i>, not additional types of leaven. Would a verse that <b>is dealing with those who</b> may not <b>eat</b> leaven come to <b>include</b> additional types of foods that may not <b>be eaten?</b>
<b>Rav Natan, father of Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, strongly objects to this: And anywhere that</b> a verse <b>is dealing with those who eat, does</b> it necessarily <b>not</b> come to <b>include</b> additional <b>types of food</b> in the prohibition? <b>Wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“For anyone who eats the fat of the domesticated animal, of which men present</b> an offering of fire to God, the soul that eats it shall be cut off from its people” (Leviticus 7:25)? The Sages interpreted this verse: <b>I have</b> derived from this verse that the prohibition applies <b>only</b> to the <b>fats</b> of <b>unblemished</b> animals <b>that are fit to be sacrificed. From where</b> is it derived that it is also prohibited to eat the <b>fats of blemished animals,</b> which may not be offered as sacrifices? <b>The verse states: “Of the domesticated animal.” From where</b> is it derived that it is prohibited to eat the <b>fats of non-sacred</b> animals? <b>The verse states: “For anyone</b> who eats the fat.” Rav Natan explains his objection: <b>Here, isn’t</b> the verse <b>dealing with those who eat</b> fats, and nevertheless, its superfluous phrases come to <b>include</b> types of foods that may not <b>be eaten.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the verse concerning prohibited fats, <b>where there are no</b> additional people <b>who eat</b> of it to include, as the prohibition already applies to everyone, the superfluous expression comes <b>to include</b> additional <b>foods. Here,</b> in the verse that deals with leavened bread, <b>where there are</b> people <b>who eat</b> of it who can be included, namely women, the verse does <b>not exclude</b> people <b>who eat and include</b> foods that are <b>eaten.</b> Generally, there should be a connection between the content of a verse and that which is derived from it. Only when no other derivation is possible is a less related matter derived.
The Gemara explains: <b>And the Rabbis, who are not of</b> the opinion that leaven in a <b>mixture</b> is included in the prohibition, <b>do not interpret</b> that the term: <b>Anything [<i>kol</i>],</b> comes to include other matters; neither with regard to leaven in a mixture nor with regard to <i>karet</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> in that case, <b>from where do they</b> derive that it is prohibited for <b>women</b> to eat leavened bread?
The Gemara answers: Although <b>they do not derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from the term: <b>Anything, they derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from the expression: <b>For anyone [<i>ki kol</i>],</b> in the verse: “For anyone who eats leaven.”
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if indeed the phrase: For anyone, is a more inclusive expression than the simple word anything, then according to <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> another <i>halakha</i> could also be derived from here. <b>Say</b> that the phrase: <b>Anyone</b> who eats leaven, comes <b>to include the women,</b> and the phrase: <b>For anyone</b> who eats, comes <b>to include</b> leaven in <b>its mixture.</b> According to Rabbi Eliezer, then, one would be punishable by <i>karet</i> for eating leaven in a mixture.
<b>And lest you say that Rabbi Eliezer does not derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from the phrase: <b>For anyone [<i>ki kol</i>],</b> as he does not consider this an inclusive expression, the result would be another contradiction. <b>Wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: “For no [<i>ki kol</i>] leaven nor any honey shall be offered as a burnt-offering before God” (Leviticus 2:11)? Had the verse stated only: <b>You shall not offer leaven, I would have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than the <i>halakha</i> that it is prohibited to sacrifice <b>an entire</b> piece of leaven. <b>From where</b> is it derived that it is also prohibited to sacrifice <b>part of it? The verse states: “No [<i>kol</i>]</b> leaven,” indicating that it is prohibited to sacrifice even part of it. <b>From where</b> is it derived that it is prohibited to sacrifice leaven in <b>a mixture? The verse states: “For no</b> [<b><i>ki kol</i></b>] leaven.” The Gemara analyzes this statement: <b>Whom did you hear who derives</b> <i>halakhot</i> from the term: <b><i>Kol</i>?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Eliezer, and</b> nevertheless, <b>he derives</b> additional details from the expression: <b><i>Ki kol</i>.</b>
The Gemara concludes: This matter remains <b>difficult,</b> as no satisfactory explanation has been found for why Rabbi Eliezer does not derive from the expression <i>ki kol</i> that leaven in a mixture is also prohibited.
After discussing leaven in a mixture, the Gemara states a more general principle. <b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: With regard to all prohibitions of the Torah, a permitted</b> substance <b>does not join together with a prohibited</b> substance. If one eats a permitted food with a prohibited food, and together they constitute the minimum prohibited measure, he is exempt from punishment for this act of consumption. This principle applies to all <i>halakhot</i> <b>except for the prohibitions of a nazirite,</b> who is liable for eating a mixture of that kind, <b>as the Torah said</b> with regard to a nazirite: “He shall abstain from wine and strong drink; he shall drink no vinegar of wine, or vinegar of strong drink, nor shall he drink anything <b>soaked</b> in grapes” (Numbers 6:3). This verse indicates that a nazirite is prohibited from consuming not only wine and vinegar, but also any food that was soaked in these liquids.
<b>And Ze’eiri said:</b> Permitted and prohibited substances <b>also</b> combine with regard to <b>the prohibition against offering leaven</b> on the altar, as it states: “For no [<i>kol</i>] leaven and no [<i>kol</i>] honey shall be offered as a burnt-offering before the Lord” (Leviticus 2:11). This indicates that one is also liable for sacrificing leaven in a mixture (<i>Tosafot</i>) in addition to the liability for sacrificing pure leaven.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Ze’eiri issue his ruling? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who derives</b> from the term <b><i>kol</i></b> that any mixture that contains any amount of a prohibited substance is not nullified.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b>

Daf 44a

with regard <b>to the matter of leavened bread on Passover</b> one should <b>also</b> be liable for eating a prohibited substance joined together with a permitted substance.
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, indeed it is so, and</b> the prohibition mentioned by Ze’eiri against sacrificing leaven in offerings was only <b>to exclude</b> the statement <b>of Abaye, who said: There is</b> significance to <b>offering less than an olive-bulk</b> of leaven on the altar, and one is flogged for sacrificing an offering of that kind. By noting that one is liable because permitted substances combine with prohibited substances, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that an offering</b> of <b>less than an olive-bulk</b> is <b>not</b> considered an offering, and therefore sacrificing it is not punishable by lashes.
<b>Rav Dimi sat and stated this <i>halakha</i></b> that a permitted substance does not join together with a prohibited substance to constitute the requisite measure, except in the case of a nazirite. <b>Abaye said to Rav Dimi: And</b> is it true that with regard to <b>all</b> other <b>prohibitions in the Torah, a permitted</b> substance <b>does not join together with a prohibited</b> substance?
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to thick <b>soup</b> prepared <b>with <i>teruma</i></b> produce whose <b>garlic and oil</b> are <b>of non-sacred</b> produce, <b>and one who immersed himself during that day touched some of</b> the ingredients, <b>he disqualified all</b> the contents of the pot, as they are subsumed within the <i>teruma</i> soup. However, if the thick <b>soup</b> was prepared <b>with non-sacred</b> produce <b>and the garlic and the oil were of <i>teruma</i>, and one who immersed himself during that day touched some of them, he disqualifies only</b> the ingredients in the <b>place that he touched.</b>
Abaye continues. <b>And we discussed this</b> issue: <b>Why</b> are the ingredients in the <b>place that he touched disqualified?</b> The <b>spices,</b> i.e., the garlic or oil, <b>are nullified by the majority.</b> Since the major portion of the dish is composed of non-sacred produce, it should not be disqualified by contact with one who immersed himself during that day. <b>And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> in reply: <b>What is the reason</b> that it becomes disqualified? It is <b>since a non-priest is flogged for</b> eating <b>an olive-bulk</b> of the soup, as anything into which <i>teruma</i> is mixed is considered <i>teruma</i> by Torah law. <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this ruling that a non-priest is flogged? Is it <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that the permitted</b> substance <b>joins together with the prohibited</b> substance?
Rav Dimi rejects this contention: <b>No; what is</b> the meaning of <b>an olive-bulk</b> in this mishna? It means <b>that there is</b> sufficient <i>teruma</i> in the mixture that when one eats from the mixture he will consume <b>an olive-bulk</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread. In that case one is liable for punishment for eating this olive-bulk, as if he ate the <i>teruma</i> alone.
Abaye asked him: <b>Is</b> eating <b>an olive-bulk in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law, and one is punished for it? He <b>said to him: Yes.</b>
Abaye asked in response: <b>If so, why do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer with regard to</b> eating <b>Babylonian <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a dip that contains flour, on Passover? The Rabbis maintain that one is not punished by Torah law for eating a mixture containing leaven. Although the Rabbis do not derive from the word: Anything [<i>kol</i>], that leaven in a mixture is prohibited, they should nonetheless hold one liable for eating an olive-bulk of a prohibited substance in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf of bread.
Rav Dimi said: <b>Rather, what</b> conclusion must be drawn; the reason that a non-priest is flogged for eating the <i>teruma</i> soup is <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>a permitted</b> substance <b>joins together with a prohibited</b> substance? If so, <b>ultimately, why do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer with regard to</b> eating <b>Babylonian <i>kutaḥ</i>? Rather, leave Babylonian <i>kutaḥ</i>, as</b> in eating that mixture <b>there is no</b> possibility that one will consume <b>an olive-bulk</b> of the leaven <b>in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread. <b>If</b> he <b>eats</b> <i>kutaḥ</i> <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, <b>by swallowing it</b> as food, not as a dip, <b>his intention is</b> rendered <b>irrelevant by</b> the opinions of <b>all</b> other <b>people.</b> It is unusual for a person to eat a pungent dip by itself, all the more so, for him to eat it so quickly. One receives no punishment for conduct that anomalous. <b>And if he dips</b> other food into the <i>kutaḥ</i> <b>and eats</b> it, he will <b>not</b> consume <b>an olive-bulk in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread. Due to the pungency of the dip, one needs to add only a small portion to his food.
Abaye <b>raised an objection to</b> Rav Dimi from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>two pots, one of non-sacred</b> produce <b>and</b> the other <b>one of <i>teruma</i>, before which</b> were <b>two mortars,</b> one in <b>which non-sacred</b> produce was pounded, <b>and one</b> in <b>which <i>teruma</i></b> produce was pounded, <b>and</b> the contents of <b>these</b> mortars <b>fell into these</b> pots, but it is unknown which produce fell into which pot, <b>it is</b> all <b>permitted.</b> The reason for this ruling is <b>as I say,</b> since there is no definitive proof to the contrary, that the <b><i>teruma</i> fell into the <i>teruma</i> and</b> the <b>non-sacred produce fell into</b> the <b>non-sacred produce.</b>
Abaye explains his objection: <b>And if you say</b> that eating <b>an olive-bulk</b> of a prohibited substance <b>in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread is prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>why do we say</b> this principle: <b>As I say that</b> the <b><i>teruma</i></b> fell <b>into</b> the <i>teruma</i>, <b>etc.?</b> If the <i>teruma</i> produce fell into the pot containing non-sacred produce, one who eats from the mixture will consume an olive-bulk of <i>teruma</i> within the time it takes to eat a half-loaf of bread, and he will thereby violate a Torah prohibition. Rav Dimi <b>said to him: Leave <i>teruma</i></b> separated from <b>spices,</b> which is <i>teruma</i> <b>by rabbinic</b> law. By Torah law one is required to separate <i>teruma</i> only from grain, wine and oil. The Sages are lenient with regard to <i>teruma</i> by rabbinic law.
Abaye <b>raised</b> another <b>objection</b> from a similar <i>baraita</i>: In a case where there are <b>two baskets, one</b> filled with <b>non-sacred</b> produce <b>and the other</b> filled with <b><i>teruma</i>, and before them</b> were <b>two</b> vessels each containing a <b><i>se’a</i></b> of produce, <b>one</b> filled with <b>non-sacred</b> produce <b>and</b> the other <b>one</b> filled <b>with <i>teruma</i>, and these,</b> the contents of each of the baskets, <b>fell into those,</b> each of the <i>se’a</i> vessels. It is possible that the <i>teruma</i> fell into the non-sacred produce, and it is prohibited for non-priests to eat a mixture of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce. Nevertheless, the contents of the <i>se’a</i> vessel containing the non-sacred produce are <b>permitted, as I say</b> that <b>the non-sacred produce fell into the non-sacred produce and the <i>teruma</i> fell into the <i>teruma</i>.</b> The obligation to separate <i>teruma</i> from grain is by Torah law, <b>and if you say</b> that eating <b>an olive-bulk</b> of forbidden food <b>in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread is prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>why do we say</b> the principle: <b>As I say</b> the non-sacred grain fell into the non-sacred grain? Why aren’t the Sages concerned that one might eat an olive-bulk of <i>teruma</i> in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf, which is prohibited by Torah law?
<b>He said to him: Leave <i>teruma</i> in modern times,</b> as it is in effect <b>by rabbinic</b> law. Once the Jewish people were exiled from their land, the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>teruma</i> and tithes apply by rabbinic law, not Torah law. This is the basis for the lenient ruling in the case of this mixture.
The Gemara returns to its discussion of Rabbi Abbahu’s statement with regard to the meaning of the word soaked in the verse: “He shall abstain from wine and strong drink; he shall drink no vinegar of wine, or vinegar of strong drink, nor shall he drink anything soaked in grapes,” and whether or not a permitted substance combines with a prohibited one. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>this</b> word: <b>Soaked, come to</b> teach <b>that</b> mixtures are prohibited in this case? That verse <b>is required to</b> derive <b>that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> elsewhere: <b>Soaked,</b>

Daf 44b

comes <b>to establish</b> the principle that the legal status of the <b>taste</b> of a forbidden food is <b>like</b> that of its <b>substance.</b> This term teaches that any food that absorbs the taste of a prohibited item assumes the status of this prohibited item itself. <b>As,</b> in a case <b>where one soaked grapes in water and</b> the water <b>has the taste of wine,</b> a nazirite <b>is liable</b> for drinking this mixture, as it assumes the status of wine.
<b>From here you derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to the entire Torah;</b> in all cases, the legal status of the taste of a forbidden food is like that of its substance. The Gemara elaborates. <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a nazirite, whose prohibition</b> against eating grapes <b>is not an eternal prohibition,</b> as he will be permitted to eat grapes once his period of naziriteship is over, <b>and</b> furthermore, <b>his prohibition is not a prohibition</b> against deriving <b>benefit</b> from wine, <b>and there is dissolution for his prohibition</b> against eating grape products by requesting a Sage to release him from his vow, nevertheless, in <b>his</b> case, the Torah <b>rendered</b> the legal status of the <b>taste</b> of food forbidden to him <b>like</b> that of its <b>substance;</b> with regard to a forbidden mixture of <b>diverse kinds, whose prohibition is an eternal prohibition [<i>issuro issur olam</i>] and whose prohibition is a prohibition</b> against deriving <b>benefit, and there is no dissolution for its prohibition, is it not right that</b> the Torah <b>should render</b> the legal status of the <b>taste</b> of its forbidden food <b>like</b> that of its <b>substance?</b>
<b>And the same is true of fruit that grows on a tree during the first three years after it was planted [<i>orla</i>], on two</b> of three counts: Although the prohibition of <i>orla</i> is not an eternal prohibition, as one may eat the fruit of this tree after three years have passed, it is prohibited to derive benefit from <i>orla</i>, and this prohibition cannot be dissolved, as the fruits that grow during the first three years remain prohibited. Therefore, based on the same <i>a fortiori</i> inference, the principle: The legal status of its taste is like that of its substance, should apply in this case as well. Similarly, all other prohibitions in the Torah are more severe than the case of a nazirite in one of these aspects, and therefore this principle is universal. In any case, this entire derivation presents a difficulty for Rabbi Yoḥanan, who derives a different <i>halakha</i> from the term: Soaked.
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <b>whose opinion</b> is the previously cited derivation? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who derive this <i>halakha</i> from the term: Soaked. However, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said</b> that a permitted substance joins together with a prohibited substance, holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara asks: To <b>which</b> statement of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> is the Gemara referring? <b>If you say</b> it is referring to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> in the following <b>mishna, as we learned: Rabbi Akiva says,</b> with regard to <b>a nazirite who soaked his bread in wine, and</b> the bread and the wine <b>contain</b> enough <b>to join together to</b> constitute <b>an olive-bulk,</b> that <b>he is liable; from where do we</b> know <b>that</b> Rabbi Akiva means an amount of an olive-bulk taken <b>from the bread and the wine</b> together? <b>Perhaps</b> he meant that the measure is calculated <b>from</b> the <b>wine alone?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And lest you say</b> that if this amount is <b>from</b> the <b>wine alone, what</b> purpose is there <b>to state</b> this <i>halakha</i>, <b>this</b> statement comes to <b>teach us that even though</b> the prohibited item is <b>in a mixture,</b> one is nonetheless liable for consuming it. Since this mishna can be explained as referring to an olive-bulk from wine alone, it cannot be cited as proof for Rabbi Akiva’s opinion with regard to the combination of a permitted substance with a prohibited substance.
The Gemara states: <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan holds in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva in the <i>baraita</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says: A nazirite who soaked his bread in wine and ate an olive-bulk</b> of the mixture <b>from</b> the <b>bread and</b> the <b>wine is liable.</b> This <i>baraita</i> indicates that according to Rabbi Akiva, a permitted substance joins together with a prohibited substance.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Akiva, from where</b> does he derive the principle: The legal status of the <b>taste</b> is <b>like</b> that of the <b>substance</b> itself? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives</b> this principle from the prohibition of <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk.</b> In that case, there is <b>merely</b> the <b>taste</b> of the milk absorbed by the meat, <b>and</b> the mixture <b>is</b> nonetheless <b>forbidden. Here, too,</b> in the case of other prohibitions, it is <b>no different,</b> and the same principle applies.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> why don’t they derive this principle from meat cooked in milk? The Gemara answers: The Rabbis claim that <b>from meat in milk we do not derive</b> other prohibitions, <b>as</b> that prohibition <b>is a novelty.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is</b> the <b>novelty</b> in that prohibition? <b>If you say that</b> it is unique in that <b>this</b> meat <b>alone and that</b> milk <b>alone</b> are each <b>permitted, and</b> yet <b>together they are forbidden,</b> that characteristic is not unique to meat cooked in milk. In the case of prohibited mixtures of <b>diverse kinds too, this</b> element <b>alone and that</b> element <b>alone</b> are each <b>permitted, and</b> yet <b>together they are prohibited.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> the novelty is <b>that if one soaks</b> meat <b>in milk all day, it is permitted</b> by Torah law, despite the fact that the meat certainly absorbed some taste of the milk, whereas if <b>one cooked</b> the meat in milk even for a short time, the mixture <b>is prohibited</b> by Torah law.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Akiva too</b> certainly agrees that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>meat in milk is a novelty.</b> How can he derive a general principle from this case?
<b>Rather, he derives</b> the principle: The legal status of the taste is like that of the substance itself <b>from</b> the required <b>purging</b> of the vessels of <b>gentiles.</b> In the section of the Torah that deals with the spoils of Midian (Numbers 31:21–24), it states that a vessel used by a gentile to cook food must be purged through fire and purified before it may be used by a Jew. <b>Isn’t</b> the <b>purging</b> of vessels of <b>gentiles</b> necessary only to cleanse them from the <b>mere taste</b> that was absorbed through the process of cooking? Even so, these vessels are <b>prohibited</b> if this cleansing was not performed. <b>Here, too,</b> it is <b>no different;</b> the same reasoning applies in all cases.
The Gemara comments: <b>And the Rabbis</b> do not derive this principle from this source, as they maintain that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>purging</b> vessels of <b>gentiles is</b> also <b>a novelty.</b> What is the novelty of this <i>halakha</i>? <b>As</b> in general, <b>anything that contributes taste</b> that renders the food <b>tainted is permitted.</b> If the taste added by the prohibited food does not enhance the permitted food, then as a rule it does not render the permitted substance prohibited. <b>As we derive</b> this principle <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>an</b> unslaughtered <b>animal carcass</b> that is unfit for consumption is not classified as a prohibited animal carcass and is not prohibited. <b>However, here,</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of purging vessels of gentiles, the Torah states that even if they contribute taste that renders the food tainted they are <b>prohibited.</b> If twenty-four hours have passed since food was cooked in a pot, the assumption is that it will contribute a negative taste to any foods cooked in the pot subsequently. Nevertheless, vessels taken from gentiles remain prohibited until they are purged, even though the taste they contribute taints the food.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who derives this principle from the required purging of the vessels of gentiles, respond to the previous claim? The Gemara explains: He holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion subsequently cited in the name of <b>Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Huna, who said: The Torah prohibited</b> unpurged vessels of gentiles <b>only in</b> the case of <b>a pot</b> that was used <b>on that day. Therefore, it is not</b> a case where the pot <b>contributes taste</b> that renders the food <b>tainted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> say about deriving the <i>halakha</i> from a pot used on that day? The Gemara answers: In their opinion, <b>even</b> in the case of <b>a pot</b> used <b>on that day, it is impossible that</b> the vessel <b>does not slightly taint</b> the food absorbed in the vessel. Consequently, the <i>halakha</i> of purging vessels of gentiles is indeed a novel case from which principles cannot be derived.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: From</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, let us learn</b> the correct interpretation of the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva. Don’t the Rabbis say</b> that the term <b>soaked teaches</b> that the principle that the legal status of <b>taste is like</b> that of <b>substance</b> applies not only to a nazirite, but that <b>from here you derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to all prohibitions of the Torah? According to Rabbi Akiva as well,</b> the term <b>soaked teaches</b> that <b>the permitted</b> substance <b>joins together with the prohibited</b> substance with regard to a nazirite, and <b>from here you derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to all prohibitions of the Torah.</b> This explanation is contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, who applies this principle only to a nazirite.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> This cannot serve as a proof,

Daf 45a

<b>due to</b> the fact that the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a nazirite</b> and those of <b>a sin-offering</b> are <b>two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., to teach the same principle, and two verses that teach the same principle <b>do not teach</b> that principle by analogy.
The Gemara elaborates: The derivation that a permitted substance joins together with a prohibited substance in the case of <b>a nazirite</b> is <b>that which we stated</b> above. With regard to <b>a sin-offering, what is</b> the derivation that permitted material combines with prohibited material? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“Anything that touches in its flesh shall become consecrated”</b> (Leviticus 6:20). I <b>might</b> have thought that non-sacred meat that touched any part of a sin-offering is rendered prohibited <b>even if it did not absorb</b> the taste of the sin-offering it touched. Therefore, <b>the verse states: In its flesh shall become consecrated,</b> to teach that this meat is not consecrated <b>until</b> the taste of the sin-offering <b>is absorbed within its flesh.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Shall become consecrated</b> means that <b>its</b> legal status <b>becomes like</b> that of the sin-offering itself; <b>that</b> is, <b>if</b> the sin-offering <b>is disqualified,</b> this meat <b>will</b> also <b>be disqualified. And if</b> the sin-offering <b>is valid,</b> the meat that touched it may <b>be eaten in accordance with the more stringent</b> standards <b>of</b> a sin-offering as far as when and where it may be eaten. The principle that a permitted substance joins together with a prohibited substance applies in the case of a sin-offering as well. Therefore, the principle cannot be extended to the entire Torah, as a <i>halakha</i> stated in two cases is not applied elsewhere.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the Rabbis as well, let</b> the cases of <b>a nazirite and a sin-offering</b> be considered <b>two verses that come as one and they do not teach</b> the principle that the legal status of taste is like that of the substance with regard to the entire Torah.
The Gemara answers that the Rabbis <b>say:</b> Both of <b>these</b> cases <b>are necessary</b> as they could not have been derived from each other. Therefore, they are not two verses that come as one and it is possible to derive a principle from these two <i>halakhot</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Akiva,</b> who does not derive a general principle from these verses, would respond by asking: In <b>what</b> way <b>are</b> they <b>necessary? Granted, if the Merciful One had written</b> this principle only with regard <b>to a sin-offering,</b> one would <b>not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a nazirite from it,</b> as <b>we do not derive</b> <i>halakhot</i> of <b>non-sacred</b> objects <b>from</b> those of <b>consecrated</b> objects. Certain stringencies and strictures apply only to consecrated property. <b>However, let the Merciful One write</b> this principle <b>with regard to a nazirite, and you</b> could <b>bring</b> the case of the <b>sin-offering and derive</b> it from the case of a nazirite, just <b>as</b> the application of this principle to <b>all prohibitions in the Torah is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a nazirite.</b> Since this principle is stated in both cases unnecessarily, these are two verses that come as one, and one cannot derive a principle from them.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> as they maintain that the principle that the legal status of the taste of a prohibited substance is like that of the substance itself is not limited to these two cases, they would <b>say to you</b> that both sources <b>are necessary.</b> The case of the <b>sin-offering</b> is necessary <b>to</b> derive the principle <b>that a permitted</b> substance <b>joins together with a prohibited</b> substance, as <b>one cannot derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>from consecrated</b> property. <b>And</b> the term <b>soaked,</b> which appears in the context of the <i>halakhot</i> of a nazirite, <b>teaches</b> the principle that the legal status of <b>taste is like</b> that of the <b>substance.</b> Since both examples are necessary, they are not considered two verses that come as one, and it is therefore possible to derive a principle from them. <b>And</b> consequently <b>from here you derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to all of the Torah in its entirety.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how could <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> respond to this claim? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Akiva would say that <b>both</b> cases teach the principle that <b>a permitted</b> substance <b>joins together with a prohibited</b> substance, <b>and they are</b> indeed <b>two verses that come as one,</b> to teach about the same issue. <b>And</b> the rule is that <b>any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> overarching principles.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana: But</b> with regard to <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse: “He shall eat <b>nothing that is made of the grapevine, from the grape skins to the grape seed”</b> (Numbers 6:4), <b>taught with regard to prohibitions of a nazirite that</b> these substances <b>join together.</b> If the nazirite ate only a small amount of each substance that when joined together constitute the measure that determines liability, he is liable. <b>Now</b> the following question arises: <b>According to Rabbi Akiva,</b> who maintains that <b>prohibited and permitted</b> substances <b>join together, is it necessary</b> to teach that one <b>prohibited</b> substance <b>joins together with</b> another <b>prohibited</b> substance? Apparently, according to Rabbi Akiva’s opinion, this derivation is unnecessary.
Rav Kahana <b>said to him</b> that this derivation is necessary because the two cases are not identical: Whereas <b>prohibited and permitted</b> substances combine only when they are eaten <b>simultaneously, prohibited and</b> other <b>prohibited</b> substances join together even when eaten <b>one after the other.</b> In other words, if a nazirite eats half an olive-bulk of grape skins and then eats half an olive-bulk of grape seeds, he is liable according to Rabbi Akiva.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>dough that is in the cracks of a</b> kneading <b>bowl, if there is an olive-bulk</b> of dough <b>in one place,</b> one <b>is obligated to remove</b> it. <b>And if</b> the dough does <b>not</b> add up to this amount, <b>it is nullified due to its insignificance.</b>
<b>And similarly, with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of immersion to purify the bowl from <b>ritual impurity, if one is particular about</b> the dough that is stuck in the cracks and he plans to remove it and use it, <b>it</b> is a foreign substance that <b>interposes</b> between the kneading bowl and the water of the ritual bath, and invalidates the immersion of the bowl, leaving it ritually impure. <b>And if he wants</b> the dough <b>to remain</b> in place, <b>its</b> status <b>is like</b> that <b>of the</b> kneading <b>bowl</b> itself and is not an interposition.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: They taught</b> that one is obligated to remove a combined olive-bulk of leaven <b>only in a case where the</b> pieces of dough <b>are not</b> in a position where they <b>serve to reinforce</b> the kneading bowl. <b>However, in a case where they serve to reinforce</b> the bowl and they will remain there for this purpose, <b>he is not obligated to remove</b> them; he may simply render them null and void.
The Gemara concludes: This proves <b>by inference</b> that with regard to <b>less than an olive-bulk, even in a place where it does not serve to reinforce</b> the bowl, <b>one is not obligated to remove</b> it.
<b>Some teach</b> the statement of Rav Yehuda with regard <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And if</b> the dough is <b>not</b> an olive-bulk, <b>it is nullified due to its insignificance. Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: They taught</b> that one is obligated to remove less than an olive-bulk of dough in one place <b>only in a place where it serves to reinforce</b> the bowl; <b>however, in a place where it does not serve to reinforce</b> the bowl, <b>one is obligated to remove it.</b> This proves <b>by inference that</b> if there is <b>an olive-bulk</b> of dough in one place, <b>even in a place where it serves to reinforce</b> the bowl, <b>one is obligated to remove it.</b>
The Gemara comments: It <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with the first version</b> of Rav Yehuda’s statement, and it <b>was taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with the latter version</b> of his statement. The Gemara elaborates: It <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with the first version</b> of Rav Yehuda’s statement: With regard to <b>dough that is in the cracks of a</b> kneading <b>bowl in a place where it is serves to reinforce</b> the bowl, it <b>does not interpose</b> and invalidate the immersion for ritual impurity, <b>and one does not violate</b> the prohibition against having leaven in his possession during Passover. <b>And in a case where it does not serve to reinforce</b> the bowl, <b>it interposes, and one violates</b> the prohibition against having leaven in his possession on Passover. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>in</b> the case of <b>an olive-bulk</b> of dough; <b>however,</b> in a case where there is <b>less than olive-bulk, even in a case where it does not serve to reinforce</b> the bowl, <b>it does not interpose and</b> one <b>does not violate</b> a prohibition by having it in his possession.
<b>And</b> it <b>was taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with the latter version</b> of Rav Yehuda’s statement: With regard to <b>dough that is in the cracks of a</b> kneading <b>bowl, in a place where it serves to reinforce</b> the bowl,

Daf 45b

<b>it does not interpose</b> in the immersion <b>and one does not violate</b> the prohibition against having leaven in his possession during Passover. <b>In a case where</b> the dough <b>does not serve to reinforce</b> the bowl, <b>it interposes</b> in the immersion <b>and one violates</b> the prohibition against owning leaven on Passover. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>in</b> a case where the dough is <b>less than an olive-bulk. However, if it is an olive-bulk, even in a case where it serves to reinforce</b> the bowl <b>it interposes</b> in the immersion <b>and one violates</b> a prohibition by having it in his possession during the Festival.
The Gemara asks: In any case, these <i>baraitot</i> <b>contradict each other. Rav Huna said: Delete the</b> first, <b>lenient</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>from before the stringent one.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: Have you removed the <i>tanna’im</i> from the world? It is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> The <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the ruling of another Sage and is not the result of a flawed <i>baraita</i>, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>bread that grew moldy</b> and is no longer edible, <b>one is obligated to remove</b> it, <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>it is suitable to be ground and to leaven other dough.</b> Apparently, one is obligated to remove even inedible leaven.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where</b> the bread was <b>maintained for consumption; however, a mass of</b> hardened <b>leaven that one designated for</b> the purpose of <b>sitting</b> upon it, not for consumption, <b>is nullified.</b> Rav Yosef infers from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said</b> that this leaven <b>is nullified,</b> this proves <b>by inference</b> that <b>the first <i>tanna</i> maintains</b> that in that case, the leaven <b>is not nullified. Apparently,</b> the first <i>tanna</i> <b>maintains</b> that with regard to <b>any olive-bulk</b> of leaven, <b>even though one renders</b> it <b>null and void,</b> it <b>is not nullified.</b> The respective opinions of these two Sages are presented in the two conflicting <i>baraitot</i> with regard to dough in a bowl.
<b>Abaye said to him: You resolved</b> the contradiction between the <i>baraitot</i> <b>with regard to an olive-bulk</b> of leaven by establishing it as a tannaitic dispute. According to the first <i>tanna</i>, an olive-bulk of leaven cannot be nullified at all, whereas Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar maintains that it can be nullified. However, <b>did you resolve</b> the contradiction with regard to <b>less than an olive-bulk</b> of leaven? <b>Rather,</b> both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, and</b> nevertheless it is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, where he prohibits the dough in a crack of the bowl, refers to a situation where the dough <b>is in</b> the <b>place</b> in the bowl where <b>kneading</b> takes place, as any dough he later inserts into the bowl will come into contact with the dough in the crack. However, in <b>that</b> case, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar rules leniently, as the dough <b>is not in</b> the <b>place</b> in the bowl where <b>kneading</b> takes place.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Do not say</b> that dough <b>not in</b> the <b>place</b> in the bowl where <b>kneading</b> takes place, refers only to the area <b>on</b> the <b>back of,</b> i.e., outside <b>the basin; rather,</b> it also refers to the area <b>on the edge of the basin,</b> as dough does not come into contact with that part of the bowl.
The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious;</b> why was it necessary to make that statement? The Gemara answers: Rav Ashi’s statement is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that dough <b>sometimes drips there</b> and it should therefore be considered the place in the bowl where kneading takes place. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case, and one is not obligated to remove leavened dough from that part of the bowl.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> that a mass of leaven designated for the purpose of sitting upon is nullified.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashi say</b> that <b>Rav said: If one covered the surface</b> of a mass of leaven <b>with mortar,</b> the leaven <b>is nullified?</b> The Gemara infers: If <b>he covered</b> it with mortar, <b>yes,</b> it is nullified; however, if he did <b>not cover</b> it with mortar, <b>no,</b> it is <b>not</b> nullified. In this statement, Rav states that a mass of leaven is nullified only if it is covered with mortar.
The Gemara answers: <b>He who teaches this</b> statement <b>does not teach that</b> statement, as there is a dispute between <i>amora’im</i> with regard to Rav’s opinion.
<b>Some say</b> an alternative version of the above statement. <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, as Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: If one covered the surface</b> of a mass of leaven <b>with mortar, it is nullified.</b> This ruling indicates that if one did not cover the surface with mortar, the leavened dough is not nullified, in accordance with the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>two half-olive-bulk</b> portions of leavened dough <b>with a string of dough</b> connecting <b>between them, one observes:</b> In <b>any</b> case <b>that were the string taken and</b> the portions are <b>taken with it, one is obligated to remove</b> the dough, as the string unites them into an olive-bulk of leaven. <b>And if</b> the portions are <b>not</b> taken with it, <b>one is not obligated to remove</b> them.
<b>Ulla said: We stated</b> this leniency that it is not necessary to remove half-olive-bulk portions of leavened dough <b>only</b> when the segments are <b>in a</b> kneading <b>bowl,</b> stuck separately to the sides of the bowl. <b>However,</b> if they are located <b>in a house, one is obligated to remove</b> them even in the absence of a string of dough connecting the two pieces.
<b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because</b> a person <b>will sometimes gather them</b> when cleaning his house <b>and they will fall</b> adjacent <b>to each other.</b> If this occurs, the two portions will form an olive-bulk of leavened dough.
<b>Ulla said:</b> The Sages <b>raise a dilemma in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: If one piece of leavened bread was in the main area of a <b>house and</b> the other piece was <b>in the upper</b> story, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If one piece is in <b>the house</b> and the other is in <b>a portico, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Similarly, if the two segments are in <b>two houses, one inside the other, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara states: <b>Let</b> these dilemmas <b>stand</b> unresolved.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to <b>bread that grew moldy and was rendered inedible for consumption by a person, but a dog can eat it,</b> it <b>can become impure</b> with the <b>ritual impurity of foods in</b> the measure <b>of an egg-bulk</b> in size, as it is still considered food. If the moldy bread was ritually pure <i>teruma</i>, <b>it</b> may <b>be burned with ritually impure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>on Passover.</b> Once the bread is no longer fit for human consumption, the prohibition against actively rendering it impure no longer applies. <b>They said in the name of Rabbi Natan: It cannot become ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which we learned</b> in a mishna: The Sages <b>stated</b> a <b>principle with regard to ritual purity: Any</b> food <b>that is designated as food for a person</b> that becomes impure remains <b>ritually impure until it is rendered unfit to be consumed by a dog.</b> The Gemara reiterates: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is that statement? The Gemara answers: It is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan,</b> as his statement indicates that food designated as food for a person is rendered ritually pure as soon as it becomes unfit to be eaten by a person.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to <b>tanners’ bowls into which</b> one <b>placed flour</b> in the production process of leather, if the flour was placed <b>within three days</b> of the start of Passover, <b>one is obligated to remove</b> it, as it is still considered edible leaven. However, if one added the flour <b>prior to three days</b> before Passover, <b>one is not obligated to remove</b> the contents of the bowl, as the flour will have already been rendered inedible by the odor of the vessel before the beginning of Passover, and is no longer considered edible. <b>Rabbi Natan said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where one did not place</b> animal <b>hides into</b> the bowl; <b>however,</b> if <b>one placed hides into</b> the bowl, <b>even</b> if Passover is <b>within three</b> days of when he placed the flour in the bowl, <b>he is not obligated to remove</b> the flour. Once the foul-smelling hides are placed in the bowl, the flour is certainly no longer edible.
<b>Rava said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan</b> with regard to this issue. Consequently, there is no set time at which the flour is considered spoiled, as it is considered inedible <b>even one day or even one hour</b> after hides were added to the bowl.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And similarly, with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of immersion to purify the bowl from <b>ritual impurity, if one is particular about</b> the dough that is stuck in the cracks and he plans to remove it and use it, <b>it</b> is a foreign substance that <b>interposes</b> between the kneading bowl and the water of the ritual bath, and invalidates the immersion of the bowl, leaving it ritually impure. <b>And if he wants</b> the dough <b>to remain</b> in place, <b>its</b> status <b>is like</b> that <b>of the</b> kneading <b>bowl</b> itself and is not an interposition.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is it comparable?</b> How can the mishna compare the <i>halakhot</i> of leaven on Passover to the <i>halakhot</i> of interpositions that invalidate an immersion to purify from ritual impurity? <b>There,</b> with regard to leaven, <b>the matter is contingent upon the measure</b> of the dough, as an olive-bulk of leaven is prohibited. <b>Here,</b> with regard to interpositions that invalidate an immersion, <b>the matter is contingent upon</b> whether or not one is <b>particular</b> about the presence of the dough. In other words, with regard to interpositions it is the attitude of the owner of the bowl that is the decisive factor, not the quantity of the dough.
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Yehuda said: Say</b> that the mishna should be read: <b>And with regard to</b> interpositions that invalidate an immersion to purify from <b>ritual impurity, it is not so,</b> as it is not the quantity of the dough but the particularity of the owner that is the decisive factor.
<b>Abaye said to him: Doesn’t</b> the mishna <b>teach: And similarly with regard to ritual impurity.</b> The text of the mishna cannot be so drastically emended merely to resolve a difficulty. <b>Rather, Abaye said: This is</b> what the mishna <b>is saying: And similarly</b>

Daf 46a

<b>with regard to the combination</b> of two pieces vis-à-vis <b>ritual impurity during Passover,</b> when it depends upon their volume. However, <b>during the rest of the year there is a distinction</b> based upon whether the owner is particular about it or not.
The Gemara explains: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the mishna’s case? It is a case <b>where there is less than an egg-bulk of</b> ritually impure <b>food, and it touched this dough</b> in the bowl, and then it came into contact with ritually pure food. <b>During Passover,</b> when <b>the prohibition</b> that applies to the dough causes it to be considered <b>significant</b> although it is a very small quantity, <b>it combines</b> with the first piece of food. Together they are the size of an egg-bulk, which is able to transmit the ritual impurity of foods. However, <b>during the rest of the year, when</b> there is no prohibition that imparts this significance to the dough, <b>the matter is dependent on</b> the owner’s <b>particularity; if he is particular about it,</b> i.e., he does not want the dough to be there, it is considered food rather than part of the bowl, and <b>it combines</b> with the other piece of food. However, <b>if one prefers its</b> continued <b>presence</b> in its current location, <b>it is</b> considered <b>like</b> part of <b>the kneading bowl</b> itself, rather than food.
<b>Rava strongly objects to this: Was</b> the language <b>taught</b> in the mishna: <b>Combines? Didn’t</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that <b>it interposes?</b> Abaye’s explanation does not account for this term. <b>Rather, Rava said</b> that the mishna should be understood as saying: <b>And so too</b> with regard to <b>purifying the kneading bowl</b> via immersion.
The Gemara explains: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the mishna’s case? It is a case <b>where the kneading bowl became ritually impure, and</b> one <b>wishes to immerse it. During Passover, when the prohibition</b> of an olive-bulk of leaven causes it to be considered <b>significant, it interposes</b> between the water and the kneading bowl, <b>and the immersion is ineffective.</b> However, <b>during the rest of the year, the matter depends upon</b> whether or not the owner is <b>particular</b> about it. <b>If he is particular about</b> the dough and wishes to remove it, <b>it interposes</b> between the water and the bowl. However, <b>if</b> the owner <b>desires it to be present, it is</b> considered <b>like</b> part of the <b>kneading bowl</b> itself, and it does not interpose between the water and the bowl.
<b>Rav Pappa strongly objects to this: Was</b> the language <b>taught</b> in the mishna: <b>And similarly with regard to ritual purity? Didn’t</b> the mishna <b>teach: And similarly with regard to ritual impurity? Rather, Rav Pappa said</b> the mishna should be understood as saying: <b>And similarly with regard to the transfer of ritual impurity to the kneading bowl</b> via this dough.
The Gemara explains: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the mishna’s case? It is a case <b>where</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal touched this dough. During Passover, when its prohibition</b> causes the dough to be considered <b>significant, it interposes</b> between the bowl and the creeping animal, and <b>ritual impurity does not descend to the kneading bowl,</b> i.e., the kneading bowl does not become impure. <b>During the rest of the year, when it depends</b> upon whether one is <b>particular</b> about the presence of the dough, <b>if he is particular about it, it interposes</b> between the bowl and the creeping animal and prevents the bowl from becoming impure. However, <b>if he desires it to be present, it is</b> considered <b>like</b> it is part of <b>the kneading bowl</b> itself. Therefore, the entire bowl becomes ritually impure when the carcass of the creeping animal touches the dough.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Deaf dough</b> is dough for which it is difficult to determine if it has been leavened. It is comparable to a deaf-mute, who cannot communicate. <b>If there is</b> dough <b>similar to it</b> in that water was added to both at the same time, <b>which became leavened,</b> the deaf dough <b>is prohibited.</b> Although it has not shown external signs of becoming leavened, it can be presumed that the deaf dough has also become leavened.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara seeks to clarify the ruling of the mishna: <b>If there is no</b> dough <b>similar to it, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said:</b> According to the Sages, leavening occurs in the time it takes <b>a person</b> to <b>walk</b> the distance <b>from Migdal Nunaya</b> to <b>Tiberias,</b> which is <b>a <i>mil</i>,</b> two thousand cubits.
The Gemara asks about this formulation: Why is it necessary to mention the distance between these two places? <b>Let us say</b> that leavening begins after the time it takes a person to walk a <b><i>mil</i>.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> statement incidentally <b>teaches us that the length of a <i>mil</i></b> is the distance <b>from Migdal Nunaya to Tiberias.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: With regard to a kneader,</b> i.e., one who kneads dough for others and should maintain the ritual purity of the dough; <b>and</b> similarly, <b>with regard to</b> washing one’s hands for <b>prayer</b> (<i>Arukh</i>), <b>and with regard to washing hands</b> before eating, one must search either for a ritual bath to immerse the vessel he is using to knead the dough, or for water to purify his hands, provided that water is accessible within the time it takes to walk <b>four <i>mil</i>,</b> eight thousand cubits.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Ayvu said</b> this <i>halakha</i>, <b>and he said it</b> about <b>four</b> cases, as opposed to the three cases mentioned previously. <b>And one of them</b> pertained to the <b>tanning</b> of hides, which lasts for the time that it takes a person to walk four <i>mil</i>. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>And all</b> types of thin, soft hides, which have the status of flesh with regard to ritual impurity because their texture is similar to flesh, <b>that were tanned</b> in order to be made into leather, <b>or that one trod upon</b> for as long as necessary <b>for</b> the <b>leatherworking</b> process, <b>are ritually pure.</b> They are considered to be leather and are no longer considered like the flesh of the animal, <b>except for</b> the <b>skin of a human</b> corpse, which always remains ritually impure. The Gemara asks: <b>How much</b> time must one tread upon <b>a hide for the leatherworking</b> process? <b>Rabbi Ayvu said that Rabbi Yannai said:</b> It is the amount of time it takes to <b>walk four <i>mil</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: They taught</b> that one must search for water to wash one’s hands before eating or prayer for the amount of time it takes to walk four <i>mil</i> <b>only</b> when the water <b>is before him,</b> in the direction that he is traveling. <b>However,</b> when it is <b>behind him, he need not return even a <i>mil</i>. Rav Aḥa said: From this</b> statement one may infer that <b>he</b> need <b>not return a <i>mil</i>, but he must return less than one <i>mil</i></b> in order to obtain water.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>How does one separate <i>ḥalla</i> in ritual impurity during the Festival</b> day of Passover? Ordinarily, one may separate ritually pure <i>ḥalla</i> from dough and give it to a priest immediately so that he may eat it. Ritually impure <i>ḥalla</i> is unfit for a priest and must be burned, yet it is prohibited to bake or burn anything that is not fit to be eaten during the Festival day. However, it is also prohibited to wait and burn it after the Festival day, since it will become leavened in the meantime.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> A woman <b>should not designate it</b> as <i>ḥalla</i> prior to baking; rather, she should refrain from doing so <b>until it is baked.</b> In other words, she should wait until she has baked all of the dough, and there is no risk of it becoming leavened. Only then should she separate <i>ḥalla</i> from it. The portion of <i>ḥalla</i> may then be kept until after the Festival day, when it may be burned. <b>Ben Beteira says: She should</b> separate the <i>ḥalla</i> before it is baked, and <b>place</b> the dough <b>in cold</b> water so that it will not become leavened. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said:</b>

Daf 46b

<b>This is not the leavened bread about which we are warned</b> with the prohibitions: <b>It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found.</b> These prohibitions do not apply because the <i>ḥalla</i> does not actually belong to the owner of the dough; it is instead considered to be consecrated property. <b>Rather, she should separate</b> the <i>ḥalla</i> <b>and leave it until the evening; and if it becomes leavened,</b> then <b>it will become leavened,</b> but this is of no concern.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to benefit</b> of <b>discretion,</b> i.e., benefit accrued from the option of giving <i>ḥalla</i>, <i>teruma</i> and tithes to whichever priest or Levite one chooses. The Sages debated whether this benefit has monetary value and would constitute a form of ownership. <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds: Benefit</b> of <b>discretion is</b> considered to have <b>monetary</b> value. Therefore, one owns the <i>ḥalla</i> he separates, and he must be careful to prevent it from becoming leavened. However, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua holds: Benefit</b> of <b>discretion is not</b> considered to have <b>monetary</b> value. One does not own the <i>ḥalla</i>, and therefore he may allow it to become leavened.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No, everyone holds</b> that <b>benefit</b> of <b>discretion is not</b> considered to have <b>monetary</b> value, <b>and here they disagree</b> with regard to the principle of: <b>Since, etc. As Rabbi Eliezer holds: We say</b> that <b>since, if he wants, he can ask</b> to have his separation of the <i>ḥalla</i> voided when he regrets having done so, <b>it is his property.</b> Even if one does not actually revoke the status of the <i>ḥalla</i>, the fact that the potential for such an action exists indicates that he still maintains a form of ownership of this dough. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua holds: We do not say</b> that <b>since</b> he could theoretically revoke the status of the <i>ḥalla</i>, the dough is considered his. Consequently, he may leave it until the end of the Festival day without being concerned that it will become leavened.
Apropos the principle: Since, etc., the Gemara cites a related dispute. <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagree with regard to <b>one who bakes</b> bread on <b>a Festival</b> day <b>for</b> use during <b>the week. Rav Ḥisda said: He is flogged</b> because he has desecrated the Festival. <b>Rabba said: He is not flogged.</b>
The Gemara explains the two opinions: <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>he is flogged</b> because <b>we do not say</b> that <b>since guests</b> may <b>happen</b> to visit <b>him,</b> the bread is <b>fit for him</b> on the Festival day itself. <b>Rabba said</b> that <b>he is not flogged</b> because <b>we say</b> that <b>since</b> guests may visit him, the bread is considered to have been baked for use on the Festival day itself. Even if guests do not actually come, he has not desecrated the Festival.
<b>Rabba said to Rav Ḥisda: According to you, who said that we do not say</b> the principle: <b>Since, etc., how</b> is it permitted to <b>bake</b> on <b>a Festival for Shabbat? He said to him:</b> One is permitted to bake on a Festival for Shabbat <b>due to the joining of cooked foods [<i>eiruv tavshilin</i>]</b> instituted by the Sages.
Rabba responded: <b>Due to</b> the practice of <b>the joining of cooked foods,</b> which was instituted by the Sages, <b>may one permit a Torah prohibition?</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: By Torah</b> law, whatever one <b>needs</b> for <b>Shabbat</b> may <b>be done on a Festival,</b> and the prohibition against performing labor during the Festival does not apply to preparations for Shabbat. <b>It was the Sages who decreed</b> that one may not bake on a Festival for Shabbat, as <b>a decree lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>one may bake on the Festival even for</b> use during <b>the week. And since the Sages required a joining of cooked foods, one has a conspicuous marker</b> reminding him that baking on the Festival for Shabbat is permitted but baking on the Festival for a weekday is prohibited.
Rabba <b>raised an objection to</b> Rav Ḥisda’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: If one wishes to slaughter <b>a dangerously</b> ill <b>animal</b> before it dies on its own and becomes prohibited for consumption, <b>he may not slaughter</b> it on a Festival day <b>unless</b> there is enough time so that <b>he can eat an olive-bulk of it roasted while it is still day.</b> Rabba reads this statement precisely: The <i>baraita</i> stipulates that the slaughter is permitted if <b>one can eat</b> the meat while it is still day, <b>although he is not required to</b> actually <b>eat</b> the meat. <b>Granted, according to my</b> position, <b>that I said</b> that one may rely on the principle: <b>Since, etc.,</b> this ruling is reasonable. <b>Since if one wants to eat he may eat, due to that</b> reason alone <b>he may slaughter</b> the animal. <b>But</b> according to <b>you, who</b> said <b>that we do not say</b> the principle of: <b>Since, etc., why may he slaughter</b> such an animal?
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him:</b> He is permitted to slaughter the animal <b>due to</b> the <b>monetary loss</b> that would be incurred by not slaughtering it, and not due to the principle of: Since, etc. Rabba asked rhetorically: <b>Will we permit a Torah prohibition due to monetary loss?</b>
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: Yes,</b> although this factor on its own does not mitigate the prohibition. Rather, <b>due to</b> the <b>monetary loss</b> that would otherwise be incurred, <b>one decided to eat an olive-bulk</b> of the meat, although he does not need to. <b>And</b> since <b>it is impossible</b> to eat even <b>an olive-bulk of meat without slaughtering</b> the animal, one is permitted to slaughter the animal.
Rabba <b>raised</b> another <b>objection to him: The shewbread</b> in the Temple

Daf 47a

may be <b>eaten on the ninth, tenth,</b> or <b>eleventh</b> days from when it is baked, <b>no less and no more. How so? In its</b> usual <b>manner</b> it is eaten <b>on the ninth</b> day after it was baked, as <b>it is baked on Shabbat eve</b> and <b>it is eaten on</b> the next <b>Shabbat, on the ninth</b> day from when it was baked. If <b>a Festival occurs on Shabbat eve,</b> the shewbread is not baked on the Festival day but rather on Thursday, the eve of the Festival. Consequently, <b>it is eaten on Shabbat</b> of the next week, <b>on the tenth</b> day from when it was baked.
