<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The Paschal lamb that</b> the priest <b>slaughtered not for its</b> own <b>purpose,</b> i.e., at the time of slaughter he said that his intent was to slaughter it as a different offering, e.g., a peace-offering or burnt-offering, rather than as a Paschal lamb; or if the priest <b>received</b> the blood, or <b>carried</b> the blood to the altar, or <b>sprinkled</b> the blood on the altar while saying that it was <b>not for the purpose</b> of the Paschal lamb; <b>or</b> if the priest performed the rites both <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose and not for its</b> own <b>purpose; or not for its</b> own <b>purpose and for its</b> own <b>purpose;</b> in all these cases, the Paschal lamb is <b>disqualified.</b>
<b>How</b> does one perform the rites <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose and not for its</b> own <b>purpose?</b> It is in a case where the priest said that his intent is <b>for the purpose of the Paschal lamb and for the purpose of a peace-offering.</b> And how does one perform rites <b>not for its</b> own <b>purpose and for its</b> own <b>purpose?</b> It is in a case where the priest says that the offering is <b>for the purpose of a peace-offering and for the purpose of a Paschal lamb.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma:</b> The mishna says: For its own purpose and not for its own purpose. <b>Did we learn</b> in the mishna concerning a case where the priest had both intentions while performing <b>one rite,</b> i.e., he stated both intentions while slaughtering? <b>Or, did we learn</b> in the mishna concerning a case where the priest had the two intentions while performing <b>two rites,</b> i.e., during one rite he said that it was for its own purpose and in another of the four rites he said that it was not for its own purpose?
Rav Pappa elaborates on the difference between these two different explanations. Shall we say that <b>we learn</b> in the mishna <b>with regard to one rite,</b> and therefore our mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who said that a person is held</b> accountable <b>even for the conclusion of his statement?</b> Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Meir disagree in the case of one who says: This animal is a burnt-offering and a peace-offering. Rabbi Yosei says that not only the beginning but also the conclusion of his statement is significant, and the animal has been consecrated as both a burnt-offering and a peace-offering. It is therefore unfit to be offered on the altar; rather, it must be sold when it develops a defect and the money used to purchase animals for both a burnt-offering and a peace-offering. And similarly in the case of our mishna, where the priest says that his intent is for the purpose of a Paschal lamb and for the purpose of a peace-offering, Rabbi Yosei would say that the animal has been slaughtered for both a Paschal lamb and a peace-offering, and is therefore disqualified.
<b>For if</b> our mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> surely <b>he said: Hold</b> one accountable for <b>the first expression,</b> and what he says after that is of no consequence. Rabbi Meir disagrees with Rabbi Yosei about the case of one who says: This animal is a burnt-offering and a peace-offering, for he maintains that the sacrifice has the status of a burnt-offering. Since the first term that he uttered was burnt-offering, the animal is consecrated as a burnt-offering, and it can no longer become a peace-offering. And similarly in the case of our mishna, where the priest says that his intent is for the purpose of a Paschal lamb and for the purpose of a peace-offering, Rabbi Meir would say that the animal has been slaughtered only for a Paschal lamb and the offering is fit.

Daf 60a

<b>Or perhaps</b> the mishna meant to <b>teach</b> a case of <b>two rites.</b> During the first rite, one had a particular intent, and during the second rite he had a different intent. Then, <b>even</b> according to <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that in general we <b>hold</b> one accountable for <b>the first expression, this</b> rule <b>applies</b> only <b>in one rite, but in two rites</b> even <b>he concedes that it disqualifies.</b> Since the second statement was made during a different rite, it too is significant.
<b>They said: To which</b> part of the mishna <b>does this</b> discussion refer? <b>If we say</b> that the discussion pertains to the case in the mishna of slaughtering an offering first <b>for a different purpose and</b> then <b>for its own purpose,</b> then <b>whether</b> these intentions are verbalized <b>during one rite or during two rites, whether according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir or according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> the offering <b>is disqualified from the first</b> statement, <b>as also Rabbi Yosei holds that a person is held accountable even for the conclusion of his statement.</b> That does not mean that the final statement is primary but that it too has value and complements the previous one. Therefore, since one initially intended to offer the Paschal lamb for a different purpose, it was immediately disqualified. <b>Rather,</b> the question is concerning the case of slaughtering an animal first <b>for its own purpose and</b> then <b>for a different purpose; what</b> exactly are the parameters of that case?
The Gemara cites a series of sources in order to resolve this question. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the question from what is taught in the mishna: <b>A Paschal lamb</b> that one <b>sacrificed for a different purpose, and he received</b> the blood, <b>and carried</b> it to the altar, <b>and sprinkled</b> it <b>for a different purpose,</b> is disqualified. This needs clarification: <b>What</b> exactly <b>are the circumstances? If we say</b> that the case is exactly <b>as it was taught,</b> that these four rites are all performed for a different purpose, <b>why do I need</b> to say that <b>he intended</b> to perform <b>all of them,</b> i.e., the slaughter, receiving of the blood, carrying the blood to the altar, and sprinkling it upon the altar, for a different purpose? The offering has been <b>disqualified from the first</b> improper intention during slaughter.
<b>Rather, is this not what</b> the mishna <b>is teaching: A Paschal lamb</b> that one <b>slaughtered for a different purpose, or alternatively,</b> he <b>slaughtered it for its own purpose, but received</b> the blood, <b>and carried</b> the blood, <b>and sprinkled</b> the blood <b>for a different purpose, or alternatively, he slaughtered it, and received</b> the blood, <b>and carried</b> the blood <b>for its own purpose, but sprinkled</b> the blood <b>for a different purpose,</b> in all these situations the offering is disqualified? If so, <b>it is</b> a case of different intentions in <b>two rites,</b> and the mishna can also be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>For its own purpose and for a different purpose.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say</b> that one had these two intentions <b>during two</b> different <b>rites, that is</b> precisely the meaning of <b>the first clause</b> and there is no need to repeat it. <b>Rather, must we not</b> say that in this part of the mishna, one had both intentions <b>during one rite,</b> and the mishna is <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who said that a person is held accountable even for the conclusion of his statement?</b>
This proof is refuted: <b>No, actually</b> it is possible to explain that even the latter clause of the mishna is referring to a case in which one has conflicting intentions <b>during two</b> different <b>rites, and</b> the difference between the first clause and the latter clause of the mishna is as follows: <b>The first clause</b> is referring to a case in which <b>one is standing at</b> the time of <b>the slaughter and thinking about slaughtering</b> the animal as a different offering; <b>alternatively, he is standing</b> at the time of the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>and thinking about sprinkling</b> for a different purpose.
<b>The latter clause</b> of the mishna, on the other hand, is referring to a case in which <b>one is standing at</b> the time of <b>the slaughter and thinking about sprinkling</b> for a different purpose. For example, where <b>he said: I am hereby slaughtering the Paschal lamb for its own purpose,</b> but my intent is <b>to sprinkle its blood for a different purpose. And</b> the mishna <b>teaches us</b> a new <i>halakha</i>, <b>that one can intend from one rite to another rite,</b> meaning that one can disqualify an offering through an improper intention about an upcoming rite while performing an earlier rite. <b>And this was the question</b> raised <b>by Rav Pappa</b> on a different occasion. He asked if intent during one rite concerning the performance of a different rite can disqualify an offering.
Since our question has not been resolved, it is necessary to bring another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is taught in the last clause of the mishna: <b>Or for a different purpose and for its own purpose,</b> the offering <b>is disqualified.</b> The Gemara analyzes this statement: <b>What</b> exactly <b>are the circumstances? If we say</b> that it speaks <b>about two rites,</b> there is a difficulty: <b>Now</b> that <b>you</b> have already <b>said that</b> if the priest first performed a rite while intending that the offering be <b>for its own purpose, and</b> then performed a rite with the intention that it be <b>for a different purpose,</b> the Paschal lamb <b>is disqualified, is it necessary to say</b> that it is disqualified when the priest first performed a rite while intending that the offering be <b>for a different purpose, and</b> then performed a rite with the intention that it be <b>for its own purpose?</b> It is obvious that the offering is disqualified immediately with the first expression of intent.
<b>Rather, isn’t</b> the mishna addressing a case in which the priest has two intentions <b>during one rite? And since the last clause</b> of the mishna talks <b>about one rite, the earlier clause</b> of the mishna must <b>also</b> speak <b>about one rite,</b> and the mishna is according to Rabbi Yosei.
The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>No, actually</b> it is possible to explain that the last clause speaks <b>about two rites, and by right it was not necessary</b> to include this case, as it could have been inferred from the previous case. It was included for stylistic considerations: <b>Since</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> the case in which the rites are performed <b>for its own purpose and for a different purpose, it also taught</b> the case in which the rites are performed <b>for a different purpose and for its own purpose.</b>
The Gemara again attempts to bring a proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is taught in a different mishna: <b>If</b> one <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb with the intent that it be <b>for</b> those <b>who cannot eat it,</b> i.e., for people who physically cannot consume it; or <b>for</b> those who were <b>not registered for it,</b> i.e., for people who did not register in advance for this particular offering; or <b>for uncircumcised or ritually impure</b> people, whom the Torah forbids from consuming the Paschal lamb, <b>it is disqualified. Here,</b> in the mishna cited, <b>it is obvious</b> that one had this intent <b>during one rite,</b> as the mishna explicitly states that he had this intent during the slaughtering. <b>And since the latter clause,</b> which is the next mishna, speaks <b>about one rite, the first clause,</b> which is the current mishna, must <b>also</b> speak <b>about one rite,</b> and it is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
The Gemara refutes this proof. <b>Are</b> the two cases <b>comparable?</b> Need they be exactly parallel? Perhaps <b>this</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is. The latter clause,</b> the next mishna, speaks <b>about one rite,</b> whereas <b>the first clause,</b> the current mishna, speaks <b>either about one rite</b> and is not according to Rabbi Meir <b>or about two rites</b> and is even according to Rabbi Meir.
The Gemara further proposes: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution based on what was taught later in that other mishna: If one slaughtered the Paschal lamb with the intent that it be <b>for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it, it is valid.</b> This ruling must be clarified: <b>What</b> exactly <b>are the circumstances? If we say</b> that one had two intentions <b>during two</b> different <b>rites,</b> e.g., he slaughtered it for those who can eat it and sprinkled the blood for those who cannot eat it, <b>then the reason</b> that the sacrifice is valid <b>is that he had the</b> disqualifying <b>intention at</b> the time of the <b>sprinkling,</b> which does not invalidate the offering <b>because there is no intent concerning those who can eat it during the sprinkling.</b> That is, intent to feed the Paschal lamb to those who are unable to eat it invalidates the offering only during the slaughter but not during the sprinkling.
<b>But</b> if one had both intentions <b>during one rite, such as the slaughter, during which intent with regard to those who will eat</b> the offering <b>is effective,</b> the sacrifice <b>is disqualified.</b> However, this conclusion is difficult, <b>for we maintain that</b> if only <b>some of those who are to eat</b> the Paschal lamb are unable to do so, such as in this case, the offering is <b>not disqualified.</b>

Daf 60b

<b>Rather, doesn’t it</b> refer to a case in which one had both intentions during <b>one rite,</b> and nevertheless it is valid? <b>And since the latter clause</b> speaks about <b>one rite, the first clause,</b> the current mishna, must <b>also</b> speak about <b>one rite,</b> and yet the offering is disqualified, because even the conclusion of one’s statement is significant, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei.
The Gemara refutes this proof as it refuted the previous one: <b>Are</b> the two cases <b>comparable?</b> Perhaps <b>this</b> case is <b>as it is and that</b> case is <b>as it is.</b> There is no reason to equate the cases, as it is possible to say that <b>the latter clause</b> speaks <b>about one rite,</b> whereas <b>the first clause,</b> the current mishna, speaks <b>either about one rite or about two rites.</b> Therefore, there is no conclusive resolution to Rav Pappa’s question.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>A Paschal lamb that one slaughtered on the rest of the days of the year</b> other than the eve of Passover <b>for its own purpose and for a different purpose, what is its</b> status? The Gemara clarifies the two sides of the issue: <b>Does</b> the intent to offer the sacrifice <b>for a different purpose come and nullify</b> the intent to offer the sacrifice <b>for its own purpose</b> and thereby <b>make it valid, or not?</b> The law is that a Paschal lamb that was slaughtered for a different purpose at a time other than Passover eve attains the status of a peace-offering and is therefore valid. The question raised here is whether or not partial intent to slaughter the animal as a peace-offering rather than as a Paschal lamb suffices to validate the offering.
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said: I raised this question in the presence of Rabbi Yirmeya</b> and expressed my opinion: <b>Since</b> intent to offer the sacrifice <b>for its own purpose validates it at its proper time,</b> i.e., on the eve of Passover, <b>and</b> intent to offer the sacrifice <b>for a different purpose validates it not at its proper time,</b> i.e., the rest of the year, there is room to equate the two situations. <b>Just</b> as intent <b>for its own purpose, which validates it at its proper time, does not nullify</b> the intent to offer the sacrifice <b>for a different purpose,</b> i.e., if one intends to offer the sacrifice both for its own purpose and for a different purpose it is disqualified, <b>so too,</b> intent to offer the sacrifice <b>for a different purpose, which validates it not at its proper time, does not nullify</b> the intent to offer the sacrifice <b>for its own purpose, and it is disqualified.</b> It can be concluded from here that whenever one’s thoughts concerning an offering are a combination of validating and disqualifying intentions, the offering is disqualified.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said to me: No,</b> this reasoning is not to be relied upon. <b>If you say</b> this rule concerning the intent to offer a Paschal lamb applies when it is sacrificed <b>for a different purpose,</b> it is <b>because</b> this disqualification <b>applies to all offerings,</b> as slaughtering an offering for a purpose other than its own disqualifies all offerings to one extent or another. Therefore, intent for the sacrifice’s own purpose does not nullify intent for a different purpose. But <b>can you</b> necessarily <b>say</b> the same thing <b>about</b> the intent to slaughter a Paschal lamb <b>for its own purpose</b> at other times of the year, a disqualification <b>that does not apply to all offerings but to the Paschal lamb alone?</b> Only the Paschal lamb is disqualified if it is slaughtered for its own purpose not at its proper time, and therefore intent for a different purpose can indeed nullify intent for its own purpose.
Rav Dimi’s argument having been refuted, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> conclusion was reached <b>about</b> Rav Dimi’s question? <b>Rava said: A Paschal lamb that one slaughtered on the rest of the days of the year</b> with the intent that it be <b>for its own purpose and for a different purpose is valid.</b> The reason for this is as follows: <b>In an</b> otherwise <b>undetermined</b> situation, the animal <b>stands</b> to be offered <b>for its own purpose,</b> for one did not rescind its status as a Paschal lamb either verbally or by intent. <b>But nevertheless, when he slaughters it for a different purpose, it is valid.</b>
<b>Apparently,</b> then, the intent to offer the sacrifice <b>for a different purpose comes and nullifies</b> the presumed intent to offer it <b>for its own purpose;</b> the statement that one makes to slaughter the offering as a peace-offering rather than as a Paschal lamb has the power to remove it from its previous status as a Paschal lamb. Accordingly, we should <b>also</b> say that <b>when</b> the priest <b>slaughters</b> the animal both <b>for its own purpose and for a different purpose,</b> the intent to offer it <b>for a different purpose</b> carries more weight and <b>comes and nullifies</b> the stated intent to offer it <b>for its own purpose.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rava: Perhaps</b> a case <b>where</b> one explicitly <b>said</b> that he was slaughtering the offering for its own purpose and for a different purpose <b>is different from</b> a case <b>where he did not say</b> this. The proof of this is that if one slaughtered the Paschal lamb <b>for those who can eat it and those who cannot eat it, it is valid, but wherever he slaughters it only for the sake of those who cannot eat it, it is disqualified. Now, why</b> should this be? <b>Surely in an</b> otherwise <b>undetermined</b> situation, the animal <b>stands</b> to be offered <b>for those who can eat it.</b> This indicates that presumed intention cannot be equated with intention that is explicitly verbalized. <b>Rather,</b> a case <b>where</b> one explicitly <b>said</b> that he is slaughtering the animal for those who can eat it and those who cannot eat it <b>is different from</b> a case <b>where he did not say</b> this. <b>So too,</b> a case <b>where he</b> explicitly <b>said</b> that he is slaughtering the offering for its own purpose and for a different purpose <b>is different from</b> a case <b>where he did not say</b> this.
Rava <b>said to him: Are</b> the two cases <b>comparable? Granted, there,</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb and the purpose for which it is offered, <b>as long as</b> one <b>did not uproot</b> the animal’s status as a Paschal lamb <b>at</b> the time of <b>slaughter, in an</b> otherwise <b>undetermined</b> situation, <b>it certainly stands</b> to be offered <b>for its own purpose;</b> its standing as a Paschal lamb can be changed only if it is explicitly designated as something else. <b>But here,</b> with regard to a Paschal lamb and the people for whom it is slaughtered, <b>in an</b> otherwise <b>undetermined</b> situation, <b>does it stand</b> to be slaughtered <b>for those who</b> are registered to <b>eat it?</b>
This is not the case, for in the instance of every Paschal lamb, there is the possibility that <b>perhaps these will withdraw and others will come and register for it. For we learned</b> in a mishna: People can <b>register</b> for a particular Paschal lamb <b>and withdraw from it until it is slaughtered.</b> Therefore, it is possible that this Paschal lamb will not be suitable for its subscribers at the time of its slaughter, and it makes sense to distinguish between a situation in which one explicitly stated that it is for people who can eat it, in which case it is valid even if he intended it also for people who cannot eat it, and a situation in which he did not make an explicit statement. This is different from slaughtering a Paschal lamb not in its time, for in that case the offering maintains its previous status as a Paschal lamb until its status is explicitly changed through a verbal statement.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>a Paschal lamb that one slaughtered on the rest of the days of the year with a change of owner,</b> i.e., he slaughtered it not for the sake of its original owner, <b>what is its</b> status? <b>Is a change of owner like a change of sanctity?</b> A Paschal lamb whose sanctity is changed to that of a peace-offering now has the status of a peace-offering, and so too, a Paschal lamb that is slaughtered not for the sake of its original owner, an intention that at its proper time would disqualify the sacrifice, now has the status of a peace-offering. <b>And it validates it,</b> for a peace-offering that was slaughtered not for the sake of its original owner is valid. <b>Or,</b> perhaps <b>not,</b> for it remains a Paschal lamb and is disqualified.
<b>Rav Pappa said: I raised this question in the presence of Rava</b> and expressed my opinion: <b>Since a change in sanctity invalidates it</b> as an offering <b>in its proper time,</b> as if one intended it in its proper time as a peace-offering it is invalid, <b>and a change in owner,</b> i.e., one intended that the offering be for someone other than its owner, also <b>invalidates it in its proper time,</b> the following analogy is made: <b>Just as a change in sanctity, which invalidates it in its proper time, validates it</b> as an offering <b>after its proper time, a change in owner, which invalidates it in its proper time, also validates it</b> as an offering <b>after its proper time.</b>
<b>And</b> Rava <b>said to me: No,</b> this analogy is not to be accepted: <b>If you say</b> this <b>about a change in sanctity,</b> it is <b>because the disqualification it</b> causes <b>is in</b> the offering <b>itself,</b> for the disqualification relates to the very sanctity of the offering, <b>and it applies to all four of the rites,</b> for the disqualification caused by a change in sanctity can occur not only during the slaughter but also during any of the four rites performed with an offering.

Daf 61a

<b>And</b> furthermore, the disqualification following from a change in sanctity <b>applies after death.</b> If one consecrates an offering and dies, his son must bring the offering in his place, and it can be invalidated through a change in sanctity. Moreover, <b>it applies to communal</b> offerings <b>as it does to</b> the offerings of <b>an individual.</b> However, <b>can you</b> necessarily <b>say</b> the same thing <b>with regard to a change in owner</b> that does not have these characteristics? <b>Its disqualification is not in</b> the offering <b>itself; and it does not</b> apply <b>to all four rites</b> but only to the sprinkling of the blood on the altar; <b>and it does not</b> apply <b>after death,</b> for after the owner has died there is no true owner of the offering, and therefore, if the priest intends to offer it for someone else the offering remains valid; <b>and it does not</b> apply <b>to communal</b> offerings <b>as it does to</b> the offerings of <b>an individual,</b> since it is not possible to have in mind a different owner, as it is owned by the whole community.
<b>And even though two</b> of these differences <b>are not</b> fully <b>accurate</b> and can be disputed, as will be explained, <b>two, at least, are accurate.</b> The Gemara explains the lack of accuracy: <b>For what is different about a change in owner</b> that defines <b>its disqualification</b> as <b>not being in</b> the offering <b>itself? Is it that its disqualification is merely</b> due to <b>thought?</b> If so, it is possible to say that <b>a change of sanctity is also merely a disqualification</b> due to <b>thought</b> and not in the offering itself, and therefore there is no real difference.
<b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to <b>that which was said,</b> that <b>a change in owner does not</b> apply <b>after death,</b> there is the following difficulty: <b>According to Rav Pineḥas, son of Rav Ami, who said that</b> the disqualification resulting from <b>a change in owner applies after death,</b> so that if the offering of the deceased was brought for a different person, the son of the deceased must bring another offering in his father’s name, <b>what is there to say?</b> However, <b>at least two</b> of these differences <b>are accurate.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> Rav Pappa’s suggestion should be rejected, and <b>Rava said: A Paschal lamb that one slaughtered on the rest of the days of the year with a change of owner is considered like one that does not have an owner.</b> In other words, it is considered like a Paschal lamb that was slaughtered not for the sake of its owner <b>at its</b> proper <b>time</b> on Passover eve, <b>and it is disqualified.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>for</b> people <b>who cannot eat it</b> or for <b>those who did not register</b> in advance to eat it, or if one slaughtered it for <b>people who are uncircumcised or for those who are ritually impure,</b> whom the Torah prohibits from eating the Paschal lamb, it <b>is disqualified.</b> However, if one slaughtered it <b>for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it; for those who have registered for it and for those who have not registered for it; for the circumcised and for the uncircumcised; for the ritually impure and for the ritually pure, it is valid,</b> for a partially invalid intent does not disqualify the offering.
If one <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>before midday it is disqualified, as it is stated:</b> “And the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel shall slaughter it <b>in the afternoon”</b> (Exodus 12:6). If he <b>slaughtered it before the daily</b> afternoon <b>offering it is valid, as long as another</b> person <b>stirs its blood</b> in order to prevent it from congealing <b>until the</b> blood of the <b>daily offering is sprinkled. And if</b> the blood of the Paschal lamb <b>is sprinkled</b> before the blood of the daily offering, <b>it is</b> nonetheless <b>valid,</b> as this change does not disqualify the offering.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>How so</b> the case of slaughtering the Paschal lamb <b>for those who cannot eat it?</b> It is a case where one slaughtered it <b>for the sake of a sick person or for the sake of an old person</b> who is unable to eat even an olive-sized portion of the Paschal lamb. <b>How so</b> the case of slaughtering the Paschal lamb <b>for those who did not register for it?</b> It is a case where <b>one group registered for it, and one slaughtered it for the sake of a different group.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> which are not explicitly written in the Torah, derived? The Gemara answers: <b>As the Sages taught</b> with regard to the verse: “And if the household be too little for a lamb, then he and his neighbor who is close to his house shall take one according to the number of the souls; according to every man’s eating you shall make your count for the lamb” (Exodus 12:4). <b>“According to the number of” teaches that the Paschal lamb is slaughtered only for those who have registered for it.</b> Everything is done according to the number of people who have registered before the slaughtering.
I <b>might</b> have thought that if <b>he slaughtered it for those who did not register for it, he would be</b> considered <b>as one who has violated a commandment,</b> but nonetheless the offering would be <b>valid</b> after the fact. Therefore, <b>the Torah teaches</b> this law with the double formulation of <b>“according to the number”</b> and <b>“you shall make your count”; the verse repeated it to make</b> this requirement <b>indispensable,</b> so that the offering is disqualified if it is slaughtered for those who did not register for it.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The term “you shall make your count [<i>takhosu</i>]” <b>is Aramaic [<i>Sursi</i>], like one who says to his fellow: Slaughter [<i>kos</i>] me this lamb,</b> to teach that the registration must take place before the slaughtering.
<b>We have found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that a Paschal lamb slaughtered <b>for those who have not registered for it</b> is disqualified. But <b>from where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that it is similarly disqualified if it is slaughtered <b>for those who cannot eat it?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>the verse says: “According to every man’s eating you shall make your count”; those who eat it are juxtaposed,</b> and thereby equated, <b>to those who are registered</b> for it. This teaches that just as the offering is disqualified if it is slaughtered for those who did not register for it, it is likewise disqualified if it is slaughtered for those who cannot eat it.

Daf 61b

If one <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>for</b> people who are <b>circumcised on condition that uncircumcised</b> people <b>achieve atonement through the sprinkling</b> of its blood, i.e., although the uncircumcised people are prohibited from eating the Paschal lamb, it was his intention that they achieve atonement through the blood of the offering, <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The offering is <b>disqualified. Rabba said:</b> It is <b>valid.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> it is <b>disqualified</b> because <b>intent</b> that the offering should be <b>for uncircumcised</b> people has sufficient force to disqualify the offering <b>at</b> the time of <b>the sprinkling. Rabba said</b> that it is <b>valid</b> because <b>intent</b> that the offering should be for <b>uncircumcised</b> people can only disqualify the offering during the slaughter and <b>not during the sprinkling.</b>
<b>Rabba said: From where do I</b> derive to <b>say this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: I <b>might</b> have thought that an uncircumcised person <b>would disqualify the</b> other fit <b>members of the group who come with him. And</b> it may be inferred <b>logically</b> to the contrary that he does not disqualify the others: <b>Since lack of circumcision disqualifies</b> a Paschal lamb slaughtered for that person, <b>and</b> similarly, <b>ritual impurity disqualifies</b> it, the following can be said: <b>Just as</b> with <b>ritual impurity, partial impurity was not made to be like full impurity,</b> meaning that if one member of the group for which the offering is slaughtered is ritually impure, the offering is not disqualified for the entire group, <b>so too, with lack of circumcision; partial lack of circumcision was not made to be like full lack of circumcision,</b> meaning that if one member of the group is uncircumcised, the offering is not disqualified as it would be if all members of the group were uncircumcised.
<b>Or</b> perhaps <b>go this way</b> and maintain the following: <b>Since lack of circumcision disqualifies</b> the offering, <b>and</b> similarly, intent to eat the offering beyond the allotted <b>time disqualifies</b> the offering, this can be said: <b>Just as</b> if one said at the time of the slaughter that he intended to eat part of the offering beyond the allotted <b>time, partial</b> invalid intent <b>was made to be like</b> intent to eat the <b>entire</b> offering at an invalid <b>time,</b> and the offering is disqualified, <b>so too, with lack of circumcision; partial lack of circumcision was made to be like full lack of circumcision,</b> and the offering is disqualified.
<b>Let us see to which it is similar,</b> i.e., which comparison seems more reasonable: Do <b>we derive a matter,</b> namely, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to uncircumcised males, <b>that does not apply to all offerings, from</b> another <b>matter,</b> namely, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the ritually impure, <b>that does not apply to all offerings,</b> as when it comes to other offerings, one who is ritually impure may send his offering with a proxy and thereby achieve atonement? <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to intent to eat the offering beyond the allotted <b>time, which applies to all</b> other <b>offerings, should not</b> be used to <b>prove</b> anything about our case.
<b>Or,</b> perhaps, <b>go this way: We derive a matter,</b> namely, the law with regard to uncircumcised males, <b>for which no allowance</b> is made <b>from its rule, from a matter,</b> namely improper intent with regard to the time, <b>for which no allowance</b> is made <b>from its rule,</b> as there are no exceptions for either of these two disqualifications. <b>And</b> the law with regard to <b>ritual impurity should not</b> be used to <b>prove</b> anything, <b>as</b> there are circumstances in which <b>an allowance</b> is made <b>from its rule.</b> Under certain circumstances it is permitted to offer the Paschal lamb while ritually impure, such as when the entire Jewish people is ritually impure.
In order to resolve this issue, <b>the verse states: “This,”</b> as it says: “And the Lord said to Moses and Aaron: This is the ordinance of the Passover: No stranger shall eat of it; but every man’s servant that is bought for money, when you have circumcised him, then shall he eat of it” (Exodus 12:43–44). <b>What</b> is implied from the emphasis of <b>“this”? If you say</b> that it comes to teach that if <b>all</b> the members of the group are <b>uncircumcised</b> the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> but if only <b>part of</b> the group is uncircumcised <b>it is not disqualified, this is derived from</b> the words <b>“and all uncircumcised males,”</b> in the verse: “And all uncircumcised males shall not eat of it” (Exodus 12:48). The amplification indicated by the word all teaches that the offering is invalidated only if all members of the group are uncircumcised.
<b>Rather, is this not what it is teaching: The verse states: “And all uncircumcised</b> males,” to teach that only if <b>all</b> members of the group are <b>uncircumcised is</b> the offering <b>disqualified,</b> but if only <b>part</b> of the group is <b>uncircumcised it is not disqualified. And if you say</b> that <b>the same is true of sprinkling</b> the blood of the offering, i.e., that if it is done for a group whose members are <b>all uncircumcised,</b> the offering <b>is in any event disqualified;</b> therefore <b>the verse states: “This,”</b> to restrict application of this law and teach: <b>It is during slaughter that if all</b> members of a group are <b>uncircumcised,</b> the offering <b>is disqualified; but during sprinkling, even</b> if <b>all</b> members of the group are <b>uncircumcised, it is not disqualified.</b>
<b>And if you say: What is the leniency of sprinkling</b> such that this intent for a group whose members are all uncircumcised disqualifies the offering only during the slaughter but not during the sprinkling? Rabba’s reasoning is that <b>there is no intent concerning those who may eat</b> of the offering <b>during the sprinkling.</b> Intent to feed the Paschal lamb to those who are unable to eat it invalidates the offering only during the slaughter, but not during the sprinkling.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda</b> is of the opinion that, <b>on the contrary,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should be understood <b>in the opposite direction. The verse states: “And all uncircumcised</b> males,” teaching that only if <b>all</b> the members of the group are <b>uncircumcised is</b> the offering <b>disqualified,</b> but if only <b>part</b> of the group is <b>uncircumcised, it is not disqualified.</b> This applies during slaughter; <b>however,</b> during the <b>sprinkling, even</b> if only <b>part</b> of the group is uncircumcised <b>it is disqualified. And if you say</b> that <b>the same is true of sprinkling</b> in <b>that</b> the offering <b>is not disqualified unless all</b> members are uncircumcised; therefore <b>the verse states “this”</b> to restrict the application of this <i>halakha</i> and teach that it is only during <b>slaughter that part of</b> the group <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering, <b>but</b> during the <b>sprinkling even part of</b> the group <b>disqualifies</b> the offering.
<b>And if you say: What is the stringency of sprinkling</b> such that part of the group being uncircumcised disqualifies the offering during the sprinkling, but not during slaughter? The answer is that <b><i>piggul</i></b> status <b>is established only during sprinkling.</b> The status of <i>piggul</i> applies to an offering when one performs at least one of the rites with the intent that the offering be consumed outside the allotted time, but only if no rite was performed with some other invalid intent, such as intending that the offering be eaten outside its designated place. This can only be confirmed at the time of the sprinkling, which is the last of the four essential rites. Consequently, sprinkling is the rite most likely to disqualify an offering due to improper intent.
<b>Rav Ashi strongly objects to this</b> method of interpretation: <b>From where</b> do you derive <b>that this</b> expression <b>“and all uncircumcised</b> males” <b>means that all</b> the members of the group are uncircumcised? <b>Perhaps this</b> expression <b>“and all [<i>kol</i>] uncircumcised</b> males” <b>means that any</b> of its members <b>is uncircumcised.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One says</b> in the Torah: <b>“This,”</b> to teach that the offering <b>is not disqualified unless all of it</b>s members are <b>uncircumcised,</b> and <b>there is no difference between slaughtering and sprinkling.</b> Therefore, the dispute between Rabba and Rav Ḥisda must be based on some other proof text and issue. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: Rav Ḥisda and Rabba</b>

Daf 62a

<b>disagree with regard to this verse,</b> which is stated with regard to a different offering: <b>“And it shall be accepted for him to make atonement for him”</b> (Leviticus 1:4). It is inferred: <b>For him and not for his fellow.</b> One cannot achieve atonement through an offering that has been designated for someone else. Rabba and Rav Ḥisda disagree with regard to the halakhic conclusions that should be drawn from this law. <b>Rabba holds</b> that the law applies to <b>another</b> who is <b>similar to him: Just as he is eligible for atonement</b> through the sprinkling of the blood of this offering, <b>so</b> the law applies to <b>another who is eligible for atonement.</b> This comes <b>to exclude this uncircumcised person, who is not eligible for atonement.</b> Since an uncircumcised person is not fit for the Paschal lamb, slaughtering it for him does not disqualify the offering.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda holds</b> that with regard to <b>this uncircumcised person as well, since he is obligated</b> to bring the Paschal lamb, <b>he is</b> considered <b>eligible for atonement</b> through the Paschal lamb. Why is an uncircumcised person seen as obligated to bring the Paschal lamb? <b>Since if he wants, he can make himself fit</b> through circumcision, and the obligation will automatically apply to him. There is a way for him to include himself among those who eat the offering; therefore, he cannot categorically be considered someone who is not eligible for atonement. Consequently, slaughtering the Paschal lamb for him disqualifies the offering.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>But does Rav Ḥisda accept</b> this argument of <b>since?</b> Does he maintain that one can discuss a situation that does not exist due to the possibility that the present circumstances might change? <b>But it was said</b> that Rabba and Rav Ḥisda disagree about this as it pertains to the case of <b>one who bakes on a Festival for</b> use <b>during the week: Rav Ḥisda said he is flogged</b> for having violated the Festival by baking in order to eat the food on a weekday; <b>Rabba said he is not flogged.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Rabba said he is not flogged</b> for the following reason: <b>Since if guests arrive,</b> whatever he bakes will be <b>fit for him</b> to use on the Festival itself, and he will not be guilty of any transgression, <b>now too,</b> although guests have not yet arrived, the food is considered <b>fit for him, and he is not flogged.</b> At the time of the baking, the act was not unequivocally prohibited. <b>Rav Ḥisda said he is flogged; we do not state</b> the principle of <b>since.</b> At first glance, there is an internal contradiction with regard to the opinions of both Rabba and Rav Ḥisda.
The Gemara notes: <b>Granted,</b> the apparent contradiction between the first statement <b>of Rabba and</b> the second statement <b>of Rabba is not difficult. Here,</b> in the case of the Paschal lamb whose blood is sprinkled for an uncircumcised person, <b>an action is lacking,</b> as the person must undergo circumcision in order to become eligible to eat from the Paschal lamb. However, <b>there,</b> in the case of one who bakes on a Festival, <b>no action is lacking</b> on the part of the baker. <b>But</b> the first statement <b>of Rav Ḥisda</b> and the second statement <b>of Rav Ḥisda</b> are <b>difficult</b> to reconcile. <b>They say,</b> in answer to this contradiction: <b>When Rav Ḥisda does not</b> accept the principle of <b>since,</b> it is only <b>to be lenient</b> and exempt a person from lashes; however, <b>to be stringent</b> and disqualify the Paschal lamb, <b>he does</b> accept this line of reasoning.
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina:</b> The <i>baraita</i> quoted above <b>teaches: Since lack of circumcision disqualifies</b> a Paschal lamb <b>and ritual impurity</b> also <b>disqualifies</b> it, the following comparison applies: <b>Just as</b> in the case of <b>ritual impurity, partial impurity was not made to be like full impurity, so too,</b> in the case of <b>lack of circumcision, partial lack of circumcision was not made to be like full lack of circumcision.</b> The Gemara clarifies: With regard to <b>this ritual impurity, what are the circumstances? If you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>the ritual impurity of the people</b> who registered for the offering, then there is a difficulty. For <b>what</b> then is the meaning of the ruling in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>partial impurity was not made to be like full impurity?</b> It means <b>that if there are four or five people who are impure and four or five people who are pure, those who are impure do not disqualify those who are pure.</b>
This, however, is difficult, as <b>with regard to lack of circumcision as well,</b> those who are uncircumcised <b>do not disqualify</b> the offering, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: If one slaughtered the Paschal lamb <b>for</b> both <b>circumcised and uncircumcised people, it is valid. What is different</b> about the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>impurity, that</b> there <b>it is obvious to him</b> that those who are ritually impure do not disqualify the members of their group who are pure? <b>And what is different</b> about the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>lack of circumcision, that</b> there <b>he is in doubt</b> about the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> must certainly be explained as referring to the <b>impurity of the meat</b> of the offering. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the ruling in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>partial impurity was not made to be like full impurity?</b> It means <b>that if one of the limbs became impure, that which became impure we burn and the rest we eat.</b>
This conclusion is challenged: <b>How did you establish</b> this <i>baraita</i>? It was established as referring to a case of <b>impurity of the meat.</b> If so, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the same <i>baraita</i> as follows: <b>We derive a matter that does not apply to all offerings,</b> the case of uncircumcised men, <b>from a matter that does not apply to all offerings,</b> namely ritual impurity, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to intent to eat the offering outside the allotted <b>time, which applies to all offerings, should not</b> be used to <b>prove anything</b> about the case at hand. Now, <b>what</b> type of <b>impurity</b> is being discussed here? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>impurity of the meat, why</b> do you say that <b>it does not apply to all offerings?</b> This <i>halakha</i> certainly applies to all offerings.
<b>Rather, it is obvious</b> that the clause under discussion relates to <b>impurity of the people</b> who are to eat from the offering. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the statement that <b>it does not apply to all offerings?</b> It means <b>that with regard to all offerings, an uncircumcised person and one who is ritually impure</b> cannot eat from the offering, but nonetheless they can <b>send their offerings</b> with others who can sacrifice them on their behalf; <b>however, with regard to the Paschal lamb, an uncircumcised person and one who is impure cannot send their offerings.</b> Consequently, the Gemara arrives at the surprising conclusion that <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>impurity of the meat, while the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> relates to <b>impurity of the people.</b>
Ravina <b>said to</b> Mar Zutra: <b>Yes,</b> this explanation can be accepted. The <i>baraita</i> can be understood as <b>arguing from the</b> general <b>category of impurity,</b> which applies in one case and not in another, rather than from a specific type of impurity in both cases.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> a different answer: <b>The latter clause</b> is <b>also</b> referring to <b>impurity of</b> the <b>meat. And what is</b> the meaning of the statement that <b>it does not apply to all offerings?</b> It means <b>that with regard to all offerings, whether the fats</b> of the offering that are burned on the altar <b>have become impure and the meat</b> of the offering <b>remains,</b> or <b>the meat has become impure and the fats remain,</b> the priest <b>may sprinkle the blood,</b> and the offering is accepted through the burning of the sacrificial parts or through the priests’ consumption of the meat.
However, when it comes to <b>the Paschal lamb,</b> if <b>the fats have become impure and the meat remains</b> pure and fit to be eaten, the priest <b>may sprinkle the blood;</b> but if the <b>meat has become impure and the fats remain</b> pure and fit to be burned on the altar, <b>he may not sprinkle the blood,</b> because in the case of the Paschal lamb, the owner’s obligation to eat the meat is the essence of the offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>How did you establish</b> this <i>baraita</i>? It was established as referring to a case of <b>impurity of</b> the <b>meat.</b> If so, <b>say the next clause</b> of this same <i>baraita</i> as follows: <b>We derive a matter,</b> i.e., the <i>halakha</i> with regard to uncircumcised people, <b>for which no allowance</b> is made <b>from its rule, from a matter,</b> i.e., improper intent with regard to the time, <b>for which no allowance</b> is made <b>from its rule. And</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>ritual impurity should not</b> be used to <b>prove</b> anything, <b>as there are</b> circumstances in which <b>an allowance</b> is made <b>from its rule,</b> since it is permitted to offer the Paschal lamb while ritually impure. The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> type of impurity is being discussed here? <b>If you say</b> that it is

Daf 62b

<b>impurity of the meat, where is it permitted</b> to eat impure sacrificial meat? <b>Rather, it is obvious</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is talking here <b>about impurity of the people. And where is an allowance</b> made <b>from its rule?</b> It is made <b>in the community;</b> when the majority of the community is ritually impure, it is permitted to offer the Paschal lamb and eat it while impure.
The Gemara expresses surprise again: It turns out then that <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>impurity of the meat,</b> while <b>the latter clause</b> relates to <b>impurity of the people.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> and there is no difficulty, as the <i>baraita</i> <b>argues from the</b> general <b>category of impurity</b> without necessarily relating to the same type of impurity.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> a different answer: The <b>entire</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>impurity of the meat, and where is it permitted</b> to eat impure sacrificial meat? It is permitted <b>in</b> a case of the <b>impurity of the Paschal lamb, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A Paschal lamb that comes in impurity,</b> e.g., when the majority of the community is ritually impure and the offering may be brought in impurity, may also <b>be eaten in impurity, as from the very outset it came only to be eaten.</b> This is unlike the law with regard to other offerings that are brought in impurity; their blood is sprinkled on the altar, but their meat may not be eaten. Consequently, even the prohibition to consume impure sacrificial meat is permitted under certain circumstances.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> that teaches: The Paschal sacrifice may be a young lamb or goat less than one year old. In the case of <b>a Paschal lamb that has passed its</b> first <b>year,</b> so that it has automatically become a peace-offering, if <b>he slaughtered it at its</b> appointed <b>time</b> on Passover eve <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose</b> as a Paschal lamb, <b>and similarly,</b> if <b>he slaughtered another</b> offering, e.g., a lamb that had been sanctified as a peace-offering, <b>for the purpose of a Paschal lamb at its</b> set <b>time,</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree with regard to the status of the offering. <b>Rabbi Eliezer disqualifies</b> the offering; <b>and Rabbi Yehoshua validates it,</b> based on the principle that offerings brought for the purpose of other offerings are valid. The only exception is the Paschal lamb, which when brought for another purpose is invalid. According to Rabbi Yehoshua, in both of these cases the animal is not truly a Paschal lamb; rather, it is a peace-offering brought with the intent that it serve as a Paschal lamb.
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that the sacrifice is disqualified <b>is</b> that it was brought <b>at its</b> proper <b>time;</b> it is in this case that the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree. <b>But if it was not</b> brought <b>at its</b> proper <b>time, it is valid</b> according to everyone, as it is like any other peace-offering that was slaughtered for a different purpose. <b>But why</b> is this so? <b>Let us say: Since</b> slaughtering another sacrifice for the purpose of a Paschal lamb <b>disqualifies</b> it <b>at its</b> proper <b>time,</b> this should <b>also disqualify</b> it <b>not at its</b> proper <b>time.</b> Consequently, the ruling quoted above is difficult according to the opinion of Rav Ḥisda, who accepts the principle of since for the sake of stringency.
<b>Rav Pappa said: It is different there</b> in the case of another sacrifice slaughtered for the purpose of a Paschal lamb, <b>as the verse said: “And you shall say: It is a Passover sacrifice</b> to the Lord, Who passed over the houses of the children of Israel in Egypt when He smote Egypt, and delivered our houses. And the people bowed the head and prostrated themselves” (Exodus 12:27). The word <b>“it”</b> indicates that the Paschal lamb must be brought <b>as it is,</b> according to its details, without any change. <b>It,</b> the Paschal lamb, must <b>not</b> be offered <b>for the purpose of other</b> sacrifices; <b>and other</b> sacrifices must <b>not</b> be offered <b>for its purpose,</b> i.e., as a Paschal lamb. In both of these cases, the offering is disqualified.
It may now be inferred: <b>At its</b> proper <b>time,</b> on Passover eve, when the Paschal lamb <b>is disqualified</b> if it is brought <b>for the purpose of other</b> sacrifices, <b>other</b> sacrifices <b>are disqualified</b> according to Rabbi Eliezer if they are brought <b>for its purpose,</b> i.e., as a Paschal lamb. But <b>not at its</b> proper <b>time,</b> when a Paschal lamb offered <b>for the purpose of other</b> sacrifices <b>is valid, other</b> sacrifices offered <b>for its purpose</b> as a Paschal lamb <b>are</b> also <b>valid.</b> Since the verse’s use of the word “it” links the disqualifications of a Paschal lamb offered as a different sacrifice and any other sacrifice offered for the purpose of a Paschal lamb, the principle of since does not apply.
There is a fundamental problem in the mishna that was clarified during the course of a particular incident: <b>Rabbi Simlai came before Rabbi Yoḥanan. He said to him: Would the Master teach me the Book of Genealogies?</b> The Book of Genealogies was a collection of tannaitic teachings that formed a midrash on the book of Chronicles. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: Where are you from? He said to him: From Lod.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan further asked: <b>And where is your</b> present place of <b>residence?</b> He said to him: <b>In Neharde’a.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> I have a tradition that <b>we teach</b> these subjects <b>neither to Lodites nor to Neharde’ans, and certainly</b> not to <b>you who</b> comes <b>from Lod and your residence is in Neharde’a,</b> such that you have both shortcomings. Rabbi Simlai <b>pressured</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan until <b>he agreed</b> to teach him.
Rabbi Simlai <b>said to him: Teach me</b> the Book of Genealogies <b>in three months.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>took a clod</b> of dirt, <b>threw it at him,</b> and <b>said to him: Berurya, wife of Rabbi Meir</b> and <b>daughter of Rabbi Ḥananya ben Teradyon,</b> was so sharp and had such a good memory that she <b>learned three hundred <i>halakhot</i> in one day from three hundred Sages, and nonetheless she did not fulfill her responsibility</b> to properly learn the Book of Genealogies <b>in three years</b> because it is especially long and difficult. <b>And you say</b> that I should teach it to you <b>in three months?</b> After your inappropriate request, I am not inclined to teach you at all.
<b>When</b> Rabbi Simlai <b>was taking leave to go, he said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: Even so, <b>my teacher,</b> as I have already come, let me ask you a question: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> one who offers a Paschal lamb both <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose and for a different purpose,</b> in which case the offering is disqualified, and one who offers the sacrifice with the intent that it be both <b>for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it,</b> in which case the offering is not disqualified?
<b>He said to him: Since</b> I understand from your question that <b>you are a Torah scholar, come and I will tell you</b> the answer: When one sacrifices an offering <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose and for a different purpose,</b> the <b>disqualification is in</b> the offering <b>itself;</b> that is, the disqualifying intention relates to the sacrifice itself. In contrast, when one sacrifices an offering <b>for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it,</b> the <b>disqualification is not in</b> the offering <b>itself,</b> as the disqualifying intent relates to the people who are to eat from it.
Furthermore, when one sacrifices an offering <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose and for a different purpose, it is impossible to identify its prohibition;</b> that is, there is no way to differentiate between valid and invalid parts of the offering. In contrast, when one sacrifices an offering <b>for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it, it is possible to identify its prohibition.</b> If some of the people may eat it and some may not, it is possible to distribute the offering to each group and thereby determine which part of the offering is invalid.
Furthermore, the intent that the offering be <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose and for a different purpose applies</b> and can disqualify the offering <b>in</b> all <b>four rites,</b> namely: Slaughtering, receiving the blood, carrying the blood to the altar, and sprinkling it on the altar; however, the intent that it be <b>for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it does not</b> apply <b>during</b> all <b>four rites,</b> as it has no effect during the time of the sprinkling. Moreover, the intent that the offering be <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose and for a different purpose</b> is a disqualification <b>that applies to communal</b> sacrifices <b>as</b> it does <b>to individual</b> sacrifices; in contrast, the intent that it be <b>for those who can eat it and those who cannot eat it does not</b> apply <b>to the community as</b> it does <b>to an individual.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that careful analysis of these answers demonstrates the following: The argument that <b>its disqualification is in</b> the offering <b>itself and</b> the argument that <b>it is impossible to identify its prohibition are one</b> and the same <b>thing;</b> they are not two separate reasons. As, <b>what is the reason that</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>says</b> that when one brings an offering for a different purpose, <b>its disqualification is in</b> the offering <b>itself?</b> It is <b>because it is impossible to identify its prohibition,</b> and therefore the prohibition applies to the offering itself.
Having mentioned the Book of Genealogies, the Gemara notes that <b>Rami bar Rav Yuda said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> the following about it: <b>From the day the Book of Genealogies was hidden</b> and no longer available to the Sages, <b>the strength of the Sages has been weakened, and the light of their eyes has been dimmed,</b> as the book contained the reasons for many Torah laws and lists of genealogies that are now lost.
<b>Mar Zutra said:</b> The Book of Genealogies’ exposition of Chronicles was so extensive that it was said, in exaggeration, that the verses <b>from</b> the word <b>Azel</b> mentioned in the verse: “And Azel had six sons and these are their names: Azrikam, Bocru, and Ishmael and Sheariah and Obadia and Hanan; all these were the sons of Azel” (I Chronicles 8:38), <b>to</b> the word <b>Azel</b> mentioned in a different verse with the identical wording: “And Azel had six sons and these are their names: Azrikam, Bocru, and Ishmael and Sheariah and Obadia and Hanan; these were the sons of Azel” (I Chronicles 9:44), <b>bore four hundred camels of expositions</b> written about these verses.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> If one sacrifices a Paschal lamb for both circumcised and uncircumcised people and had in mind <b>first the circumcised people and then the uncircumcised people,</b> the offering is <b>valid.</b> But if he had in mind first <b>the uncircumcised people</b> and then <b>the circumcised people, it is disqualified.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about having in mind first <b>the circumcised people</b> and then <b>the uncircumcised people,</b> such <b>that</b> the offering <b>is valid?</b> One might say <b>that</b> in order to disqualify the sacrifice, <b>we require that all the people</b> he has in mind <b>be uncircumcised, and</b> this <b>is not</b> the case here, as some of them are circumcised. But if this is so, when he has in mind first <b>the uncircumcised people</b> and then <b>the circumcised people,</b> we should <b>also</b> say <b>that</b> in order to disqualify the sacrifice <b>we require that all the people</b> he has in mind <b>be uncircumcised, and</b> this <b>is not</b> the case here. What, then, is the difference between the two cases?

Daf 63a

The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say that <i>Aḥerim</i> hold that slaughter is not</b> legally significant <b>until the end,</b> meaning that the slaughter is considered to take place only at the end of the rite and not during the time it takes to perform the act of slaughter, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava</b> in a different context. <b>As Rava said: It is still a dispute,</b> meaning that the disagreement whether one is held accountable only for his first expression or also for the conclusion of his statement applies even when it is one’s clear intention that the status he wishes to confer should apply only at a particular time, e.g., if one says that an animal should be consecrated as a burnt-offering until midday and from then on as a peace-offering (Rabbeinu Ḥananel). The opinion of Rabbi Meir, referred to here as <i>Aḥerim</i>, is that one is held accountable only for his first expression.
<b>Therefore,</b> based on these two assumptions, if <b>one put the circumcised people before the uncircumcised people,</b> his statement with regard to <b>circumcised people applies</b> but his statement with regard to <b>uncircumcised people does not apply.</b> If the slaughter is legally considered to take effect in a single instant, and if one said that his intention is for circumcised people at that moment, his statement takes effect. In the reverse case, if <b>one put the uncircumcised people before the circumcised people,</b> his statement with regard to <b>uncircumcised people applies,</b> but his statement with regard to <b>circumcised people does not apply.</b>
<b>Rabba said: No,</b> we should not say this. <b>Actually, <i>Aḥerim</i> hold that slaughter is</b> legally significant <b>from beginning to end, and with what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where one decided in his mind</b> to slaughter the offering <b>for both of them, both circumcised and uncircumcised people, and he verbally expressed</b> his intention with the phrase: <b>For uncircumcised people, but did not have a chance to say: For circumcised people, before the slaughter was</b> already <b>finished</b> as he was saying: <b>For uncircumcised people. And it is with regard to this</b> point <b>that they disagree: Rabbi Meir,</b> who is <i>Aḥerim</i>, <b>holds that we do not require that one’s mouth and heart be the same;</b> what is legally significant is his verbal expression. Since he said: For uncircumcised people, he has disqualified the offering. <b>And the Rabbis hold that we require that his mouth and heart be the same.</b> Since he wanted to express his intent for both circumcised and uncircumcised people, he has not disqualified the offering.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>But does Rabbi Meir hold that we require that his mouth and heart be the same?</b> The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on a mishna in tractate <i>Terumot</i> that states: With regard to <b>one who intended to say</b> that the produce he has designated should be <b><i>teruma</i>, but he</b> mistakenly <b>said</b> the word <b>tithe;</b> or he intended to say <b>tithe but</b> mistakenly <b>said <i>teruma</i>;</b> or he intended to vow: <b>I will not enter this house, but</b> mistakenly <b>said: That</b> house, i.e., he mistakenly referred to a different house; or he intended to vow: <b>I will not derive benefit from this person, but he said: From that</b> person, i.e., he mistakenly referred to someone else; <b>he has not said anything until his mouth and heart are the same.</b> This is an unattributed mishna, and unattributed <i>mishnayot</i> are presumed to be authored by Rabbi Meir.
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> the following explanation: We are dealing with a case where the person expressed two different intentions within the act of slaughter itself, as valid slaughter involves cutting most of both the windpipe and the esophagus of the animal. <b>The first clause</b> is referring to a case where <b>he said:</b> I cut <b>the first</b> organ <b>for circumcised people and the second</b> organ <b>even for uncircumcised people, so that in the second</b> organ <b>even circumcised people are included.</b> Consequently, he had circumcised people in mind at each stage of the slaughtering. <b>The latter clause</b> is referring to a case where <b>he said:</b> I cut <b>the first</b> organ <b>for uncircumcised people</b> and <b>the second</b> organ <b>for circumcised people, so that in the first</b> organ <b>circumcised people are not included,</b> and his intent during that stage is solely for uncircumcised people.
<b>And Rabbi Meir follows</b> his own line of <b>reasoning, as he says</b> that <b><i>piggul</i> status can be conferred</b> upon an offering <b>at half of what renders it permitted.</b> In other words, <i>piggul</i> status applies not only when one has a disqualifying intent during the entire act that renders the animal permitted, e.g., while slaughtering both the windpipe and the esophagus, but even if one has the disqualifying intent during half of the act that renders the animal permitted, e.g., while slaughtering one of those two organs. <b>And the Rabbis</b> also <b>follow</b> their regular line of <b>reasoning, as they say</b> that <b><i>piggul</i> status cannot be conferred at half of what permits</b> it. Since he expressed his intent for both uncircumcised and circumcised people over the course of the entire act of slaughter, the offering is not disqualified.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who slaughters the Paschal lamb with leavened bread</b> still in his possession <b>violates a negative commandment,</b> as the Torah states: “You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread; neither shall the sacrifice of the festival of Passover be left until the morning” (Exodus 34:25). <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> one who slaughters <b>the daily</b> afternoon <b>offering</b> on Passover eve with leaven in his possession violates the commandment. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> One who slaughters <b>the Paschal lamb on the fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose</b> with leaven in his possession <b>is liable;</b> but if he slaughtered it <b>for a different purpose he is exempt. And</b> for <b>all other offerings</b> that one slaughters on Passover eve, when owning leaven is prohibited, <b>whether</b> he slaughtered them <b>for their</b> own <b>purpose or</b> he slaughtered them <b>for a different purpose, he is exempt.</b>
<b>And during the festival</b> of Passover, if one slaughtered the Paschal lamb <b>for its</b> own <b>purpose he is exempt.</b> Since a Paschal lamb that is slaughtered for its own purpose at an improper time is disqualified, it is not an offering at all and there is no violation of the commandment: “You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread.” However, if he slaughtered it <b>for a different purpose</b> and thereby validated the sacrifice as a peace-offering, <b>he is liable</b> for having sacrificed it with leaven in his possession. <b>And</b> for <b>all other offerings</b> that one slaughters on Passover, when it is prohibited to slaughter with leaven in one’s possession, <b>whether</b> he slaughtered them <b>for their</b> own <b>purpose</b> or he slaughtered them <b>for a different purpose, he is liable.</b> This is <b>with the exception of a sin-offering that he slaughtered for a different purpose</b> with leaven in his possession. Unlike other offerings, a sin-offering is disqualified if it is slaughtered for a different purpose, and therefore one does not violate the prohibition of “You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread.”
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: One is never liable</b> for having violated the commandment: “You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread” <b>unless the leavened bread belongs to the one who slaughters</b> the Paschal lamb, <b>or to the one who sprinkles</b> its blood,

Daf 63b

or <b>to one of the members of the group;</b> and he is liable <b>only if</b> the leaven <b>is with him in the Temple courtyard</b> itself. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> He is liable <b>even if</b> the leaven <b>is not with him in the Temple courtyard. With regard to what</b> principle do <b>they disagree? If you say</b> that <b>they disagree</b> with regard to whether the expression <b>“with”</b> indicates <b>next to,</b> namely, <b>that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish holds that “with”</b> always indicates <b>next to,</b> and therefore “You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread” means that the leaven must not be next to the one slaughtering the sacrifice, in the Temple courtyard itself, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that</b> when the verse says <b>“with,” we do not require</b> that the leaven be <b>next to</b> the slaughterer in order to transgress, then this is difficult, because <b>they have already disagreed about this once</b> before.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who slaughters a thanks-offering inside</b> the Temple courtyard while <b>its bread,</b> namely the forty loaves that are brought together with the offering, <b>is outside the wall, the bread has not become sanctified,</b> as the verse states: “And he shall offer with the thanks-offering unleavened cakes.” (Leviticus 7:12).
A question was raised with regard to this mishna: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase <b>outside the wall? Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It means <b>outside the wall of Beit Pagei,</b> the outermost wall around Jerusalem, <b>but</b> if the bread was merely <b>outside the wall of the Temple courtyard, it has been sanctified, as we do not require</b> that the bread, described as <b>“with”</b> the offering, be <b>next to</b> it in order to be sanctified. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> disagreed and <b>said: Even</b> if the bread was merely <b>outside the wall of the Temple courtyard, it has not been sanctified. Apparently,</b> he holds that <b>we require</b> that the bread described as <b>“with”</b> the offering be <b>next to</b> it in order to be sanctified. Since Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish have already disputed this issue, they presumably did not repeat this same dispute in other contexts.
<b>Rather,</b> say that <b>they disagree about an uncertain warning.</b> There is a general rule that the courts only administer corporal punishment if the transgressor was warned before he committed the transgression. The question arises as to whether punishments are administered after an uncertain warning, i.e., when it is unclear at the time of the warning whether or not the person being warned will actually transgress. It is possible to explain that this is the basis of the dispute with regard to leaven: If the leaven is outside the Temple courtyard, the one issuing the warning cannot be certain that the person he is warning actually has leaven in his possession at the time of the slaughter. The Gemara suggests that such a warning is considered an uncertain warning, and Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that an uncertain warning is a valid warning while Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish disagrees. However, this is difficult, as <b>they also disagreed about this once</b> before.
As <b>it was stated</b> that if a person said: I take <b>an oath that I will eat this loaf today, and the day passed and he did not eat it, Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish both said</b> that <b>he is not flogged</b> even though he violated his oath and thereby transgressed the prohibition of: “You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain” (Exodus 19:7). However, they disagree about the reason for this law. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: He is not flogged because it is a prohibition whose</b> transgression <b>does not involve an action,</b> as his transgression was in failing to eat the loaf, and there is a principle that <b>for any prohibition whose</b> transgression <b>does not involve an action one is not flogged; however, an uncertain warning is considered a</b> valid <b>warning.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: He is not flogged because it is an uncertain warning, and an uncertain warning is not considered a warning.</b> For example, if he is warned in the middle of the day that if he does not eat the loaf he will be flogged, the warning is uncertain because even if he does not eat the loaf at that moment he still has time to eat it later. <b>But for a prohibition whose</b> transgression <b>does not involve an action one is flogged.</b> Thus, Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish have already disagreed with regard to this issue as well, and there would have been no reason for them to repeat their dispute.
<b>They say</b> in answer to this: <b>Actually,</b> we can explain that <b>they disagree about</b> whether <b>“with”</b> indicates <b>next to, and it is necessary</b> to teach that they disagree about the case involving the leaven in addition to the case of the loaves of the thanks-offering, because the cases are not entirely comparable. <b>As, if they disagreed</b> only <b>with regard to leaven, I would have said</b> that <b>it is</b> only <b>with regard to that</b> case <b>that Rabbi Yoḥanan said that</b> when the verse says <b>“with,” we do not require</b> that the slaughterer have the leaven <b>next to</b> him in order to transgress, <b>because it is a prohibition, and wherever it is, it is.</b> On the eve of Passover in the afternoon one is prohibited to possess leaven anywhere.
<b>However, with regard to sanctification of the bread, it becomes sanctified only inside</b> the Temple courtyard. Consequently, <b>say that</b> in that case Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>concedes to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish that we require</b> that the bread described as <b>“with”</b> the offering be <b>next to</b> it. Therefore, <b>if it is inside, it is sanctified; and if not, it is not sanctified.</b> This is <b>just as it is</b> with regard to <b>a vessel used in the</b> Temple <b>service,</b> which sanctifies a meal-offering only when the meal is inside it and not when the meal is outside of it. Therefore, <b>it is necessary</b> to teach that the dispute applies in both cases.
<b>And had we been taught</b> the dispute only <b>with regard to sanctification of the bread, I would have said that</b> only <b>in this</b> case <b>did Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say that we require</b> that the bread described as <b>“with”</b> the sacrifice be <b>next to it,</b> such <b>that if it is inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>it is sanctified; and if not, it is not sanctified. But with regard to leavened bread, he concedes to Rabbi Yoḥanan that</b> when the verse says <b>“with,” we do not require</b> that the slaughterer have the leaven <b>next to</b> him in order to transgress, <b>for it is a prohibition and wherever it is, it is.</b> Therefore, <b>it is necessary</b> to say that they argued in both cases.
<b>Rav Oshaya asked Rabbi Ami</b> the following question: If <b>the slaughterer does not have</b> leaven in his possession <b>but one of the members of the group does have, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Ami <b>said to him: Is it written: You shall not offer</b> the blood of My sacrifice <b>with your leavened bread,</b> meaning you may not slaughter the Paschal lamb with the leaven of the slaughterer? <b>It is written: “You shall not offer with leavened bread”</b> (Exodus 34:25), meaning you may not slaughter it with anyone’s leaven and not necessarily leaven that belongs to the slaughterer.
Rav Oshaya <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>If so, even if someone at the end of the world</b> has leaven it should <b>also</b> be a violation. Since there is no limitation to this prohibition, it should apply even if the leaven belongs to someone who is not associated in any way with this Paschal lamb. Rav Ashi <b>said to him</b> that <b>the verse says: “You shall not offer,”</b> and the end of the verse states: <b>“Neither shall</b> the sacrifice of the festival of Passover <b>be left</b> until the morning.” The verse equates the two prohibitions, from which the following may be derived: <b>“You shall not offer with leavened bread”</b> applies to <b>those who are governed</b> by the prohibition of <b>“neither shall be left over,”</b> namely, the members of the group that registered for this Paschal lamb. People who are not part of this group are not obligated to ensure that the Paschal lamb does not remain until the morning; similarly, they are not taken into account with regard to the prohibition against sacrificing the offering while in possession of leaven.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Therefore,</b> based on this reason, <b>the priest who burns the fats</b> of the Paschal lamb <b>transgresses the negative commandment</b> of “You shall not offer” if he has leaven in his possession. <b>Since he is included in</b> the prohibition of <b>leaving over sacrificial parts</b> of the offering, he is also included in the prohibition against sacrificing the offering with leaven, although he is not one of the people who will eat this Paschal lamb.
The Gemara points out that <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Pappa: One who slaughters the Paschal lamb with leavened bread</b> in his possession <b>transgresses a negative commandment. When? When</b> the leaven belongs <b>to the slaughterer, or to the one who sprinkles</b> the blood, <b>or to one of the members of the group.</b> If leaven belonged <b>to someone at the end of the world, he is not bound to him,</b> meaning that the slaughterer need not take him into account. <b>And</b> whether <b>he slaughters</b> the animal, <b>or he sprinkles</b> the blood, <b>or he burns</b> the fats, he is <b>liable. But one who pinches</b> the neck of <b>a bird,</b> which is not a Paschal offering but a burnt-offering or sin-offering, if he does so with leaven in his possession <b>on the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, after the prohibition against owning leaven has taken effect, <b>he does not transgress anything.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who slaughters the Paschal lamb with leavened bread</b> in his possession <b>transgresses a negative commandment. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> one who slaughters <b>the daily</b> afternoon <b>offering</b> on the eve of Passover with leavened bread in his possession violates the prohibition. <b>They said to him: They stated</b> this prohibition <b>only with regard to the Paschal lamb. When</b> does one transgress the prohibition? <b>When the slaughterer, or the one who sprinkles</b> the blood, <b>or one of the members of the group has</b> leaven in his possession. <b>If someone at the end of the world had</b> leaven, <b>he is not bound to him.</b>
