The Gemara answers: <b>He holds in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Natan says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> In order for <b>a <i>zav</i></b> to become ritually impure, he <b>needs</b> to experience a discharge substantial enough to cause <b>a blockage of the tip of the</b> male <b>organ. But the Rabbis did not agree with him.</b> Thus, according to Rabbi Natan, a <i>zav</i> only becomes ritually impure if he experiences a discharge of a particular amount. <b>And one who experienced a seminal emission is compared to a <i>zav</i></b> and therefore the same amount of discharge is required in order to cause ritual impurity. Therefore, the ritual impurity of a leper is more severe than that of one who experienced a seminal emission, and the original <i>a fortiori</i> inference applies.
The Gemara asks: The expressions “any <i>zav</i>” and “anyone impure” teach that their respective categories are more inclusive than one would otherwise have thought. But <b>why do I</b> need the inclusive expression <b>“and any leper”?</b> What does the word “any” include? The Gemara explains: Since <b>it is written “any <i>zav</i>,” it is also written “any leper,”</b> so that the wording of the verse will be consistent.
The Gemara challenges the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> quoted above: <b>Rabbi Shimon spoke well</b> when he derived the three camps from which the three different classes of people are sent out from the verse: “That they send out from the camp any leper and any <i>zav</i> and anyone impure by reason of a corpse.” How does Rabbi Yehuda counter this argument?
The Gemara answers: <b>He needs that</b> verse <b>for that which was taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>if <i>zavin</i> and lepers pushed and entered</b> the Temple <b>courtyard during</b> the offering of <b>a Paschal lamb that is brought in</b> a state of <b>impurity,</b> when the majority of the nation are ritually impure due to contact with a corpse, that <b>perhaps they would be liable</b> for punishment for having violated the prohibition of entering the Temple while ritually impure. They are prohibited from entering even under such circumstances. <b>Therefore the verse states: “That they send out from the camp any leper and any <i>zav</i> and anyone impure by reason of a corpse”</b> (Numbers 5:2), which teaches us that <b>at a time when those impure due to a corpse are sent out, <i>zavin</i> and lepers are sent out</b> and are liable to <i>karet</i> for entering the Temple; but when <b>those impure due to a corpse are not sent out, <i>zavin</i> and lepers are not sent out,</b> meaning, they are not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for entering the Temple.
<b>The Master said</b> above: The fact that the verse does not just say <b>“<i>zav</i>”</b> but rather the inclusive expression <b>“and any <i>zav</i>”</b> comes <b>to include a person who experienced a seminal emission.</b> The Gemara notes: This exposition <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, for Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The tunnels</b> under the Temple <b>were not sanctified</b> with the sanctity of the Temple; <b>and a person who experienced a seminal emission is sent outside the two camps</b> just like a <i>zav</i>. The exposition quoted above supports this second ruling of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on what we learned in a mishna: The law governing <b>a person who experienced a seminal emission is like</b> the law governing someone who became ritually impure through <b>contact with a creeping animal. What, is</b> the intent <b>not</b> to compare them with regard to <b>their</b> respective <b>camps,</b> that one who experienced a seminal emission is prohibited from the same camps that are prohibited to one who touched a creeping animal? Thus, it follows that a person who experienced a seminal emission is permitted to enter the Levite camp. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> they are compared with regard to <b>their impurity,</b> in that each is impure only until the evening.
The Gemara expresses surprise: Why did the mishna need to teach that they are comparable with regard to <b>their impurity? Impurity until evening is</b> explicitly <b>written</b> in the Torah <b>about this one,</b> meaning that one who came into contact with a creeping animal is impure until the evening and then must undergo ritual immersion in order to become pure, as it states: “And for these you shall be unclean; whoever touches the carcass of them shall be unclean until evening” (Leviticus 11:24). <b>And impurity until evening is</b> explicitly <b>written about that one,</b> one who experienced a seminal emission, as it states: “And if semen goes out from a man, then shall he bathe all his flesh in water and be unclean until evening” (Leviticus 15:16). <b>Rather, is it not</b> that they are compared with regard to <b>their camps,</b> which is not explicit in the Torah?
The Gemara answers: <b>No, actually</b> it is possible to say that the comparison relates to <b>their impurity, and it teaches us that a person who experienced seminal emission is</b> governed by <b>the same</b> law <b>as</b> someone who became ritually impure through <b>contact with a creeping animal</b> in another regard: <b>Just as contact with a creeping animal imparts ritual impurity through an accident,</b> even when the contact is unintentional, <b>so too a person who experienced a seminal emission becomes ritually impure through an accident,</b> even when the emission of semen is unintentional, unlike the law governing a <i>zav</i>.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b>

Daf 68a

We learned in the continuation of the previously cited mishna that the law governing <b>one who had relations with a menstruating woman is like</b> the law governing <b>one who is ritually impure due to a corpse. With regard to what</b> did they formulate this comparison? <b>If we say</b> they made the comparison with regard to <b>their impurity,</b> that they are both impure for seven days, <b>impurity for seven days is</b> explicitly <b>written about this one,</b> someone who had relations with a menstruating woman, <b>and impurity for seven days is</b> explicitly <b>written about that one,</b> someone who is impure due to a corpse, and so there would be no need for the mishna to inform us of these laws.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> that they are compared with regard to <b>their camps,</b> to teach that one who had relations with a menstruating woman is sent out from the same camp as someone ritually impure due to a corpse? <b>And from the</b> fact that the comparison in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna relates to <b>their camps,</b> it stands to reason that the comparison in <b>the earlier clause</b> of that same mishna between one who experienced a seminal emission and one who became ritually impure through contact with a creeping animal <b>also</b> relates to <b>their camps,</b> and not as we explained it earlier. The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Are</b> the cases <b>comparable? This</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is;</b> each part of the mishna formulates its own comparison.
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> from that which was taught: The legal status of <b>a leper is more severe than a <i>zav</i> and</b> the legal status of <b>a <i>zav</i> is more severe than one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> with regard to which camps they are prohibited to enter; <b>to the exclusion of a person who experienced a seminal emission, for</b> the legal status of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse is more severe than his</b> status.
The Gemara wishes to clarify this enigmatic statement: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the words, <b>to the exclusion</b> of a person who experienced a seminal emission? <b>Is</b> the intent <b>not</b> that <b>he is excluded from the category of a <i>zav</i> and enters the category of one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse, for</b> the legal status of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse is more severe than his</b> status, as his impurity lasts for seven days, <b>and</b> nonetheless <b>he is permitted in the Levite camp.</b> We should therefore learn from here that someone who experienced a seminal emission is also permitted in the Levite camp.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>No,</b> the intent is that one who experienced a seminal emission is <b>excluded from the camp of one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse, and he enters the camp of a <i>zav</i>,</b> meaning that he is excluded from the Levite camp, just like a <i>zav</i>. <b>And although</b> the legal status of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse is more severe than his</b> status <b>and</b> he <b>is permitted in the Levite camp,</b> and so it would seem that one who experienced a seminal emission should similarly be permitted, nonetheless, <b>we compare him to that to which he is similar.</b> The ritual impurity of one who experienced a seminal emission is fundamentally similar to that of a <i>zav</i>, and different from that of one who is ritually impure due to a corpse.
<b>A <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi:</b> “If there be among you a man that is impure by reason of a nocturnal occurrence, he shall go outside the camp, he shall not come within the camp” (Deuteronomy 23:11). This verse may be expounded as follows: <b>“He shall go outside the camp,” this is the camp of the Divine Presence. “He shall not come within the camp,” this is the Levite camp. From here</b> we derive that <b>a person who experienced a seminal emission must go out from two camps.</b>
Rav Yitzḥak <b>said to</b> the <i>tanna</i>: Something is amiss in the wording of this <i>baraita</i>: <b>You have not yet brought him in</b> and <b>you</b> already <b>send him out?</b> In other words, in order to say that the words “he shall not come within the camp” teach that a person who experienced a seminal emission must leave the Levite camp, you must first prove that he was there to begin with. <b>Another version,</b> which differs from the previous one only in formulation but not in substance: <b>You have not yet sent him out</b> and <b>you</b> already <b>bring him in?</b> In other words, how can you say that the words “he shall not come within the camp” refer to the Levite camp if we have not yet learned that he must leave that camp in the first place? <b>Rather,</b> emend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say</b> that it reads as follows: <b>“Outside the camp,” this is the Levite camp. “He shall not come within the camp,” this is the camp of the Divine Presence.</b>
<b>Ravina strongly objects to</b> this exposition of the verse: <b>Say</b> that both <b>this and that</b> refer <b>to the camp of the Divine Presence,</b> that he must leave the camp of the Divine Presence and may not enter it; and the repetition comes to teach <b>that he violates a positive</b> command to leave the camp <b>and a negative</b> command barring entry into the camp. The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let the verse say</b> only: <b>“He shall go outside the camp, he shall not come within,”</b> or “within it.” <b>Why do I</b> need the repetition of the word <b>“the camp”? Conclude from this</b> that it is <b>to give him a different camp;</b> it refers not to the same camp that he left but rather to a different one.
We learned in the mishna that <b>cleaning the intestines</b> of the Paschal lamb overrides Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> meant by <b>cleaning the intestines? Rav Huna said:</b> It means <b>that he punctures them with a knife</b> allowing the excrement to exit. <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Rav said:</b> It refers to the removal of <b>the secretions of the intestine, which come out through the pressure of the knife</b> and would ruin the entire sacrifice and cause it to become putrid were they allowed to remain in the intestines.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said: What is Ḥiyya bar Rav’s reason</b> for explaining the term in this manner? <b>As it is written:</b> “Then shall the lambs feed as in their pasture, <b>and the ruins of the fat ones [<i>meḥim</i>] shall wanderers eat”</b> (Isaiah 5:17). <b>From where may it be inferred</b> that this verse is in any way connected to our discussion? <b>As Rav Yosef translates</b> this verse: <b>“And the righteous shall inherit the possessions of the wicked.”</b> This indicates that the word <i>meḥim</i>, understood by Rav Yosef as referring to the wicked, is a term of degradation. This led Ḥiyya bar Rav to interpret the mishna’s clause with regard to cleaning [<i>miḥui</i>] the intestines as referring to removing the repulsive matter inside.
Having explained the latter part of the verse in Isaiah, the Gemara turns to the beginning of that same verse. <b>“Then shall the lambs feed as in their pasture</b> [<b><i>kedavram</i>].” Menashya bar Yirmeya said that Rav said: As was said about them</b> [<b><i>kamedubar bam</i>],</b> i.e., as the prophet promised. To <b>what</b> prophecy does the verse refer with the expression <b>“as was said about them”? Abaye said:</b> It is referring to the continuation of the verse: <b>“And the ruins of the fat ones shall wanderers eat.” Rava said to him</b> that this cannot be: <b>Granted, were it written</b> only <b>“the ruins</b> of the fat ones,” it would be possible to explain <b>as you said. Now that it is written “and the ruins,”</b> with the addition of the word “and,” this indicates that <b>it states something else,</b> and the verse contains two separate prophecies.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> This verse should be understood <b>in accordance with</b> what <b>Rav Ḥananel said that Rav said. For Rav Ḥananel said that Rav said: In the future, the righteous will resurrect the dead. It is written here: “Then shall the lambs feed [<i>vera’u</i>] as in their pasture,”</b> the lambs serving as an allusion to the righteous, <b>and it is written there:</b> “Tend your people with your staff, the flock of your heritage, who dwell alone in the wood, in the midst of Carmel; <b>let them feed [<i>yiru</i>] in Bashan and Gilad as in the days of old”</b> (Micah 7:14).
<b>“Bashan” is</b> an allusion to the prophet <b>Elisha, who came from the Bashan.</b> How do we know that Elisha came from Bashan? <b>As it is stated:</b> “Joel the chief, and Shafam the next, <b>and Yanai and Shafat in the Bashan”</b> (I Chronicles 5:12), <b>and it is written: “Here is Elisha ben Shafat who poured water on the hands of Elijah”</b> (II Kings 3:11). <b>“Gilad” is</b> an allusion to <b>Elijah, as it is stated: “And Elijah the Tishbite, who was of the inhabitants of Gilad, said”</b> (I Kings 17:1). Based on the similarity of the verses and the verbal analogy between the two instances of the word “feed,” we learn that in the future the righteous will be like Elijah and Elisha, who resurrected the dead.
This idea is derived from a different source as well. <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said that Rabbi Yonatan said: In the future the righteous will resurrect the dead, as it is stated: “Old men and old women shall yet again dwell in the streets of Jerusalem, and every man with his staff in his hand for very age”</b> (Zechariah 8:4). <b>And</b> the staff will then be used as it was used by Gehazi when Elisha sent him to bring the son of the Shunamite woman back to life, as <b>it is written: “And you shall lay my staff on the face of the child”</b> (II Kings 4:29).
As we have been discussing the world of the future and the resurrection of the dead, the Gemara cites additional statements on these topics. <b>Ulla raised a contradiction</b> between two verses: In one verse <b>it is written: “He will destroy death forever,</b> and the Lord God will wipe away tears from off all faces, and the insult of His people shall He take away from off all the earth; for the Lord has spoken” (Isaiah 25:8). <b>And</b> in another verse <b>it is written:</b> “There shall be no more there an infant who lives a few days, nor an old man who has not filled his days; <b>for the youngest shall die a hundred years old”</b> (Isaiah 65:20), implying that people will live long lives, but death will not be totally eradicated. Ulla answers: This is <b>not difficult: Here,</b> in the first verse, it is referring to <b>Jews,</b> who will not die at all, while <b>there,</b> in the second verse, it is referring to <b>gentiles,</b> who will live exceedingly long lives but eventually die. The Gemara asks: <b>What are gentiles doing there</b> in the future world? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written: “And strangers shall stand and feed your flocks, and the sons of the alien shall be your plowmen and your vineyard workers”</b> (Isaiah 61:5).
<b>Rav Ḥisda raised a contradiction</b> between two verses: In one verse <b>it is written: “Then the moon shall be confounded and the sun ashamed,</b> when the Lord of Hosts shall reign in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, and before His elders will be His glory” (Isaiah 24:23), which indicates that in the future there will be no light at all from the sun or the moon. <b>And</b> elsewhere <b>it is written: “Moreover the light of the moon shall be as the light of the sun, and the light of the sun shall be sevenfold, as the light of seven days,</b> on the day that the Lord binds up the breach of His people and heals the stroke of their wound blow” (Isaiah 30:26), which indicates that the light of the sun and moon will be even brighter than before. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult: Here,</b> where it says that the sun and the moon will be ashamed before the glow of the Divine Presence, it is referring <b>to the World</b>-<b>to</b>-<b>Come,</b> which is an entirely different world; while <b>there,</b> where it says that their light will increase, it is referring <b>to the days of the Messiah.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, who said</b> that <b>there is no difference between this world and the days of the Messiah except for subjugation</b> to foreign <b>kingdoms,</b> but in all other ways, including the illumination of the celestial bodies, the world order will remain unchanged, <b>what is there to say</b> to reconcile these verses? The Gemara answers: <b>This and that</b> refer <b>to the World</b>-<b>to</b>-<b>Come, and</b> it is <b>not difficult: Here,</b> where it says that the sun and the moon will be totally ashamed, it refers to <b>the camp of the Divine Presence;</b> while <b>there,</b> where it says that the light of the sun and moon will be greatly magnified, it refers to <b>the camp of the righteous.</b>
<b>Rava raised a contradiction</b> between two parts of a verse. <b>It is written: “I put to death and I make live”</b> (Deuteronomy 32:39) <b>and</b> in that same verse <b>it is written: “I wound and I heal.” Now</b> once it says that <b>He gives life</b> to the dead, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that <b>He</b> can <b>heal</b> those who are still alive? What then does the second clause add to the first? <b>Rather,</b> the second clause clarifies the first one: <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: Those</b> same people <b>whom I put to death I will bring to life, just as</b> those people <b>whom I wounded I will heal.</b> In other words, the verse means to say that just as God will heal the same people He wounded, so will He revive those He put to death; and not, as the verse might otherwise have been understood, that He puts some people to death and gives life to others.
Similarly, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“I put to death and I make live”;</b> one <b>might have thought</b> that this refers to <b>death for one</b> person <b>and life,</b> i.e., birth, <b>for another</b> person, <b>in the customary manner of the world.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “I wound and I heal”; just as the wounding and the healing</b> mentioned here clearly refer to the <b>same</b> person, <b>so too death and life</b> refer to the <b>same</b> person. <b>From this</b> verse, there is <b>a refutation to those who say that there is no Torah source for the resurrection of the dead,</b> for it is explicitly mentioned in this verse. <b>Alternatively,</b> the verse can be explained as follows: <b>At first, those whom I put to death I will bring to life,</b> but they will be revived with the same injuries that they had when they died; <b>and subsequently, those whom I wounded I will heal,</b> meaning that their injuries will be healed after they are resurrected.

Daf 68b

We learned in the mishna that when the eve of Passover occurs on Shabbat, <b>burning the fats</b> of the Paschal lamb overrides Shabbat. The Gemara notes that <b>it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon said: Come and see how dear is a mitzva</b> performed <b>in its</b> proper <b>time. For burning the fats and limbs and inner fats is valid all night</b> and it would have been possible to wait until the conclusion of Shabbat and burn them at night, but nonetheless <b>we do not wait with them until nightfall;</b> rather, we burn them immediately, even on Shabbat.
The mishna also taught that <b>carrying</b> the Paschal lamb through a public domain, <b>bringing it</b> from outside the Shabbat limit and cutting off its wart do not override Shabbat. The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another mishna in tractate <i>Eiruvin</i>, which teaches: <b>One may cut off a wart</b> by hand on Shabbat <b>in the Temple but not in</b> the rest of <b>the country</b> outside the Temple. <b>And if</b> the wart is to be removed <b>with an instrument, it is forbidden</b> both <b>here,</b> in the Temple, <b>and there,</b> outside the Temple. From here we see that in the Temple cutting off a wart, at least by hand, is permitted.
Two <i>amora’im</i>, <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina,</b> disagreed about how to resolve this contradiction. <b>One</b> of them <b>said:</b> Both <b>this</b> mishna in <i>Pesaḥim</i> <b>and that</b> mishna in <i>Eiruvin</i> speak of cutting off the wart <b>by hand. This</b> mishna that forbids cutting it off refers to <b>a moist</b> wart, which is considered like the flesh of the animal. It is therefore prohibited by rabbinic decree to cut off the wart; and since it could have been removed before Shabbat, the decree applies even in the Temple, where rabbinic decrees are generally not applicable. <b>That</b> mishna that permits cutting it off refers to <b>a dry</b> wart, which breaks apart by itself, and so there is no prohibition even by rabbinic decree to cut it off. <b>And</b> the other <b>one said:</b> Both <b>this</b> mishna <b>and that</b> mishna speak of cutting off <b>a moist</b> wart, <b>and</b> it is <b>not difficult. This</b> mishna that says it is permitted talks about removing the wart <b>by hand,</b> which is prohibited only by a rabbinic decree that was not applied to the Temple; whereas <b>that</b> mishna that says it is prohibited talks about removing the wart <b>with an instrument,</b> which is prohibited by Torah law and forbidden everywhere.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the one who says</b> that <b>this</b> mishna speaks about cutting off the wart <b>by hand and that</b> mishna speaks about cutting it off <b>with an instrument, what is the reason that he did not state</b> like the other <i>amora</i> that <b>this and that</b> talk about cutting off the wart <b>by hand, and</b> it is <b>not difficult; this</b> mishna speaks of <b>a moist</b> wart, while <b>that</b> mishna speaks of <b>a dry</b> wart? The Gemara answers that <b>he</b> could have <b>said to you: A dry</b> wart <b>breaks apart</b> by itself, and so there would be no need to teach us that it may be removed. Both <i>mishnayot</i> must therefore refer to a moist wart, and the difference between them is whether the wart is being removed by hand or with an instrument.
The Gemara reverses the question: <b>And according to the one who says</b> that both <b>this</b> mishna <b>and that</b> mishna talk about removing the wart <b>by hand, and</b> it is <b>not difficult; this</b> speaks of <b>a moist</b> wart while <b>that</b> speaks of <b>a dry</b> wart. <b>What is the reason that he did not state</b> like the other <i>amora</i> that <b>this and that</b> are discussing <b>a moist</b> wart <b>and</b> it is <b>not difficult; this</b> mishna in <i>Eiruvin</i> speaks about cutting off the wart <b>by hand</b> and <b>that</b> mishna in <i>Pesaḥim</i> speaks about cutting it off <b>with an instrument?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>he</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> The case of cutting off the wart with <b>an instrument is taught there</b> in <i>Eiruvin</i> in that very same mishna: <b>If</b> the wart is to be removed <b>with an instrument, it is forbidden</b> both <b>here,</b> in the Temple, <b>and there,</b> outside the Temple. Therefore, there would be no reason to repeat the same <i>halakha</i> here in this mishna, as it is stated explicitly in the other mishna.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>amora</i>, how does he account for the repetition according to his explanation? The mishna <b>here teaches</b> the law with regard to <b>an instrument</b> because <b>it comes to teach us the dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua;</b> for according to our mishna, Rabbi Eliezer permits cutting off a moist wart even with an instrument in order to render the animal fit to be brought as a Paschal offering.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer said</b> that <b>if slaughter,</b> which is ordinarily forbidden on Shabbat as a biblically prohibited labor, nevertheless overrides Shabbat when performed for the sake of the Paschal lamb, then activities that are prohibited by rabbinic decree should certainly override Shabbat when performed for that purpose. Rabbi Yehoshua disagreed, arguing that the law governing a Festival proves otherwise. Rabbi Eliezer countered that the law governing an optional activity, such as preparing food on a Festival, cannot be brought as proof with regard to the mitzva of offering the Paschal lamb. The Gemara notes that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua follows his</b> regular line of <b>reasoning, for he said</b> that <b>rejoicing on a Festival is also a mitzva,</b> and therefore whatever one does in order to enhance one’s enjoyment of the Festival is considered an act performed for the sake of a mitzva, just like the offering of a sacrifice.
<b>For it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that these two <i>tanna’im</i> disagreed about this matter: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: A person has nothing but</b> to choose <b>on a Festival; he either eats and drinks or sits and learns</b> the entire day, but there is no specific mitzva to eat on the Festival. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> on the other hand, <b>says: Divide</b> the day, <b>half of it for eating and drinking and half of it for the study hall,</b> for he holds that eating and drinking are obligatory on the Festival.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And both of them derived</b> their opinions from <b>one verse,</b> i.e., the two of them addressed the same textual difficulty, resolving it in different ways. For <b>one verse says: “It shall be an assembly for the Lord your God;</b> you shall do no labor” (Deuteronomy 16:8), which indicates that the day is set aside for Divine service, <b>and another verse says: “It shall be an assembly for you;</b> you shall do no servile labor” (Numbers 29:35), which indicates a celebratory assembly for the Jewish people. <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that the two verses should be understood as offering a choice: The day is to be <b>either entirely for God or entirely for you. And Rabbi Yehoshua holds</b> that it is possible to fulfill both verses: <b>Split</b> the day into two, <b>half of it for God and half of it for you.</b>
<b><i>Ayin</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>mem</i></b> is <b>a mnemonic</b> consisting of the first letter of <i>Atzeret</i>, the middle letter of Shabbat and the final letter of Purim. <b>Rabbi Elazar said: All agree with regard to <i>Atzeret</i>,</b> the holiday of <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>that we require</b> that it be <b>also “for you,”</b> meaning that it is a mitzva to eat, drink, and rejoice on that day. <b>What is the reason? It is the day on which the Torah was given,</b> and one must celebrate the fact that the Torah was given to the Jewish people. <b>Rabba said: All agree with regard to Shabbat that we require</b> that it be <b>also “for you.” What is the reason?</b> Because the verse states: <b>“If you proclaim Shabbat a delight,</b> the sacred day of God honored” (Isaiah 58:13). <b>Rav Yosef said: All agree with regard to Purim that we require</b> that it be <b>also “for you.” What is the reason?</b> Because <b>it is written:</b> “To observe them as <b>days of feasting and gladness”</b> (Esther 9:22).
The Gemara relates: <b>Mar, son of Ravina, would spend the entire year fasting</b> during the day and eating only sparsely at night, <b>except for <i>Shavuot</i>, Purim, and the eve of Yom Kippur.</b> He made these exceptions for the following reasons: <b><i>Shavuot</i></b> because <b>it is the day on which the Torah was given</b> and there is a mitzva to demonstrate one’s joy on that day; <b>Purim</b> because <b>“days of feasting and gladness” is written</b> about it; <b>the eve of Yom Kippur, as Ḥiyya bar Rav of Difti taught: “And you shall afflict your souls on the ninth day of the month</b> in the evening, from evening to evening you shall keep your Sabbath” (Leviticus 23:32). <b>But does one fast on the ninth</b> of Tishrei? <b>Doesn’t one fast on the tenth</b> of Tishrei? <b>Rather,</b> this comes <b>to tell you: One who eats and drinks on the ninth, the verse ascribes him</b> credit <b>as if he fasted on</b> both <b>the ninth and the tenth</b> of Tishrei.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Yosef, on the day of <i>Shavuot</i>,</b> would <b>say: Prepare me a</b> choice <b>third-born calf. He said: If not for this day</b> on which the Torah was given <b>that caused</b> the Jewish people to have the Torah, <b>how many Yosefs would there be in the market?</b> It is only due to the importance of Torah study that I have become a leader of the Jewish people, and I therefore have a special obligation to rejoice on this day.
A somewhat similar story is told about <b>Rav Sheshet,</b> that <b>every thirty days he would review his studies</b> that he had learned over the previous month, <b>and he would stand and lean against the bolt of the door and say: Rejoice my soul, rejoice my soul, for you I have read</b> Scripture, <b>for you I have studied</b> Mishna. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so,</b> that Torah study is beneficial only for the soul of the person who has studied? <b>But didn’t Rabbi Elazar say: If not for the Torah</b> and its study, <b>heaven and earth would not be sustained, as it is stated: “If not for My covenant by day and by night, I would not have set up the laws of heaven and earth”</b> (Jeremiah 33:25). It is the Torah, the eternal covenant that is studied day and night, that justifies the continued existence of the world. The Gemara answers: This is indeed correct, but <b>at the outset when a person does</b> this mitzva, <b>he does it for himself,</b> and only afterward does he have in mind the benefit that will be brought to the entire world.
<b>Rav Ashi said: And even according to what Rabbi Eliezer said,</b> that rejoicing on a <b>Festival is optional, there is a refutation: If</b> on <b>a Festival, when</b> a biblically prohibited <b>labor,</b> such as slaughtering, baking, or cooking, <b>is permitted</b> even when it is performed <b>for an optional</b> activity, nonetheless <b>a rabbinic decree that is with it is not permitted,</b> and we do not say that since they permitted an optional activity they permitted everything associated with it; how much more so on <b>Shabbat, when a</b> biblically prohibited <b>labor is only permitted</b> when it is performed <b>for a mitzva, isn’t it right not to permit a rabbinic decree that is with it?</b> Activities that are forbidden due to a rabbinic decree should thus be prohibited on Shabbat even for the purpose of a mitzva, against the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.

Daf 69a

<b>And Rabbi Eliezer</b> rejects this refutation because, in his opinion, permitting <b>a rabbinic decree for</b> the sake of <b>a mitzva is preferable.</b> We cannot derive through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference that since rabbinic decrees were not permitted for optional activities associated with rejoicing on festivals, they must not be permitted for the purpose of a mitzva on Shabbat. This is because it is possible that they permitted rabbinic decrees for mitzva purposes due to the importance of the mitzva.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer said: What</b> reason do <b>I</b> have? <b>If actions that facilitate</b> the performance of <b>the mitzva</b> and are done <b>after the slaughter,</b> such as cleaning the intestines which is permitted according all opinions, <b>override Shabbat</b> even though <b>the mitzva has</b> already <b>been done,</b> is it possible to say that <b>actions that facilitate</b> the performance of <b>the mitzva</b> and must be done <b>before the slaughter do not</b> also <b>override Shabbat?</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva said to him: What</b> reason do <b>I</b> have to reject this comparison? <b>If actions that facilitate</b> the performance of <b>the mitzva</b> that are done <b>after the slaughter override Shabbat,</b> that is <b>because slaughter has</b> already <b>overridden Shabbat</b> and therefore an action that violates a rabbinic decree is performed, after Shabbat has already been overridden; <b>can you say that actions that facilitate</b> the performance of <b>the mitzva</b> and are done <b>before the slaughter should override Shabbat</b> even though <b>slaughter has not</b> yet <b>overridden Shabbat? Alternatively,</b> Rabbi Akiva has another reason: <b>Perhaps the offering will be found to be disqualified</b> due to a blemish <b>and</b> the person <b>will be found to have violated Shabbat retroactively</b> when he slaughtered the animal without fulfilling a mitzva.
Rabbi Eliezer rejects this argument: <b>If so,</b> if you are concerned about this possibility, <b>it should also not be slaughtered;</b> for <b>perhaps the offering will be found to be invalid and</b> the person <b>will be found to have violated Shabbat retroactively. Rather,</b> the course of the discussion must have gone as follows: Rabbi Akiva <b>said this</b> last reason <b>to</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>at the beginning and he refuted it</b> as explained above; <b>and then</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>said to him this</b> other reason of: <b>What</b> reason do <b>I</b> have to reject this comparison? <b>If</b> actions that facilitate the performance of the mitzva <b>override,</b> etc.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Akiva responded and said</b> to Rabbi Eliezer that the law governing the <b>sprinkling</b> of the purifying water of a red heifer <b>proves</b> that actions prohibited by a rabbinic decree, even when they are performed for the sake of a mitzva, do not override Shabbat. He then goes on to argue that we can reverse the order of the argument and conclude by way of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference that even slaughter does not override Shabbat. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him</b> about this: <b>Akiva, you have</b> lightheartedly <b>responded to me</b> with a faulty <i>a fortiori</i> inference with regard to <b>slaughter. His death will be with slaughter;</b> meaning, as punishment for this disrespect you will be slaughtered by other people. Rabbi Akiva <b>said to him: My teacher, do not deny my</b> contention <b>at the time</b> we are discussing this <b>inference,</b> for <b>this</b> is the tradition <b>I received from you: Sprinkling is</b> forbidden by <b>rabbinic decree and does not override Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Seeing that</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>taught</b> Rabbi Akiva this <i>halakha</i> that sprinkling purifying water does not override Shabbat, <b>what is the reason he retracted</b> his opinion? <b>Ulla said: When Rabbi Eliezer taught him</b> this <i>halakha</i>, <b>he taught</b> it to <b>him</b> with respect to <b>sprinkling</b> that is performed in order to enable a ritually impure priest to partake of <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> This sprinkling does not override Shabbat <b>because</b> even separating <b><i>teruma</i> itself does not override Shabbat.</b> But he never taught Rabbi Akiva this <i>halakha</i> with respect to sprinkling that is performed in order enable someone to eat of the Paschal lamb.
The Gemara notes that <b>Rabbi Akiva as well, when he challenged</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>challenged him</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of <b>sprinkling for <i>teruma</i>,</b> and his objection should be understood as follows: Eating <i>teruma</i> <b>is a mitzva,</b> and sprinkling purifying water on someone who is ritually impure is only prohibited <b>due to a rabbinic decree;</b> nevertheless, sprinkling purifying water on a ritually impure priest, in order to enable him to eat <i>teruma</i>, is prohibited on Shabbat. Thus it follows by <i>a fortiori</i> inference that slaughter, which is a biblically prohibited labor, should certainly be forbidden on Shabbat, even when performed for the sake of a mitzva. <b>And</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>thought</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>was challenging him</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of <b>sprinkling</b> that is performed in order to enable someone to eat of <b>the Paschal lamb;</b> that is why he said that he disagreed about sprinkling as well.
<b>Rabba raised an objection</b> to Ulla’s explanation, based on a different <i>baraita</i> which states: <b>Rabbi Akiva responded and said: The sprinkling</b> of purifying water on <b>someone who is ritually impure due to</b> contact with <b>a corpse proves</b> the matter when <b>his seventh day</b> of impurity <b>occurs on Shabbat and</b> it is also <b>the eve of Passover, for it is</b> done <b>for</b> the sake of <b>a mitzva,</b> in order to allow the person to eat of the Paschal lamb, <b>and it is</b> prohibited only <b>due to a rabbinic decree, and</b> nonetheless <b>it does not override Shabbat.</b> From this <i>baraita</i> it is clear that Rabbi Akiva challenged Rabbi Eliezer with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of sprinkling that is performed in order to enable someone to eat the Paschal lamb.
<b>Rather,</b> we must reject Ulla’s explanation and say instead that Rabbi Eliezer <b>certainly taught</b> Rabbi Akiva about <b>sprinkling</b> that is performed in order to enable someone to eat of the <b>Paschal lamb.</b> And with regard to the question that <b>seeing that</b> Rabbi Eliezer himself <b>taught him</b> this <i>halakha</i>, <b>what is the reason that Rabbi Eliezer refutes it,</b> the Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Eliezer forgot his</b> own <b>teaching and Rabbi Akiva came to remind him of his teaching</b> by drawing an <i>a fortiori</i> inference that would cause Rabbi Eliezer to remember what he himself had taught. The Gemara asks: If so, then <b>let</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>say explicitly</b> that this is what Rabbi Eliezer himself had taught him. The Gemara answers: <b>He thought that it would not be proper</b> to tell his teacher that he had forgotten his teaching, and therefore his initial attempt was to remind him indirectly.
The Gemara questions the reason for the <i>halakha</i> under discussion. <b>What is the reason that</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of purifying water <b>does not override Shabbat? Since it</b> involves the <b>mere moving</b> of the liquid from the utensil in his hand to the body of the person seeking purification, why should it be forbidden on Shabbat? <b>Let it</b> at least <b>override Shabbat on account</b> of the mitzva <b>of the Paschal lamb. Rabba said:</b> The prohibition against sprinkling is <b>a</b> rabbinic <b>decree</b> that was instituted <b>lest one take</b> the utensil containing the purifying water <b>and carry it</b> a distance of <b>four cubits in the public domain,</b> thus violating an actual Torah prohibition. This is consistent with Rabba’s opinion in several other places in the Talmud that the Sages forbade the fulfillment of certain mitzvot due to a similar concern about carrying in the public domain.
The Gemara asks: At least <b>according to Rabbi Eliezer, let us carry</b> the purifying water even in the public domain, <b>for Rabbi Eliezer said</b> as a general rule that actions that <b>facilitate</b> the performance of <b>a mitzva override Shabbat,</b> even if they are not mitzvot themselves and involve transgression of Torah prohibitions. <b>They say</b> that there is room to distinguish between different situations: The rule that actions necessary to facilitate a mitzva override Shabbat only <b>applies when the person himself is fit</b> to fulfill the mitzva <b>and the obligation</b> to fulfill it <b>is incumbent upon him. But here where the person himself is not fit</b> to eat the Paschal lamb, as he is presently ritually impure, <b>the obligation</b> to fulfill the mitzva <b>is not incumbent upon him,</b> and therefore actions that would enable him to fulfill the mitzva do not override Shabbat.
<b>Rabba said: According to the statement of Rabbi Eliezer</b> that when a person is unfit no obligation is incumbent upon him, in the case of <b>a healthy baby, one may heat water for him to strengthen him</b> even further in order <b>to circumcise him on Shabbat, as he is</b> already now <b>fit</b> to be circumcised. But in the case of <b>a sickly baby, one may not heat water for him to strengthen him</b> in order <b>to circumcise him, for</b> owing to his sickliness <b>he is not</b> presently <b>fit</b> for the mitzva, and acts that facilitate a mitzva do not override Shabbat if the person is not currently fit for the mitzva.
<b>Rava said: But if</b> the baby <b>is healthy, why does he</b> need <b>hot water to strengthen him? Rather, Rava said: All</b> babies <b>are</b> considered <b>sickly with respect to circumcision,</b> as they all need to be washed with hot water. Therefore, <b>both</b> in the case of <b>a healthy baby and</b> in the case of <b>a sickly baby, one may not heat water for him to strengthen him</b> in order <b>to circumcise him on Shabbat,</b> even according to Rabbi Eliezer, <b>as he is not</b> presently <b>fit</b> for the mitzva.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rabba’s distinction between someone who is currently fit for the mitzva and someone who is not, based on what was taught elsewhere in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An uncircumcised</b> adult <b>who did not circumcise</b> himself before Passover <b>is liable to the punishment of <i>karet</i></b> for having intentionally violated the mitzva to bring the Paschal lamb, as an uncircumcised person may not eat of the offering; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. But here the person himself is not fit,</b> for as long as he is uncircumcised he is not obligated to bring the Paschal lamb, and nonetheless the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching that he is punished with <i>karet</i>. Apparently, the obligation is incumbent upon him</b> even though he is presently unfit to perform the mitzva.
<b>Rabba said</b> in answer to this objection: <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that <b>one may not slaughter</b> the Paschal lamb <b>or sprinkle</b> its blood <b>for someone who is ritually impure due to</b> contact with <b>a creeping animal</b> because he is currently impure, even though he can immerse in a ritual bath and become pure by the night of Passover.

Daf 69b

<b>And</b> Rabbi Eliezer further maintains with regard to <b>any</b> form of impurity due to which <b>an individual is deferred</b> to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, that if the entire community is afflicted with it, <b>they observe</b> the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b> And he accepts yet another principle: <b>Anything that applies to the community applies to an individual, and anything that does not apply to the community does not apply to an individual.</b>
On the basis of these principles, we can say as follows: With regard to <b>lack of circumcision, if the entire community is uncircumcised we say to them: Arise, and circumcise yourselves, and offer the Paschal lamb,</b> and we do not allow them to offer the sacrifice while uncircumcised. Therefore, with regard to <b>an individual as well, we say to him: Arise, and circumcise yourself, and offer the Paschal lamb; and if he does not circumcise</b> himself <b>and offer</b> the Paschal lamb, <b>he is liable to the punishment of <i>karet</i>.</b>
With regard to <b>impurity,</b> however, <b>if the whole community is impure we do not sprinkle</b> the purifying water <b>on them; rather, they offer</b> the Paschal lamb <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b> Therefore, <b>an individual, as well, is exempt</b> from sprinkling; and since he is exempt, sprinkling does not override Shabbat. A distinction may be drawn between the two cases: An uncircumcised person must circumcise himself, but a person who is ritually impure need not undergo purification.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said to Rava:</b> Are these principles really correct? <b>But</b> there is <b>the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, which does not apply to the community and</b> yet <b>it applies to an individual.</b> Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Huna: <b>It is different there, as the community</b> already <b>offered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>on the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> in a state of ritual impurity, and therefore the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> can apply to individuals although it does not apply to the community.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> in which it was taught: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that only one who was pure and not on a distant journey is punishable by <i>karet</i></b> for having neglected to offer the Paschal lamb, as the Torah explicitly states that a person who was ritually impure or on a distant journey is exempt from the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> and obligated in the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. But as for one who was <b>uncircumcised or ritually impure from a creeping animal and all the others who are ritually impure</b> not from a corpse, and they did not undergo circumcision or purification before Passover, <b>from where</b> do we know that they are also liable to receive <i>karet</i>? <b>The verse states:</b> “But the man that is clean, and is not on a journey, and fails to keep the Passover, then that person shall be cut off from his people” (Numbers 9:13); the expression <b>“but the man”</b> comes to include anyone who can become pure and fit to participate in the Paschal lamb, but fails to do so.
The Gemara infers from this <i>baraita</i>: <b>From</b> the fact that <b>he searches for</b> a source to include <b>one who is ritually impure from a creeping animal,</b> it is clear that <b>he holds that one may not slaughter</b> the Paschal lamb <b>or sprinkle</b> its blood <b>for someone who is ritually impure from a creeping animal. For if one may slaughter and sprinkle for someone impure from a creeping animal, why did he search for</b> a source to include <b>it? He is</b> the same as anyone who is <b>pure</b> and did not offer the Paschal lamb, for he could have sent his offering with someone else and eaten from it in the evening after having undergone ritual immersion. Rather, it is clear that one may not slaughter or sprinkle for him; and, nonetheless, if he neglected the mitzva of the Paschal lamb, he is liable to receive <i>karet</i>. <b>Apparently</b> then, <b>although he was not fit</b> at that time to offer the Paschal lamb, <b>the obligation is</b> nonetheless <b>incumbent upon him</b> to render himself fit. <b>And although this does not apply to the community,</b> for a community that is impure with the impurity of a creeping animal brings the Paschal lamb in a state of impurity, <b>it does apply to an individual.</b>
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that we should reject the previous statement and say instead that <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds that one may slaughter</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and sprinkle</b> its blood <b>for someone who is ritually impure from a creeping animal, and the same is true with regard to someone who is ritually impure from a corpse on his seventh</b> day of impurity. If so, <b>for what</b> purpose is the <b>sprinkling</b> of the purifying water? If it is possible to slaughter the Paschal lamb and sprinkle its blood on this person’s behalf even when he is impure, the only reason to sprinkle the purifying water is <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>eating</b> the Paschal lamb. However, <b>eating of the Paschal lamb is not essential</b> for the fulfillment of the mitzva, for if the blood of the sacrifice is sprinkled in a permitted fashion on someone’s behalf and afterward he is unable to eat the meat of the sacrifice, e.g., it became impure or was lost, he has fulfilled his obligation and is not liable to receive <i>karet</i>. This being the case, sprinkling the purifying waters is not an act that is necessary to facilitate a mitzva and does not override Shabbat even according to Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>Rav Adda bar Abba said to Rava: If</b> it is <b>so,</b> that one may slaughter the Paschal lamb for someone who is ritually impure from a creeping animal, <b>it turns out that the Paschal lamb is slaughtered for</b> people <b>who cannot eat it,</b> and it is stated elsewhere that such a sacrifice is disqualified. Rava <b>said to him:</b> When it says that a Paschal lamb that is slaughtered <b>for</b> people <b>who cannot eat</b> is disqualified, this refers to a case where it is slaughtered <b>for a sick or elderly person who is not</b> at all <b>fit</b> to eat the sacrifice. <b>But this</b> person is essentially <b>fit</b> to eat the sacrifice but <b>has not</b> yet <b>been made ready</b> to actually eat it. He himself is regarded as fit to eat the sacrifice, and it is only some external factor that prevents him from doing so.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Akiva stated a principle</b> that any prohibited labor required for the offering of the sacrifice that can be performed before Shabbat does not override Shabbat; whereas slaughter, which cannot be performed on the eve of Shabbat, overrides Shabbat.<b>Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb. The Gemara points out that <b>we also learned</b> something <b>similar to this</b> in another mishna <b>with regard to circumcision: Rabbi Akiva stated a principle: Any prohibited labor</b> required for circumcision <b>that can be performed on the eve of Shabbat</b> because it need not be done specifically on the day of the circumcision <b>does not override Shabbat;</b> the <b>circumcision</b> itself, <b>which cannot be performed on the eve of Shabbat,</b> since it is not yet time to perform the circumcision, <b>overrides Shabbat. And Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> with regard to circumcision.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state this ruling in both cases, <b>for had</b> Rav <b>taught us</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva only <b>with regard to the Paschal lamb,</b> the conclusion would have been: It is specifically <b>there that the facilitators of a mitzva</b> that can be performed the day before <b>do not override Shabbat because thirteen covenants were not established upon</b> the Paschal lamb, and it is therefore not so significant. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>circumcision, upon which thirteen covenants were established,</b> as is evidenced by the fact that the word covenant appears thirteen times in the chapter relating to circumcision (Genesis 17), which serves as a covenant between God and the Jewish nation, <b>I would say</b> that even facilitating actions that could have been performed on Shabbat eve should <b>override</b> Shabbat.
<b>And had</b> Rav <b>taught us</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva only <b>with regard to circumcision,</b> the conclusion would have been: <b>It is</b> specifically <b>there that the facilitators of a mitzva</b> that can be performed before Shabbat <b>do not override Shabbat, as there is no</b> punishment of <b><i>karet</i></b> if the circumcision is delayed, since liability for <i>karet</i> only applies when the child becomes obligated in mitzvot and chooses not to circumcise himself. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>the Paschal lamb, where there is <i>karet</i></b> for one who fails to offer the sacrifice at its proper time, <b>I would say that</b> such facilitators <b>should override</b> Shabbat. <b>It is</b> therefore <b>necessary</b> to teach that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva in both cases.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>When does one bring a Festival peace-offering with</b> the Paschal lamb? A special offering is brought on the fourteenth of Nisan together with the Paschal lamb <b>when</b> the Paschal lamb <b>comes on a weekday</b> rather than on Shabbat, and when it comes <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity</b> as opposed to when it is brought in a state of impurity because most of the community is impure, <b>and</b> when many people are registered for the Paschal lamb so that each person will receive only <b>a small</b> portion from it. When these three conditions are met, the Festival peace-offering is eaten first and the Paschal lamb is eaten afterward. <b>When,</b> however, the Paschal lamb <b>comes on Shabbat,</b> or <b>when</b> few people are registered for it so that each person will receive <b>a large</b> portion, or when it is brought <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity, one does not bring a Festival peace-offering with it.</b>
With regard to the extra offering itself, the <b>Festival peace-offering would come from the flock, from the herd, from sheep or from goats, from males or from females,</b> as the Festival peace-offering is not bound by the limitations governing the Paschal offering, which must be specifically a young male sheep or goat. <b>And</b> the Festival peace-offering <b>is eaten for two days and one night</b> like other peace-offerings.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara questions why this <i>halakha</i> is recorded here: <b>What did</b> the mishna previously <b>teach that</b> made it relevant to <b>teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a Festival peace-offering</b> despite the fact that it seems to be unconnected to the previous <i>mishnayot</i>? The Gemara answers: Since <b>it taught that carrying</b> the Paschal lamb through a public domain <b>and bringing it</b> from outside the Shabbat limit <b>do not override Shabbat, it also taught</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a Festival peace-offering, that it does not override Shabbat. And this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: When does one bring a Festival peace-offering with</b> the Paschal lamb? <b>When it comes on a weekday, in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity, and when</b> each person’s portion is <b>small.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: Learn from this</b> that <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, which comes with the Paschal lamb and is the subject of our mishna, as opposed to the Festival peace-offering that is brought on the first day of Passover and is called the Festival peace-offering of the fifteenth,

Daf 70a

<b>is not an obligation,</b> meaning there is no Torah obligation to bring this offering. <b>For if it should enter your mind</b> to say that <b>it is an obligation, it should come</b> even <b>on Shabbat, and it should come</b> even when each member of the group will receive <b>a large</b> portion of the Paschal lamb, <b>and it should come</b> even <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: If there is no obligation to bring this offering, <b>what is the reason that it nevertheless comes</b> when each person’s portion of the Paschal lamb is <b>small?</b> The Gemara explains that the reason is <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Festival peace-offering that comes with the Paschal lamb is eaten first;</b> the reason for this is <b>so that the Paschal lamb will be eaten when</b> one is already <b>satiated.</b> The Paschal lamb should not be eaten in a needy manner, but rather in joy and when one is already filled to satisfaction.
The mishna taught that the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth <b>is eaten for two days</b> and the intervening night. The Gemara notes that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Teima, for it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>ben Teima says: The Festival peace-offering that comes with the Paschal lamb</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan <b>is like the Paschal lamb and is eaten for only a day and a night,</b> whereas <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fifteenth,</b> i.e., the Festival peace-offering brought on the first day of Passover, just as it is brought on the first day of each of the other Festivals, is treated like a regular peace-offering and <b>is eaten for two days and one,</b> i.e., the intervening, <b>night.</b>
<b>And</b> if one consecrated an animal to be used as <b>a Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth,</b> but it was not slaughtered on that day, on the next day <b>he can fulfill with it</b> his obligation to bring a peace-offering of <b>rejoicing,</b> as it is stated: “And you shall rejoice on your Festival,” but <b>he cannot fulfill with it</b> his obligation to bring a <b>Festival peace-offering</b> of the fifteenth.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> and scriptural basis <b>for ben Teima’s</b> opinion? The Gemara explains: <b>As Rav taught his son Ḥiyya</b> based on the following verse: <b>“Neither shall the offering of the feast of the Passover be left to the morning”</b> (Exodus 34:25). <b>“The offering of the feast,” this</b> is referring to <b>the Festival peace-offering; “the Passover,” as per its plain meaning,</b> i.e., this is referring to the Paschal lamb itself. <b>And</b> with regard to both sacrifices, <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“It shall not be left</b> to the morning.” This proves that the Festival peace-offering may be eaten for only a day and a night.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>ben Teima, is</b> the Festival peace-offering that is brought with the Paschal lamb <b>eaten roasted</b> like the Paschal lamb itself <b>or is it not eaten roasted?</b> The possible considerations are as follows: <b>When the Merciful One compares</b> the Festival peace-offering <b>to the Paschal lamb</b> in the Torah, was that only <b>with regard to leaving</b> it <b>over</b> until the morning, <b>but with regard to</b> the mitzva of <b>roasting, no</b> such comparison is made? <b>Or perhaps there is no difference;</b> the comparison was complete, and the Festival peace-offering is roasted just like the Paschal lamb.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution from what was taught in a mishna: In the time of the Temple, one of the questions that the children would ask on the night of Passover was: How is this night different from all other nights? For on all other nights we eat meat that is roasted, stewed, or boiled, whereas <b>on this night it is all roasted. And Rav Ḥisda said: This is the statement of ben Teima,</b> indicating that even the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth must be roasted. The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from this</b> that the Festival peace-offering must be roasted just like the Paschal lamb.
Another <b>dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>ben Teima, does</b> the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth <b>come from the herd or does it not come from the herd,</b> like the Paschal offering, which must be brought from the flock? <b>Does it come</b> even <b>from females or does it not come from females,</b> just like the Paschal offering comes only from males? <b>Does it come</b> even from <b>a two-year-old</b> animal <b>or does it not come</b> from <b>a two-year-old</b> animal, but rather only from a one-year-old animal, like the Paschal offering itself?
The Gemara explains that this dilemma is based on a fundamental question similar to the one raised earlier: <b>When the Merciful One compares</b> the Festival peace-offering <b>to the Paschal lamb</b> in the Torah, was that only <b>with regard to matters</b> pertaining to <b>eating</b> and the time during which the Paschal lamb must be eaten, <b>but for everything</b> else there is <b>no</b> comparison? <b>Or perhaps there is no difference</b> and the Torah compared these two offerings in every way.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an answer to these questions from what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Festival peace-offering that comes with the Paschal offering</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan <b>is like the Paschal offering</b> in every respect. <b>It comes from the flock and does not come from the herd, it comes from males and does not come from females, it comes</b> from an animal that is <b>a year old and does not come</b> from an animal that is <b>two years old, and it is eaten for only a day and a night, and it is eaten only roasted, and it is eaten only by those who registered for it</b> in advance.
The Gemara explains how this <i>baraita</i> answers the questions raised above: <b>Who have you heard adopts this reasoning,</b> comparing the Paschal offering and the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth? Surely it is <b>ben Teima. Learn from this</b> that <b>we require everything,</b> that the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth must parallel the Paschal offering in all its details. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> that they are comparable in every way.
Yet another <b>dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>ben Teima, is</b> the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth <b>subject to</b> the prohibition against <b>breaking a bone,</b> as is the Paschal lamb, with regard to which the Torah explicitly states: “And you shall not break a bone in it” (Exodus 12:46), <b>or is it not subject to</b> the prohibition against <b>breaking a bone?</b> The possible considerations are as follows: Do we say that <b>even though the Merciful One compares</b> the Festival peace-offering <b>to the Paschal lamb, the verse</b> that teaches the prohibition against breaking a bone <b>says “in it,”</b> and these words serve as a qualifying statement, indicating that the prohibition applies only <b>in it,</b> the Paschal lamb, <b>and not in the Festival peace-offering</b> that comes with it? <b>Or perhaps this</b> term, <b>“in it,”</b> teaches that the prohibition applies only <b>to a fit</b> Paschal lamb <b>but not to a disqualified</b> one.
The Gemara proposes: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution based on the following mishna: If <b>a</b> slaughtering <b>knife was found on the fourteenth</b> day of Nisan in Jerusalem, <b>one may slaughter with it immediately</b> without concern that perhaps it is ritually impure, for presumably any knife that is valid for slaughtering had already been immersed on the previous day so that it could be used for slaughtering the Paschal lamb. But if it was found <b>on the thirteenth</b> day of Nisan, <b>he must immerse</b> it <b>again</b> due to the possibility that it had not yet been immersed and purified.As for <b>a cleaver [<i>kofitz</i>],</b> a large knife that is used primarily for chopping bones, <b>whether</b> it was found <b>on this</b> day, the fourteenth, <b>or on the other</b> day, the thirteenth, <b>he must immerse</b> it <b>again.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Whose</b> opinion is taught in this mishna? <b>If you say it is</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who permit breaking the bones of the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth, <b>what is different</b> about a slaughtering <b>knife</b> found on the fourteenth <b>that</b> we say its owner presumably <b>immersed</b> it on the previous day? Is it <b>because it is fit for</b> slaughtering <b>the Paschal lamb?</b> If so, <b>a cleaver</b> found on the fourteenth should <b>also</b> not require immersion before being used, for presumably its owner already immersed it, as <b>it is fit for</b> chopping the bones of <b>the Festival peace-offering.</b>
<b>Rather, is it not</b> the opinion of <b>ben Teima, and learn from this</b> that even the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition against <b>breaking a bone,</b> and therefore a cleaver must be immersed again even if it was found on the fourteenth. Since no bones may be broken on the fourteenth of Nisan, neither those of the Paschal lamb nor those of the Festival peace-offering, it is possible that the knife was not immersed in preparation for the Festival.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>No, actually</b> one can explain that the mishna reflects the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the time to slaughter the Paschal lamb <b>comes on Shabbat.</b> In this circumstance, all agree that the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth is not sacrificed. Since there is no need for a cleaver, there is no reason to assume that the knife had been immersed in preparation for the Festival.
The Gemara asks: <b>But from the fact that the latter clause</b> of that same mishna <b>teaches</b> that <b>if the fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>occurred on Shabbat he may slaughter with</b> the knife <b>immediately,</b> without immersing it, and similarly, if he found it <b>on the fifteenth,</b> i.e., on the first day of the Festival, <b>he may slaughter with it immediately,</b> as it was certainly immersed the day before, and <b>if a cleaver was found tied to</b> a slaughtering <b>knife,</b> then even if it was found on the fourteenth on a weekday, <b>it is like the</b> slaughtering <b>knife,</b> as they were certainly immersed together, it follows <b>by inference that</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>we are not dealing with</b> a case where the fourteenth of Nisan occurred on <b>Shabbat.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> this understanding must be rejected and instead we should say that the mishna is talking about a case where the Paschal lamb <b>came</b>

Daf 70b

with few people registered for it, so that each person receives a <b>large</b> portion of the offering. Therefore, there is no need for a Festival peace-offering or for a cleaver. The Gemara questions this answer: <b>How do</b> the owners <b>know</b> already on the thirteenth that only a small number of people will be registered for the Paschal lamb? Perhaps more people will register for the offering before it is slaughtered, in which case we should assume that the cleaver was immersed, as it might be necessary to bring a Festival peace-offering together with the Paschal lamb.
<b>Rather,</b> we must say that we are talking about a Paschal lamb <b>that came in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> in which case a Festival peace-offering is not brought, and consequently there is no need for a cleaver. The Gemara asks: <b>Ultimately, how do</b> the owners <b>know</b> already on the thirteenth when they are immersing their knives that the Paschal lamb will be brought in ritual impurity, so that they need not immerse their chopping knives? Perhaps it will turn out that most of the community is ritually pure.
The Gemara answers that we are talking about a situation <b>where the <i>Nasi</i> died,</b> in which case all of Israel must defile themselves in order to participate in his burial. The Gemara asks: <b>When did the <i>Nasi</i> die? If you say that he died on the thirteenth</b> and everyone became ritually impure as a result, <b>why do I</b> need <b>to immerse the</b> slaughtering <b>knife</b> to begin with? It will become ritually impure again in any event. <b>Rather, he died on the fourteenth</b> and they did not know in advance that the Paschal lamb would be brought in a state of impurity. But if so, <b>what is different</b> about <b>the</b> slaughtering <b>knife</b> that <b>he immerses</b> it <b>and what is different</b> about <b>the cleaver</b> that <b>he does not immerse it?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case where <b>the <i>Nasi</i> was in a dying state on the thirteenth.</b> With regard to <b>a</b> slaughtering <b>knife,</b> about which there is only <b>one doubt,</b> that perhaps the <i>Nasi</i> will die before the Festival and the Paschal lamb will be brought in a state of ritual impurity, <b>he immerses it,</b> for if the <i>Nasi</i> does not die he will need a ritually pure knife to slaughter his Paschal lamb. With regard to <b>a cleaver,</b> about which there are <b>two doubts,</b> that perhaps the <i>Nasi</i> will die and a ritually pure knife will not be needed, and that even if he does not die, perhaps the meat of the Paschal lamb will be plentiful and the Festival peace-offering will not be brought, <b>he does not immerse it.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Yehuda ben Dortai separated</b> himself from the other Rabbis, <b>he and Dortai his son, and went and settled in the south</b> so that he would not be obligated to bring the Paschal lamb, seeing that he was at a great distance from Jerusalem. He did this because he disagreed with the Rabbis with regard to the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth, which in their view does not override Shabbat. <b>He said: If Elijah will come and say to the Jewish people: For what</b> reason <b>did you not sacrifice the Festival peace-offering on Shabbat, what</b> will <b>they say to him? I am astounded at the two</b> most <b>eminent</b> scholars <b>of the generation, Shemaya and Avtalyon, who are great sages and great expositors</b> of the Torah, <b>and</b> yet <b>they did not tell the Jewish people</b> that even <b>the Festival peace-offering</b> of the fourteenth <b>overrides Shabbat.</b>
<b>Rav said: What is ben Dortai’s reason? As it is written: “And you shall slaughter the Paschal offering to the Lord your God from the flock and from the herd,</b> in the place which the Lord shall choose to rest His name there” (Deuteronomy 16:2). A question must be asked: Does the Paschal offering come from the herd, i.e., from cattle? <b>Doesn’t the Paschal offering</b> come <b>from only the sheep and from the goats,</b> as commanded in the book of Exodus (12:5)? <b>Rather,</b> the verse should be understood as follows. <b>“Flock”; this</b> is referring to <b>the Paschal offering. “Herd”; this</b> is referring to <b>the Festival peace-offering</b> that is brought along with it. <b>And the Merciful One says: “And you shall slaughter the Paschal offering,”</b> thus teaching that the two offerings are sacrificed together. From here ben Dortai derived that the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth is like the Paschal offering in every way, and so it too overrides Shabbat.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Need we arise and explain the reason of those who separated</b> themselves from the other Rabbis? Ben Dortai and his son broke away from all the other sages of the Jewish people, and we need not occupy ourselves with the opinions of such people. <b>Rather, the verse comes</b> to explain the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman, for Rav Naḥman said that Rabba bar Avuh said: From where</b> is it derived that <b>a leftover Paschal offering is sacrificed as a peace-offering?</b> A leftover Paschal offering is an animal that had been consecrated as a Paschal offering but was subsequently lost and later found after a different animal had already been sacrificed in its place. Alternatively, if one set aside and consecrated money for the purchase of a Paschal lamb and then the price of livestock dropped so that there was money left over after the purchase was made, the extra money has the status of a leftover Paschal lamb.
<b>As it is stated: “And you shall slaughter the Paschal offering to the Lord your God from the flock and from the herd.” Does the Paschal offering come from the herd? Doesn’t it come from only the sheep and from the goats? Rather,</b> the verse comes to teach that <b>a leftover Paschal offering shall be</b> brought <b>as something that comes from the flock and from the herd,</b> that is, as a peace-offering, which may be brought from all types of flock and cattle, including both males and females.
The Gemara asks about the crux of the matter: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, what is the reason</b> that the Festival peace-offering <b>does not override Shabbat? It is certainly a communal offering,</b> and all communal offerings override Shabbat.
<b>Rabbi Ile’a said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda ben Safra: The verse said</b> with regard to the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>: <b>“And you shall celebrate it as a Festival for the Lord, seven days in the year;</b> it shall be a statute forever in your generations; you shall celebrate it in the seventh month” (Leviticus 23:41). Now is the festival of <i>Sukkot</i> <b>seven</b> days? <b>They are eight</b> days, as the Eighth Day of Assembly is always celebrated at the conclusion of <i>Sukkot</i>. <b>Rather, from here</b> we derive <b>that the Festival peace-offering</b> [<b><i>ḥagiga</i></b>], about which the verse states: “And you shall celebrate [<i>veḥagotem</i>] it,” <b>does not override Shabbat.</b> Since every eight-day period contains a Shabbat, the Torah said that the Festival [<i>ḥag</i>] is celebrated, i.e., the Festival peace-offering [<i>ḥagiga</i>] can be brought the entire seven days of the Festival.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said: I said before my teachers,</b> pointing out the following difficulty with regard to this source: <b>There are times when you find only six</b> days on which the Festival peace-offering can be brought, <b>for example, when the first day of the Festival occurs on Shabbat,</b> in which case the Eighth Day of Assembly also falls on Shabbat, and so there are only six days on which the Festival peace-offering may be brought. <b>Abaye said: Would the bereaved Avin,</b> another name for Ravin, <b>say such a thing</b> and be so careless as to ask an unfounded question? There is a big difference: <b>Eight you do not find at all;</b> the eight days of the Festival cannot possibly pass without a Shabbat. But <b>seven</b> days on which the Festival peace-offering can be brought <b>are</b> in fact <b>found in most years.</b>
<b>Ulla said that Rabbi Elazar said:</b> With regard to <b>peace-offerings that one slaughtered on the eve of the Festival, one fulfills with them neither</b> the mitzva to bring peace-offerings of <b>rejoicing nor</b> the mitzva to bring a <b>Festival peace-offering.</b> The mitzva of bringing peace-offerings of <b>rejoicing</b> is not fulfilled, <b>as it is written: “And you shall slaughter</b> peace-offerings and eat there, <b>and you shall rejoice</b> before the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 27:7). Based on this verse, <b>we require</b> that the <b>slaughter</b> be

Daf 71a

<b>at the time of rejoicing,</b> on the Festival itself, <b>and</b> if it was slaughtered on the fourteenth <b>it is not.</b> The mitzva to bring a <b>Festival peace-offering</b> is also not fulfilled, for <b>it is something that is an obligation,</b> as everyone is obligated to bring this offering, and the principle is that <b>anything that is an obligation must come only from that which is unconsecrated,</b> meaning that one cannot bring an obligatory offering from an animal that has already been consecrated for another purpose.
The Gemara proposes: <b>Let us say that</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>supports him.</b> The verse states: “Seven days shall you celebrate to the Lord your God in the place that the Lord shall choose, for the Lord your God shall bless you in all your produce and in all the work of your hands, and you shall be but joyous” (Deuteronomy 16:15). This verse seems superfluous, as it was already stated in the previous verse: “And you shall rejoice in your Festival.” The <i>baraita</i> expounds: <b>“And you shall be but joyous”</b> comes <b>to include the last night of the Festival.</b> Even then you must make sure there is <b>rejoicing</b> by eating the appropriate peace-offerings. The <i>baraita</i> considers: <b>Do you say</b> that the verse comes to include <b>the last night of the Festival? Or</b> perhaps <b>it</b> comes to include <b>only the first night of the Festival.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And you shall be <b>but joyous”;</b> the word “but” <b>restricts</b> this mitzva, meaning that there is not always a mitzva to be joyous.
The Gemara clarifies how this <i>baraita</i> supports Ulla: <b>What is the reason</b> that we learn from this expression that it is specifically on the first night that there is no mitzva of rejoicing? <b>Is it not because</b> on the first night <b>he has nothing with which to rejoice?</b> As Ulla said, one cannot fulfill the mitzva of rejoicing with a peace-offering that was slaughtered on the eve of the Festival, because it was not slaughtered at the time of rejoicing. On the last night of the Festival, on the other hand, one can rejoice with a peace-offering that was slaughtered the previous day, i.e., the last intermediate day of the Festival, which is also a time of rejoicing.
The Gemara rejects this support: <b>No,</b> it is not for this reason, but rather <b>for the reason taught</b> in the continuation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What did you see to include the last night of the Festival</b> in the mitzva of rejoicing <b>and to exclude the first night of the Festival,</b> a distinction that is not even hinted at in the verse? The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>I include the last night of the Festival</b> in the mitzva of rejoicing, <b>for there is rejoicing</b> on the days of the Festival <b>preceding it, and I exclude the first night of the Festival, for there is no</b> day of <b>rejoicing preceding it.</b> Thus, no support for Ulla can be deduced from the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> against the opinion of Ulla: It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth</b> that <b>one fulfills with it</b> the mitzva to bring peace-offerings of <b>rejoicing, but one does not fulfill with it</b> the mitzva to bring a <b>Festival peace-offering.</b> We can ask, <b>why?</b> Surely, according to Ulla, <b>we require</b> that the <b>slaughter</b> be performed <b>at a time of rejoicing, and</b> this requirement <b>is not</b> fulfilled in this case. The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Idi bar Avin said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring here to a case <b>where he delayed and slaughtered it</b> only on the fifteenth, i.e., on the Festival, which is a time of rejoicing.
<b>Rav Ashi said: So too, it is reasonable</b> to understand the <i>baraita</i> in this manner, <b>for if you do not say so,</b> but rather that the Festival peace-offering was slaughtered on the fourteenth, there is a difficulty, for <b>who taught this <i>baraita</i>?</b> Is it not <b>ben Teima</b> who taught it? According to <b>ben Teima,</b> however, <b>he has disqualified it by leaving it overnight,</b> for in his view this Festival peace-offering is similar to a Paschal lamb and may not be eaten the following day. <b>Learn from this</b> that the <i>baraita</i> must be referring to a case where the Festival peace-offering was slaughtered not on the fourteenth, but on the fifteenth.
