<b>Rava raised an objection</b> against the opinion of Ulla: It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>the <i>hallel</i></b> is recited <b>and</b> the mitzva of <b>rejoicing</b> with the peace-offerings of rejoicing is observed on the festival of <i>Sukkot</i> for <b>eight</b> days. Now <b>if you say we require</b> that the <b>slaughter</b> be performed <b>at a time of rejoicing, many times you find</b> that the mitzva of rejoicing is observed for <b>only seven</b> days, <b>such as when the first day of the Festival occurs on Shabbat,</b> when a peace-offering of rejoicing may not be slaughtered. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda, said: One rejoices with the male goats of the Festivals.</b> That is to say, in such a situation the mitzva of rejoicing can be fulfilled with the meat of the goats that are brought on the Festivals as sin-offerings, as these offerings, being communal offerings, may be slaughtered even on Shabbat.
<b>Rava said: There are two</b> possible <b>responses to</b> refute <b>this. One</b> is <b>that the male goats of the Festivals are eaten raw</b> and <b>are not eaten roasted.</b> Being a non-essential part of the service, roasting the meat is forbidden on Shabbat. Therefore, the meat can be eaten only raw, <b>and there is no rejoicing with raw</b> meat. <b>And furthermore,</b> only <b>the priests eat</b> of the meat of these sin-offerings. <b>With what</b> then <b>do</b> ordinary <b>Israelites rejoice? Rather, Rav Pappa said:</b> In such a situation, <b>one rejoices with clean clothes and old wine.</b>
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he related a different version of what <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> With regard to <b>peace-offerings that one slaughtered on the eve of the Festival, one fulfills with them</b> the mitzva to bring peace-offerings of <b>rejoicing, but one does not fulfill with them</b> the mitzva to bring a <b>Festival peace-offering.</b> He explains: <b>One fulfills</b> the mitzva of <b>rejoicing,</b> because <b>we do not require</b> that the <b>slaughter</b> be performed <b>at the time of rejoicing</b> as long as the offering is eaten at the time of rejoicing. <b>But one does not</b> fulfill the mitzva of the <b>Festival peace-offering,</b> because the Festival peace-offering is <b>something that is an obligation, and</b> the principle is that <b>anything that is an obligation must come only from unconsecrated</b> animals.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> against Ravin from the <i>baraita</i> that was taught above: <b>“And you shall be but joyous”</b> comes <b>to include the last night of the Festival</b> in the mitzva of <b>rejoicing.</b> The <i>baraita</i> considers: <b>Do you say</b> that the verse comes <b>to include the last night</b> in the mitzva of rejoicing? <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it</b> comes <b>to include only the first night of the Festival?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And you shall be <b>but</b> joyous”; the word <b>“but” restricts</b> this mitzva, meaning that there is not always a mitzva to be joyous.
The Gemara explains how this <i>baraita</i> is difficult according to Ravin: <b>What is the reason</b> that we learn from here that it is specifically on the first night that there is no mitzva of rejoicing? <b>Is it not because</b> on the first night <b>he has nothing with which to rejoice,</b> as one cannot fulfill the mitzva of rejoicing with peace-offerings slaughtered not at a time of rejoicing? The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>No,</b> the reason is <b>as it was taught</b> in the continuation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What did you see to include the last night of the Festival</b> in the mitzva of rejoicing <b>and to exclude the first night of the Festival?</b> The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>I include the last night of the Festival, for there is rejoicing</b> on the days of the Festival <b>preceding it, and I exclude the first night of the Festival, for there is no</b> day of <b>rejoicing preceding it.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana said: From where</b> is it derived that <b>the sacrificial parts of the Festival peace-offering of the fifteenth</b> of Nisan, i.e., those portions of the offering that are consumed on the altar, <b>are disqualified when left overnight</b> on the first night after the offering is slaughtered, despite the fact that the meat of the offering may be consumed for an additional day? <b>As it is stated:</b> “You shall not offer the blood of My offering with leaven; <b>neither shall the fat of my Festival offering be left over until morning”</b> (Exodus 23:18), <b>and, juxtaposed with it</b> is the word <b>first,</b> in the verse: “The first of the first fruits of your land you shall bring to the house of the Lord your God” (Exodus 23:19). This comes <b>to say</b> to us <b>that the morning</b> mentioned in the first verse is the <b>first morning</b> after the offering has been sacrificed.
<b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to this</b> proof: <b>The reason is that it wrote</b> the word <b>first. But had it not written</b> the word <b>first, I would have said: What is</b> the meaning of the term <b>morning? The second morning</b> after it was sacrificed. This raises a question: <b>Is there anything</b> like this <b>where the meat</b> of an offering that is to be eaten <b>is disqualified</b> already <b>from the evening,</b> as the meat of a Festival peace-offering may be eaten only for two days and the night between them, <b>while the sacrificial parts</b> to be consumed on the altar are permitted <b>until the</b> next <b>morning?</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: Why not? For</b> there is <b>the Paschal offering according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya,</b> who holds <b>that the meat</b> that is to be eaten <b>is disqualified</b> already <b>from midnight</b> and may no longer be eaten after that time, <b>while the sacrificial parts</b> to be consumed on the altar may be offered <b>until morning.</b>
<b>Rava said: This is what was difficult to Rav Yosef: Is there anything</b> like this, i.e., <b>that the <i>tanna</i> does not need</b> the word <b>“first”</b> to teach us that the word “morning,” written <b>with regard to the meat</b> of an offering, is referring to the first morning, <b>whereas Rav Kahana requires</b> the word <b>“first”</b> to teach us that the word “morning,” written <b>with regard to the sacrificial portions</b> to be consumed on the altar, is referring to the first morning? This is despite the fact that the latter, owing to their greater sanctity, are obviously more easily disqualified than the former.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this source alluded to by Rava? The Gemara explains: <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“Nor shall any of the meat that you sacrifice on the first day at evening remain overnight until the morning”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:4),

Daf 71b

this verse <b>teaches that the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth is eaten for two days and one night;</b> that is, it may not remain overnight until the morning of the sixteenth. <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is</b> eaten <b>for only a day and a night;</b> that is, it may not remain overnight until the morning of the fifteenth. Since for that it would have sufficed to say that an offering sacrificed “on the first day shall not remain overnight,” <b>when it says</b> that an offering sacrificed <b>“on the first day</b> shall not remain overnight <b>until the morning”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:4), the extra phrase “until the morning” indicates that the verse <b>speaks of the second morning.</b>
There is still room to say: <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is</b> eaten <b>only</b> until <b>the first morning, and how do I establish</b> what the Torah says, that <b>a Festival peace-offering may be eaten for two days and one night?</b> This applies to Festival peace-offerings <b>other than this</b> one. The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>When it says</b> with regard to a peace-offering: “But <b>if</b> the sacrifice of his offering <b>is a vow or a free-will offering,</b> it shall be eaten on the same day that he sacrifices his offering; and on the morrow also, the remainder of it shall be eaten” (Leviticus 7:16), <b>it teaches that</b> any peace-offering, whether a vow or a free-will offering, or an obligation, including <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth, is eaten for two days and one night.</b>
<b>The Master said</b> above in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only the first morning.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But you</b> already <b>said</b> that <b>when it says</b> that any offering sacrificed <b>“on the first day</b> shall not remain overnight <b>until the morning,”</b> the extra phrase “until the morning” indicates that the verse <b>speaks of the second morning.</b> What need is there then to prove this a second time? The Gemara explains that <b>this is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> that <b>the verse is speaking about two</b> different <b>Festival peace-offerings, one</b> being <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth and one the Festival peace-offering of the fifteenth,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>this,</b> the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth, may be eaten for only a day and a night until <b>its morning,</b> the morning of the fifteenth, <b>and this,</b> the Festival peace-offering of the fifteenth, may be eaten for only a day and a night until <b>its morning,</b> the sixteenth of Nisan.
<b>It then says: But</b> with regard to <b>that which we maintain, that a Festival peace-offering may be eaten for two days and one night, if so,</b> the verse that addresses a peace-offering and says: <b>“But if</b> the sacrifice of his offering <b>is a vow or a free-will offering,” with regard to what</b> case is it discussing? <b>If</b> it is talking about <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth, surely it is written about it,</b> according to this interpretation, that it is eaten for only <b>a day and a night. And if</b> it is talking about <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fifteenth, surely it is written about it</b> that it too is eaten for only <b>a day and a night.</b>
<b>Rather, this</b> verse that discusses a vow or free-will offering clearly must be discussing <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fifteenth, and the entire other verse:</b> “Nor shall…remain overnight until the morning,” is referring to <b>the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth</b> and thus <b>has taught that the Festival peace-offering of the fourteenth is eaten for two days and one night.</b>
The Gemara returns to what it wanted to prove with regard to the term “first”: <b>The reason is that it is written</b> that an offering sacrificed <b>“on the first day</b> shall not remain overnight <b>until the morning,” for what is</b> the implication of the word <b>morning? The second morning. We can infer</b> from here <b>that wherever</b> the term <b>morning is written unmodified</b> and without further specification, it is referring to <b>the first morning</b> after the offering was sacrificed, <b>even though</b> the word <b>“first” is not written in relation to</b> “morning.” Thus, Rav Kahana’s derivation from the word “first” was unnecessary.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A Paschal lamb that one slaughtered for a different purpose on Shabbat,</b> not knowing that it is prohibited for him to do so, is disqualified, and <b>he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering for it</b> because he unwittingly performed a prohibited labor on Shabbat.
As for <b>all other offerings,</b> such as a peace-offering, <b>that one</b> unwittingly <b>slaughtered</b> on Shabbat <b>for the purpose of a Paschal offering, if they were not fit</b> for the Paschal offering, e.g., if they were female or cattle or more than a year old and clearly ineligible for the Paschal offering, <b>he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering. Because he did not fulfill the mitzva to bring a Paschal offering, his act of slaughter was therefore unnecessary. <b>And if they were fit, Rabbi Eliezer</b> nevertheless <b>deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering</b> for his unwitting transgression. <b>But Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him, because he maintains that if someone intended to perform a mitzva, and despite his error he in fact performed a mitzva, he is not liable to bring a sin-offering. And in this case he performed a mitzva, because offerings that are sacrificed for a different purpose are still fit.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>If,</b> with regard to <b>the Paschal lamb, which is permitted</b> to be slaughtered on Shabbat <b>for its own purpose, when one changed its purpose he is</b> nevertheless <b>liable,</b> then, with regard to other <b>offerings that are forbidden</b> to be slaughtered on Shabbat even <b>for their own purpose, when one changed their purpose, is it not right that he should be liable? Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: No,</b> this reasoning is faulty. <b>If you say</b> that one is liable to bring a sin-offering if he slaughtered <b>a Paschal lamb</b> for a different purpose, it is <b>because he changed</b> its purpose <b>for something forbidden,</b> as the offering he intended it to be may not be slaughtered on Shabbat. But <b>can you</b> necessarily <b>say</b> the same thing <b>about</b> other <b>offerings that he</b> slaughtered for the purpose of a Paschal offering and thus <b>changed</b> their purpose <b>for something</b> that is <b>permitted</b> to be sacrificed on Shabbat?
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>Let the communal offerings,</b> such as the daily offering and the additional-offerings of Shabbat and the Festivals, <b>prove</b> the matter, <b>for they are permitted</b> to be slaughtered on Shabbat <b>for their own purpose, and</b> nevertheless, <b>one who</b> unnecessarily <b>slaughters</b> a different offering <b>for their purpose is liable.</b> This indicates that even when a particular offering may be slaughtered, one is nevertheless liable if he slaughtered a different offering for the purpose of the permitted offering. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: No, if you say</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>communal offerings,</b> it is <b>because they have a limit,</b> as there is a specific number of communal offerings that must be offered on any particular day and there is no reason one would mistakenly sacrifice extra offerings for this purpose. But <b>can you</b> necessarily <b>say</b> the same thing <b>about the Paschal lamb, which does not have a limit,</b> making it more likely for someone to make a mistake?
<b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> According to Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>even one who</b> unwittingly <b>slaughters</b> other offerings <b>for the purpose of communal offerings</b> beyond their daily limit <b>is exempt</b> for the same reason, i.e., that he intended to fulfill a mitzva that is permitted on Shabbat.
The mishna continues with another <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Paschal lamb: <b>If one slaughtered</b> a Paschal lamb on Shabbat and mistakenly intended it <b>for those who cannot eat it,</b> such as sick or elderly people who are unable to eat the meat, <b>or for those who did not register for it,</b> or <b>for</b> the sake of <b>the uncircumcised or for those ritually impure,</b> the offering is disqualified and <b>he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering for his unnecessary act of slaughter. If, however, he slaughtered it <b>for those who can eat it and for those who cannot eat it,</b> or <b>for those who registered for it and for those who did not register for it,</b> or <b>for the circumcised and for those who are uncircumcised,</b> or <b>for those who are ritually impure and those who are ritually pure, he is exempt.</b> Since a Paschal lamb slaughtered with dual intentions of these types is valid, the act of slaughter was justified.
If <b>he slaughtered it and it was found to have a blemish,</b> the offering is disqualified, and <b>he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering for having unwittingly performed a prohibited labor on Shabbat, as he should have examined the animal before it was slaughtered. If <b>he slaughtered it and it was found to have a hidden condition that would cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>]</b> and that could not have been discovered before the slaughter even if it were examined properly, the offering is disqualified, but <b>he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering. This is not a case of <i>shogeg</i>, unwitting violation of Shabbat, but rather of <i>ones</i>, an unavoidable accident.
If <b>he slaughtered it and</b> afterward <b>it became known that the owners had withdrawn</b> from it and registered for a different Paschal lamb, in which case this one was slaughtered unnecessarily, as no one was registered for it, <b>or</b> it became known that <b>they had died or became ritually impure,</b> in all these cases <b>he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering, <b>because he slaughtered with permission.</b> At the time of the slaughter, he did not know and had no reason to suspect that the offering would be disqualified.

Daf 72a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> When the mishna speaks of one who slaughtered a Paschal lamb on Shabbat for a different purpose, <b>with what</b> precisely <b>are we dealing? If you say</b> we are dealing <b>with one who erred</b> in that he actually thought this was a different offering and not a Paschal offering, <b>learn from it,</b> i.e., from the fact that the offering is disqualified and he is therefore liable to bring a sin-offering, that <b>the erroneous uprooting</b> of the status of an offering <b>constitutes uprooting,</b> even though he had no intention to do so. It would, however, be surprising to find the mishna taking a stand on this issue, as we find elsewhere that it is the subject of an amoraic dispute (<i>Tosafot</i>). <b>Rather,</b> the mishna must certainly be referring to <b>one who</b> intentionally <b>uprooted</b> the animal’s designation as a Paschal lamb and offered it as a different offering.
If so, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: As for <b>all other offerings that one</b> unwittingly <b>slaughtered</b> on Shabbat <b>for the purpose of a Paschal offering, if they were not fit</b> for the Paschal offering, <b>he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering. <b>And if they are fit, Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> whereas <b>Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him. <b>Now if</b> the mishna is referring to one who intentionally <b>uprooted</b> the original designation of the animal, which he knew was not a Paschal offering, <b>what does it matter to me whether</b> the animal was <b>fit or unfit?</b> He certainly does not think that he is performing a mitzva; why then does Rabbi Yehoshua exempt him from bringing a sin-offering?
<b>Rather, it is obvious</b> that we must be dealing with <b>one who erred.</b> But if so, we have a contradiction in the mishna, as <b>the first clause</b> is referring to <b>one who</b> intentionally <b>uprooted</b> the animal’s designation, <b>whereas the latter clause</b> is referring to <b>one who erred</b> about it. <b>Rabbi Avin said: Yes,</b> we must accept this conclusion even though it is unusual: <b>The first clause</b> deals with <b>one who uprooted</b> the animal’s designation, <b>whereas the latter clause</b> deals with <b>one who erred</b> about it.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef</b> once <b>found Rabbi Abbahu standing among a multitude [<i>okhlosa</i>] of people,</b> and <b>he said to him: What is</b> the meaning of <b>our mishna?</b> Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him: The first clause</b> is referring to <b>one who</b> intentionally <b>uprooted</b> the animal’s status, <b>whereas the latter clause</b> is referring to <b>one who erred</b> about it. Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef <b>learned</b> this statement <b>from him forty times, and it seemed to him as though it were resting in his pouch;</b> i.e., he repeated it many times until the mishna became crystal clear to him and etched in his memory.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with this understanding of the mishna: <b>We learned</b> in the continuation of the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer said</b> to Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>If</b> with regard to <b>the Paschal lamb, which is permitted</b> to be slaughtered on Shabbat <b>for its own purpose, when one changed its purpose he is</b> nevertheless <b>liable,</b> then with regard to other <b>offerings that are forbidden</b> to be slaughtered on Shabbat even <b>for their own purpose, when he changed their purpose is it not right that he should be liable? And if it is so</b> that the two parts of the mishna are not talking about the same case, <b>surely they are not similar</b> and cannot be compared; <b>as the first clause</b> is referring to <b>one who</b> intentionally <b>uprooted</b> the animal’s status, <b>whereas the latter clause</b> is referring to <b>one who erred</b> about it.
The Gemara answers: <b>According to Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who put forward this <i>a fortiori</i> argument, <b>there is no difference,</b> for in his opinion someone who erred while intending to perform a mitzva is liable to bring a sin-offering, even if he made a reasonable mistake. Thus, he does not differentiate between the deliberate uprooting of the animal’s status and the erroneous sacrificing of the offering for a different purpose. The Gemara asks: But <b>according to Rabbi Yehoshua, for whom there is a difference</b> between the two cases, <b>let him answer</b> Rabbi Eliezer in <b>this</b> way, that the first clause of the mishna is referring to one who intentionally uprooted the status of an offering, while the latter clause is referring to one who erred about it. Why does he introduce another factor, that in the first clause he changed the animal’s purpose for something forbidden, whereas in the latter clause he changed it for something permitted?
The Gemara explains that <b>this is what</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to</b> Rabbi Eliezer: <b>According to me,</b> these cases are <b>not comparable,</b> because <b>the first clause</b> deals <b>with one who</b> intentionally <b>uprooted</b> the animal’s designation, <b>whereas the latter clause</b> deals <b>with one who erred</b> about it. However, even <b>according to you,</b> who do not differentiate in this manner, I can still answer as follows: <b>No, if you say</b> that one is liable if he slaughtered <b>a Paschal lamb</b> for a different purpose, it is <b>because he changed its purpose for something prohibited.</b> But can <b>you say</b> the same thing <b>about</b> other <b>offerings that he</b> slaughtered for the purpose of a Paschal offering and thus <b>changed their purpose for something permitted?</b>
The mishna continues with what <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>Let the communal offerings prove</b> the matter, <b>for they are permitted</b> for slaughter on Shabbat <b>for their own purpose, and</b> nevertheless, <b>one who</b> unnecessarily <b>slaughters</b> different offerings <b>for their purpose is liable. Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: No, if you said</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>communal offerings,</b> it is <b>because they have a limit.</b> But can <b>you</b> necessarily <b>say</b> the same thing with <b>regard to the Paschal lamb, which does not have a limit?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that wherever there is a limit, Rabbi Yehoshua deems liable</b> one who erred while intending to perform a mitzva? <b>But</b> with regard to the circumcision of <b>babies</b> on Shabbat, <b>which has a limit, we</b> nevertheless <b>learned</b> in a mishna that with regard to <b>one who had two babies</b> to circumcise, <b>one</b> of whom he needed <b>to circumcise after Shabbat and one</b> of whom he needed <b>to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised</b> the one that should have been circumcised <b>after Shabbat on Shabbat, he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering. This is because he performed the prohibited labor of causing a wound not in the framework of performing a mitzva, as no obligation yet existed to circumcise the child.
If, however, there were two babies, <b>one</b> of whom he needed <b>to circumcise on Shabbat eve, and one</b> of whom he needed <b>to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> that he should have circumcised on <b>Shabbat eve on Shabbat, Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> As circumcision after its appointed time does not override Shabbat, he has therefore unwittingly violated Shabbat. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him. Since he intended to perform a mitzva, and despite his error in fact performed a mitzva, he is exempt from bringing a sin-offering. Thus, we see that even though there is a limit in the case of the babies, Rabbi Yehoshua nevertheless exempts one who errs while intending to perform a mitzva.
<b>Rabbi Ami said: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> the circumciser <b>first</b> unwittingly <b>circumcised</b> the baby who should have been circumcised on <b>Shabbat eve on Shabbat,</b> when <b>there is</b> still <b>this</b> other baby who should be circumcised on <b>Shabbat with whom he is preoccupied.</b> Since he was legitimately preoccupied with a mitzva, as he knew that there was a baby that needed to be circumcised, he is exempt from bringing a sin-offering. <b>Here,</b> however, with regard to offerings, we are dealing with a case <b>where he first slaughtered the</b> required <b>communal offerings at the beginning,</b> so that there was no need to slaughter any more offerings, as communal offerings have a limit. Since he had no reason to make a mistake, he is liable to bring a sin-offering for having unnecessarily slaughtered an animal on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> how do we understand the continuation of the mishna, where <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that according to Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>even one who</b> unwittingly <b>slaughters</b> other offerings <b>for the purpose of communal offerings</b> beyond their daily limit <b>is exempt?</b> According to our explanation, this must be true <b>even though he first slaughtered the</b> required <b>communal offerings at the beginning. But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya from</b> the village of <b>Avel Arav teach</b> in a <i>baraita</i> another version of the dispute, according to which <b>Rabbi Meir said: Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua did not disagree over one who had two babies</b> to circumcise, <b>one to circumcise</b> on <b>Shabbat eve and one to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the</b> one who should have been circumcised on <b>Shabbat eve on Shabbat;</b> in that case, everyone agrees <b>that he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering.
<b>With regard to what did they disagree? With regard to one who had two babies</b> to circumcise, <b>one to circumcise after Shabbat and one to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the</b> baby who should have been circumcised <b>after Shabbat on Shabbat, as Rabbi Eliezer deems him liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> this <i>baraita</i> in its current formulation? <b>If there,</b> in the latter clause, where he circumcised the baby who should have been circumcised after Shabbat on Shabbat, so that <b>he did not perform a mitzva</b> because the baby was not yet eight days old and the mitzva did not yet apply, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua</b> nevertheless <b>exempted</b> him because he erred while intending to perform a mitzva. Then <b>where he did perform a mitzva,</b> i.e., where he circumcised a baby on Shabbat who was already eight days old before Shabbat and to whom the mitzva of circumcision applied, would Rabbi Yehoshua <b>deem him liable?</b>
The Rabbis of <b>the school of Rabbi Yannai said: The first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a unique situation, <b>where</b> the circumciser <b>first</b> unwittingly <b>circumcised on Shabbat eve</b> the baby who should have been circumcised on <b>Shabbat.</b>

Daf 72b

In that case, <b>Shabbat does not stand to be overridden</b> at all. Since the baby who should have been circumcised on Shabbat was already circumcised, and the only one left is the baby who should have been circumcised on Friday, the circumciser should have known that he has no circumcisions to perform on Shabbat, because a circumcision that was delayed beyond the eighth day does not override Shabbat. Therefore, he is liable if he performed the circumcision on Shabbat. In <b>the latter clause,</b> however, the circumcision was performed in a situation where <b>Shabbat stands to be overridden for him,</b> as the baby who should have been circumcised on Shabbat was not yet circumcised.
Based on the understanding that everything depends on whether or not Shabbat stands to be overridden, it may be argued that <b>here</b> too, <b>Shabbat stands to be overridden with regard to a communal offering.</b> Therefore, one who on Shabbat unwittingly slaughters other offerings for the purpose of communal offerings is exempt from bringing a sin-offering, because he knows that communal offerings must be brought on Shabbat, and consequently there is some justification for his error.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana</b> that this explanation is difficult: <b>Here too,</b> it may be argued that <b>Shabbat stands to be overridden with regard to babies in general,</b> as it is permitted to circumcise a baby whose eighth day occurs on Shabbat, and so there is some minimal justification for his mistake. Rav Kahana <b>said to him:</b> That is indeed so. <b>However, with regard to this person,</b> Shabbat <b>does not stand</b> to be overridden, as there is no longer any child who is supposed to be circumcised on Shabbat. Therefore, if he unwittingly performed a circumcision on Shabbat, it is not considered as if he performed a transgression while preoccupied with the performance of a mitzva.
We learned in the mishna with regard to <b>all other offerings that one</b> unwittingly <b>slaughtered</b> on Shabbat <b>for the purpose of a Paschal offering,</b> that <b>if they were not fit</b> for the Paschal offering, <b>he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering, <b>and if they were fit, Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i> that distinguishes between</b> offerings <b>that are fit</b> for the Paschal lamb <b>and those that are not fit?</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>It is Rabbi Shimon, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one unwittingly slaughters other offerings on Shabbat for the purpose of a Paschal offering, <b>whether</b> they are <b>offerings that are fit</b> for the Paschal lamb <b>or</b> they are <b>offerings that are not fit, and similarly,</b> if <b>he</b> unwittingly <b>slaughters</b> other offerings <b>for the purpose of communal offerings</b> on Shabbat, <b>he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Shimon said: Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua did not disagree about</b> one who slaughtered offerings <b>that are not fit,</b> for in that case all agree <b>that he is liable. With regard to what did they disagree? With regard to</b> one who slaughtered offerings <b>that are fit, for Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering and Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him. This indicates that the unattributed ruling of our mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.
<b>Rav Beivai said that Rabbi Elazar said: Rabbi Meir would exempt</b> him <b>even</b> in the case of <b>a calf of a peace-offering that he slaughtered for the purpose of the Paschal offering,</b> even though one does not ordinarily mistake a calf for a lamb. <b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rav Beivai: But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir conceded</b> that if one slaughtered <b>blemished</b> animals on Shabbat he is liable to bring a sin-offering? <b>He said to him: With regard to blemished</b> animals, <b>he is not</b> at all <b>preoccupied with them,</b> because he knows that they are ineligible to be offered as sacrifices. <b>But as for this</b> calf, <b>he is preoccupied with</b> sacrificing it as an offering, and he may therefore make a mistake.
<b>Rava raised a dilemma before</b> Rav Naḥman: If one unwittingly slaughtered an <b>unconsecrated</b> animal <b>for the purpose of a Paschal offering, what would Rabbi Meir say?</b> Would he exempt him in this case as well? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Rabbi Meir would exempt</b> him <b>even</b> if he slaughtered an <b>unconsecrated</b> animal <b>for the purpose of a Paschal offering.</b>
Rava asked him: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir concedes</b> that if one slaughtered <b>blemished</b> animals on Shabbat he is liable to bring a sin-offering, as they are never sacrificed as offerings, and similarly, unconsecrated animals are never sacrificed as offerings? Rav Naḥman responded: There is room for a distinction. <b>Blemished</b> animals <b>cannot be confused</b> with unblemished ones, and so there is no legitimate reason for error; but <b>these,</b> i.e., unconsecrated animals, <b>can</b> easily <b>be confused</b> with consecrated animals, as they are externally indistinguishable from one another, and therefore one who confuses them is exempt.
Rava asked further: <b>And is Rabbi Meir’s reason</b> really <b>that these can be confused and these cannot be confused</b> with a legitimate offering? <b>But didn’t Rav Beivai say that Rabbi Elazar said</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir would exempt</b> him <b>even</b> in the case of <b>a calf of a peace-offering that he slaughtered for the purpose of the Paschal offering,</b> even though there is no way to mistake a calf for an animal that can be brought for the Paschal offering? Therefore, <b>it is apparent</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir’s reason is that he is preoccupied</b> with sacrificing the calf as an offering, and consequently he is exempt if he erred and slaughtered it for the purpose of a Paschal lamb. But why should one be exempt if he brought an unconsecrated animal for the purpose of a Paschal offering? He is not preoccupied with bringing it as an offering.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him:</b> Both reasons apply according to Rabbi Meir. If one is <b>preoccupied</b> with bringing the animal as an offering, he is exempt <b>even though</b> the animal <b>cannot</b> easily <b>be confused</b> with the one he was supposed to sacrifice. And when the animal <b>can</b> easily <b>be confused</b> with the one set aside as an offering, he is exempt, <b>even though he is not preoccupied</b> with bringing it as an offering. This comes <b>to exclude blemished</b> animals, <b>which cannot be confused</b> with unblemished animals <b>and</b> with whose sacrifice he <b>is not preoccupied.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak were sitting on the porch of Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak, and they sat and said: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: If one</b> unwittingly <b>confused a spit of leftover</b> sacrificial meat, which it is prohibited to eat and which makes one liable to receive the punishment of <i>karet</i> when one eats it intentionally, <b>with a spit of roasted</b> sacrificial meat, which is a mitzva to eat, <b>and he ate it, he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering. Although he intended to do a mitzva, since he unwittingly transgressed the prohibition against eating leftover sacrificial meat, he must bring a sin-offering.
<b>And</b> they further reported that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If <b>one</b> unwittingly <b>engaged in sexual intercourse with his wife while she was menstruating, he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering. But if <b>he</b> unwittingly <b>engaged in sexual intercourse with his sister-in-law who was waiting</b> to become his wife through <b>levirate marriage while she was menstruating, he is exempt,</b> because the act of intercourse itself is a mitzva. A man whose brother died without children is obliged by Torah law to marry his deceased brother’s widow and “come to her” (Deuteronomy 25:5), so that even if he mistakenly transgressed while attempting to fulfill the mitzva, he is exempt from bringing a sin-offering.
The Gemara attempts to determine whether Rabbi Yoḥanan agrees or disagrees with Reish Lakish’s ruling: <b>Some say</b> that <b>all the more so in the</b> first case, where one unwittingly ate a spit of leftover sacrificial meat, Rabbi Yoḥanan would <b>deem</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring a sin-offering, <b>for he did not</b> actually <b>perform a mitzva</b> when he ate the meat, even though he intended to do so. This stands in contrast to the second case, where the person unwittingly engaged in sexual intercourse with his wife while she was menstruating, where he at least performed a small mitzva, as will be explained shortly.
<b>Others say</b> that according to Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>in that</b> case where one ate leftover sacrificial meat, <b>he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering. <b>What is the reason? There,</b> where he had sexual intercourse with his wife while she was menstruating, he is liable, <b>for he should have asked</b> her if she was menstruating, and because he failed to do so he is liable to bring a sin-offering. <b>But here, where</b> he ate a spit of leftover sacrificial meat, <b>he did not have</b> anyone <b>to ask,</b> and so he is <b>not</b> liable to bring a sin-offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, what is different</b> about one who unwittingly engaged in sexual intercourse with <b>his sister-in-law,</b> in that he is exempt from bringing a sin-offering? Is it <b>that he performed a mitzva,</b> i.e., the mitzva of levirate marriage? If so, then <b>also</b> in the case where he unwittingly engaged in sexual intercourse with <b>his wife</b> while she was menstruating, <b>he performed a mitzva,</b> for he occupied himself in the fulfillment of the mitzva of procreation. The Gemara answers that we are dealing here with a case <b>where his wife is pregnant,</b> such that intercourse cannot lead to procreation.
The Gemara raises another question: Nevertheless, <b>there is</b> the mitzva of the <b>enjoyment of conjugal rights.</b> One of a husband’s marital obligations is to engage in sexual intercourse with his wife at regular intervals (see Exodus 21:10), and this is considered a mitzva. The Gemara answers that we are talking about a case <b>where it is not the time of her conjugal rights.</b>
The Gemara asks further: Even so, <b>didn’t Rava say</b> that <b>a man is obligated to please his wife through a mitzva?</b> That is to say, he must engage in sexual intercourse with her when she so desires, even if it is not the time of her conjugal rights. The Gemara answers that we are dealing with a case where it was <b>near her expected date</b> of menstruation, when sexual relations are prohibited due to a concern that the woman may already be menstruating or that she may begin to menstruate during the sexual act.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if they engaged in sexual intercourse near the woman’s expected date of menstruation when he should have refrained from doing so, then <b>even</b> in the case where he had sexual intercourse with <b>his sister-in-law</b> and she turned out to be menstruating, he should <b>also</b> be liable, as the mitzva of levirate marriage does not apply at that time. The Gemara explains that with regard to <b>his sister-in-law, he is</b> still <b>shy [<i>bazeiz</i>]</b> in front <b>of her</b> and uncomfortable asking her whether she is close to her expected menstruation date, whereas with regard to <b>his wife, he is not shy</b> in front <b>of her,</b> and so he should have asked her.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan, in accordance with whose</b> opinion did he rule with regard to one who erred while engaged in a mitzva? <b>If you say</b> he ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> If <b>the first Festival day of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i> <b>occurs on Shabbat, and he forgot and carried</b> his <b><i>lulav</i> out into the public domain</b> and continued to transport it there, unwittingly performing a prohibited labor, <b>he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering. That is <b>because he carried it out with permission,</b> that is to say, he was acting with the intention of fulfilling a mitzva.
There is room to differentiate between Rabbi Yosei’s ruling and that of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>Perhaps it is different there, as he is pressed for time.</b> Since by Torah law the mitzva of <i>lulav</i> applies only one day a year, he is anxious to fulfill the mitzva and therefore does not realize that he is violating a Torah prohibition. This is unlike the case of levirate marriage, which need not be performed at any specific time and about which he is less pressured.
<b>Rather,</b> one might say that Rabbi Yoḥanan issued his ruling in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua</b> in our mishna <b>with regard to offerings,</b> for according to Rabbi Yehoshua, one who unwittingly slaughtered another offering on Shabbat for the purpose of a Paschal offering, and the animal was fit to be brought as a Paschal offering, is exempt from bringing a sin-offering. Here too, however, there is room to differentiate. <b>Perhaps there also</b> we can say that Rabbi Yehoshua exempts him because <b>he is pressed for time.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> one might say that Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua with regard to babies,</b> one that should have been circumcised on Shabbat eve and the other on Shabbat, and the circumciser forgot and circumcised the one that should have been circumcised on Shabbat eve on Shabbat. In that case the circumciser is exempt from bringing a sin-offering. But once again there is room to differentiate: Perhaps <b>there too,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua exempts him because <b>he is pressed for time.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> we should say that Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua with regard to <i>teruma</i>, as we learned</b> in a mishna: If a priest <b>was eating <i>teruma</i>, and it became known that he was the son of a divorced woman or a woman who underwent <i>ḥalitza</i></b> and he is therefore disqualified from the priesthood and may not eat <i>teruma</i>, <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to pay <b>the</b> value of the <b>principal and</b> an additional <b>fifth,</b> like any non-priest who unwittingly ate <i>teruma</i>, whereas <b>Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him. In this case, one who thought he was a priest and therefore fulfilling a mitzva when he ate the <i>teruma</i> was actually committing a transgression, but nevertheless, Rabbi Yehoshua exempts him from the ordinary penalty. On the face of it, this is similar to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling.
This comparison can, however, be rejected, for <b>perhaps</b> that case should be explained <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye. For Rav Beivai bar Abaye said:</b> The mishna is talking about a disqualified priest who ate <b><i>teruma</i></b> which is leaven <b>on the eve of Passover, whose time is pressing,</b> because if he does not eat it quickly he will have to burn it.
<b>Alternatively,</b> there may be another reason to differentiate: Eating <b><i>teruma</i> is different, because it is called</b> sacred <b>service, and the Merciful One validates service</b> performed by someone of priestly descent even if he is not fit for the priesthood.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: If a priest <b>was standing and sacrificing offerings</b> on the altar, <b>and it became known that he was the son of a divorced woman or the son of a woman who underwent <i>ḥalitza</i>, all the offerings that he offered on the altar</b> until that time <b>are disqualified,</b> because only service performed by a priest deemed fit is acceptable. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua validates</b> them. <b>And we said: What is the reason of Rabbi Yehoshua? As it is written</b> with regard to the tribe of Levi: <b>“Bless, Lord, his substance and accept the work of his hands”</b> (Deuteronomy 33:11), which teaches that after the fact, God accepts the work of a priest’s hands, even if it becomes clear that he was actually disqualified at the time he performed the service.
The Gemara questions what was stated above: <b>And where is <i>teruma</i> called service?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving Rabbi Tarfon, who did not come in the evening to the study hall. In the morning, Rabban Gamliel found him</b> and <b>said to him: For what</b> reason <b>did you not come in the evening to the study hall? He said to him: I was performing</b> sacred <b>service. He said to him: All your words are astonishing; from where</b> do we have <b>service in this time</b> after the destruction of the Temple? <b>He said to him: It says</b> in Scripture:

Daf 73a

<b>“I have given you the priesthood as a service of gift; and the stranger that comes near shall be put to death”</b> (Numbers 18:7). This verse is found in the context of the priestly gifts, including <i>teruma</i>, and comes to teach us that <b>they made the eating of <i>teruma</i> in the outlying areas,</b> i.e., outside the Temple, <b>like the service of the Temple.</b>
We learned in our mishna that if <b>one</b> unwittingly <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb on Shabbat <b>for those who cannot eat it</b> or for those who did not register for it, he is liable to bring a sin-offering. The Gemara asks: <b>It is obvious. Since there,</b> with regard to the slaughter itself, <b>it is invalid, here,</b> with regard to Shabbat, <b>he is liable,</b> for it turns out that he performed a prohibited labor that was not necessary for sacrificing an offering. The Gemara answers: <b>Since the latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>taught</b> cases in which he is <b>exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering, <b>the first clause taught</b> cases in which he is <b>liable,</b> even though it does not really teach us anything new.
The Gemara asks: <b>But this also is obvious, since there,</b> the offering is <b>valid, here</b> with regard to Shabbat <b>he is exempt,</b> as the slaughter did not involve a desecration of Shabbat. <b>Rather, since</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> the case of one who <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>for a different purpose on Shabbat, it also taught</b> the case of one who slaughtered it <b>for those who cannot eat it.</b> The Gemara asks further: <b>And it itself,</b> the case of slaughtering the Paschal offering for a different purpose, <b>why do I</b> need it? The <i>halakha</i> there is also obvious. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the mishna <b>wished</b> to teach <b>the dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> it taught all these other <i>halakhot</i> as well.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana said to his son: When you go before Rabbi Zerika, ask him: According to the opinion that says that one who inflicts a destructive wound is exempt,</b> i.e., that one who causes a wound on Shabbat that has no constructive effect but rather is purely destructive in nature has not performed a prohibited labor and is therefore exempt from bringing a sin-offering, how are we to understand the mishna’s ruling that <b>one who slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>for those who cannot eat it is liable?</b> Since the slaughter is invalid, he should be seen as having wounded the animal in a way that brings no benefit and is simply destructive. <b>What has he improved</b> through the slaughter that he should be liable for having performed a prohibited labor?
The Gemara answers: <b>He has improved</b> it in that <b>if</b> the sacrificial parts of the offering <b>ascended</b> to the top of the altar, <b>they do not descend.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that if the sacrificial parts of a disqualified offering are inadvertently brought up to the top of the altar, they need not be removed and they may be burned on the altar. Thus, the slaughter had some constructive effect.
The Gemara asks further: We learned in the mishna that if one <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and it was found to have a blemish, he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering. Here too, it may be asked: <b>What has he improved</b> through the slaughter, so that he should be liable? The Gemara answers: <b>He has improved</b> it if the blemish was small, e.g., if it was <b>on the</b> animal’s <b>eyelid, and in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that in the case of an offering with such a small blemish, <b>if</b> its sacrificial parts <b>ascended</b> to the top of the altar, <b>they do not descend</b> from it, because it is not a disgrace to the altar for the sacrificial parts of such an offering to be burned on it.
We learned in the next clause of our mishna that if one <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and it was found to have a hidden condition that would cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>], he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering. The mishna’s wording indicates that <b>if</b> the animal’s condition <b>is visible,</b> its owner <b>is liable.</b> It may be asked: <b>What has he improved</b> by slaughtering an animal with a such a condition? The Gemara answers: <b>He has improved</b> it in that he <b>removed it from</b> the category of <b>an animal carcass [<i>neveila</i>],</b> i.e., an animal that died of natural causes or as the result of an improperly carried out act of ritual slaughter. Had the animal died on its own it would have been treated as a <i>neveila</i>, which is a primary source of ritual impurity, rendering those who touch or carry it ritually impure. Proper slaughter of the animal prevents it from falling into that category and imparting ritual impurity.
<b>Ravina strongly objects to this:</b> With regard to <b>that which was taught</b> elsewhere in a <i>baraita</i>, that <b>one who</b> unwittingly <b>slaughters a sin-offering on Shabbat outside</b> the Temple <b>for</b> the sake of <b>idolatry is liable to</b> bring <b>three sin-offerings for it:</b> For desecrating Shabbat, for slaughtering an offering outside the Temple, and for practicing idolatry; here too, the question may be raised: <b>What has he improved</b> by slaughtering the animal? Here we cannot answer that he removed it from the category of an animal carcass and prevented it from becoming a primary source of ritual impurity, because any animal that was used as an idolatrous offering imparts ritual impurity. Therefore, it would seem that the slaughter served no constructive purpose.
<b>Rav Avira said:</b> Even here he has improved it in that <b>he removed it from</b> the category of <b>limbs from a living creature.</b> Even a gentile is liable if he eats meat taken from a living animal, but once the animal is slaughtered there is no longer any liability. Accordingly, even this act of slaughter has achieved a productive result.
We learned in the mishna that if <b>one slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and it became known</b> afterward that the owners had died, he is exempt from bringing a sin-offering. <b>Rav Huna said that Rav said:</b> Regarding <b>a guilt-offering that was consigned to grazing:</b> If the owner of a guilt-offering dies or achieves atonement through a different guilt-offering, the animal is sent out to graze in the field until it develops a blemish, at which point it can be sold. The money from the sale is used to purchase a burnt-offering. <b>And</b> if, before it developed a blemish, someone <b>slaughtered it without specifying</b> its purpose, <b>it is valid as a burnt-offering.</b> The Gemara concludes that Rav <b>apparently holds that it does not require uprooting.</b> There is no need for an explicit declaration in order to change the status of the offering; even if it is slaughtered without its purpose specified it is valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> even <b>when it has not</b> yet <b>been consigned</b> to grazing, it should <b>also</b> be valid, for any guilt-offering whose owner has achieved atonement through a different offering is presumably going to be brought as a free-will burnt-offering. The Gemara answers: This invalidation stems from a rabbinic <b>decree</b> with regard to a guilt-offering <b>after</b> its owner achieved <b>atonement</b> with a different offering <b>due to</b> concern about a guilt-offering <b>before</b> its owner achieved <b>atonement</b> with a different offering. Before the owner achieves atonement the animal is certainly considered a guilt-offering; it is only after the owner achieves atonement that the offering becomes valid for use as a burnt-offering, and then by strict <i>halakha</i> it is immediately valid for that purpose, even before the animal develops a blemish.
<b>From where do you say</b> that this is the case? <b>As we learned</b> elsewhere in a mishna: <b>A guilt-offering whose owner has died or whose owner has achieved atonement</b> through a different guilt-offering <b>grazes until it becomes unfit,</b> whereupon <b>it is sold and its money is used for a</b> communal <b>free-will burnt-offering. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> This guilt-offering is made to <b>die</b> on its own. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> When it develops a blemish, <b>it is sold, and he brings a burnt-offering</b> for himself <b>with its money.</b>
This indicates that according to Rabbi Yehoshua, as soon as the owner achieves atonement, his animal loses its status as a guilt-offering and it becomes a burnt-offering. Nevertheless, even he says that the animal that is bought <b>with its money</b> may <b>indeed</b> be brought as a burnt-offering, <b>but</b> the guilt-offering <b>itself</b> must <b>not</b> be sacrificed as a burnt-offering. Undoubtedly, his reason must be that the Sages issued <b>a decree</b> with regard to a guilt-offering <b>after</b> its owner achieved <b>atonement</b> with a different offering, <b>due to</b> concern about a guilt-offering <b>before</b> its owner achieved <b>atonement</b> with a different offering. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that this is correct.
<b>Rav Ḥisda raised an objection to Rav Huna</b> with regard to his opinion about uprooting the status of an offering from what we learned in our mishna: If <b>one slaughtered</b> a Paschal lamb on Shabbat <b>and</b> afterward <b>it became known that the owners had withdrawn</b> from it and registered for a different one, or that they had died or become ritually impure, he is exempt from bringing a sin-offering, because he slaughtered with permission.

Daf 73b

<b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to this</b> mishna that <b>on a weekday, in a case like this,</b> where it turns out that there is no one to eat the Paschal offering, <b>it should be burned immediately. Granted, if you say</b> that an offering that has no owner <b>requires uprooting</b> from its previous status in order for its status to change and in the absence of explicit uprooting it retains its original status, here too it can be argued that <b>this is</b> still <b>a Paschal offering. And since it has no owners, its disqualification is in</b> the body of the offering <b>itself,</b> because it was sacrificed for no purpose, and <b>therefore it should be burned immediately.</b>
<b>But if you say</b> that an offering such as this <b>does not require uprooting,</b> but rather its original status is automatically void upon the death of its owner, and <b>it was a peace-offering from the beginning,</b> as a Paschal offering whose status has been revoked is considered a peace-offering, <b>due to what</b> then <b>is its disqualification? Due to something else,</b> i.e., <b>that he slaughtered it after the daily afternoon offering,</b> which is the proper time to slaughter the Paschal lamb. But a peace-offering that is slaughtered then is disqualified. In that case, however, <b>it should require</b> that it be left overnight until <b>its form decays,</b> thus attaining the status of leftover sacrificial meat, and only then should it be burned.
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>This is the principle: Any</b> offering <b>whose disqualification is in</b> the body of the offering <b>itself should be burned immediately</b> and without delay. But if the disqualification is <b>in the blood</b> of the offering or <b>in the owners,</b> the meat must be kept overnight, so that <b>its form</b> is allowed to <b>decay,</b> and only then <b>should it be taken out to the place of burning.</b> Thus, the <i>baraita</i> that says that a Paschal lamb that was slaughtered on a weekday, and afterward it became known that the owners had died, should be burned immediately proves, against the opinion of Rav Huna, that an offering that has no owners still requires explicit uprooting from its previous status for its status to change.
<b>Rather, do not say</b> that Rav said that a guilt-offering that one <b>slaughtered without specification is valid as a burnt-offering. Say rather</b> that he said that if one took a guilt-offering whose owner had already achieved atonement through a different animal and he explicitly <b>slaughtered it as a burnt-offering, it is valid.</b> And conclude from this that Rav <b>apparently</b> holds that changing the status of an offering <b>requires</b> explicit <b>uprooting.</b>
The Gemara asks: A difficulty arises <b>according to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Gamda, who</b> dealt with the question whether a Paschal lamb requires uprooting and <b>said</b> that <b>it was thrown out from the group</b> of scholars who were studying the issue, <b>and they</b> all <b>said</b> as follows: Uprooting is required in a case <b>where the owners</b> of the offering <b>were ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse</b> during the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>and they were pushed off to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>,</b> for in that case, they presumably want to sacrifice this animal as their Paschal offering on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, and therefore its status does not change unless it is explicitly uprooted.
The Gemara infers from this that <b>it is</b> only <b>this</b> offering that <b>requires</b> explicit <b>uprooting,</b> because it is reasonable to assume that its owners still intend to use it for its original purpose, <b>but in general it does not require uprooting.</b> According to this opinion, <b>what is there to say,</b> as it would seem that our mishna indicates that explicit uprooting is necessary?
<b>Rather, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: With what are we dealing here</b> in our mishna? We are dealing with a case <b>where they designated</b> the animal to be sacrificed as their Paschal offering <b>before midday,</b> and midday came and it was firmly established as their Paschal offering, <b>and the owners died after midday, such that</b> the offering <b>was</b> first considered <b>fit and</b> then <b>rejected:</b> It was originally fit to be sacrificed as either a Paschal offering or a peace-offering, and then it was rejected as a peace-offering when it was firmly established as a Paschal offering, and rejected as a Paschal offering when its owners died. And the principle is that <b>anything that was</b> first <b>fit and</b> afterward <b>rejected does not return to being fit.</b> The offering is therefore disqualified and burned immediately, as it can never be brought as a Paschal offering or as a peace-offering.
The Gemara rejects this answer: <b>Is this reason</b> necessary <b>for anyone but Rav,</b> who holds that explicit uprooting is not required? <b>But Rav</b> himself <b>said</b> that <b>living creatures cannot be</b> permanently <b>rejected.</b> The <i>halakha</i> of rejection applies only to animals that were already slaughtered, but living creatures cannot be permanently rejected from their sanctified status or eligibility for a mitzva.
<b>Rather, Rav Pappa said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i> that adds to the mishna the detail that on a weekday the disqualified offering is immediately burned? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said: And similarly,</b> if <b>one slaughtered another</b> offering, such as a peace-offering, <b>for the purpose of a Paschal offering,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> If so, <b>its disqualification is in</b> the body of the offering <b>itself,</b> and so it should be burned immediately.
The Gemara asks: <b>But if it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, he would deem him liable also to bring a sin-offering</b> for having slaughtered an invalid offering on Shabbat, <b>for Rabbi Eliezer does not accept</b> the position that <b>one who errs in regard to a mitzva is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering. This explanation must, therefore, be rejected.
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef, son of Rav Salla the Ḥasid, explained before Rav Pappa</b> as follows: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Yosef ben Ḥonai. As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Yosef ben Ḥonai says:</b> Other offerings <b>that are slaughtered for the purpose of a Paschal offering or for the purpose of a sin-offering are disqualified,</b> as he agrees with Rabbi Eliezer in this regard. <b>It is apparent</b> that <b>its disqualification is in</b> the body of the offering <b>itself and therefore it should be burned immediately. But with regard to exemptions</b> from sin-offerings in cases of unintentional desecration of Shabbat, <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> that one who errs in regard to a mitzva is exempt.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> a different answer to this question: <b>Rav said</b> his ruling with regard to a guilt-offering <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: If</b> one slaughtering the Paschal offering on Shabbat still <b>has time in the day to clarify whether the owners withdrew or died or became ritually impure, he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering for having slaughtered on Shabbat, <b>and</b> the meat must be kept overnight so that <b>its form</b> be allowed to <b>decay, and</b> then <b>it should be taken out to the place of burning. What is the reason</b> that its form must be allowed to decay? <b>Is it not because</b> he holds that <b>it does not require uprooting?</b> And for that reason the disqualification is not inherent in the offering, and so it must be left overnight to attain the status of leftover sacrificial meat before being burned.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>From where</b> is this known to be correct? <b>Perhaps</b> it requires uprooting and the disqualification is inherent. And the fact that he requires decay of form <b>is because he agrees with the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabba bar Avuh, who said</b> that <b>even <i>piggul</i>,</b> an offering disqualified by improper intent, which is considered an inherent disqualification, <b>also requires decay of form, for he derived</b> this requirement by way of a verbal analogy between the word <b>“iniquity”</b> (Leviticus 7:18) stated in relation to an offering disqualified by improper intent and the word <b>“iniquity”</b> (Leviticus 19:7) stated <b>with regard to leftover</b> sacrificial meat.
<b>For if you do not say so,</b> i.e., that the <i>baraita</i> was taught in accordance with this opinion, then in a case in which <b>the owners became ritually impure, what is there to say?</b> In that case <b>it certainly requires uprooting, for Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Gamda said</b> that <b>it was thrown out from the group</b> of scholars who were studying the issue: Uprooting is required in a case <b>where the owners</b> of the offering <b>were ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse</b> during the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>and they were pushed off to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.</b> Since their offering is presumably set to be used on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, explicit change of the offering’s status is required.
<b>Rather, it is clear</b> that it is <b>as he answered at the beginning,</b> that our mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Yosef ben Ḥonai.</b> Therefore, on weekdays the offering is burned immediately, and on Shabbat, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, one does not become liable to bring a sin-offering.

Daf 74a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>How does one roast the Paschal lamb? One brings a spit [<i>shappud</i>] of pomegranate</b> wood <b>and thrusts it into the mouth</b> of the lamb <b>until</b> it reaches <b>its anus, and</b> one then <b>puts its legs and entrails inside it</b> and roasts it all together; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> One does not insert its legs and entrails inside it, as <b>this is a type of cooking.</b> Anything placed inside the offering does not get roasted directly by the fire and is considered to have been cooked. <b>Rather, one suspends</b> the legs and entrails from the spit above the animal’s head <b>outside it. One</b> may <b>not roast the Paschal lamb on the</b> metal <b>spit nor on</b> a metal <b>grill [<i>askela</i>].</b> However, <b>Rabbi Tzadok said: There was an incident with Rabban Gamliel, who said to his slave Tavi: Go and roast the Paschal lamb for us on the grill.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let them bring a metal</b> spit. The Gemara answers: With regard to a metal utensil, <b>once part of it is hot, it is all hot, and</b> the meat is <b>roasted due to the</b> heat of the <b>spit. And the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that the Paschal lamb must be <b>roasted in fire and not roasted through something else.</b> The Gemara asks why it is necessary to use specifically a spit of pomegranate wood: <b>Let them bring</b> a spit <b>of palm</b> wood. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the palm branch <b>has grooves</b> between the leaves, <b>it gives off</b> a small amount of <b>water</b> from the grooves during roasting. The meat of the offering that touches the spit <b>is as though it is cooked.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let them bring</b> a spit <b>of fig</b> wood. The Gemara answers: <b>Since it is hollow</b> and has sap inside, <b>it gives off water, and it is as though</b> the meat <b>is cooked.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let them bring</b> a spit made <b>from an oak</b> or <b>from a carob</b> tree or <b>from a sycamore,</b> which are hard and do not have sap. The Gemara answers: With regard to each one of these trees, <b>since it has knots</b> and one must cut them off in order to smooth the branch, <b>it gives off water</b> from the locations of the cuts during roasting, and the meat is considered cooked.
The Gemara asks: A branch <b>from a pomegranate</b> tree <b>also has knots.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Its knots are smooth.</b> There is no need to straighten the branch with a knife in order to use it, and therefore it does not emit water. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring to <b>a branch</b> within its first <b>year, which does not</b> yet <b>have knots.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But there is the place it was cut</b> from the tree, and water will come from there. The Gemara answers: <b>One leaves the place it was cut outside</b> of the animal rather than inserting that side of the branch into the animal.
The Gemara notes that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Just as</b> the part of <b>a spit of wood</b> that is inside the animal <b>is not burned,</b> although it is over the fire, <b>so</b> the part of <b>a spit of metal</b> that is inside the animal <b>does not become burning hot.</b> There is no concern that the meat will be roasted from the heat of the spit. The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> This is not the case. With regard to <b>this,</b> the metal, when <b>part of it is hot, it is all hot. And</b> with regard to <b>that,</b> the wood, when <b>part of it is hot, not all of it is hot,</b> and therefore the meat is cooked by the heat of the fire and not by the heat of the spit.
It was taught in the mishna that according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <b>one places the legs</b> and entrails inside the lamb’s body and roasts them together. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> would <b>call</b> the Paschal lamb: <b><i>Tokh</i>, <i>tokh</i>,</b> because when one roasts the legs and entrails inside the lamb they make that sound, like other things that are cooked. <b>Rabbi Tarfon</b> would <b>call it: Helmeted kid.</b> In his opinion, the entrails must be roasted when they are suspended from the spit above the head of the animal, somewhat resembling a helmet.
<b>The Sages taught: Which is the kid roasted whole that it is prohibited to eat on the nights of Passover in modern times,</b> so as not appear as though one sacrificed the Paschal lamb outside the Temple? It is <b>any</b> kid <b>that one roasted all at once</b> in the manner that the Paschal lamb was roasted. However, if <b>one of its limbs is severed</b> or <b>one of its limbs is boiled, it is no</b> longer considered <b>a kid roasted whole.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise at the formulation of this <i>baraita</i>. <b>Now, one can say</b> that if <b>one of its limbs is severed, although one roasts it together with</b> the rest of the animal, <b>you said</b> that it is <b>no</b> longer considered a kid roasted whole, and it is permitted in modern times. If one of its limbs <b>is</b> severed and <b>boiled,</b> which is not an approved method of preparation of the Paschal lamb, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that that it is not considered roasted whole? <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where one boiled</b> the limb <b>while it was attached</b> to the rest of the animal. The <i>halakha</i> teaches that even if the animal remains whole, if one of its limbs is cooked it is no longer considered a kid roasted whole.
The Gemara raises a general halakhic discussion related to the mishna. <b>Rabba said: This stuffing</b> of raw meat inside another animal that is being roasted <b>is permitted,</b> even if the meat that is stuffed inside has not been salted to remove the blood. <b>Abaye said to him: But</b> the meat of the animal being roasted <b>absorbs blood</b> from the stuffing. <b>He said to him: As it absorbs it, so it</b> then <b>emits it.</b> The heat of the fire causes blood to be released from the meat used as stuffing into the meat of the animal being stuffed, and the heat then draws the blood out of that meat as well.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that</b> this mishna <b>supports him: He places its legs and its entrails inside</b> the Paschal lamb and roasts them together. <b>What is the reason</b> that it is permitted to do this? Is it <b>not because we say: As it absorbs it, so it emits it?</b> Although Rabbi Akiva disputes this statement, his opinion is due to the unique <i>halakhot</i> of the Paschal lamb. It seems that everyone agrees that there is no concern about the prohibition against consuming blood. The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>Say it is different there,</b> in the case of the Paschal lamb. <b>Since there is the place of the slaughter, which is hollow</b> and open,

Daf 74b

the blood <b>flows</b> out. However, in the case of regular stuffing, which is closed on all sides, there is no way for the blood to drain.
The Gemara suggests further: <b>Let us say</b> that the following mishna <b>supports him:</b> With regard to <b>the heart</b> of an animal, one must <b>tear it and remove its blood</b> before one roasts or cooks it. And if <b>he did not tear it</b> beforehand, <b>he tears it after it is cooked,</b> i.e., roasted, <b>and it is permitted. What is the reason</b> the heart is permitted although there is presumably still blood inside? <b>Is it not because we say</b> that <b>as it absorbs it, so it emits it,</b> and therefore as the heart is roasted the blood is absorbed in the meat and then discharged, so that no blood is left in the meat, and whatever is still inside the hollow part of the heart can be removed when it is torn open? This would support the opinion of Rabba.
The Gemara refutes the proof: <b>A heart is different</b> because <b>it is smooth</b> and does not absorb much blood. However, generally one does not necessarily rely on the principle that as it absorbs it so it emits it.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Ravin the Elder wrap a particular young dove in dough for Rav</b> and roast it, <b>and</b> Rav <b>said to him: If its dough</b> tastes <b>good, give me</b> some <b>and I will eat?</b> Apparently, according to Rav, although the breading absorbed blood, it also certainly discharged it during the roasting. The Gemara refutes this point: <b>That</b> incident involved <b>fine flour [<i>semida</i>], which is crumbly</b> and allows the blood to flow through it.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rava happen</b> to come <b>to the house of the Exilarch, and they breaded a young goose for him,</b> and <b>he said: If I had not seen that</b> the breading <b>is</b> as <b>clear as a white,</b> i.e., new, <b>coin, I</b> would <b>not eat from it</b> out of concern that it absorbed some of the blood? <b>And if it should enter your mind</b> to accept the principle that <b>as it absorbs it so it emits it, why</b> note that he ate it <b>particularly because it was clear? Even if it was not clear,</b> it should <b>also</b> be permitted. The Gemara responds: <b>There,</b> it was talking about <b>white</b> flour, <b>which is firm</b> and does not allow the blood to pass through; Rava ate it only because its color indicated that no blood remained in the breading.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that if one makes the breading <b>of fine flour, whether it turned red</b> from blood <b>or did not turn red, it is permitted.</b> The following rule applies to breading <b>of white</b> flour: <b>If it is clear like a white coin, it is permitted; if not, it is prohibited.</b> With regard to breading <b>of other</b> types of <b>flour,</b> which are not especially firm or crumbly, if the breading <b>turned red, it is prohibited;</b> if <b>it did not turn red, it is permitted.</b>
With regard to <b>this</b> meat <b>stuffing</b> in an animal: <b>The one who prohibits</b> one to eat it, Abaye, does so <b>even</b> if <b>the opening</b> is facing <b>downward,</b> allowing the blood to escape more easily. <b>And the one who permits</b> one to eat it, Rabba, does so <b>even</b> if <b>the opening</b> is facing <b>upward.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is that stuffing is permitted even</b> if <b>the opening</b> is facing <b>upward,</b> in accordance with the lenient opinion.
The Gemara quotes a further discussion concerning the topic of blood absorbed in meat and the preparation of meat permitted for eating. The Gemara addresses three cases: <b>Raw meat [<i>umtza</i>]</b> that is eaten without being salted, <b>testicles</b> of an animal, <b>and</b> the large <b>veins</b> of the neck. <b>Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagreed about this.</b> The Gemara points out: <b>In all</b> their discussions about <b>the Torah,</b> whenever there is a dispute between them and there is no explanation as to which of them holds which opinion, the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa is stringent and</b> the opinion of <b>Ravina is lenient, and the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ravina to be lenient.</b> This applies to all their disputes <b>except for these three,</b> in which <b>Rav Aḥa is lenient and Ravina is stringent, and the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa to be lenient.</b>
The Gemara explains: With regard to <b>this</b> piece of <b>raw meat that became red</b> from the blood inside it, if <b>one cut it and salted it,</b> it is <b>permitted even to</b> cook them in <b>a pot</b> because it is clear that salt removes blood from meat. If one <b>put it on a spit</b> in order to roast it, <b>it is permitted</b> because the blood <b>flows</b> out. With regard to a case where one <b>placed it on coals, Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagreed about</b> the <i>halakha</i> in <b>this</b> case; <b>one prohibited</b> it <b>and one permitted</b> it. <b>The one who prohibited</b> it reasoned that the coals cause the meat <b>to shrivel</b> and harden, trapping the blood inside. <b>And the one who permitted</b> it reasoned that the heat of the coals <b>draws out</b> the blood, leaving only the meat. <b>And the halakha</b> is that the heat of the coals <b>draws out</b> the blood.
<b>And, so too,</b> with regard to <b>testicles:</b> If one <b>cut them and salted them, they are permitted even to</b> be cooked in <b>a pot.</b> If one <b>hung them on a spit</b> in order to roast them, <b>they are permitted</b> because the blood <b>flows</b> out. With regard to a case where one <b>placed them on coals, Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagreed about this; one prohibited</b> it <b>and one permitted</b> it. <b>The one who prohibited</b> it reasoned that <b>it shrivels, and the one who permitted</b> it reasoned that the heat <b>draws out</b> the blood.
<b>And, so too,</b> with regard to large <b>veins:</b> If one <b>cut them and salted them, it is permitted even to</b> cook them in <b>a pot.</b> If one <b>hung them on a spit</b> and <b>the place of the</b> incision of the <b>slaughter is</b> facing <b>downward, it is permitted</b> because the blood <b>flows</b> out. With regard to a case where one <b>placed it on coals, Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagreed about this</b> matter; <b>one prohibited</b> it <b>and one permitted</b> it. <b>The one who prohibited</b> it reasoned that <b>it shrivels, and the one who permitted</b> it reasoned that the heat <b>draws out</b> the blood. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that the heat of the coals <b>draws out</b> the blood, and it is permitted.
The Gemara raises another discussion with regard to blood absorbed in meat. People would soak raw meat (<i>Tosafot</i>) in vinegar in order to ensure that none of the blood would separate from its original place and prohibit the meat from being eaten, as it is permitted to eat blood that has not separated from its original place. <b>This</b> piece of <b>raw meat, whose vinegar became red</b> due to the blood absorbed in it, <b>is forbidden.</b> If <b>its vinegar did not become red, it is permitted. Ravina said: Even</b> if <b>its vinegar did not become red, it is forbidden; it is impossible that it does not have streaks of blood. Mar bar Ameimar said to Rav Ashi: Father,</b> i.e., Ameimar, <b>would swallow</b> the vinegar and was unconcerned that there may be blood in it. <b>Some say Rav Ashi himself would swallow it.</b>
<b>Mar bar Ameimar said to Rav Ashi:</b> The practice of my <b>father,</b> Ameimar, was that with regard to <b>vinegar in which he had soaked</b> meat <b>one time</b> to keep in its blood, <b>he would not soak</b> meat <b>in it again.</b> It could no longer keep the blood in the meat. The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way is vinegar that has been used once <b>different from weak vinegar, in which we soak</b> meat without concern that it will be unable to keep the blood in the meat? The Gemara explains: <b>There, the</b>

Daf 75a
