<b>sharpness of the fruit</b> remains present in the vinegar <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form, despite the fact that the vinegar itself is not sharp. <b>Here, the sharpness of the fruit does not</b> remain present in the vinegar <b>in its pure,</b> unadulterated form because it has already been used with the meat. Therefore, the vinegar is no longer potent enough to keep the blood in the meat.
It was taught in the mishna that <b>one</b> may <b>not roast the Paschal lamb</b> on a grill. Subsequently, the mishna quotes an incident in which Rabban Gamliel instructed his servant to roast the Paschal lamb for him on a grill. The Gemara expresses surprise: Was <b>an incident</b> cited <b>to contradict</b> what was previously stated? The Gemara responds: The mishna <b>is incomplete and is teaching the following: And if it is a perforated grill,</b> so that the fire reaches each part of the meat and the animal will not be roasted from the heat of the grill itself, <b>it is permitted. And</b> with regard to this <b>Rabbi Tzadok said</b> that <b>there was an incident with Rabban Gamliel, who said to his slave Tavi: Go and roast the Paschal lamb for us on the perforated grill.</b>
The Gemara cites a discussion related to the subject of roasting the Paschal lamb. <b>Rav Ḥinnana bar Idi raised a dilemma before Rav Adda bar Ahava:</b> In the case of <b>an oven that one fired with peels of</b> fruit that are <b><i>orla</i>,</b> i.e., fruit that grows on a tree the first three years after it was planted, from which one may not receive any benefit, if, after the oven became very hot, <b>he swept it</b> and removed the fuel and the ashes, <b>and he baked bread in it, according to the opinion that prohibits</b> bread baked directly with heat from <i>orla</i> fuel, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to this bread? It was baked with the heat trapped in the oven only after the fuel was removed. <b>He said to him: The bread is permitted.</b>
Rav Ḥinnana <b>said to him: But didn’t Rav Ḥinnana the Elder say</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If there is <b>an oven that one fired and swept</b> so that the heat remains but there is no longer any fire in the oven, <b>and</b> one then <b>roasted the Paschal lamb in it, this is not</b> a fulfillment of the Torah’s command that the Paschal lamb must be <b>roasted in fire, as it is stated</b> in the Torah: “And they shall eat the meat on that night, <b>roasted in fire,</b> and <i>matzot</i>; with bitter herbs they shall eat it. Do not eat of it raw, nor boiled in water, but <b>roasted in fire;</b> its head with its legs and with its inner parts” (Exodus 12:8–9), and since it says the phrase: Roasted in fire, <b>two times,</b> the verse emphasizes that the Paschal lamb must literally be roasted on the fire?
The following can now be inferred: <b>The reason</b> is specifically because <b>the Merciful One reveals</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Paschal lamb in the Torah by repeating: <b>Roasted in fire, roasted in fire, twice. But</b> if <b>the Merciful One had not revealed</b> this <i>halakha</i> by emphasizing the need to roast it directly on the fire, <b>I would have said</b> a Paschal lamb roasted in an oven that has already been swept <b>is</b> nonetheless considered <b>roasted in fire.</b> Therefore, in other situations in which something is roasted in an oven, even if it is not roasted directly from the heat of a fire, its status should be comparable to something that was roasted directly from the fuel. If the fuel is forbidden, the food should be forbidden.
Rav Adda bar Ahava <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥinnana bar Idi: <b>The Merciful One reveals it there,</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb, <b>and we learn from it</b> that even in other areas of <i>halakha</i>, only something that is roasted directly by a fire is considered roasted in fire.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> a different answer instead: <b>There,</b> in the case of the Paschal lamb, <b>the reason</b> one may not roast the lamb if one has already swept out the oven <b>is that the Merciful One writes “roasted in fire” twice. But</b> if <b>the Merciful One had not written “roasted in fire” twice, I would have said that the Merciful One is particular about fire,</b> meaning that the source of the heat in the oven should be fire, <b>and even if one swept it, it is</b> still considered <b>roasted in fire.</b> It was therefore necessary to repeat the phrase “roasted in fire.” <b>But here,</b> in the case of <i>orla</i>, <b>the Merciful One is particular about the prohibited fuel, and it is not here</b> in the oven. Therefore, there is no reason to prohibit the bread.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>one cuts</b> the Paschal lamb superficially in several places <b>and places it on coals, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I say that this is</b> considered <b>roasted in fire,</b> as coals have the status of real fire. <b>Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami raised a contradiction to Rav Ḥisda: Did Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi actually <b>say that coals are</b> considered like <b>fire?</b>
Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami <b>raised a contradiction</b> based on the Torah’s statement with regard to the laws of leprosy: “Or flesh that shall have on its skin <b>a burn from fire”</b> (Leviticus 13:24). From the fact that it says a burn from fire, I have derived <b>nothing other</b> than a case in which <b>it is burned by fire</b> itself; if it <b>is burned by a coal, by burning ash, by burning lime, by burning plaster [<i>gipsis</i>], or</b> by <b>anything</b> else that is burning <b>and</b> whose source of heat <b>comes from fire, to include</b> also <b>water heated by fire, from where</b> is it derived that these are also considered a burn from fire? <b>The verse states: A burn, a burn,</b> twice. By repeating the term, <b>it includes</b> all these types of burns.
The following can now be inferred: <b>The reason is that the Merciful One includes</b> these types of burns in the Torah through the words: <b>A burn, a burn. But</b> if <b>the Merciful One had not included</b> them through the repetitive expression <b>a burn, a burn,</b> one would have assumed that <b>coals are not</b> considered <b>fire,</b> which contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi that any usage of the term fire includes coals as well.
<b>He said to him:</b> With regard to a red-hot <b>wood coal,</b> it is <b>not necessary</b> for <b>the verse to include it.</b> As long as it is burning, it is certainly considered a fire. <b>Where a verse is necessary</b> is with regard <b>to</b> a red-hot <b>piece of metal</b> that was heated by a fire. Without the verse, it would have been possible to think a person burned by hot metal it is not considered burned by fire.
The Gemara expresses surprise at the previous answer: <b>And are</b> red-hot <b>pieces of metal not</b> considered <b>fire? But with regard to a daughter of a priest</b> who committed adultery after betrothal, <b>it is written:</b> “And the daughter of a priest, if she profanes herself through adultery, she profanes her father; <b>in fire she shall be burned”</b> (Leviticus 21:9), <b>and Rav Mattana said:</b> They would not literally burn her in fire; rather, <b>they would prepare for her</b> a molten <b>bar of lead.</b> They would execute her by pouring molten lead down her throat. This proves that burning metal is considered fire.
The Gemara responds: <b>It is different there, as the verse states</b> not simply fire, but <b>“in fire she shall be burned.”</b> The expression <b>“she shall be burned”</b> comes <b>to include all burnings that come from fire.</b>
The Gemara suggests: If so, <b>all the more so fire itself</b> fulfills the requirement of burning. <b>Let us surround her</b> with <b>bundles of branches and burn her</b> with them. The Gemara responds: <b>It comes</b> from a verbal analogy between the word <b>“burning”</b> stated here and the word <b>“burning”</b> stated and in the context of the death of <b>the sons of Aaron: Just as below,</b> with regard to the sons of Aaron, the verse states that they were burned with fire (see Leviticus 10:2), and it was <b>a burning of the soul and the body remained,</b> as even their clothes were not burned, <b>so too, here,</b> with regard to the daughter of a priest, it means the <b>burning of the soul and the body remains.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>Let us</b> execute <b>her with</b> boiling <b>water heated by fire.</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>due to</b> the statement of <b>Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>the verse states: “And you shall love your fellow as yourself”</b> (Leviticus 19:18). When executing someone, <b>select for him a kind death.</b> Even when someone must be executed, his dignity should be protected. He should be executed in the most comfortable way possible.
The Gemara asks: <b>Once there is</b> the reason of <b>Rav Naḥman, why do I</b> need <b>the verbal analogy</b> derived from the sons of Aaron? Even without it, Rav Naḥman’s ruling requires the court to carry out the execution with molten lead, which provides an easier death. <b>Say</b> in answer to this question: <b>If not</b> for the <b>verbal analogy, I would have said that burning the soul</b> while <b>the body remains is not</b> considered <b>burning. And if</b> it were only <b>due to</b> the statement of <b>Rav Naḥman</b> that one must select a kind death, <b>we should add many bundles of branches so that she would die quickly.</b> Therefore, the verbal analogy <b>teaches us</b> that executing with molten lead is considered burning.
<b>But</b> if it so that the verse says “she shall be burned” to include all methods of burning, <b>for what do I need</b> the expression <b>“in fire”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>To exclude lead from its source.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira:</b> Is it true that <b>anywhere that it is written: “In fire she shall be burned”</b> it comes <b>to include all</b> methods of <b>burning that come from fire? But</b> what of <b>bulls that are burned,</b> about <b>which it is written: “And he shall burn it on wood in fire,</b> where the ash is poured it shall be burned” (Leviticus 4:12), <b>and it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In fire, and not in burning lime and not in burning plaster?</b> Why aren’t all methods of burning permitted in this case as well?
<b>He said to him: How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the daughter of a priest, <b>it is written: “In fire,” and</b> the verse <b>subsequently</b> states that <b>she shall be burned,</b> which comes <b>to include all</b> methods of <b>burning that come from fire. Here,</b> in the case of a bull, <b>it is written: “And he shall burn it on wood in fire.” At the end</b> it says <b>fire, to say that</b> with regard to <b>fire, yes,</b> it may be used, but with regard to <b>something else, no,</b> it may not be used.
The Gemara objects: <b>There, too,</b> with regard to bulls that are burned, <b>burning is written at the end, as it is written</b> at the end of that verse:

Daf 75b

<b>“Where the ash is poured it shall be burned”</b> (Leviticus 4:12). The Gemara responds: <b>Say: That</b> usage of the expression <b>“it shall be burned” is needed for that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>It shall be burned even though there is no ash there,</b> as the presence of ash from the altar is not essential for burning the bulls. <b>“It shall be burned”</b> also teaches that <b>although the fire has consumed most of it,</b> that is not sufficient. One must take care to complete the burning process.
<b>Ravina said</b> that the contradiction cited earlier between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement, that roasting over coal is considered roasting over fire, and the <i>baraita</i>, which requires a derivation to indicate that coal is considered fire with regard to leprosy, can be answered by changing the text of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Combine and teach</b> the first two types of burns together. From the phrase <b>“a burn from fire,” I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than a case in <b>which one was burned by a fire or by a coal.</b> With regard to one who is <b>burned by hot ash, by burning lime, or by burning plaster, or by anything</b> else that is burning <b>and</b> whose source of heat <b>comes from fire, to include water heated by fire, from where</b> is it derived that these cases are also considered a burn from fire? <b>The verse states: A burn, a burn,</b> twice. By repeating the term, <b>it includes</b> all these types of burns.
<b>Rava raised a contradiction: Did Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi actually <b>say</b> that <b>coals are called fire? And we raise a contradiction</b> based on the verse: “And he shall take a pan full of burning coals from upon the altar before the Lord” (Leviticus 16:12). From the verse’s use of the word <b>coals,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that one may bring <b>smoldering</b> coals, meaning that the fire is almost extinguished and is not noticeable from the outside. <b>Therefore, the verse states: Fire. If</b> it had stated only <b>fire,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought it was referring to <b>a flame. Therefore, the verse states: Coals. How</b> are these two requirements reconciled? <b>One brings from the</b> coals that are <b>flickering,</b> meaning that the fire is visible. <b>Apparently,</b> plain <b>coals are not called fire.</b>
<b>Say</b> in answer to this question: <b>Isn’t this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself difficult? You said:</b> From the verse’s use of the word <b>coals,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought the verse is referring to coals that are <b>smoldering. Apparently,</b> it is clear that <b>flickering</b> coals <b>are</b> considered <b>fire. Say the latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i> as follows: <b>If</b> it had stated only <b>fire,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought it was referring to a flame. <b>Therefore, the verse states: Coals. Apparently, even flickering</b> coals <b>are not</b> considered <b>fire,</b> and there is an internal contradiction in the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>And Rav Sheshet said,</b> in order to resolve this contradiction: <b>This is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching:</b> From the verse’s use of the word <b>coals,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought he can take whatever he wants, <b>whether smoldering or flickering. Therefore, the Torah states: Fire. If</b> it had stated only <b>fire,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought it was referring to <b>a flame. Therefore, the verse states: Coals. How</b> is this to be understood? <b>He brings from the flickering</b> coals. <b>In any event,</b> it is derived from here that <b>coals,</b> even if they are flickering, <b>are not called fire.</b> This poses <b>a difficulty</b> to the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, according to which coals are considered fire.
<b>Abaye said</b> that the <b>answer</b> is <b>as follows:</b> Based on the word <b>coals,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought they must be <b>smoldering and not flickering. Therefore, the verse states: Fire. If</b> it had stated only <b>fire,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that if <b>one wanted a flame he</b> may <b>bring</b> it, and if <b>he wanted a coal he</b> may <b>bring</b> it. <b>Therefore, the Torah states: Coals. How</b> is this to be understood? <b>He brings from the flickering</b> coals. According to this, it is clear that coals are considered fire, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Rabba said:</b> In this last explanation, it was stated that one might have thought that if <b>he wanted a coal he</b> may <b>bring</b> it, and <b>if he wanted a flame he</b> may <b>bring</b> it. Under <b>what circumstances</b> can <b>a flame without a coal be found?</b> The Gemara answers: In a case <b>where one smears a utensil with oil and lights it on fire.</b> However, for a case like <b>this, why do I</b> need <b>a verse to exclude it</b> and indicate that one may not bring such a flame? <b>Now, in front of a king of flesh and blood one does not do this,</b> as it is considered disgraceful to bring such a flame before a king; <b>in front of the King of kings, the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> a disgrace? Therefore, the verse would not need to exclude this type of flame.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that one should <b>answer as follows:</b> Based on the word <b>coals,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought they must be <b>smoldering and not flickering; therefore, the verse states: Fire. If</b> it had said only <b>fire,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought <b>one should bring half coal and half fire,</b> meaning that when one takes the coals from the altar they should be burning strongly and their flame should be visible, and <b>by</b> the time <b>he enters</b> the <b>inside</b> of the Holy of Holies the fire will die down <b>and it will be all coal. Therefore, the verse states: “And he shall take a coal-pan full of burning coals from upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 16:12), which indicates that <b>from the time of</b> their <b>taking they should be coals</b> and not flames.
Since the discussion until now has focused on smoldering coals, the Gemara mentions that <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages in the study hall about whether the word smoldering should be rendered <b><i>omemot</i></b> with an <i>alef</i> <b>or <i>omemot</i></b> with an <i>ayin</i>. <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said:</b> It should be rendered with an <i>ayin</i>, as it is stated: <b>“The cedars in the garden of God could not hide it [<i>amamuhu</i>]”</b> (Ezekiel 31:8), as the word <i>amamuhu</i> in the verse is spelled with an <i>ayin</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the Paschal lamb <b>touched</b> the <b>earthenware</b> surface <b>of an oven, one</b> must <b>peel</b> off <b>its place</b> on the Paschal lamb, as it was roasted by the heat of the oven and not by the fire itself. If some <b>of</b> the <b>gravy</b> of the Paschal lamb <b>dripped on the earthenware and</b> then <b>returned to it,</b> i.e., the gravy splattered back onto the meat, <b>one</b> must <b>remove its place.</b> Peeling off the outer layer is not enough, and one must remove some of the meat underneath the outer layer, because it is considered to have been cooked by the liquid rather than roasted by the fire. If some <b>of</b> the Paschal lamb’s <b>gravy dripped onto</b> hot <b>flour, one</b> must <b>remove a handful of</b> flour from <b>its place,</b> i.e., the place where the gravy landed in the flour, and destroy it.
In a case where one <b>smears</b> the Paschal lamb <b>with <i>teruma</i> oil, if</b> the Paschal lamb belongs to <b>a group of priests they may eat it,</b> as they are permitted to eat <i>teruma</i>. <b>If</b> the Paschal lamb belongs to a group <b>of Israelites,</b> then <b>if</b> it is still <b>raw, one</b> must <b>rinse it</b> in order to remove the <i>teruma</i> oil; <b>and if it is roasted, one</b> must <b>peel off the outer</b> layer that has absorbed the oil, so that the Israelites do not eat the <i>teruma</i>, which is prohibited to them. If <b>one smears</b> the Paschal lamb <b>with oil of</b> the <b>second tithe, he may not demand money for it from the members of the group, as one</b> may <b>not redeem second tithe in Jerusalem.</b> Second-tithe produce that is in Jerusalem is meant to be eaten; it may be given as a gift to others, but may not be redeemed or sold.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Based on the mishna, the Gemara introduces a general discussion concerning the <i>halakhot</i> of forbidden foods that come into contact with other foods. <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to these matters, but first the Gemara mentions the cases that are clear: If <b>a hot</b> food item falls <b>into</b> another <b>hot</b> item, e.g., hot meat falls into boiling milk or hot permitted meat falls into hot prohibited soup, <b>all agree</b>

Daf 76a

that the permitted foods become <b>forbidden,</b> because they absorb some of the forbidden food. If a <b>cold</b> food item falls <b>into</b> another <b>cold</b> item, <b>all agree it is permitted;</b> the food needs only to be rinsed off. The dispute pertains to a <b>hot</b> food item that falls <b>into a cold</b> one or <b>a cold</b> food item that falls <b>into a hot</b> one. <b>Rav said: The upper one prevails.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is determined based upon the state of the upper substance. If the upper food is hot, the case is judged as though a hot food fell into another hot food because the upper food heats the lower food. If the upper food is cold, the case is similar to a situation where a cold food falls into another cold food because the upper food cools down the lower one and prevents absorption. <b>And Shmuel said: The lower one prevails.</b> In his opinion, if the upper substance is hot and the lower one is cold, the permitted food remains permitted; if the lower one is hot and upper one is cold, they are forbidden.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If some <b>of the gravy of</b> the Paschal lamb <b>dripped onto the earthenware and returned to it, one</b> must <b>remove its place. It</b> might <b>enter your mind</b> to say that this is referring to <b>cold earthenware. Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, who said the upper one prevails,</b> it is <b>due to this</b> reason that <b>one</b> must <b>remove its place.</b> According to Rav’s view, <b>the gravy goes and heats the earthenware, and then the earthenware heats the gravy, and when the gravy returns to the Paschal lamb, the Paschal lamb becomes roasted from the heat of the earthenware, and the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“Roasted in fire”</b> (Exodus 12:8), <b>and not roasted due to something else.</b>
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, who said the lower one prevails, since the earthenware is cold, it cools down the gravy.</b> In that case, <b>why must he remove its place?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Shmuel said</b> in explanation of the mishna’s next ruling in the case of gravy that dripped onto flour: The mishna is referring to <b>hot flour. Here, too,</b> it is referring to <b>hot earthenware.</b> Since the earthenware is already hot, it is a case of something hot that fell onto something hot, even according to Shmuel.
<b>We</b> also <b>learned</b> in the mishna that if some <b>of</b> the Paschal lamb’s <b>gravy dripped onto flour, one</b> must <b>remove a handful of</b> flour from <b>its place. It</b> could <b>enter your mind</b> to say that this is talking about <b>cold flour. Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, who said the upper one prevails,</b> it is <b>due to this</b> reason that <b>one</b> must <b>remove a handful</b> of flour from <b>its place, as</b> the gravy <b>heats the flour around it, and the flour then heats</b> the gravy, <b>and the gravy is roasted from the heat of the flour, and the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“Roasted in fire,” and not roasted due to something else.</b>
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, who said the lower one prevails, since the flour is cold it cools down</b> the gravy. In that case, <b>why do I</b> need to say: <b>One</b> must <b>remove a handful</b> of flour from <b>its place? It should be enough for one to remove</b> a small amount from <b>its place,</b> and it should not be necessary to take anything more. With regard to this <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The mishna is referring to <b>hot flour.</b> The gravy is therefore roasted from the heat of the flour, and an entire handful of flour must be removed.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: In a case where <b>one smears</b> the Paschal lamb <b>with <i>teruma</i> oil, if</b> the Paschal lamb belongs to <b>a group of priests they may eat it,</b> as they are permitted to eat <i>teruma</i>. <b>If</b> it belongs to a group <b>of Israelites,</b> then <b>if</b> the Paschal lamb is still <b>raw, one</b> must <b>rinse it</b> in order to remove the <i>teruma</i> oil; <b>and if it is roasted, one</b> must <b>peel off the outer</b> layer. <b>Granted, according to Rav, who said the upper one prevails, for this</b> reason <b>it is sufficient</b> to remove only the outer <b>peel, because the upper one is cold</b> and therefore the oil is not absorbed deeply into the meat.
<b>But</b> according <b>to Shmuel, who said: The lower one prevails, since</b> the meat, which is on the bottom, <b>is hot, it absorbs</b> the oil. In that case, <b>why is it enough for it</b> to be permitted when only the outer <b>peel</b> is removed? <b>It should be entirely forbidden.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Smearing is different because it is done with only a minute amount.</b> Since one smears only a little bit of oil, there is not enough oil to render the entire offering forbidden.
It <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel:</b> If <b>hot</b> permitted food falls <b>into hot</b> forbidden food, <b>it is forbidden. And, so too, cold</b> permitted food <b>that one put into hot</b> forbidden food <b>is forbidden.</b> If <b>hot</b> food falls <b>into cold</b> food, <b>and</b> similarly, if <b>cold</b> food falls <b>into cold</b> food, <b>one</b> must <b>rinse</b> the permitted food, and it remains permitted.
The Gemara asks: Is it true that if <b>hot</b> permitted food falls <b>into cold</b> forbidden food, <b>one</b> must <b>rinse</b> the permitted food and it remains permitted? <b>Since it is hot, until</b> the bottom food <b>cools it, it is impossible that it will not absorb a little</b> of the forbidden food. Therefore, <b>it should at least require</b> the removal of the outer <b>peel;</b> rinsing it should not be sufficient. <b>Rather, say</b> the following corrected version: If <b>hot</b> food falls <b>into cold</b> food, <b>one</b> must <b>peel</b> off the outer layer; if <b>cold</b> food falls <b>into cold</b> food, <b>one</b> must <b>rinse</b> it off and that is sufficient.
<b>It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Hot meat that fell into hot milk, and so too, cold</b> meat <b>that fell into hot</b> milk, <b>is prohibited.</b> If <b>hot</b> meat falls <b>into cold</b> milk <b>and</b> similarly, if <b>cold</b> meat falls <b>into cold</b> milk, <b>one</b> must <b>rinse</b> it off and that is sufficient. The Gemara asks: Is it true that if <b>hot</b> meat falls <b>into cold</b> milk, <b>one</b> must <b>rinse</b> it off and that is sufficient? <b>Since it is hot, until</b> the bottom food <b>cools it, it is impossible that it will not absorb a little</b> of the milk. Therefore, <b>it should at least require</b> the removal of the outer <b>peel. Rather, say</b> the following corrected version: If <b>hot</b> meat falls <b>into cold</b> milk, <b>one</b> must <b>peel</b> off the outer layer; if <b>cold</b> meat falls <b>into cold</b> milk, <b>one</b> must <b>rinse</b> it off and that is sufficient.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> quoted above: If <b>cold</b> meat falls <b>into cold</b> milk or into a prohibited food, <b>one</b> must <b>rinse</b> it off and that is sufficient. <b>Rav Huna said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case where <b>he did not salt</b> either of the food items. <b>However, if he salted</b> one of them <b>it is forbidden, as Shmuel said: A salted</b> food item <b>is</b> considered <b>like a boiling</b> food item with regard to its ability to transmit flavor. Additionally, a food item <b>marinated</b> in vinegar, brine, or the like <b>is</b> considered <b>like a cooked</b> food item, as it absorbs flavor from the liquid in which it is marinated or from other foods with which it is marinated.
<b>Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>that which Shmuel said,</b> that <b>a salted</b> food <b>is like a boiling</b> food, <b>we said</b> it <b>only</b> with regard to something salted to the point that <b>it is not</b> typically <b>eaten due to its salt. But</b> if the food is still <b>eaten due to its salt,</b> i.e., despite its having been salted, then it is <b>not</b> considered like something that is boiling, and it does not transmit flavor.
There was <b>a particular young bird that fell into a jug of <i>kamka</i>,</b> also known as <i>kutaḥ</i>, a food item that contains milk. There was a question whether the food is considered a forbidden mixture of meat and milk. <b>Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rava of</b> the city of <b>Pashronya, permitted</b> it.
<b>Rava said</b> about this: <b>Who is wise</b> enough <b>to permit something</b> as complicated <b>as this, if not Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rava of Pashronya, as he is a great man</b> and can recognize the reason for leniency even in a case that appears to be prohibited? <b>He</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in explanation of his lenient ruling: <b>When Shmuel said</b> that <b>a salted</b> food item <b>is like a boiling</b> food item, that <i>halakha</i> concerned a food that was salted to the point that <b>it is not eaten due to its salt,</b> but <b>this</b> <i>kutaḥ</i> <b>is</b> still <b>eaten due to,</b> i.e., despite, <b>its salt.</b> Therefore, the case is comparable to a cold food that falls into another cold food, which is permitted after it is rinsed.
The Gemara points out that <b>this applies</b> only if the bird is <b>raw; but</b> if it is <b>roasted, it requires</b> the removal of the outer <b>peel.</b> The roasting softens the meat, enabling it to absorb flavor more easily. <b>And we said</b> that the bird is permitted <b>only when it does not have cracks; but</b> if <b>it has cracks, it is forbidden</b> because the milk is absorbed into the cracks. <b>And if it has been flavored with spices it is forbidden</b> because the spices soften the meat, causing it to be absorbent.
<b>Rav said:</b>

Daf 76b

<b>Fatty kosher meat that one roasted</b> in an oven together <b>with lean non-kosher meat is forbidden,</b> even if the two meats never came into contact with one another. <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? It is that <b>they are flavored from one another.</b> The fatty meat emits an aroma that is absorbed in the non-kosher meat. The aroma is then transferred back to the kosher meat, causing the kosher meat to absorb some aroma from the non-kosher meat.
<b>And Levi said:</b> That aroma does not cause meat to be forbidden. <b>Even lean kosher meat that one roasted with fatty non-kosher meat is permitted. What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? Although the non-kosher meat emits an aroma that is absorbed into the kosher meat, <b>it is merely an aroma, and an aroma is nothing</b> significant. The Gemara relates that <b>Levi took action,</b> meaning that he put his opinion into practice, <b>in the house of the Exilarch with a kid and something else,</b> i.e., a pig, that had been roasted together. Levi did not prohibit the meat of the kid due to the aroma of the pig.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection: One</b> may <b>not roast two Paschal lambs together due to the mixing. What, is it not</b> prohibited due to <b>the mixing of flavors,</b> i.e., due to the aromas that waft from one to the other, <b>and it</b> poses <b>a difficulty to</b> the opinion of <b>Levi?</b> The Gemara rejects this challenge: <b>No,</b> it is prohibited <b>due to the mixing of carcasses.</b> The groups who are roasting their Paschal offerings might accidentally switch offerings, in which case the offerings will be eaten by people who did not register for them.
The Gemara adds: <b>So too,</b> one can conclude that <b>this</b> explanation <b>is reasonable from</b> the fact <b>that it is taught in the latter clause</b> that the ruling applies <b>even</b> if the two offerings are <b>a kid and a lamb. Granted, if you say</b> that the reason is <b>due to</b> the mixing of <b>carcasses, this is</b> why it <b>was taught</b> that the <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>even a kid and a lamb.</b> The <i>baraita</i> needed to teach that although they do not look alike, there is still a concern that after they have been skinned they will be mixed up. <b>But if you say</b> that the reason is <b>due to the mixing of flavors, what is</b> the difference between a case in which the two offerings are <b>a kid and a lamb and</b> one in which they are <b>a kid and</b> another <b>kid?</b> The case of the kid and the lamb mentioned at the end of the <i>baraita</i> would not teach anything new.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what</b> do you say? <b>Perforce,</b> it is <b>due to the mixing of carcasses that it is prohibited, but a mixing of flavors is permitted. Let us say that this will be a refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> who prohibited the mixing of flavors by means of an aroma. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where one roasted</b> the offerings <b>in two pots.</b> Consequently, they do not absorb flavor from one another.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>Could it enter your mind</b> to say that they roasted the Paschal offerings <b>in two pots?</b> It is prohibited to the roast the Paschal offering in a pot. <b>Rather, say</b> that they were roasted in a manner <b>similar to two pots,</b> meaning that they were distanced from each other and separated by a partition. <b>And this is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> is <b>saying: One</b> may <b>not roast two Paschal offerings together due to mixing. What</b> is this <b>mixing?</b> It is <b>the mixing of flavors. And even</b> roasting them in a manner <b>similar to two pots, where there is no mixing of flavors, is</b> also <b>prohibited, due to</b> the concern with regard to the <b>mixing of carcasses. And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if the animals are <b>a kid and a lamb.</b>
<b>Rav Mari said:</b> This is <b>like</b> the following dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>:</b> In the case of <b>one who removes hot bread</b> from an oven <b>and places it on top of a barrel of wine</b> that is <b><i>teruma</i>, Rabbi Meir prohibits</b> a non-priest from eating the bread. In his opinion, the bread absorbs the aroma of the <i>teruma</i> wine and therefore attains the status of <i>teruma</i>. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> it. <b>And Rabbi Yosei permits</b> bread made <b>of wheat,</b> which is not very absorbent, <b>but prohibits</b> bread made <b>of barley, because barley draws out</b> and absorbs the aroma. <b>What, is it not</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>? One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds that an aroma is nothing</b> significant, <b>and one Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds that an aroma is something</b> significant.
The Gemara says: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Levi,</b> i.e., that aroma is insignificant, <b>it certainly is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei hold that it is significant, and Levi accepts the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda that aroma is insignificant. However, according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, shall we say it is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>?</b>
<b>Rav</b> could have <b>said to you: Everyone agrees that aroma is something</b> significant. The dispute is about whether bread absorbs aroma in the circumstance under discussion. <b>Was it not stated with regard to that</b> mishna that <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said that Reish Lakish said: With regard to hot bread and an open barrel, everyone agrees that it is prohibited</b> because it certainly draws out the aroma; and <b>with regard to cold bread and a closed barrel, everyone agrees it is permitted? They disagreed only with regard to hot bread and a sealed barrel</b> because perhaps the bread nonetheless draws out aroma through the cracks. Similarly, they disputed the case of <b>cold bread and an open barrel. And this</b> case of two Paschal offerings roasted in the same oven <b>is also</b> considered <b>like</b> the case of <b>hot bread and an open barrel.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana, son of Rav Ḥinnana the Elder, teaches:</b> In the case of <b>bread that one baked</b> together <b>with roasting</b> meat <b>in the oven, it is prohibited to eat</b> the bread <b>with <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> which contains milk, because the bread absorbs some of the meat’s aroma. The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain fish that was roasted</b> together <b>with meat, Rava of Parzikiyya prohibited it from being eaten with <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> due to the meat flavor absorbed in the fish. <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said: Even</b> to merely eat it <b>with salt is also prohibited because</b> meat that is roasted or cooked with fish is <b>bad for odor,</b> meaning it causes bad breath, <b>and for something else,</b> i.e., leprosy. Therefore, one should avoid eating it due to the danger involved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Five items,</b> i.e., offerings, may <b>be brought in</b> a state of ritual <b>impurity,</b> but <b>they</b> may <b>not be eaten in</b> a state of ritual <b>impurity.</b> They are all communal offerings: <b>The <i>omer</i>,</b> which is brought in Nisan; <b>the two loaves</b> brought on <i>Shavuot</i>; <b>the shewbread,</b> which were arranged each week; <b>the communal peace-offerings,</b> which were brought on <i>Shavuot</i>; <b>and the goats</b> sacrificed on <b>the New Moons,</b> which were sin-offerings eaten by the priests. However, <b>the Paschal lamb that is sacrificed in impurity is eaten</b> even <b>in impurity, as it is brought to begin with only for eating,</b> which is the essence of the mitzva. With regard to other offerings, the essence of their mitzva is fulfilled when they are sacrificed on the altar, and the eating is non-essential.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna mentions the number <b>five.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>To exclude what</b> does the mishna emphasize this number? The Gemara answers: It is <b>to exclude the Festival peace-offering of the fifteenth</b> of Nisan, which is a Festival peace-offering brought on the Festival itself and which may not be sacrificed in a state of ritual impurity.
<b>It could enter your mind to say: Since it is a communal offering,</b> as each individual sacrifices it on the Festival in a public setting, <b>and its time is set,</b> as it cannot be brought every day, <b>it should override ritual impurity</b> like the other communal offerings that have a set time. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us: Since there is redress all seven</b> days of the Festival if the offering was not brought on the fifteenth, <b>it does not override Shabbat. And</b> since <b>it does not override Shabbat, it does not override ritual impurity.</b> Therefore, this offering may not be brought in a state of ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let it also teach</b> that <b>the goats</b> brought as sin-offerings on <b>the Festivals</b> override ritual impurity. The Gemara answers: <b>It did teach</b> that, as the goats are included in the category of <b>communal peace-offerings.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so, it should also not</b> be necessary to <b>teach</b> separately that <b>the goats</b> sacrificed on <b>the New Moons</b> are brought in a state of ritual impurity, <b>as it</b> already <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the communal peace-offerings. Say</b> in answer to this question:

Daf 77a

It was <b>necessary for</b> the mishna to mention <b>the goats</b> sacrificed on <b>the New Moons. It could enter your mind to say that</b> since the term <b>appointed time is not written with regard to them,</b> these offerings do not override Shabbat or ritual impurity as do other communal offerings during their appointed times. Therefore, <b>it teaches us that</b> even <b>the New Moon is called an appointed time.</b>
This is <b>in accordance with what Abaye</b> said in order to defend the tradition that the spies returned from Eretz Yisrael and the entire Jewish people cried unnecessarily on the Ninth of Av, which resulted in the Ninth of Av becoming a day of crying for future generations. The calculation of the days does not work out precisely, and therefore <b>Abaye said: They filled out Tammuz of that year,</b> meaning that it was a thirty-day month, rather than a twenty-nine-day month as it is nowadays. There is an allusion to this in a verse, <b>as it is written: “He proclaimed an appointed time against me to crush my young men”</b> (Lamentations 1:15), meaning that the New Moon was proclaimed in order to harm the Jewish people in the future. This proves that even the New Moon is called an appointed time.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that all of them come from,</b> i.e., are derived from, the term <b>appointed time? From where are these matters</b> derived? The Gemara answers: It is <b>as the Sages taught</b> based upon the verse: <b>“And Moses declared the appointed times of the Lord</b> to the children of Israel” (Leviticus 23:44). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> this phrase? This phrase is necessary <b>because we</b> had <b>learned only that the daily offering and the Paschal lamb</b> override Shabbat and ritual impurity, <b>as it is stated with regard to them: In its appointed time,</b> from which it is derived that each of them must be sacrificed <b>in its appointed time and even on Shabbat, in its appointed time and even in ritual impurity.</b>
With regard to <b>the rest of the communal offerings, from where</b> is it derived that they also override Shabbat and ritual impurity? <b>As it is stated</b> with regard to additional offerings that are brought on the Festivals: <b>“These you shall sacrifice to the Lord in your appointed times”</b> (Numbers 29:39).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include the <i>omer</i> and</b> the lambs that are <b>sacrificed with it, the two loaves</b> sacrificed on <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>and</b> the communal peace-offerings that are <b>sacrificed with them? The verse states: “And Moses declared the appointed times of the Lord to the children of Israel”</b> after it lists Shabbat and the Festivals. This indicates that <b>the verse established one time for all of them.</b> All of these days are considered appointed times, and their offerings are not deferred.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>all these</b> derivations? It should have been sufficient to provide one derivation and use that as a model for all communal offerings. The Gemara answers: <b>They are</b> all <b>necessary. As, if the Merciful One had written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>the daily offering</b> in the Torah, <b>I would have said: The daily offering</b> is unique in that it <b>is frequent and it is consumed,</b> as it is entirely consumed as a burnt-offering, and that is why it overrides Shabbat and ritual impurity; <b>but the Paschal lamb,</b> which does not have either of these characteristics, does <b>not</b> override Shabbat and ritual impurity. Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that the Paschal lamb also overrides Shabbat and ritual impurity.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to the <b>Paschal lamb,</b> I would have said that the <b>Paschal lamb, for which one is punished with <i>karet</i></b> if one neglects to sacrifice it, overrides Shabbat and ritual impurity; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>the daily offering, for which one is not punished with <i>karet</i></b> for neglecting to sacrifice it, <b>say that it does not</b> override Shabbat and ritual impurity. Therefore, <b>it comes to teach us</b> that the daily offering also overrides Shabbat and ritual impurity.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>these two</b> offerings, <b>I would have said</b> that <b>it is</b> only with regard to <b>these</b> offerings that the <i>halakha</i> applies, because <b>they have a stringent aspect. The daily offering is frequent and</b> entirely <b>consumed</b> on the altar, and one who neglects to bring <b>the Paschal lamb is punished with <i>karet</i>. But</b> with regard to <b>the rest of the communal offerings,</b> which do not have these stringencies, <b>say</b> that they do <b>not</b> override Shabbat and ritual impurity. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “These you shall sacrifice to the Lord in your appointed times,”</b> to teach that even these override Shabbat and ritual impurity.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written “These you shall sacrifice to the Lord in your appointed times”</b> and nothing else, <b>I would have said that</b> only the <b>other communal offerings that come to atone</b> for sins are included, such as sin-offerings and burnt-offerings. Burnt-offerings atone for the neglect of positive commandments and for the violation of negative commandments that can be rectified through positive commandments. <b>But the <i>omer</i> and the two loaves, which do not come to atone</b> for sin <b>but merely come to permit,</b> as the <i>omer</i> permits the consumption of the new crop of grain and the two loaves permit using the new crop of grain as offerings in the Temple, do <b>not</b> override Shabbat and ritual impurity. Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that even these override Shabbat and ritual impurity.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written: The <i>omer</i> and the two loaves, by themselves, I would have said: On the contrary, the <i>omer</i> and the two loaves, which are important</b> because <b>they come to permit,</b> override Shabbat and ritual impurity, <b>but these</b> other communal offerings do <b>not.</b> Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> each of the derivations separately.
Since the Gemara has discussed communal offerings that are brought even in a state of ritual impurity, it addresses the basic <i>halakhot</i> relating to this area. The Gemara posits two assumptions and then compares the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua to the mishna. It states as a preface that the Sages originally <b>assumed that everyone agrees that ritual impurity is overridden in</b> cases involving <b>the public.</b> In other words, the prohibition against sacrificing offerings in a state of ritual impurity applies to communal offerings, but it is superseded by the obligation to sacrifice the offering. Therefore, <b>the frontplate</b> of the High Priest <b>is required to appease</b> God for the sacrifice of the offering in a state of ritual impurity.
<b>There is no <i>tanna</i> that you have heard</b> of <b>who said</b> that <b>ritual impurity</b> is entirely <b>permitted in</b> cases involving <b>the public,</b> i.e., that with regard to the public there is no significance to ritual impurity in the Temple, <b>except for Rabbi Yehuda. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The frontplate</b> of the High Priest, <b>whether it is on his forehead or whether it is not on his forehead, appeases</b> God and thereby facilitates the acceptance of offerings sacrificed in a state of impurity; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> When <b>it is still on his forehead it appeases</b> God, but when <b>it is no longer on his forehead it does not appease</b> Him, as indicated in the verse: “And it shall be on Aaron’s forehead, that Aaron may bear the iniquity of the sacred things which the children of Israel shall hallow” (Exodus 28:38).
<b>Rabbi Shimon said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: <b>The</b> <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>High Priest on Yom Kippur shall prove</b> it, <b>as</b> the frontplate <b>is not on his forehead, and it</b> nonetheless <b>appeases</b> God if communal offerings are brought in a state of ritual impurity. The High Priest spends part of Yom Kippur wearing only the four white garments instead of his usual golden vestments, which include the frontplate.
Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to him: Set aside Yom Kippur, as ritual impurity</b> is wholly <b>permitted in</b> cases involving <b>the public.</b> The frontplate is needed only to atone for individual offerings that are brought in a state of ritual impurity. This proves <b>by inference that Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that <b>ritual impurity is overridden in</b> cases involving <b>the public,</b> but it is not wholly permitted. Therefore, the frontplate is needed to appease God for the sacrifice of the offering in a state of ritual impurity.
The Sages also presumed that <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>the frontplate</b> appeases God only for the sacrifice of the offering and the burning of the requisite parts on the altar in a state of ritual impurity, but it <b>does not appease</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten.</b> Therefore, although the offering is valid, it may not be eaten. <b>As, the only <i>tanna</i> you have heard say the frontplate appeases</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten is Rabbi Eliezer, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The frontplate appeases</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that supposed to be <b>eaten.</b> And <b>Rabbi Yosei says: The frontplate does not appease</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten.</b>
On the basis of these two assumptions, <b>let us say</b> that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And you shall sacrifice your burnt-offerings, the flesh and the blood,</b> upon the altar of the Lord your God, and the blood of your offerings shall be poured out against the altar of the Lord your God, and you shall eat the flesh” (Deuteronomy 12:27), that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: If there is no blood</b> that is fit to be sprinkled on the altar, due to the fact that it became ritually impure or was lost, <b>there is no meat,</b> as the meat is also disqualified. Similarly, <b>if there is no meat</b> that is fit for use, due to the fact that it became ritually impure or was lost, <b>there is no blood</b> sprinkled on the altar, and the offering does not bring atonement.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Blood</b> brings atonement <b>although there is no</b> suitable <b>meat, as it is stated: “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured out.”</b> Blood is the aspect of the offering most essential for atonement. <b>And how do I uphold</b> the significance of the juxtaposition of flesh and blood in the verse: <b>“And you shall sacrifice your burnt-offerings, the flesh and the blood”?</b> I hold that it is there <b>to tell you</b> that <b>just as the blood</b> is presented upon the altar <b>via sprinkling, so too, the meat</b> is presented <b>via throwing.</b>
<b>You must say,</b> based upon this, that <b>there is a small gap between the ramp and the altar.</b> In order to fulfill the requirement to throw, the priest would proceed as follows: Rather than walking to the arrangement of wood and putting down the meat, he would stand on the ramp and throw the meat of the offering over the gap between the ramp and the altar, onto the arrangement of wood on the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua as well, isn’t it written: “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured out,”</b> which indicates that the blood is the essential part of the offering? <b>He</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that <b>it is written</b> right next to <b>it: “And you shall eat the flesh,”</b> which indicates that the meat is also essential and must still be suitable for eating.

Daf 77b

The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>these two</b> parts of the <b>verse?</b> According to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, the <i>halakha</i> that both the blood and meat are essential is derived twice from the verse. The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> part of the verse is referring <b>to a burnt-offering and one</b> part is referring <b>to a peace-offering.</b> The Gemara notes that both derivations are <b>necessary, as if the Merciful One had written</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the meat must be suitable for eating only <b>with regard to a burnt-offering, I would have said</b> that it applies only to <b>a burnt-offering, which is stringent, as it is</b> totally <b>consumed</b> on the altar. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a peace-offering, which is not stringent,</b> as most of its meat is eaten by the priests and by the one who brought the offering, <b>say</b> that its meat is <b>not</b> essential.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a peace-offering, I would have said: On the contrary,</b> the meat of a peace-offering is more important <b>because it has two</b> forms of <b>consumption.</b> The sacrificial parts are burned on the altar, and the owners and priests eat the rest of the meat. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a burnt-offering, which</b> is completely burned on the altar and therefore <b>does not have two</b> forms of <b>consumption, say</b> that its meat is <b>not</b> essential. For this reason, <b>it teaches us</b> the <i>halakha</i> in both cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer as well, isn’t it written: “And you shall eat the flesh”?</b> The Gemara answers that Rabbi Eliezer could have <b>said to you: That</b> part of the verse <b>is necessary</b> to teach <b>that the meat</b> of an offering <b>is not permitted to be eaten until the blood is sprinkled.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, say</b> that <b>the entire</b> verse <b>comes for this</b> purpose, and in that case, <b>from where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that one sprinkles the <b>blood even though there is no</b> suitable <b>meat</b> because it became ritually impure or was lost?
The Gemara answers that Rabbi Eliezer could have <b>said to you: If so, the Merciful One should have written “and you shall eat the flesh” and then “and the blood of your offerings shall be poured out,” as it is written in the first clause</b> of that verse: <b>“And you shall sacrifice your burnt-offerings, the flesh, and the blood,”</b> listing the meat before the blood. <b>What is different that</b> caused the verse <b>to precede</b> “and you shall eat the flesh” with the phrase <b>“the blood of your offerings”? Learn from it</b> that <b>blood</b> brings atonement <b>although there is no meat, and learn from it</b> also <b>that the meat is not permitted to be eaten until the blood is sprinkled.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi Yehoshua</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that <b>the meat is not permitted to be eaten until the blood is sprinkled?</b> The Gemara answers that according to his opinion, <b>it is an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>sacrificial portions</b> brought on the altar, <b>which do not preclude</b> acceptance of the offering <b>when they are not present, when they are present they do preclude</b> the eating of the meat; with regard to <b>blood, which precludes</b> acceptance of the offering <b>when it is not present,</b> e.g., when it became ritually impure or lost, then <b>when it is present, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear <b>that it precludes</b> the continuation of the service and the eating the meat until it is sprinkled?
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> if there is an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, why did the Torah have to write this <i>halakha</i> explicitly in a verse? The Gemara answers: <b>A matter that</b> could be <b>derived by</b> means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, the verse</b> nonetheless <b>exerted</b> itself and <b>wrote it</b> explicitly. Even when a <i>halakha</i> can be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, the Torah sometimes writes it explicitly in order to emphasize the <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara asks: How does <b>Rabbi Yehoshua</b> respond to this claim? The Gemara answers: <b>Anywhere that there is</b> a possibility <b>to expound</b> the verse and thereby derive a new <i>halakha</i>, <b>we expound</b> it rather than explain that the verse taught only a <i>halakha</i> that could also have been derived in a different manner.
<b>Now,</b> after these introductions, <b>let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua: Since he said</b> that <b>we require</b> the <b>two</b> parts of the offering to be valid, i.e., the meat and the blood, and since he presumably holds that the <b>frontplate does not appease</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten,</b> and consequently only the blood of these offerings is valid, <b>how can they be brought in ritual impurity?</b>
The Gemara refutes this statement: <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> it is not difficult. <b>Rather, Rabbi Yehoshua holds that the frontplate appeases</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of <b>that which goes up,</b> i.e., the sacrificial parts that are brought onto the altar and burned. These portions may be burned on the altar even when they are impure. This is considered a form of consumption. Since part of meat is therefore suitable for consumption, the blood may be sprinkled.
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> works out <b>well</b> with regard to communal animal <b>offerings,</b> from which <b>there are</b> portions that <b>go up</b> onto the altar. <b>But</b> what of <b>the <i>omer</i> and the two loaves,</b> of which <b>there are no</b> parts that <b>go up</b> onto the altar? These offerings are entirely eaten by the priests except for the handful of flour which is scooped out and burned on the altar, and which serves the same function for a meal-offering as the sprinkling of the blood for an animal offering. <b>What is there to say</b> concerning those offerings? <b>Say</b> in answer to this question: <b>When Rabbi Yehoshua said that we require</b> the <b>two</b> parts of the offering to be valid, he said it <b>with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings;</b> but <b>with regard to meal-offerings he did not say</b> it.
The Gemara expresses surprise: Is it true that <b>with regard to meal-offerings he did not say</b> that there is a requirement that both the handful and the remainder of the meal-offering remain valid? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: If <b>the remainder</b> of the meal-offering, i.e., everything left after the handful has been separated, <b>became ritually impure,</b> or if <b>the remainder was lost, according to the principle of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who says that the blood is fit even if there is no meat, <b>it is valid,</b> but <b>according to the principle of Rabbi Yehoshua it is disqualified?</b>
The Gemara responds: It is <b>in accordance with the principle</b> of Rabbi Yehoshua <b>but not</b> entirely <b>in accordance with the principle</b> of Rabbi Yehoshua, meaning that the statement in the mishna is similar but not entirely consistent with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua. It is <b>in accordance with the principle of Rabbi Yehoshua in that we need</b> the <b>two</b> parts of the offering to be valid. <b>And</b> it is <b>not in accordance with the principle of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> because <b>whereas Rabbi Yehoshua</b> himself <b>said</b> so <b>with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings</b> but <b>with regard to meal-offerings he did not say</b> so, <b>this <i>tanna</i></b> quoted in the mishna extended Rabbi Yehoshua’s opinion and <b>holds</b> that it applies <b>even to meal-offerings.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And who is this <i>tanna</i> who holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua <b>and is more stringent than him? And furthermore, it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer</b> both <b>with regard to meal-offerings and with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings; and</b> I see as correct <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua</b> both <b>with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings and with regard to meal-offerings.</b>
Rabbi Yosei explains: <b>The statement of Rabbi Eliezer</b> is correct <b>with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings, as he would say</b> that the <b>blood</b> brings atonement <b>although there is no meat. The statement of Rabbi Yehoshua</b> is correct <b>with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings, as he would say</b> that <b>if there is no blood, there is no meat,</b> and <b>if there is no meat, there is no blood. The statement of Rabbi Eliezer</b> is correct <b>with regard to meal-offerings, as he would say</b> that <b>the handful</b> is fit <b>although there is no remainder. The statement of Rabbi Yehoshua</b> is correct <b>with regard to meal-offerings, as he would say</b> that <b>if there is no</b> valid <b>handful, there is no remainder,</b> and <b>if there is no remainder, there is no handful.</b> This indicates that Rabbi Yehoshua disputes the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer concerning meal-offerings, just as he disputes his opinion concerning animal offerings.
<b>Rather,</b> the previous answer should be rejected and the answer is as follows: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua holds</b> that <b>the frontplate appeases</b> God both <b>for</b> the impurity of sacrificial limbs that <b>go up</b> onto the altar and <b>for</b> the impurity of portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten.</b> The Gemara has now rejected its previous assumption that, according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, the frontplate does not appease God for the impurity of the portions of offerings that are eaten. Consequently, the mishna, which rules that impure communal offerings are valid, is consistent with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>If so, why</b> does the mishna cited above say that, <b>in accordance with the principle of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> an impure offering <b>is disqualified?</b> The Gemara responds: This opinion was stated only with regard to meat that was <b>lost or burned;</b> however, if it became ritually impure, the frontplate appeases God, and the offerings remain valid.
The Gemara asks: But if so, <b>according to whom</b> is the mishna <b>teaching</b> the case of a meal-offering that <b>became impure? According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the meal-offering remains valid: <b>Now</b> that it has been mentioned that in a case where it was <b>lost or burned, when they are not</b> present at all, <b>Rabbi Eliezer validates</b> the offering, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to mention that when it <b>became impure, when it is</b> still in existence, the offering is valid? <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that this case is mentioned in order to teach the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, and it is teaching</b> that according to him it is <b>disqualified.</b>
<b>And furthermore, it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> With regard to <b>all</b> animal <b>offerings in the Torah, whether the meat became ritually impure and the fat</b> of the offering, which is the part that is burned on the altar, <b>remains</b> valid, <b>or the fat became impure and the meat remains</b> valid, <b>one may sprinkle the blood.</b> The following inference can be made from this <i>baraita</i>: <b>But if both of them became ritually impure,</b> he may <b>not</b> sprinkle the blood. <b>Apparently, Rabbi Yehoshua holds</b> that <b>the frontplate does not appease</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of the parts of the offering that <b>go up</b> onto the altar <b>or for</b> the impurity of portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the previous answers have been rejected and the answer is as follows: <b>Actually, the mishna is</b> even in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, and it</b> is <b>not difficult: There,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua was referring to the <i>halakha <b>ab initio</b></i><b>; here,</b> in the mishna, it is referring to the <i>halakha</i> <b>after the fact. When Rabbi Yehoshua said</b> that if the meat is disqualified the blood may not be brought to the altar, that was only <b><i>ab initio</i>; after the fact</b> he did <b>not</b> disqualify it.
<b>And from where do you say that Rabbi Yehoshua differentiates between <i>ab initio</i> and after the fact? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the <b>meat became impure or it was disqualified</b> through contact with one who has immersed during the day but does not become fully pure until nightfall, <b>or</b> if the meat <b>went outside the hangings</b> and was thereby disqualified, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> the blood <b>may be sprinkled</b> and it is valid; <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says it may not be sprinkled. And Rabbi Yehoshua concedes that if one sprinkled</b> the blood, the offering <b>is accepted.</b>
The Gemara rejects this answer for two reasons. <b>One</b> reason to reject it is that the term <b>disqualified indicates</b> that the offering is invalid even <b>after the fact</b> and not only <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And furthermore,</b> the mishna’s statement that <b>five items may be brought in</b> a state of ritual impurity <b>indicates</b> that they may be brought even <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>

Daf 78a

<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>not difficult: There,</b> where Rabbi Yehoshua said that it is invalid <i>ab initio</i>, he was referring to the offering of <b>an individual. Here, in</b> the mishna, which states that it may be sacrificed even <i>ab initio</i>, it is referring to an offering involving <b>the public.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that <b>the frontplate appeases</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten. Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <b>the frontplate does not appease</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten;</b> it appeases God only for the impurity of the parts of offerings that are burned on the altar.
The Gemara explains the question: It could <b>enter your mind</b> to say: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Yosei said</b> that <b>the frontplate does not appease</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten,</b> it can be inferred that <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, who said</b> that <b>we require</b> the <b>two</b> parts of the offering, the blood and the meat, to be valid. If this were not the case, it would be sufficient for the frontplate to appease God for the impurity of the blood, and it would not be necessary for the frontplate to appease God for the impurity of the portions of offerings that are supposed to be eaten. <b>Let us now say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b>
The Gemara rejects this assertion: <b>No, Rabbi Yosei holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> that the <b>blood</b> of an offering is accepted <b>although there is no meat.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, with regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> did Rabbi Yosei say that <b>the frontplate does not appease</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten?</b> Even if it does not appease God for the impurity of these portions, the offering remains valid. The Gemara rejects the question: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> with regard to <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> himself, <b>who said</b> that <b>the frontplate appeases</b> God for the impurity of the portions that are supposed to be <b>eaten, since he said</b> that the <b>blood</b> may be sprinkled <b>although there is no meat, with regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> did he make his other statement that <b>the frontplate appeases</b> God for the impurity of the portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten?</b> Clearly, whether the frontplate appeases God is significant for reasons other than ensuring that an offering is accepted.
<b>Rather,</b> the fact that <b>they disagree</b> about whether the frontplate appeases God for the impurity of the portions of offerings that are supposed to be eaten determines whether it is possible <b>to establish</b> the offering <b>as</b> one <b>disqualified due to improper intent [<i>piggul</i>] and</b> whether it is possible <b>to exclude</b> the offering <b>from</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse of consecrated property.</b> The dispute is to be understood in this light: <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that <b>the frontplate appeases</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of the meat that is supposed to be eaten, <b>and it renders it like pure</b> meat that is not disqualified. Therefore, although the meat may not be eaten, it may be <b>established as <i>piggul</i>.</b> Similarly, because it is treated as though it were pure, the sprinkling of the blood of the offering <b>excludes</b> the meat <b>from</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse of consecrated property.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>the frontplate does not appease God for</b> the impurity of sacrificial meat that has become impure, <b>and it does not render it like pure</b> meat. Therefore, sprinkling the blood of the offering <b>does not establish it as <i>piggul</i> and does not exclude it from</b> the prohibition of <b>misusing consecrated property.</b>
<b>Rav Mari strongly objects to this</b> conclusion: <b>Even granting that Rabbi Yosei holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> that an offering is accepted through the blood alone, even if the meat has become ritually impure, there is still a difficulty. <b>Granted,</b> in the case of animal <b>offerings,</b> which have two permitting factors, the blood and the meat, <b>there is</b> at least one of them, the <b>blood,</b> for which the frontplate appeases God and causes the offering to be accepted. With regard to the <b><i>omer</i>, too, there is the handful,</b> for which the frontplate appeases God and is thereby validated. With regard to <b>the shewbread, too, there are the bowls</b> of frankincense, which permit the bread in the same manner that the handful permits a meal-offering.
<b>But</b> with regard to <b>the two loaves, what is there to say?</b> They are completely eaten, and nothing is brought on the altar. How can they be brought in a state of ritual impurity, as the mishna has stated, according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei?
<b>And if you say</b> that the two loaves are valid because the frontplate appeases God for the impurity of the two lambs <b>that are sacrificed with them, this is</b> the same as <b>the communal peace-offerings</b> that are mentioned separately in the mishna. <b>If so, there are</b> only <b>four</b> offerings listed in the mishna. <b>But we learned</b> in the mishna that there are <b>five,</b> because the two loaves and the communal peace-offerings are listed separately.
<b>Rather,</b> the previous suggestion is rejected. Instead, it is suggested that <b>Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>ritual impurity is permitted in</b> cases involving <b>the public,</b> even without the frontplate. Therefore, the two loaves remain valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>But wasn’t</b> the following <i>baraita</i> <b>taught</b> concerning the purity of both the High Priest on Yom Kippur and the priest who burns the red heifer, each of whom is separated from his house for seven days to ensure his purity? The <i>baraita</i> states: In the case of <b>both this</b> priest <b>and that</b> priest, <b>one sprinkles on him all seven</b> days of his separation <b>from all the purification offerings,</b> i.e., the ashes of the red heifers, <b>that are there</b> in the Temple. If he had become impure through contact with a corpse, he will be purified through the sprinkling of the purification offering. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says: One does not sprinkle upon him</b> on any day <b>except for the third and seventh</b> days of his separation. This ensures his purification.
<b>And if it enters your mind</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>ritual impurity is permitted in</b> cases involving <b>the public, why do I</b> need <b>sprinkling at all?</b> The offerings of Yom Kippur are communal offerings and may be sacrificed even in a state of ritual impurity. <b>Rather, it is clear</b> that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b>
With regard to Rabbi Yosei’s statement quoted earlier, <b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: Rabbi Yosei is</b> like <b>a document that awards</b> something <b>to two</b> conflicting parties, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings, and the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings, and the statement of Rabbi Eliezer with regard to meal-offerings, and the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua with regard to meal-offerings.</b>
<b>The statement of Rabbi Eliezer</b> is correct <b>with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings, as he would say</b> that the <b>blood</b> brings atonement <b>although there is no meat. The statement of Rabbi Yehoshua</b> is correct <b>with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings, as he would say</b> that <b>if there is no blood there is no meat,</b> and <b>if there is no meat there is no blood. The statement of Rabbi Eliezer</b> is correct <b>with regard to meal-offerings, as he would say</b> that <b>the handful</b> is fit <b>although there is no remainder. The statement of Rabbi Yehoshua</b> is correct <b>with regard to meal-offerings, as he would say</b> that <b>if there is no</b> valid <b>handful there is no remainder,</b> and <b>if there is no remainder there is no handful.</b> Rabbi Yosei accepted several contradictory statements.
Abaye <b>said to him:</b> Rabbi Yosei did not intend to issue a <i>halakhic</i> ruling in favor of both opinions. Rather, <b>he said what was reasonable.</b> How so? <b>When involved in</b> studying the <i>halakhot</i> of animal <b>offerings, he said: It is reasonable that just as they disagree with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings, they also disagree with regard to meal-offerings.</b> When <b>involved in</b> studying the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>meal-offerings, he said: It is reasonable that just as they disagree with regard to meal-offerings, they also disagree with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings.</b>
Rav Pappa <b>said to him:</b> It works out <b>well</b> to say that <b>when he was involved in</b> animal <b>offerings, he said: It is reasonable that just as they disagree with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings, they also disagree with regard to meal-offerings, as the essential verses written</b> about this topic <b>are written with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings. But</b> it does not seem realistic to say that <b>when he was involved in meal-offerings, he said: It is reasonable that just as they disagree with regard to meal-offerings, they disagree with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings. Aren’t the essential verses</b> about this topic <b>written with regard to</b> animal <b>offerings?</b> Clearly, meal-offerings would not serve as a model for animal-offerings.
<b>Rather,</b> this answer has been refuted, <b>and</b> Rabbi Yosei’s statement is <b>not difficult</b> for a different reason. When he said: <b>I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> he was referring to cases in which part of the offering <b>became impure.</b> When he said that he agreed with <b>the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> he was referring to cases in which part of the offering <b>was lost or burned.</b> In other words, Rabbi Yosei partially accepts the opinions of both Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua.
The Gemara asks: <b>In</b> a case in which the offering <b>became impure, what is the reason</b> that Rabbi Yosei accepts the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer? It is <b>because the frontplate appeases</b> God for the impurity. But this is impossible, as <b>you have heard that Rabbi Yosei said</b> that <b>the frontplate does not appease</b> God <b>for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are supposed to be <b>eaten.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> this answer should be rejected, and Rabbi Yosei’s opinion is <b>not difficult</b> for the following reason. When he said: <b>I see</b> as correct <b>the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> he was referring <b>to</b> a case <b>in</b> which an offering involves <b>the public.</b> When he said: <b>I see</b> as correct <b>the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> he was referring <b>to</b> the offering of <b>an individual.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to</b> an offering involving <b>the public, what is the reason</b> that Rabbi Yosei accepts the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer? It is <b>because ritual impurity is permitted in</b> cases involving <b>the public.</b> This explanation can be rejected for two reasons. <b>One</b> reason is <b>that you have heard that Rabbi Yosei said</b> that <b>ritual impurity is</b> merely <b>overridden in</b> cases involving <b>the public;</b> it is not wholly permitted. <b>And furthermore, if</b> Rabbi Yosei was referring <b>to</b> the offering of <b>the public,</b> is it only <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> who validates the offering, <b>and not Rabbi Yehoshua?</b>

Daf 78b

<b>Didn’t you say</b> that <b>with regard to</b> an offering involving <b>the public, even Rabbi Yehoshua concedes</b> that ritual impurity is permitted?
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yosei’s statement should be understood differently. When he said: <b>I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> he was referring to <b>after the fact.</b> When he said: I see as correct <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> he meant <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>After the fact Rabbi Yehoshua also concedes, as it teaches: Rabbi Yehoshua concedes that if one sprinkled</b> the blood, <b>it was accepted</b> and the offering is valid.
The Gemara responds: <b>This</b> case is <b>with regard to ritual impurity,</b> and <b>that</b> case is <b>with regard to</b> an offering that was <b>lost or burned.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>When it teaches</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua concedes that if one sprinkled</b> the blood <b>it is accepted,</b> that is <b>with regard to</b> a case in which the meat of the offering <b>became impure; but with regard to</b> a case where the meat of the offering was <b>lost or burned,</b> he does <b>not</b> agree, even after the fact. <b>When Rabbi Yosei said: I see</b> as correct <b>the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer after the fact,</b> that was <b>with regard to</b> cases in which the meat <b>was lost or burned,</b> with regard to which Rabbi Yehoshua did not concede to Rabbi Eliezer.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>the meat</b> of the Paschal lamb <b>became ritually impure, and the fat remains</b> pure and may be burned on the altar, <b>one</b> may <b>not sprinkle the blood.</b> On the other hand, if <b>the fat became impure and the meat remains</b> pure, <b>one</b> may <b>sprinkle the blood</b> because the meat remains fit to be eaten. This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a Paschal lamb, whose primary purpose is to be eaten by those who have registered for it. However, <b>with regard to</b> other <b>offerings it is not so. Rather, although the meat has become impure and the fat remains</b> pure, <b>one</b> may <b>sprinkle the blood,</b> because part of the offering still remains valid.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav said: If one sprinkled</b> the blood despite the fact that the meat was ritually impure, <b>it was</b> nonetheless <b>accepted;</b> one is not obligated to observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Don’t we require</b> that the Paschal lamb be <b>eaten,</b> which could not occur in this case? The Gemara answers: Failure to engage in <b>eating</b> the offering <b>does not preclude</b> it from being accepted.
