<b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that a nazirite and one bringing a Paschal lamb are considered pure, <b>said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to impurity of the deep. However,</b> if the source of <b>impurity</b> was <b>known</b> to some but not to the individual who became impure, <b>he is</b> nevertheless <b>impure.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And which</b> corpse is considered <b>impurity of the deep? Any</b> corpse <b>of which no one is aware,</b> even <b>at the end of the earth; but</b> if even <b>one</b> individual <b>is aware of it,</b> even if that individual is <b>at the end of the earth, this is not</b> considered <b>impurity of the deep.</b>
In order to ascertain whether anyone ever knew about the corpse, its condition is taken into account. If <b>one finds it hidden in hay</b> or <b>in dirt</b> or <b>in pebbles,</b> and it is possible that the person died in an avalanche, in which case it is likely that the corpse had never been found, <b>this is impurity of the deep.</b> But if he finds it <b>in water,</b> or <b>in a dark</b> place, or <b>in the clefts of the rocks, this is not impurity of the deep.</b> Although these are places where people do not often go, with the passage of time the corpse is likely to be discovered, and it is quite possible that someone already passed by and saw it. <b>And they said</b> the leniency of <b>impurity of the deep only with regard to a corpse,</b> but not with regard to other sources of ritual impurity.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the <b>whole</b> Paschal lamb <b>or most of it became ritually impure, one burns it before the Temple [<i>habira</i>] with wood from the arrangement</b> of wood on the altar that was given to the owners of the Paschal lamb for this purpose. If <b>a minority of it became impure, and</b> similarly, with regard to <b>the</b> parts of the Paschal lamb that are <b>leftover,</b> which must be burned, the owners of the Paschal lamb <b>burn it in their courtyards or on their roofs, with their own wood.</b> Only <b>the miserly,</b> who want to save the expenditure of wood, <b>burn it before the Temple in order to benefit from the wood of the arrangement.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that the Paschal lamb must be burned before the Temple and that those who prefer to burn it elsewhere are not permitted to do so? <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: In order to embarrass them.</b> Presumably, the reason that most of the offering became impure is because the owners were not sufficiently careful with it. Therefore, the Sages decreed that it be burned in a public place.
It was stated in the mishna that if <b>a minority of it became ritually impure,</b> and similarly, if part of it was left over, it is burned in the owners’ courtyards with their own wood. The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on what was taught in a different mishna: <b>And similarly,</b> with regard to <b>one who left Jerusalem and remembers that there is consecrated meat in his hand,</b> which is now disqualified because it has left Jerusalem and must therefore be burned, <b>if he passed</b> Mount <b>Scopus, he burns</b> the meat <b>at the site</b> where <b>he</b> is located, and he need not return to burn it in Jerusalem; <b>and if</b> he has <b>not</b> yet passed Mount Scopus,

Daf 82a

he must <b>return and burn it before the Temple with wood from the arrangement.</b> The mishna’s formulation uses the word remembered, implying that not only a large piece of meat that became ritually impure or somehow disqualified, but even a piece that is so small that it could become forgotten, must be burnt with wood from the arrangement.
<b>Rav Ḥama bar Ukva said:</b> It is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where it is stated that one burns it in the Temple with wood from the arrangement, it <b>is referring to a visitor</b> who does not live in Jerusalem or have wood there, and he may therefore use wood from the arrangement. While <b>there,</b> where it is stated that one burns it at home with one’s own wood, it <b>is referring to a resident</b> of Jerusalem.
<b>Rav Pappa said: This</b> case <b>and that</b> case both refer <b>to a visitor. Here,</b> where it is stated that one may use wood from the arrangement, it <b>is referring to</b> one who already <b>set out on the road,</b> and it is difficult for him to collect wood. <b>There,</b> where it is stated that one must use his own wood, it <b>is referring to</b> a case in which the visitor <b>has not</b> yet <b>set out on the road,</b> and he can gather his own wood.
<b>Rav Zevid</b> disagreed with Rav Pappa and clarified Rav Ḥama bar Ukva’s opinion. He <b>said: Actually,</b> it can be explained <b>as</b> Rav Ḥama <b>initially said: Here,</b> it <b>is referring to a visitor; there,</b> it <b>is referring to a resident. And even though he did not</b> yet <b>set out on the road, a visitor</b> may use wood from the arrangement for the following reason: <b>Since he does not have</b> his own wood, the Sages <b>treated him like the misers, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The misers burn it before the Temple in order to benefit from the wood of the arrangement.</b> This indicates that anyone who is unconcerned about his reputation, like a miser, may use wood from the arrangement, and this is not considered to be a misuse of consecrated property. Similarly, the Sages also permitted a visitor to use wood from the arrangement.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: If individuals <b>came</b> and wanted <b>to burn</b> the Paschal lamb that had become ritually impure <b>in their courtyards and</b> wanted to take <b>wood from the arrangement</b> to use for this purpose, <b>one does not listen to them.</b> Similarly, if they wanted to burn it <b>before the Temple with their own wood, one does not listen to them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> if people want to burn it <b>with wood from the arrangement in their</b> own <b>courtyards one does not listen to them.</b> This is because the Sages were concerned <b>lest they leave over some of the</b> wood they took to burn the Paschal lamb <b>and come to</b> experience <b>a mishap with it</b> by using the wood for another purpose. <b>But</b> in the case in which they wanted to burn the offering <b>before the Temple with their own wood, what is the reason</b> one does <b>not</b> listen to them?
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> It is <b>in order not to embarrass one who does not have</b> the means to bring his own wood. If it were permitted to bring one’s own wood to burn in the Temple, people would realize that only the poor people take wood from the Temple. This would be embarrassing to the poor. <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>due to suspicion.</b> People would take back their own unused wood that they had brought, and others might suspect that they were stealing consecrated wood from the Temple.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between these</b> two answers? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them is</b> the case of one who <b>brings reeds</b> or <b>palm branches that are not fit for the arrangement.</b> Since these types of branches are not used for the arrangement of wood on the altar, there is no concern that people would be wrongly suspected of stealing them from the Temple; therefore, Rava would permit it. However, the concern that the poor will be embarrassed is still relevant, and so Rav Yosef would prohibit it.
Another mishna teaches a similar dispute between Rav Yosef and Rava on a different subject: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there,</b> in tractate <i>Tamid</i>: The <b>head of the watch would stand the ritually impure</b> priests <b>at</b> the entrance to <b>the eastern gate</b> each morning. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that they did not simply send them home without making them stand at the entrance to the eastern gate? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> It was <b>in order to embarrass them</b> for not having been careful to avoid becoming impure. <b>Rava said:</b> They would stand them there <b>to</b> avoid <b>suspicion,</b> so that people would realize that they were not performing the Temple service because they were impure, rather than in order to work in their regular professions.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between these</b> two opinions? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them is</b> the case of <b>pampered people</b> who never work, whom others would not suspect of avoiding Temple service in order to work in their regular professions. <b>Alternatively,</b> it is the case of <b>one who twists ropes</b> for a living. No one would suspect someone of missing the Temple service in order to work in such a lowly and non-profitable occupation. These two categories of people would not have to stand at the gate according to Rava’s opinion, but would have to according to Rav Yosef’s opinion.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A Paschal lamb that was taken out</b> of its permissible area <b>or that became ritually impure should be burned immediately</b> on the eve of Passover. If <b>the owners became ritually impure or died, its form must</b> be allowed to <b>decay</b> by leaving it for a period of time instead of burning it immediately, <b>and it should be burned on the sixteenth</b> of Nisan, immediately after the first day of the Festival. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: This, too, should be burned immediately, because it has no one to eat it,</b> which is also so severe a disqualification that decay of form is not required.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> the fact that <b>ritually impure</b> sacrificial meat must be burned <b>is written</b> in the Torah, as it says: <b>“The flesh that touches any impure item shall not be eaten, it shall be burned in fire”</b> (Leviticus 7:19). <b>But</b> sacrificial meat that <b>is taken out</b> of its permissible area, <b>from where do we</b> derive that it must be burned?
The Gemara responds: It is derived from the verses describing Moses admonishing Aaron and his sons about the fact that they did not eat the sin-offering on the eighth day of inauguration, <b>as it is written: “Behold, its blood was not brought into the Sanctuary within;</b> you should have eaten it in the Sanctuary, as I commanded” (Leviticus 10:18). This should be understood as follows: <b>Moses said to Aaron: Why didn’t you eat the sin-offering? Perhaps its blood entered the innermost</b> chamber, the Sanctuary, in which case it must be burned? Aaron <b>said to him: No.</b>
Moses <b>said to him: Perhaps it was taken outside of its boundary,</b> and that is the reason you did not eat it? <b>He said to him: No, it was in the sacred</b> area, i.e., the courtyard. Moses <b>said to him: If it was in the sacred</b> area the entire time, <b>behold, its blood was not brought into the Sanctuary within, why didn’t you eat it?</b> This proves <b>by inference that if it leaves</b> its boundary, <b>or alternatively, if its blood enters within</b> the Sanctuary of the Temple, <b>it must be burned.</b> This can serve as a model for all offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to sacrificial meat that <b>became ritually impure, the Merciful One reveals</b> that <i>halakha</i> in the Torah <b>with regard to offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> as the verse: “The flesh that touches any impure item shall not be eaten,” is referring to a peace-offering, and it applies <b>all the more so with regard to offerings of the most sacred order. However,</b> with regard to sacrificial meat that <b>is taken out</b> of its boundary, <b>we</b> have <b>found</b> a source that this applies to <b>offerings of</b> only <b>the most sacred order.</b> With regard to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> such as the Paschal lamb, <b>from where do we</b> derive that they too must be burned? <b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>the blood</b> of an offering <b>was left overnight</b> instead of being sprinkled on the altar on the day it was slaughtered,

Daf 82b

or <b>its blood was spilled,</b> or <b>its blood was taken outside the hangings</b> that denoted the courtyard of the Tabernacle, <b>we maintain</b> that it must be <b>burned; from where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara answers: <b>We derive it from</b> the exposition of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The verse that states: “Any sin-offering from which some blood has been brought to the Tent of Meeting, to make atonement <b>in the sacred place,</b> shall not be eaten; <b>it shall be burned in fire”</b> (Leviticus 6:23), <b>has taught that the burning of a sin-offering is in the sacred</b> area, the Temple courtyard.
<b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>this alone,</b> a sin-offering; with regard to <b>the rest of the disqualified offerings of the most sacred order and the portions of offerings of lesser sanctity</b> that are consumed on the altar, <b>from where do we</b> derive that they must be burned in the Temple courtyard, which is their boundary when they are valid? <b>The verse states: “Any…in the sacred place…shall be burned in fire,”</b> which teaches that any consecrated item must be burned in a sacred place.
The Gemara asks further: <b>We found</b> a source for <b>offerings of the most sacred order; from where do we derive</b> that it also applies to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity? Rather,</b> we must say as follows: <b>Anything disqualified in the sacred</b> area, the Temple courtyard, must be <b>burned.</b> It is <b>no different</b> whether it is <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, and</b> it is <b>no different</b> whether it is <b>offerings of the most sacred order; they learned it as a tradition. And the sin-offering of Aaron</b> that was burned on the eighth day of inauguration was mentioned only <b>because the incident that took place, took place in this way.</b> It was not mentioned in order to teach the <i>halakhot</i> of offerings.
The Gemara proceeds to ask an unrelated question with regard to <i>piggul</i>: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>the <i>tanna</i> from the school of Rabba bar Avuh, who said</b> that <b>even <i>piggul</i>,</b> which is a disqualification of the animal itself, <b>requires decay of form,</b> meaning that it must be left over until the next day so that it will begin to decay and is only then burned, <b>from where do we</b> derive that it requires decay of form?
The Gemara answers: <b>It is derived</b> from a verbal analogy from the parallel words <b>“iniquity”</b> and <b>“iniquity.”</b> With regard to <i>piggul</i>, the verse states: “It remains rejected [<i>piggul</i>]; and the soul that eats it shall bear its iniquity” (Leviticus 7:18), and with regard to <b>leftover</b> sacrificial meat, the verse states: “And whatever is leftover…shall be burned in fire…and each of those who eat it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 19:6–8). Just as leftover sacrificial meat is burned after it has been left over to the next day, so too, <i>piggul</i> is burned only after it has been left over to the next day and its form has decayed.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us</b> instead <b>learn</b> the rules of <i>piggul</i> <b>through</b> a verbal analogy based on the parallel words <b>“iniquity”</b> and <b>“iniquity”</b> from <b>the sin-offering of Aaron,</b> with regard to which the verse states: “Why did you not eat the sin-offering in the place of sanctity…and He gave it to you to bear the iniquity of the congregation” (Leviticus 10:17). The sin-offering of Aaron was burned immediately, without decay of form, so why can it not be learned from there that <i>piggul</i> does not require decay of form either? That <i>tanna</i> could have <b>said to you: The sin-offering of Aaron in a case like this would also require decay of form</b> were it to occur <b>in</b> future <b>generations; but there,</b> when it was burned immediately, <b>it was a provisional edict</b> issued in exigent circumstances.
The Gemara asks: <b>Now that we say</b> that we have accepted the conclusion that <b>all disqualified sacred</b> offerings must be <b>burned,</b> and it is <b>no different</b> whether they are disqualified <b>offerings of the most sacred order</b> or <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> because in both cases <b>they learned it as a tradition,</b> with regard to the verse that says: <b>“In the sacred place…shall be burned in fire,” why do I</b> need it? What does this verse teach that is not known from oral tradition? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is required</b> to teach that the requirement of burning that is learned from the oral tradition cannot take place anywhere; <b>its burning</b> must take place only <b>in the sacred</b> place, the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara asks further: If the source of the <i>halakha</i> is an oral tradition, with regard to the verse that states: <b>“The flesh that touches any impure item shall not be eaten, it shall be burned in fire”</b> (Leviticus 7:19), <b>why do I</b> need it? This <i>halakha</i> is included in the oral tradition and should not require its own verse.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse is <b>necessary for itself. It could enter your mind to say</b> that <b>disqualified sacred</b> offerings include only a case <b>where its blood was left overnight</b> instead of being sprinkled on the altar on the day the offering was slaughtered; or <b>its blood was spilled;</b> or <b>its blood was taken outside</b> the hangings; <b>and</b> similarly, the case of an offering that <b>was slaughtered at night.</b> In all these cases, the offering must be <b>burned</b> because these are disqualifications unique to sanctified offerings <b>that do not exist with regard to unconsecrated</b> items.
<b>But</b> if the meat <b>became ritually impure, which disqualifies unconsecrated</b> meat <b>also, say</b> that <b>since it was treated in the manner of unconsecrated items,</b> as the disqualification is not unique to consecrated items, <b>it should not require burning, and burial should be sufficient for it.</b> Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that an offering that is disqualified through ritual impurity must also be burned.
It was taught in the mishna that if <b>the owners</b> of the offering <b>became ritually impure or died</b> before the offering was completed, <b>its form</b> must be left to <b>decay,</b> and it is burned after the first day of the Festival. Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka disagrees and says that it is burned immediately. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> is about a case in which <b>the owners became ritually impure after the sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>because the meat was fit for eating</b> since all its services were completed in a valid way. <b>But</b> if <b>the owners became ritually impure before the sprinkling</b> of the blood, such that <b>the meat was not fit for eating</b> even for a moment, <b>all agree</b> that <b>it should be burned immediately.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this statement based on the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>This is the principle:</b> In <b>all</b> cases in which <b>its disqualification is in itself, it should be burned immediately.</b> If the disqualification is <b>in the blood</b> of the offering or <b>in the owners, its form</b> should be left to <b>decay, and</b> then <b>it should be taken out to the place</b> designated for <b>burning.</b>
The following inference can be made based on the formulation of the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>It is teaching</b> that the case of disqualified <b>owners</b> is <b>similar to</b> the case of disqualified <b>blood: Just as</b> in the case of <b>blood</b> the disqualification necessarily occurred <b>before the sprinkling</b> of the blood, as the offering is not disqualified if anything happens to the blood after sprinkling, <b>so too,</b> the case of <b>owners</b> is referring to one in which they became disqualified even <b>before the sprinkling</b> of the blood, which contradicts the statement of Rav Yosef.
<b>Rather, if</b> this <b>was stated</b> in the name of Rav Yosef, <b>it was stated as follows:</b> This <b>dispute</b> is specifically about a case in which <b>the owners became ritually impure before the sprinkling</b> of the blood, such that <b>the meat was never fit for eating, which</b> makes it <b>as though its disqualification is in itself. But</b> if <b>the owners became ritually impure after sprinkling</b> of the blood, such that <b>the meat was fit for eating, all agree</b> that <b>its disqualification is due to a different matter,</b> i.e., an external factor, <b>and it requires decay of form.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even</b> a case in which the owners became ritually impure <b>after sprinkling</b> the blood <b>is</b> included in <b>the dispute</b> about whether decay of form is necessary. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka and Rabbi Neḥemya said the same thing.</b> The statement of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka is that which we said.</b>
With regard to <b>Rabbi Neḥemya, what is</b> the ruling in which he expressed his opinion? It is <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> Aaron’s sin-offering that was burned on the eighth day of inauguration <b>was burned due to acute mourning,</b> as that was the day his sons Nadav and Avihu died. <b>For this</b> reason, <b>it is stated</b> that Aaron explained to Moses: “Now that events such <b>as these</b> befell me, were I to eat this day’s sin-offering would the Lord approve?” (Leviticus 10:19). In other words, it was due to the deaths of his sons, which Aaron referred as “events such as these,” that Aaron burned the sin-offering instead of eating it.
Rabbi Yoḥanan analyzes Rabbi Neḥemya’s statement: <b>Now, acute mourning is similar to</b> a case of disqualification <b>after sprinkling</b> of the blood, because acute mourning merely disqualifies the owners from eating the offering. It does not disqualify the actual performance of the sacrificial service by a High Priest, such as Aaron. Therefore, it is like other disqualifications that take effect after the sprinkling, which simply prohibit the eating of the meat. <b>And when it was burned, it was burned immediately,</b> without waiting until the following day. This shows that Rabbi Neḥemya agrees that an offering that becomes disqualified after its blood has been sprinkled should be burned immediately.

Daf 83a

<b>Rabba adds</b> that these tanna’im were not the only ones who maintain this opinion; <b>even Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> agreed with them, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: The entire matter</b> that is stated in the verse: “Any sin-offering from which some blood has been brought to the Tent of Meeting, to make atonement in the sacred place, shall not be eaten; it shall be burned in fire” (Leviticus 6:23) is not stated with regard to a regular sin-offering improperly brought inside the Sanctuary; rather, it <b>speaks only about bulls that are burned and goats that are burned.</b> These are unique sin-offerings, and the Torah states that their blood should be brought inside the Sanctuary. The verse is stated with regard to these sin-offerings both in order to command the Jewish people <b>to burn the disqualified ones in the place of the <i>bira</i></b> on the Temple Mount <b>and</b> in order <b>to establish a prohibition with regard to their consumption.</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: If you expound the verse in this fashion, then with regard to a regular <b>sin-offering whose blood entered inside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>from where</b> is it derived that it must be burned? <b>He said to them:</b> It is derived from the verse: <b>“Behold, its blood was not brought into the Sanctuary within”</b> (Leviticus 10:18). This proves <b>by inference that if</b> the sin-offering <b>is taken out</b> of its permitted area, <b>or alternatively,</b> if <b>its blood enters</b> the Sanctuary, it must be <b>burned</b> immediately without waiting for decay of form.
The Gemara explains: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> did not include Rabbi Yosei HaGelili because Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>holds</b> that there is a difference between the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and those of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka and Rabbi Neḥemya. The reason for this difference is that impurity of <b>blood and meat,</b> about which Rabbi Yosei HaGelili was speaking, <b>is one matter,</b> and impurity of the blood can therefore be considered a disqualification in the animal itself, but disqualification of the <b>owners is a different matter.</b> Therefore, Rabbi Yosei HaGelili does not necessarily agree with the <i>tanna’im</i> who allow the offering to be burned immediately in the case of disqualification of the owners.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The bones</b> of the Paschal lamb that contain edible marrow but cannot be eaten because it is prohibited to break the bones of the Paschal lamb; <b>and the sinews; and the leftover</b> meat <b>should</b> all <b>be burned on the sixteenth</b> of Nisan, immediately after the first day of the Festival. If <b>the sixteenth occurs on Shabbat, they should be burned on the seventeenth, because</b> the mitzva to burn <b>them does not override Shabbat or the Festival.</b> Therefore, they are burned on the first weekday.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Mari bar Avuh said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Bones of offerings that served</b> as a base for <b>leftover,</b> meaning that they have leftover meat on them or inside them after the time of eating, <b>render hands impure,</b> just as the leftover sacrificial parts themselves render hands impure. <b>Since</b> the bones <b>have become a base for an</b> intrinsically <b>prohibited object,</b> they are treated in the same manner as the prohibited object itself. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following expression in the mishna <b>supports him: The bones, and the sinews, and the leftover should be burned on the sixteenth</b> of Nisan.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> in which <b>these bones</b> must be burned? <b>If we say</b> that <b>there is no marrow in them, why</b> must they be <b>burned? We should discard them,</b> as the Torah requires that leftover parts of offerings be burned only when they are edible. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that</b> we are dealing with bones that <b>have marrow in them.</b> The marrow is part of the meat of the offering, and in other offerings one would have broken the bones in order to eat the marrow.
<b>Granted, if you say that</b> an item that <b>serves</b> as a base or container for <b>leftover is something</b> significant and becomes disqualified in the same manner as the leftover themselves, <b>because of this it needs burning</b> like the leftover itself. <b>But if you say that serving</b> as a base for <b>leftover is nothing</b> significant, <b>why do these</b> bones need to be <b>burned? Let us break them, and remove their marrow, and burn</b> the marrow, <b>and discard</b> the bones. <b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from it that serving</b> as a base for <b>leftover is something</b> significant, and the bones themselves become prohibited and impart ritual impurity due to their consecrated contents?
<b>Say</b> in refutation of this proof: <b>No. Actually, I could say to you that serving</b> as a base for <b>leftover is nothing</b> significant, <b>and</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>holds</b> that the prohibition stated in the Torah: “And you shall not break a bone <b>in it”</b> (Exodus 12:46), applies <b>even to a disqualified</b> Paschal lamb. The prohibition to break the bones of the Paschal lamb applies even when the Paschal lamb itself may no longer be eaten. Thus, the bones must be burned because there is no way to extract the marrow. They are not burned because they themselves have served as a base for the leftover marrow.
The Gemara expresses surprise at the previous answer: <b>Can</b> it <b>enter your mind</b> to say that the prohibition applies <b>even to a disqualified</b> Paschal lamb? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>But one who leaves over</b> part of <b>a pure</b> Paschal lamb or <b>one who breaks</b> the bone of <b>a ritually impure</b> Paschal lamb <b>does not receive forty</b> lashes, which indicates that the Torah prohibition to break a bone applies only to a Paschal lamb that is still valid? The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> when the mishna indicates that it is prohibited to break even the bone of a disqualified Paschal lamb, it is referring to a case where <b>it had a time when it was valid,</b> such as leftover sacrificial meat, which was valid before it was left over, and the prohibition therefore became relevant when it was valid. <b>There,</b> when the other mishna stated that the prohibition does not apply, it is referring to sacrificial meat <b>that did not have a time when it was valid.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>And who is the <i>tanna</i> who differentiates between</b> a Paschal lamb <b>that had a time when it was valid and</b> one that <b>did not have a time when it was valid? It is Rabbi Ya’akov, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And you shall not break a bone in it,”</b> and the emphasis of the expression <b>“in it”</b> teaches that the prohibition applies only <b>to a valid</b> Paschal lamb <b>and not to a disqualified</b> one. <b>Rabbi Ya’akov says:</b> If an offering <b>had a time when it was valid and</b> then <b>became disqualified, it is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone;</b> if <b>it did not have</b> any <b>time when it was valid, it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> With regard to <b>both this and that,</b> whether the offering was valid at some point or not, once it becomes disqualified <b>it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on what was taught in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>No bones of offerings require burning except for the bones of the Paschal lamb, due to the</b> possibility that leaving the bones around will lead to <b>a mishap</b> because one may eventually transgress the prohibition of breaking the bones. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> in which <b>these bones</b> must be burned? <b>If we say</b> we are dealing with a case <b>where there is no marrow</b> in the bones, <b>why must they be burned?</b> They should simply be discarded. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that there is marrow in them. And if it should enter your mind that serving</b> as a base for <b>leftover</b> meat of an offering <b>is something</b> significant, <b>why do bones of</b> other <b>offerings not require burning?</b> They are serving as a base for the leftover marrow in them.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a special case <b>where one finds</b> bones from which the marrow had already been <b>removed.</b> Therefore, there is room to differentiate between the different cases: With regard to <b>bones of</b> other <b>offerings, to which</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone does not apply,</b> one may presume that <b>before they became leftover one removed</b> the marrow from them and ate it. Therefore, these bones <b>were not serving</b> as a base for <b>leftover</b> sacrificial meat, <b>and they do not require burning</b> and may be discarded.
On the other hand, <b>bones of the Paschal lamb, to which</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone does apply,</b> were certainly not broken while the prohibition applied; rather, <b>it was after they became leftover that one removed</b> the marrow <b>from them,</b> when the prohibition of breaking a bone no longer applied, according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon above. In that case, the bones temporarily <b>served</b> as a base for <b>leftover</b> sacrificial meat, and therefore <b>they require burning.</b>
<b>Rav Zevid said</b> that one can answer in a different way: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>such as</b>

Daf 83b

<b>when one finds them in piles, and</b> he sees that <b>some of them</b> have had their marrow <b>removed.</b> If these bones are <b>bones of offerings to which</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone does not apply,</b> one can assume that the owner <b>removed</b> the marrow from <b>all</b> the bones before the marrow became leftover <b>and ate it, and they do not require burning.</b>
On the other hand, with regard to <b>the bones of the Paschal lamb, to which</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone does apply, perhaps</b> the owner <b>removed</b> the marrow from <b>these, and from those he did not remove</b> the marrow, <b>and they require burning.</b> Therefore, although one needs to check all the bones of the Paschal lamb he finds to ensure that they do not have marrow left in them, he does not need to burn them due to the unconfirmed possibility that the marrow was removed after it became leftover. The bones would need to be burned only if there was still marrow in them or if one knew for certain that they had served as a base for leftover sacrificial meat.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: All the sinews</b> in an animal are considered <b>like meat.</b> Therefore, one can fulfill his obligation to eat the Paschal lamb by eating them and one can register for them, <b>except for the sinews of the neck,</b> which are so hard that they are not considered meat.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>The bones, and the sinews, and the leftover shall be burned on the sixteenth.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> in which <b>these sinews</b> must be burned? <b>If we say</b> they are <b>sinews of meat, let us eat them.</b> Why are they burned? <b>And if</b> they are sinews <b>that were left over</b> and not eaten for some other reason, <b>they are leftover,</b> so why does the mishna list sinews separately? <b>Rather, it is obvious</b> that the mishna is referring to <b>sinews of the neck,</b> which are different than other sinews and are therefore mentioned separately.
<b>Granted, if you say they are meat, due to that they require burning; but if you say they are not meat, why do they</b> require <b>burning?</b> One should simply discard them like other waste. <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The mishna’s mention of sinews <b>is necessary only for the sciatic nerve, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> The prohibition to eat the sciatic nerve according to Torah law <b>applies only to</b> the sciatic nerve in <b>one</b> of the animal’s thighs, and not to both, <b>and logic dictates</b> that it is <b>the right</b> thigh. However, since there is no absolute proof that this is correct, the sciatic nerve must be removed from both sides. Although in theory the forbidden sciatic nerve may be discarded and the permitted one may be eaten, since there is uncertainty as to which one is permitted, neither of them may be eaten. Both must be burned.
The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we then conclude that Rabbi Yehuda was uncertain</b> about which sciatic nerve is forbidden? The Sages were unsure whether Rabbi Yehuda was absolutely convinced that it is the sciatic nerve from the right side that is forbidden, or if he was saying that this would seem likely to be the case, but he was not certain. <b>As, if it were clear to him</b> that it is the sciatic nerve from the right thigh that is forbidden, the proper procedure would be different: <b>The one that is permitted we should eat, and</b> the one <b>that is forbidden we should discard. Why should he</b> require <b>burning?</b>
<b>Rav Ika bar Ḥinnana said,</b> in response to this attempted proof: The mishna addresses a case <b>where</b> the two sciatic nerves <b>were known, but in the end</b> became <b>mixed</b> together. In other words, at first it was known which was the forbidden right nerve and which was the permitted left nerve. However, they were then mixed together and can no longer be identified. Therefore, due to the uncertainty, they must both be burned.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The mishna’s ruling that the sinews must be burned <b>is necessary only</b> with regard to <b>the fat of the sciatic nerve, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The fat</b> around the sciatic nerve <b>is permitted</b> according to Torah law, but <b>the Jewish people are holy and treat it as forbidden.</b> Since it is permitted according to Torah law, it has the status of meat and may not be simply discarded. However, since the Jewish people treat it as forbidden, they do not eat it even from the Paschal lamb. Therefore, it is left until after the time when the meat may be eaten and burned in accordance with the general <i>halakha</i> of leftover.
<b>Ravina said:</b> This discussion pertains to the <b>outer</b> nerve, <b>and</b> it is in accordance with that which <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: There are two sinews</b> in the sciatic nerve: The <b>inner</b> sinew <b>that is next to the bone is forbidden</b> according to Torah law, <b>and one is liable</b> to be flogged <b>for</b> eating <b>it. The outer</b> sinew <b>that is next to the meat is forbidden</b> by rabbinic law, and therefore <b>one is not liable</b> to be flogged <b>for</b> eating <b>it.</b> Since the outer sinew is permitted according to Torah law, it attains the status of leftover when it is not eaten.
It was taught in the mishna that if <b>the sixteenth</b> of Nisan <b>occurs</b> on Shabbat, the burning of the leftover does not override Shabbat, and they are burned on the seventeenth. The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> isn’t the leftover of the Paschal lamb burned on the Festival day itself? <b>The positive mitzva</b> to burn the leftover <b>should come and override the prohibition</b> that prohibits the performance of labor on Festivals.
<b>Ḥizkiya said, and similarly,</b> one of the Sages in <b>the school of Ḥizkiya taught: The verse states: “And you shall not leave any of it until morning; and that which remains of it until morning you shall burn with fire”</b> (Exodus 12:10). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state “until morning,”</b> and repeating that phrase adds nothing to the verse, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “until morning”?</b> It is <b>to give it a second morning for its burning.</b> In other words, it comes to teach that the mitzva to burn the leftover does not apply on the first morning, i.e., the morning of the Festival when they become prohibited to eat, but on the second morning, the sixteenth of Nisan. However, when the sixteenth falls on Shabbat, the burning is delayed until the seventeenth.
<b>Abaye said:</b> The reason is because <b>the verse states: “The burnt-offering of each Shabbat on its Shabbat</b> in addition to the continual burnt-offering and its libation” (Numbers 28:10). This indicates that the burnt-offering of Shabbat may be offered on the altar on Shabbat or burned if it is disqualified, but <b>not the burnt-offering of a weekday on Shabbat, and not the burnt-offering of a weekday on a Festival.</b> It is derived from here that one may not burn anything on Shabbat that is not an obligation of that day.
<b>Rava said</b> a different reason: <b>The verse states</b> concerning Festivals: “And on the first day there shall be a sacred convocation; no kind of labor shall be done on them, save that which every man must eat, <b>only that may be done for you”</b> (Exodus 12:16). From this verse one can infer the following: <b>That,</b> i.e., the food itself, you may prepare, <b>but</b> you may <b>not</b> perform acts that <b>facilitate its</b> preparation, which must be done beforehand. The word <b>only</b> is also exclusive; it indicates that only food preparation is permitted,

Daf 84a

<b>but not a circumcision</b> that is <b>not at its</b> ideal <b>time</b>. If, for some reason, circumcision was not performed on the eighth day after birth, its performance at a later date does not override a Festival, because the obligation to perform the circumcision is not particular to that specific day. This needed to be emphasized. Otherwise, it would have <b>come</b> to be derived <b>through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that circumcision does override Shabbat and Festivals, based on the fact that it overrides the laws of leprosy. Therefore, the Torah emphasized that circumcision performed later than the eighth day does not override Festivals.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> a different reason that the leftover Paschal lamb is not burned on the Festival: The obligation of <b>solemn rest</b> stated <b>with regard to Festivals is a positive</b> mitzva. Therefore, the <i>halakhot</i> of Festivals include both a positive mitzva to rest from performing prohibited labor and a prohibition to avoid such labor, <b>and a positive</b> mitzva such as burning leftover sacrificial meat <b>does not override</b> both <b>a prohibition and a positive</b> mitzva.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Anything that is</b> fit to be <b>eaten in an adult ox,</b> whose bones have fully hardened, may <b>be eaten in a young kid.</b> One may register for a Paschal offering in order to eat any of these parts, and eating any such part is considered a fulfillment of the mitzva to eat the Paschal lamb. However, any part of the animal that is inedible in an adult ox is not considered meat, even if it is soft enough to be eaten in a young kid. One may not register for a Paschal offering in order to eat one of these parts, and eating it is not a fulfillment of the mitzva to eat the Paschal lamb. <b>And</b> the soft <b>ends of the ribs and the cartilage</b> are soft enough to be considered edible and may therefore be eaten from the Paschal lamb.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabba raised a contradiction: We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>anything that is</b> fit to be <b>eaten in an adult ox may be eaten in a young kid,</b> which indicates clearly that anything <b>that is not eaten</b> in an adult ox is <b>not</b> eaten even when it comes from a young kid. <b>Say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>The ends of the ribs and the cartilage</b> of the young kid may be eaten. <b>But these are not eaten in an adult ox,</b> because they have already become as hard as bone and are no longer edible.
<b>Rather, it is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> and both opinions are mentioned in the mishna, <b>and this is what it is teaching: Anything eaten in an adult ox may be eaten in a young kid, and</b> anything <b>that is not eaten</b> in an adult ox is <b>not</b> eaten in a young kid. <b>And some say</b> that <b>even the ends of the ribs and the cartilage</b> are eaten from a young kid, because even these parts of an adult ox can be made edible through extensive cooking.
<b>Rava said:</b> The mishna <b>teaches</b> employing the style: <b>What are they,</b> in which the mishna establishes a principle and then provides detail, <b>and this is what it is teaching: Anything that is</b> fit to be <b>eaten in an adult ox through cooking may be eaten in a young kid through roasting,</b> even if this part of an adult ox cannot be made edible through roasting. <b>And what are these</b> parts? They are <b>the ends of the ribs and the cartilage.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava: Anything that is</b> fit to be <b>eaten in an adult ox through cooking may be eaten in a young kid through roasting; and what are these</b> parts? They are <b>the ends of the ribs and the cartilage; and the soft sinews are judged as meat.</b>
<b>It was stated</b> that the Sages disputed the issue of <b>sinews that will eventually harden</b> but are currently soft. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One may register for them in the Paschal lamb. Reish Lakish said: One may not register for them in the Paschal lamb.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>one may register for them</b> in the Paschal lamb because <b>we follow the current</b> condition of the sinews; since they are edible in their current state, they are considered meat. <b>Reish Lakish said</b> that <b>one may not register for them</b> in the Paschal lamb because <b>we follow the eventual</b> condition of the sinews, and they eventually become inedible.
<b>Reish Lakish raised an objection to Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> It was stated that <b>anything eaten in an adult ox may be eaten in a young kid, and what are these</b> parts? They are <b>the ends of the ribs and the cartilage.</b> This indicates that with regard to <b>these</b> items, <b>yes,</b> they may be eaten; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>sinews that will eventually harden, no,</b> they may not. This contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: It taught these,</b> the ends of the ribs and the cartilage, <b>and the same is true for those,</b> i.e., the same <i>halakha</i> applies to sinews that will eventually harden. <b>What is the reason</b> that people may register for <b>these,</b> the ends of the ribs and the cartilage? It is <b>because they are eaten in an adult ox through cooking. These, too,</b> the sinews that will eventually harden, <b>are eaten in an adult ox through cooking.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Avin: When you go before Rabbi Abbahu, raise</b> the following <b>contradiction to him: Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say:</b> With regard to <b>sinews that will eventually harden,</b> people <b>may register for them in the Paschal lamb,</b> which would <b>apparently</b> indicate that <b>we go</b> according to <b>the current</b> condition of the sinews? <b>But Reish Lakish asked Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to <b>the hide of the head of a young calf,</b> which is still edible, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the possibility of it <b>becoming ritually impure</b> as a food? Do we view it as a food and apply the rules of ritual impurity of foods, or do we view it as a hide? <b>And he said to him: It does not become ritually impure. Apparently, we go</b> according to <b>the eventual</b> condition of the hide, which contradicts Rabbi Yoḥanan’s own opinion with regard to sinews.
When Rabbi Avin came before Rabbi Abbahu and asked him this question, Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him:</b> Whoever <b>asked you this</b> question <b>was not concerned for his flour,</b> meaning he did not carefully consider what he said. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan retracted</b> his opinion in this regard in favor of the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish, and</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him,</b> at the end of their discussion on the topic: <b>Do not trouble me</b> by asking a question based on a mishna that seems to prove that we follow the current state of the hide, <b>as I teach it in the singular.</b> That mishna, on which I previously relied, is the opinion of one Sage and should not be relied upon. This proves that Rabbi Yoḥanan changed his mind and concluded that the status of parts of the animal is established based on their eventual condition. The opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan with regard to the Paschal lamb was stated before he changed his mind.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who breaks the bone of a Paschal lamb that is ritually pure receives forty lashes</b> for having violated a prohibition stated in the Torah. <b>But one who leaves over</b> part <b>of a ritually pure</b> Paschal lamb <b>and one who breaks</b> the bone <b>of a ritually impure</b> Paschal lamb <b>do not receive forty lashes.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara analyzes the mishna’s rulings: <b>Granted, one who leaves over</b> part <b>of a ritually pure</b> Paschal lamb is not flogged for having violated Torah law. There is good reason for this, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And you shall not leave any of it until morning; and that which remains of it until morning</b> you shall burn with fire” (Exodus 12:10). <b>The verse comes to provide a positive</b> mitzva to burn the leftover <b>after the prohibition</b> against leaving it over, <b>to say that one is not flogged</b> because any prohibition that can be rectified by the performance of a positive mitzva does not carry a punishment of lashes. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov says: This is not for</b> that <b>reason. Rather,</b> it is <b>because it is a prohibition that does not involve an action.</b> The transgression is simply the failure to consume all the meat during the allotted time rather than the performance of an action. <b>And one is not flogged for</b> any prohibition that does not involve an action<b>. But</b> with regard to <b>one who breaks</b> the bone <b>of a ritually impure</b> Paschal lamb, <b>from where do we</b> derive that he, too, does not receive lashes? The Gemara answers that the source is <b>as the verse states:</b> “In one house shall it be eaten; you shall not remove any of the meat from the house to the outside, <b>and you shall not break a bone in it”</b> (Exodus 12:46). It may be inferred that the prohibition applies <b>“in it,” in a valid</b> Paschal lamb, <b>and not in a disqualified</b> one.
<b>The Sages taught</b> with regard to that same topic: <b>“And you shall not break a bone in it”;</b> the prohibition applies <b>in it,</b> i.e., <b>in a valid</b> Paschal lamb <b>and not in a disqualified</b> one. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that this <i>halakha</i> should be learned in the following manner: It states: <b>“In one house shall it be eaten,”</b> and shortly thereafter the verse states: <b>“And you shall not break a bone in it,”</b> from which one can derive that <b>any</b> Paschal lamb <b>fit for eating is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone, and</b> any Paschal lamb <b>that is not fit for eating is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone</b>.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between them? Rabbi Yirmeya said: The practical difference between them is</b> with regard to <b>a Paschal lamb that is brought</b> when the majority of the nation is <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b> According <b>to the one who says</b> that the prohibition of breaking a bone applies only to <b>a valid</b> Paschal lamb,

Daf 84b

<b>this one is disqualified,</b> and the prohibition does not apply. However, <b>according to the one who says</b> that it depends on whether the offering is <b>fit for eating, this</b> offering that is brought in a state of ritual impurity <b>is also fit for eating,</b> and the prohibition of breaking a bone therefore applies.
<b>Rav Yosef said: In a case like this,</b> in which the Paschal lamb was brought in a state of ritual impurity, <b>everyone agrees that it is not subject to</b> the prohibition <b>of breaking a bone.</b> This is <b>because Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi only <b>came to be lenient, and this</b> offering <b>is disqualified</b> due to the fact that it is ritually impure, despite the fact that such an offering is accepted and therefore obligatory.
<b>Rather, the practical difference between them is</b> with regard to a Paschal lamb that <b>had a time when it was valid and</b> then <b>became disqualified. According to the one who says</b> that the verse should be understood as indicating that the prohibition of breaking a bone applies only to <b>a valid</b> Paschal lamb, <b>this one is valid</b> and the prohibition applies. <b>According to the one who says</b> that the prohibition applies only to an offering that is <b>fit for eating, it is not fit for eating now,</b> and therefore the prohibition does not apply.
<b>Abaye said: In any case like this, everyone agrees that it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone. What is the reason? Now, at least, it is disqualified. Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>breaking a bone while it is still day</b> on Passover eve <b>is the practical difference between them. According to the one who says</b> the verse should be understood as applying the prohibition to any Paschal lamb that is <b>valid, this one is valid</b> and the prohibition applies. <b>According to the one who says</b> the prohibition applies to a Paschal lamb that is <b>fit for eating, now it is not fit for eating</b> and therefore the prohibition does not yet apply.
<b>The Gemara raises an objection: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: One may register for</b> a Paschal lamb to eat <b>the marrow of the head, and one may not register for</b> the purpose of eating <b>the marrow of the thigh bone.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the reason</b> one may register for <b>the marrow of the head?</b> It is <b>since one can extract it</b> from inside the head <b>and remove it</b> without breaking any of the bones, which is not the case with regard to marrow from the thigh bone. <b>And if it should enter your mind</b> to say <b>that breaking a bone while it is still day seems well,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi should hold that <b>we may break the thigh bone as well and remove its marrow, and</b> it should be permitted to <b>register for it.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Abaye could have said to you: And according to your reasoning, after nightfall</b> there is <b>also</b> a permissible way to consume the marrow of the thigh bone: <b>We should bring a coal, and place it on</b> the bone, <b>and burn it, and remove its marrow, and</b> therefore it should be permissible to <b>register for it, for it was taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>But one who burns bones</b> of the Paschal lamb <b>and one who cuts sinews do not</b> transgress the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone.</b>
<b>Rather, what have you to say</b> in order to explain why one may not remove the marrow from the thigh bone by burning the bone? It must be due to a rabbinic prohibition. Why did the Sages enact this prohibition? <b>Abaye said:</b> It is <b>because</b> the heat might cause the bone to <b>burst</b> at a location other than where the coal is placed, which would be considered breaking rather than burning. <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>due to ruining sacrificial food, as one</b> who burns a hole in the bone <b>ruins it actively</b> because <b>it is possible that the fire will consume some of its marrow.</b> Similarly, breaking a bone <b>while it is still day is also</b> prohibited due to rabbinic <b>decree.</b> The Sages prohibited the breaking a bone while it still day <b>due to</b> the concern lest one do so <b>after dark.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> With regard to <b>any case like this, everyone agrees it is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone. What is the reason?</b> It is because <b>at night it will be fit for eating. Rather,</b> it is <b>with regard to a portion of a limb</b> that <b>has gone out</b> of its permissible boundary and thereby become disqualified that <b>they disagree.</b> In such an instance, one removes the disqualified part in order to be able to eat the rest, and the Sages disagree about whether one may cut the bone. According to <b>the one who said</b> that the verse limits the prohibition of breaking a bone to a Paschal lamb that is <b>valid, this one is valid,</b> and it is therefore prohibited to break a bone. <b>And</b> according to <b>the one who said</b> the prohibition applies to any Paschal lamb that is <b>fit for eating, this one is not fit for eating,</b> and it should therefore be permitted to break its bones.
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says:</b> If <b>a portion of a limb has gone out</b> of its permissible boundary <b>and one broke it,</b> one has not transgressed. <b>It is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone. This is</b> in accordance with the view that the prohibition of breaking bones applies only to a Paschal lamb that is fit for eating.
<b>Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> With regard to <b>any case like this, everyone agrees that it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone, as this limb is disqualified</b> and not merely unfit for eating. <b>Rather, breaking a bone</b> of a Paschal lamb <b>when</b> it is not yet fully roasted and still <b>raw is the practical difference between them.</b> According to <b>the one who said</b> the prohibition applies only to a Paschal lamb that is <b>valid, this one is valid,</b> and it is therefore prohibited to break a bone. <b>And</b> according to <b>the one who said</b> the prohibition applies to any Paschal lamb that is <b>fit for eating,</b> the prohibition does not apply to this offering because <b>now it is not fit for eating.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Any case like this is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone. What is the reason?</b> It is <b>because it is</b> still considered <b>fit for eating,</b> since one can <b>roast it and eat it. Rather, breaking</b> a bone in <b>the tail is the practical difference between them. According to the one who says</b> the prohibition applies to any Paschal lamb that is <b>valid, this one is valid</b> and the prohibition applies. <b>According to the one who says</b> the prohibition applies to any Paschal lamb that is <b>fit for eating, this is not fit for eating, as the tail</b> is consecrated <b>to God,</b> meaning that it is burned on the altar.
<b>Rav Ashi said: A case like this is certainly not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone, as</b> the tail <b>is certainly not fit for eating at all. Rather,</b> the case of <b>a limb upon which there is not an olive-bulk of meat is the practical difference between them. According to the one who says</b> the prohibition applies to any Paschal lamb that is <b>valid, this is valid,</b> and the prohibition applies. <b>According to the one who says</b> the prohibition applies to any Paschal lamb that is <b>fit for eating, we require the</b> minimal <b>measure of</b> meat that would constitute an act of <b>eating, and there is not</b> enough meat on this bone; therefore, the prohibition does not apply.
<b>Ravina said: Any case like this is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone, as we require the</b> minimal <b>measure</b> of meat that would constitute an act of <b>eating. Rather,</b> the case of <b>a limb upon which there is not an olive-bulk of meat in this place and there is an olive-bulk of meat in another place is the practical difference between them. According to the one who says</b> the prohibition applies to any Paschal lamb that is <b>valid, this one is valid,</b> and it is prohibited to break a bone. <b>According to the one who says</b> the prohibition applies to any Paschal lamb that is <b>fit for eating, we require the</b> minimal <b>measure</b> of meat that would constitute an act of <b>eating in the place of the break, and there is not</b> enough meat there. Therefore, the prohibition of breaking a bone does not apply.
The Gemara points out that <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with four of</b> the interpretations cited above. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The verse <b>“In one house shall it be eaten…and you shall not break a bone in it”</b> (Exodus 12:46) teaches that <b>one is liable for</b> breaking the bone of <b>a valid</b> Paschal lamb, <b>and one is not liable for</b> breaking the bone of a <b>disqualified</b> Paschal lamb.
If <b>it had a time in which it was valid and it became disqualified at the time of eating, it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone.</b> This supports the opinion of Rav Yosef.
If <b>it has the</b> minimal <b>measure</b> of meat that would constitute an act of <b>eating, it is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone; if it does not have the</b> minimal <b>measure</b> of meat necessary to constitute an act of <b>eating, it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone.</b> This supports the opinion of both Rav Ashi and Ravina.
<b>That which is fit for the altar,</b> such as the tail, <b>is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone.</b> This supports the opinion of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak.
<b>At the time of eating, it is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone; when it is not the time for eating, it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone.</b> This supports the opinion of Abaye.
<b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> argued about the following matter: In the case of <b>a limb upon which there is not an olive-bulk of meat in this place</b> in which one breaks the bone, <b>and there is an olive-bulk of meat in a different place,</b> has one violated the prohibition of breaking a bone? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: It is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And you shall not break a bone in it,”</b> which indicates that the prohibition applies to <b>both a bone upon which there is an olive-bulk of meat and a bone upon which there is not an olive-bulk of meat. What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>Upon which there is not an olive-bulk of meat? If we say that it does not have an olive-bulk of meat on it at all,</b> it is not fit for eating at all. <b>Why,</b> then, <b>is it subject to</b> the prohibition against <b>breaking a bone? Rather, is it not</b> true that <b>this is what it is saying:</b> The prohibition applies <b>both</b> to <b>a bone upon which there is an olive-bulk of meat in this place, and</b> to a bone <b>upon which there is not an olive-bulk of meat in this place and there is an olive-bulk of meat in a different place?</b> This poses <b>a difficulty to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish.</b>
<b>He said to him:</b>

Daf 85a

<b>No,</b> that is not what it means to say. Rather, <b>this is what it is saying:</b> It is prohibited to break <b>both a bone upon which there is an olive-bulk of meat on the outside and a bone upon which there is not an olive-bulk of meat on the outside,</b> but <b>there is an olive-bulk of meat,</b> i.e., bone marrow, <b>on</b> the <b>inside at the place of the break.</b>
<b>And</b> as a proof, the Gemara cites that which <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And you shall not break a bone in it”</b> (Exodus 12:46). This prohibition includes <b>both a bone in which there is marrow and a bone in which there is no marrow. How do I establish</b> the positive mitzva expressed in the verse: <b>“And they shall eat the meat on that night”</b> (Exodus 12:8)? It is to be fulfilled exclusively <b>with meat that is on the bone.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it</b> means <b>only</b> that the positive mitzva also applies <b>to the</b> marrow <b>meat that is inside the bone. And</b> if so, <b>how do I establish</b> the prohibition: <b>And you shall not break a bone in it?</b> It is referring specifically <b>to a bone that does not have marrow. However,</b> in the case of <b>a bone that does have marrow, one may break and eat</b> the marrow. <b>And do not be surprised</b> that one may violate the prohibition of breaking a bone in order to eat the marrow, <b>as</b> it is possible to say that <b>the positive</b> mitzva to eat the meat <b>comes and overrides the prohibition</b> prohibiting one to break a bone, in accordance with the general principle that positive mitzvot override negative mitzvot.
<b>When it says:</b> “They shall leave none of it until the morning, <b>nor break a bone in it”</b> (Numbers 9:12), <b>with regard to the</b> Paschal lamb of the <b>second <i>Pesaḥ</i>,</b> for <b>which there is no need for the verse to state</b> this prohibition, <b>as it is already stated “according to all the statute of the Paschal lamb they shall keep it,”</b> which includes the prohibition to break a bone, <b>you must say</b> that it is repeated in order to emphasize the prohibition and indicate that it applies to <b>both a bone in which there is marrow and a bone in which there is no marrow.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the view of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: If <b>a portion of a limb has gone out</b> of its permissible boundary, <b>one</b> must <b>cut</b> through the meat <b>until one reaches the bone, and</b> then <b>peel</b> the meat that did not go out of the boundary away from the bone <b>until one reaches the joint, and cut</b> off the limb. One then eats the meat that has been detached from the bone and discards the bone and the portion of the limb that went out of the appropriate location.
<b>And if you say that a limb upon which there is not an olive-bulk of meat in this place but there is</b> an olive-bulk of meat <b>in a different place is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone, why do I need</b> the <i>halakha</i> requiring one to <b>peel</b> the meat <b>until he reaches the joint and</b> then <b>cut</b> off the bone? <b>Let him peel a little bit</b> from the section of bone that adjoins the portion that went out of the boundary <b>and break</b> the bone once there is no meat at the location of the break.
<b>Abaye said:</b> One may not do this, <b>due to</b> a concern that the entire bone will <b>crack,</b> including a part of the bone that has meat on it. <b>Ravina said:</b> This ruling was stated with regard to <b>a thigh bone,</b> which has a large amount of marrow in it. It cannot be broken even if one peels away the meat from the location of the break.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there,</b> at the end of the tractate: <b><i>Piggul</i> and leftover</b> sacrificial meat <b>render hands impure</b> due to rabbinic edict, although they are not ritually impure by Torah law. <b>Rav Huna and Rav Ḥisda</b> disagreed with regard to the reason for this. <b>One said:</b> The reason is <b>due to priests,</b> who were <b>suspected</b> of purposely disqualifying the offerings of people they disliked via improper intentions. The Sages decreed that the disqualified offerings immediately render the hands of the priest impure as a penalty. <b>And one said:</b> The reason is <b>due to lazy priests.</b> The decree is meant to stop them from allowing offerings to go uneaten.
The Gemara explains that they do not really argue: One <b>Sage teaches</b> his reason <b>with regard to <i>piggul</i>, and</b> the other <b>Sage teaches</b> his reason <b>with regard to leftover</b> sacrificial meat. <b>The one who teaches</b> the reason <b>with regard to <i>piggul</i></b> says: The decree is <b>due to priests suspected</b> of purposely disqualifying offerings via improper intentions, as an offering only becomes <i>piggul</i> through intent. <b>And the one who teaches</b> the reason <b>with regard to leftover</b> sacrificial meat says: It is <b>due to lazy priests</b> who would not eat the meat.
One <b>Sage teaches</b> that this ritual impurity applies to meat in the amount of <b>an olive-bulk, and</b> the other <b>Sage teaches</b> that the minimum amount of meat necessary for the decree to apply is <b>an egg-bulk.</b> The Gemara explains: The reason for <b>the one who teaches</b> that the minimum amount of meat necessary for the decree to apply is <b>an olive-bulk</b> is that the decree is <b>like its prohibition;</b> one violates the prohibition to eat <i>piggul</i> or leftover sacrificial meat only when one eats an olive-bulk. <b>And the one who teaches</b> that the decree applies only when there is <b>an egg-bulk</b> of meat reasons that it is <b>like its ritual impurity;</b> by Torah law, only an egg-bulk of food can impart ritual impurity.
<b>A dilemma was raised before the</b> Sages: With regard to sacrificial meat <b>that has gone out</b> of its permitted boundaries, did <b>the Sages decree</b> that it attains <b>ritual impurity or not? Do we say that</b> a decree had to be made with regard to <b>leftover</b> sacrificial meat, <b>as</b> the priests <b>would come to be lazy about it</b> and not eat it; <b>but</b> with regard to sacrificial meat that has <b>gone out</b> there is no reason for concern, because priests would not <b>actively take it out</b> of its boundaries and thereby disqualify it, and therefore <b>the Sages did not decree that it</b> be considered ritually impure? <b>Or perhaps it is no different,</b> as the Sages decreed that all disqualified sacrificial meat be considered ritually impure, so that the people handling it would do so with greater care.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution to this dilemma based on the following mishna: If <b>a portion of a limb has gone out</b> of its permissible boundary, <b>one must cut</b> through the meat <b>until one reaches the bone, and</b> then <b>peel</b> the meat away from the bone <b>until one reaches the joint, and cut</b> off the limb. <b>And if you say the Sages decreed ritual impurity</b> on sacrificial meat that has gone out of its boundary, <b>when one cuts it, what has</b> been accomplished? The portion that has gone out <b>renders impure</b> the rest of the sacrificial meat through contact.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> a case of <b>ritual impurity</b> in <b>a concealed</b> place, as the part that has gone out would impart ritual impurity to the portion that has not gone out due to the contact they make underneath the skin, which is concealed from view; and the principle is that <b>ritual impurity</b> in <b>a concealed</b> place <b>does not render</b> other objects <b>impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Ravina, who said</b> that <b>connections</b> between two pieces <b>of food are not</b> considered true <b>connections and are comparable to</b> foods that are <b>separate,</b> and therefore it cannot be considered ritual impurity in a concealed place, <b>what is there to say? They touch each other, and</b> one <b>imparts ritual impurity</b> to the other. The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> according to his opinion, this must be explained differently: <b>According to the one who teaches</b> that the decree applies only when there is <b>an olive-bulk</b> of meat, the mishna may be addressing a case in which <b>it does not have an olive-bulk</b> of meat. And according to <b>the one who teaches</b> that the decree applies only when there is <b>an egg-bulk</b> of meat, the mishna may be addressing a case in which <b>it does not have an egg-bulk</b> of meat.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different proof from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one removes the meat of a Paschal lamb from</b> the location of one <b>group to</b> the location of another <b>group, although he</b> violates <b>a prohibition,</b> as the Torah prohibits removing the Paschal lamb from the location of the group that registered for it, the Paschal lamb remains <b>pure.</b> The Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>What, is it not</b> that the meat remains <b>pure, and</b> yet it is <b>prohibited</b> to eat it, because a Paschal lamb that <b>goes out from</b> the location of one <b>group to</b> that of another <b>group is comparable to</b> any offering that <b>goes out of its boundary, and it is disqualified? And even so, it is teaching</b> that the meat remains <b>pure. Apparently,</b> based on this it seems that <b>the Sages did not decree ritual impurity</b> on meat that goes out of the location of its group.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should be understood as teaching that the meat is <b>pure and permitted</b> to be eaten because meat that <b>goes from</b> the location of one <b>group to</b> the location of another <b>group is not comparable to</b> sacrificial meat that <b>goes out of its boundary, and it is not disqualified.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach</b> that <b>one who eats</b> the meat of a Paschal lamb that was removed from the location of its group <b>is in</b> violation of <b>a prohibition? Granted, according to the one who said</b> that the Sages decreed ritual impurity on offerings only when there is at least <b>an egg-bulk,</b> the case in this <i>baraita</i> may be one in which <b>there is an olive-bulk,</b> which is the minimal measure one must eat to violate the prohibition, <b>and there is not an egg-bulk,</b> which is the minimal measure necessary for the rabbinic decree of ritual impurity to take effect. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that the Sages decreed ritual impurity even on <b>an olive-bulk, what is there to say?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the previous answers may be withdrawn in favor of the following: <b>With regard to</b> meat that <b>goes out</b> of its location that is <b>from the Paschal lamb,</b> it is <b>not necessary for us</b> to say that <b>the Sages did not decree ritual impurity</b> on it, because it is obvious. <b>What is the reason</b> the Sages did not decree it to be ritually impure? It is because <b>the members of the group are zealous and are</b> very <b>careful</b> to ensure that the meat remains in its proper location, making it unnecessary to penalize those who allow the meat to leave the location of its group. <b>Rather, when</b> this question <b>was asked,</b> it was <b>with regard to</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> meat <b>that has gone out</b> of its boundary. <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara does not have an answer to this question and concludes: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara questions the source of a <i>halakha</i> mentioned above: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>one who carries out meat</b> from the <b>Paschal lamb</b>

Daf 85b

<b>from</b> the location of its <b>group to</b> the location of another <b>group, from where</b> is it derived that he has violated a prohibition? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “In one house shall it be eaten; <b>you shall not carry out any of the meat from the house to the outside”</b> (Exodus 12:46), <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that it is prohibited to remove meat <b>from house to house; from where</b> do I derive that it is prohibited even to transfer the meat <b>from group to group</b> within one house? <b>The verse states: To the outside,</b> which includes any case in which one brings the meat <b>outside of</b> the place where <b>it may be eaten.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ami said: One who carries out the meat of the Paschal lamb from</b> the location of one <b>group to</b> another <b>group is not liable until he places</b> the meat in the location of the second group. The reason for this is that the term <b>carrying out is written about it,</b> as the Torah says: “You shall not carry out,” which is similar to the prohibited labor of the same name <b>pertaining to Shabbat.</b> Therefore, <b>just as</b> when it comes to <b>Shabbat one is not liable</b> for carrying from one domain to another <b>until he performs</b> an act of <b>lifting</b> from one domain <b>and placing</b> in the other domain, <b>so too, here also</b> one is not liable <b>until he performs</b> an act of <b>lifting</b> the meat from the location of one group <b>and placing</b> it in the location of another group.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Mammal raised an objection</b> based upon the <i>halakha</i> that those who remove the inner sin-offerings from the Temple become ritually impure. A <i>baraita</i> with regard to that <i>halakha</i> teaches as follows: If those carrying the inner sin-offerings <b>were carrying them on poles,</b> and <b>those in front</b> already <b>went outside the wall</b> around the Temple courtyard, <b>and those in the rear had not</b> yet <b>gone out, the ones in front</b> nonetheless immediately cause <b>their garments</b> to become <b>ritually impure, and the ones in the rear do not</b> cause <b>their garments</b> to become <b>ritually impure</b> until they also leave. This proves that the people carrying these offerings become impure immediately. <b>But</b> the meat <b>has not</b> yet <b>been placed</b> outside the courtyard, so why should it already be considered to have been taken out?
<b>He raised the objection and he resolved it:</b> The <i>baraita</i> addresses a case in which the people are <b>dragging</b> the offerings, and therefore as soon as they leave the courtyard the offerings are considered to have been placed on the ground.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a portion of a limb has gone out</b> of its permissible boundary, <b>one must cut</b> the meat <b>until one reaches the bone</b> at the point that separates between the part of the limb that went out of its boundary and the part that did not, <b>and</b> then <b>peel</b> the meat away from the bone <b>until one reaches the joint, and cut</b> off the limb at the joint, as it is prohibited to break the bone itself. <b>And with regard to</b> other <b>offerings, one may chop</b> off the part that exited <b>with a hatchet, as it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone.</b>
How does one determine the outer boundaries of a particular location? Anything that is located <b>from the</b> inside of the <b>doorway inward is</b> considered <b>as though</b> it is <b>inside,</b> and anything that is located <b>from the doorway outward is</b> considered <b>as though</b> it is <b>outside. And the windows</b> in the wall <b>and the thickness of the wall are</b> considered <b>as though</b> they are <b>inside,</b> such that an offering is considered to have exited the premises only if it is taken outside the wall.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: And</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>similar with regard to prayer,</b> in that one who is standing outside the doorway cannot be included together with those praying inside. The Gemara notes that Rav <b>disagrees with Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Even a barrier of iron does not separate between the Jewish people and their Father in Heaven.</b> Barriers are irrelevant with regard to prayer.
The Gemara questions the mishna: <b>This matter itself is difficult;</b> the mishna itself contains an internal contradiction. At first <b>you said</b> that the space <b>from the doorway inward is considered as though</b> it is <b>inside, which</b> indicates that the space of the <b>doorway itself is like the outside.</b> Now you <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna’s ruling, which states that <b>from the doorway outward is considered as though</b> it is <b>outside, which</b> indicates that the <b>doorway itself is considered as though</b> it is <b>inside.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It is not difficult,</b> as one can explain that these two statements are referring to different situations: <b>Here,</b> in the latter clause of the mishna’s ruling, it is referring <b>to the gates of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard,</b> where the inside of the doorways were considered as though they were inside the courtyard and had the sanctity of the courtyard itself. <b>There,</b> in the first clause, it is discussing <b>the gates of Jerusalem,</b> where the insides of the gates were considered like the outside and did not have the sanctity of Jerusalem.
<b>As Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said: For what</b> reason were the insides of the <b>gates of Jerusalem not sanctified? Because lepers protect themselves</b> by sitting <b>under them; in the sun</b> they protect themselves <b>from the sun and in the rain</b> they sit in the gateway to protect themselves <b>from the rain.</b> Lepers are not permitted to enter Jerusalem.
