<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: By Torah law, there is not even a positive mitzva</b> that restricts one who has immersed that day and will become pure only upon nightfall from entering the Temple, <b>as it is stated: “And Jehoshaphat stood in the congregation of Judea and Jerusalem, in the House of the Lord, before the new courtyard”</b> (II Chronicles 20:5). <b>What</b> is indicated by identifying the courtyards as <b>the new courtyard?</b> It indicates <b>that they innovated something in it, and they said: One who has immersed on that day</b> but will become pure only upon nightfall <b>may not enter the Levite camp,</b> which includes the entire Temple Mount. This suggests that the prohibition is of rabbinic origin and is not a positive mitzva.
The case of a <b><i>beit haperas</i>,</b> in which the Sages did not uphold their decree, is <b>as it was taught</b> in a mishna: <b>And Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel agree</b>

Daf 92b

<b>that we examine</b> a <i>beit haperas</i> that lies in the path to Jerusalem <b>for those offering the Paschal lamb</b> to determine whether there is actually any ritual impurity present, in order to enable those who pass through it to know whether they are still ritually pure and able to offer the Paschal lamb. But <b>we do not examine</b> a <i>beit haperas</i> <b>for</b> the sake of <b>those eating <i>teruma</i></b> in order that they should be able to eat <i>teruma</i> in purity. The Gemara asks:
<b>What is</b> meant when we say that <b>we examine for those offering the Paschal lamb?</b> Practically, how is it examined? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One must blow</b> the dust on the path before taking each step in <b>the <i>beit haperas</i> as he walks</b> through it, in order to see if there is a hidden bone there. <b>Rav Yehuda bar Abaye in the name of Rav Yehuda said: A <i>beit haperas</i> that has been trodden</b> underfoot is considered <b>ritually pure,</b> since it is assumed that any bones that were there have been removed or broken. The impurity of a <i>beit haperas</i> is due to a rabbinic decree. The Sages waived this decree in a case where the necessary examination is made, in order to allow people to be able to offer their Paschal lambs. However, this leniency is limited to the case of the Paschal lamb, since its neglect carries the prohibition of <i>karet</i>. It is not extended to other cases, such as the prohibition to eat impure <i>teruma</i>.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who was</b> ritually <b>impure or on a distant journey and did not observe</b> the <b>first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> by participating in the offering of the Paschal lamb on the fourteenth of Nisan <b>should observe the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> by participating in the offering on the fourteenth of Iyyar. If one <b>unwittingly</b> forgot <b>or</b> was <b>prevented</b> due to circumstances <b>beyond his control and did not observe the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>he</b> too <b>should observe the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>. <b>If so,</b> that the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> is observed even by someone who forgot or was prevented from observing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>why is it stated</b> in the Torah that the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> is observed only by one who was ritually <b>impure or on a distant journey?</b> These cases were specified in order to teach <b>that these</b> two groups of people <b>are exempt from <i>karet</i></b> if they do not observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>but those</b> who were not ritually impure or on a distant journey <b>are liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>,</b> as the Gemara will explain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed about the following issue: If <b>one was on a distant journey and</b> others <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and sprinkled</b> its blood <b>on his</b> behalf, and he arrived in time to eat the Paschal lamb, does he need to observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> since he was far away at the time that the sacrifice was offered? <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> His offering <b>was accepted,</b> and he need not observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> His offering <b>was not accepted,</b> and he must sacrifice the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. The Gemara explains their opinions. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> His offering <b>was accepted</b> because <b>the Torah has mercy on</b> one who was on a distant journey and allows him the option of observing the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>; but <b>if he</b> nonetheless <b>did</b> participate in the sacrifice of the Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, may <b>blessing come upon him. And Rav Sheshet said:</b> His offering <b>is not accepted</b> because <b>the Torah deferred his</b> observance to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> just <b>as</b> it does for <b>one who is ritually impure.</b> Just as one who is ritually impure may not voluntarily participate in the Paschal lamb, neither may one who is on a distant journey.
<b>Rav Naḥman said: From where do I say</b> my opinion? <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One who was ritually impure or on a distant journey and did not observe</b> the <b>first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>should observe the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>. The expression: And did not observe, indicates <b>by inference that</b> regarding one who was on a distant journey, <b>had he wished, he</b> could have <b>observed</b> it and would thereby be exempt from participating in the sacrifice of the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<b>And Rav Sheshet said</b> in response: <b>If so,</b> consider <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches:</b> If one <b>unwittingly</b> forgot <b>or</b> was <b>prevented</b> due to circumstances <b>beyond his control and did not observe the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>he should observe the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>. According to your reasoning, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it is taught: And did not observe,</b> conclude <b>by inference that had he wished, he</b> could have <b>observed</b> it. However, this is not possible, <b>as</b> the mishna states explicitly that <b>he unwittingly</b> forgot <b>or</b> was <b>prevented</b> due to circumstances <b>beyond his control</b> and was unable to observe the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna must be explained differently, as follows: Even though it does not say so explicitly, the mishna <b>is teaching</b> with the phrase: And he did not observe, the case of one who <b>intentionally</b> refrained from observing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> together <b>with</b> the other cases in the mishna. <b>Here, too,</b> in the first part of the mishna, the phrase: And he did not observe, must be understood as including another category of people: It <b>is teaching</b> the case of <b>an acute mourner,</b> i.e., one whose relative died that same day and has not yet been buried, together <b>with the</b> other cases. The first part of the mishna includes three cases: One who was ritually impure, one who was on distant journey, and one who was an acute mourner. Therefore, it cannot be inferred that had he wished to observe the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, he could have done so.
<b>Rav Ashi said: The mishna is also precisely</b> formulated according to this interpretation, <b>as it teaches: These are exempt from <i>karet</i>, but those are liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>. To which</b> part of the mishna is this referring? <b>If we say</b> that this statement is referring <b>to one who unwittingly</b> forgot <b>and one who</b> was <b>prevented</b> due to circumstances <b>beyond his control, are one who unwittingly</b> forgot <b>and one</b> who was <b>prevented</b> due to circumstances <b>beyond his control subject to</b> the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>?</b> One is liable to receive <i>karet</i> only for performing a transgression intentionally. <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to the case of one who <b>intentionally</b> refrained from observing the <i>Pesaḥ</i>, which is included in the phrase in the latter clause: And he did not observe, <b>and to</b> the case of <b>an acute mourner,</b> which is included in the parallel phrase in the first clause? These two categories of people are liable to receive <i>karet</i> if they fail to sacrifice the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<b>And Rav Naḥman</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in response: <b>Actually,</b> the mishna refers <b>only to</b> the case of one who <b>intentionally</b> refrains from observing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> and not to the case of an acute mourner; <b>and by right it</b> should have <b>taught</b> this ruling with the expression: <b>He is liable,</b> in the singular. <b>And</b> the reason <b>that it teaches</b> this ruling with the phrase: These <b>are liable,</b> in the plural, is that <b>since the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>teaches</b> its ruling with the expression: These <b>are exempt,</b> in the plural, <b>the latter clause</b> also <b>teaches</b> its ruling with the expression: Those <b>are liable,</b> in the plural. Therefore, the phrase in the first clause: And did not observe the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, teaches that one on a journey has the option of observing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> if he wishes. And the same phrase in the latter clause: And did not observe, comes to include the case of one who intentionally refrains from observing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<b>Rav Sheshet said: From where do I say</b> my opinion? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says: It is stated that</b> one who is <b>ritually impure</b> on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> observes the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>and it is stated</b> that one who is on a <b>distant journey</b> observes the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>;

Daf 93a

<b>just as</b> the case of one who was <b>ritually impure</b> is referring to <b>one who has the means to observe</b> the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> via an agent but <b>does not do</b> so because the Torah prohibited him from doing so, <b>so too,</b> the case of one who was on a <b>distant journey also</b> refers to one <b>who has the means to observe</b> the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> via an agent and eat the offering at night, but <b>does not do</b> so because the Torah prohibited him from doing so.
<b>And Rav Naḥman</b> could have <b>said to you: Rabbi Akiva</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he holds that one</b> may <b>not slaughter</b> a Paschal lamb <b>and sprinkle</b> its blood <b>on</b> behalf of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> due to contact with <b>a</b> dead <b>creeping animal,</b> even though he could immerse and become ritually pure in time to partake of the Paschal lamb in the evening. This indicates that according to Rabbi Akiva, one who is unfit when the blood is sprinkled is completely disqualified from participating in the offering. <b>But I hold in accordance with the one who said:</b> One may <b>slaughter</b> a Paschal lamb <b>and sprinkle</b> its blood <b>on</b> behalf of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> due to contact with a dead <b>creeping animal,</b> and therefore Rabbi Akiva’s ruling is not relevant to my opinion.
The Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> in support of Rav Naḥman’s opinion. <b>The Sages taught</b> that <b>these</b> are the people <b>who observe the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>: <b><i>Zavim</i> and <i>zavot</i>;</b> male <b>lepers and</b> female <b>lepers; and menstruating women and those</b> men <b>who had sexual relations with menstruating women; and women after childbirth; those who</b> failed to observe the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>unwittingly, and those who</b> were <b>prevented</b> due to circumstances <b>beyond their control, and those who intentionally</b> refrained from doing so; <b>and one who was ritually impure; and one who was on a distant journey.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If so,</b> if one who missed the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> for any reason observes the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>why</b> is the case of one who was <b>ritually impure stated</b> explicitly in the Torah? The Gemara expresses surprise at this question: <b>Why is it stated?</b> It was necessary to mention this case to teach <b>that if</b> an impure person <b>wishes to perform</b> the sacrifice of the Paschal lamb <b>on the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>we do not allow him</b> to do so. <b>Rather,</b> the question should be: <b>Why</b> is the case of <b>one</b> who is <b>on a distant journey stated</b> in the Torah? It is stated <b>to exempt him from <i>karet</i></b> even if he does not observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. <b>And</b> this is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that if the Paschal lamb was slaughtered on behalf of one who was on a distant journey <b>it was accepted,</b> which is the opinion of Rav Naḥman.
The <i>baraita</i> mentioned several types of ritually impure women who observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> rather than the first. The Gemara asks: <b>Is a woman obligated</b> to observe <b>the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>? <b>Wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>only one</b> who is <b>impure</b> due to ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse or one who was on a distant journey observe the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>; with regard to <b><i>zavim</i>,</b> male <b>lepers, and those</b> men <b>who had sexual relations with menstruating women, from where</b> is it derived that they may observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>? <b>The verse states:</b> “If <b>any man [<i>ish ish</i>]</b> of you or of your generations shall be ritually impure due to a dead body or is on a journey far away, he shall still offer the Paschal lamb to the Lord” (Numbers 9:10). The word <i>ish</i> is doubled in order to include these other cases. Women are not included by the repetition of the word <i>ish</i>.
The Gemara answers that this is <b>not difficult: This</b> first <i>baraita</i>, which includes women, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> that one may slaughter the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> for women, and <b>that</b> second <i>baraita</i>, which includes only men, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon,</b> who hold that women do not have a full-fledged obligation to observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: One <b>is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> intentionally refraining from observing <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>; similarly, one who could not observe the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i></b> if he intentionally refrained from observing <b>the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Natan says: One is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> intentionally refraining from observing <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>; <b>and one is exempt</b> from <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> intentionally refraining from observing <b>the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> even if he unwittingly failed to observe the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, as the Torah does not specify a punishment of <i>karet</i> with regard to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya says: Even for</b> intentionally failing to observe <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>one is liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> only if he</b> intentionally <b>fails to observe the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
The Gemara adds that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Natan <b>follow their</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> as demonstrated by another dispute between them, which is related to the dispute quoted above. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A convert who converted</b> during the month <b>between the</b> offering of the <b>two Paschal lambs</b> on the first and second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>and similarly, a minor who grew up</b> and became obligated in mitzvot during the month <b>between the</b> offering of the <b>two Paschal lambs, is obligated to observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Natan says: Whoever needs</b> to observe <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>needs</b> to observe <b>the second; whoever does not need</b> to observe <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>, e.g., one who is a minor or is not yet Jewish, <b>does not need</b> to observe <b>the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> either.
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>is its own Festival,</b> and anyone who did not participate in the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> is obligated to participate in the second even if he was not fit to bring the Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
Conversely, <b>Rabbi Natan holds</b> that <b>the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>is</b> merely <b>a redress for the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>, such that if one was obligated to bring the Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> and did not, he may do so on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>; however, <b>it does not repair the</b> failure to bring the Paschal lamb on <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>. Therefore, one who intentionally refrained from bringing the Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> is liable to receive <i>karet</i> even if he brought the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. However, if one unwittingly failed to sacrifice the Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, he is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> even if he intentionally refrained from observing the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<b>And Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya held: The second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>repairs the</b> failure to offer the Paschal lamb on the <b>first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>. In other words, the Paschal lamb brought on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> is not an independent obligation; rather, it allows a second chance to avoid the liability to receive <i>karet</i>.
<b>And</b> all <b>three of them expounded the same verse</b> to derive their opinions: <b>“But the man who is ritually pure, and is not on a journey,</b> and refrains from offering the Paschal lamb, that soul shall be cut off from his people; because [<i>ki</i>] he did not bring the offering of the Lord in its appointed season, that man shall bear his sin” (Numbers 9:13). <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that the verse should be understood as follows: The phrase: <b>“And refrains from offering the Paschal lamb,</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off,”</b> means <b>that he did not participate</b> in the offering on <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>. In the continuation of the verse, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi understands the word <i>ki</i> to mean: If, as the word <i>ki</i> has various meanings, one of which is: If. Therefore, the verse can be interpreted in the following manner: <b>If he also “did not bring the offering of the Lord in its appointed season,”</b> with regard to <b>the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>, “that man shall bear his sin.”
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where</b> do we know <b>that this</b> phrase: <b>Shall bear his sin,</b> refers to <b><i>karet</i></b> and not to some other punishment?

Daf 93b

<b>He holds</b> that with regard to the case of the <b>blasphemer</b> mentioned in the verse: “That person blasphemes the Lord and that soul shall be cut off [<i>karet</i>] from among his people” (Numbers 15:30), <b>this is</b> identical to the case of <b>one who blesses the name</b> of God, a euphemism for cursing God’s name. <b>And it is written with regard to one who blesses the name</b> of God: “Whoever curses his God <b>shall bear his sin”</b> (Leviticus 24:15). Therefore, the punishment of <i>karet</i> applies to a sin about which the Torah states: Shall bear his sin.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>learned</b> the meaning of <b>this</b> phrase: “And he shall bear <b>his sin,”</b> stated <b>here,</b> with regard to one who did not sacrifice the Paschal lamb, by way of a verbal analogy <b>from</b> the phrase: “Shall bear <b>his sin”</b> stated <b>there,</b> with regard to the blasphemer. <b>Just as later,</b> with regard to the blasphemer, it is referring to the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>, so too here,</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb, it is referring to the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>.</b> This concludes the Gemara’s explanation of the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>And Rabbi Natan holds</b> that the verse should be understood differently. In the verse: <b>“And refrains from offering the Paschal lamb,</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off</b> from his people; because [<i>ki</i>] he did not bring the offering of the Lord in its appointed season” (Numbers 9:13), <b>this</b> word <b><i>ki</i></b> has the <b>meaning of: Because. And this is</b> what <b>the Torah is saying: “Because he did not bring the offering of the Lord in its appointed season,”</b> referring to participating in the Paschal lamb on <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>, he is liable to receive <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>that</b> part of the verse which says: <b>He shall bear his sin, what does</b> Rabbi Natan <b>do with it?</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Natan <b>holds</b> that <b>the</b> case of the <b>blasphemer is not</b> identical with the case of one who <b>blesses the name</b> of God; blasphemy refers instead to one who sings praises to false gods. Thus, the Torah does not specify the punishment of one who curses God. <b>He learned</b> the meaning of <b>that</b> phrase <b>“his sin,” there,</b> with regard to one who curses God, by way of a verbal analogy <b>from this</b> phrase <b>“his sin” here,</b> in the case of one who did not offer the Paschal lamb. <b>Just as here,</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb, the punishment is <b><i>karet</i>, so too there,</b> with regard to one who curses God, the phrase: He shall bear his sin, is a reference to the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya holds</b> that the word <i>ki</i> in the verse should be rendered: If, as Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi interpreted it, but the verse should be understood as follows: <b>“And refrained from participating</b> in the offering of <b>the Paschal lamb,</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off</b> from his people <b>if he did not bring the offering of the Lord in its appointed season,”</b> which is <b>on the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>that</b> phrase: <b>“He shall bear his sin,” what does</b> Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya <b>do with it?</b> The Gemara answers: He uses it in the same way as Rabbi Natan, <b>as we said</b> above, to derive the punishment for one who curses God.
<b>Therefore,</b> if one <b>intentionally</b> refrained from offering the Paschal lamb <b>on both</b> the first and second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>all agree</b> that he is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>. If one <b>unwittingly</b> forgot <b>on both</b> the first and second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>all agree</b> that he is <b>exempt</b> from <i>karet</i>.
If one <b>intentionally</b> refrained from offering the Paschal lamb <b>on the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>and unwittingly</b> forgot <b>on the second,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabbi Natan he</b> is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>, because he intentionally refrained from offering the sacrifice on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> and did not rectify his mistake on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>; however, according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> because he holds that one is liable only if he intentionally refrained both times from offering the Paschal lamb.
If one <b>unwittingly</b> forgot <b>on the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>and intentionally</b> refrained from bringing the offering <b>on the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>, according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>he is liable,</b> because Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi considers the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> an independent Festival that is mandatory for all those who did not offer the Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>. According <b>to</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya,</b> who hold that the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> is a chance to redress the sin of the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, since he did not intentionally fail to offer the Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, he is <b>exempt</b> from the punishment of <i>karet</i> even if he intentionally failed to offer the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>What is the</b> definition of <b>a distant journey</b> that exempts one from observing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>? Anywhere <b>from the</b> city of <b>Modi’im and beyond, and</b> from anywhere located an equal <b>distance</b> from Jerusalem and beyond <b>in every direction;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Eliezer says: From the threshold of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard and beyond</b> is considered a distant journey; therefore, anyone located outside the courtyard at the time that the Paschal lamb is slaughtered is exempt from observing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>. <b>Rabbi Yosei said to him: Therefore,</b> the word is <b>dotted over the</b> letter <b><i>heh</i></b> in the word “distant [<i>reḥoka</i>]” <b>to say</b> that the meaning of the word should be qualified: It should be understood that <b>it is not because he is really distant; rather,</b> it includes anyone located <b>from the threshold of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard and beyond.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Ulla said:</b> The distance <b>from the</b> city of <b>Modi’im to Jerusalem is fifteen <i>mil</i>. He held like this</b> following opinion <b>that Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: How</b> far <b>can an</b> average <b>person walk on an</b> average <b>day?</b> One can walk <b>ten parasangs [<i>parsaot</i>],</b> which are forty <i>mil</i>. This is divided in the following way: <b>From dawn until sunrise</b> one can walk a distance of <b>five <i>mil</i>,</b> and <b>from sunset until the emergence of the stars</b> one can walk another <b>five <i>mil</i>.</b> There are <b>thirty</b> <i>mil</i> <b>remaining</b> that one can walk in a day: <b>Fifteen from the morning until midday, and fifteen from midday until evening.</b>
The Gemara explains that <b>Ulla</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning</b> below, <b>as Ulla said: What is</b> the definition of <b>a distant journey?</b> It is <b>any</b> distance from which <b>one is unable to</b> reach Jerusalem and <b>enter</b> the Temple <b>by the</b> earliest <b>time of the slaughter</b> of the Paschal lamb. The obligation to slaughter the Paschal lamb begins at noon; therefore, if one is a distance of fifteen <i>mil</i> from the Temple in the morning, he will not be able to arrive there before the time that the offering may be slaughtered.
The Gemara addresses the previously mentioned discussion: <b>The Master said</b> that <b>from dawn until sunrise</b> one can walk a distance of <b>five <i>mil</i>. From where do we</b> derive this? <b>As it is written: “And when the morning arose, the angels hastened Lot,</b> saying: Arise, take your wife and your two daughters that are here, lest you be swept away in the iniquity of the city” (Genesis 19:15), <b>and it is written: “The sun was risen upon the earth when Lot came to Zoar”</b> (Genesis 19:23). Therefore, the distance between Sodom and Zoar is the distance one can walk between dawn and sunrise, <b>and Rabbi Ḥanina said: I myself saw that place, and it is</b> a distance of <b>five <i>mil</i>.</b> This serves as a biblical proof that one can walk five <i>mil</i> between dawn and sunrise.
The Gemara discusses <b>the matter</b> of the above statement <b>itself. Ulla said: What is</b> the definition of <b>a distant journey; any</b> journey of a distance from which <b>one is unable to</b> reach Jerusalem and <b>enter</b> the Temple <b>by the</b> earliest <b>time of the slaughter</b> of the Paschal lamb. <b>And Rav Yehuda said: Any</b> journey of a distance from which <b>one is unable to</b> reach Jerusalem, where the Paschal lamb is eaten, and <b>enter during the time of the eating,</b> the following night.
<b>Rabba said to Ulla:</b> According <b>to your</b> opinion it is <b>difficult, and</b> according <b>to Rav Yehuda’s</b> opinion it is <b>difficult.</b> According <b>to your</b> opinion it is <b>difficult, as you said</b> that <b>any</b> journey of a distance from which <b>one is unable to</b> reach Jerusalem and <b>enter</b> the Temple courtyard <b>by the time of the slaughter</b> of the Paschal lamb is considered a distant journey. <b>Yet</b> with regard to <b>one who is ritually impure</b> due to contact with a dead <b>creeping animal, who is unable to enter</b> the Temple courtyard <b>at the time of the slaughter</b> due to his impurity, <b>you said: One</b> may <b>slaughter</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and sprinkle</b> its blood <b>on</b> behalf of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> due to contact with a dead <b>creeping animal,</b> even though he will only become pure after nightfall, when the Paschal lamb is eaten.
<b>And</b> according <b>to Rav Yehuda’s</b> opinion it is <b>difficult, as he said</b> that <b>any</b> journey of a distance from which <b>one is unable to enter</b> Jerusalem <b>during the time of the eating</b> is considered a distant journey; <b>yet</b> with regard to <b>one who is ritually impure</b> due to contact with a dead <b>creeping animal, who</b> is able to <b>enter</b> Jerusalem and participate in consuming the offering <b>at the time of the eating, he said</b> the opposite: <b>One</b> may <b>not slaughter</b> the Paschal lamb <b>and sprinkle</b> its blood <b>on</b> behalf of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> due to contact with a dead <b>creeping animal,</b> even though he will be able to immerse and become ritually pure by nightfall, when the offering is to be eaten.
Ulla <b>said to him: According to my</b> opinion it is <b>not difficult, and according to Rav Yehuda’s</b> opinion it is <b>not difficult. According to my</b> opinion it is <b>not difficult</b> because I hold that the concept of <b>a distant journey</b> applies only <b>to one who is ritually pure, and the</b> principle of a <b>distant journey</b> does <b>not</b> apply <b>to one who is ritually impure.</b> If one is ritually impure at the time of the slaughter, his obligation is immediately deferred to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> regardless of the fact that he will become ritually pure in time to eat the offering at nightfall.

Daf 94a

<b>According to Rav Yehuda’s</b> opinion it is also <b>not difficult,</b> because in his opinion <b>the Torah</b> itself <b>deferred</b> the obligation of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> through contact with a dead <b>creeping animal</b> to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>as it is written: “If any man of you or of your generations shall be ritually impure due to a dead body”</b> (Numbers 9:10). <b>Are we not dealing</b> even with a situation in which <b>his seventh</b> day of purification <b>occurs on Passover eve,</b> such that he can be ritually pure by nightfall and therefore he has the same status on that seventh day as one who became impure due to contact with a dead creeping animal? <b>And nonetheless the Torah stated</b> that <b>his</b> obligation <b>shall be deferred.</b> This teaches that anyone who is ritually impure at the time of the slaughtering has his obligation deferred to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, even if he would be able to immerse and become pure in time to eat the offering on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> with the rest of the Jewish people.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>one was standing outside the</b> city <b>of Modi’im and was able to enter</b> Jerusalem <b>on horses or mules</b> but not by walking, I <b>might</b> have thought <b>he would be liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> for failing to come to Jerusalem and offer the Paschal lamb; <b>therefore, the verse states: “And is not on a journey”</b> (Numbers 9:13). <b>This</b> person <b>was on a</b> distant <b>journey</b> and is therefore exempt.
On the other hand, if <b>one was standing closer</b> to Jerusalem <b>than Modi’im</b> but <b>was not able to enter due to the camels and carriages that are</b> carrying his family and <b>delaying him,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought <b>he would not be liable</b> for failing to offer the Paschal lamb because he is trying to enter; <b>therefore, the verse states: “And was not on a journey,” and</b> this person <b>was not on a</b> distant <b>journey</b> and is therefore liable. This person could have dismounted and come to Jerusalem on foot, but he wanted to bring his family with him in a carriage and was consequently delayed. One’s liability is determined based on his distance from Jerusalem.
The discussion above pertaining to the distance that an average person can walk in a day is based on the assumption that he walks five <i>mil</i> between dawn and sunrise. The Gemara brings support for this assumption. <b>Rava said: The</b> size of the <b>world is six thousand parasangs, and the thickness of the firmament is one thousand parasangs. One</b> of these measurements with regard to the size of the world <b>is a tradition, and one</b> of the measurements <b>is</b> based upon Rava’s own <b>reasoning.</b>
The Gemara explains: Rava <b>holds like that</b> statement <b>which Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: How far can an average person walk in a day?</b> One can walk <b>ten parasangs,</b> which are forty <i>mil</i>. This is explained: <b>From dawn until sunrise</b> one can walk a distance of <b>five <i>mil</i>; from sunset until the emergence of the stars</b> one can walk another <b>five <i>mil</i>.</b> Therefore, <b>it is found</b> that <b>the thickness of the firmament is one-sixth</b> of the distance that the sun travels during <b>the day.</b> Between sunrise and sunset, the sun travels a distance of six thousand parasangs during the amount of time an average person can walk thirty <i>mil</i>. During the dawn and twilight periods in the morning and evening, when the sun passes through the thickness of the firmament, an average person can walk five <i>mil</i>, which is one-sixth of the distance he can walk between sunrise and sunset. Consequently, during dawn and twilight the sun must also travel one-sixth of the distance it travels between sunrise and sunset, i.e., one thousand parasangs, which is the thickness of the firmament.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The thickness of the firmament is</b> only <b>one-tenth</b> of the distance that the sun travels during <b>the day. Know</b> that this is true because <b>how far can an average person walk in a day</b> between dawn and the emergence of the stars? One can walk <b>ten parasangs,</b> which are forty <i>mil</i>, <b>and from dawn until sunrise</b> one can walk only <b>four <i>mil</i>,</b> which are one parasang. Therefore, <b>it is found that the thickness of the firmament is</b> only <b>one-tenth</b> of the distance that the sun travels during <b>the day.</b> This is <b>a refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rava.</b> Similarly, it is <b>a refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla,</b> who holds that an average person can walk fifteen <i>mil</i> in half a day, whereas Rabbi Yehuda holds that the average person can walk sixteen <i>mil</i> in half a day. The Gemara concludes: <b>It is</b> indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this <b>will be a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of Rabba bar bar Ḥana, citing <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> with regard to how far an average person can walk in a day. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yoḥanan could have <b>said to you: I am speaking</b> about the total distance that an average person can walk <b>in an</b> entire <b>day,</b> but I never specified the distance one can walk during different parts of the day. <b>And it was the Sages</b> Ulla and Rava who <b>erred</b> in interpreting my opinion by saying that one can walk five <i>mil</i> and not four during each intermediate period, <b>because</b> when <b>they calculated</b> five <i>mil</i> before sunrise and after sunset they included the distance walked by people who set out <b>earlier</b> in the morning, before dawn, and by those who continued walking after nightfall.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say it is a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> who proved from biblical verses that the distance from Sodom to Zoar is five <i>mil</i>. The angels and Lot walked that distance between dawn and sunrise, which implies that it is only four <i>mil</i>. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> that verse states: “The angels hastened Lot,” which indicates that they traveled very quickly. Therefore, <b>hastened is different;</b> because they hurried, they traveled five <i>mil</i> in the time one would normally walk four <i>mil</i>.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a challenge from a <i>baraita</i> to the previous opinion with regard to the size of the world: The size of <b>Egypt was four hundred parasangs by four hundred parasangs, and Egypt is one-sixtieth</b> of the size <b>of Cush, and Cush is one-sixtieth of the world, and the world is one-sixtieth</b> the size <b>of the Garden</b> of Eden, <b>and the Garden</b> of Eden <b>is one-sixtieth of Eden, and Eden is one sixtieth</b> of the size <b>of Gehenna.</b> Therefore, <b>it is found that the entire world is like a pot cover,</b> which is a small part of the total size of the pot, compared <b>to Gehenna.</b> In any event, based upon the sizes of Egypt and Cush, it is apparent that the entire world is larger than six thousand parasangs. This is indeed a <b>conclusive refutation.</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another challenge: One of the Sages of <b>the school of Eliyahu taught</b> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: The entire settlement,</b> the area of the world that is inhabited, <b>sits under one star. Know</b> that this is correct because when <b>a person focuses his eye on one star,</b> he can <b>travel east</b> as far as he wishes within the settled part of the world and the star <b>remains opposite him</b> in the same place, and he can travel <b>in the four directions of the world</b> and the star <b>remains</b> in place <b>opposite him. By inference, the entire settlement</b> of the world <b>rests under one star;</b> and since so many stars are visible and each one covers an area of the world comparable in size to the entire settled portion of the world, it must be that the world is larger than six thousand parasangs. The Gemara comments that this is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of Rava’s opinion.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another challenge from another <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that the constellation <b>Ursa Major is in the north and</b> the constellation <b>Scorpio is in the south, and the entire settlement sits between Ursa Major and Scorpio,</b> as the relative positions of these two constellations appear to be the same from any location in the settled areas of the world. The ratio of <b>the entire settlement</b> to the world as a whole is comparable to <b>only one hour in a day, as the sun enters</b> the sky above <b>the settlement</b> for <b>only one hour a day</b> while the rest of the day it is outside the settlement.
<b>Know</b> that this is correct because <b>at five</b> hours into the day <b>the sun is</b> still <b>in the east, and at seven</b> hours <b>the sun is in the west.</b> During the second <b>half of</b> the <b>sixth</b> hour <b>and</b> the first <b>half of</b> the <b>seventh</b> hour <b>the sun is positioned on top of everyone,</b> as it is in the middle of the sky in every inhabited area during this time. Apparently, the sun travels over the inhabited parts of the world in a single hour while the rest of the day it travels over the uninhabited parts. Therefore, the entire settled portion of the world is equal to one-twelfth of the world. It was established that the settled part of the world itself is several parasangs, so the entire world must be larger than six thousand parasangs. This also serves as <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of Rava’s opinion.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another challenge, <b>as Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said: What response did the Divine Voice answer to that wicked man,</b> Nebuchadnezzar, <b>when he said: “I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will be like the Most High”</b> (Isaiah 14:14)? <b>A Divine Voice emerged and said to him: Wicked man, son of a wicked man,</b>

Daf 94b

the <b>disciple</b> in corruption <b>of Nimrod the wicked, who caused the entire world to rebel against Me during his reign</b> by advising the generation of the dispersion to build a tower in order to fight the Hosts of Heaven, <b>how many are the years of a person</b> altogether? <b>Seventy years, and if</b> he is <b>with strength, eighty years, as it is stated: “The days of our years are seventy years and with strength eighty years”</b> (Psalms 90:10).
In contrast, <b>from the earth to the</b> first <b>firmament</b> of seven (see Ḥagiga 12b) <b>is a walking</b> distance <b>of five hundred years, and the thickness of the firmament is a walking</b> distance <b>of five hundred years,</b> which is equal to approximately 1.8 million parasangs, <b>and between each firmament is</b> another <b>walking</b> distance <b>of five hundred years, and so too between each and every firmament.</b> Therefore, how can you, Nebuchadnezzar, hope to reach the heavens in your lifetime, such that you say: “I will be like the Most High”? Rather, as the verse continues: <b>“Yet you shall be brought down to the netherworld, to the uttermost parts of the pit”</b> (Isaiah 14:15). In any event, this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of Rava’s opinion that the thickness of the firmament is only one thousand parasangs.
In a discussion related to the structure of the natural world, <b>the Sages taught: The Jewish Sages say the celestial sphere</b> of the zodiac <b>is stationary, and the constellations revolve</b> in their place within the sphere; <b>and the sages of the nations of the world say the</b> entire <b>celestial sphere revolves, and the constellations are stationary</b> within the sphere. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: A refutation of their words</b> that the entire sphere moves can be derived from the fact that <b>we have never found</b> the constellation of <b>Ursa Major in the South or Scorpio in the North.</b> This indicates that it is the stars themselves that revolve in place and not the celestial sphere as a whole, because otherwise it would be impossible for Ursa Major to remain in the North and Scorpio to remain in the South.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov strongly objects to this</b> proof: <b>And perhaps</b> the stars are stationary within the sphere <b>like the steel</b> socket <b>of a mill,</b> which remains stationary while the stones of the mill revolve around it. <b>Alternatively,</b> perhaps they are stationary <b>like the pivot of a door,</b> which remains stationary while the door makes wide turns around it; similarly, perhaps the constellations are stationary within a sphere, and there is an outer sphere within which the sun revolves around all the constellations. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement is not necessarily true.
The Gemara presents a similar dispute: <b>The Jewish Sages say</b> that <b>during the day the sun travels beneath the firmament</b> and is therefore visible, <b>and at night</b> it travels <b>above the firmament. And the sages of the nations of the world say</b> that <b>during the day the sun travels beneath the firmament, and at night</b> it travels <b>beneath the earth</b> and around to the other side of the world. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: And the statement</b> of the sages of the nations of the world <b>appears</b> to be more accurate <b>than our statement.</b> A proof to this is <b>that during the day, springs</b> that originate deep in the ground <b>are cold, and during the night they are hot</b> compared to the air temperature, which supports the theory that these springs are warmed by the sun as it travels beneath the earth.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: During the summer the sun travels high in the sky,</b> above the earth, and <b>therefore the entire world is hot, and springs</b> that originate deep in the ground <b>are cold.</b> On the other hand, <b>during the winter the sun travels low in the sky,</b> over the edges of the earth. <b>Therefore, the entire world is cold,</b> but <b>springs are hot</b> relative to the air temperature.
<b>The Sages taught: The sun travels in four paths</b> during the four seasons of the year, and each causes a unique weather pattern: During the months of <b>Nisan, Iyyar, and Sivan,</b> the sun <b>travels over the mountains in order to melt the snows</b> that collected during the winter. During <b>Tammuz, Av, and Elul, it travels over the</b> areas of <b>the settlement in order to ripen the produce.</b> During <b>Tishrei, Marḥeshvan, and Kislev, it travels over the seas in order to dry the rivers,</b> as the rivers flow more gently during that time of year and the water turns into rain clouds. During <b>Tevet, Shevat, and Adar, it travels over the desert in order to not dry the seeds</b> that were planted in the inhabited areas of settlement, which begin to sprout during this time.
It was taught in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> Anyone located <b>from the threshold</b> of the Temple courtyard and beyond is considered to be on a distant journey. The Gemara objects: <b>And even though he is able to enter</b> the courtyard, <b>we do not say to him: Get up and enter;</b> rather, we rely on the fact that at the critical moment he is outside the courtyard. <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An</b> adult <b>uncircumcised Jew who did not circumcise</b> himself <b>will be punished with <i>karet</i></b> for being unable to eat the Paschal lamb on Passover; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Eliezer himself requires one to take action and circumcise himself so that the obligation to bring the Paschal lamb will apply to him. If one does not do so, he is considered to have intentionally refrained from eating the Paschal lamb and will receive <i>karet</i>. This <i>baraita</i> in which Rabbi Eliezer requires a person to be proactive seems to contradict the mishna in which Rabbi Eliezer permits a person to remain passive.
<b>Abaye said:</b> The exemption from observing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> granted to one on a <b>distant journey</b> was stated only <b>for one who is ritually pure, and there is no</b> exemption of a <b>distant journey for one who is ritually impure</b> or is unfit to offer the Paschal lamb for any other reason. One who is unfit to offer the sacrifice must take action to enable him to fulfill his obligation, and he is not included in the exemption of being on a distant journey. Conversely, the exemption does apply to people who are inherently fit to offer the sacrifice, and who are therefore not liable to <i>karet</i> if they do not enter the courtyard. There is no need to warn them to offer the Paschal lamb.
<b>Rava said: It is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> as to Rabbi Eliezer’s true opinion, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The exemption of <b>a distant journey is stated with regard to the Paschal lamb, and</b> the exemption of <b>a distant journey is stated with regard to</b> the second <b>tithe,</b> as the verse states: “And if the way be too long for you, so that you are not able to carry it because the place is too far from you, which the Lord your God shall choose to set His name there” (Deuteronomy 14:24). <b>Just as later</b> in the Torah, with regard to the second tithe, the exemption applies only to someone located <b>outside</b> the area <b>where it</b> may <b>be eaten,</b> as the second tithe may be eaten only in Jerusalem, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb, the exemption of a distant journey applies only to one located <b>outside</b> the place in which <b>it</b> may <b>be eaten,</b> which is the entire city of Jerusalem. According to this opinion, anyone located in Jerusalem is included in the obligation to offer the Paschal lamb.
However, <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Rabbi Yehuda says, citing Rabbi Eliezer:</b> The exemption of a distant journey applies to anyone located <b>outside</b> the area <b>where</b> the offering of the Paschal lamb may <b>be performed,</b> which is the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Rav Yosef said:</b> In determining whether the majority of the community is ritually pure or <b>ritually impure, follow the majority of those standing in the courtyard,</b> and do not take into consideration people who are in Jerusalem but have not come to the courtyard. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion that <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Rabbi Yehuda said, citing Rabbi Eliezer,</b> which is as follows: Circumstances that can change the details of one’s obligation to offer the Paschal lamb, such as whether one is in a state of ritual impurity or whether he is on a distant journey, are determined based on whether or not one is within the Temple courtyard at the time of the slaughter.
It was taught in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei said to him: Therefore,</b> there is a dot over the letter <i>heh</i>. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says:</b> If the verse had said simply: “A distant <b>journey,” One</b> would <b>conclude</b> from it that it means the distance of at least <b>a two- or three-day walk.</b> However, <b>when it says</b> later: “But the man who is ritually pure <b>and is not on a journey”</b> (Numbers 9:13) and does not specify a distant journey, <b>it teaches that from the threshold of the courtyard and beyond is called a journey,</b> and the exemption is not limited to one on a distant journey as the first verse seemed to imply.

Daf 95a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between </b>the Paschal lamb offered on <b>the first <i>Pesaḥ</i></b> and the Paschal lamb offered on <b>the second </b><i>Pesaḥ</i>? On <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i>, at the time of slaughtering the Paschal lamb, <b>it is prohibited</b> to own leavened bread due to the prohibitions: <b>It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found. And</b> on <b>the second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> it is permissible for one to have both <b>leavened bread and <i>matza</i> with him in the house.</b> Another difference is that the Paschal lamb offered on <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>requires</b> the recitation of <b><i>hallel</i> as it is eaten and the second does not require</b> the recitation of <b><i>hallel</i> as it is eaten.</b> However, they are the same in that the Paschal lambs sacrificed on <b>both</b> the first and second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>require</b> the recitation of <b><i>hallel</i> as they are prepared,</b> i.e., as they are slaughtered, <b>and they are</b> both <b>eaten roasted with <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs, and they override Shabbat</b> in that they may be slaughtered and their blood sprinkled even on Shabbat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> a halakhic midrash pertaining to the Paschal lamb offered on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. The verse states with regard to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>: “They shall leave none of it to the morning, nor break a bone in it; <b>according to all the entire statute of the Paschal lamb they shall offer it”</b> (Numbers 9:12). The fact that the verse says “it” indicates that <b>the verse is speaking of a mitzva applicable to</b> the <b>body</b> of the Paschal lamb, meaning that <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to the actual Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> apply equally to the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
The midrash continues: With regard to <b>a mitzva related to</b> the <b>body</b> of the Paschal lamb but not actually performed on the body of the offering, <b>from where</b> is it derived that it applies to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> as well? <b>The verse states: “They shall eat it with <i>matzot</i> and bitter herbs”</b> (Numbers 9:11). One <b>might</b> have thought that one must fulfill all mitzvot related to the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>even mitzvot not</b> at all <b>related to</b> the <b>body</b> of the Paschal lamb, such as the requirement to destroy all one’s leaven. <b>Therefore, the Torah states: “And they shall not break a bone in it”</b> (Numbers 9:12), which teaches that <b>just as</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking a bone is notable</b> among the mitzvot related to the Paschal lamb in that it is <b>a mitzva applicable to</b> the Paschal lamb <b>itself, so too, any mitzva applicable to</b> the Paschal lamb <b>itself</b> must be fulfilled on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. However, other mitzvot pertaining to the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> need not be fulfilled on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<b>Isi ben Yehuda says:</b> It is unnecessary to derive that <i>halakha</i> from the end of the verse quoted, as the phrase in the first half of the verse: <b>“They shall perform it,”</b> indicates that <b>the verse is speaking</b> only <b>of mitzvot applicable to</b> the <b>body</b> of the Paschal lamb <b>itself.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the details of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that one must fulfill <b>even a mitzva not</b> at all <b>related to</b> the <b>body</b> of the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>But you said</b> that <b>the verse is speaking</b> only <b>of a mitzva applicable to</b> the <b>body</b> of the Paschal lamb, so why would one think that unrelated mitzvot are also included?
The Gemara explains that <b>this is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Now that you said</b> the additional <i>halakha</i> that <b>they shall eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs, apparently</b> the phrase: <b>“They shall perform it,” is not specific</b> and does not limit the <i>halakhot</i> of the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> to those applicable to the Paschal lamb itself, <b>say</b> that this verse <b>is</b> expounded according to the principle of <b>a detail and a generalization,</b> as it first said: “They shall eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs” and “They shall leave none of it to the morning,” and then it stated a generalization: “According to all the statute of the Paschal lamb they shall perform it.” The principles of halakhic midrash state that in that case, <b>the generalization adds to the detail and even</b> includes <b>everything,</b> such that all the mitzvot of the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> would apply equally to the second, including the removal of leaven. Therefore, the verse “They shall not break a bone in it” <b>teaches us</b> that mitzvot unrelated to the Paschal lamb do not apply to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>What does Isi ben Yehuda do with</b> the end of <b>the</b> verse: “And they shall not break a <b>bone</b> in it”? The Gemara answers: <b>He needs it</b> to teach that the prohibition of breaking a bone applies <b>both to a bone that has marrow and to a bone that does not have marrow.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who expound differently than Isi ben Yehuda, <b>what do they do with this</b> phrase: “They shall perform it”? The Gemara answers: <b>They need it</b> to teach <b>that one does not slaughter the Paschal</b> lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>on</b> behalf of a single <b>individual.</b> Since the verse speaks of people performing the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> in the plural, it is derived <b>that as much as it is possible to search</b> for more people to join this individual in his Paschal lamb, <b>we search</b> for them, even if it means causing another individual to become ritually impure to prevent him from performing the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“According to the entire statute of the Paschal lamb they shall offer it”</b> (Numbers 9:12). <b>One might</b> have thought <b>that just as</b> at the time of the sacrifice of the Paschal lamb on <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> it <b>is prohibited</b> to own leaven due to the prohibitions of: <b>It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, so too,</b> at the time of the sacrifice of <b>the</b> Paschal lamb on the <b>second</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>it is prohibited</b> to own leaven due to the prohibitions of: <b>It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found. Therefore, the Torah states: “They shall eat it with <i>matzot</i> and bitter herbs”</b> (Numbers 9:11), which indicates that the other mitzvot pertaining to the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> do not apply on the second.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> from here <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>positive mitzvot</b> related to the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> apply on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>; <b>from where</b> do I derive that the same is true of <b>negative mitzvot? The verse states: “They shall leave none of it to the morning,</b> nor break a bone in it” (Numbers 9:12).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> from this verse <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>a negative mitzva</b> whose violation <b>can be rectified by</b> the fulfillment of <b>a positive</b> mitzva applies on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, e.g., the prohibition of leaving over meat from the Paschal lamb until morning, which can be rectified by the positive mitzva of burning the leftovers; <b>from where</b> is it derived that the same is true of <b>a full-fledged negative mitzva? The verse states: “They shall not break a bone in it.”</b> It may be concluded from these examples that <b>just as the detail,</b> i.e., the specific mitzvot mentioned in these verses, <b>is explicit</b> and includes <b>a positive mitzva, a prohibition</b> whose violation <b>can be rectified by</b> the fulfillment of <b>a positive mitzva, and a full-fledged negative mitzva; so too, every positive mitzva,</b> every <b>prohibition</b> whose violation <b>can be rectified by</b> the fulfillment of <b>a positive mitzva, and</b> every <b>full-fledged negative mitzva</b> is included.
Now that the generalization has been interpreted as referring to the specific examples mentioned earlier, <b>what is included through the generalization of unleavened bread and bitter herbs?</b> The Gemara answers: It comes to teach that the mitzva of <b>roasting in fire</b> applies to the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> as well as to the first. Given that unleavened bread and bitter herbs is also a qualifying detail, <b>what does it exclude through its detail?</b> It teaches that the mitzva of <b>removal of leaven</b> does not apply on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. The Gemara asks: Perhaps <b>I</b> can <b>reverse it</b> and say that on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> one is not obligated to roast the offering by fire, but one is obligated to remove all leaven? The Gemara answers: <b>A mitzva relating to</b> the Paschal lamb <b>itself is preferable,</b> as it is more reasonable to assume that the first and second <i>Pesaḥ</i> are comparable with regard to <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to the offering itself.
The Gemara asks further: <b>What is included through the generalization of: They shall leave none of it to the morning?</b> The Gemara answers that it includes the prohibition of: <b>You shall not remove any of its</b> meat from one group to another, <b>which is similar to it, as</b> through <b>this</b> prohibition mentioned in the verse <b>it is disqualified as leftovers, and</b> through <b>this</b> prohibition of removing the meat of the offering <b>it is disqualified as</b> sacrificial meat that <b>has left</b> its permitted boundary.
The Gemara asks further: <b>What does it exclude through its detail?</b> It excludes the prohibitions: <b>It shall not be seen, and: It shall not be found, which are similar to it, as</b> one who violates <b>this</b> prohibition of leaving over the meat of the offering until morning <b>is not flogged because it is a prohibition</b> whose violation <b>can be rectified by</b> fulfilling <b>a positive mitzva</b> by burning the leftovers; <b>and</b> one who violates <b>this</b> prohibition of owning leaven <b>is not flogged because it is a prohibition</b> whose violation <b>can be rectified by</b> fulfilling <b>a positive mitzva</b> of burning the leaven. The Gemara asks: Perhaps <b>I</b> can <b>reverse it</b> and say that the generalization is meant to include removal of leaven and the detail excludes the prohibition of leaving over the meat of the offering? The Gemara answers: In a comparison of the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> and the second, including <b>a mitzva related to</b> the Paschal lamb <b>itself is preferable</b> to including one that does not relate to the Paschal lamb.
The Gemara continues to ask: <b>Through the generalization: They shall not break a bone in it,</b>

Daf 95b

<b>what is it including,</b> beyond what is mentioned explicitly in the verse? The Gemara answers that it includes the mitzva: <b>“Do not eat from it raw”</b> (Exodus 12:9). The Gemara asks: <b>What does it exclude through its detail?</b> The Gemara answers that it excludes the mitzva: <b>“You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread”</b> (Exodus 34:25). The Gemara asks: Perhaps <b>I</b> can <b>reverse it</b> and say the opposite, that the prohibition against eating the offering raw is excluded, and the prohibition against owning leaven is included. The Gemara answers: Including <b>a mitzva related to</b> the Paschal lamb <b>itself is preferable</b> to including one that does not relate as directly to the Paschal lamb. Therefore, the prohibition against eating the Paschal lamb raw is included, and the prohibition against slaughtering the Paschal lamb with leaven in one’s possession is excluded.
It was taught in the mishna that the Paschal lamb on <b>the first</b> <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>requires</b> the recitation of <b><i>hallel</i> as it is eaten,</b> whereas on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> it does not. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said, citing Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak,</b> that <b>the verse states: “You shall have a song as in the night when a Festival is sanctified”</b> (Isaiah 30:29). From here it may be derived that <b>a night sanctified as a Festival,</b> on which labor is prohibited, such as the first night of Passover, <b>requires</b> the recitation of <b><i>hallel</i>;</b> however, <b>a night which is not sanctified as a Festival,</b> such as the night when the Paschal lamb is eaten following the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>does not require</b> the recitation of <b><i>hallel</i>.</b>
It was stated in the mishna that the Paschal lambs sacrificed on <b>both</b> the first and second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>require</b> the recitation of <b><i>hallel</i> as they are prepared.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that <i>hallel</i> must be recited while one prepares the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the verse quoted above: “As in the night when a festival is sanctified,” <b>excludes</b> laws that apply at <b>night,</b> but <b>it does not exclude</b> laws that apply by <b>day;</b> therefore, the recitation of <i>hallel</i> is required while slaughtering the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> just as it is required while slaughtering the Paschal lamb on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> simply makes logical sense: <b>Is it possible</b> that <b>the Jewish people</b> are <b>slaughtering their Paschal lambs</b> or <b>taking their <i>lulavim</i></b> on <i>Sukkot</i> <b>and not reciting <i>hallel</i>?</b> It is inconceivable that they would not be reciting <i>hallel</i> and there is no need for an explicit biblical source for this <i>halakha</i>.
It was also taught in the mishna that the Paschal lambs on both the first and second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>are eaten roasted</b> and override Shabbat. It may be inferred from this that with regard to <b>Shabbat, yes,</b> it is overridden by the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, but with regard to <b>ritual impurity, no,</b> it is not overridden for the sake of the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. The Gemara points out that this understanding of <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>overrides Shabbat and does not override ritual impurity. Rabbi Yehuda says: It overrides even ritual impurity.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>?</b> He holds that once this person <b>was deferred</b> from the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>due to ritual impurity, shall he</b> now <b>return and perform</b> the offering of the Paschal lamb on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>in ritual impurity? And Rabbi Yehuda</b> reasoned: <b>The Torah sought</b> to allow this person the opportunity <b>to perform</b> the offering of the Paschal lamb <b>in ritual purity;</b> if it ultimately becomes clear that <b>he did not merit</b> doing so, <b>let him</b> at least <b>perform</b> the offering of the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>The</b> offering of the Paschal lamb on the <b>first <i>Pesaḥ</i> overrides Shabbat,</b> and similarly, the offering of the Paschal lamb on the <b>second <i>Pesaḥ</i> overrides Shabbat.</b> The <b>first <i>Pesaḥ</i> overrides ritual impurity,</b> and similarly, <b>the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> overrides ritual impurity. The first <i>Pesaḥ</i> requires remaining</b> until morning, meaning that it is prohibited for people who have participated in the Paschal lamb to return that night to their homes outside Jerusalem, and similarly, <b>the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> requires remaining</b> until morning.
The Gemara clarifies: With regard to the statement that the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>overrides ritual impurity, in accordance with whose</b> opinion is this? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>But according to Rabbi Yehuda, does</b> the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> <b>require remaining</b> until morning? <b>Wasn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: From where</b> is it derived that <b>the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> does not require remaining</b> until morning? <b>As it is stated</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb: “And you shall roast and eat it in the place which the Lord your God shall choose; <b>and you shall turn in the morning and go to your tents”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:7), <b>and it is written</b> immediately after: <b>“Six days you shall eat <i>matzot</i>;</b> and on the seventh day shall be a solemn assembly to the Lord your God; you shall do no work on it” (Deuteronomy 16:8). From this juxtaposition it may be concluded that the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>, which is followed by the mitzvah <b>to eat</b> <i>matza</i> <b>for six</b> days, <b>requires remaining</b> until morning, whereas the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, which is not followed by the mitzva <b>to eat</b> <i>matza</i> <b>for six</b> days, <b>does not require remaining</b> until morning. This contradicts what was previously stated citing Rabbi Yehuda.
The Gemara answers: These statements were made by <b>two <i>tanna’im</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> but the two <i>tanna’im</i> disagreed about whether or not Rabbi Yehuda maintained that one is required to stay overnight on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> When <b>the Paschal lamb is sacrificed in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity</b> due to the fact that the majority of the Jewish people are ritually impure, <b><i>zavim</i>, and <i>zavot</i>,</b> and <b>menstruating women, and women after childbirth may not eat it,</b> because the Paschal lamb overrides only ritual impurity imparted by a corpse, but it does not override other forms of ritual impurity. However, <b>if they</b> violated the <i>halakha</i> and <b>ate</b> from the offering, <b>they are exempt from <i>karet</i>.</b> One who eats sacrificial food in a state of ritual impurity is generally liable to receive <i>karet</i>; however, since in this case the offering is sacrificed in a state of ritual impurity, there is no punishment of <i>karet</i> even for ritually impure individuals who are not permitted to eat it.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer exempts</b> these individuals from <i>karet</i> <b>even for entering the Temple</b> in a state of ritual impurity, despite their not being permitted to enter, because people who are impure due to ritual impurity imparted by a corpse are permitted to enter the Temple in this situation despite their impurity.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b><i>zavim</i>, <i>and zavot</i>,</b> and <b>menstruating women, and women after childbirth who ate of the Paschal lamb that was sacrificed</b> while the majority of the Jewish people were <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that they would be <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>; <b>therefore, the verse states:</b> “The meat that touches any impure thing shall not be eaten, it shall be burned in fire; <b>and the meat, every one that is ritually pure may eat the meat. But the soul that eats of the meat of the sacrifice of peace-offerings, that belong to the Lord, having his impurity upon him,</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off [<i>venikhreta</i>]</b> from his people” (Leviticus 7:19–20).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The juxtaposition of these verses teaches that if the offering <b>is eaten</b> only <b>by</b> people who are <b>ritually pure,</b> ritually impure people are <b>liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> being <b>ritually impure, but if it is not eaten</b> only <b>by</b> people who are <b>ritually pure,</b> because it was offered when the majority of the Jewish people were impure, <b>those who are ritually impure are not liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> being <b>impure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that if <b><i>zavim</i></b> or lepers <b>pushed</b> their way in <b>and entered the courtyard,</b> which they are prohibited from entering, in order to sacrifice <b>the Paschal lamb that is brought</b> when the majority of the Jewish people are <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they would be liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> for entering the Temple while ritually impure; therefore, <b>the verse states: “That they send out from the camp any leper and any <i>zav</i> and anyone defiled by the dead”</b> (Numbers 5:2). This teaches that <b>at a time when those who are impure</b> due to ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse are sent out</b> from the Temple, <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers are</b> also <b>sent out;</b> when <b>those who are impure</b> due to ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse are not sent out</b> but are permitted to sacrifice the offering in a state of ritual impurity, <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers are</b> also <b>not sent out.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef asked</b> a question related to the <i>halakhot</i> discussed above: <b>If those who are impure</b> due to ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse pushed</b> their way in <b>and entered the Sanctuary,</b> which is an area in which no services are performed for the Paschal lamb and which only priests may enter <i>ab initio</i>, and this occurs in a case in which the <b>Paschal lamb is brought</b> when the majority of the Jewish people are <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the <i>halakha</i> that <b>since ritual impurity was permitted in the courtyard</b> for the sake of the Paschal lamb, <b>ritual impurity in the Sanctuary was also permitted; or perhaps what was permitted was permitted</b> and <b>what was not permitted was not permitted,</b> and consequently they are liable for entering the Sanctuary?
<b>Rava said</b> in answer to this question that <b>the verse states: “They send out from the camp”</b> (Numbers 5:2); the phrase “from the camp” indicates that the <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> to <b>a part of the camp.</b> Therefore, when the majority of the Jewish people are ritually impure, even though people who are ritually impure are permitted to enter part of the Temple, as they must bring their offerings to the Temple courtyard, they are not permitted to enter everywhere inside the Temple, and the prohibition of entering the Sanctuary remains in place.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>Rava said</b> a different answer: <b>The verse states: “That they send out from the camp</b> any leper and any <i>zav</i> and anyone defiled by the <b>dead…outside the camp you shall send them”</b> (Numbers 5:2–3). This implies that <b>anywhere that we apply</b> the phrase: <b>“Outside the camp you shall send them,”</b> which is referring to a case in which the majority of the Jewish people are ritually pure and indicates that the impure people must be sent outside of the entire camp, <b>we</b> also <b>apply</b> the phrase: <b>“They must send out from the camp,”</b> meaning it is prohibited for people who are ritually impure to enter the Sanctuary. However, if the majority of the Jewish people are impure and the offering is sacrificed in a state of impurity, those who are impure are not liable if they enter the Sanctuary.
<b>Rav Yosef asked</b> a similar question: <b>If people who are impure</b> due to ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse pushed</b> their way in <b>and ate portions</b> that are supposed to be consumed on the altar, such as the fats, the kidneys, and the fat tail, from <b>a Paschal lamb offered in ritual impurity,</b>

Daf 96a

<b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Are they liable for eating sacrificial meat while they were ritually impure? Do we say that <b>since ritual impurity of the meat</b> that is eaten <b>was permitted, ritual impurity of the</b> sacrificial <b>portions</b> offered on the altar <b>was also permitted; or perhaps</b> we say that <b>what was permitted was permitted,</b> and <b>what was not permitted was not permitted?</b>
<b>Rava said: After all, from where</b> was the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to eating the sacrificial <b>portions</b> in a state of <b>ritual impurity included?</b> It is derived <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to eating the <b>meat</b> in a state of <b>ritual impurity, as it is written:</b> “But the soul that eats of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace-offerings <b>that pertain to the Lord,</b> having his ritual impurity upon him, that soul shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:20); the apparently superfluous phrase “that pertain to the Lord” is there <b>to include the</b> sacrificial <b>portions</b> and establish that one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating these portions in a state of ritual impurity.
Since this is the source, there is a limitation to the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to sacrificial portions: <b>Anywhere that there is</b> liability <b>for</b> eating the <b>meat</b> in a state of <b>ritual impurity, there is</b> liability for eating the sacrificial <b>portions</b> in a state of <b>ritual impurity;</b> conversely, <b>anywhere that there is no</b> liability for eating the <b>meat</b> in a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> such as in the case of a Paschal lamb offered in a state of ritual impurity, <b>there is no</b> liability for eating the sacrificial <b>portions</b> in a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira asked:</b> With regard to <b>the</b> sacrificial <b>portions of the Paschal lamb</b> that the Jewish people sacrificed in <b>Egypt</b> on the first Passover, just before they left Egypt, <b>where did they burn them?</b> The Torah does not say that they constructed an altar for this purpose. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> What place is there for such a question? <b>Who will tell us that they did not make them roasted</b> and eat them? The Jewish people had not yet been commanded with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of sacrifices; therefore, they presumably did not distinguish between meat and forbidden fats, and they roasted and consumed the entire animal (<i>Arukh</i>).
<b>And furthermore, Rav Yosef taught</b> that <b>there were</b> three parts of the door upon which the blood was sprinkled that took the place of <b>three altars there</b> in Egypt. The blood was applied <b>upon the lintel and upon the two doorposts; and there was nothing else.</b> Presumably, the Jewish people did not fulfill any mitzva not explicitly mentioned in the Torah, and since no other altar is mentioned, one can conclude that they did not offer the fats and other sacrificial portions on an altar.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>What</b> are the differences <b>between the Paschal lamb</b> that the Jewish people offered in <b>Egypt and the Paschal lamb</b> offered in all later <b>generations? The Paschal lamb</b> the Jewish people offered in <b>Egypt</b> had to be <b>taken from the tenth</b> of the month of Nisan <b>and required</b> the people to <b>sprinkle</b> its blood <b>with a bundle of hyssop,</b> unlike the Paschal lamb in all later years, <b>and</b> its blood was also sprinkled <b>upon the lintel and the two doorposts, and it was eaten with haste;</b> in addition, the Paschal lamb in Egypt was only <b>on one night,</b> whereas <b>the Paschal lamb</b> throughout the <b>generations is observed for seven</b> days.
The Gemara discusses the meaning of this difficult phrase, as obviously, the Paschal lamb is slaughtered on the fourteenth and eaten on the evening of the fifteenth. <strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> conclude that the requirements of the Paschal lamb sacrificed in Egypt do not apply to later generations? <b>As it is written: “Speak to all the congregation of Israel, saying: On the tenth day of this month they shall take</b> to them every man a lamb, according to their fathers’ houses, a lamb for a household” (Exodus 12:3); and we derive from the superfluous word “this” that <b>this</b> Paschal lamb offered in Egypt had to be <b>taken from the tenth</b> of Nisan, <b>and the Paschal lamb of</b> later <b>generations is not taken from the tenth</b> of Nisan.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>However, if</b> that is <b>so,</b> when the verse states later in the same section: <b>“And you shall keep it until the fourteenth day of this month”</b> (Exodus 12:6), <b>so too</b> it should be inferred that <b>this</b> Paschal lamb in Egypt <b>requires examination four days prior to</b> its <b>slaughter, and no other</b> offering <b>requires examination four days prior to</b> its <b>slaughter.</b>
<b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>ben Bag Bag says: From where</b> do we know that <b>the daily offering requires examination four days prior to</b> its <b>slaughter? It is stated</b> with regard to the daily offering: “Command the children of Israel, and say to them: My food which is presented to Me for offerings made by fire, of a sweet flavor to Me, <b>you shall safeguard it to sacrifice to Me in its due season”</b> (Numbers 28:2), <b>and it states there,</b> with regard to the Paschal lamb: <b>“And it shall be for you as a safeguard until the fourteenth day of this month”</b> (Exodus 12:6). <b>Just as</b> in the verse <b>there,</b> the Paschal lamb <b>requires examination four days prior to</b> its <b>slaughter, so too here,</b> the daily offering <b>requires examination four days prior to</b> its <b>slaughter.</b> There is no inference from the phrase “this month” that the requirement of examining an offering four days before is limited to the Paschal lamb sacrificed in Egypt.
